analyzed: nidāna kathā  tattha dīghāgamaḥ nāma sīla kkhandha vaggaḥ mahā vaggaḥ pāthika vaggo ti vaggataḥ ti vaggo

translated: “It is possible that bad monks, thinking that the Teacher has passed away

analyzed: yaṃ nūna aham dhammañca vinayañca saṅgāyeyyam yathayidam sāsanam addhaniyam assa cira ṭṭhitikam

analyzed: sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharāmi kassapaḥ api  bhikkhave yāvat eva ākaṅkhati vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam
translated: I enter upon and abide in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion; and so does Kassapa.

analyzed: canda upama paṭipadāya ca pasaṃsitaḥ tassa kimaññam āṇaṇyam bhavissati nanu mamam bhagavā

translated: And he encouraged the monks to recite the Dhamma and the Discipline by this special favour and by this high praise. As it is said:

analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahākassapaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi ekam idā aham āvuso samayam pāvāya
translated: “Then the venerable Kassapa addressed the monks, saying: ‘On one occasion, friends,

translated: I was travelling along the highway from Pāvā to Kusināra with a large company of monks, with five hundred monks.’🔽The whole of the Subhadda Chapter should be understood in detail. But the meaning of it will be explained at the end of the Great Passing

translated: we will tell you when we get there.

translated: “Come, friends, let us recite the Dhamma and the Discipline, lest they be lost. Now wrong Dhamma shines, wrong Discipline shines,

analyzed: paṭibāhiyyati pure avinayaḥ dippati vinayo paṭibāhiyyati pure adhamma vādino balavanto
translated: the Vinaya is suppressed, the non-Dhamma is seen to prosper, the Dhamma is suppressed, the non-discipline is seen to prosper, the discipline is suppressed, the non-Dhamma-vādins are strong,

analyzed: bhikkhū āhaṃsu tena hi bhante theraḥ bhikkhū uccinatu uti thero pana sakala navaṅga satthu sāsana pariyatti dhare  puthujjana sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmi sukkha vipassaka khīṇāsava bhikkhū aneka sate  aneka sahasse ca vajjetvā tipiṭaka sabba pariyatti pabheda dhare paṭisambhidā appatte mahā anubhāve

translated: Herein, the Vinaya Piṭaka is the Discipline, and the rest of the Buddha’s Word is the True Idea. That is why it is said ‘ Suppose we were to recite the True Idea and the Discipline ’ , and ‘ I shall ask Upāli about the Discipline and Ānanda about the True Idea ’ . This is how it is of two kinds as the True Idea and the Discipline.

original: Kathaṃ paṭhamamajjhimapacchimavasena tividhaṃ? Sabbameva hidaṃ paṭhamabuddhavacanaṃ, majjhimabuddhavacanaṃ, pacchimabuddhavacananti tippabhedaṃ hoti. Tattha –
analyzed: katham paṭhama majjhima pacchima vasena tividham sabbam eva hi dam paṭhama buddha vacanam majjhima buddha vacanam pacchima buddha vacanam ti ti pabhedam hoti tattha
translated: How is it of three kinds as the first, the middle, and the last? All this is of three kinds as the first, the middle, and the last of the Buddha’s Word. Herein,

original: “Anekajātisaṃsāraṃ, sandhāvissaṃ anibbisaṃ;🔽Gahakāraṃ gavesanto, dukkhā jāti punappunaṃ.

translated: Grief stricken am I, now I see the house-builder. You will not build the house again.🔽All your rafters have been broken,🔽your ridgepole shattered,

original: Idaṃ paṭhamabuddhavacanaṃ. Keci “yadā have pātubhavanti dhammā”ti khandhake udānagāthaṃ🔽vadanti. Esā pana pāṭipadadivase sabbaññubhāvappattassa somanassamayañāṇena paccayākāraṃ
analyzed: idam paṭhama buddha vacanam keci yadā have pātubhavanti khandhake udāna gātham  vadanti esā pana pāṭipada divase sabbaññu bhāva ppattassa somanassa maya ñāṇena paccaya ākāram
translated: This is the first utterance of the Buddha. Some say the verse of the Udana in the Khandhakas, namely, “When the ideas become manifest to one who meditates” .

original: paccavekkhantassa uppannā udānagāthāti veditabbā.🔽Yaṃ pana parinibbānakāle abhāsi – “handa dāni, bhikkhave, āmantayāmi vo, vayadhammā🔽saṅkhārā, appamādena sampādethā”ti idaṃ pacchimabuddhavacanaṃ. Ubhinnamantare yaṃ

translated: But this verse should be understood as the verse of the Udana arisen in one who, on the day of the footing of the practice, had reached omniscience and was reviewing the mode of conditionality with knowledge accompanied by joy.

original: vuttaṃ, etaṃ majjhimabuddhavacanaṃ nāma. Evaṃ paṭhamamajjhimapacchimabuddhavacanavasena tividhaṃ.

translated: But that which he uttered on the occasion of his attaining extinction, namely, “Now, bhikkhus, I exhort you: Impermanent are compounded things. original: Kathaṃ piṭakavasena tividhaṃ? Sabbampi cetaṃ vinayapiṭakaṃ suttantapiṭakaṃ abhidhammapiṭakanti

translated: Because it is the means of knowing the Sutta, the Sutta is called the Sutta.🔽For it shows the meaning classed as one’s own benefit, another’s benefit, and so on. And here the meaning is well spoken because it is spoken in accordance with the dispositions of those who need training.

original: dhenu viya khīraṃ, paggharāpetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Suṭṭhu ca ne tāyati, rakkhatīti vuttaṃ

original: hoti. Suttasabhāgañcetaṃ, yathā hi tacchakānaṃ suttaṃ pamāṇaṃ hoti, evametampi viññūnaṃ.

translated: So “the knower of the basket’s meaning” is the knower of the meaning of the container for the tradition.🔽Now, “So, having combined them, the three, the Discipline, etc., should be known” . Having combined them thus with the word “basket” in its two senses,

original: Idāni ‘tena samodhānetvā tayopi vinayādayo ñeyyā’ti, tena evaṃ duvidhatthena piṭakasaddena🔽saha samāsaṃ katvā vinayo ca so piṭakañca pariyattibhāvato, tassa tassa atthassa🔽bhājanato cāti vinayapiṭakaṃ, yathāvutteneva nayena suttantañca taṃ piṭakañcāti suttantapiṭakaṃ,
analyzed: idāni tena samodhānetvā vinaya ādayaḥ tena evam duvidha tthena piṭaka saddena  saha samāsam katvā vinayaḥ ca saḥ piṭakam ca pariyatti bhāvataḥ tassa tassa atthassa  bhājanataḥ ca ati vinaya piṭakam yathā vuttena iva nayena suttantam ca tam piṭakam ca ati suttanta piṭakam
translated: the Discipline is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of Long Discourses is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the Mother of the Buddha’s Disciples is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the First-Rain Utterances is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the Miscellaneous is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the Great is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the Eights is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the Tens is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,🔽and the Collection of the Elevens is the basket because it is the container for the tradition’s meaning and because it is the container for the meaning of each particular case,

original: abhidhammo ca so piṭakañcāti abhidhammapiṭakanti. Evamete tayopi vinayādayo ñeyyā.
analyzed: abhidhammo ca so piṭakam ca ati abhidhamma piṭakam ti evam ete vinaya ādayaḥ ñeyyā
translated: and the Collection of the Twelves is the basket because it is the container for the

original: Evaṃ ñatvā ca punapi tesuyeva piṭakesu nānappakārakosallatthaṃ –
analyzed: evam ñatvā ca puna pi tesu yeva piṭakesu
translated: And having understood thus, he should then, for the sake of skill in the three Piṭakas,

original: “Desanāsāsanakathābhedaṃ tesu yathārahaṃ;
analyzed: desa nāsā āsana kathā bhedam tesu yathāraham
translated: “In them, the teaching and the training, the difference of talk, as is fitting,

original: Sikkhāppahānagambhīrabhāvañca paridīpaye.
analyzed: sikkhā ppahāna gambhīra bhāvañca paridīpaye
translated: And the profundity of the training and the abandoning should be shown.

original: Pariyattibhedaṃ sampattiṃ, vipattiñcāpi yaṃ yahiṃ;
analyzed: pariyatti bhedam sampattim vipattim ca api yam yahim
translated: The difference of learning, the excellence, and also the failure, wherever it is,

original: Pāpuṇāti yathā bhikkhu, tampi sabbaṃ vibhāvaye”.
analyzed: pāpuṇāti yathā bhikkhu tam pi sabbam vibhāvaye
translated: That a bhikkhu may attain—all that should be analysed.”

original: Tatrāyaṃ paridīpanā vibhāvanā ca. Etāni hi tīṇi piṭakāni yathākkamaṃ āṇāvohāraparamatthadesanā,
analyzed: tatra ayam paridīpanā vibhāvanā ca etāni hi tīṇi piṭakāni yathākkamam āṇā vohāra paramattha desanā
translated: Here is the exposition and the analysis. These three Piṭakas are respectively the teaching of injunction, the teaching of talk, and the teaching of ultimate meaning,

original: yathāparādhayathānulomayathādhammasāsanāni, saṃvarāsaṃvaradiṭṭhiviniveṭhananāmarūpaparicchedakathāti🔽ca vuccanti. Ettha hi vinayapiṭakaṃ āṇārahena bhagavatā āṇābāhullato desitattā āṇādesanā,
analyzed: yathā aparādha yathā anuloma yathā dhamma sāsanāni saṃvara asaṃvara diṭṭhi viniveṭhana nāma rūpa pariccheda kathā ati  ca vuccanti ettha hi vinaya piṭakam āṇā rahena bhagavatā āṇā bāhullataḥ desita ttā āṇā desanā
translated: and they are also called the training precepts, the talk on restraint and non-restraint, and the talk on the analysis of mind and matter.🔽Herein, the Vinaya Piṭaka is called the teaching of injunction because it was taught by the Blessed One, who is worthy of an injunction, in abundance with injunctions.

original: suttantapiṭakaṃ vohārakusalena bhagavatā vohārabāhullato desitattā vohāradesanā,
analyzed: suttanta piṭakam vohāra kusalena bhagavatā vohāra bāhullataḥ desita ttā vohāra desanā
translated: The Suttanta Piṭaka is called the teaching of talk because it was taught by the Blessed One, who is skilled in the use of talk, in abundance with talk.

original: abhidhammapiṭakaṃ paramatthakusalena bhagavatā paramatthabāhullato desitattā paramatthadesanāti vuccati.🔽Tathā paṭhamaṃ – ‘ye te pacurāparādhā sattā, te yathāparādhaṃ ettha sāsitā’ti yathāparādhasāsanaṃ,
analyzed: abhidhammapiṭakam paramattha kusalena bhagavatā paramattha bāhullataḥ desita ttā paramattha desanā ati vuccati  tathā paṭhamam ye te sattā te yathāparādham ettha sā āsitā ati yathāparādha sāsanam
translated: The Abhidhamma Piṭaka is called “teaching of the ultimate truth” because it was taught by the Blessed One, who was skilled in the ultimate truth, and because it abounds in ultimate truth.🔽Similarly, the first is called “teaching of the way of action according to the deed” because it teaches the way of action according to the deed for those beings who have committed various crimes.

original: dutiyaṃ – ‘anekajjhāsayānusayacariyādhimuttikā sattā yathānulomaṃ ettha sāsitā’ti🔽yathānulomasāsanaṃ, tatiyaṃ – ‘dhammapuñjamatte “ahaṃ mamā”ti saññino sattā yathādhammaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam aneka ajjhāsaya anusaya cariyā adhimuttikā sattā yathā anulomam ettha sā āsitā ti  yathā anuloma sāsanam tatiyam dhamma puñja matte aham mama ati saññinaḥ sattāḥ yathādhammam
translated: The second is called “teaching of the way of action according to the individual” because it teaches the way of action according to the individual for beings who have various dispositions, latent tendencies, characters, and inclinations.

original: ettha sāsitā’ti yathādhammasāsananti vuccati.
analyzed: ettha sā āsitā ati yathā dhamma sāsananti vuccati
translated: The third is called “teaching of the way of action according to the Dhamma” because it teaches the way of action according to the Dhamma for beings who are attached to mere Dhamma and mere good fortune, thinking “Dhamma is mine, good fortune is mine.”

original: Tathā paṭhamaṃ – ajjhācārapaṭipakkhabhūto saṃvarāsaṃvaro ettha kathitoti saṃvarāsaṃvarakathā.
analyzed: tathā paṭhamam ajjhācāra paṭipakkha bhūto saṃvara asaṃvaraḥ ettha kathito ti saṃvara asaṃvara kathā
translated: Similarly, the first is called “the section on restraint and non-restraint” because restraint and non-restraint, which are opposed to misconduct, are discussed here.

original: Saṃvarāsaṃvaroti khuddako ceva mahanto ca saṃvaro, kammākammaṃ viya, phalāphalaṃ
analyzed: saṃvara asaṃvaraḥ ti khuddako ca iva mahantaḥ ca saṃvaro kamma akammam viya phala aphalam
translated: Restraint and non-restraint are like action and its result, like the fruit and the tree.

original: viya ca, dutiyaṃ – “dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhipaṭipakkhabhūtā diṭṭhiviniveṭhanā ettha kathitā”ti
analyzed: ca dutiyam dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi paṭipakkha bhūtā diṭṭhi viniveṭhanā ettha kathitā ati
translated: The second is called “the section on the bringing of views to an end” because the bringing of the sixty-two views to an end is discussed here.

original: diṭṭhiviniveṭhanakathā, tatiyaṃ – “rāgādipaṭipakkhabhūto nāmarūpaparicchedo ettha🔽kathito”ti nāmarūpaparicchedakathāti vuccati.
analyzed: diṭṭhi viniveṭhana kathā tatiyam rāga ādi paṭipakkha bhūtaḥ nāma rūpa paricchedaḥ ettha  kathitā ti nāma rūpa pariccheda kathā ati vuccati
translated: The exposition of the view-obsession is the third. It is called the exposition of mentality-materiality because mentality-materiality is taught here as the opposite of greed, etc.,

original: Tīsupi cetesu tisso sikkhā, tīṇi pahānāni, catubbidho ca gambhīrabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: tīsu pi ca itesu tissaḥ sikkhā tīṇi pahānāni catubbidhaḥ ca gambhīra bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The exposition of the three Piṭakas is called the “exposition of the three trainings” because the three trainings are included in the three Piṭakas.🔽The Vinaya Piṭaka is called the “exposition of the training in higher virtue” because it is the chief means for the development of the training in higher virtue.

original: Tathā hi vinayapiṭake visesena adhisīlasikkhā vuttā, suttantapiṭake adhicittasikkhā,🔽abhidhammapiṭake adhipaññāsikkhā.🔽Vinayapiṭake ca vītikkamappahānaṃ, kilesānaṃ vītikkamapaṭipakkhattā sīlassa. Suttantapiṭake
analyzed: tathā hi vinaya piṭake visesena adhi sīla sikkhā vuttā suttanta piṭake adhi citta sikkhā  abhidhammapiṭake adhipaññā sikkhā  vinaya piṭake ca vītikkama ppahānam kilesānam vītikkama paṭipakkha ttā sīlassa suttanta piṭake
translated: The Sutta Piṭaka is called the “exposition of the training in higher consciousness” because it is the chief means for the development of the training in higher consciousness.🔽The Abhidhamma Piṭaka is called the “exposition of the training in higher understanding” because it is the chief means for the development of the training in higher understanding.🔽The Vinaya Piṭaka is called the “exposition of the relinquishment of transgression” because virtue is the opposite of transgression.

original: pariyuṭṭhānappahānaṃ, pariyuṭṭhānapaṭipakkhattā samādhissa. Abhidhammapiṭake anusayappahānaṃ,
analyzed: pariyuṭṭhāna ppahānam pariyuṭṭhāna paṭipakkha ttā samādhissa abhidhammapiṭake anusaya ppahānam
translated: The Sutta Piṭaka is called the “exposition of the relinquishment of obsession” because concentration is the opposite of obsession.🔽The Abhidhamma Piṭaka is called the “exposition of the relinquishment of inherent tendency” because understanding is the opposite of inherent tendency.

original: anusayapaṭipakkhattā paññāya. Paṭhame ca tadaṅgappahānaṃ, itaresu vikkhambhanasamucchedappahānāni.
analyzed: anusaya paṭipakkha ttā paññāya paṭhame ca tad aṅga ppahānam itaresu vikkhambhana samuccheda ppahānāni
translated: In the first Piṭaka the relinquishment is a relinquishing of factors; in the other two it is a suppression and a cutting off respectively.

original: Paṭhame ca duccaritasaṃkilesappahānaṃ, itaresu taṇhādiṭṭhisaṃkilesappahānaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhame ca duccarita saṃkilesa pahānam itaresu taṇhā diṭṭhi saṃkilesa ppahānam
translated: In the first Piṭaka the defilement that is relinquished is the defilement of misconduct; in the other two it is the defilement of craving and the defilement of views respectively.

original: Ekamekasmiñcettha catubbidhopi dhammatthadesanā paṭivedhagambhīrabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: ekam ekasmin ca itthā catubbidhaḥ api dhamma attha desanā paṭivedha gambhīra bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: And in each case the fourfold teaching of the True Idea, etc., should be understood as the profundity of penetration.

original: Tattha dhammoti tanti. Atthoti tassāyeva attho. Desanāti tassā manasā vavatthāpitāya
analyzed: tattha dhammo ti tanti attho ti tassāya eva atthaḥ desanā ati tassā manasā vavatthāpitāya
translated: Herein, the True Idea is the Thread. The meaning is the meaning of that. The teaching is the teaching of that Thread which is defined in the mind.

original: tantiyā desanā. Paṭivedhoti tantiyā tantiatthassa ca yathābhūtāvabodho. Tīsupi cetesu
analyzed: tantiyā desanā paṭivedho ti tantiyā tanti atthassa ca yathā bhūta avabodho ca
translated: Penetration is the understanding of the Thread and the meaning of the Thread as they are. And in each of these three

original: ete dhammatthadesanāpaṭivedhā. Yasmā sasādīhi viya mahāsamuddo mandabuddhīhi dukkhogāḷhā
analyzed: ete dhamma attha desanā paṭivedhāḥ yasmā sa sādīhi viya mahā samuddaḥ manda buddhīhi dukkha ugāḷhā
translated: the teaching of the True Idea, etc., is the profundity of penetration. Because it is hard to enter upon like the great ocean with its sharks, etc., and because it is hard to fathom with its water of suffering,

original: alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭhā ca, tasmā gambhīrā. Evaṃ ekamekasmiṃ ettha catubbidhopi gambhīrabhāvo veditabbo.🔽Aparo nayo, dhammoti hetu. Vuttañhetaṃ – “hetumhi ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā”ti. Atthoti
analyzed: ca tasmai gambhīrā evam ekam ekasmin ettha catubbidhaḥ api gambhīra bhāvaḥ veditabbo  aparaḥ nayaḥ dhammo ti hetu vuttam ha etam hetumhi ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā ti atthaḥ ti
translated: and because it is hard to find a footing in, it is profound. So the profundity should be understood as fourfold in each case.🔽Another method: the True Idea is the cause. For this is said: “Knowledge of the cause is the discrimination of the True Idea” . The meaning is🔽the fruit of the cause. For this is said: “Knowledge of the cause and fruit is the discrimination of the meaning” . The teaching is the description.

original: hetuphalaṃ, vuttañhetaṃ – “hetuphale ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā”ti. Desanāti paññatti,
analyzed: hetu phalam hetu phale ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā ati desanā ati paññatti
translated: The intention is that it is the expression of the True Idea according to the True Idea.🔽The penetration is the understanding of the True Idea according to the True Idea. And in each of these three

original: yathā dhammaṃ dhammābhilāpoti adhippāyo. Anulomapaṭilomasaṅkhepavitthārādivasena
analyzed: yathā dhammam dhamma abhilāpo ti adhippāyaḥ anuloma paṭiloma saṅkhepa vitthāra ādi vasena
translated: the teaching of the True Idea, etc., is the profundity of penetration. Because it is hard to enter upon like the great ocean with its sharks, etc., and because it is hard to fathom with its water of suffering,🔽and because it is hard to find a footing in, it is profound.

original: vā kathanaṃ. Paṭivedhoti abhisamayo, so ca lokiyalokuttaro visayato asammohato ca,🔽atthānurūpaṃ dhammesu, dhammānurūpaṃ atthesu, paññattipathānurūpaṃ paññattīsu avabodho.
analyzed: vā kathanam paṭivedhaḥ ti abhisamayo saḥ ca lokiya lokuttaraḥ visayataḥ a sammohato ca  attha anurūpam dhammesu dhamma anurūpam atthesu paññatti patha anurūpam paññattīsu avabodhaḥ
translated: and the teaching of it. Penetration is the penetration of the truths. That is of two kinds as mundane and as supramundane. It is mundane when it is not confused about the object,🔽and it is supramundane when it is not confused about the object and is also not confused about confusion. It is the understanding of the meaning according to the teaching, of the teaching according to the meaning, and of the modes of teaching according to the modes of teaching.

original: Tesaṃ tesaṃ vā tattha tattha vuttadhammānaṃ paṭivijjhitabbo salakkhaṇasaṅkhāto aviparītasabhāvo.
analyzed: tesam tesam vā tattha tattha vutta dhammānam paṭivijjhitabbaḥ sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhāto aviparīta sabhāvo
translated: Or it is the unperverted individual essences of dhammas called their characteristics, etc., that should be penetrated in each case.

original: Idāni yasmā etesu piṭakesu yaṃ yaṃ dhammajātaṃ vā atthajātaṃ vā, yā cāyaṃ yathā yathā
analyzed: idāni yasmai etesu piṭakesu yam yam dhamma jātam vā attha jātam vā yā ca ayam yathā yathā
translated: Now, in these Piṭakas, whatever dhammas there are and whatever meanings there are,

original: ñāpetabbo attho sotūnaṃ ñāṇassa abhimukho hoti, tathā tathā tadatthajotikā desanā,
analyzed: ñāpetabbaḥ atthaḥ sotūnam ñāṇassa abhimukhaḥ hoti tathā tathā tad attha jotikā desanā
translated: and the teaching that illuminates that meaning, which is the means by which the meaning to be taught becomes evident to the listeners’ knowledge,

original: yo cettha aviparītāvabodhasaṅkhāto paṭivedho, tesaṃ tesaṃ vā dhammānaṃ paṭivijjhitabbo🔽salakkhaṇasaṅkhāto aviparītasabhāvo. Sabbampetaṃ anupacitakusalasambhārehi duppaññehi
analyzed: yaḥ ca ittha aviparīta avabodha saṅkhātaḥ paṭivedhaḥ tesam tesam vā dhammānam paṭivijjhitabbaḥ  sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhātaḥ a viparīta sabhāvaḥ sabbam petam an upacita kusala sambhārehi duppaññehi
translated: and the penetration called the unperverted understanding of that, and the unperverted individual essences of dhammas called their characteristics, etc., that should be penetrated in each case,🔽all this is as hard to come by as a foothold in the great ocean is for a man without hands and feet, or for a man of little wit who has not accumulated the requisite good karma.

original: sasādīhi viya mahāsamuddo dukkhogāḷhaṃ alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭhañca, tasmā gambhīraṃ.
analyzed: sasādīhi viya mahā samuddaḥ dukkha ugāḷham a labbha neyya patiṭṭham ca tasmai gambhīram
translated: So it is “profound.”

original: Evampi ekamekasmiṃ ettha catubbidhopi gambhīrabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam pi ekam ekasmin ettha catubbidhaḥ pi gambhīra bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: So the fourfold profundity should be understood here in each case.

original: Ettāvatā ca –🔽“Desanāsāsanakathā, bhedaṃ tesu yathārahaṃ;
analyzed: ettāvatā ca  desa nāsā āsana kathāḥ bhedam tesu yathāraham
translated: And at this point the following is to be said:🔽The teaching, the training, the explanation, the analysis,

original: Sikkhāppahānagambhīra, bhāvañca paridīpaye”ti –
analyzed: sikkhā ppahāna gambhīra bhāvañca paridīpaya iti
translated: The training, the abandoning, the profundity, and the meaning,

original: Ayaṃ gāthā vuttatthāva hoti.
analyzed: ayam gāthā vuttatthā ava hoti
translated: The verse is stated with its meaning.

original: “Pariyattibhedaṃ sampattiṃ, vipattiñcāpi yaṃ yahiṃ;
analyzed: pariyatti bhedam sampattim vipattim ca api yam yahim
translated: The analysis of the scriptures, the success, and the failure,🔽And how the bhikkhu attains them all—

original: Pāpuṇāti yathā bhikkhu, tampi sabbaṃ vibhāvaye”ti –
analyzed: pāpuṇāti yathā bhikkhu tam pi sabbam vibhāvaya iti
translated: This too should be explained.

original: Ettha pana tīsu piṭakesu tividho pariyattibhedo daṭṭhabbo. Tisso hi pariyattiyo – alagaddūpamā, nissaraṇatthā, bhaṇḍāgārikapariyattīti.
analyzed: ettha pana tīsu piṭakesu tividhaḥ pariyatti bhedaḥ daṭṭhabbo tissaḥ hi pariyattiyaḥ nissaraṇa atthā bhaṇḍāgārika pariyattī iti
translated: Herein, the analysis of the scriptures should be understood as threefold in the three Piṭakas. For there are three kinds of scriptures: the scripture like a crocodile, the scripture for the attainment of the deliverance of Nibbāna, and the scripture as a storehouse.

original: Tattha yā duggahitā, upārambhādihetu pariyāpuṭā, ayaṃ alagaddūpamā. Yaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: tattha yā upārambha ādi hetu pariyāpuṭā yam sandhāya
translated: Herein, that which is wrongly grasped and is wrapped up in the cause of dispute, etc., is like a crocodile.

original: vuttaṃ “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso alagaddatthiko alagaddagavesī alagaddapariyesanaṃ
analyzed: vuttam seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ alagaddatthikaḥ alagadda gavesī alagadda pariyesanam
translated: And that is said thus: “Bhikkhus, suppose a man needing a crocodile, seeking a crocodile, wandering in search of a crocodile,🔽were to see a big crocodile on dry land. He might think: ‘This is a big crocodile.

original: caramāno, so passeyya mahantaṃ alagaddaṃ, tamenaṃ bhoge vā naṅguṭṭhe vā gaṇheyya,
analyzed: caramānaḥ saḥ passeyya mahantam alagaddam tam enam bhoge vā naṅguṭṭhe vā gaṇheyya
translated: If I seize it by the head, it will overturn me and if I seize it by the tail, it will drag me along.

original: tassa so alagaddo paṭiparivattitvā hatthe vā bāhāyaṃ vā aññatarasmiṃ vā aṅgapaccaṅge
analyzed: tassa saḥ alagaddaḥ paṭiparivattitvā hatthe vā bāhāyam vā aññatarasmim vā aṅga paccaṅge
translated: That snake would turn back and bite his hand or his arm or some other part of his body,

original: ḍaṃseyya, so tato nidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigaccheyya, maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ. Taṃ kissa
analyzed: ḍaṃseyya saḥ tatas nidānam maraṇam vā nigaccheyya maraṇa mattam vā dukkham tam kissa
translated: and he might die from that bite or suffer death-like suffering. And why is that?

original: hetu? Duggahitattā, bhikkhave, alagaddassa. Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacce moghapurisā
analyzed: hetu duggahita ttā bhikkhave alagaddassa evam eva kho bhikkhave idha ekacce mogha purisā
translated: Because of his wrong grasp of the snake. So too, here some worthless men

original: dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇanti, suttaṃ…pe… vedallaṃ, te taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā tesaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: dhammam pariyāpuṇanti suttaṃpe vedallam te tam dhammam pariyāpuṇitvā tesam dhammānam
translated: learn the Dhamma … and the exposition of the Dhamma. But they do not investigate the meaning of those teachings with wisdom.

original: paññāya atthaṃ na upaparikkhanti, tesaṃ te dhammā paññāya atthaṃ anupaparikkhataṃ

translated: In the sense of pointing out: ‘I am not self-existent, nor have I realized this,’ thus exonerating himself, he points out the entire sutta to be spoken now, saying: ‘Thus have I heard,’ ‘I have heard in this way.’

original: Avadhāraṇatthena – “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahussutānaṃ
analyzed: avadhāraṇa atthena etat aggam bhikkhave mama sāvakānam bhikkhūnam bahu ssutānam
translated: In the sense of determining: ‘The most distinguished among my bhikkhu disciples in being learned is Ānanda,

original: yadidaṃ ānando, gatimantānaṃ, satimantānaṃ, dhitimantānaṃ, upaṭṭhākānaṃ yadidaṃ ānando”ti.
analyzed: yat idam ānandaḥ gatimantānam satimantānam dhitimantānam upaṭṭhākānam yat idam ānanda iti
translated: in having gone to the goal, in being mindful, in being wise, and in being attendants is Ānanda.’

original: Evaṃ bhagavatā – “āyasmā ānando atthakusalo, dhammakusalo, byañjanakusalo, niruttikusalo,
analyzed: evam bhagavatā āyasmai ānandaḥ attha kusalaḥ dhamma kusalaḥ byañjana kusalaḥ nirutti kusalaḥ
translated: Thus the Blessed One said: ‘The venerable Ānanda is skilled in the meaning, skilled in the Dhamma, skilled in the language, skilled in phrasing,

original: pubbāparakusalo”ti. Evaṃ dhammasenāpatinā ca pasatthabhāvānurūpaṃ attano dhāraṇabalaṃ🔽dassento sattānaṃ sotukāmataṃ janeti – ‘evaṃ me sutaṃ’, tañca kho atthato vā byañjanato
analyzed: pubba apara kusalaḥ ti evam dhamma senāpatinā ca pasattha bhāva anurūpam attanaḥ dhāraṇa balam  dassentaḥ sattānam sotu kāma tam janeti evam me sutam tat ca kho atthataḥ vā byañjanataḥ
translated: He is skilled in what is past and future. ’ In this way he shows that his own power of retention is equal to the praise of the General of the Dhamma.

original: vā anūnamanadhikaṃ, evameva na aññathā daṭṭhabba”nti.
analyzed: vā anūnam anadhikam evam eva na aññathā daṭṭhabbanti
translated: He arouses in beings the desire to listen by saying ‘Thus I heard’ in the sense that ‘Just as it was grasped by me so it is being told by me without increase or decrease, and it should be regarded in this way and not otherwise.’

original: Me-saddo tīsu atthesu dissati. Tathā hissa – “gāthābhigītaṃ me abhojaneyya”ntiādīsu
analyzed: me saddaḥ tīsu atthesu dissati tathā hi ssa gāthā abhigītam me abhojaneyya nti ādīsu
translated: The word me occurs in three senses. For in such passages as ‘What is recited in verse is not fit to be eaten by me’ (A.i,11)

original: mayāti attho. “Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetū”tiādīsu mayhanti🔽attho. “Dhammadāyādā me, bhikkhave, bhavathā”tiādīsu mamāti attho. Idha pana mayā
analyzed: mayā iti sādhu me bhante bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammam desetu uti ādīsu mayhanti  atthaḥ dhamma dāyādāḥ me bhikkhave bhavatha atiādīsu mama ati atthaḥ idha pana mayā
translated: it means ‘by me.’ In such passages as ‘It would be good, venerable sir, if the Blessed One would teach me the Dhamma in brief’ (A.i,1)

original: sutanti ca, mama sutanti ca atthadvaye yujjati.
analyzed: su tanti ca mama su tanti ca attha dvaye yujjati
translated: it means ‘by me.’ In such passages as ‘Be my heirs, bhikkhus, in the Dhamma’ it means ‘by me.’ But here the two meanings ‘by me’ and ‘mine’ are appropriate.

original: Sutanti ayaṃ suta-saddo saupasaggo ca anupasaggo ca – gamanavissutakilinna-upacitānuyoga-sotaviññeyya-sotadvārānusāra-viññātādianekatthappabhedo,
analyzed: sutanti ayam suta saddo sa upasaggo ca anupasaggo ca gamana vissuta kilinna aupacita anuyoga sota viññeyya sota dvāra anusāra viññāta ādi aneka attha ppabhedaḥ
translated: The word heard is used in many senses, such as going, seeing, flowing, spreading, accumulating, to be known by the ear, following the ear door, being cognized, and so on.

original: tathā hissa “senāya pasuto”tiādīsu gacchantoti attho. “Sutadhammassa passato”tiādīsu
analyzed: tathā hi ssa senāya pasutaḥ tiādīsu gacchanto ti atthaḥ suta dhammassa passataḥ tiādīsu
translated: In such passages as “The one who sees the Dhamma seen by the one who is well-versed in the Dhamma”

original: vissutadhammassāti attho. “Avassutā avassutassā”tiādīsu kilinnākilinnassāti attho.
analyzed: vissuta dhammassa ati atthaḥ avassutā avassutassa atiādīsu kilinna akilinnassa ati atthaḥ
translated: the meaning is “the one who is well-versed in the Dhamma”. In such passages as “The one who is not lustful, the one who is not lustful” the meaning is “the one who is not wet, the one who is not wet”.

original: “Tumhehi puññaṃ pasutaṃ anappaka”ntiādīsu upacitanti attho. “Ye jhānapasutā dhīrā”tiādīsu🔽jhānānuyuttāti attho. ‘Diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ muta’ntiādīsu sotaviññeyyanti attho. “Sutadharo
analyzed: tumhehi puññam pasutam anappakam ti ādīsu upacitanti atthaḥ ye jhāna pasutāḥ dhīrā ti ādīsu  jhāna anuyuttā ati atthaḥ diṭṭham sutam mutam ti ādīsu sota viññeyyanti attho sutadharo
translated: In such passages as “You have made much merit” the meaning is “you have accumulated”. In such passages as “The wise ones who are devoted to jhana”🔽the meaning is “those who are devoted to jhana”. In such passages as “Seen, heard, sensed” the meaning is “sensed by the ear”. In such passages as “One who remembers what he has heard,

original: sutasannicayo”tiādīsu sotadvārānusāraviññātadharoti attho. Idha panassa sotadvārānusārena🔽upadhāritanti vā upadhāraṇanti vāti attho. ‘Me’ saddassa hi ‘mayā’ti atthe sati ‘evaṃ
analyzed: suta sannicayaḥ ti ādīsu sota dvāra anusāra viññāta dharo ti attho idha pana assa sota dvāra anusārena  upadhāritanti vā upadhāraṇanti vā ati atthaḥ me saddassa hi mayā ati atthe sati evam
translated: one who has stored up what he has heard” the meaning is “one who remembers what has been sensed by the ear”. But here the meaning is “what has been borne in mind by following the ear door”

original: mayā sutaṃ’ sotadvārānusārena upadhāritanti yujjati. ‘Mamā’ti atthe sati evaṃ mama🔽sutaṃ sotadvārānusārena upadhāraṇanti yujjati.
analyzed: mayā sutam sota dvāra anusārena upadhāritanti yujjati mama ati atthe sati evam mama 🔽sutam sotadvāra anusārena yujjati
translated: or “what is borne in mind by following the ear door”. For when the word “me” has the meaning “by me,” the expression “thus by me was it heard” is appropriate, meaning “what was borne in mind by me by following the ear door.” But when the word “me” has the meaning “of me,” the expression “thus of me was it heard” is appropriate, meaning “what is borne in mind by me by following the ear door.”

original: Evametesu tīsu padesu evanti sotaviññāṇādiviññāṇakiccanidassanaṃ. Meti vuttaviññāṇasamaṅgipuggalanidassanaṃ.
analyzed: evam etesu tīsu padesu evam ti sota viññāṇa ādi viññāṇa kicca nidassanam mā iti vutta viññāṇa samaṅgi puggala nidassanam
translated: So in these three terms the word “thus” shows the function of the consciousness that is eye-consciousness, etc., the word “I” shows the person possessing the consciousness stated,

original: Sutanti assavanabhāvapaṭikkhepato anūnādhikāviparītaggahaṇanidassanaṃ. Tathā evanti
analyzed: sutam ti assavana bhāva paṭikkhepataḥ anūna adhika aviparīta ggahaṇa nidassanam tathā evam ti
translated: and the word “heard” shows the apprehension that is neither less nor more than that and is not wrongly apprehended, by excluding the state of not hearing. So too, the word “thus”

original: tassā sotadvārānusārena pavattāya viññāṇavīthiyā nānappakārena ārammaṇe pavattibhāvappakāsanaṃ.🔽Meti attappakāsanaṃ. Sutanti dhammappakāsanaṃ. Ayañhettha saṅkhepo – “nānappakārena
analyzed: tassā sota dvāra anusārena pavattāya viññāṇa vīthiyā nānappakārena ārammaṇe pavatti bhāva ppakāsanam  mā iti atta ppakāsanam sutam ti dhamma ppakāsanam ayam ha ittha saṅkhepaḥ nānā pakārena
translated: shows the occurrence of the consciousness process in the various ways in the various objects that occur with the ear as their proximate cause.

original: ārammaṇe pavattāya viññāṇavīthiyā mayā na aññaṃ kataṃ, idaṃ pana kataṃ, ayaṃ dhammo suto”ti.
analyzed: ārammaṇe pavattāya viññāṇa vīthiyā mayā na aññam katam idam pana katam ayam dhammo suto ti
translated: The word “I” shows the self, and the word “heard” shows the states. The meaning is this: “In the various ways in which the consciousness process occurred in the various objects, I did not do this, but I heard this state.”

original: Tathā evanti niddisitabbadhammappakāsanaṃ. Meti puggalappakāsanaṃ. Sutanti puggalakiccappakāsanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti. “Yaṃ suttaṃ niddisissāmi, taṃ mayā evaṃ suta”nti.
analyzed: tathā evam ti niddisitabba dhamma pakāsanam mā iti puggala ppakāsanam sutam ti puggala kicca ppakāsanam idam vuttam hoti yam suttam niddisissāmi tam mayā evam sutam ti
translated: So too, the word “thus” shows the states that are to be demonstrated, and the word “I” shows the person, and the word “heard” shows the function of the person. The meaning is this: “The sutta that I shall demonstrate was heard by me thus.”

original: Tathā evanti yassa cittasantānassa nānākārappavattiyā nānatthabyañjanaggahaṇaṃ hoti,
analyzed: tathā evam ti yassa citta santānassa nānā ākāra ppavattiyā nānattha byañjana ggahaṇam hoti
translated: Likewise, “thus” is the description of the mode of the continuity of consciousness in which there is apprehension of the various meanings and phrasing of the teaching.

original: tassa nānākāraniddeso. Evanti hi ayamākārapaññatti. Meti kattuniddeso. Sutanti visayaniddeso.
analyzed: tassa nānā ākāra niddeso evam ti hi ayam ākāra paññatti mā iti kattu niddeso suta nti visaya niddeso
translated: “Thus” is the description of the mode; “I” is the description of the doer; “heard” is the description of the objective field.

original: Ettāvatā nānākārappavattena cittasantānena taṃ samaṅgino kattu visayaggahaṇasanniṭṭhānaṃ kataṃ hoti.
analyzed: ettāvatā nānā ākāra ppavattena citta santānena tam samaṅgino kattu visaya ggahaṇa sanniṭṭhānam katam hoti
translated: At this point the act of apprehending and determining the objective field by the continuity of consciousness endowed with the various modes of teaching is completed.

original: Athavā evanti puggalakiccaniddeso. Sutanti viññāṇakiccaniddeso. Meti ubhayakiccayuttapuggalaniddeso.🔽Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo, “mayā savanakiccaviññāṇasamaṅginā puggalena viññāṇavasena
analyzed: athavā evam ti puggala kicca niddeso suta nti viññāṇa kicca niddeso mā iti ubhaya kicca yutta puggala niddeso  ayam pana ittha saṅkhepaḥ mayā savana kicca viññāṇa samaṅginā puggalena viññāṇa vasena
translated: Or alternatively, “thus” is the description of the function of the person; “heard” is the description of the function of consciousness; “I” is the description of the person associated with the two functions.

original: laddhasavanakiccavohārena suta”nti.🔽Tattha evanti ca meti ca saccikaṭṭhaparamatthavasena avijjamānapaññatti. Kiñhettha
analyzed: laddha savana kicca vohārena  tattha evam ti ca mā iti ca saccikaṭṭha paramattha vasena avijjamāna paññatti kiñhā ittha
translated: But in brief, “I, the person endowed with the function of hearing, have heard by means of the consciousness that has acquired the designation ‘that which has the function of hearing.’ ”

original: taṃ paramatthato atthi, yaṃ evanti vā meti vā niddesaṃ labhetha? Sutanti vijjamānapaññatti.
analyzed: tam paramatthataḥ atthi yam evam iti vā mā iti vā niddesam labhetha sutam ti vijjamāna paññatti
translated: Herein, “thus” and “I” are descriptions that do not exist in the ultimate sense. What is there that exists in the ultimate sense that could get the description “thus” or “I”? “Heard” is a description that exists.

original: Yañhi taṃ ettha sotena upaladdhaṃ, taṃ paramatthato vijjamānanti. Tathā ‘eva’nti
analyzed: yat hi tam ettha sotena upaladdham tam paramatthataḥ vijjamānanti tathā evanti
translated: What is apprehended here by the ear is in the ultimate sense existent.

original: ca, meti ca, taṃ taṃ upādāya vattabbato upādāpaññatti. ‘Suta’nti diṭṭhādīni upanidhāya🔽vattabbato upanidhāpaññatti. Ettha ca evanti vacanena asammohaṃ dīpeti. Na hi sammūḷho🔽nānappakārapaṭivedhasamattho hoti. ‘Suta’nti vacanena sutassa asammosaṃ dīpeti. Yassa🔽hi sutaṃ sammuṭṭhaṃ hoti, na so kālantarena mayā sutanti paṭijānāti. Iccassa asammohena
analyzed: ca mā iti ca tam tam upādāya vattabbataḥ upādā paññatti sutanti diṭṭha ādīni upanidhāya  vattabbataḥ upanidhā paññatti ettha ca evam ti vacanena asammoham dīpeti na hi sammūḷhaḥ  nānā pakāra paṭivedha samatthaḥ hoti suta nti vacanena sutassa asammosam dīpeti yassa  hi sutam sammuṭṭham hoti na saḥ kāla antarena mayā sutanti paṭijānāti iccassa a sammohena
translated: ‘Thus’ is a designation by way of what is to be stated, since it is to be stated in dependence on this and that. ‘Heard’ is a designation by way of what is to be stated in dependence on what is seen, etc.

original: paññāsiddhi, asammosena pana satisiddhi. Tattha paññāpubbaṅgamāya satiyā byañjanāvadhāraṇasamatthatā,🔽satipubbaṅgamāya paññāya atthapaṭivedhasamatthatā. Tadubhayasamatthatāyogena atthabyañjanasampannassa
analyzed: paññā siddhi asammosena pana sati siddhi tattha paññā pubbaṅgamāya satiyā byañjana avadhāraṇa samattha tā  sati pubbaṅgamāya paññāya attha paṭivedha samattha tā tad ubhaya samattha tā yogena attha byañjana sampannassa
translated: And here the word ‘thus’ indicates non-delusion, for one who is deluded is not capable of penetrating the various kinds of things. The word ‘heard’ indicates the non-forgetting of what is heard, for one whose hearing is confused does not acknowledge later on that he heard this or that. Thus, through non-delusion, his understanding is accomplished, and through non-forgetting, his mindfulness is accomplished. Herein, through the mindfulness that has understanding as its forerunner, he is able to retain the letter ;

original: dhammakosassa anupālanasamatthato dhammabhaṇḍāgārikattasiddhi.
analyzed: dhamma kosassa anupālana samatthataḥ
translated: through the understanding that has mindfulness as its forerunner, he is able to penetrate the meaning. Through the combination of both, he is able to preserve the Dhamma-treasure endowed with both meaning and letter.

original: Aparo nayo, evanti vacanena yoniso manasikāraṃ dīpeti. Ayoniso manasikaroto hi nānappakārapaṭivedhābhāvato.🔽Sutanti vacanena avikkhepaṃ dīpeti, vikkhittacittassa savanābhāvato. Tathā hi vikkhittacitto
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ evanti vacanena yonisaḥ manasikāram dīpeti ayonisaḥ manasikarotaḥ hi nānā pakāra paṭivedha abhāvato  sutam ti vacanena avikkhepam dīpeti vikkhitta cittassa savana abhāvataḥ tathā hi vikkhitta cittaḥ
translated: Another method: by the word “thus” he shows reasoned attention, for there is no penetration of the various kinds without reasoned attention.

original: puggalo sabbasampattiyā vuccamānopi “na mayā sutaṃ, puna bhaṇathā”ti bhaṇati. Yoniso🔽manasikārena cettha attasammāpaṇidhiṃ pubbe ca katapuññataṃ sādheti, sammā appaṇihitattassa🔽pubbe akatapuññassa vā tadabhāvato. Avikkhepena saddhammassavanaṃ sappurisūpanissayañca
analyzed: puggalaḥ sabba sampattiyā vuccamānaḥ api na mayā sutam puna bhaṇatha ati bhaṇati yoniso  manasikārena ca ittha atta sammāpaṇidhim pubbe ca kata puñña tam sādheti sammā appaṇihita ttassa  pubbe akata puññassa vā tad abhāvataḥ avikkhepena saddhamma ssavanam sappurisa upanissayam ca
translated: By the word “heard” he shows non-distraction, for there is no hearing for one whose mind is distracted. For a person whose mind is distracted says, “I did not hear it,” even when he is being told something that is for his welfare, and he says, “Speak again.”🔽Herein, by reasoned attention he accomplishes the right aspiration of self-guidance and the performance of merit in the past, for without that right aspiration and that performance of merit in the past there is no such thing.

original: sādheti. Na hi vikkhittacitto sotuṃ sakkoti, na ca sappurise anupassayamānassa savanaṃ atthīti.
analyzed: sādheti na hi vikkhitta cittaḥ sotum sakkoti na ca sappurise anupassayamānassa savanam atthi iti
translated: By non-distraction he accomplishes the hearing of the true Dhamma and the attendance on true men, for one whose mind is distracted cannot hear, and there is no hearing for one who does not attend on true men.

original: Aparo nayo, yasmā evanti yassa cittasantānassa nānākārappavattiyā nānatthabyañjanaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ yasmai evanti yassa citta santānassa nānā ākāra ppavattiyā nānattha byañjana ggahaṇam
translated: Another method: by the word “thus” he shows the occurrence in a single continuity of consciousness of the apprehension of the various meanings and the various phrasing.

original: hoti, tassa nānākāraniddesoti vuttaṃ, so ca evaṃ bhaddako ākāro na sammāappaṇihitattano
analyzed: hoti tassa nānā ākāra niddeso ti vuttam saḥ ca evam bhaddakaḥ ākāro na sammā appaṇihita ttano
translated: and the description of the various kinds of it is given. And that kind is so good that it is not properly directed.

original: pubbe akatapuññassa vā hoti, tasmā evanti iminā bhaddakenākārena pacchimacakkadvayasampattimattano🔽dīpeti. Sutanti savanayogena purimacakkadvayasampattiṃ. Na hi appatirūpadese vasato
analyzed: pubbe a kata puññassa vā hoti tasmai evam ti iminā bhaddakena ākārena pacchima cakka dvaya sampattimattano  dīpeti savana yogena purima cakka dvaya sampattim na hi appatir upadese vasato
translated: and that good form is not his if he has not previously made merit or if he has not rightly applied himself,🔽so he shows that he himself has the good form of the last two wheels by “thus” and that of the first two wheels by “I have heard.”🔽For there is no hearing for one who lives in an unsuitable locality or

original: sappurisūpanissayavirahitassa vā savanaṃ atthi. Iccassa pacchimacakkadvayasiddhiyā
analyzed: sappurisa upanissaya virahitassa vā savanaṃ atthi iccassa pacchima cakka dvaya siddhiyā
translated: who is devoid of the support of good men. So the purification of his inclination is established by his success in the last two wheels,

original: āsayasuddhisiddhā hoti, purimacakkadvayasiddhiyā payogasuddhi, tāya ca āsayasuddhiyā
analyzed: āsaya suddhi siddhā hoti purima cakka dvaya siddhiyā tāya ca āsaya suddhiyā
translated: and the purification of his effort by his success in the first two wheels. And by the purification of his inclination

original: adhigamabyattisiddhi, payogasuddhiyā āgamabyattisiddhi. Iti payogāsayasuddhassa āgamādhigamasampannassa
analyzed: adhigama byatti siddhi payoga suddhiyā āgama byatti siddhi iti payoga āsaya suddhassa āgama adhigama sampannassa
translated: the success of his penetration of the Teaching is established, and by the purification of his effort the success of his penetration of the Discipline. So the Blessed One shows that he himself has the success of both the Teaching and the Discipline by “I have heard.”🔽The statement of one whose effort and inclination are purified and who has the success of both the Teaching and the Discipline

original: vacanaṃ aruṇuggaṃ viya sūriyassa udayato yoniso manasikāro viya ca kusalakammassa
analyzed: vacanam aruṇuggam viya sūriyassa udayataḥ yonisas manasikāraḥ viya ca kusala kammassa
translated: is like the dawn to the world, and right reflection on profitable action is like the rising of the sun.

original: arahati bhagavato vacanassa pubbaṅgamaṃ bhavitunti ṭhāne nidānaṃ ṭhapento – “evaṃ me suta”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: arahati bhagavato vacanassa pubbaṅgamam bhavitunti ṭhāne nidānam ṭhapentaḥ evam me suta nti ādim āha
translated: He is worthy to be a forerunner of the word of the Blessed One. ” So he says “Thus I heard” in order to establish the setting.

original: Aparo nayo, ‘eva’nti iminā nānappakārapaṭivedhadīpakena vacanena attano atthapaṭibhānapaṭisambhidāsampattisabbhāvaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ evam ti iminā nānā pakāra paṭivedha dīpakena vacanena attanaḥ attha paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā sampatti sabbhāvam
translated: Another method: by the word “thus” he shows that he himself is endowed with the perfection of the discrimination of perspicuity of meaning,

original: dīpeti. ‘Suta’nti iminā sotabbappabhedapaṭivedhadīpakena dhammaniruttipaṭisambhidāsampattisabbhāvaṃ.
analyzed: dīpeti sutam ti iminā sotabba ppabheda paṭivedha dīpakena dhamma nirutti paṭisambhidā sampatti sabbhāvam
translated: by the word “heard” he shows that he is endowed with the perfection of the discrimination of perspicuity of language.

original: ‘Eva’nti ca idaṃ yoniso manasikāradīpakaṃ vacanaṃ bhāsamāno – “ete mayā dhammā manasānupekkhitā,🔽diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā”ti dīpeti. ‘Suta’nti idaṃ savanayogadīpakaṃ vacanaṃ bhāsamāno
analyzed: evam ti ca idam yonisas manasikāra dīpakam vacanam bhāsamānaḥ ete mayā dhammāḥ manasā an upekkhitā  diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā iti dīpeti sutam ti idam savana yoga dīpakam vacanam bhāsamānaḥ
translated: By the word “thus” he shows that he has well seen and penetrated the meaning of the Dhamma with his wisdom,🔽by the word “heard” he shows that he has heard the Dhamma with his ear,

original: – “bahū mayā dhammā sutā dhātā vacasā paricitā”ti dīpeti. Tadubhayenāpi atthabyañjanapāripūriṃ
analyzed: bahū mayā dhammā sutā dhātā vacasā paricitā ati dīpeti tad ubhayena api attha byañjana pāripūrim
translated: and by both he shows the perfection of the meaning and the letter.

original: dīpento savane ādaraṃ janeti. Atthabyañjanaparipuṇṇañhi dhammaṃ ādarena assuṇanto
analyzed: dīpentaḥ savane ādaram janeti attha byañjana paripuṇṇam hi dhammam ādarena assuṇantaḥ

analyzed: bhagavā iti garu garun hi loke bhagavā iti vadanti ayam ca sabba guṇa visiṭṭha tāya sabba sattānam garu tasmā bhagavā iti veditabbaḥ porāṇehi pi vuttam
translated: “Bhagavā” is “venerable.” For in the world they call one who is venerable “bhagavā.” And this Blessed One is venerable to all beings because of his excellence in all good qualities. Therefore he should be understood as “bhagavā.” It is said by the Ancients:🔽“The word ‘bhagavā’ is the best,

original: “Bhagavāti vacanaṃ seṭṭhaṃ, bhagavāti vacanamuttamaṃ;
analyzed: bhagavā ati vacanam seṭṭham bhagavā ati vacanam uttamam
translated: The word ‘bhagavā’ is the highest;🔽He is venerable, endowed with veneration,

original: Garu gāravayutto so, bhagavā tena vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: so bhagavā tena vuccati iti
translated: Therefore he is called ‘bhagavā.’

original: Api ca –
analyzed: api ca
translated: And further:🔽Endowed with fortune, and with what is broken,🔽And with what is distributed by portions,

original: “Bhāgyavā bhaggavā yutto, bhagehi ca vibhattavā;
analyzed: bhāgyavā bhaggavā yuttaḥ bhagehi ca
translated: And with what is eaten, and with what is gone to the end,

original: Bhattavā vantagamano, bhavesu bhagavā tato”ti.
analyzed: bhattavā vanta gamanaḥ bhavesu bhagavā tatoti
translated: Therefore he is ‘bhagavā’ in existences.”

original: Imissā gāthāya vasenassa padassa vitthāraattho veditabbo. So ca visuddhimagge buddhānussatiniddese vuttoyeva.
analyzed: imissā gāthāya vasena assa padassa vitthāra atthaḥ veditabbo saḥ ca visuddhi magge buddha anussati niddese vuttaḥ yeva
translated: The detailed meaning of the word “thus” should be understood in accordance with this verse. And that meaning has already been given in the Description of the Recollection of the Buddha in the Path of Purity.

original: Ettāvatā cettha evaṃ me sutanti vacanena yathāsutaṃ dhammaṃ dassento bhagavato dhammakāyaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā ca itthā evam me sutam ti vacanena yathāsutam dhammam dassentaḥ bhagavataḥ dhammakāyam
translated: So far, by the words “Thus have I heard,” the Exalted One, showing the Dhamma body of the Exalted One as he had heard it,

original: paccakkhaṃ karoti. Tena “nayidaṃ atikkantasatthukaṃ pāvacanaṃ, ayaṃ vo satthā”ti🔽satthu adassanena ukkaṇṭhitaṃ janaṃ samassāseti.
analyzed: paccakkham karoti tena na idam atikkanta satthukam ayam vaḥ satthā ti  satthu a dassanena ukkaṇṭhitam janam samassāseti
translated: reassures the people who are dispirited at the thought that the Teacher is no more, saying: “This is not a dispensation that has passed beyond the Teacher’s lifetime. This is your Teacher.”

original: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavāti vacanena tasmiṃ samaye bhagavato avijjamānabhāvaṃ dassento
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā iti vacanena tasmin samaye bhagavataḥ avijjamāna bhāvam dassento
translated: By the words “at one time the Exalted One,” the Exalted One shows that at that time the Exalted One was no more.

original: rūpakāyaparinibbānaṃ sādheti. Tena “evaṃvidhassa nāma ariyadhammassa desako dasabaladharo
analyzed: rūpa kāya parinibbānam sādheti tena evaṃvidhassa nāma ariya dhammassa desakaḥ dasa bala dharo
translated: Thus he establishes the passing away of the physical body. Thereby he arouses a sense of urgency in the people who are intoxicated with the conceit of life, saying: “The Exalted One, the bearer of the ten powers, the teacher of such and such a noble Dhamma,

original: vajirasaṅghāta samānakāyo sopi bhagavā parinibbuto, kena aññena jīvite āsā janetabbā”ti
analyzed: vajira saṅghāta samāna kāyaḥ saḥ api bhagavā parinibbutaḥ kena aññena jīvite āsā janetabbā ati
translated: whose body was like a diamond, he too has attained final Nibbāna. What hope can there be of life for anyone else?”

original: jīvitamadamattaṃ janaṃ saṃvejeti, saddhamme cassa ussāhaṃ janeti.
analyzed: jīvita mada mattam janam saṃvejeti saddhamme ca ssa ussāham janeti
translated: And he arouses in them a sense of urgency with regard to the true Dhamma.

original: Evanti ca bhaṇanto desanāsampattiṃ niddisati. Me sutanti sāvakasampattiṃ. Ekaṃ samayanti kālasampattiṃ. Bhagavāti desakasampattiṃ.
analyzed: evam iti ca bhaṇantaḥ desanā sampattim niddisati me suta iti sāvaka sampattim ekam samayanti kāla sampattim bhagavān ati desaka sampattim
translated: and saying “Thus” he shows the excellence of the Teaching. “I heard” shows the excellence of the hearer. “At one time” shows the excellence of the time. “The Blessed One” shows the excellence of the teacher.

original: Antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandanti antarā-saddo kāraṇakhaṇacittavemajjhavivarādīsu
analyzed: antarā ca rājagaham antarā ca na āḷandanti antarāsaddaḥ kāraṇa khaṇa citta vemajjha vivara ādīsu
translated: The word “between” is seen in the sense of cause, moment, mind, middle, and space.

original: dissati. “Tadantaraṃ ko jāneyya aññatra tathāgatā”ti ca, “janā saṅgamma mantenti
analyzed: dissati tad antaram kaḥ jāneyya aññatra tathāgata ati ca janā saṅgamma mantenti
translated: “Who but a Tathāgata could know the cause of that?” and “People gather and talk,

original: mañca tañca kimantara”nti ca ādīsu hi kāraṇe antarā-saddo. “Addasa maṃ, bhante, aññatarā🔽itthī vijjantarikāya bhājanaṃ dhovantī”tiādīsu khaṇe. “Yassantarato na santi kopā”tiādīsu🔽citte. “Antarā vosānamāpādī”tiādīsu vemajjhe. “Api cāyaṃ, bhikkhave, tapodā dvinnaṃ
analyzed: ādīsu hi kāraṇe antarāsaddaḥ addasa mama bhante aññatarā  itthī vijjantarikāya bhājanam dhovanti iti ādīsu khaṇe yaḥ santarataḥ na santi kopāḥ ati ādīsu  citte antarā vosānam āpādi iti ādīsu vemajjhe api ca ayam bhikkhave tapodā dvinnam
translated: and what is the cause of that?” and so on. In the passage “Lady, I saw a certain woman washing a dish in the lightning’s flash” it is a moment.

original: mahānirayānaṃ antarikāya āgacchatī”tiādīsu vivare. Svāyamidha vivare vattati, tasmā
analyzed: vivare svāyamidha vivare vattati
translated: In the passage “In whom there is no anger in the heart” it is mind. In the passage “He died in mid-course” it is middle. In the passage “But this, bhikkhus, the Lightning-flash River comes between the two great hells” it is space. Here it is space that is intended.

original: rājagahassa ca nāḷandāya ca vivareti evametthattho veditabbo. Antarā-saddena pana🔽yuttattā upayogavacanaṃ kataṃ. Īdisesu ca ṭhānesu akkharacintakā “antarā gāmañca🔽nadiñca yātī”ti evaṃ ekameva antarāsaddaṃ payujjanti, so dutiyapadenapi yojetabbo
analyzed: rājagahassa ca nāḷandāya ca vivare iti evam etthatthaḥ veditabbaḥ antarāsaddena pana  upayoga vacanam katam īdisesu ca ṭhānesu akkhara cintakāḥ antarā  nadit ca yāti iti evam ekam eva antarāsaddam payujjanti saḥ dutiya padena api yojetabbo
translated: and between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā. This is how the meaning should be understood here. But because of the word ‘between’,🔽the word ‘going’ is used. And in such places as this, those who think about the letters use only one word ‘between’, as in ‘between the village and the river he goes’,

original: hoti, ayojiyamāne upayogavacanaṃ na pāpuṇāti. Idha pana yojetvāyeva vuttoti.🔽Addhānamaggappaṭipanno hotīti addhānasaṅkhātaṃ maggaṃ paṭipanno hoti, “dīghamagga”nti
analyzed: ho ti a yojiyamāne upayoga vacanam na pāpuṇāti idha pana yojetvāya iva vutto ti  addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ hoti iti addhāna saṅkhātam maggam paṭipannaḥ hoti dīgha maggam ti
translated: and that has to be construed with the second part of the compound as well. If it is not construed, it does not come under the rule about the use of the word ‘going’. But here it is stated after being construed.

original: attho. Addhānagamanasamayassa hi vibhaṅge “aḍḍhayojanaṃ gacchissāmīti bhuñjitabba”ntiādivacanato
analyzed: atthaḥ addhāna gamana samayassa hi vibhaṅge aḍḍha yojanam gacchissāmi iti bhuñjitabba nti ādi vacanataḥ
translated: He was travelling on the main road: he was travelling on a road called ‘the main road’, the meaning of which is ‘a long road’. For in the analysis of the time for travelling the main road, the words ‘I shall go a yojana and a half’ are used,

original: aḍḍhayojanampi addhānamaggo hoti. Rājagahato pana nāḷandā yojanameva.
analyzed: aḍḍha yojanam pi addhāna maggaḥ hoti rājagahataḥ pana nāḷandā yojanam eva
translated: and so a yojana and a half is the main road. But from Rājagaha to Nāḷandā it is only a yojana.

original: Mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhinti ‘mahatā’ti guṇamahattenapi mahatā, saṅkhyāmahattenapi
analyzed: mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhinti mahatā ati guṇa mahattena pi mahatā saṅkhyā mahattena pi
translated: Together with a great community of bhikkhus: ‘great’ by greatness of special qualities and also by greatness of number.

original: mahatā. So hi bhikkhusaṅgho guṇehipi mahā ahosi, appicchatādiguṇasamannāgatattā.
analyzed: mahatā saḥ hi bhikkhu saṅghaḥ guṇehi pi mahā ahosi appiccha tā ādi guṇa samannāgata ttā
translated: For this community of bhikkhus was great in qualities too, since it was endowed with the qualities of fewness of wishes, etc.🔽It was great in number too, since it numbered five hundred.

original: Saṅkhyāyapi mahā, pañcasatasaṅkhyattā. Bhikkhūnaṃ saṅgho ‘bhikkhusaṅgho’, tena bhikkhusaṅghena.
analyzed: mahā pañca sata saṅkhyattā bhikkhūnam saṅghaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ tena bhikkhu saṅghena
translated: The community of bhikkhus is the community of those who have entered upon the way .🔽The meaning is: with a community of those who have entered upon the way that is a community in the sense of a gathering together of those who are similar in virtue and view.

original: Diṭṭhisīlasāmaññasaṅghātasaṅkhātena samaṇagaṇenāti attho. Saddhinti ekato.🔽Pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehīti pañcamattā etesanti pañcamattāni. Mattāti pamāṇaṃ vuccati,🔽tasmā yathā “bhojane mattaññū”ti vutte “bhojane mattaṃ jānāti, pamāṇaṃ jānātī”ti🔽attho hoti, evamidhāpi – “tesaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ pañcamattā pañcapamāṇa”nti evamattho
analyzed: diṭṭhi sīla sāmañña saṅghāta saṅkhātena samaṇa gaṇena ati attho saddhinti ekatas  pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi iti pañcamattāḥ etesan ti pañcamattāni mattā ati pamāṇam vuccati  tasmā yathā bhojane vutte bhojane mattam jānāti pamāṇam jānāti iti  atthaḥ hoti evam idha api tesam bhikkhu satānam pañca mattā pañca pamāṇam ti evam atthaḥ
translated: Together with: together with.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Bhikkhūnaṃ satāni bhikkhusatāni, tehi pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ bhikkhūnam satāni bhikkhu satāni tehi pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: With five hundred bhikkhus: with five hundred bhikkhus is with five hundred of those who are bhikkhus.

original: Suppiyopi kho paribbājakoti suppiyoti tassa nāmaṃ. Pi-kāro maggappaṭipannasabhāgatāya
analyzed: suppiyaḥ api kho paribbājako ti suppiyaḥ ti tassa nāmam pikāraḥ magga paṭipanna sabhā gatāya
translated: The wanderer Suppiya: Suppiya is his name. The syllable pi is used in the sense of one who is on the way.

original: puggalasampiṇḍanattho. Kho-kāro padasandhikaro, byañjanasiliṭṭhatāvasena vutto. Paribbājakoti🔽sañjayassa antevāsī channaparibbājako. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “yadā bhagavā taṃ addhānamaggaṃ
analyzed: puggala sampiṇḍana ttho khokāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ byañjana siliṭṭha tā vasena vutto paribbājakaḥ ti  sañjayassa antevāsī channa paribbājakaḥ idam vuttam hoti yadā bhagavā tam addhānamaggam
translated: It is a person-compounding word. The syllable kho is a word-connector, stated by way of the mode of letters.

original: paṭipanno, tadā suppiyopi paribbājako paṭipanno ahosī”ti. Atītakālattho hettha hoti-saddo.
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ tadā suppiyaḥ api paribbājakaḥ paṭipannaḥ ahosi iti atīta kāla atthaḥ ha ittha hoti saddo
translated: The wanderer: the wanderer Channa, a pupil of Sañjaya. This is what is meant: “When the Blessed One was travelling along that road, then the wanderer Suppiya was also travelling along it.” The word hoti here has the meaning of past time.

original: Saddhiṃ antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavenāti – ettha ante vasatīti antevāsī. Samīpacāro
analyzed: saddhim antevāsinā brahmadattena māṇavena ati ettha ante vasati iti antevāsī samīpa cāro
translated: Together with the brahmin student Brahmadatta, his pupil: here, he lives near (ante vasati), thus he is a pupil (antevāsi). He is a companion (samīpacāra),

original: santikāvacaro sissoti attho. Brahmadattoti tassa nāmaṃ. Māṇavoti sattopi coropi taruṇopi vuccati.
analyzed: santika avacaro sisso ti attho brahmadatto ti tassa nāmam māṇavo ti sattaḥ api coraḥ api taruṇaḥ pi vuccati
translated: a follower (santikāvacara), a disciple (sissa), is the meaning. Brahmadatta is his name. Student (māṇava) is said of a fool, a thief, and a youth.🔽“Those students who are heedless,

original: “Coditā devadūtehi, ye pamajjanti māṇavā;
analyzed: coditāḥ deva dūtehi ye pamajjanti māṇavā
translated: Though warned by the gods’ messengers,

original: Te dīgharattaṃ socanti, hīnakāyūpagā narā”ti. –
analyzed: te dīgharattam socanti hīna kāyu upagāḥ
translated: For a long time they grieve, those men who have gone to a lowly rebirth.”🔽For in the beginning a being (satta) is called a student. In such passages as:

original: Ādīsu hi satto māṇavoti vutto. “Māṇavehipi samāgacchanti katakammehipi akatakammehipī”tiādīsu
analyzed: ādīsu hi sattaḥ māṇavaḥ ti vuttaḥ māṇavehi pi samāgacchanti kata kammehi pi a kata kammehi pi iti ādīsu
translated: “They come together with students, with those who have done their duty, and with those who have not done their duty,”

original: coro. “Ambaṭṭho māṇavo, aṅgako māṇavo”tiādīsu taruṇo ‘māṇavo’ti vutto. Idhāpi ayamevattho.
analyzed: coraḥ ambaṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ aṅgakaḥ māṇavaḥ ti ādīsu taruṇaḥ māṇavaḥ ti vuttaḥ idha api ayam eva attho
translated: “Ambattha the student, Angaka the student” , etc., a young man is called a student. Here too the meaning is the same.

original: Idañhi vuttaṃ hoti – brahmadattena nāma taruṇantevāsinā saddhinti.
analyzed: idam hi vuttam hoti brahmadattena nāma taruṇa antevāsinā saddhinti
translated: For this is said: “with a young man named Brahmadatta who was a pupil of his.”

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ addhānamagge, tesu vā dvīsu janesu. Sudanti nipātamattaṃ. Anekapariyāyenāti🔽pariyāya-saddo tāva vāradesanākāraṇesu vattati. “Kassa nu kho, ānanda, ajja pariyāyo🔽bhikkhuniyo ovaditu”ntiādīsu hi vāre pariyāyasaddo vattati. “Madhupiṇḍikapariyāyotveva
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin addhāna magge tesu vā dvīsu janesu su danti nipāta mattam aneka pariyāyena ati  pariyāya saddo tāva vāradesanā kāraṇesu vattati kassa nu kho ānanda ajja pariyāyaḥ  bhikkhuniyaḥ ovaditum ti ādīsu hi vāre pariyāya saddo vattati
translated: There: on that road, or in the case of those two men. Sud: this is merely a particle. By many a line of reasoning:🔽the word pariyāya occurs in the sense of turn, teaching, and reason. For in such passages as “Ānanda, whose turn is it today to advise the bhikkhunīs?” ,

original: naṃ dhārehī”tiādīsu desanāyaṃ. “Imināpi kho, te rājañña, pariyāyena evaṃ hotū”tiādīsu
analyzed: nam dhārehi itiādīsu iminā api kho te rājañña pariyāyena evam hotu utiādīsu
translated: the word pariyāya occurs in the sense of turn. In such passages as “You should remember it as the Honeyball Advice” , it is in the sense of teaching. In such passages as “In this way too, prince, you may know” ,

original: kāraṇe. Svāyamidhāpi kāraṇe vattati, tasmā ayamettha attho – “anekavidhena kāraṇenā”ti,
analyzed: kāraṇe su āyam idha api kāraṇe vattati tasmai ayam ettha atthaḥ anekavidhena kāraṇena ati
translated: it is in the sense of reason. And here too it occurs in the sense of reason, so this is the meaning here: “by many a line of reasoning,”

original: “bahūhi kāraṇehī”ti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: bahūhi kāraṇehi iti vuttam hoti
translated: “by many reasons.”

original: Buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti avaṇṇavirahitassa aparimāṇavaṇṇasamannāgatassāpi buddhassa🔽bhagavato – “yaṃ loke jātivuḍḍhesu kattabbaṃ abhivādanādisāmīcikammaṃ ‘sāmaggiraso’ti
analyzed: buddhassa avaṇṇam bhāsati iti avaṇṇa virahitassa aparimāṇa vaṇṇa samannāgatassa api buddhassa  bhagavataḥ yam loke jāti vuḍḍhesu kattabbam abhivādana ādi sāmīcikammam sāmaggi rasaḥ ti
translated: He speaks dispraise of the Enlightened One: of the Blessed One, who is free from dispraise, who is endowed with immeasurable praise,

original: vuccati, taṃ samaṇassa gotamassa natthi tasmā arasarūpo samaṇo gotamo, nibbhogo,
analyzed: vuccati tam samaṇassa gotamassa na atthi tasmai a rasa rūpaḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ nibbhogaḥ
translated: he says: “The proper conduct towards those who are senior in the world by age, etc., is called ‘the essence of concord.’ The recluse Gotama has none of that. Therefore the recluse Gotama is without essence, is empty-handed,

original: akiriyavādo, ucchedavādo, jegucchī, venayiko, tapassī, apagabbho. Natthi samaṇassa🔽gotamassa uttarimanussadhammo alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso. Takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo
analyzed: a kiriya vādaḥ uccheda vādaḥ jegucchī venayikaḥ tapassī a pagabbhaḥ na atthi samaṇassa  gotamassa uttari manussa dhammaḥ alam ariya ñāṇa dassana viseso samaṇo
translated: is a nihilist, is a destroyer, is contemptible, is a mortifier, is a do-nothing, is a eunuch. The recluse Gotama

original: gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ, sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ. Samaṇo gotamo na sabbaññū,
analyzed: gotamaḥ dhammam deseti vīmaṃsā anucaritam sayaṃpaṭibhānam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ na sabbaññū
translated: has no superhuman states, no distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. The recluse Gotama teaches a Dhamma hammered out by reasoning, following his own line of inquiry as it occurs to him. The recluse Gotama is not omniscient and all-seeing,

original: na lokavidū, na anuttaro, na aggapuggalo”ti. Evaṃ taṃ taṃ akāraṇameva kāraṇanti vatvā
analyzed: na loka vidū na anuttaraḥ na agga puggalaḥ ti evam tam tam akāraṇam eva kāraṇam ti vatvā
translated: he is not a Tathāgata, he is not the foremost man, he is not a teacher of men to be tamed.” Thus he speaks dispraise, speaks ill, speaks contemptuously,

original: tathā tathā avaṇṇaṃ dosaṃ nindaṃ bhāsati.
analyzed: tathā tathā avaṇṇam dosam nindam bhāsati
translated: saying this and that, though it is not so, as the reason.

original: Yathā ca buddhassa, evaṃ dhammassāpi taṃ taṃ akāraṇameva kāraṇato vatvā – “samaṇassa🔽gotamassa dhammo durakkhāto, duppaṭivedito, aniyyāniko, anupasamasaṃvattaniko”ti
analyzed: yathā ca buddhassa evam dhammassa api tam tam akāraṇam eva kāraṇataḥ vatvā samaṇassa  gotamassa dhammaḥ durakkhātaḥ duppaṭiveditaḥ a niyyānikaḥ an upasamasaṃvattanikaḥ ti
translated: And just as he does so with regard to the Enlightened One, so also with regard to the True Idea, he misrepresents some reason or other as a reason for saying: “The recluse Gotama’s True Idea is badly expounded, hard to see, hard to understand, beyond the sphere of reasoning, incomprehensible, intelligible only to the wise.

original: tathā tathā avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.🔽Yathā ca dhammassa, evaṃ saṅghassāpi yaṃ vā taṃ vā akāraṇameva kāraṇato vatvā – “micchāpaṭipanno
analyzed: tathā tathā avaṇṇam bhāsati  yathā ca dhammassa evam saṅghassa api yam vā tam vā akāraṇam eva kāraṇataḥ vatvā micchā paṭipannaḥ
translated: It is not expounded for the sake of abatement, for the sake of relinquishment, for the sake of ending, for the sake of stilling, for the sake of direct-knowledge, for the sake of full comprehension, for the sake of Emancipation, for the sake of extinction of cankers” .

original: samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakasaṅgho, kuṭilapaṭipanno, paccanīkapaṭipadaṃ ananulomapaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: samaṇassa gotamassa sāvaka saṅgho kuṭila paṭipanno paccanīka paṭipadam ananuloma paṭipadam
translated: And just as he does so with regard to the True Idea, so also with regard to the Community, he misrepresents some reason or other as a reason for saying: “The recluse Gotama’s community of disciples is practising the good way, is practising the straight way, is practising the true way, is practising the proper way;

translated: Now he would have to praise the Blessed One. But because of the loss of gain and honour and the loss of his own faction, he is jealous of the Blessed One even to this day. For as long as the Buddha does not appear in the world, so long do gains and honour accrue to the sectarians; but from the time of the Buddha’s appearance they lose their gains and honour and become destitute like the sun’s rays when the sun has risen. So for these two reasons the wanderer is jealous of the Blessed One even to this day. Therefore he should be understood as one who, emitting the venom of his jealousy, speaks only dispraise of the Three Jewels.

translated: Water in a puddle does not reach the water in a deep pool. Water in a deep pool does not reach the water in a river. Water in a river does not reach the water in the five great rivers. The water in a bowl is less than the water in the hand. … The water in the great ocean under the Himalayas is less than the water in the ocean surrounding the earth. Thus, taking the water above as less and the water below as more, it should be understood that the virtue below is less and the virtue above is more. Hence it was said: “But, bhikkhus, this virtue is trifling, slight, of no importance, of no significance” .

translated: They are “ordinary folk” because they are “many” in that they are many in body, many in speech, many in mind, many in defilements, many in evil-propensities, many in cankers, many in suffering, many in ideas, many in views, many in cravings, many in destinies, many in births. They are “ordinary folk” because they are “many” in that they are many in the various kinds of determinations they determine, in that they are carried away by the various kinds of floods, in that they are heated by the various kinds of heats, in that they are burnt by the various kinds of fires, in that they are attached, greedy, infatuated, obsessed, cleaving, cleaving to, cleaving closely to, the five cords of sense desire. They are “ordinary folk” because they are “many” in that they are enveloped, covered, overspread, overhung, beset, obstructed, obstructed and beset by the five hindrances. They are “ordinary folk” because they are included among the “many” who have passed beyond count, who have turned their backs on the noble truth of suffering, who behave in a way befitting those in the underworld. They are “ordinary folk” because they are “many” in that they are reckoned separately, in that they are not in communion with the noble ones who are possessed of virtue, learning, etc.

original: ariyehi janehīti puthujjanoti.

original: tathā amhākampi bhagavā āgato. Evaṃ tathā āgatoti tathāgato.
analyzed: tathā amhākam pi bhagavā āgataḥ evam tathā āgataḥ iti tathāgataḥ
translated: and having made them familiar, came; so too has our Blessed One come. Thus he has come in such a way; therefore he is the Tathāgata.

original: “Yatheva lokamhi vipassiādayo,
analyzed: yathā iva lokamhi vipassi ādayo
translated: “Just as Vipassī and the rest came in the world,

original: Sabbaññubhāvaṃ munayo idhāgatā;
analyzed: sabbaññu bhāvam munayaḥ idha āgatāḥ
translated: The sages who have come here are the same in their all-knowingness;

original: Tathā ayaṃ sakyamunīpi āgato,
analyzed: tathā ayam āgataḥ
translated: So has this Sage of the Sakyans come;

original: Tathāgato vuccati tena cakkhumā”ti.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ vuccati tena cakkhumā ti
translated: Therefore he is called the Enlightened One, the Visionary.

original: Evaṃ tathā āgatoti tathāgato.🔽Kathaṃ tathā gatoti tathāgato? Yathā sampatijāto vipassī bhagavā gato…pe… kassapo bhagavā gato.
analyzed: evam tathā āgataḥ iti tathāgataḥ  katham tathā gataḥ iti tathāgataḥ yathā sampati jātaḥ vipassī bhagavā gata upe kassapaḥ bhagavā gataḥ
translated: So he is the Tathāgata in the sense of come thus.

original: Kathañca so bhagavā gato? So hi sampati jātova samehi pādehi pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya🔽uttarābhimukho sattapadavītihārena gato. Yathāha – “sampatijāto kho, ānanda, bodhisatto
analyzed: kathañca saḥ bhagavā gataḥ saḥ hi sampati jātaḥ uva samehi pādehi pathaviyam patiṭṭhāya  uttara abhimukhaḥ satta padavī tihārena gataḥ yathā āha sampatijātaḥ kho ānanda bodhisatto
translated: How is he the Tathāgata in the sense of gone thus? As Vipassī, as Sikhī, as Vessabhū, as Kakusandha, as Koṇāgamana, as Kassapa, the Blessed One, has gone, so has this Blessed One gone.

original: samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahitvā uttarābhimukho sattapadavītihārena gacchati, setamhi
analyzed: samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahitvā uttara abhimukhaḥ satta padavī tihārena gacchati setamhi
translated: And how has he gone? As soon as he was born, he stood with his feet planted firmly on the ground,

original: chatte anudhāriyamāne sabbā ca disā anuviloketi, āsabhiṃ vācaṃ bhāsati – ‘aggohamasmi
analyzed: chatte anudhāriyamāne sabbā ca disāḥ anuviloketi āsabhim vācam bhāsati aggaḥ ham asmi
translated: and after surveying all the four quarters, he took seven strides and said:🔽“I am the chief in the world, supreme in the world, eldest in the world.

original: lokassa, jeṭṭhohamasmi lokassa, seṭṭhohamasmi lokassa, ayamantimā jāti, natthidāni punabbhavo’ti”.
analyzed: lokassa jeṭṭhaḥ uham asmi lokassa seṭṭhaḥ uham asmi lokassa ayam antimā jāti natthi idāni punabbhavoti
translated: This is my last birth, now there is no renewal of being for me.”

original: Tañcassa gamanaṃ tathaṃ ahosi? Avitathaṃ anekesaṃ visesādhigamānaṃ pubbanimittabhāvena.
analyzed: tat cassa gamanam tatham ahosi avitatham anekesam visesa adhigamānam pubba nimitta bhāvena
translated: And was that going of his in accordance with the truth? It was in accordance with the truth in the sense of being a premonition of the attainment of many special qualities.

original: Yañhi so sampatijātova samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahi. Idamassa caturiddhipādapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: yat hi saḥ sampati jātaḥ iva samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahi idam assa catur iddhipāda paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam
translated: For when he stood firm with feet placed evenly on the ground, this was a premonition of his acquisition of the four bases for spiritual success .

original: Uttarābhimukhabhāvo pana sabbalokuttarabhāvassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: uttara abhimukha bhāvaḥ pana sabba lokuttara bhāvassa pubba nimittam
translated: And his facing north was a premonition of his becoming the chief in the whole world.

original: Sattapadavītihāro, sattabojjhaṅgaratanapaṭilābhassa.
analyzed: satta padavī tihāro satta bojjhaṅga ratana paṭilābhassa
translated: His taking seven strides was a premonition of his acquisition of the seven gems of enlightenment.

original: “Suvaṇṇadaṇḍā vītipatanti cāmarā”ti, ettha vuttacāmarukkhepo pana sabbatitthiyanimmaddanassa.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa daṇḍāḥ vītipatanti cāmarā ti ettha vutta cāmara ukkhepaḥ pana sabba titthiya nimmaddanassa
translated: And the shaking of the Cāmara trees mentioned in the passage, “The Cāmara trees waved their crests for him” , was a premonition of his overthrow of all the opponents’ doctrines.

original: Setacchattadhāraṇaṃ, arahattavimuttivaravimalasetacchattapaṭilābhassa.🔽Sattamapadūpari ṭhatvā sabbadisānuvilokanaṃ, sabbaññutānāvaraṇañāṇapaṭilābhassa.
analyzed: setacchatta dhāraṇam  sattama pada upari sabba disā anuvilokanam sabbaññu tā anāvaraṇa ñāṇa paṭilābhassa
translated: His holding up the white parasol was a premonition of his acquisition of the supreme taintless liberation, which is like a white parasol.🔽His surveying all the directions after standing on the seventh step was a premonition of his acquisition of the unobstructed knowledge of omniscience.

original: Āsabhivācābhāsanaṃ appaṭivattiyavaradhammacakkappavattanassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: āsa abhivācā bhāsanam appaṭivattiya vara dhamma cakka ppavattanassa pubba nimittam
translated: And his utterance of the words, “In the east and west, in the north and south, above and below, I am the chief” , was a premonition of his setting in motion the supreme, irreversible wheel of the Dhamma.

original: Tathā ayaṃ bhagavāpi gato, tañcassa gamanaṃ tathaṃ ahosi, avitathaṃ, tesaṃyeva visesādhigamānaṃ pubbanimittabhāvena.
analyzed: tathā ayam bhagavā api gataḥ tat cassa gamanam tatham ahosi avitatham tesam yeva visesa adhigamānam pubba nimitta bhāvena
translated: And so did the Blessed One go, and that going of his was true, not otherwise, in that it was a sign of the attainment of the distinction of those who had gone before.

original: Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: tena āhu porāṇā
translated: Hence the ancients said:

original: “Muhuttajātova gavampatī yathā,
analyzed: muhutta jātā uva gavampatī yathā
translated: “As soon as he was born, the Lord of the Sages,

original: Samehi pādehi phusī vasundharaṃ;

original: So vikkamī satta padāni gotamo,
analyzed: saḥ vikkamī satta padāni gotamaḥ
translated: Took seven steps, and the Maruts

original: Setañca chattaṃ anudhārayuṃ marū.
analyzed: setañca chattam anudhārayum marū
translated: Held up a white parasol.

original: Gantvāna so satta padāni gotamo,🔽Disā vilokesi samā samantato;
analyzed: gantvāna saḥ satta padāni gotamaḥ  disā vilokesi samā samantataḥ
translated: Having gone seven steps, the Lord of the Sages,🔽Surveyed the four quarters all around,

original: Aṭṭhaṅgupetaṃ giramabbhudīrayi,
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅga upetam
translated: And uttered a lion’s roar,

original: Sīho yathā pabbatamuddhaniṭṭhito”ti.
analyzed: sīhaḥ yathā pabbata muddha niṭṭhito ti

original: Evaṃ tathā gatoti tathāgato.

translated: So he is the Tathāgata because he has gone in the same way.

analyzed: atha vā yathā vipassī bhagavā āpe yathā kassapaḥ bhagavā ayam pi bhagavā tathā iva nekkhammena  kāma chandam pahāya gataḥ a byāpādena byāpādam āloka saññāya thinam iddham a vikkhepena
translated: Or alternatively, just as the Blessed One Vipassī, … just as the Blessed One Kassapa, so too has this Blessed One gone forth from the home life into homelessness with the going forth of those who have gone,🔽with the going forth of those who are going forth, with the going forth of those who will go forth, with the going forth of those who are worthy of going forth, with the going forth of those who are noble ones’ fields of action, with the going forth of those who are the supreme field of merit for the world.

analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam dhamma vavatthānena vicikiccham pahāya ñāṇena avijjam padāletvā
translated: He has gone by means of non-greed, abandoning greed, by means of non-hate, abandoning hate, by means of non-delusion, abandoning delusion, by means of non-covetousness, abandoning covetousness, by means of non-ill will, abandoning ill will, by means of right view, abandoning wrong view, by means of the first jhāna, abandoning sense desire and ill will, by means of the second jhāna, abandoning initial and sustained application of mind, by means of the third jhāna, abandoning rapture, by means of the fourth jhāna, abandoning in-and-out breathing, by means of the base of infinite space, abandoning the form element, by means of the base of infinite consciousness, abandoning the base of infinite space, by means of the base of nothingness, abandoning the base of infinite consciousness, by means of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, abandoning the base of nothingness, by means of the cessation of perception and feeling, abandoning the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, by means of the fruit of stream-entry, abandoning the fetter of uncertainty, by means of the fruit of once-return, abandoning the fetter

analyzed: pāmojjena aratim vinodetvā paṭhama jhānena nīvaraṇa kavāṭam ugghāṭetvā dutiya jhānena

analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana samāpattiyāḥ ākāsānañcāyatana saññaṃ ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattiyāḥ viññāṇañcāyatana saññaṃ

analyzed: nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattiyāḥ ākiñcaññāyatana saññam samatikkamitvā gataḥ  anicca anupassanāya nicca saññam pahāya dukkha anupassanāya sukha saññam anatta anupassanāya

analyzed: atta saññam nibbida anupassanāya nandim virāga anupassanāya rāgam nirodha anupassanāya

analyzed: samudayam paṭinissagga anupassanāya ādānam khaya anupassanāya ghana saññam vayā anupassanāya
