original: āyūhanaṃ, vipariṇāmānupassanāya dhuvasaññaṃ, animittānupassanāya nimittaṃ, appaṇihitānupassanāya
analyzed: āyūhanam vipariṇāma anupassanāya dhuva saññam animitta anupassanāya nimittam appaṇihita anupassanāya
translated: By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to change he has gone by abandoning the perception of self.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to cankers he has gone by abandoning the perception of health.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to death he has gone by abandoning the perception of permanence.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to sorrow he has gone by abandoning the perception of ease.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to defilement he has gone by abandoning the perception of purity.

original: paṇidhiṃ, suññatānupassanāya abhinivesaṃ, adhipaññādhammavipassanāya sārādānābhinivesaṃ,🔽yathābhūtañāṇadassanena sammohābhinivesaṃ, ādīnavānupassanāya ālayābhinivesaṃ, paṭisaṅkhānupassanāya
analyzed: paṇidhim suññatā anupassanāya abhinivesam adhi paññā dhamma vipassanāya sāra ādāna abhinivesam  yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanena sammoha abhinivesam ādīnava anupassanāya ālaya abhinivesam paṭisaṅkhā anupassanāya
translated: By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to birth he has gone by abandoning the perception of being.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to cankers he has gone by abandoning the perception of pleasure.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to death he has gone by abandoning the perception of permanence.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to sorrow he has gone by abandoning the perception of ease.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to defilement he has gone by abandoning the perception of purity.

original: appaṭisaṅkhaṃ, vivaṭṭānupassanāya saṃyogābhinivesaṃ, sotāpattimaggena diṭṭhekaṭṭhe🔽kilese bhañjitvā, sakadāgāmimaggena oḷārike kilese pahāya, anāgāmimaggena aṇusahagate
analyzed: appaṭisaṅkham vivaṭṭa anupassanāya saṃyoga abhinivesam sotāpatti maggena diṭṭhekaṭṭhe  kilese bhañjitvā sakadāgāmi maggena oḷārike kilese pahāya anāgāmi maggena aṇu sahagate
translated: By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to birth he has gone by abandoning the perception of being.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to cankers he has gone by abandoning the perception of pleasure.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to death he has gone by abandoning the perception of permanence.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to sorrow he has gone by abandoning the perception of ease.

original: kilese samugghāṭetvā, arahattamaggena sabbakilese samucchinditvā gato. Evampi tathā gatoti tathāgato.
analyzed: kilese samugghāṭetvā arahatta maggena sabba kilese samucchinditvā gataḥ evam pi tathā gataḥ iti tathāgataḥ
translated: By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject to defilement he has gone by abandoning the perception of purity.🔽By contemplation of the sixfold base as a phenomenon subject

original: Kathaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato?Pathavīdhātuyā kakkhaḷattalakkhaṇaṃ tathaṃ
analyzed: katham tatha lakkhaṇam āgato ti tathāgata upathavī dhātuyā kakkhaḷatta lakkhaṇam tatham
translated: How has he come to the state of such a specific characteristic? He has come to the state of the specific characteristic of the earth element as hardness,

original: avitathaṃ. Āpodhātuyā paggharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Tejodhātuyā uṇhattalakkhaṇaṃ. Vāyodhātuyā
analyzed: avitatham āpaḥ dhātuyā paggharaṇa lakkhaṇam tejaḥ dhātuyā uṇhatta lakkhaṇam vāyo dhātuyā
translated: of the water element as cohesion, of the fire element as caloricity, of the air element as mobility,

original: vitthambhanalakkhaṇaṃ. Ākāsadhātuyā asamphuṭṭhalakkhaṇaṃ. Viññāṇadhātuyā vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: vitthambhana lakkhaṇam ākāsa dhātuyā asamphuṭṭha lakkhaṇam viññāṇa dhātuyā vijānana lakkhaṇam
translated: of the space element as invisibility, of consciousness as cognizing.

original: Rūpassa ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vedanāya vedayitalakkhaṇaṃ. Saññāya sañjānanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Viññāṇassa vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: rūpassa ruppana lakkhaṇam vedanāya vedayita lakkhaṇam saññāya sañjānana lakkhaṇam saṅkhārānam abhisaṅkharaṇa lakkhaṇam viññāṇassa vijānana lakkhaṇam
translated: He has come to the state of the specific characteristic of material form as deformation, of feeling as the act of being felt, of perception as perceiving, of formations as forming, of consciousness as cognizing.

original: Vitakkassa abhiniropanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vicārassa anumajjanalakkhaṇaṃ pītiyā pharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Sukhassa sātalakkhaṇaṃ. Cittekaggatāya avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Phassassa phusanalakkhaṇaṃ.

translated: He has come to the state of the specific characteristic of applied thought as adverting, of sustained thought as pressing, of happiness as exhilaration, of bliss as soothing, of concentration as non- distraction, of contact as touching.

original: Saddhindriyassa adhimokkhalakkhaṇaṃ. Vīriyindriyassa paggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Satindriyassa upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Samādhindriyassa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Paññindriyassa pajānanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: saddhi indriyassa adhimokkha lakkhaṇam vīriya indriyassa paggaha lakkhaṇam sati indriyassa upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇam samādhi indriyassa avikkhepa lakkhaṇam paññindriyassa pajānana lakkhaṇam
translated: The faculty of faith has the characteristic of resolution. The faculty of energy has the characteristic of exerting. The faculty of mindfulness has the characteristic of establishing. The faculty of concentration has the characteristic of non-distraction. The faculty of wisdom has the characteristic of understanding.

original: Saddhābalassa assaddhiye akampiyalakkhaṇaṃ. Vīriyabalassa kosajje, satibalassa muṭṭhassacce. Samādhibalassa uddhacce, paññābalassa avijjāya akampiyalakkhaṇaṃ.

translated: The power of faith has the characteristic of unshakability by non-faith. The power of energy has the characteristic of unshakability by indolence. The power of mindfulness has the characteristic of unshakability by forgetfulness. The power of concentration has the characteristic of unshakability by agitation. The power of wisdom has the characteristic of unshakability by ignorance.

analyzed: vīriya sambojjhaṅgassa paggaha lakkhaṇam pīti sambojjhaṅgassa pharaṇa lakkhaṇam passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa

translated: tranquillity. The concentration factor of complete awakening has the characteristic of non-distraction. The equanimity factor of complete awakening has the characteristic of

original: paṭisaṅkhānalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhāna lakkhaṇam
translated: reflection.

original: Sammādiṭṭhiyā dassanalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsaṅkappassa abhiniropanalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāvācāya
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ dassana lakkhaṇam sammāsaṅkappassa abhiniropana lakkhaṇam sammāvācāya
translated: Right view has the characteristic of seeing. Right thought has the characteristic of directing onto. Right speech has the characteristic of delimitation.

original: pariggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammākammantassa samuṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāājīvassa vodānalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pariggaha lakkhaṇam sammākammantassa samuṭṭhāna lakkhaṇam sammāājīvassa vodāna lakkhaṇam
translated: Right action has the characteristic of originating. Right livelihood has the characteristic of cleansing.

original: Sammāvāyāmassa paggahalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsatiyā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ. Sammāsamādhissa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sammāvāyāmassa paggaha lakkhaṇam sammā satiyāḥ upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇam sammā samādhissa avikkhepa lakkhaṇam
translated: Right effort has the characteristic of exerting. Right mindfulness has the characteristic of establishing. Right concentration has the characteristic of non-distraction.

original: Avijjāya aññāṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Saṅkhārānaṃ cetanālakkhaṇaṃ. Viññāṇassa vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: avijjāya aññāṇa lakkhaṇam saṅkhārānam cetanā lakkhaṇam viññāṇassa vijānana lakkhaṇam
translated: Ignorance has the characteristic of non-penetration. Formations have the characteristic of accumulating. Consciousness has the characteristic of cognizing.

original: Nāmassa namanalakkhaṇaṃ. Rūpassa ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ. Saḷāyatanassa āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: nāmassa namana lakkhaṇam rūpassa ruppana lakkhaṇam saḷāyatanassa āyatana lakkhaṇam
translated: Mentality has the characteristic of bending. Materiality has the characteristic of being molested. The sixfold base has the characteristic of stationing.

original: Phassassa phusanalakkhaṇaṃ. Vedanāya vedayitalakkhaṇaṃ. Taṇhāya hetulakkhaṇaṃ. Upādānassa
analyzed: phassassa phusana lakkhaṇam vedanāya vedayita lakkhaṇam taṇhāya hetu lakkhaṇam upādānassa
translated: Contact has the characteristic of touching. Feeling has the characteristic of being felt. Craving has the characteristic of cleaving. Clinging has the characteristic of grasping.

original: gahaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Bhavassa āyūhanalakkhaṇaṃ. Jātiyā nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ. Jarāya jīraṇalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: gahaṇa lakkhaṇam bhavassa āyūhana lakkhaṇam jātiyāḥ nibbatti lakkhaṇam jarāya jīraṇa lakkhaṇam
translated: Becoming has the characteristic of accumulating. Birth has the characteristic of causing to be born. Ageing has the characteristic of causing to age.

original: Maraṇassa cutilakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: maraṇassa cuti lakkhaṇam
translated: Death has the characteristic of causing to die.

original: Dhātūnaṃ suññatālakkhaṇaṃ. Āyatanānaṃ āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ. Satipaṭṭhānānaṃ upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇaṃ.🔽Sammappadhānānaṃ padahanalakkhaṇaṃ. Iddhipādānaṃ ijjhanalakkhaṇaṃ. Indriyānaṃ adhipatilakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dhātūnam suñña tā lakkhaṇam āyatanānam āyatana lakkhaṇam sati paṭṭhānānam upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇam  sammappadhānānam padahana lakkhaṇam iddhipādānam ijjhana lakkhaṇam indriyānam adhipati lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the elements is voidness. The characteristic of the sense bases is their domain. The characteristic of the foundations of mindfulness is their domain.🔽The characteristic of the right efforts is their exertion. The characteristic of the bases of success is their success. The characteristic of the faculties is their predominance.

original: Balānaṃ akampiyalakkhaṇaṃ. Bojjhaṅgānaṃ niyyānalakkhaṇaṃ. Maggassa hetulakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: balānaṃ akampiya lakkhaṇam bojjhaṅgānaṃ niyyāna lakkhaṇam maggassa hetu lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the powers is their unshakability. The characteristic of the factors of awakening is their penetration. The characteristic of the path is its conditionality.

original: Saccānaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ. Samathassa avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Vipassanāya anupassanālakkhaṇaṃ. Samathavipassanānaṃ ekarasalakkhaṇaṃ. Yuganaddhānaṃ anativattanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: saccānam tatha lakkhaṇam samathassa avikkhepa lakkhaṇam vipassanāya anupassanā lakkhaṇam samatha vipassanānam eka rasa lakkhaṇam yuga naddhānam an ativattana lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the truths is their reality. The characteristic of serenity is non-distraction. The characteristic of insight is its contemplation. The characteristic of serenity and insight is their single taste. The characteristic of yoking them is their non-excess.

original: Sīlavisuddhiyā saṃvaralakkhaṇaṃ. Cittavisuddhiyā avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ. Diṭṭhivisuddhiyā dassanalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sīla visuddhiyā saṃvara lakkhaṇam citta visuddhiyā avikkhepa lakkhaṇam diṭṭhi visuddhiyā dassana lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of purification of virtue is restraint. The characteristic of purification of mind is non-distraction. The characteristic of purification of view is seeing.

original: Khaye ñāṇassa samucchedanalakkhaṇaṃ. Anuppāde ñāṇassa passaddhilakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: khaye ñāṇassa samucchedana lakkhaṇam anuppāde ñāṇassa passaddhi lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of knowledge of destruction is its cutting off. The characteristic of knowledge of non-arising is its peacefulness.

original: Chandassa mūlalakkhaṇaṃ. Manasikārassa samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇaṃ. Phassassa samodhānalakkhaṇaṃ.🔽Vedanāya samosaraṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Samādhissa pamukhalakkhaṇaṃ. Satiyā ādhipateyyalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: chandassa mūla lakkhaṇam manasikārassa samuṭṭhāpana lakkhaṇam phassassa samodhāna lakkhaṇam  vedanāya samosaraṇa lakkhaṇam samādhissa pamukha lakkhaṇam satiyāḥ ādhipateyya lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of will is its being the root. The characteristic of attention is its being the source. The characteristic of contact is its being the meeting-place.🔽The characteristic of feeling is its being the convergence. The characteristic of concentration is its being the fore-front. The characteristic of mindfulness is its being the overseer.

original: Paññāya tatuttariyalakkhaṇaṃ. Vimuttiyā sāralakkhaṇaṃ… amatogadhassa nibbānassa pariyosānalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: paññāya tatuttariya lakkhaṇam vimuttiyā sāra lakkhaṇam amatogadhassa nibbānassa pariyosāna lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of understanding is its being the guide. The characteristic of deliverance is its being the essence. The characteristic of Nibbāna, which is the culmination of the deathless, is its being the goal.

original: tathaṃ avitathaṃ. Evaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ ñāṇagatiyā āgato avirajjhitvā patto anuppattoti
analyzed: tatham avitatham evam tatha lakkhaṇam ñāṇa gatiyā āgataḥ a virajjhitvā pattaḥ anuppatto ti
translated: It is thus, not otherwise, that the Realised One has come to the knowledge of the characteristics of dhammas, without attachment, attained, dwelt in, and reached.

original: tathāgato. Evaṃ tathalakkhaṇaṃ āgatoti tathāgato.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ evam tatha lakkhaṇam āgataḥ ti tathāgataḥ
translated: Thus he is the Realised One because he has come to the knowledge of the characteristics of dhammas.

original: Kathaṃ tathadhamme yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato? Tathadhammā nāma cattāri
analyzed: katham tathadhamme yāthāvataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ ti tathāgato tathadhammā nāma cattāri
translated: How is he the Realised One because he has fully awakened to the real nature of dhammas? The real nature of dhammas is the four noble truths.

original: ariyasaccāni. Yathāha – “cattārimāni, bhikkhave, tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni.
analyzed: ariya saccāni yathā āha cattāri imāni bhikkhave tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni
translated: As it is said: “There are these four real natures, bhikkhus, which are not unreal, which are not otherwise.

original: Katamāni cattāri? ‘Idaṃ dukkha’nti bhikkhave, tathametaṃ avitathametaṃ anaññathameta”nti
analyzed: katamāni cattāri idam dukkhanti bhikkhave tatham etam avitatham etam anaññatham etam ti
translated: What are the four? ‘This is suffering’ is real, bhikkhus, it is not unreal, it is not otherwise.

original: vitthāro. Tāni ca bhagavā abhisambuddho, tasmā tathānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhisambuddhattā
analyzed: vitthāraḥ tāni ca bhagavā abhisambuddhaḥ tasmā tathānam dhammānam abhisambuddha ttā
translated: and the detailed explanation. And the Blessed One has awakened to these things, thus

original: tathāgatoti vuccati. Abhisambuddhattho hettha gatasaddo.
analyzed: tathāgato ti vuccati abhisambuddha atthaḥ ha ittha gata saddo
translated: he is called the Tathāgata because of his awakening to these things. The word “gone” has the sense of “awakened” here.

original: Api ca jarāmaraṇassa jātipaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho…pe…,
analyzed: api ca jarā maraṇassa jāti paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭho tathaḥ avitathaḥ anaññathā upe
translated: Moreover, the meaning of “arisen” and “come about” through the condition of birth as the source of aging-and-death is “thus,” not otherwise, not different, …

original: saṅkhārānaṃ avijjāpaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho…pe…, tathā🔽avijjāya saṅkhārānaṃ paccayaṭṭho, saṅkhārānaṃ viññāṇassa paccayaṭṭho…pe…, jātiyā
analyzed: saṅkhārānaṃ avijjā paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭhaḥ tathaḥ avitathaḥ anaññathā upe tathā  avijjāya saṅkhārānam paccaya ṭṭho saṅkhārānam viññāṇassa paccaya ṭṭho upe jātiyā
translated: the meaning of “arisen” and “come about” through the condition of ignorance as the source of formations is “thus,” not otherwise, not different, …

original: jarāmaraṇassa paccayaṭṭho tatho avitatho anaññatho. Taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavā abhisambuddho,
analyzed: jarā maraṇassa paccaya ṭṭho tathaḥ avitathaḥ anaññathaḥ tam sabbam bhagavā abhisambuddhaḥ
translated: the meaning of the condition of ignorance for formations, the meaning of the condition of formations for consciousness, … the meaning of the condition of birth for aging-and-death is “thus,” not otherwise, not different. The Blessed One has awakened to all that,

original: tasmāpi tathānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhisambuddhattā tathāgatoti vuccati. Evaṃ tathadhamme
analyzed: tasmā api tathānam dhammānam abhisambuddha ttā tathāgataḥ ti vuccati evam tatha dhamme
translated: thus he is called the Tathāgata because of his awakening to these things. So he is the Tathāgata because he has awakened to things as they really are

original: yāthāvato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato.
analyzed: yāthāvataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ iti tathāgataḥ
translated: in accordance with actuality.

original: Kathaṃ tathadassitāya tathāgato? Bhagavā yaṃ sadevake loke…pe…, sadevamanussāya pajāya
analyzed: katham tatha dassitāya tathāgataḥ bhagavā yam sa devake lokepe sa deva manussāya pajāya
translated: How is he the Tathāgata because of his seeing in accordance with actuality? The Blessed One has seen that whatever is of the nature to arise, all that is of the nature to stop, in this world together with its gods, its Māras and its Brahmās, this generation with its religieux and brahmans, with its gods and men.

original: aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ cakkhudvāre āpāthamāgacchantaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ🔽nāma atthi, taṃ sabbākārato jānāti passati. Evaṃ jānatā passatā ca, tena taṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhādivasena
analyzed: aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam cakkhu dvāre āpātham āgacchantam rūpa ārammaṇam  nāma atthi tam sabba ākārataḥ jānāti passati evam jānatā passatā ca tena tam iṭṭha aniṭṭha ādi vasena
translated: There is visible-data object that comes into the eye door’s focus in countless world systems among countless beings.🔽He knows and sees that in all its aspects. And when he knows and sees it thus,🔽then it is either as desirable, undesirable, and so on, or else as the words that can be used about what is seen, heard, sensed, or cognized.

original: vā diṭṭhasutamutaviññātesu labbhamānakapadavasena vā. “Katamaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ?
analyzed: vā diṭṭha suta muta viññātesu labbhamānaka pada vasena vā katamam tam rūpam rūpa āyatanam
translated: “What is that materiality which is the visible-data base?

original: Yaṃ rūpaṃ catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya vaṇṇanibhā sanidassanaṃ sappaṭighaṃ nīlaṃ
analyzed: yam rūpam catunnam mahābhūtānam upādāya vaṇṇa nibhā sa nidassanam sa paṭigham nīlam
translated: That materiality derived from the four primary elements which has colour and is visible, has resistance, is blue,

original: pītaka”ntiādinā nayena anekehi nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvepaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānaṃ
analyzed: pītakanti ādinā nayena anekehi nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvepaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānam
translated: yellow … ” and so on, and in the thirteen ways, and in the fifty-two ways,

original: tathameva hoti, vitathaṃ natthi. Esa nayo sotadvārādīsupi āpāthaṃ āgacchantesu saddādīsu.
analyzed: tatham eva hoti vitatham natthi āpātham āgacchantesu sadda ādīsu
translated: it is just as he has analyzed it, not otherwise. So too with the sound, etc., that come into focus in the ear door, and so on.

original: Vuttañcetaṃ bhagavatā – “yaṃ bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa…pe… sadevamanussāya pajāya
analyzed: vuttam ca itam bhagavatā yam bhikkhave sa devakassa lokassa pe sa deva manussāya pajāya
translated: And this is said by the Blessed One: “Bhikkhus, whatever in this world … with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmans,

original: diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ jānāmi.
analyzed: diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam pattam pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā tam aham jānāmi
translated: I know what is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, attained, sought after, pondered by the mind.

original: Tamahaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, taṃ tathāgatassa viditaṃ, taṃ tathāgato na upaṭṭhāsī”ti. Evaṃ
analyzed: tam aham abbhaññāsim tam tathāgatassa viditam tam tathāgataḥ na upaṭṭhāsi iti evam
translated: I have directly known that, the Tathāgata has understood that, the Tathāgata has developed that, therefore he is called the Tathāgata.’

original: tathadassitāya tathāgato. Tattha tathadassī atthe tathāgatoti padasambhavo veditabbo.
analyzed: tathā dassitāya tathāgato tattha tathā dassī atthe tathāgato ti pada sambhavaḥ veditabbo
translated: Thus he is the Tathāgata because of seeing thus. Herein, the derivation of the word should be understood in this way: he is the Tathāgata because he is a seer of what is actually so .

original: Kathaṃ tathavāditāya tathāgato? Yaṃ rattiṃ bhagavā bodhimaṇḍe aparājitapallaṅke nisinno🔽tiṇṇaṃ mārānaṃ matthakaṃ madditvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho, yañca rattiṃ
analyzed: katham tathavāditāya tathāgataḥ yam rattim bhagavā bodhimaṇḍe aparājita pallaṅke nisinnaḥ  tiṇṇam mārānam matthakam madditvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ yañca rattim
translated: How is he the Tathāgata because of speaking thus? On the night when the Blessed One, sitting in the invincible seat of enlightenment,

original: yamakasālānamantare anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi, etthantare pañcacattālīsavassaparimāṇe
analyzed: yamaka sālānam antare anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi ettha antare pañcacattālīsa vassa parimāṇe
translated: after crushing the head of Māra’s army, reached the supreme full enlightenment, and on the night when he attained final Nibbāna in the Nibbāna-element without residue of clinging, in the interval of fifty years’ duration,

original: kāle paṭhamabodhiyāpi majjhimabodhiyāpi pacchimabodhiyāpi yaṃ bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ
analyzed: kāle majjhima bodhiyā api pacchima bodhiyā api yam bhagavatā bhāsitam
translated: whether he was teaching the first, middle, or last part of the Teaching,

original: – suttaṃ, geyyaṃ…pe… vedallaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ atthato ca byañjanato ca anupavajjaṃ, anūnamanadhikaṃ,
analyzed: suttam geyyam pe vedallam tat sabbam atthataḥ ca byañjanataḥ ca anupavajjam anūnam anadhikam
translated: The discourses, mixed prose and verse, expositions, verses, inspired utterances, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and questions-and-answers: all of them are faultless in terms of meaning and phrasing, neither deficient nor in excess.

original: sabbākāraparipuṇṇaṃ, rāgamadanimmadanaṃ, dosamohamadanimmadanaṃ. Natthi tattha vālaggamattampi
analyzed: sabba ākāra paripuṇṇam rāga mada nimmadanam dosa moha mada nimmadanam natthi tattha vā ālagga mattam pi
translated: They are complete in every aspect, and they crush passion, hatred, and delusion. There is not even an amount as small as the dust on a fingernail that

original: avakkhalitaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ ekamuddikāya lañchitaṃ viya, ekanāḷiyā mitaṃ viya, ekatulāya🔽tulitaṃ viya ca, tathameva hoti avitathaṃ anaññathaṃ. Tenāha – “yañca, cunda, rattiṃ
analyzed: avakkhalitam sabbam tam eka muddikāya lañchitam viya eka nāḷiyā mitam viya eka tulāya  tulitam viya ca tatham eva hoti avitatham anaññatham tena āha yat ca cunda rattim
translated: is not included in them. All of it is as if marked with a single seal, as if measured with a single scale,

original: tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā🔽parinibbāyati, yaṃ etasmiṃ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati, sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti,
analyzed: tathāgataḥ anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambujjhati yañca rattim an upādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā  parinibbāyati yam etasmin antare bhāsati lapati niddisati sabbam tam tathā iva hoti
translated: as if weighed on a single scale. It is just so, not otherwise, not otherwise. Therefore it is said: ‘Cunda, whatever the Tathagata speaks, utters, or explains with reference to the fundamentals of the holy life that he has directly experienced, all that is just so and not otherwise.

original: no aññathā. Tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti. Gadattho hettha gatasaddo. Evaṃ tathavāditāya tathāgato.
analyzed: no aññathā tasmā tathāgato ti vuccati iti gada tthaḥ ha ittha gata saddo evam tathavāditāya tathāgato
translated: Therefore he is called the Tathagata.’ Here the word ‘gone’ has the meaning of ‘gone to.’ Thus the Tathagata is so called because he has gone to suchness.

original: Api ca āgadanaṃ āgado, vacananti attho. Tayo aviparīto āgado assāti, da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti evametasmiṃ atthe padasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: api ca āgadanam āgadaḥ vacananti attho tayo aviparītaḥ āgadaḥ assa ati dakārassa takāram katvā tathāgataḥ iti evam etasmin atthe pada siddhi veditabbā
translated: And āgati is coming, that is, speech. He has three kinds of coming that are not upside-down. The da of āgati is changed to ta, giving āgata. Thus the derivation of the word should be understood in this way.

original: Kathaṃ tathākāritāya tathāgato? Bhagavato hi vācāya kāyo anulometi, kāyassapi vācā,
analyzed: katham tathā kāritāya tathāgataḥ bhagavataḥ hi vācāya kāyaḥ kāyaḥ anulomā iti kāyaḥ api vācā
translated: How is he the Tathāgata because of acting in accordance with what is true? The Blessed One’s body acts in accordance with his speech, and his speech acts in accordance with his body.

original: tasmā yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī ca hoti. Evaṃbhūtassa cassa yathāvācā,
analyzed: tasmai yathāvādī tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī ca hoti evaṃbhūtassa ca ssa yathāvācā
translated: Therefore he is one who acts in accordance with what he says and says what he acts. And his body has come to be in accordance with his speech,

original: kāyopi tathā gato pavattoti attho. Yathā ca kāyo, vācāpi tathā gatā pavattāti tathāgato.🔽Tenevāha – “yathāvādī, bhikkhave, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī. Iti yathāvādī
analyzed: kāyaḥ api tathā gato pavatto ti atthaḥ yathā ca kāyaḥ vācā api tathā gatā pavattā ati tathāgato  tena iva āha yathāvādī bhikkhave tathāgataḥ tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī iti yathāvādī
translated: and his speech has come to be in accordance with his body. Thus the meaning of “Tathāgata” is one who has come to be in accordance with what is true.🔽Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, the Tathāgata acts in accordance with his word, the Tathāgata speaks in accordance with his action. Thus he is the Tathāgata, the One of True Word, the Possessor of True Speech” .

original: tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī. Tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti. Evaṃ tathākāritāya tathāgato.
analyzed: tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī tasmai tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti evam tathākāritāya tathāgataḥ
translated: Thus he is the Tathāgata because of acting in accordance with what is true.

original: Kathaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato? Upari bhavaggaṃ heṭṭhā avīciṃ pariyantaṃ katvā
analyzed: katham abhibhavana ṭṭhena tathāgataḥ upari bhavaggam heṭṭhā avīcim pariyantam katvā
translated: How is he the Tathāgata in the sense of overcoming?

original: tiriyaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu sabbasatte abhibhavati sīlenapi samādhināpi paññāyapi
analyzed: tiriyam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu sabba satte abhibhavati sīlena api samādhinā api paññāya api
translated: He surpasses all beings in the countless world systems in the ten directions by his virtue, concentration, wisdom,

original: vimuttiyāpi, vimuttiñāṇadassanenapi na tassa tulā vā pamāṇaṃ vā atthi; atulo appameyyo🔽anuttaro rājātirājā devadevo sakkānaṃ atisakko brahmānaṃ atibrahmā. Tenāha – “sadevake,🔽bhikkhave, loke…pe… sadevamanussāya pajāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso
analyzed: vimuttiyā api vimutti ñāṇa dassanena api na tassa tulāḥ vā pamāṇam vā atthi atulaḥ appameyyaḥ  anuttaraḥ rājā atirājā devadevaḥ sakkānam atisakkaḥ brahmānam atibrahmā tena āha sa devake  bhikkhave lokepe sa deva manussāya pajāya tathāgataḥ an abhibhūtaḥ
translated: liberation, and knowledge and vision of liberation. There is no one to equal him, no one to compare with him, in virtue, concentration, wisdom,

original: vasavattī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: vasa vattī tasmā tathāgataḥ ti vuccati iti
translated: liberation, and knowledge and vision of liberation. He is incomparable, matchless, unrivaled, unique, the best of men, the supreme of men, the holy one, the Tathāgata. Therefore he is called the Tathāgata.

original: Tatrevaṃ padasiddhi veditabbā. Agado viya agado. Ko panesa? Desanāvilāsamayo ceva🔽puññussayo ca. Tena hesa mahānubhāvo bhisakko dibbāgadena sappe viya sabbaparappavādino
analyzed: tatra ivam veditabbā agadaḥ viya agadaḥ kaḥ pana īsa desanā vilāsa mayaḥ ca iva  puññussayaḥ ca tena ha isa mahā anubhāvaḥ bhisakkaḥ dibbāgadena sappe viya sabba para ppavādinaḥ
translated: Herein, the derivation of the word should be understood as follows. The word is a compound of agada and agado. But what is this? It is the time of the display of teaching and the time of the accumulation of merit.

original: sadevakañca lokaṃ abhibhavati. Iti sabbālokābhibhavane tatho aviparīto desanāvilāsamayo
analyzed: sa devakam ca lokam abhibhavati iti aviparītaḥ desanā vilāsa mayaḥ
translated: Therefore this one of great power, this great physician, surpasses all other teachers and all the world with its gods by the divine medicine of the True Idea. Thus the time of the display of teaching and the time of the accumulation of merit are the same in being the time of the Tathāgata’s supremacy over all the world.

original: ceva puññussayo ca agado assāti. Da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti veditabbo.
analyzed: ca iva puññussayo ca a gadaḥ assa ati dakārassa takāram katvā tathāgataḥ iti veditabbaḥ
translated: and he is the one who has gone to the shelter of merit and to the shelter of the safe place. By changing the da to a ta, he should be understood as the Tathāgata.

original: Evaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena tathāgato.
analyzed: evam abhibhavana ṭṭhena tathāgataḥ
translated: Thus he is the Tathāgata in the sense of overcoming.

original: Api ca tathāya gatotipi tathāgato, tathaṃ gatotipi tathāgato. Gatoti avagato, atīto patto paṭipannoti attho.
analyzed: api ca tathāya gataḥ iti pi tathāgataḥ tatham gataḥ iti pi tathāgataḥ gataḥ iti avagataḥ atītaḥ patto paṭipanno ti attho
translated: Moreover, he is the Tathāgata because he has gone in the suchlike manner, and he is the Tathāgata because he has gone thus. Gone means known, passed away, attained, and entered upon, is the meaning.

original: Tattha sakalalokaṃ tīraṇapariññāya tathāya gato avagatoti tathāgato. Lokasamudayaṃ🔽pahānapariññāya tathāya gato atītoti tathāgato. Lokanirodhaṃ sacchikiriyāya tathāya
analyzed: sakala lokam tīraṇa pariññāya tathāya gataḥ avagataḥ ti tathāgataḥ loka samudayam  pahāna pariññāya tathāya gataḥ atītaḥ uti tathāgataḥ loka nirodham sacchikiriyāya tathāya
translated: Herein, he is the Tathāgata because he has gone, because he has known, all the world by means of the full-understanding of its discernment as an object.🔽He is the Tathāgata because he has gone beyond, because he has passed away from the world by means of the full-understanding of the abandoning of its origin.🔽He is the Tathāgata because he has attained, because he has attained cessation of the world by means of the full-understanding of its cessation.

original: gato pattoti tathāgato. Lokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ tathaṃ gato paṭipannoti tathāgato.
analyzed: gataḥ patto ti tathāgataḥ loka nirodha gāminim paṭipadam gataḥ paṭipanno ti tathāgataḥ
translated: He is the Tathāgata because he has entered upon, because he has entered upon the way leading to the cessation of the world by means of the full-understanding of the way leading to the cessation of the world.

original: Tena vuttaṃ bhagavatā –🔽“Loko, bhikkhave, tathāgatena abhisambuddho, lokasmā tathāgato visaṃyutto. Lokasamudayo,
analyzed: tena vuttam bhagavatā  lokaḥ bhikkhave tathāgatena abhisambuddhaḥ lokasmā tathāgataḥ visaṃyuttaḥ loka samudayaḥ
translated: Hence it was said by the Blessed One:🔽“Bhikkhus, the world has been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata; the Tathāgata is detached from the world.

original: bhikkhave, tathāgatena abhisambuddho, lokasamudayo tathāgatassa pahīno. Lokanirodho,
analyzed: bhikkhave tathāgatena abhisambuddhaḥ loka samudayaḥ tathāgatassa pahīnaḥ loka nirodho
translated: The origin of the world has been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata; the origin of the world has been abandoned by the Tathāgata. The cessation of the world has been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata; the cessation of the world has been realized by the Tathāgata. The way leading to the cessation of the world has been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata; the way leading to the cessation of the world has been developed by the Tathāgata. The Tathāgata, bhikkhus, is freed from birth, aging, and death; from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair; he is freed from suffering, I say” .

original: bhikkhave, tathāgatena abhisambuddho, lokanirodho tathāgatassa sacchikato. Lokanirodhagāminī🔽paṭipadā, bhikkhave, tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, lokanirodhagāminī paṭipadā tathāgatassa
analyzed: bhikkhave tathāgatena abhisambuddhaḥ loka nirodhaḥ tathāgatassa sacchikataḥ loka nirodha gāminī  paṭipadā bhikkhave tathāgatena abhisambuddhā loka nirodha gāminī paṭipadā tathāgatassa
translated: The cessation of the world has been realized by the Tathāgata.🔽The way leading to the cessation of the world has been discovered by the Tathāgata.

original: bhāvitā. Yaṃ bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa…pe… sabbaṃ taṃ tathāgatena abhisambuddhaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvitā yam bhikkhave sa devakassa lokassape sabbam tam tathāgatena abhisambuddham
translated: The way leading to the cessation of the world has been developed by the Tathāgata. Whatever there is in this world together with its gods, etc., all that has been fully awakened to by the Tathāgata.

original: Tasmā, tathāgatoti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: Therefore he is called the Tathāgata.”

original: Tassapi evaṃ attho veditabbo. Idampi ca tathāgatassa tathāgatabhāvadīpane mukhamattameva. Sabbākārena pana tathāgatova tathāgatassa tathāgatabhāvaṃ vaṇṇeyya.🔽Katamañca taṃ bhikkhaveti yena appamattakena oramattakena sīlamattakena puthujjano
analyzed: tassa api evam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ idam pi ca tathāgatassa tathāgata bhāva dīpane mukha mattam eva sabba ākārena pana tathāgataḥ uva tathāgatassa tathāgata bhāvam vaṇṇeyya  katamat ca tam bhikkhave iti yena appamattakena oramattakena sīla mattakena puthujjanaḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way. And this is only a brief explanation of the Tathāgata’s name in the sense of one who has reached the state of a Tathāgata. But the Tathāgata himself could explain the Tathāgata’s name in the sense of a Tathāgata in all its aspects.

original: tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno vadeyya, taṃ katamanti pucchati? Tattha pucchā nāma
analyzed: tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya tam katamanti pucchati tattha pucchā nāma
translated: “What, bhikkhus, is that?” He asks this in order to point out the mere trifle, the mere fraction of virtue, by which the worldling would praise the Tathāgata. Here the question is

original: adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā, diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā, vimaticchedanā pucchā, anumatipucchā,
analyzed: a diṭṭha jotanā pucchā diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchā vimati chedanā pucchā anumati pucchā
translated: Questioning for the purpose of showing what has not been seen, questioning for the purpose of confirming what has been seen, questioning for the purpose of cutting off perplexity, questioning for the purpose of consent,

original: kathetukamyatā pucchāti pañcavidhā hoti.
analyzed: kathā itu kamyatā pucchā ati pañcavidhā hi iti
translated: questioning for the purpose of desire to speak.

original: Tattha katamā adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā? Pakatiyā lakkhaṇaṃ aññātaṃ hoti, adiṭṭhaṃ atulitaṃ
analyzed: tattha katamā adiṭṭha jotanā pucchā pakatiyā lakkhaṇam aññātam hoti adiṭṭham atulitam
translated: Herein, what is questioning for the purpose of showing what has not been seen? The characteristic is not known by nature, not seen, not compared,

original: atīritaṃ avibhūtaṃ avibhāvitaṃ, tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya tulanāya tīraṇāya vibhāvanāya
analyzed: atīritam a vibhūtam a vibhāvitam tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya tulanāya tīraṇāya vibhāvanāya
translated: not measured, not penetrated, not manifested. He asks a question for the purpose of knowing, seeing, comparing, measuring, penetrating,

original: pañhaṃ pucchati, ayaṃ adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā.
analyzed: pañham pucchati ayam a diṭṭha jotanā pucchā
translated: manifesting that. This is questioning for the purpose of showing what has not been seen.

original: Katamā diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā? Pakatiyā lakkhaṇaṃ ñātaṃ hoti, diṭṭhaṃ tulitaṃ tīritaṃ
analyzed: katamā diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchā pakatiyā lakkhaṇam ñātam hoti diṭṭham tulitam tīritam
translated: What is questioning for the purpose of confirming what has been seen? The characteristic is known by nature, seen, compared,

original: vibhūtaṃ vibhāvitaṃ, tassa aññehi paṇḍitehi saddhiṃ saṃsandanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchati,
analyzed: vibhūtam vibhāvitam tassa aññehi paṇḍitehi saddhim saṃsandana tthāya pañham pucchati
translated: measured, penetrated, manifested. He asks a question for the purpose of confirming that with others who are wise.

original: ayaṃ diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchā.
analyzed: ayam diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchā
translated: This is questioning for the purpose of confirming what has been seen.

original: Katamā vimaticchedanā pucchā? Pakatiyā saṃsayapakkhando hoti, vimatipakkhando, dveḷhakajāto,
analyzed: katamā vimati chedanā pucchā pakatiyā saṃsaya pakkhando hoti vimati pakkhando dveḷhaka jāto
translated: What is questioning for the purpose of cutting off perplexity? The state of being subject to doubt by nature, the state of being subject to perplexity, the state of being double-tongued,

original: “evaṃ nu kho, na nu kho, kinnu kho, kathaṃ nu kho”ti. So vimaticchedanatthāya pañhaṃ🔽pucchati. Ayaṃ vimaticchedanā pucchā.🔽Katamā anumatipucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ anumatiyā pañhaṃ pucchati – “taṃ kiṃ maññatha,
analyzed: evam nu kho na nu kho kinnu kho katham nu kho ti so vimati chedana tthāya pañham  pucchati ayam vimati chedanā pucchā  katamā anumati pucchā bhagavā bhikkhūnam anumatiyā pañham pucchati tam kim maññatha
translated: “Is it so? Is it not so? What is it? How is it?” He asks a question in order to decide on the doubt. This is a question for deciding on doubt.🔽What is a question for consent? The Blessed One asks a question with the consent of the bhikkhus: “What do you think, bhikkhus, is form permanent or impermanent?” “Impermanent, venerable sir.” “But what is impermanent, is that unpleasant or pleasant?” “Unpleasant, venerable sir.” “But what is impermanent, unpleasant, and changeable by nature, is it proper to regard it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?” “No, venerable sir.” This is a question for consent.

original: bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti. Aniccaṃ, bhante. Yaṃ panāniccaṃ, dukkhaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhave rūpam niccam vā aniccam vā ati aniccam bhante yam pana aniccam dukkham
translated: What is a question out of compassion? The Blessed One asks a question out of compassion for the bhikkhus: “Bhikkhus, these four foundations of mindfulness,🔽developed and cultivated, if used properly, lead to a supreme71861  penetration of insight.” “But, venerable sir, how should they be used properly so that they lead to a supreme penetration of insight?” “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the body in the body, ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.

original: vā taṃ sukhaṃ vāti? Dukkhaṃ bhanteti sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ, ayaṃ anumatipucchā.🔽Katamā kathetukamyatā pucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ kathetukamyatāya pañhaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: vā tam sukham vāti dukkham bhante ti sabbam vattabbam ayam anumati pucchā  katamā kathetu kamyatā pucchā bhagavā bhikkhūnam kathetu kamyatāya pañham pucchati
translated: Translation: Evaṃ nu kho, na nu kho, kinnu kho, kathaṃ nu khoti | So vimaticchedanatthāya pañhaṃ pucchati | Ayaṃ vimaticchedanā pucchā |🔽Katamā anumatipucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ anumatiyā pañhaṃ pucchati – ”taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti? Aniccaṃ, bhante | Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vāti? Dukkhaṃ, bhanteti sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ, ayaṃ anumatipucchā |

original: Cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā. Katame cattāro?…Pe… aṭṭhime bhikkhave maggaṅgā.🔽Katame aṭṭhāti, ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā.🔽Iti imāsu pañcasu pucchāsu adiṭṭhassa tāva kassaci dhammassa abhāvato tathāgatassa
analyzed: cattāro me bhikkhave sati paṭṭhānā katame cattāro pe aṭṭhime bhikkhave maggaṅgā 🔽katame ayam pucchā 🔽iti imāsu pañcasu pucchāsu adiṭṭhassa tāva kassacid dhammassa abhāvato tathāgatassa
translated: Katamā kathetukamyatā pucchā? Bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ kathetukamyatāya pañhaṃ pucchati – ”cattārome, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānā | Katame cattāro? Pe… aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, maggaṅ

original: adiṭṭhajotanā pucchā natthi. “Idaṃ nāma aññehi paṇḍitehi samaṇabrāhmaṇehi saddhiṃ🔽saṃsanditvā desessāmī”ti samannāhārasseva anuppajjanato diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchāpi🔽natthi. Yasmā pana buddhānaṃ ekadhammepi āsappanā parisappanā natthi, bodhimaṇḍeyeva
analyzed: adiṭṭha jotanā pucchā natthi idam nāma aññehi paṇḍitehi samaṇa brāhmaṇehi saddhiṃ  saṃsanditvā desessāmi iti samannāhārassa iva an uppajjanataḥ diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchā api  natthi yasmā pana buddhānam eka dhamme pi āsappanā parisappanā natthi
translated: There is no question of “seeking light from others.” “I shall teach this after discussing it with other wise men, ascetics and brahmans,” and so on. There is no question of “seeking discussion with others.”

original: sabbā kaṅkhā chinnā; tasmā vimaticchedanā pucchāpi natthiyeva. Avasesā pana dve pucchā
analyzed: sabbā kaṅkhā chinnā tasmā vimati chedanā pucchā api natthiyā iva avasesā pana dve pucchā
translated: But since the Buddhas have no doubts about even a single thing, since they have cut off all doubts right at the root at the foot of the Bodhi Tree, there is no question of “seeking to resolve doubts.” The remaining two kinds of questions

original: buddhānaṃ atthi, tāsu ayaṃ kathetukamyatā pucchā nāma.
analyzed: buddhānam atthi tāsu ayam kathā itu kamya tā pucchā nāma
translated: are found in the Buddhas. Of these, this is called the question of “desire to speak.”

original: 8. Idāni taṃ kathetukamyatāya pucchāya pucchitamatthaṃ kathetuṃ “pāṇātipātaṃ pahāyā”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha pāṇassa atipāto pāṇātipāto, pāṇavadho, pāṇaghātoti vuttaṃ hoti. Pāṇoti cettha
analyzed: idāni tam kathetu kamyatāya pucchāya pucchitam attham kathetum pāṇa atipātam pahāya ati ādim āha  tattha pāṇassa atipātaḥ pāṇa atipātaḥ pāṇa vadhaḥ pāṇa ghāto ti vuttam hoti pāṇaḥ iti ca ittha
translated: Now, in order to answer the question of “desire to speak,” he said, “Having abandoned the killing of living beings” and so on.

original: vohārato satto, paramatthato jīvitindriyaṃ, tasmiṃ pana pāṇe pāṇasaññino jīvitindriyupacchedakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: vohārato satto paramatthataḥ jīvitindriyam tasmin pana pāṇe pāṇa saññinaḥ jīvitindriya upacchedaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: Herein, the killing of a living being is the killing of a living being, the slaying of a living being, the destruction of a living being. A living being is a being by convention, in the ultimate sense the life faculty. But in regard to that living being, the act of killing is the act of killing a living being, the act of slaying a living being, the act of destroying a living being.

original: kāyavacīdvārānaṃ aññataradvārappavattā vadhakacetanā pāṇātipāto. So guṇavirahitesu
analyzed: kāya vacī dvārānaṃ aññatara dvāra ppavattā vadhaka cetanā pāṇātipātaḥ so guṇa virahitesu
translated: Killing breathing things is the volition to kill that occurs as a door of kamma among the doors of the body and the tongue.

original: tiracchānagatādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāsarīre mahāsāvajjo, kasmā?🔽Payogamahantatāya. Payogasamattepi vatthumahantatāya. Guṇavantesu manussādīsu appaguṇe🔽pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāguṇe mahāsāvajjo. Sarīraguṇānaṃ pana samabhāve sati kilesānaṃ
analyzed: tiracchāna gata ādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appa sāvajjaḥ mahā sarīre mahā sāvajjaḥ kasmā  payoga mahanta tāya payoga samatte api vatthu mahanta tāya guṇavantesu manussa ādīsu appaguṇe  pāṇe appasāvajjaḥ mahā guṇe mahā sāvajjaḥ sarīra guṇānam pana sama bhāve sati kilesānam
translated: In the case of breathing things devoid of special qualities, such as animals, etc., killing a small breathing thing is less blameworthy, and killing a big one more so. Why?

original: upakkamānañca mudutāya appasāvajjo, tibbatāya mahāsāvajjoti veditabbo.
analyzed: upakkamānam ca mudu tāya appa sāvajjo tibba tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: Because of the magnitude of the means. And even when the means are equal, it is more blameworthy when the object is greater. In the case of breathing things possessing special qualities, such as human beings, etc., killing a breathing thing with few special qualities is less blameworthy, and killing one with many more so. But when the special qualities of the bodies are equal, it should be understood that killing a breathing thing with tender feelings is less blameworthy, and killing one with tough feelings more so.

original: Tassa pañca sambhārā honti – pāṇo, pāṇasaññitā, vadhakacittaṃ, upakkamo, tena maraṇanti.
analyzed: tassa pañca sambhārāḥ honti pāṇaḥ pāṇa saññitā vadhaka cittam upakkamaḥ tena maraṇanti
translated: It has five constituents: a breathing thing, the perception of a breathing thing, the volition to kill, the effort, and death thereby.

original: Cha payogā – sāhatthiko, āṇattiko, nissaggiyo, thāvaro, vijjāmayo, iddhimayoti. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: cha payogā sāhatthikaḥ āṇattikaḥ nissaggiyaḥ thāvaraḥ vijjā mayaḥ iddhi mayaḥ ti imasmin
translated: There are six means: by one’s own person, by command, by throwing, by causing to fall, by incantation, by gemination.

original: panatthe vitthāriyamāne ativiya papañco hoti, tasmā taṃ na vitthārayāma, aññañca
analyzed: panatthe vitthāriyamāne ativiya papañcaḥ hoti tasmā tam na vitthārayāma aññañca
translated: But when this is being expounded there is too much detail, so we shall not expound it.

original: evarūpaṃ. Atthikehi pana samantapāsādikaṃ vinayaṭṭhakathaṃ oloketvā gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: evarūpam atthikehi pana samantapāsādikam vinaya ṭṭhakatham oloketvā gahetabbam
translated: Those who want to know should look it up in the Vinaya Commentary, which is entirely trustworthy.🔽Having abandoned: having abandoned that unvirtuousness called the volition of killing breathing things.

original: Pahāyāti imaṃ pāṇātipātacetanāsaṅkhātaṃ dussīlyaṃ pajahitvā. Paṭiviratoti pahīnakālato
analyzed: pahāya ati imam pāṇa atipāta cetanā saṅkhātam dussīlyam pajahitvā paṭivirataḥ ti pahīna kālataḥ
translated: Abstaining: from the time of abandoning,🔽he is one who abstains, who turns away, from that unvirtuousness.🔽There are no ideas cognizable by the eye or ear

original: paṭṭhāya tato dussīlyato orato viratova. Natthi tassa vītikkamissāmīti cakkhusotaviññeyyā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya tatas dussīlyato oratas virataḥ va natthi tassa vītikkamissāmi iti cakkhu sota viññeyyā
translated: that he would transgress, thinking: “I shall not do this.”

original: dhammā pageva kāyikāti imināva nayena aññesupi evarūpesu padesu attho veditabbo.🔽Samaṇoti bhagavā samitapāpatāya laddhavohāro. Gotamoti gottavasena. Na kevalañca
analyzed: dhammā pagā iva kāyikā ti iminā ava nayena aññesu pi evarūpesu padesu atthaḥ veditabbo  samaṇaḥ iti bhagavā samita pāpa tāya laddha vohāraḥ gotamaḥ iti gotta vasena na kevalam ca
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the other instances of this kind.🔽The Blessed One is called a recluse because he has attained the state of peace from evil deeds.🔽He is called a Gotama because of his clan.

original: bhagavāyeva pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, bhikkhusaṅghopi paṭivirato, desanā pana ādito
analyzed: bhagavāya iva pāṇātipātā paṭivirataḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ api paṭivirataḥ desanā pana āditas
translated: And not only the Blessed One but also the Community of Bhikkhus abstains from killing breathing things. But the teaching is given in this way from the beginning.

original: paṭṭhāya evaṃ āgatā, atthaṃ pana dīpentena bhikkhusaṅghavasenāpi dīpetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya evam āgatā attham pana dīpentena bhikkhu saṅgha vasena api dīpetum vaṭṭati
translated: However, when the meaning is being elucidated, it is allowable to elucidate it also by reference to the Community of Bhikkhus.

original: Nihitadaṇḍo nihitasatthoti parūpaghātatthāya daṇḍaṃ vā satthaṃ vā ādāya avattanato
analyzed: nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita sattho ti para upaghāta tthāya daṇḍam vā sattham vā ādāya avattanato
translated: He has laid aside cudgel and sword: because he has laid aside cudgel and sword for the purpose of harming others, and because he is not engaged in that,

original: nikkhittadaṇḍo ceva nikkhittasattho cāti attho. Ettha ca ṭhapetvā daṇḍaṃ sabbampi
analyzed: nikkhitta daṇḍo ca iva nikkhitta sattho ca ati atthaḥ ettha ca ṭhapetvā daṇḍam sabbam pi
translated: the meaning is, he has laid aside the stick and the sword. And here, apart from the stick,

original: avasesaṃ upakaraṇaṃ sattānaṃ viheṭhanabhāvato satthanti veditabbaṃ. Yaṃ pana bhikkhū
analyzed: avasesam upakaraṇam sattānam viheṭhana bhāvataḥ satthanti veditabbam yam pana bhikkhū
translated: The meaning is that he has laid aside the stick and the sword. And here all the other requisites except the stick should be understood as the sword, since they are a means of harming living beings.

original: kattaradaṇḍaṃ vā dantakaṭṭhaṃ vā vāsiṃ pipphalikaṃ vā gahetvā vicaranti, na taṃ parūpaghātatthāya.
analyzed: kattaradaṇḍam vā dantakaṭṭham vā vā asim pipphalikam vā gahetvā vicaranti na tam para upaghāta tthāya
translated: But when monks go about carrying a stick for warding off elephants, etc., a tooth-stick, a razor, or a small knife, it is not for the purpose of harming others.

original: Tasmā nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho tveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: tasmai nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita satthaḥ tu eva saṅkhyam gacchati
translated: So they are reckoned as “having laid aside the stick and the sword.”

original: Lajjīti pāpajigucchanalakkhaṇāya lajjāya samannāgato. Dayāpannoti dayaṃ mettacittataṃ
analyzed: lajjī iti pāpa jigucchana lakkhaṇāya lajjāya samannāgataḥ dayā āpanno ti dayam
translated: Modest: endowed with shame in the sense of abhorrence of wrongdoing. Compassionate: one who has attained compassion, that is, loving-kindness.

original: āpanno. Sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampīti; sabbe pāṇabhūte hitena anukampako. Tāya dayāpannatāya
analyzed: āpannaḥ sabba pāṇabhūta hita anukampī iti sabbe pāṇabhūte hitena anukampako tāya dayā panna tāya
translated: Sympathizing with all living beings: one who sympathizes with all living beings through a wish for their welfare.🔽The meaning is that he has a mind desiring the welfare of all living beings because he has attained compassion.

original: sabbesaṃ pāṇabhūtānaṃ hitacittakoti attho. Viharatīti iriyati yapeti yāpeti pāleti.
analyzed: sabbesam pāṇa bhūtānam hita cittakaḥ ti atthaḥ viharati iti iriyati yapeti yāpeti pāleti
translated: He lives: he moves, he acts, he conducts himself.

original: Iti vā hi, bhikkhaveti evaṃ vā bhikkhave. Vā saddo upari “adinnādānaṃ pahāyā”tiādīni
analyzed: iti vā hi bhikkhave iti evam vā bhikkhave vā saddaḥ upari adinnādānam pahāya ati ādīni
translated: Thus, bhikkhus: in this way, bhikkhus. The word “thus” is a particle; it is a term for non-defective.

original: apekkhitvā vikappattho vutto, evaṃ sabbattha purimaṃ vā pacchimaṃ vā apekkhitvā vikappabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: apekkhitvā vikappa atthaḥ vuttaḥ evam sabbattha purimam vā pacchimam vā apekkhitvā vikappa bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning of the permutation is stated with reference to the expectation. So too, in all cases the state of permutation should be understood with reference to the former or the latter.

original: Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo – bhikkhave, puthujjano tathāgatassa vaṇṇaṃ vadamāno evaṃ
analyzed: ayam pana ittha saṅkhepaḥ bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ evam
translated: But here is a brief explanation: “Bhikkhus, when the worldling speaks in praise of the Tathāgata, he speaks praise in this way:

original: vadeyya – “samaṇo gotamo pāṇaṃ na hanati, na ghāteti, na tattha samanuñño hoti, virato🔽imasmā dussīlyā; aho, vata re buddhaguṇā mahantā”ti, iti mahantaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā vaṇṇaṃ🔽vattukāmopi appamattakaṃ oramattakaṃ ācārasīlamattakameva vakkhati. Upari asādhāraṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vadeyya samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ pāṇam na hanati na ghāteti na tattha samanuññaḥ hoti virato  imasmai dussīlyai aho vata re buddha guṇāḥ mahantā iti mahantam ussāham katvā vaṇṇam  vattu kāmaḥ api appamattakam ora mattakam ācāra sīla mattakam eva vakkhati upari asādhāraṇa bhāvam
translated: ‘The recluse Gotama does not kill living beings, does not order others to kill living beings, and does not approve of the killing of living beings. He is restrained from killing living beings, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from killing living beings.🔽He is restrained from taking what is not given, from sexual misconduct, from false speech, and from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.
