analyzed: nissāya vaṇṇam vattum na sakkhissati na kevalam ca sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmi arahantaḥ pi
translated: He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.🔽He is restrained from storing up goods for enjoyment, and he teaches the Dhamma to his disciples for the purpose of restraining them from storing up goods for enjoyment.

original: paccekabuddhāpi na sakkontiyeva; tathāgatoyeva pana sakkoti, taṃ vo upari vakkhāmīti,
analyzed: paccekabuddhā api na sakkonti yeva tathāgataḥ yeva pana sakkoti tam vaḥ upari vakkhāmi iti
translated: and the Paccekabuddhas cannot do so either; only the Tathāgata can do so, and I will tell you about that later.”🔽

original: ayamettha sādhippāyā atthavaṇṇanā. Ito paraṃ pana apubbapadameva vaṇṇayissāma.
analyzed: ayam ettha sa adhippāyā attha vaṇṇanā itas param pana apubba padam eva vaṇṇayissāma
translated: From here on we shall comment only on the words not commented on in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: Adinnādānaṃ pahāyāti ettha adinnassa ādānaṃ adinnādānaṃ, parasaṃharaṇaṃ, theyyaṃ,
analyzed: a dinna ādānam pahāya ati ettha a dinnassa ādānam a dinna ādānam para saṃharaṇam theyyam
translated: Abandoning taking what is not given: taking what is not given is the taking of what is not given, the seizing of what is not given, theft,

original: corikāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha adinnanti parapariggahitaṃ, yattha paro yathākāmakāritaṃ
analyzed: corikā iti vuttam hoti tattha adinnam ti para pariggahitam yattha paraḥ yathā kāma kāritam
translated: robbery. Herein, what is not given is what is owned by another, where the other, by having ownership or possession,

original: āpajjanto adaṇḍāraho anupavajjo ca hoti. Tasmiṃ parapariggahite parapariggahitasaññino,
analyzed: āpajjantaḥ a daṇḍa ārahaḥ an upavajjaḥ ca hoti tasmin para pariggahite para pariggahita saññinaḥ
translated: is not at fault in using it as he likes. In what is owned by another, by one who perceives it as owned by another,

original: tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā theyyacetanā adinnādānaṃ. Taṃ hīne parasantake appasāvajjaṃ,🔽paṇīte mahāsāvajjaṃ, kasmā? Vatthupaṇītatāya. Vatthusamatte sati guṇādhikānaṃ santake🔽vatthusmiṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ. Taṃ taṃ guṇādhikaṃ upādāya tato tato hīnaguṇassa santake
analyzed: tad ādāyaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpikā theyya cetanā adinnādānam tam hīne para santake appasāvajjam  paṇīte mahā sāvajjam kasmai vatthu paṇīta tāya vatthu samatte sati guṇa adhikānam santake  vatthusmim mahā sāvajjam tam tam guṇa adhikam upādāya tatas tatas hīna guṇassa santake
translated: the intention to steal that is the origin of the action of taking it is taking what is not given. That is less blameworthy when the other’s property is inferior or small,🔽more blameworthy when it is superior or large. Why? Because of the excellence of the object. When the object is equal, it is more blameworthy in one of superior qualities than in one of inferior qualities.

original: vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjaṃ.
analyzed: vatthusmim appasāvajjam
translated: When the object is equal, it is less blameworthy in one of superior qualities than in one of inferior qualities.

original: Tassa pañca sambhārā honti – parapariggahitaṃ, parapariggahitasaññitā, theyyacittaṃ,
analyzed: tassa pañca sambhārāḥ honti para pariggahitam para pariggahita saññitā theyya cittam
translated: There are five components: what is owned by another, the perception of it as such, the intention to steal,

original: upakkamo, tena haraṇanti. Cha payogā – sāhatthikādayova. Te ca kho yathānurūpaṃ theyyāvahāro,🔽pasayhāvahāro, paṭicchannāvahāro, parikappāvahāro, kusāvahāroti imesaṃ avahārānaṃ
analyzed: upakkamaḥ tena haraṇanti cha payogā sāhatthika ādayaḥ va te ca kho yathānurūpam theyya avahāro  pasayhāvahāro paṭicchannāvahāro parikappāvahāro kusāvahāro ti imesam avahārānam
translated: the effort, and the removal of it from its base. There are six methods: by force, etc., and these are applied according to the methods of theft, such as by stealth,

original: vasena pavattā, ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana samantapāsādikāyaṃ vutto.
analyzed: vasena pavattā ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana samantapāsādikāyam vutto
translated: by theft, by concealment, by stratagem, and by fraud. This is the brief account here. But the detailed account is given in the Samantapāsādikā.

original: Dinnameva ādiyatīti dinnādāyī. Cittenapi dinnameva paṭikaṅkhatīti dinnapāṭikaṅkhī.🔽Thenetīti theno. Na thenena athenena. Athenattāyeva sucibhūtena. Attanāti attabhāvena.
analyzed: dinnam eva ādiyati iti dinna ādāyī cittena api dinnam eva paṭikaṅkhati iti dinna pāṭikaṅkhī  thena iti iti thenaḥ na thenena athenena athenattāya iva suci bhūtena attanā ati atta bhāvena
translated: He takes what is given: he expects only what is given.

original: Athenaṃ sucibhūtaṃ attānaṃ katvā viharatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ paṭhamasikkhāpade🔽vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Yathā ca idha, evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: atha enam suci bhūtam attānam katvā viharati iti vuttam hoti sesam paṭhama sikkhāpade 🔽vutta nayena iva yojetabbam yathā ca idha evam sabbattha
translated: He is upright: he is not crooked. He is pure: he is pure in bodily conduct. He is clean: he is clean in bodily conduct. He is of clean habits: he is clean in his bodily conduct and in his use of the refuse-rag robe, etc. He dwells in a clean place: he dwells in a place that is clean in the sense of being free from such impurities as excrement, urine, spittle, and vomit. He is of clean character: he is clean in his bodily conduct and in his speech and mind. He is of clean aspiration: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his aspiration for the going forth. He is of clean pursuit: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his pursuit of the going forth. He is of clean livelihood: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his livelihood. He is of clean practice: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his practice of the training precepts. He is of clean liberation: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his attainment of the noble fruitions. He is of clean insight: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his insight that ends with arahantship. He is of clean conduct: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his conduct that ends with arahantship. He is of clean character: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his character that ends with arahantship. He is of clean aspiration: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his aspiration that ends with arahantship. He is of clean pursuit: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his pursuit that ends with arahantship. He is of clean livelihood: he is clean in his bodily conduct, etc., and in his livelihood that ends with arahantship.

original: Abrahmacariyanti aseṭṭhacariyaṃ. Brahmaṃ seṭṭhaṃ ācāraṃ caratīti brahmacārī. Ārācārīti🔽abrahmacariyato dūracārī. Methunāti rāgapariyuṭṭhānavasena sadisattā methunakāti
analyzed: a brahmacariyanti a seṭṭha cariyam brahmam seṭṭham ācāram carati iti brahmacārī ārācārī iti  a brahmacariyataḥ dūra cārī methunā ati rāga pariyuṭṭhāna vasena sadisa ttā methunakā ati
translated: Un-Brahma-conduct : non-noble conduct. He who conducts himself with the noble, best conduct is a Brahma-charin . He who conducts himself far from un-Brahma-conduct is an Araka-charin .🔽The word methuna is derived from the root man , to think, and the prefix methuna , which is a reduplication, is used in the sense of ‘ thinking alike ‘ because of the state of being ‘ alike ‘ through the state of being obsessed by lust.

original: laddhavohārehi paṭisevitabbato methunāti saṅkhyaṃ gatā asaddhammā. Gāmadhammāti gāmavāsīnaṃ dhammā.
analyzed: laddha vohārehi paṭisevitabbataḥ methunā ati saṅkhyam gatāḥ asat dhammāḥ gāma dhammā ati gāma vāsīnam dhammāḥ
translated: The word gāmadhamma is derived from the word gāma , which is used in the sense of ‘ village ‘ because of the state of being ‘ frequented ‘ by those who live in a village.

original: 9. Musāvādaṃ pahāyāti ettha musāti visaṃvādanapurekkhārassa atthabhañjanako vacīpayogo
analyzed: musāvādam pahāya ati ettha musā ati visaṃvādana purekkhārassa attha bhañjanakaḥ vacī payogaḥ
translated: Having abandoned false speech : here, the word musā is a verbal expression that breaks the meaning of the word musā , which is used in the sense of ‘ deception ‘.

original: kāyapayogo, vā visaṃvādanādhippāyena panassa paravisaṃvādakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādo.
analyzed: kāya payogaḥ vā visaṃvādana adhippāyena pana assa para visaṃvādaka kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā musāvādaḥ
translated: Or else, the volition that originates the bodily and verbal actions of deception is false speech.

original: Aparo nayo, ‘musā’ti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu. ‘Vādo’ti tassa bhūtato tacchato viññāpanaṃ.
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ musā ati abhūtam ataccham vatthu vādo ti tassa bhūtataḥ tacchataḥ viññāpanam
translated: Another method: the word musā is a non-existent, untrue state of affairs. The word vādo is used in the sense of ‘ making known ‘ that as it really is.

original: Lakkhaṇato pana atathaṃ vatthuṃ tathato paraṃ viññāpetukāmassa tathāviññattisamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: lakkhaṇato pana atatham vatthum tathatas param viññāpetu kāmassa tathā viññatti samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: By characteristic, false speech is the volition that originates the intention to make known to another as it really is a non-existent state of affairs as it really is.

original: cetanā musāvādo. So yamatthaṃ bhañjati, tassa appatāya appasāvajjo, mahantatāya mahāsāvajjo.
analyzed: cetanā musāvādaḥ saḥ yam attham bhañjati tassa appa tāya appa sāvajjaḥ mahanta tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ
translated: and the volition is the lying. It is less blameworthy when the thing is of less value and more blameworthy when it is of greater value.

original: Api ca gahaṭṭhānaṃ attano santakaṃ adātukāmatāya natthītiādinayappavatto appasāvajjo,🔽sakkhinā hutvā atthabhañjanatthaṃ vutto mahāsāvajjo, pabbajitānaṃ appakampi telaṃ
analyzed: api ca gaha ṭṭhānam attanaḥ santakam a dātu kāma tāya natthi iti ādi naya ppavatto appa sāvajjaḥ  sakkhinā hutvā attha bhañjana attham vuttaḥ mahā sāvajjaḥ pabbajitānam appakampi telam
translated: Moreover, for householders, lying that occurs as the refusal to give what one has is less blameworthy,🔽while lying that occurs for the purpose of destroying the opponent’s case is more blameworthy. For those gone forth, lying that occurs for the purpose of obtaining oil, ghee,

original: vā sappiṃ vā labhitvā hasādhippāyena – “ajja gāme telaṃ nadī maññe sandatī”ti pūraṇakathānayena
analyzed: vā sappim vā labhitvā hasa adhippāyena ajja gāme telam nadī maññe sandati iti pūraṇa kathā nayena
translated: or molasses, with the intention of laughing and joking, as when one says, “Today in the village oil is flowing in the streets like water,”

original: pavatto appasāvajjo, adiṭṭhaṃyeva pana diṭṭhantiādinā nayena vadantānaṃ mahāsāvajjo.
analyzed: pavattaḥ appasāvajjaḥ adiṭṭham yeva pana diṭṭham ti ādinā nayena vadantānam mahāsāvajjaḥ
translated: is less blameworthy, while lying that occurs by saying, “I have seen what I have not seen,” and so on, is more blameworthy.

original: Tassa cattāro sambhārā honti – atathaṃ vatthu, visaṃvādanacittaṃ, tajjo vāyāmo, parassa
analyzed: tassa cattāro sambhārāḥ honti atatham vatthu visaṃvādana cittam tad jaḥ vā āyāmaḥ parassa
translated: It has four constituents: the object that is not as it is, the intention to deceive, the effort that is appropriate to that, and the other’s

original: tadatthavijānananti. Eko payogo sāhatthikova. So kāyena vā kāyapaṭibaddhena vā vācāya
analyzed: tad attha vijānanam ti ekaḥ payogo sāhatthikaḥ uva saḥ kāyena vā kāya paṭibaddhena vā vācāya
translated: understanding of the meaning. There is only one means of committing it: by body or by speech.

original: vā paravisaṃvādanakiriyākaraṇena daṭṭhabbo. Tāya ce kiriyāya paro tamatthaṃ jānāti,
analyzed: vā para visaṃvādana kiriyā karaṇena daṭṭhabbaḥ tāya ce kiriyāya paraḥ tam attham jānāti
translated: It should be understood as the performance of the act of deceiving another. And if the other understands the meaning of the act,

original: ayaṃ kiriyasamuṭṭhāpikacetanākkhaṇeyeva musāvādakammunā bajjhati.
analyzed: ayam musāvāda kammunā bajjhati
translated: The volition that instigates the action is guilty of the action of lying at the very moment it comes into existence.

original: Yasmā pana yathā kāyakāyapaṭibaddhavācāhi paraṃ visaṃvādeti, tathā “idamassa bhaṇāhī”ti
analyzed: yasmai pana yathā param visaṃvāda iti tathā idam assa bhaṇāhi iti
translated: But just as he deceives another by means of his body and speech, so too by means of a command,

original: āṇāpentopi paṇṇaṃ likhitvā purato nissajjantopi, “ayamattho evaṃ daṭṭhabbo”ti kuḍḍādīsu
analyzed: āṇāpentaḥ api paṇṇam likhitvā puratas nissajjantaḥ api ayam atthaḥ evam daṭṭhabbaḥ iti kuḍḍa ādīsu
translated: by placing a written message in front of him, by placing a written message on a wall, etc., with the words “This is the meaning,”

original: likhitvā ṭhapentopi. Tasmā ettha āṇattikanissaggiyathāvarāpi payogā yujjanti, aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: likhitvā ṭhapentaḥ api tasmai ettha payogāḥ yujjanti aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: and so on. So the kinds of instigation and the kinds of intimation are applicable here.

original: pana anāgatattā vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbā.🔽Saccaṃ vadatīti saccavādī. Saccena saccaṃ sandahati ghaṭetīti saccasandho. Na antarantarā🔽musā vadatīti attho. Yo hi puriso kadāci musā vadati, kadāci saccaṃ, tassa musāvādena
analyzed: pana anāgata ttā vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbā  saccam vadati iti sacca vādī saccena saccam sandahati ghaṭa iti iti sacca sandhaḥ na antar antarā  musā vadati iti atthaḥ yaḥ hi puriso kadāci musā vadati kadāci saccam tassa musāvādena
translated: But they are not mentioned in the commentaries. They should be understood by inference.🔽He speaks truth: he is a truth-speaker . He is bound by truth, he is bound to truth: he is bound by truth, he is bound to truth, in the sense that he is not a person who speaks falsehood now and then,🔽but one who speaks truth and is consistent with truth.

original: antaritattā saccaṃ saccena na ghaṭīyati; tasmā so na saccasandho. Ayaṃ pana na tādiso,
analyzed: saccam saccena na tasmā saḥ na sacca sandhaḥ ayam pana na tādisaḥ
translated: For when a man speaks falsehood now and then, his truth is not consistent with truth because it is interrupted by falsehood.🔽But this man is not like that.

original: jīvitahetupi musā avatvā saccena saccaṃ sandahati yevāti saccasandho.🔽Thetoti thiro thirakathoti attho. Eko hi puggalo haliddirāgo viya, thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇu
analyzed: musā avatvā saccena saccam sandahati sacca sandho  theto ti thiraḥ thira kathaḥ ti attho ekaḥ hi puggalaḥ haliddi rāgaḥ viya thusa rāsimhi
translated: and he does not tell a lie even for the sake of life, but he confirms truth by truth. Thus he is “one who confirms truth” .🔽“Steadfast”: the meaning is, “one who speaks steadfastly.” For one kind of person speaks unsteadfastly, like a chameleon, like a post stuck in a heap of chaff,

original: viya, assapiṭṭhe ṭhapitakumbhaṇḍamiva ca na thirakatho hoti, eko pāsāṇalekhā viya,
analyzed: viya assa piṭṭhe ṭhapita kumbhaṇḍam iva ca na thira kathaḥ hoti ekaḥ pāsāṇa lekhā viya
translated: like a water-snake placed on a drum, while another speaks steadfastly, like a line drawn on stone,

original: indakhīlo viya ca thirakatho hoti, asinā sīsaṃ chindantepi dve kathā na katheti, ayaṃ vuccati theto.
analyzed: indakhīlaḥ viya ca thira kathaḥ hoti asinā sīsam chindante pi dve kathā na kathā iti ayam vuccati
translated: like an iron pillar. The latter is called “steadfast.” He would not speak two different statements even if his head were cut off with a sword.

original: Paccayikoti pattiyāyitabbako, saddhāyitabbakoti attho. Ekacco hi puggalo na paccayiko
analyzed: paccayikaḥ ti pattiyāyitabbako saddhāyitabbako ti attho ekaccaḥ hi puggalaḥ na paccayikaḥ
translated: “One who has confidence in the doctrine”: one who has confidence in the attainment. For one kind of person does not have confidence in the attainment,

original: hoti, “idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā”ti vutte “mā tassa vacanaṃ saddahathā”ti vattabbataṃ
analyzed: hoti idam kena vuttam asukena ati vutte mā tassa vacanam saddahatha ati vattabbatam
translated: and when it is said, “This was said by so and so,” he is one who should be told, “Do not have confidence in his word.”

original: āpajjati. Eko paccayiko hoti, “idaṃ kena vuttaṃ, asukenā”ti vutte “yadi tena vuttaṃ,
analyzed: āpajjati ekaḥ paccayikaḥ hoti idam kena vuttam asukena ati vutte yadi tena vuttam
translated: But another has confidence in the attainment, and when it is said, “This was said by so and so,” he is one who should be told, “If it was said by him,

original: idameva pamāṇaṃ, idāni upaparikkhitabbaṃ natthi, evameva ida”nti vattabbataṃ āpajjati,
analyzed: idam eva pamāṇam idāni upaparikkhitabbam na atthi evam eva idam ti vattabba tam āpajjati
translated: that alone is a reason ; there is no need to investigate further; it is just so.”

original: ayaṃ vuccati paccayiko. Avisaṃvādako lokassāti tāya saccavāditāya lokaṃ na visaṃvādetīti attho.🔽Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāyātiādīsu yāya vācāya yassa taṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, tassa hadaye attano piyabhāvaṃ, parassa ca suññabhāvaṃ karoti, sā pisuṇā vācā.
analyzed: ayam vuccati paccayikaḥ a visaṃvādakaḥ lokassa ati tāya sacca vādi tāya lokam na visaṃvādeti iti attho  pisuṇam vācam pahāya ati ādīsu yāya vācāya yassa tam vācam bhāsati tassa hadaye attano piya bhāvam parassa ca suñña bhāvam karoti sā pisuṇā vācā
translated: This is called the dependent one. He is not a deceiver of the world: the meaning is that by this truth-speaking he does not deceive the world.🔽Abandoning malicious speech: the speech by which one makes oneself dear to another’s heart and empties another’s heart is malicious speech.

original: Yāya pana attānampi parampi pharusaṃ karoti, yā vācā sayampi pharusā, neva kaṇṇasukhā na hadayaṅgamā, ayaṃ pharusā vācā.
analyzed: yāya pana attānam pi param pi pharusam karoti yā vācā sayam pi pharusā na iva kaṇṇa sukhā na hadayaṅgamā ayam pharusā vācā
translated: But the speech by which one makes both oneself and another harsh, and which is itself harsh, not pleasing to the ear, disagreeable, unlovely to hear, is harsh speech.

original: Yena samphaṃ palapati niratthakaṃ, so samphappalāpo.
analyzed: yena sampham palapati niratthakam saḥ sampha palāpaḥ
translated: That by which one prattles meaninglessly is chatter.

original: Tesaṃ mūlabhūtā cetanāpi pisuṇavācādināmeva labhati, sā eva ca idhādhippetāti.
analyzed: mūla bhūtā cetanā api pisuṇa vācā ādinām eva labhati sā eva ca idha adhippetā ati
translated: And the volition that is the root cause of these is called malicious speech, etc., and that is what is intended here.

original: Tattha saṃkiliṭṭhacittassa paresaṃ vā bhedāya attano piyakamyatāya vā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: tattha saṃkiliṭṭha cittassa paresam vā bhedāya attanaḥ piya kamyatāya vā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: Herein, the volition that occurs in one whose mind is corrupted, either to break up others’ friendship or to make himself dear, and that instigates bodily and verbal effort,

original: cetanā pisuṇavācā. Sā yassa bhedaṃ karoti, tassa appaguṇatāya appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā.
analyzed: cetanā pisuṇa vācā sā yassa bhedam karoti tassa appaguṇa tāya appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā
translated: is malicious speech. It is less blameworthy when the person whose friendship is broken is of less distinction, and it is more blameworthy when he is of greater distinction.

original: Tassā cattāro sambhārā – bhinditabbo paro, “iti ime nānā bhavissanti, vinā bhavissantī”ti
analyzed: tassā cattāro sambhārā bhinditabbo paraḥ iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissanti iti
translated: or the intention to split them up by thinking, “Thus they will be different, they will be divided,”🔽or the desire for popularity by thinking, “Thus I shall be dear and popular,”

original: bhedapurekkhāratā vā, “iti ahaṃ piyo bhavissāmi vissāsiko”ti piyakamyatā vā, tajjo
analyzed: bheda purekkhāra tā vā iti aham piyaḥ bhavissāmi vissāsikaḥ iti piya kamya tā vā tajjo
translated: or the effort to that end, or the knowledge of the purpose of that .

original: vāyāmo, tassa tadatthavijānananti. Imesaṃ bhedāyāti, yesaṃ itoti vuttānaṃ santike🔽sutaṃ tesaṃ bhedāya.
analyzed: tassa tad attha vijānanan ti imesam bhedāya ati yesam itas ti vuttānam santike  sutam tesam bhedāya
translated: For the sake of their division: for the sake of those who are mentioned as “these” being divided.

original: Bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātāti dvinnaṃ mittānaṃ vā samānupajjhāyakādīnaṃ vā kenacideva kāraṇena
analyzed: bhinnānam vā sandhātā ati dvinnam mittānam vā samāna upajjhāyaka ādīnam vā kenacid eva kāraṇena
translated: Or for the sake of uniting those who are divided: for the sake of uniting those who are divided, either two friends or two pupils of the same teacher, etc., by any means,

original: bhinnānaṃ ekamekaṃ upasaṅkamitvā “tumhākaṃ īdise kule jātānaṃ evaṃ bahussutānaṃ idaṃ
analyzed: bhinnānam ekam ekam upasaṅkamitvā tumhākam īdise kule jātānam evam bahu sutānam idam
translated: by approaching each one separately and saying, “This is not proper for those born in such and such clans, so learned as you are,” and so on.

original: na yutta”ntiādīni vatvā sandhānaṃ kattā anukattā. Anuppadātāti sandhānānuppadātā.
analyzed: na yutta nti ādīni vatvā sandhānam kattā anukattā anuppadātā ati sandhāna anuppadātā
translated: For the sake of not causing the arising of what has not arisen: for the sake of not causing the arising of what has not arisen, namely, the uniting.

original: Dve jane samagge disvā – “tumhākaṃ evarūpe kule jātānaṃ evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānaṃ
analyzed: dve jane samagge disvā tumhākam evarūpe kule jātānam evarūpehi guṇehi samannāgatānam
translated: Having seen two people in agreement, thinking, “Those born in such and such clans, endowed with such and such qualities,

original: anucchavikameta”ntiādīni vatvā daḷhīkammaṃ kattāti attho. Samaggo ārāmo assāti samaggārāmo.
analyzed: anucchavikam etat ti ādīni vatvā daḷhīkammam kattā ati attho samaggaḥ ārāmaḥ assa ati samagga ārāmaḥ
translated: and he should make it firm by saying, “This is proper for me” and so on. The meaning is that he should make it strong.

original: Yattha samaggā natthi, tattha vasitumpi na icchatīti attho. Samaggarāmotipi pāḷi,
analyzed: yattha samaggā na atthi tattha vasitum pi na icchati iti
translated: He is one who delights in unity: he does not want to live where there is no unity. The text reads samagga-rāmo,

original: ayamevettha attho. Samaggaratoti samaggesu rato, te pahāya aññattha gantumpi na icchatīti🔽attho. Samagge disvāpi sutvāpi nandatīti samagganandī, samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitāti
analyzed: ayam eva ittha attho samagga rato ti samaggesu rato te pahāya aññattha gantum pi naḥ icchati iti  samagge disvā api sutvā api nandati iti samagga nandī samagga karaṇim vācam bhāsitā ati
translated: but the meaning is the same. He is one who delights in unity: he does not want to go elsewhere, leaving the united.

original: yā vācā satte samaggeyeva karoti, taṃ sāmaggiguṇaparidīpikameva vācaṃ bhāsati, na itaranti.
analyzed: yā vācā satte samaggeya iva karoti tam sāmaggi guṇa paridīpikam eva vācam bhāsati na itaranti
translated: He is one who rejoices in unity: he is glad to see and hear about unity. He speaks speech that creates unity: he speaks speech that reveals the special qualities of unity, not the opposite.

original: Parassa mammacchedakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā ekantapharusacetanā pharusāvācā.🔽Tassā āvibhāvatthamidaṃ vatthu – eko kira dārako mātuvacanaṃ anādiyitvā araññaṃ gacchati,
analyzed: parassa ekanta pharusa cetanā pharusā avācā  tassāḥ āvibhāva attham idam vatthu ekaḥ kira dārakaḥ mātu vacanam an ādiyitvā araññam gacchati
translated: Harsh speech is the intention to hurt that is the source of bodily and verbal acts of molesting another.🔽The following story illustrates its analysis. A certain boy, it seems, went to the forest without paying attention to his mother’s words.

original: taṃ mātā nivattetumasakkontī – “caṇḍā taṃ mahiṃsī anubandhatū”ti akkosi. Athassa
analyzed: tam mātā nivattetum a sakkontī caṇḍā tam mahiṃsī anubandhatu iti akkosi athassa
translated: Unable to make him turn back, she cursed him: “May a fierce buffalo pursue you!”

original: tatheva araññe mahiṃsī uṭṭhāsi. Dārako “yaṃ mama mātā mukhena kathesi, taṃ mā hotu,
analyzed: tathā iva araññe mahiṃsī uṭṭhāsi dārakaḥ yam mama mātā mukhena kathesi tam mā hotu
translated: and the cow stood still in the forest. The boy thought, “Let not what my mother said with her mouth come to pass,

original: yaṃ cittena cintesi taṃ hotū”ti, saccakiriyamakāsi. Mahiṃsī tattheva baddhā viya
analyzed: yam cittena cintesi tam hotu uti mahiṃsī tattha iva baddhā viya
translated: but let what she thought in her heart come to pass.” And he performed the action of truth. The cow stood there as though tied,

original: aṭṭhāsi. Evaṃ mammacchedakopi payogo cittasaṇhatāya na pharusā vācā hoti. Mātāpitaro
analyzed: evam payogo citta saṇhatāya na pharusā vācā hoti mātā pitaro
translated: and the boy was able to lead her home. Thus speech that is harsh is not so by reason of the words but by reason of the intention.

original: hi kadāci puttake evaṃ vadanti – “corā vo khaṇḍākhaṇḍaṃ karontū”ti, uppalapattampi
analyzed: hi kadāci puttake evam vadanti corāḥ vaḥ khaṇḍākhaṇḍam karontu iti uppala pattam pi
translated: For parents sometimes say to their children, “Let thieves cut you to pieces limb by limb,”

original: ca nesaṃ upari patantaṃ na icchanti. Ācariyupajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evaṃ vadanti
analyzed: ca nesam upari patantam na icchanti ācariya upajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake evam vadanti
translated: and yet they do not want even a lotus leaf to fall on them. And teachers and preceptors sometimes say to their pupils,🔽“What is this you have done, you shameless one? Get out of here,”

original: – “kiṃ ime ahirīkā anottappino caranti, niddhamatha ne”ti, atha ca nesaṃ āgamādhigamasampattiṃ🔽icchanti. Yathā ca cittasaṇhatāya pharusā vācā na hoti, evaṃ vacanasaṇhatāya apharusā
analyzed: kim ime ahirīkāḥ anottappino caranti atha ca āgama adhigama sampattim  icchanti yathā ca citta saṇhatāya pharusā vācā na evam vacana saṇhatāya a pharusā
translated: and yet they want them to acquire the scriptures and the supernormal powers.🔽And just as speech is not harsh by reason of the words but by reason of the intention, so it is not gentle by reason of the words but by reason of the intention. For the words, “Lie down and sleep happily,”

original: vācā na hoti. Na hi mārāpetukāmassa – “imaṃ sukhaṃ sayāpethā”ti vacanaṃ apharusā
analyzed: vācā na hoti na hi mārāpetu kāmassa imam sukham vacanam a pharusā
translated: spoken by one who wants to kill are not gentle by reason of the words.

original: vācā hoti, cittapharusatāya panesā pharusā vācāva. Sā yaṃ sandhāya pavattitā, tassa🔽appaguṇatāya appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā tayo sambhārā – akkositabbo
analyzed: vācā hoti citta pharusa tāya pana isā pharusā vācā ava sā yam sandhāya pavattitā tassa  appaguṇa tāya appasāvajjā mahāguṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā tassā tayo sambhārā akkositabbo
translated: But because of the harshness of the mind, it is also harsh speech.🔽It is less blameworthy when it occurs in one who has few good qualities, and more blameworthy when it occurs in one who has great good qualities.🔽It has three constituents: one who should be abused,

original: paro, kupitacittaṃ, akkosanāti.
analyzed: paras kupita cittam
translated: It is harsh speech because it is harshness of mind. It is less reprehensible when it is used with reference to one who has few good qualities, and more reprehensible when used with reference to one who has great good qualities. It has three constituents: another person who is to be scolded, a mind that is angry, and the scolding.

original: Nelāti elaṃ vuccati doso, nāssā elanti nelā, niddosāti attho. “Nelaṅgo setapacchādo”ti,🔽ettha vuttanelaṃ viya. Kaṇṇasukhāti byañjanamadhuratāya kaṇṇānaṃ sukhā, sūcivijjhanaṃ🔽viya kaṇṇasūlaṃ na janeti. Atthamadhuratāya sakalasarīre kopaṃ ajanetvā pemaṃ janetīti
analyzed: na ilā ti elam vuccati dosaḥ na assā elanti na ilā niddosā ati attho na ilaṅgo seta pacchādo ti  ettha vutta nelam viya byañjana madhura tāya kaṇṇānam sukhā  viya kaṇṇa sūlam na janeti attha madhura tāya sakala sarīre kopam a janetvā pa imam janeti iti
translated: Nelā is a name for hate. It is not nelā because it does not have nelā , that is, because it is free from hate, as in the passage, “Nelā-limbed, white- coated” .

original: pemanīyā. Hadayaṃ gacchati, appaṭihaññamānā sukhena cittaṃ pavisatīti hadayaṅgamā.
analyzed: pemanīyā hadayam gacchati a paṭihaññamānā sukhena cittam pavisati iti hadayaṅgamā
translated: Kaṇṇasukhā is pleasant to the ear because of the sweetness of the expression, like a needle of cotton-wool does not cause pain in the ear. Because of the sweetness of the meaning it does not cause irritation in the body, but it causes love to arise, thus it is lovely. It goes to the heart, it enters the mind easily without being repulsed, thus it is heart-winning.

original: Guṇaparipuṇṇatāya pure bhavāti porī pure saṃvaḍḍhanārī viya sukumārātipi porī. Purassa
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa tāya pure bhavāti porī pure porī purassa
translated: It is soft because it is full of good qualities, like a woman who has been brought up in comfort. It is soft because it is not harsh, like a soft bed.

original: esātipi porī. Nagaravāsīnaṃ kathāti attho. Nagaravāsino hi yuttakathā honti. Pitimattaṃ
analyzed: porī nagara vāsīnam kathā ati atthaḥ nagara vāsinaḥ hi yutta kathāḥ honti
translated: “They say” means “they speak.” The meaning is, “the talk of town-dwellers.” For town-dwellers are talkative. They say “father” when they mean “uncle,”

original: pitāti vadanti, bhātimattaṃ bhātāti vadanti, mātimattaṃ mātāti vadanti. Evarūpī kathā
analyzed: pitā ati vadanti bhātimattam bhātā ati vadanti mātimattam mātā ati vadanti evarūpī kathā
translated: “brother” when they mean “cousin,” and “mother” when they mean “aunt.” Such talk

original: bahuno janassa kantā hotīti bahujanakantā. Kantabhāveneva bahuno janassa manāpā cittavuḍḍhikarāti bahujanamanāpā.🔽Anatthaviññāpikā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā akusalacetanā samphappalāpo. So āsevanamandatāya
analyzed: bahuno janassa kantā hoti iti bahu jana kantā kanta bhāvena iva bahunaḥ janassa manāpā citta vuḍḍhi karā ati bahu jana manāpā  anattha viññāpikā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā akusala cetanā samphappalāpaḥ saḥ āsevana manda tāya
translated: is “dear to many people” because it is liked by many people. It is “agreeable to many people” because it is liked by many people and because it increases their mental satisfaction.

original: appasāvajjo, āsevanamahantatāya mahāsāvajjo, tassa dve sambhārā – bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādiniratthakakathāpurekkhāratā,
analyzed: appasāvajjaḥ āsevana mahanta tāya mahāsāvajjaḥ tassa dve sambhārā bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa ādi niratthaka kathā purekkhāra tā
translated: Frivolous speech is an unprofitable choice of consciousness that is a source of bodily and verbal effort and that announces what is not beneficial. It is “less blamable” when its repetition is slight and “more blamable” when its repetition is great. Its two constituents are the desire to talk about such pointless things as the battle of the Bharatas or the abduction of Sita,

original: tathārūpī kathā kathanañca.🔽Kālena vadatīti kālavādī vattabbayuttakālaṃ sallakkhetvā vadatīti attho. Bhūtaṃ tathaṃ
analyzed: tathārūpī kathā kathanañca  kālena vadati iti kāla vādī vattabba yutta kālam sallakkhetvā vadati iti atthaḥ bhūtam tatham
translated: and the talking about them.

original: tacchaṃ sabhāvameva vadatīti bhūtavādī. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikatthasannissitameva
analyzed: tat śam sabhāvam eva vadati iti bhūta vādī diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika attha sannissitam eva
translated: “One who speaks at the proper time” is one who speaks after considering the proper time for what should be said. “One who speaks what is correct” is one who speaks what is factual, true, and real. “One who speaks what is in accordance with the goal” is one who speaks what is connected with the good of this life and the next.

original: katvā vadatīti atthavādī. Navalokuttaradhammasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti dhammavādī
analyzed: katvā vadati iti attha vādī nava lokuttara dhamma sannissitam katvā vadati iti dhamma vādī
translated: He speaks having made it dependent on the nine supramundane states: thus he is a “Dhamma speaker.”

original: saṃvaravinayapahānavinayasannissitaṃ katvā vadatīti vinayavādī.
analyzed: saṃvara vinaya pahāna vinaya sannissitam katvā vadati iti vinaya vādī
translated: He speaks having made it dependent on restraint, on the relinquishment of the training precepts, and on the relinquishment of defilements: thus he is a “Vinaya speaker.”

original: Nidhānaṃ vuccati ṭhapanokāso, nidhānamassā atthīti nidhānavatī. Hadaye nidhātabbayuttakaṃ🔽vācaṃ bhāsitāti attho. Kālenāti evarūpiṃ bhāsamānopi ca – “ahaṃ nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ
analyzed: nidhānam vuccati ṭhapana ukāsaḥ nidhānam assāḥ atthi iti nidhānavatī hadaye nidhātabba yuttakam  vācam bhāsitā ati kālena ati evarūpim bhāsamānaḥ api ca aham nidhānavatim vācam
translated: A place for keeping is called a “store” . He has a store: thus he is “possessing a store.”🔽He speaks words that are fit to be kept in the heart: that is the meaning.

original: bhāsissāmī”ti na akālena bhāsati, yuttakālaṃ pana apekkhitvāva bhāsatīti attho. Sāpadesanti🔽saupamaṃ, sakāraṇanti attho. Pariyantavatinti paricchedaṃ dassetvā yathāssā paricchedo🔽paññāyati, evaṃ bhāsatīti attho. Atthasaṃhitanti anekehipi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātuṃ
analyzed: bhāsissāmi iti na akālena bhāsati yutta kālam pana apekkhitvā ava bhāsati iti attho sa apadesan ti  saupamam sakāraṇam ti paricchedam dassetvā yathā assā paricchedaḥ  paññāyati evam bhāsati iti atthaḥ attha saṃhitan ti anekehi pi nayehi vibhajantena pariyādātum
translated: Even when he speaks in this way, he does not speak at the wrong time, thinking: “I shall speak words possessing a store.” The meaning is that he speaks after considering the right time.🔽With a reason, with an illustration: that is the meaning.🔽Having shown the limit, he speaks in such a way that the limit of it may be known. That is the meaning.

original: asakkuṇeyyatāya atthasampannaṃ bhāsati. Yaṃ vā so atthavādī atthaṃ vadati, tena atthena
analyzed: a sakkuṇeyyatāya attha sampannam bhāsati yam vā saḥ attha vādī attham vadati tena atthena
translated: He speaks with a meaning that is rich in meaning, since it cannot be exhausted even by the analysis of many methods. Or else, he speaks with the meaning that the Dhamma speaker speaks about.🔽With that meaning,

original: sahitattā atthasaṃhitaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, na aññaṃ nikkhipitvā aññaṃ bhāsatīti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽10. Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhāti mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījanti
analyzed: sahita ttā attha saṃhitam vācam bhāsati na aññam nikkhipitvā aññam bhāsati iti vuttam hoti  bīja gāma bhūta gāma samārambhā ati mūla bījam khandha bījam phaḷu bījam agga bījam bīja bījanti
translated: He speaks in a way that is connected with a meaning, that is to say, he does not leave one thing and go on to another without finishing what he started.🔽“Injuring seed and crops”: the five kinds of seeds, namely, root-seeds, stem-seeds, joint-seeds, seed-fruit-seeds, and rootlet-and-shoot-seeds.

original: pañcavidhassa bījagāmassa ceva, yassa kassaci nīlatiṇarukkhādikassa bhūtagāmassa
analyzed: pañcavidhassa bīja gāmassa ca iva yassa kassaci nīla tiṇa rukkha ādikassa bhūta gāmassa
translated: And also any kind of crop, such as blue-green grass, trees, etc.

original: ca samārambhā, chedanabhedanapacanādibhāvena vikopanā paṭiviratoti attho.
analyzed: ca samārambhā chedana bhedana pacana ādi bhāvena vikopanā paṭivirataḥ ti attho
translated: The meaning is that he refrains from injuring them by cutting, breaking, burning, etc.

original: Ekabhattikoti pātarāsabhattaṃ sāyamāsabhattanti dve bhattāni, tesu pātarāsabhattaṃ
analyzed: ekabhattikā iti pātarāsa bhattam sāyamāsa bhattanti dve bhattāni tesu pātarāsa bhattam
translated: “Eating in one part of the day”: there are two meals, the morning meal and the evening meal. Of these, the morning meal

original: antomajjhanhikena paricchinnaṃ, itaraṃ majjhanhikato uddhaṃ anto aruṇena. Tasmā antomajjhanhike
analyzed: antomajjhanhikena paricchinnam itaram majjhanhikataḥ uddham antar aruṇena tasmai antomajjhanhike
translated: is limited to the period before midday. The other is limited to the period after midday and before sunrise. Therefore,

original: dasakkhattuṃ bhuñjamānopi ekabhattikova hoti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “ekabhattiko”ti.
analyzed: dasa khattum bhuñjamānaḥ api ekabhattikaḥ va hoti tam sandhāya vuttam ekabhattikaḥ ti
translated: even if one eats ten meals in one day, one is still an “eater in one part of the day.” It is with reference to this that it is said: “He eats in one part of the day.”

original: Rattiyā bhojanaṃ ratti, tato uparatoti rattūparato. Atikkante majjhanhike yāva sūriyatthaṅgamanā
analyzed: rattiyā bhojanam tatas uparato ti rattu uparato atikkante majjhanhike yāva sūriyatthaṅgamanā
translated: “Abstaining from eating at night”: “night” is the period from sunset to sunrise.

original: bhojanaṃ vikālabhojanaṃ nāma. Tato viratattā virato vikālabhojanā. Kadā virato? Anomānadītīre
analyzed: bhojanam vikālabhojanam nāma tatas viratattā virataḥ vikālabhojanā kadā virataḥ anomānadī tīre
translated: Eating is called “eating at the wrong time.” He is refrained from eating at the wrong time because he has refrained from that. When was he refrained?

original: pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya.
analyzed: pabbajita divasataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: From the day of his going forth on the bank of the river Anomā.

original: Sāsanassa ananulomattā visūkaṃ paṭāṇībhūtaṃ dassananti visūkadassanaṃ. Attanā naccananaccāpanādivasena
analyzed: sāsanassa an anuloma ttā visūkam paṭāṇībhūtam visūka dassanam attanā
translated: Because it is not in conformity with the Dispensation, it is a corruption, and it is a spectacle, thus it is a corruption and a spectacle. Dancing is dancing by oneself or getting others to dance,

original: naccā ca gītā ca vāditā ca antamaso mayūranaccādivasenapi pavattānaṃ naccādīnaṃ visūkabhūtā🔽dassanā cāti naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā. Naccādīni hi attanā payojetuṃ vā parehi
analyzed: naccā ca gītā ca vāditā ca antamasaḥ mayūra naccā divasena api naccā ādīnam visūka bhūtā  dassanā ca ati nacca gīta vādita visūka dassanā nacca ādīni hi attanā payojetum vā parehi
translated: and singing and music are singing and playing music, even if it is only the dancing of peacocks, etc., and it is a corruption and a spectacle.

original: payojāpetuṃ vā payuttāni passituṃ vā neva bhikkhūnaṃ na bhikkhunīnañca vaṭṭanti.🔽Mālādīsu mālāti yaṃ kiñci pupphaṃ. Gandhanti yaṃ kiñci gandhajātaṃ. Vilepananti chavirāgakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: vā payuttāni passitum vā na iva bhikkhūnam na bhikkhunīnam ca vaṭṭanti  mālā ādīsu mālā ati yam kiñci puppham gandhanti yam kiñci gandha jātam chavi rāga karaṇam
translated: Because it is a corruption and a spectacle, thus it is the corruption and spectacle of dancing, singing, and music. For it is not allowable for bhikkhus or bhikkhunīs to see dancing, etc., that is fit for oneself to perform or to get others to perform.🔽As regards garlands, etc., a garland is any flower. Perfume is any kind of scent. Oil-seed flour is what is made from the seeds of the sesamum plant, etc.

original: Tattha piḷandhanto dhāreti nāma, ūnaṭṭhānaṃ pūrento maṇḍeti nāma, gandhavasena chavirāgavasena
analyzed: tattha piḷandhantaḥ dhārā iti nāma ūna ṭṭhānam pūrentaḥ maṇḍā iti nāma gandha vasena chavi rāga vasena
translated: Herein, one who wears it is said to “use” it, and one who replenishes a deficiency is said to “apply” it. Because of the scent and because of the oil-seed flour’s colour, etc.,

original: ca sādiyanto vibhūseti nāma. Ṭhānaṃ vuccati kāraṇaṃ. Tasmā yāya dussīlyacetanāya
analyzed: ca vibhūsā iti nāma ṭhānam vuccati kāraṇam tasmai yāya dussīlya cetanāya
translated: and adorns himself with them. “Place” is a reason. Therefore, “refraining from” means refraining from the unvirtuous volition

original: tāni mālādhāraṇādīni mahājano karoti, tato paṭiviratoti attho.
analyzed: tāni mālā dhāraṇa ādīni mahājanaḥ karoti tatas paṭivirataḥ ti attho
translated: by means of which the multitude adorns itself with garlands, etc.

original: Uccāsayanaṃ vuccati pamāṇātikkantaṃ. Mahāsayananti akappiyapaccattharaṇaṃ. Tato viratoti attho.
analyzed: uccāsayanam vuccati pamāṇa atikkantam mahā sayanam ti akappiya paccattharaṇam tatas virataḥ ti attho
translated: “High couches” are those exceeding the right size. “Large couches” are those with improper spreads. “Refraining from” means refraining from using them.

original: Jātarūpanti suvaṇṇaṃ. Rajatanti kahāpaṇo, lohamāsako, jatumāsako, dārumāsakoti ye
analyzed: suvaṇṇam rajatanti kahāpaṇaḥ loha māsakaḥ jatu māsakaḥ dāru māsakaḥ iti ye
translated: “Gold and silver” : gold is gold, and silver is the kahāpaṇa coin, the iron māsaka coin, the copper jatu māsaka coin, and the wooden dāru māsaka coin,

original: vohāraṃ gacchanti. Tassa ubhayassāpi paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato, neva naṃ uggaṇhāti,
analyzed: vohāram gacchanti tassa ubhayassa api paṭiggahaṇā paṭivirataḥ na iva nam uggaṇhāti
translated: which are used in commerce. “Refraining from accepting” means that he does not accept either of them,

original: na uggaṇhāpeti, na upanikkhittaṃ sādiyatīti attho.
analyzed: na uggaṇhāpeti na upanikkhittam sādiyati iti attho
translated: does not have them accepted, and does not consent to their being deposited.

original: Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇāti, sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsakasaṅkhātassa sattavidhassāpi
analyzed: āmaka dhañña paṭiggahaṇā ti sāli vīhi yava godhūma kaṅgu varaka kudrūsaka saṅkhātassa sattavidhassa api
translated: “Accepting raw grain” : the accepting of the seven kinds of raw grain, namely, rice, barley, wheat, millet, wild gram, green gram, and beans,

original: āmakadhaññassa paṭiggahaṇā. Na kevalañca etesaṃ paṭiggahaṇameva, āmasanampi bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: āmaka dhaññassa paṭiggahaṇā na kevalam ca etesam paṭiggahaṇam eva āmasanam pi bhikkhūnam
translated: is not only the accepting of these, but also their cooking by the bhikkhus themselves.

original: na vaṭṭatiyeva. Āmakamaṃsapaṭiggahaṇāti ettha aññatra odissa anuññātā āmakamaṃsamacchānaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭatiyā iva āmaka maṃsa paṭiggahaṇā ti ettha aññatra odissa anuññātā āmaka maṃsa macchānam
translated: It is not allowable. As to the acceptance of raw flesh: here, except in the case of fish and meat that have been specifically allowed, the acceptance of raw flesh and raw fish is not allowable.

original: paṭiggahaṇameva bhikkhūnaṃ na vaṭṭati, no āmasanaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇam eva bhikkhūnam na vaṭṭati no āmasanam
translated: It is not allowable. As regards the acceptance of raw flesh: the acceptance of raw flesh and raw fish is not allowable for monks except when it has been specifically permitted.🔽But eating it is allowable.

original: Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇāti ettha itthīti purisantaragatā, itarā kumārikā nāma, tāsaṃ paṭiggahaṇampi āmasanampi akappiyameva.
analyzed: itthi kumārika paṭiggahaṇā ti ettha itthī iti purisa antara gatā itarā kumārikā nāma tāsam paṭiggahaṇam pi āmasanam pi a kappiyam eva
translated: As regards the acceptance of women and girls: a woman is one who has reached the age of puberty; the other is a girl. The acceptance of both and eating them are not allowable.

original: Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇāti ettha dāsidāsavaseneva tesaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ na vaṭṭati. “Kappiyakārakaṃ dammi, ārāmikaṃ dammī”ti evaṃ vutte pana vaṭṭati.
analyzed: dāsi dāsa paṭiggahaṇā ti ettha dāsi dāsa vasena iva tesam paṭiggahaṇam na vaṭṭati kappiya kārakam dammi ārāmikam dammi iti evam vutte pana vaṭṭati
translated: As regards the acceptance of male and female slaves: the acceptance of them as male and female slaves is not allowable. But it is allowable to say, “I give him as a worker,” or “I give him as a monastery attendant.”

original: Ajeḷakādīsu khettavatthupariyosānesu kappiyākappiyanayo vinayavasena upaparikkhitabbo.🔽Tattha khettaṃ nāma yasmiṃ pubbaṇṇaṃ ruhati. Vatthu nāma yasmiṃ aparaṇṇaṃ ruhati.
analyzed: ajeḷaka ādīsu khetta vatthu pariyosānesu kappiya akappiya nayaḥ vinaya vasena upaparikkhitabbo  tattha khettam nāma yasmim pubbaṇṇam ruhati vatthu nāma yasmim aparaṇṇam ruhati
translated: As regards the rest, beginning with goats, the method of what is allowable and what is not allowable should be investigated by the method of the Discipline.🔽Herein, a field is what is sown in the morning ripens in the evening; a plot of land is what is sown in the evening ripens in the morning.

original: Yattha vā ubhayampi ruhati, taṃ khettaṃ. Tadatthāya akatabhūmibhāgo vatthu. Khettavatthusīsena
analyzed: vai ubhayam pi ruhati tam khettam a kata bhūmi bhāgaḥ vatthu khetta vatthu sīsena
translated: Or a field is what is sown in both the morning and the evening. The land that has not been prepared for that purpose is a plot of land. The method of what is allowable and what is not allowable in the case of a field and a plot of land is this.

original: cettha vāpitaḷākādīnipi saṅgahitāneva.
analyzed: ca itthā vāpi taḷāka ādīni pi saṅgahitān eva
translated: Here too, such things as a dug-out canoe are included.🔽A message is a mission. A letter or a message sent to householders is a mission.

original: Dūteyyaṃ vuccati dūtakammaṃ, gihīnaṃ pahitaṃ paṇṇaṃ vā sāsanaṃ vā gahetvā tattha🔽tattha gamanaṃ. Pahiṇagamanaṃ vuccati gharā gharaṃ pesitassa khuddakagamanaṃ. Anuyogo
analyzed: dūteyyam vuccati dūta kammam gihīnam pahitam paṇṇam vā sāsanam vā gahetvā tattha  tattha gamanam pahiṇa gamanam vuccati gharā gharam pesitassa khuddaka gamanam anuyogo
translated: Going on a mission is going here and there to take a letter or a message to householders.🔽Going after is the doing of both.

original: nāma tadubhayakaraṇaṃ. Tasmā dūteyyapahiṇagamanānaṃ anuyogāti. Evamettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: nāma tad ubhaya karaṇam tasmā anuyogā ti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: So the meaning here should be understood thus: ‘after a message and after going on a mission.’

original: Kayavikkayāti kayā ca vikkayā ca. Tulākūṭādīsu kūṭanti vañcanaṃ. Tattha tulākūṭaṃ
analyzed: kaya vikkayā ati kayā ca vikkayā ca tulā kūṭa ādīsu kūṭanti vañcanam tattha tulā kūṭam
translated: Bartering is by bartering. In the case of false weights and so on, cheating is ‘trickery.’ Herein, trickery with weights is

original: nāma rūpakūṭaṃ aṅgakūṭaṃ, gahaṇakūṭaṃ, paṭicchannakūṭanti catubbidhaṃ hoti. Tattha🔽rūpakūṭaṃ nāma dve tulā samarūpā katvā gaṇhanto mahatiyā gaṇhāti, dadanto khuddikāya
analyzed: nāma rūpa kūṭam aṅga kūṭam gahaṇa kūṭam paṭicchanna kūṭanti catubbidham hoti tattha  rūpakūṭam nāma dve tulā sama rūpā katvā gaṇhantaḥ mahatiyā gaṇhāti dadantaḥ khuddikāya
translated: of four kinds: trickery with weights by using false weights, trickery with weights by using defective weights, trickery with weights by using weights that are correct but obtained dishonestly, and trickery with weights by concealment.🔽Herein, trickery with weights by using false weights is when one uses a false weight to cheat.🔽Trickery with weights by using defective weights is when one uses a correct weight that has been made defective by adding a counterweight inside.🔽Trickery with weights by using weights that are correct but obtained dishonestly is when one uses a correct weight obtained by theft.

original: deti. Aṅgakūṭaṃ nāma gaṇhanto pacchābhāge hatthena tulaṃ akkamati, dadanto pubbabhāge.
analyzed: deti aṅgakūṭam nāma gaṇhantaḥ pacchābhāge hatthena tulam akkamati dadantaḥ pubbabhāge
translated: Trickery with weights by concealment is of two kinds: concealment of the object to be weighed and concealment of the weight.

original: Gahaṇakūṭaṃ nāma gaṇhanto mūle rajjuṃ gaṇhāti, dadanto agge. Paṭicchannakūṭaṃ nāma
analyzed: gahaṇakūṭam nāma gaṇhantaḥ mūle rajjum gaṇhāti dadantaḥ agge paṭicchannakūṭam nāma
translated: The “weighing-fraud” is when the one who is weighing holds the scales low when he is taking up the goods and high when he is letting them down.🔽The “concealed-fraud” is when

original: tulaṃ susiraṃ katvā anto ayacuṇṇaṃ pakkhipitvā gaṇhanto taṃ pacchābhāge karoti, dadanto aggabhāge.
analyzed: tulam su siram katvā antar aya cuṇṇam pakkhipitvā gaṇhantaḥ tam pacchābhāge karoti dadantaḥ aggabhāge
translated: he makes a hole in the scales and inserts lead therein, and when he is weighing he holds it to the back and when he is paying out he holds it to the front.

original: Kaṃso vuccati suvaṇṇapāti, tāya vañcanaṃ kaṃsakūṭaṃ. Kathaṃ? Ekaṃ suvaṇṇapātiṃ katvā🔽aññā dve tisso lohapātiyo suvaṇṇavaṇṇe karoti, tato janapadaṃ gantvā kiñcideva aḍḍhaṃ
analyzed: kaṃsaḥ vuccati suvaṇṇa pāti tāya vañcanam kaṃsakūṭam katham ekam suvaṇṇa pātim katvā  aññāḥ dve tissaḥ loha pātiyaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇe karoti tatas janapadam gantvā kiñcid eva aḍḍham
translated: The “brass-fraud” is called a brass vessel. How is there a fraud with that? He makes one brass vessel

original: kulaṃ pavisitvā – “suvaṇṇabhājanāni kiṇathā”ti vatvā agghe pucchite samagghataraṃ
analyzed: kulam pavisitvā suvaṇṇa bhājanāni kiṇatha iti vatvā agghe pucchite samagghataram
translated: and two or three iron vessels the colour of brass. Then he goes to the country and enters a certain rich man’s house, saying “Buy brass vessels.” When the price is being discussed,

original: dātukāmā honti. Tato tehi – “kathaṃ imesaṃ suvaṇṇabhāvo jānitabbo”ti vutte, “vīmaṃsitvā
analyzed: dātu kāmāḥ honti tatas tehi katham imesam suvaṇṇa bhāvaḥ jānitabbaḥ iti vutte vīmaṃsitvā
translated: he is willing to give a high price. Then when they say “How can we know the quality of the brass?” he says “Weigh them and you will know.”

original: gaṇhathā”ti suvaṇṇapātiṃ pāsāṇe ghaṃsitvā sabbā pātiyo datvā gacchati.
analyzed: gaṇhatha ati suvaṇṇa pātim pāsāṇe ghaṃsitvā sabbā pātiyaḥ datvā gacchati
translated: He gives them all the brass vessels and goes away.

original: Mānakūṭaṃ nāma hadayabhedasikhābhedarajjubhedavasena tividhaṃ hoti. Tattha hadayabhedo
analyzed: mānakūṭam nāma hadaya bheda sikhā bheda rajju bheda vasena tividham hoti tattha hadaya bhedaḥ
translated: The “measure-fraud” is of three kinds: the “heart-deceiver,” the “joint-deceiver,” and the “string-deceiver.” Herein, the “heart-deceiver” is

original: sappitelādiminanakāle labbhati. Tāni hi gaṇhanto heṭṭhāchiddena mānena – “saṇikaṃ🔽āsiñcā”ti vatvā antobhājane bahuṃ paggharāpetvā gaṇhāti, dadanto chiddaṃ pidhāya🔽sīghaṃ pūretvā deti.
analyzed: sappi tela ādi minana kāle labbhati tāni hi gaṇhantaḥ heṭṭhā chiddena mānena  āsiñcāti vatvā antobhājane bahum pagghara apetvā gaṇhāti dadantaḥ chiddam pidhāya  sīgham pūretvā deti
translated: It is found when rice, sesamum, etc., are being measured out. For when he is taking it, he says, “Pour it in slowly,” and he takes it when it has trickled down a long way through the funnel. When he is giving it, he covers the hole in the funnel and he gives it when it is full.

original: Sikhābhedo tilataṇḍulādiminanakāle labbhati. Tāni hi gaṇhanto saṇikaṃ sikhaṃ ussāpetvā gaṇhāti, dadanto vegena pūretvā sikhaṃ chindanto deti.
analyzed: sikhā bhedaḥ tila taṇḍula ādi minana kāle labbhati tāni hi gaṇhantaḥ saṇikam sikham ussāpetvā gaṇhāti dadantaḥ vegena pūretvā sikham chindantaḥ deti
translated: It is found when sesamum, rice, etc., are being winnowed. For when he is taking it, he winnows it slowly, and he takes it when it has spread out. When he is giving, he gives it quickly, cutting off the end.

original: Rajjubhedo khettavatthuminanakāle labbhati. Lañjaṃ alabhantā hi khettaṃ amahantampi mahantaṃ katvā minanti.🔽Ukkoṭanādīsu ukkoṭananti assāmike sāmike kātuṃ lañjaggahaṇaṃ. Vañcananti tehi tehi
analyzed: rajju bhedaḥ khetta vatthu minana kāle labbhati lañjam a labhantā hi khettam amahantam pi mahantam katvā minanti  ukkoṭana ādīsu ukkoṭananti assāmike sāmike kātum lañjaggahaṇam tehi tehi
translated: It is found when a field is being measured out. For when they are not getting a fair deal, they make the field bigger than it is.🔽As to the kinds of cheating beginning with “overcharging”: overcharging is taking a toll by the ounce, etc., from those who do not know it. Short-changing is giving less than a fair amount by surreptitiously making use of what is left sticking to the hand, etc., when weighing out or measuring out.

original: upāyehi paresaṃ vañcanaṃ. Tatridamekaṃ vatthu – eko kira luddako migañca migapotakañca
analyzed: upāyehi paresam vañcanam tatra idam ekam vatthu ekaḥ kira luddakaḥ migañca miga potakañca
translated: Misrepresenting the weight is using a balance with a tampered weight to cheat another. Misrepresenting the measure is using a tampered measure to cheat another. Misrepresenting the quality is, for example, exchanging inferior goods for superior ones in the case of such goods as are sold by weight, such as treacle, jaggery, etc., or in the case of such goods as are sold by measure, such as sesame seed, rice, etc., or in the case of such goods as are sold “by sight,” such as clothes, etc.

original: gahetvā āgacchati, tameko dhutto – “kiṃ bho, migo agghati, kiṃ migapotako”ti āha.
analyzed: gahetvā āgacchati tam ekaḥ dhuttaḥ kim bho migaḥ agghati kim miga potakaḥ iti āha
translated: Here is a story. A certain hunter, it seems, was coming along with a deer and a young one. A certain highwayman asked, “What is the price of the deer, friend, and what is the price of the young one?”🔽“

original: “Migo dve kahāpaṇe, migapotako eka”nti ca vutte ekaṃ kahāpaṇaṃ datvā migapotakaṃ
analyzed: migaḥ dve kahāpaṇe miga potakaḥ ekam ti ca vutte ekam kahāpaṇam da tvā miga potakam
translated: “A deer is worth two kahāpaṇas, a young deer one kahāpaṇa,” the other said. So he gave him one kahāpaṇa and took the young deer.

original: gahetvā thokaṃ gantvā nivatto – “na me bho, migapotakena attho, migaṃ me dehī”ti
analyzed: gahetvā thokam gantvā nivattaḥ na me bho miga potakena atthaḥ migam me dehi iti
translated: After going a little way, he turned back and said, “I have no use for the young deer; give me the deer.”

original: āha. Tena hi – dve kahāpaṇe dehīti. So āha – “nanu te bho, mayā paṭhamaṃ eko kahāpaṇo🔽dinno”ti? “Āma, dinno”ti. “Idaṃ migapotakaṃ gaṇha, evaṃ so ca kahāpaṇo, ayañca kahāpaṇagghanako
analyzed: āha tena hi dve kahāpaṇe dehi iti saḥ āha nanu te bho mayā paṭhamam ekaḥ kahāpaṇaḥ  dinno ti āma dinno ti idam miga potakam gaṇha evam saḥ ca kahāpaṇaḥ ayam ca kahāpaṇa gghanakaḥ
translated: “Then give me two kahāpaṇas.” “But, good man, didn’t I give you one kahāpaṇa first?”🔽“Yes, you did.” “Take this young deer, and that kahāpaṇa, and this young deer worth a kahāpaṇa; that makes two kahāpaṇas.”

original: migapotakoti dve kahāpaṇā bhavissantī”ti. So “kāraṇaṃ vadatī”ti sallakkhetvā migapotakaṃ🔽gahetvā migaṃ adāsīti. Nikatīti yogavasena vā māyāvasena vā apāmaṅgaṃ pāmaṅganti,
analyzed: miga potako ti dve kahāpaṇāḥ bhavissanti iti so kāraṇam vadati iti sallakkhetvā miga potakam  migam adāsi iti yoga vasena vā māyā vasena vā apāmaṅgam pāmaṅganti
translated: He thought, “He is speaking sense,” took the young deer, and gave him the deer.

original: amaṇiṃ maṇinti, asuvaṇṇaṃ suvaṇṇanti katvā patirūpakena vañcanaṃ. Sāciyogoti kuṭilayogo,
analyzed: a maṇim maṇinti a suvaṇṇam suvaṇṇanti katvā pati rūpakena vañcanam kuṭila yogaḥ
translated: “Deceit by resemblance” is the deceiving of another by making what is not a gem resemble a gem, or what is not gold resemble gold, by means of one’s skill or by means of a trick. “Deceit by trickery” is the trickery of a crooked man.

original: etesaṃyeva ukkoṭanādīnametaṃ nāmaṃ. Tasmā – ukkoṭanasāciyogo, vañcanasāciyogo, nikatisāciyogoti,
analyzed: etesam yeva ukkoṭana ādīnam etam tasmai ukkoṭana sāci yogaḥ vañcana sāci yogaḥ nikati sāci yogaḥ iti
translated: So the meaning should be regarded thus: “The combination of cheating, the combination of swindling, the combination of fraud.”

original: evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Keci aññaṃ dassetvā aññassa parivattanaṃ sāciyogoti vadanti.
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo keci aññam dassetvā aññassa parivattanam sāciyogaḥ ti vadanti
translated: Some say that the combination of fraud is the substitution of something else after showing something else.

original: Taṃ pana vañcaneneva saṅgahitaṃ.
analyzed: tam pana vañcanena iva saṅgahitam
translated: But that is included in swindling.

original: Chedanādīsu chedananti hatthacchedanādi. Vadhoti māraṇaṃ. Bandhoti rajjubandhanādīhi🔽bandhanaṃ. Viparāmosoti himaviparāmoso, gumbaviparāmosoti duvidho. Yaṃ himapātasamaye
analyzed: chedana ādīsu chedananti hattha chedana ādi māraṇam bandhoti rajju bandhana ādīhi  bandhanam viparāmosaḥ iti hima viparāmosaḥ gumba viparāmosaḥ iti duvidhaḥ yam hima pāta samaye
translated: As regards cutting off, etc., “cutting off” is the cutting off of hands, etc., “killing” is the act of slaying, “imprisonment” is the act of binding with ropes, etc.,

original: himena paṭicchannā hutvā maggappaṭipannaṃ janaṃ musanti, ayaṃ himaviparāmoso. Yaṃ🔽gumbādīhi paṭicchannā musanti, ayaṃ gumbaviparāmoso. Ālopo vuccati gāmanigamādīnaṃ
analyzed: himena paṭicchannāḥ hutvā magga paṭipannam janam musanti ayam hima viparāmosaḥ yam  gumba ādīhi paṭicchannāḥ ayam gumba viparāmosaḥ ālopaḥ vuccati gāma nigama ādīnam
translated: “immolation” is of two kinds, namely, immolation by cold and immolation by heat. That which kills people who are on the road and are concealed by snow is “immolation by cold.”🔽That which kills people concealed by snow-covered bushes, etc., is “immolation by heat.” “Plunder” is the act of plundering villages, towns, etc.,

analyzed: vilopa karaṇam sahasākāroti sāhasika kiriyā geham pavisitvā manussānam sattham

analyzed: ṭhapetvā icchita bhaṇḍānam gahaṇam evam etasmai sahasākārā paṭivirataḥ samaṇaḥ  gotama uti iti vā hi bhikkhave puthujjanaḥ tathāgatassa vaṇṇam vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati

translated: And so, monks, a pu

analyzed: gilāna bhesajjam paribhuñjamānā ati sabbam etam vuttam eva hoti
translated: “Using the requisite of medicine for the sick” is all this.

original: Seyyathidanti nipāto. Tassattho katamo so bījagāmabhūtagāmo, yassa samārambhaṃ anuyuttā
analyzed: nipātaḥ tassa atthaḥ katamaḥ saḥ bīja gāma bhūta gāmaḥ yassa samārambham anuyuttā
translated: Seyyathidanti is a particle. Its meaning is this: “That seed-essence and plant-essence, the beginning of which is undertaken”

original: viharantīti. Tato taṃ dassento mūlabījantiādimāha. Tattha mūlabījaṃ nāma haliddi,
analyzed: viharanti iti tatas tam dassentaḥ mūla bīja nti ādim āha tattha mūla bījam nāma haliddi
translated: and “they live devoted to the use of which.” Then, showing that, he said “root-essence” and so on. Herein, root-essence is turmeric,

analyzed: siṅgiveram vacā vacattam ativisā kaṭukarohiṇī usīram bhadda muttakanti evamādi
translated: ginger, sweet flag, sweet root, ativisa, bitter cucumber, nut-grass, good-mango, and so on.

original: Khandhabījaṃ nāma assattho, nigrodho, pilakkho, udumbaro, kacchako, kapitthanoti🔽evamādi. Phaḷubījaṃ nāma ucchu, naḷo, veḷūti evamādi. Aggabījaṃ nāma ajjakaṃ, phaṇijjakaṃ,🔽hiriveranti evamādi. Bījabījaṃ nāma pubbaṇṇaṃ aparaṇṇanti evamādi. Sabbañhetaṃ rukkhato
analyzed: khandha bījam nāma assatthaḥ nigrodhaḥ pilakkhaḥ udumbaraḥ kacchakaḥ kapitthanaḥ ti  evamādi phaḷu bījam nāma ucchu naḷaḥ veḷu iti evamādi agga bījam nāma ajjakam phaṇijjakam  hiriveranti evamādi bīja bījam nāma pubbaṇṇam aparaṇṇam ti evamādi sabbam hetam rukkhataḥ
translated: Stem-essence is the acacia, the banyan, the Indian fig, the udumbara, the silk-cotton tree, the wood-apple, and so on.🔽Leaf-essence is the coconut palm, the reed, the bamboo, and so on. Flower-essence is the ajjaka, the phaṇijjaka,🔽the hrivera, and so on. Fruit-essence is the rice, the barley, the wheat, and so on. All this, when separated from the tree, is capable of growing and is called “seed-essence.” But when not separated from the tree and not dried up,

original: viyojitaṃ viruhanasamatthameva “bījagāmo”ti vuccati. Rukkhato pana aviyojitaṃ asukkhaṃ
analyzed: viyojitam viruhana samattham eva bīja gāmaḥ ti vuccati rukkhataḥ pana a viyojitam asukkham
translated: it is called “plant-essence.”

original: “bhūtagāmo”ti vuccati. Tattha bhūtagāmasamārambho pācittiyavatthu, bījagāmasamārambho
analyzed: bhūtagāmo ti vuccati tattha bhūtagāma samārambho pācittiya vatthu bījagāma samārambho
translated: “a plant” is what is meant. Herein, the undertaking of a plant is an offence of Expiation, the undertaking of a seed is an offence of wrong-doing.

original: dukkaṭavatthūti veditabbo.
analyzed: dukkaṭa vatthu iti veditabbaḥ

analyzed: ca sallekha vasena ca vinaya vasena tāva yam kiñci annam ajja paṭiggahitam aparajju  sannidhi kārakam hoti tassa paribhoge pācittiyam attanā laddham pana sāmaṇerānam
translated: and that according to the method of the ascetic Gotama. According to the Discipline, whatever kind of food is received today may be stored up for the next day;

original: Pānasannidhimhipi eseva nayo. Tattha pānaṃ nāma ambapānādīni aṭṭha pānāni, yāni ca tesaṃ anulomāni. Tesaṃ vinicchayo samantapāsādikāyaṃ vutto.
analyzed: pāna sannidhimhi pi esā iva nayo tattha pānam nāma amba pāna ādīni aṭṭha pānāni yāni ca tesam anulomāni tesam vinicchayo samantapāsādikāyam vutto
translated: The same method applies in the case of drinks. Herein, a drink is the eight kinds of drinks beginning with mango-drink, and whatever else is similar to that. The exposition of these is given in the Samantapāsādikā.

original: gandhe āharāpetvā tasmiṃ roge vūpasante aññesaṃ vā ābādhikānaṃ dātabbā, dvāre pañcaṅguligharadhūpanādīsu
analyzed: gandhe āhara apetvā tasmin roge vūpasante aññesam vā ābādhikānam dātabbā dvāre pañcaṅguli ghara dhūpana ādīsu
