original: vā upanetabbā. “Puna roge sati bhavissantī”ti pana ṭhapetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sannidhi
analyzed: vā upanetabbā puna roge sati bhavissanti iti pana ṭhapetum na vaṭṭati sannidhi
translated: He should not keep them, thinking, “When I am sick, I will use them.”

original: ca hoti, sallekhañca kopeti.🔽Āmisanti vuttāvasesaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ, idhekacco bhikkhu – “tathārūpe kāle
analyzed: ca hoti sat lekham ca kopa iti  āmisanti vutta avasesam daṭṭhabbam seyyathidam idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu tathārūpe kāle
translated: He would then be storing up and would be violating the ascetic qualities.🔽The rest of the material things should be understood in the same way as the medicines.

original: upakārāya bhavissatī”ti tilataṇḍulamuggamāsanāḷikeraloṇamacchamaṃsavallūrasappitelaguḷabhājanādīni
analyzed: upakārāya bhavissati iti tila taṇḍula mugga māsa nāḷikera loṇa maccha maṃsa vallūra sappi tela guḷa bhājana ādīni
translated: Herein, a monk has sesame seeds, rice, kidney beans, mung beans, black gram, chickpeas, green gram, lentils, sugar cane, salt, fish, meat, curd, milk, ghee, oil, honey, molasses, pots, etc., brought and stored, thinking, “They will be useful at such and such a time.”

original: āharāpetvā ṭhapeti. So vassakāle kālasseva sāmaṇerehi yāguṃ pacāpetvā paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: āharāpetvā ṭhapeti saḥ vassa kāle kālassa iva sāmaṇerehi yāgum pacāpetvā paribhuñjitvā
translated: In the rainy season, he has the novices cook rice gruel early in the morning. After eating it,

original: “sāmaṇera, udakakaddame dukkhaṃ gāmaṃ pavisituṃ, gaccha asukaṃ kulaṃ gantvā mayhaṃ
analyzed: sāmaṇera udaka kaddame dukkham gāmam pavisitum gaccha asukam kulam gantvā mayham
translated: he sends the novices away, saying, “Novice, it is painful to enter the village when it is muddy. Go to such and such a family and tell them,

original: vihāre nisinnabhāvaṃ ārocehi; asukakulato dadhiādīni āharā”ti peseti. Bhikkhūhi –
analyzed: vihāre nisinna bhāvam ārocehi asuka kulataḥ dadhi ādīni āharāti peseti bhikkhūhi
translated: ‘The master of the house is sitting in the monastery. He wants curd and so on from such and such a family.’ ”

original: “kiṃ, bhante, gāmaṃ pavisissathā”ti vuttepi, “duppaveso, āvuso, idāni gāmo”ti vadati.
analyzed: kim bhante gāmam pavisissatha ati vutte pi duppavesaḥ āvuso idāni gāmaḥ ti vadati
translated: When monks say to him, “Venerable sir, why do you enter the village?” he says, “Friend, it is painful to enter the village now.”

original: Te – “hotu, bhante, acchatha tumhe, mayaṃ bhikkhaṃ pariyesitvā āharissāmā”ti gacchanti.
analyzed: te hotu bhante tumhe mayam bhikkham pariyesitvā āharissāma ati gacchanti
translated: They say, “Very well, venerable sirs, go; we will look for alms and bring them to you.”

original: Atha sāmaṇeropi dadhiādīni āharitvā bhattañca byañjanañca sampādetvā upaneti, taṃ
analyzed: atha sāmaṇeraḥ api dadhi ādīni āharitvā bhattam ca byañjanam ca sampādetvā upaneti tam
translated: Then the novice monk brings curd, etc., and prepares the meal and the curry and serves it.

original: bhuñjantasseva upaṭṭhākā bhattaṃ pahiṇanti, tatopi manāpaṃ manāpaṃ bhuñjati. Atha
analyzed: bhuñjantassa iva upaṭṭhākāḥ bhattam pahiṇanti tatas api manāpam manāpam bhuñjati atha
translated: While he is eating, the attendants send more food, and he eats that too, which is also good.

original: bhikkhū piṇḍapātaṃ gahetvā āgacchanti, tatopi manāpaṃ manāpaṃ gīvāyāmakaṃ bhuñjatiyeva.
analyzed: bhikkhū piṇḍapātam gahetvā āgacchanti tatas api manāpam manāpam gīvāyāmakam bhuñjatiyā iva
translated: Then the monks come back with alms food, and he eats that too, which is also good and plentiful.

original: Evaṃ catumāsampi vītināmeti. Ayaṃ vuccati – “bhikkhu muṇḍakuṭumbikajīvikaṃ jīvati,
analyzed: evam catu māsam pi vītināma iti ayam vuccati bhikkhu muṇḍa kuṭumbika jīvikam jīvati
translated: Thus he spends four months. This is called “a monk who lives the life of a Muṇḍakuṭumbika,

original: na samaṇajīvika”nti. Evarūpo āmisasannidhi nāma hoti.
analyzed: na evarūpaḥ āmisasannidhi nāma hoti
translated: not the life of an ascetic.” This is called “a store of requisites.”

original: Bhikkhuno pana vasanaṭṭhāne ekā taṇḍulanāḷi, eko guḷapiṇḍo, catubhāgamattaṃ sappīti
analyzed: bhikkhuno pana vasanaṭṭhāne ekā taṇḍula nāḷi ekaḥ guḷa piṇḍo catu bhāga mattam sappi iti
translated: But a monk is allowed to keep a store of requisites consisting of one measure of rice, one lump of jaggery, and a quarter nāḷika measure of ghee

original: ettakaṃ nidhetuṃ vaṭṭati, akāle sampattacorānaṃ atthāya. Te hi ettakampi āmisapaṭisanthāraṃ
analyzed: ettakam nidhetum vaṭṭati akāle sampatta corānam atthāya te hi ettakam pi āmisa paṭisanthāram
translated: in the place where he lives, for the sake of thieves who might come at the wrong time. For this much of a store of requisites is allowed for him,

original: alabhantā jīvitāpi voropeyyuṃ, tasmā sace ettakaṃ natthi, āharāpetvāpi ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: a labhantā jīvitā api voropeyyum tasmā sace ettakam na atthi āharāpetvā api ṭhapetum vaṭṭati
translated: If they cannot get it, they might even kill him. So if there is not that much, it is allowable to have it brought and stored.

original: Aphāsukakāle ca yadettha kappiyaṃ, taṃ attanāpi paribhuñjituṃ vaṭṭati. Kappiyakuṭiyaṃ🔽pana bahuṃ ṭhapentassāpi sannidhi nāma natthi. Tathāgatassa pana taṇḍulanāḷiādīsu
analyzed: a phāsuka kāle ca yat ettha kappiyam tam attanā api paribhuñjitum vaṭṭati kappiya kuṭiyam  pana bahum ṭhapentassa api sannidhi nāma natthi tathāgatassa pana taṇḍula nāḷi ādīsu
translated: And at a time of scarcity whatever is allowable here may be used by oneself.🔽But there is no storing even in a storehouse for allowable things.

original: vā yaṃ kiñci caturatanamattaṃ vā pilotikakhaṇḍaṃ “idaṃ me ajja vā sve vā bhavissatī”ti🔽ṭhapitaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: vā yam kiñci caturatana mattam vā pilotika khaṇḍam idam me ajja vā sve vā bhavissati iti  ṭhapitam nāma natthi
translated: But in the case of the Tathāgata there is nothing stored even to the extent of a handful of grain or a piece of broken potsherd the size of a mere thumbnail, thinking “This will be for tomorrow or the next day.”

original: 13. Visūkadassanesu naccaṃ nāma yaṃ kiñci naccaṃ, taṃ maggaṃ gacchantenāpi gīvaṃ🔽pasāretvā daṭṭhuṃ na vaṭṭati. Vitthāravinicchayo panettha samantapāsādikāyaṃ vuttanayeneva🔽veditabbo. Yathā cettha, evaṃ sabbesu sikkhāpadapaṭisaṃyuttesu suttapadesu. Ito parañhi
analyzed: visūka dassanesu naccam nāma yam kiñci naccam tam maggam gacchantena api gīvam  pasāretvā daṭṭhum na vaṭṭati vitthāra vinicchayo pana ittha samantapāsādikāyam vutta nayena iva  veditabbaḥ yathā ca ittha evam sabbesu sikkhāpada paṭisaṃyuttesu sutta padesu itas param hi
translated: As regards the “dancing, etc.,” any kind of dancing is what is meant. It is not allowable for one who is on a journey even to look at it by turning his neck;🔽the detailed explanation should be understood as given in the Samantapāsādikā.🔽And as in this case, so also in the case of all the terms of the training precepts and the passages that are recited.

original: ettakampi avatvā tattha tattha payojanamattameva vaṇṇayissāmāti.
analyzed: ettakam pi a vatvā tattha tattha payojana mattam eva vaṇṇayissāma ati
translated: For from now on we shall not quote more than just the headings, and we shall comment only on the purpose of each rule.

original: Pekkhanti naṭasamajjaṃ. Akkhānanti bhāratayujjhanādikaṃ. Yasmiṃ ṭhāne kathīyati,
analyzed: pekkhanti naṭasa majjam akkhānanti bhāratayujjhana ādikam yasmin ṭhāne kathīyati
translated: ‘Acclamations’ is the shouting of ‘Bravo!’ in a contest of wrestlers, etc.🔽It is not allowable to go there where it is being done.

original: tattha gantumpi na vaṭṭati. Pāṇissaranti kaṃsatāḷaṃ, pāṇitāḷantipi vadanti. Vetāḷanti
analyzed: tattha gantum pi na vaṭṭati pāṇissaranti kaṃsa tāḷam vadanti vetāḷanti
translated: ‘Hand-clapping’ is the clapping of hands; some say ‘hand-clapping’ is the beating of a bronze gong.🔽‘Vetāla’ is a solid gong, some say ‘the raising of a corpse by a spell.’

original: ghanatāḷaṃ, mantena matasarīruṭṭhāpanantipi eke. Kumbhathūṇanti caturassaambaṇakatāḷaṃ,🔽kumbhasaddantipi eke. Sobhanakanti naṭānaṃ abbhokkiraṇaṃ, sobhanakaraṃ vā, paṭibhānacittanti
analyzed: ghana tāḷam mantena eke  eke sobhanakanti naṭānam abbhokkiraṇam sobhana karam vā paṭibhāna cittanti
translated: ‘Drumming’ is the beating of a four-sided drum;🔽some say ‘drumming’ is the sound of a drum.🔽‘Dancing’ is the shaking of the body by actors, or it makes beauty, that is, it is said to be a mind that is reflected in beauty.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Caṇḍālanti ayoguḷakīḷā, caṇḍālānaṃ sāṇadhovanakīḷātipi vadanti. Vaṃsanti
analyzed: vuttam hoti ayaḥ guḷa kīḷā caṇḍālānam sāṇa dhovana kīḍā atipi vadanti vaṃsanti
translated: ‘Wrestling’ is the playing with iron clubs; some say ‘the playing of the Caṇḍāla women in washing the rags.’

original: veḷuṃ ussāpetvā kīḷanaṃ.
analyzed: veḷum ussāpetvā kīḷanam
translated: ‘Bamboo-walking’ is the playing of walking on bamboo poles set up.

original: Dhovananti aṭṭhidhovanaṃ, ekaccesu kira janapadesu kālaṅkate ñātake na jhāpenti,
analyzed: dhovananti aṭṭhi dhovanam ekaccesu kira janapadesu kālaṅkate ñātake na jhāpenti
translated: ‘Washing’ is the washing of bones; in some countries, it seems, when a relative dies, they do not cremate him🔽but leave him lying there. Then, when they know that the body has become rotten, they take it out and wash the bones

original: nikhaṇitvā ṭhapenti. Atha nesaṃ pūtibhūtaṃ kāyaṃ ñatvā nīharitvā aṭṭhīni dhovitvā
analyzed: nikhaṇitvā ṭhapenti atha nesam pūti bhūtam kāyam ñatvā nīharitvā aṭṭhīni dhovitvā
translated: and

original: gandhehi makkhetvā ṭhapenti. Te nakkhattakāle ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhīni ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ🔽ṭhāne surādīni ṭhapetvā rodantā paridevantā suraṃ pivanti. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “atthi,
analyzed: gandhehi makkhetvā ṭhapenti te nakkhatta kāle ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhīni ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ  ṭhāne surā ādīni ṭhapetvā rodantā paridevantā suram pivanti vuttam pi atthi
translated: They set out the meat and the liquor, and when the time of the constellations comes, they put the bones in one place,

original: bhikkhave, dakkhiṇesu janapadesu aṭṭhidhovanaṃ nāma, tattha hoti annampi pānampi
analyzed: bhikkhave dakkhiṇesu janapadesu aṭṭhidhovanam nāma tattha hoti annam pi pānam pi
translated: the liquor, etc., in another, and they drink the liquor, weeping and wailing. And this is said: “Monks, there is a place in the southern country called Aṭṭhidhovana, where there is food and drink,

original: khajjampi bhojjampi leyyampi peyyampi naccampi gītampi vāditampi. Atthetaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: khajjampi bhojjampi leyyampi peyyampi naccampi gītampi vāditampi atthetam bhikkhave
translated: hard food and soft food, clothes and bedding, and there is singing and dancing and music. I do not say that there is no such place.”

original: dhovanaṃ, netaṃ natthīti vadāmī”ti. Ekacce pana indajālena aṭṭhidhovanaṃ dhovanantipi vadanti.
analyzed: dhovanam na etam natthi iti vadāmi iti ekacce pana indajālena aṭṭhi dhovanam dhovana nti pi vadanti
translated: Some say that Aṭṭhidhovana is the place where the bones are washed by the Indra net.

original: Hatthiyuddhādīsu bhikkhuno neva hatthiādīhi saddhiṃ yujjhituṃ, na te yujjhāpetuṃ,🔽na yujjhante daṭṭhuṃ vaṭṭati. Nibbuddhanti mallayuddhaṃ. Uyyodhikanti yattha sampahāro
analyzed: hatthi yuddha ādīsu bhikkhunaḥ na iva hatthi ādīhi saddhim yujjhitum na te yujjhāpetum  na yujjhante daṭṭhum vaṭṭati nibbuddha nti malla yuddham uyyodhikam ti yattha sampahāraḥ
translated: In elephant fights, etc., it is not proper for a monk to fight with the elephants, etc., or to have others fight,

original: dissati. Balagganti balagaṇanaṭṭhānaṃ. Senābyūhanti senāniveso, sakaṭabyūhādivasena
analyzed: dissati balagganti bala gaṇana ṭhānam senā byūhanti senā niveso sakaṭa byūha ādi vasena
translated: or to watch them fighting. Nibbuddham means a wrestling match. Uyyodhika means a place where a battle is seen. Balagga means a place where troops are counted. Senābyūha means an army encampment, with the arrangement of chariots, etc.

original: senāya nivesanaṃ. Anīkadassananti – “tayo hatthī pacchimaṃ hatthānīka”ntiādinā nayena
analyzed: senāya nivesanam anīka dassanam ti tayaḥ hatthī pacchimam hattha anīkam ti ādinā nayena
translated: and the encampment of the army. The inspection of the army: “Three elephants, the rear elephant troop” , etc.

original: vuttassa anīkassa dassanaṃ.
analyzed: vuttassa anīkassa dassanam
translated: “To see the army”: to see the army arranged in order, as described in the passage beginning, “Three elephants in the rear rank of elephants” .

original: 14. Pamādo ettha tiṭṭhatīti pamādaṭṭhānaṃ. Jūtañca taṃ pamādaṭṭhānañcāti jūtappamādaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Ekekāya pantiyā aṭṭha aṭṭha padāni assāti aṭṭhapadaṃ dasapadepi eseva nayo. Ākāsanti
analyzed: pamādaḥ ettha tiṭṭhati iti pamāda ṭṭhānam jūtam ca tam pamāda ṭṭhānam ca ati jūta ppamāda ṭṭhānam  ekekāya pantiyā aṭṭha aṭṭha padāni assa ati aṭṭhapadam dasa pade pi esa iva nayo
translated: “Negligence”: a place of negligence. Gambling is a place of negligence, thus it is gambling and a place of negligence.

original: aṭṭhapadadasapadesu viya ākāseyeva kīḷanaṃ. Parihārapathanti bhūmiyaṃ nānāpathamaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhapada dasapadesu viya ākāseya iva kīḷanam nānāpatha maṇḍalam
translated: “Eight-piece game”: eight pieces on each side. The same method applies to the ten-piece game. “In the air”: a game played in the air, as it were, without a board.🔽“A path of circling”: a game played by circling round a path drawn on the ground in various patterns.

original: katvā tattha tattha pariharitabbaṃ, pathaṃ pariharantānaṃ kīḷanaṃ. Santikanti santikakīḷanaṃ.🔽Ekajjhaṃ ṭhapitā sāriyo vā sakkharāyo vā acālentā nakheneva apanenti ca upanenti
analyzed: katvā tattha tattha pariharitabbam patham pariharantānam kīḷanam santikam ti santika kīḷanam  ekajjham ṭhapitā sāriyaḥ vā sakkharāyaḥ vā a cālentā nakhena iva apanenti ca upanenti
translated: “A game of ends”: a game played with sticks.

original: ca, sace tattha kāci calati, parājayo hoti, evarūpāya kīḷāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Khalikanti
analyzed: ca sace tattha kāci calati parājayaḥ hoti evarūpāya adhivacanam
translated: “A game of counters”: a game played with counters placed in a row, which are moved by the fingers, not allowed to be moved by the nails. If any one of them moves, one loses. This is a term for a game of that kind. “Halting”:

original: jūtaphalake pāsakakīḷanaṃ. Ghaṭikā vuccati dīghadaṇḍakena rassadaṇḍakaṃ paharaṇakīḷanaṃ.
analyzed: jūta phalake pāsaka kīḷanam ghaṭikā vuccati dīgha daṇḍakena rassa daṇḍakam paharaṇa kīḷanam
translated: Playing with dice is playing with a board with dice. A ghaṭikā is a kind of game played with two sticks, a long one and a short one.

original: Salākahatthanti lākhāya vā mañjiṭṭhikāya vā piṭṭhodakena vā salākahatthaṃ temetvā
analyzed: salākahattham ti lākhāya vā mañjiṭṭhikāya vā piṭṭha udakena vā salākahattham temetvā
translated: A salāka-hand is a hand smeared with red or yellow orpiment or with a decoction of lac.

original: – “kiṃ hotū”ti bhūmiyaṃ vā bhittiyaṃ vā taṃ paharitvā hatthiassādirūpadassanakīḷanaṃ.🔽Akkhanti guḷakīḷā. Paṅgacīraṃ vuccati paṇṇanāḷikaṃ, taṃ dhamantā kīḷanti. Vaṅkakanti
analyzed: kim hotu uti bhūmiyam vā bhittiyam vā tam paharitvā hatthi assa ādi rūpa dassana kīḷanam  guḷakīḷā paṅga cīram vuccati paṇṇanāḷikam tam dhamantā kīḷanti vaṅkakanti
translated: – “What will it be?”—and then striking the ground or a wall with it, playing by pretending to see elephants, horses, etc.🔽Akkha is a kind of game with counters. Paṅgacīra is a kind of game played with a board marked with squares. Vaṅkaka is

original: gāmadārakānaṃ kīḷanakaṃ khuddakanaṅgalaṃ. Mokkhacikā vuccati samparivattanakīḷā,🔽ākāse vā daṇḍakaṃ gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ vā sīsaṃ ṭhapetvā heṭṭhupariyabhāvena parivattanakīḷāti
analyzed: gāma dārakānam kīḷanakam khuddaka naṅgalam mokkhacikā vuccati samparivattana kīḷā  ākāse vā daṇḍakam gahetvā bhūmiyam vā sīsam ṭhapetvā heṭṭhupariya bhāvena parivattana kīḷā ti
translated: a kind of game played by village boys with a small plough. Mokkhacikā is a kind of game played by turning over.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ciṅgulikaṃ vuccati tālapaṇṇādīhi kataṃ vātappahārena paribbhamanacakkaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam hoti ciṅgulikam vuccati tāla paṇṇa ādīhi katam vāta ppahārena paribbhamana cakkam
translated: – “What will it be?”—and then playing by turning over, either holding a stick in the air or placing one’s head on the ground. Ciṅgulika is a kind of game played with a wheel of palm-leaf or the like, which revolves by being spun round with the hand.

original: Pattāḷhakaṃ vuccati paṇṇanāḷikā. Tāya vālukādīni minantā kīḷanti. Rathakanti khuddakarathaṃ.
analyzed: patta āḷhakam vuccati paṇṇa nāḷikā tāya vālukā ādīni minantā kīḷanti khuddaka ratham
translated: A paṭāḷhaka is a kind of game played with a board marked with squares. Rathaka is a kind of toy cart.

original: Dhanukanti khuddakadhanumeva. Akkharikā vuccati ākāse vā piṭṭhiyaṃ vā akkharajānanakīḷā.🔽Manesikā nāma manasā cintitajānanakīḷā. Yathāvajjaṃ nāma kāṇakuṇikhujjādīnaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: dhanukanti khuddaka dhanumā eva akkharikā vuccati ākāse vā piṭṭhiyam vā akkhara jānana kīḷā  manesikā nāma manasā cintita jānana kīḍā yathāvajjam nāma kāṇa kuṇi khujja ādīnam yam
translated: Dhanukanti is a small bow. Akkharikā is a game of guessing letters in the air or on the back.

original: yaṃ vajjaṃ, taṃ taṃ payojetvā dassanakīḷā.
analyzed: yam vajjam tam tam payojetvā dassana kīḷā
translated: Manesikā is a game of guessing what is thought of in the mind. Yathāvajjaṃ is a game of showing what is defective, such as a squint, a limp, etc.

original: 15. Āsandinti pamāṇātikkantāsanaṃ. Anuyuttā viharantīti idaṃ apekkhitvā pana sabbapadesu
analyzed: āsandin ti pamāṇa atikkanta āsanam anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti idam apekkhitvā pana sabba padesu
translated: Āsandī is a couch that exceeds the right size. Anuyuttā viharantīti idaṃ apekkhitvā pana sabbapadesu

original: upayogavacanaṃ kataṃ. Pallaṅkoti pādesu vāḷarūpāni ṭhapetvā kato. Gonakoti dīghalomako
analyzed: upayoga vacanam katam pallaṅko ti pādesu vāḷa rūpāni ṭhapetvā kataḥ gonako ti dīghalomako
translated: upayogavacanaṃ kataṃ. Pallaṅko is one made by placing legs at the corners. Gonako is a large blanket with long hair,

original: mahākojavo, caturaṅgulādhikāni kira tassa lomāni. Cittakanti vānavicittaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ.🔽Paṭikāti uṇṇāmayo setattharaṇo. Paṭalikāti ghanapupphako uṇṇāmayattharaṇo. Yo āmalakapattotipi
analyzed: mahā kojavaḥ catur aṅgula adhikāni kira tassa lomāni cittakanti uṇṇāmayattharaṇam  paṭikā ati uṇṇāmayaḥ setattharaṇo paṭalikā ati ghanapupphako uṇṇāmayattharaṇaḥ yaḥ āmalaka patto tipi
translated: the hairs of which are said to be four fingers long. Cittaka is a blanket of variegated colour.🔽Paṭik is a blanket of white colour. Paṭalika is a blanket of thick flowers,

original: vuccati. Tūlikāti tiṇṇaṃ tūlānaṃ aññatarapuṇṇā tūlikā. Vikatikāti sīhabyagghādirūpavicitro
analyzed: vuccati tūlikā ati tiṇṇam tūlānam aññatara puṇṇā tūlikā vikatikā ati sīha byaggha ādi rūpa vicitraḥ
translated: which is also called āmalakapatta. Tūlikā is a blanket filled with one of the three kinds of cotton. Vikatika is a blanket variegated with the figures of lions, tigers, etc.

original: uṇṇāmayattharaṇo. Uddalomīti ubhayatodasaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ, keci “ekatouggatapuppha”nti🔽vadanti. Ekantalomīti ekatodasaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Keci “ubhatouggatapuppha”nti
analyzed: uṇṇāmayattharaṇaḥ uddalomi iti ubhayatodasam uṇṇāmayattharaṇam keci ekatas uggata pupphanti  vadanti ekantalomī iti ekatodasam keci
translated: A mattress of peacock’s tail-feathers. “With the tips turned outwards” : the tips of the feathers are turned outwards on both sides. Some say that this is the flower of the single-pointed tree.🔽“With the tips turned inwards” : the tips of the feathers are turned inwards on both sides. Some say that this is the flower of the double-pointed tree.

original: vadanti. Kaṭṭissanti ratanaparisibbitaṃ koseyyakaṭṭissamayapaccattharaṇaṃ. Koseyyanti🔽ratanaparisibbitameva kosiyasuttamayapaccattharaṇaṃ. Suddhakoseyyaṃ pana vaṭṭatīti🔽vinaye vuttaṃ. Dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “ṭhapetvā tūlikaṃ sabbāneva gonakādīni
analyzed: vadanti kaṭṭissanti ratana parisibbitam koseyya kaṭṭissa maya paccattharaṇam koseyya nti  ratana parisibbitam eva kosiya sutta maya paccattharaṇam suddha koseyyam pana vaṭṭati iti  vinaye vuttam dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāyam pana ṭhapetvā tūlikam sabbān eva gonaka ādīni
translated: A mattress of cotton is a mattress made of cotton-wool. Cotton is a mattress made of cotton-thread. But pure cotton is allowable, as it is said in the Vinaya.

original: ratanaparisibbitāni na vaṭṭantī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ratana parisibbitāni na vaṭṭanti iti vuttam
translated: But in the Commentary to the Digha Nikaya it is said that all the kinds of gonaka, etc., except tūlika are not allowable if they are mixed with gems.

original: Kuttakanti soḷasannaṃ nāṭakitthīnaṃ ṭhatvā naccanayoggaṃ uṇṇāmayattharaṇaṃ. Hatthattharaṃ
analyzed: kuttakanti nāṭakitthīnam ṭhatvā uṇṇā mayattharaṇam hatthattharam
translated: A mattress of peacock’s tail-feathers is a mattress of peacock’s tail-feathers used as a dance-mat by the sixteen kinds of dancing-girls. A mattress for the hands and feet is a mattress used for the hands and feet.

original: assattharanti hatthiassapiṭṭhīsu attharaṇaattharakāyeva. Rathattharepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: assattharanti hatthi assa piṭṭhīsu attharaṇa atthara kāya iva rathatthare pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: A mattress for elephants and horses is a mattress used on the backs of elephants and horses. The same method applies to a mattress for chariots.

original: Ajinappaveṇīti ajinacammehi mañcappamāṇena sibbitvā katā paveṇī. Kadalīmigapavarapaccattharaṇanti
analyzed: ajinappaveṇī iti ajina cammehi mañca ppamāṇena sibbitvā katā paveṇī kadalī miga pavara paccattharaṇam ti
translated: A bed-coverlet of antelope hide: a coverlet made of antelope hides, the size of a bed, sewn together. A bed-coverlet of the skin of the kadalī deer:

original: kadalīmigacammaṃ nāma atthi, tena kataṃ pavarapaccattharaṇaṃ; uttamapaccattharaṇanti
analyzed: kadalīmigacammam nāma atthi tena katam pavara paccattharaṇam uttama paccattharaṇam ti
translated: there is such a thing as the skin of the kadalī deer; a coverlet made of that is what is meant. An excellent coverlet:

original: attho. Taṃ kira setavatthassa upari kadalīmigacammaṃ pattharitvā sibbetvā karonti.🔽Sauttaracchadanti saha uttaracchadena, uparibaddhena rattavitānena saddhinti attho.
analyzed: attho tam kira seta vatthassa upari kadalī miga cammam pattharitvā sibbetvā karonti  sauttaracchadanti saha uttaracchadena upari baddhena ratta vitānena attho
translated: it seems that they make it by spreading the skin of the kadalī deer over a white cloth and sewing it on.🔽With a canopy and curtains: together with a canopy and curtains, that is, together with a red cloth spread above and red cloths on all sides.

original: Setavitānampi heṭṭhā akappiyapaccattharaṇe sati na vaṭṭati, asati pana vaṭṭati. Ubhatolohitakūpadhānanti
analyzed: seta vitānam pi heṭṭhā akappiya paccattharaṇe sati na vaṭṭati asati pana vaṭṭati ubhatolohitakūpadhānam ti
translated: If there is an unsuitable bed-coverlet underneath, a white canopy is not allowable; if there is a suitable bed-coverlet underneath, it is allowable. Pillows of both red and white:

original: sīsūpadhānañca pādūpadhānañcāti mañcassa ubhatolohitakaṃ upadhānaṃ, etaṃ na kappati.
analyzed: sīsu upadhānam ca pādu upadhānam ca ati mañcassa ubhatolohitakam upadhānam etam na kappati
translated: head-pillow and foot-pillow. A pillow at both ends of the bed is not allowable.

original: Yaṃ pana ekameva upadhānaṃ ubhosu passesu rattaṃ vā hoti padumavaṇṇaṃ vā vicitraṃ
analyzed: yam pana ekam eva upadhānam ubhosu passesu rattam vā hoti paduma vaṇṇam vā vicitram
translated: But if there is only one pillow, it is allowable for both ends of the bed to be red or the color of a lotus or variegated.

original: vā, sace pamāṇayuttaṃ, vaṭṭati. Mahāupadhānaṃ pana paṭikkhittaṃ. Alohitakāni dvepi🔽vaṭṭantiyeva. Tato uttari labhitvā aññesaṃ dātabbāni. Dātuṃ asakkonto mañce tiriyaṃ
analyzed: vā sace pamāṇa yuttam vaṭṭati mahā upadhānam pana paṭikkhittam alohitakāni dve pi  vaṭṭantiyā iva tatas uttari labhitvā aññesam dātabbāni dātum a sakkontaḥ mañce tiriyam
translated: If it is suitable in size, it is allowable. But a large sheet is prohibited. The two kinds of red are allowable.

original: attharitvā upari paccattharaṇaṃ datvā nipajjitumpi labhati. Āsandīādīsu pana vuttanayeneva
analyzed: attharitvā upari paccattharaṇam da tvā nipajjitum pi labhati āsandī ādīsu pana vutta nayena iva
translated: If one gets more than that, one should give it to others. If one is unable to give it, one may spread it out crosswise on a bed and then put a sheet on top of that and lie down on it. But in the case of a chair, etc., one should proceed

original: paṭipajjitabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ – “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, āsandiyā pāde chinditvā paribhuñjituṃ,🔽pallaṅkassa vāḷe bhinditvā paribhuñjituṃ, tūlikaṃ vijaṭetvā bimbohanaṃ kātuṃ, avasesaṃ
analyzed: paṭipajjitabbam vuttam ha etam anujānāmi bhikkhave āsandiyā pāde chinditvā paribhuñjitum  pallaṅkassa vāḷe bhinditvā paribhuñjitum tūlikam vijaṭetvā bimbohanam kātum avasesam
translated: as stated in the rule. For this is said: “Monks, I allow you to use a chair after cutting off the legs,

original: bhummattharaṇaṃ kātu”nti.🔽16. Ucchādanādīsu mātukucchito nikkhantadārakānaṃ sarīragandho dvādasavassapattakāle
analyzed: bhummattharaṇam  ucchādana ādīsu mātukucchitaḥ nikkhanta dārakānam sarīra gandhaḥ dvādasa vassapatta kāle
translated: to use a couch after breaking the frame, to make a mattress out of the cotton wool after removing the netting, and to make a floor cover out of the remaining cloth.”🔽As to the powder used for dusting, etc., the smell of the bodies of children who have just come out of the womb disappears when they are twelve years old.

original: nassati, tesaṃ sarīraduggandhaharaṇatthāya gandhacuṇṇādīhi ucchādenti, evarūpaṃ ucchādanaṃ
analyzed: nassati tesam sarīra duggandha haraṇa atthāya gandha cuṇṇa ādīhi ucchādenti evarūpam ucchādanam
translated: In order to remove the bad smell of their bodies, they are dusted with scented powder, etc.

original: na vaṭṭati. Puññavante pana dārake ūrūsu nipajjāpetvā telena makkhetvā hatthapādaūrunābhiādīnaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭati puññavante pana dārake ūrūsu nipajjāpetvā telena makkhetvā hattha pāda ūru nābhi ādīnam
translated: It is not allowable. But if the children are meritorious, they may be made to lie on their parents’ laps, and oil may be rubbed into their limbs,

original: saṇṭhānasampādanatthaṃ parimaddanti, evarūpaṃ parimaddanaṃ na vaṭṭati.🔽Nhāpananti tesaṃyeva dārakānaṃ gandhādīhi nhāpanaṃ. Sambāhananti mahāmallānaṃ viya🔽hatthapāde muggarādīhi paharitvā bāhuvaḍḍhanaṃ. Ādāsanti yaṃ kiñci ādāsaṃ pariharituṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhāna sampādana attham parimaddanti evarūpam parimaddanam na vaṭṭati  tesam yeva dārakānam gandha ādīhi nhāpanam sambāhananti mahā mallānam viya  hattha pāde muggara ādīhi paharitvā bāhu vaḍḍhanam ādāsanti yam kiñci ādāsam pariharitum
translated: and they may be massaged in order to make their limbs grow straight. Such massaging is not allowable.🔽Bathing: bathing those same children with perfumes, etc., is not allowable. Rubbing down:🔽rubbing down the limbs with a ball, etc., in order to make them grow like those of a great wrestler. Mirror: it is not allowable to carry a mirror for the purpose of looking at oneself. Collyrium:

original: na vaṭṭati. Añjananti alaṅkārañjanameva. Mālāti baddhamālā vā abaddhamālā vā. Vilepananti🔽yaṃ kiñci chavirāgakaraṇaṃ. Mukhacuṇṇaṃ mukhalepananti mukhe kāḷapīḷakādīnaṃ haraṇatthāya🔽mattikakakkaṃ denti, tena lohite calite sāsapakakkaṃ denti, tena dose khādite tilakakkaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭati añjananti alaṅkāra añjanam eva mālā ati baddha mālā vā a baddha mālā vā  yam kiñci chavi rāga karaṇam mukha cuṇṇam mukha lepananti mukhe kāḷapīḷaka ādīnam haraṇa tthāya  mattika kakkam denti tena lohite calite sāsapa kakkam denti tena dose khādite tila kakkam
translated: only for the purpose of ornament. Garlands: whether made up or not. Anointing:🔽anything that makes the skin smooth. Face-powder: they give a ball of clay🔽for the purpose of removing blackheads, etc., from the face. When blood appears, they give a ball with asafoetida. When the bile is upset, they give a ball with turmeric.

original: denti, tena lohite sannisinne haliddikakkaṃ denti, tena chavivaṇṇe ārūḷhe mukhacuṇṇakena
analyzed: denti tena lohite sannisinne haliddikakkam denti tena chavi vaṇṇe ārūḍhe mukha cuṇṇakena
translated: When the blood settles down, they give a ball with yellow orpiment. When the skin has taken on colour, they give face-powder🔽and

original: mukhaṃ cuṇṇenti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: mukham cuṇṇenti tat sabbam na vaṭṭati
translated: All this is not allowable.

original: Hatthabandhādīsu hatthe vicitrasaṅkhakapālādīni bandhitvā vicaranti, taṃ vā aññaṃ
analyzed: hattha bandha ādīsu hatthe vicitra saṅkha kapāla ādīni bandhitvā vicaranti tam vai aññam
translated: As regards armlets, etc., some go about wearing armlets of variegated conch-shells, cowries, etc., on their arms, or other such things,

original: vā sabbampi hatthābharaṇaṃ na vaṭṭati, apare sikhaṃ bandhitvā vicaranti. Suvaṇṇacīrakamuttalatādīhi
analyzed: vā sabbam pi hattha ābharaṇam na vaṭṭati apare sikham bandhitvā vicaranti suvaṇṇa cīraka mutta latā ādīhi
translated: or any arm ornament at all. Others plait their hair and go about with it. They surround it with gold leaf, with a gold plate, etc.,

original: ca taṃ parikkhipanti; taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati. Apare catuhatthadaṇḍaṃ vā aññaṃ vā pana
analyzed: ca tam parikkhipanti tam sabbam na vaṭṭati apare catu hattha daṇḍam vā aññam vā pana
translated: or with a gold fringe. All this is not allowable. Others go about with a decorated staff four cubits long or some such thing.

original: alaṅkatadaṇḍakaṃ gahetvā vicaranti, tathā itthipurisarūpādivicittaṃ bhesajjanāḷikaṃ
analyzed: alaṅkata daṇḍakam gahetvā vicaranti tathā itthi purisa rūpa ādi vicittam bhesajja nāḷikam
translated: So too with a medicine-tube of variegated design with a figure of a man or a woman, etc.,

original: suparikkhittaṃ vāmapasse olaggitaṃ; apare kaṇṇikaratanaparikkhittakosaṃ atitikhiṇaṃ🔽asiṃ, pañcavaṇṇasuttasibbitaṃ makaradantakādivicittaṃ chattaṃ, suvaṇṇarajatādivicitrā
analyzed: su parikkhittam vāma passe olaggitam apare kaṇṇika ratana parikkhitta kosam a tikhiṇam  asim pañca vaṇṇa sutta sibbitam makara dantaka ādi vicittam chattam suvaṇṇa rajata ādi vicitrā
translated: well wrapped up and tucked under the left arm. Others carry a very sharp sword in a scabbard surrounded by a fringe of gold thread,🔽an umbrella with a handle decorated with the figure of a makara’s head, etc., and with ribs of five colours,🔽sandals with an edging of gold leaf, silver leaf, etc., and with the figure of a peacock’s tail-feathers, etc.,

original: morapiñchādiparikkhittā upāhanā, keci ratanamattāyāmaṃ caturaṅgulavitthataṃ kesantaparicchedaṃ
analyzed: mora piñcha ādi parikkhittāḥ upāhanāḥ keci ratana matta āyāmam catur aṅgula vitthatam kesanta paricchedam
translated: a razor case made of precious stones, a span long and four fingers broad, with the edges of the blade covered with leather,

original: dassetvā meghamukhe vijjulataṃ viya nalāṭe uṇhīsapaṭṭaṃ bandhanti, cūḷāmaṇiṃ dhārenti,
analyzed: dassetvā megha mukhe vijju latam viya nalāṭe uṇhīsa paṭṭam bandhanti cūḷāmaṇim dhārenti
translated: and they tie a turban on their foreheads like a flash of lightning in a rain-cloud, and they wear a crest-jewel,

original: cāmaravālabījaniṃ dhārenti, taṃ sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: cāmara vāla bījanim dhārenti tat sabbam na vaṭṭati
translated: and they carry a yak’s-tail fan, all that is not allowable.

original: 17. Aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtā kathāti tiracchānakathā. Tattha
analyzed: a niyyānika ttā sagga mokkha maggānam tiracchāna bhūtā kathā ati tiracchāna kathā tattha
translated: . Because they do not lead to dispassion, to getting free from passion, to stopping, to calm, to higher knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbāna, they are called animal talk. Herein,

original: rājānaṃ ārabbha mahāsammato mandhātā dhammāsoko evaṃ mahānubhāvotiādinā nayena pavattā
analyzed: rājānam ārabbha mahāsammataḥ mandhātā dhamma asokaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ iti ādinā nayena pavattā
translated: talk about kings, such as “King Mahāsammata, King Mandhātu, King Dhammāsoka was so and so powerful” and so on,

original: kathā rājakathā. Esa nayo corakathādīsu. Tesu asuko rājā abhirūpo dassanīyotiādinā
analyzed: kathā rāja kathā esa nayo cora kathā ādīsu tesu asukaḥ rājā abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ ti ādinā
translated: is talk about kings. So too with talk about thieves. Herein, talk that goes “So and so a king is handsome, good-looking” and so on,

original: nayena gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā hoti. Sopi nāma evaṃ mahānubhāvo khayaṃ gatoti
analyzed: nayena geha sita kathā va tiracchāna kathā hoti saḥ api nāma evam mahā anubhāvaḥ khayam gataḥ ti
translated: is animal talk. But when it goes “So and so powerful has come to destruction”

original: evaṃ pavattā pana kammaṭṭhānabhāve tiṭṭhati. Coresu mūladevo evaṃ mahānubhāvo, meghamālo
analyzed: evam pavattā pana kammaṭṭhāna bhāve tiṭṭhati coresu mūladevaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ meghamālo
translated: it is fit for a meditation subject. Talk about thieves, such as “Mūladeva the thief was so and so powerful, Megha the thief was so and so powerful,”

original: evaṃ mahānubhāvoti tesaṃ kammaṃ paṭicca aho sūrāti gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā.
analyzed: evam mahā anubhāvaḥ ti tesam kammam paṭicca aho sūra ati geha sita kathā va tiracchāna kathā
translated: is animal talk when it is talk that goes “How daring they were” and so on, taking the form of admiration.

original: Yuddhepi bhāratayuddhādīsu asukena asuko evaṃ mārito, evaṃ viddhoti kāmassādavaseneva
analyzed: yuddhe api bhārata yuddha ādīsu asukena asukaḥ evam māritaḥ evam viddhaḥ iti kāmaḥ sāda vasena iva
translated: In war too, in the war of the Bharatas, for instance, it is not right to talk with relish for the taste of it, saying, “So-and-so was killed like this, he was wounded like this.”🔽Animal talk is talk about cattle, horses, etc., in the same way.

original: kathā tiracchānakathā. Tepi nāma khayaṃ gatāti evaṃ pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānameva🔽hoti. Api ca annādīsu evaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ gandhavantaṃ rasavantaṃ phassasampannaṃ khādimha
analyzed: kathā tiracchāna kathā te pi nāma khayam gatā ati evam pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānam eva  hoti api ca anna ādīsu evam vaṇṇavantam gandhavantam rasavantam phassa sampannam khādimha
translated: But when it proceeds thus, “They too have come to an end,” it is a meditation subject in all cases.

original: bhuñjimhāti kāmassādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ pana katvā pubbe evaṃ🔽vaṇṇādisampannaṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ sayanaṃ mālaṃ gandhaṃ sīlavantānaṃ adamha, cetiye
analyzed: bhuñjimha ati kāma ssāda vasena kathetum na vaṭṭati sa atthakam pana katvā pubbe evam  vaṇṇa ādi sampannam annam pānam vattham sayanam mālam gandham sīlavantānam adamha cetiye
translated: Moreover, it is not right to talk with relish for the taste of it, saying, “We have eaten such-and-such food, so delicious and well-cooked, so beautiful, so fragrant, so flavoursome, so pleasing to the touch,”

original: pūjaṃ karimhāti kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Ñātikathādīsu pana “amhākaṃ ñātakā sūrā samatthā”ti
analyzed: pūjam karimha iti kathetum vaṭṭati ñāti kathā ādīsu pana amhākam ñātakā sūrā samatthā ati
translated: but it is right to talk with reference to a good goal, saying, “In the past we gave such-and-such beautiful food, drink, clothes, carriages, beds, garlands, scents, and comestibles to virtuous people, and we made shrines and paid homage at them.”

original: vā “pubbe mayaṃ evaṃ vicitrehi yānehi vicarimhā”ti vā assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vā pubbe mayam evam vicitrehi yānehi vicarimha iti vā assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati
translated: But in the case of talk about relatives, etc., it is not right to talk with relish for the taste of it, saying, “Our relatives are powerful and able,” or “In the past we travelled about in such-and-such various kinds of vehicles.”

original: Sātthakaṃ pana katvā “tepi no ñātakā khayaṃ gatā”ti vā “pubbe mayaṃ evarūpā upāhanā
analyzed: sātthakam pana katvā te pi no ñātakā khayam gatā ati vā pubbe mayam evarūpāḥ upāhanā
translated: But it is right to talk with reference to a good goal, saying, “Those relatives of ours have come to an end,” or “In the past we used such-and-such sandals

original: saṅghassa adamhā”ti vā kathetuṃ vaṭṭati. Gāmakathāpi suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhasubhikkhadubbhikkhādivasena
analyzed: saṅghassa vā kathetum vaṭṭati gāma kathā api suniviṭṭha dunniviṭṭha subhikkha dubbhikkha ādi vasena
translated: or “I give them to the Order.”

original: vā “asukagāmavāsino sūrā samatthā”ti vā evaṃ assādavasena na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ pana
analyzed: vā asuka gāma vāsinaḥ vā evam assāda vasena na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana
translated: Nor is it allowable to talk about a village in terms of its advantages, saying, “The people who live in such-and-such a village are generous and capable” and so on. But it is allowable to talk about it in terms of what is beneficial,🔽saying “They are faithful and confident” or “They have reached decay and decline.”

original: katvā “saddhā pasannā”ti vā “khayavayaṃ gatā”ti vā vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Nigamanagarajanapadakathādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: katvā saddhā pasannā ati vā khaya vayam gatā ati vā vattum vaṭṭati nigama nagara janapada kathā ādīsu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies to talk about a town, a country, and so on.

original: Itthikathāpi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīni paṭicca assādavasena na vaṭṭati, saddhā pasannā khayavayaṃ
analyzed: itthi kathā api vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīni paṭicca assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khaya vayam
translated: Nor is it allowable to talk about a woman in terms of her advantages, referring to her complexion, figure, and so on. But it is allowable to talk about her in the same way as about a village, saying “She is faithful and confident” or “She has reached decay and decline.”

original: gatāti evameva vaṭṭati. Sūrakathāpi ‘nandimitto nāma yodho sūro ahosī’ti assādavasena🔽na vaṭṭati. Saddho ahosi khayaṃ gatoti evameva vaṭṭati. Visikhākathāpi “asukā visikhā
analyzed: gatā ati evam eva vaṭṭati sūrakathā api nandimittaḥ nāma yodhaḥ sūraḥ ahosi iti assāda vasena  na vaṭṭati saddhaḥ ahosi khayam gataḥ iti evam eva vaṭṭati visikhā kathā api asukā visikhā
translated: Nor is it allowable to talk about a hero in terms of his advantages, saying “The warrior called So-and-so was a hero.”

original: suniviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthā”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati. Saddhā pasannā khayavayaṃ
analyzed: su niviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthā ati assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khaya vayam
translated: But it is allowable to talk about him in the same way as about a village. Nor is it allowable to talk about a street in terms of its advantages, saying “Such-and-such a street is well laid out, is badly laid out, is generous, is capable.”

original: gatāti evameva vaṭṭati.
analyzed: evam eva vaṭṭati
translated: But it is allowable to talk about it in the same way as about a village.

original: Kumbhaṭṭhānakathāti udakaṭṭhānakathā, udakatitthakathātipi vuccati, kumbhadāsikathā
analyzed: kumbha ṭṭhāna kathā ati udaka ṭṭhāna kathā udaka tittha kathā ati pi vuccati kumbhadāsikathā
translated: “Talk about water-pots” is talk about water-drawing places, also called “talk about water-drawing women” .

original: vā, sāpi “pāsādikā naccituṃ gāyituṃ chekā”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati; saddhā pasannātiādinā
analyzed: vā sā api pāsādikā naccitum gāyitum chekā ati assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā ati ādinā
translated: “Talk about water-carrying vessels” is talk about water-carrying vessels or about bathing places. Or it is talk about a water-carrying maid-servant. That too is not allowable as enjoyment of flavours, but it is allowable in the way beginning, “She has faith, she has confidence” .🔽“Talk about the past” is talk about what happened in the past. Herein, the exposition is similar to that for talk about what is happening now.

original: nayeneva vaṭṭati. Pubbapetakathāti atītañātikathā. Tattha vattamānañātikathāsadiso vinicchayo.🔽Nānattakathāti purimapacchimakathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānāsabhāvā niratthakakathā.🔽Lokakkhāyikāti ayaṃ loko kena nimmito, asukena nāma nimmito. Kāko seto, aṭṭhīnaṃ🔽setattā; balākā rattā. Lohitassa rattattāti evamādikā lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā.🔽Samuddakkhāyikā nāma kasmā samuddo sāgaro? Sāgaradevena khato, tasmā sāgaro. Khato
analyzed: nayena iva vaṭṭati pubba peta kathā ati atīta ñāti kathā tattha vattamāna ñāti kathā sadisaḥ vinicchayaḥ  nānatta kathā ati purima pacchima kathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānā sabhāvā niratthaka kathā  lokakkhāyikā ti ayam loko kena nimmitaḥ asukena nāma nimmitaḥ kāko seto aṭṭhīnam  seta ttā balākā rattā lohitassa ratta ttā ati evamādikā lokāyata vitaṇḍa sallāpa kathā  samuddakkhāyikāḥ nāma kasmā samuddaḥ sāgaraḥ sāgaradevena khataḥ tasmā sāgaraḥ khataḥ
translated: “Varied talk” is talk about anything that is unconnected with the preceding and following talk and is therefore useless.

original: meti hatthamuddāya sayaṃ niveditattā “samuddo”ti evamādikā niratthakā samuddakkhāyanakathā.
analyzed: mā iti hattha muddāya sayam nivedita ttā samuddaḥ ti evamādikā niratthakā samudda khāyana kathā
translated: “Tales of kings” is talk about such kings as Mahāsammata, Bandhumā, etc., and talk about such kings as Aṅga, Magadha, etc., and talk about such kings as Mahāsudassana, Daḷhanemi, etc., and talk about such kings as Mahinda, Nāga, etc., and talk about such kings as Pasenadi, Ajātasattu, etc., and talk about such kings as Udena, Anāthapiṇḍika, etc., and talk about such kings as Bimbisāra, Kiki, etc., and talk about such kings as Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Bhagīratha, etc., and talk about such kings as Mahāsudassana, Mahāsamaya, etc., and talk about such kings as Reṇu, Reṇu, etc., and talk about such kings as Mahinda, Mahinda, etc., and talk about such kings as Tissa, Tissa, etc., and talk about such kings as Devānampiya, Devānampiya, etc., and talk about such kings as Dhammāsoka, Dhammāsoka, etc., and talk about such kings as Devānampiya, Piyadassana, etc., and talk about such kings as Bindusāra, Bindusāra, etc., and talk about such kings as Candagutta, Candagutta, etc., and talk about such kings as Candragutta, Candragutta, etc., and talk about such kings as Aśoka, Aśoka, etc., and talk about such kings as Nāgadāsaka, Nāgadāsaka, etc., and talk about such kings as Devānampiya, Piyadassana, etc., and talk about such kings as Piyadassana, Piyadassana, etc., and talk about such kings as Piyadassana, Pi

original: Bhavoti vuḍḍhi. Abhavoti hāni. Iti bhavo, iti abhavoti yaṃ vā taṃ vā niratthakakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhavoti vuḍḍhi abhavoti hāni iti bhavo iti abhavoti yam vā tam vā niratthaka kāraṇam
translated: “Existence” is growth; “non-existence” is diminution. So “existence” and “non-existence” is talk that goes on giving reasons that are pointless.

original: vatvā pavattitakathā itibhavābhavakathā.🔽18. Viggāhikakathāti viggahakathā, sārambhakathā. Tattha sahitaṃ meti mayhaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: vatvā iti bhava abhava kathā  viggāhika kathā ati viggaha kathā sa ārambha kathā tattha sahitam mā iti mayham vacanam
translated: This is talk about existence and non-existence.

original: sahitaṃ siliṭṭhaṃ atthayuttaṃ kāraṇayuttanti attho. Asahitaṃ teti tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: sahitam siliṭṭham attha yuttam kāraṇa yuttanti attho asahitam te ti vacanam
translated: “Quarrelsome talk” is talk that quarrels, talk that is contentious. Herein, “My words are coherent” means “My words are coherent, well-knit, connected with the goal, connected with the Dhamma. They have a basis in the Suttas, are attested by the Vinaya, and are not inconsistent with the Dhamma.

original: asahitaṃ asiliṭṭhaṃ. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattanti yaṃ tuyhaṃ dīgharattāciṇṇavasena
analyzed: asahitam a siliṭṭham adhiciṇṇam te viparāvattanti yam dīgha ratta a ciṇṇa vasena
translated: Your words are incoherent” means “Your words are incoherent, not well-knit, unconnected with the goal, unconnected with the Dhamma. They have no basis in the Suttas, are not attested by the Vinaya, and are inconsistent with the Dhamma.”

original: suppaguṇaṃ, taṃ mayhaṃ ekavacaneneva viparāvattaṃ parivattitvā ṭhitaṃ, na kiñci jānāsīti attho.
analyzed: su paguṇam tam mayham ekavacanena iva viparāvattam parivattitvā ṭhitam na kiñci jānāsi iti attho
translated: “What you have well learned has been turned over” means “What you have well learned over a long period, what you have well grasped, well penetrated by view, well attended to by way of knowledge, that has been turned over by me with a single statement. You know nothing about it.”

original: Āropito te vādoti mayā tava doso āropito. Cara vādappamokkhāyāti dosamocanatthaṃ🔽cara, vicara; tattha tattha gantvā sikkhāti attho. Nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti atha
analyzed: āropitaḥ te vādaḥ iti mayā tava dosaḥ āropitaḥ cara vāda ppamokkhāya ati dosa mocana attham  cara vicara tattha tattha gantvā sikkha ati atthaḥ nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosi iti atha
translated: “Your doctrine has been refuted” means “Your fault has been brought up by me.”🔽“Go and free your doctrine” means “Go and seek your way out of the fault, seek your way out by going here and there and by training yourself.”

original: sayaṃ pahosi, idānimeva nibbeṭhehīti.
analyzed: sayam pahosi idānim eva nibbeṭhehi iti
translated: “Or else, if you are able, free yourself” means “If you are able, free yourself right now.”

original: 19. Dūteyyakathāyaṃ idha gacchāti ito asukaṃ nāma ṭhānaṃ gaccha. Amutrāgacchāti tato🔽asukaṃ nāma ṭhānaṃ āgaccha. Idaṃ harāti ito idaṃ nāma hara. Amutra idaṃ āharāti asukaṭṭhānato
analyzed: gacchāti itas asukam nāma ṭhānam gaccha amutra āgacchāti  asukam nāma ṭhānam āgaccha idam harāti itas idam nāma hara amutra idam āharāti asuka ṭṭhānataḥ
translated: 19. In the case of a message: “Go here” means “Go from here to such-and-such a place.” “Come from there” means “Come from such-and-such a place to here.” “Take this” means “Take this from here.” “Bring that from there” means “Bring that from such-and-such a place

original: idaṃ nāma idha āhara. Saṅkhepato pana idaṃ dūteyyaṃ nāma ṭhapetvā pañca sahadhammike
analyzed: idam nāma idhas āhara saṅkhepato pana idam dūteyyam nāma ṭhapetvā pañca sahadhammike
translated: “Go there” means “Go from here to such-and-such a place.” “Come from there” means “Come from such-and-such a place to here.” “Take this” means “Take this from here.” “Bring that from there” means “Bring this from such-and-such a place to here.” In brief, this errand is not allowable except for the five who share the same dwelling,

original: ratanattayassa upakārapaṭisaṃyuttañca gihīsāsanaṃ aññesaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: upakāra paṭisaṃyuttam ca gihī sāsanam aññesam na vaṭṭati
translated: and for the instruction of the laity connected with the three jewels.

original: 20. Kuhakātiādīsu tividhena kuhanavatthunā lokaṃ kuhayanti, vimhāpayantīti kuhakā.
analyzed: kuhaka ati ādīsu tividhena kuhana vatthunā lokam kuhayanti vimhāpayanti iti kuhakā
translated: “Deceitful” : they deceive the world by the three kinds of deceit .🔽“Flatterers” : they flatter for the sake of gain and fame.

original: Lābhasakkāratthikā hutvā lapantīti lapakā. Nimittaṃ sīlametesanti nemittikā. Nippeso
analyzed: lābha sakkāratthikāḥ hutvā lapanti iti lapakāḥ nimittam sīlam etesanti nemittikāḥ
translated: “Augurers” : they have a sign in their virtue.🔽“Fortune-tellers” : they have a sign in their fortune.

original: sīlametesanti nippesikā. Lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanti magganti pariyesantīti lābhena
analyzed: nippesikāḥ lābhena lābham nijigīsanti magganti pariyesanti iti lābhena
translated: “Seekers after gain through gain” : they seek gain by gain.

original: lābhaṃ nijigīsitāro. Kuhanā, lapanā, nemittikatā, nippesikatā, lābhena lābhaṃ nijigīsanatāti
analyzed: lābham nijigīsitāraḥ kuhanā lapanā nemittika tā nippesika tā lābhena lābham nijigīsana tā ati
translated: “Deceit, flattery, auguring, fortune-telling, and seeking after gain through gain” are the five kinds of impure livelihood.

original: etāhi samannāgatānaṃ puggalānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārena
analyzed: etāhi samannāgatānam puggalānam adhivacanam ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārena
translated: is a term for those who possess these. This is the brief account. The detailed🔽

original: panetā kuhanādikā visuddhimagge sīlaniddeseyeva pāḷiñca aṭṭhakathañca āharitvā pakāsitāti.
analyzed: panetā kuhanā ādikā visuddhi magge sīla niddeseya iva pāḷiñca aṭṭhakathañca āharitvā pakāsitā ati
translated: This is a designation for persons who possess these. This is the brief account here. But the detailed account is given in the Visuddhimagga in the description of virtue under the heading of hypocrisy, etc., by citing the text and the commentary.

original: Ettāvatā majjhimasīlaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ettāvatā majjhima sīlam niṭṭhitam hoti
translated: So far the medium extent of virtue has been completed.

original: Mahāsīlavaṇṇanā🔽21. Ito paraṃ mahāsīlaṃ hoti. Aṅganti hatthapādādīsu yena kenaci evarūpena aṅgena🔽samannāgato dīghāyu yasavā hotītiādinayappavattaṃ aṅgasatthaṃ. Nimittanti nimittasatthaṃ.
analyzed: mahāsīla vaṇṇanā  itas param mahā sīlam hoti hattha pāda ādīsu yena kenacid evarūpena aṅgena  samannāgataḥ dīgha āyu yasavā hoti itiādi naya ppavattam aṅga sattham nimittam ti nimitta sattham
translated: The Great Extent of Virtue

original: Paṇḍurājā kira tisso muttāyo muṭṭhiyaṃ katvā nemittikaṃ pucchi – “kiṃ me hatthe”ti?
analyzed: paṇḍu rājā kira tissaḥ muttāyaḥ muṭṭhiyam katvā nemittikam pucchi kim me hatthe iti
translated: From here on the great extent of virtue begins. “Limb” : the hundred limbs that occur in the way beginning: “He who possesses such and such a limb is long-lived and has glory” . “Sign” : the hundred signs . King Paṇḍu, it seems, put three pearls in his fist and asked a fortune-teller: “What have I got in my hand?”

original: So ito cito ca vilokesi, tasmiñca samaye gharagolikāya makkhikā gayhantī muttā, so
analyzed: saḥ itas citas ca vilokesi tasmin ca samaye ghara golikāya makkhikā gayhantī muttā so
translated: He looked here and there, and at that moment a fly caught in a spider’s web fell down right in front of the king’s fist. The fortune-teller said:🔽“Pearls.” Asked again, “How many?” he heard the cock crow three times, and he said:

original: “muttā”ti āha. Puna “katī”ti puṭṭho kukkuṭassa tikkhattuṃ ravantassa saddaṃ sutvā
analyzed: muttā iti āha puna kati iti puṭṭhaḥ kukkuṭassa tikkhattum ravantassa saddam sutvā
translated: “Three.”

original: “tisso”ti āha. Evaṃ taṃ taṃ ādisitvā nimittamanuyuttā viharanti.🔽Uppātanti asanipātādīnaṃ mahantānaṃ uppatitaṃ, tañhi disvā “idaṃ bhavissati, evaṃ
analyzed: tissaḥ tissaḥ iti āha evam tam tam ādisitvā nimittam anuyuttāḥ viharanti  uppātam ti asanipāta ādīnam mahantānam uppatitam tat hi disvā idam bhavissati evam
translated: “Three,” he said. Thus they live devoted to the signs of portents.🔽Earthquakes: the occurrence of a great earthquake, etc. For when they see that, they foretell: “This will happen, this will happen.”

original: bhavissatī”ti ādisanti. Supinanti yo pubbaṇhasamaye supinaṃ passati, evaṃ vipāko🔽hoti; yo idaṃ nāma passati, tassa idaṃ nāma hotītiādinā nayena supinakaṃ anuyuttā
analyzed: bhavissati iti ādisanti supinam ti yaḥ pubbaṇha samaye supinam passati evam vipākaḥ  hoti yaḥ idam nāma passati tassa idam nāma hoti itiādinā nayena supinakam anuyuttā
translated: Dreams: they live devoted to dreams, saying: “If one sees such and such in a dream, such and such will happen to him.”

original: viharanti. Lakkhaṇanti iminā lakkhaṇena samannāgato rājā hoti, iminā uparājātiādikaṃ.
analyzed: viharanti iminā lakkhaṇena samannāgataḥ rājā hoti iminā uparā jāti ādikam
translated: Characteristics: “One who possesses such and such characteristics will become a king, one who possesses such and such will become a minister.”

original: Mūsikacchinnanti undūrakhāyitaṃ. Tenāpi hi ahate vā vatthe anahate vā vatthe ito🔽paṭṭhāya evaṃ chinne idaṃ nāma hotīti ādisanti. Aggihomanti evarūpena dārunā evaṃ
analyzed: undūra khāyitam tena api hi ahate vā vatthe an ahate vā vatthe ito  paṭṭhāya evam chinne idam nāma hoti iti ādisanti evarūpena dārunā evam
translated: Rat’s-gnawings: they say: “If a cloth is not worn or washed, if it is gnawed in such and such a way, such and such will happen.”

original: hute idaṃ nāma hotīti aggijuhanaṃ. Dabbihomādīnipi aggihomāneva, evarūpāya dabbiyā
analyzed: hute idam nāma hoti iti aggi juhanam aggi homān eva evarūpāya dabbiyā
translated: Fire-offerings: they say: “If wood is burnt in such and such a way, such and such will happen.” The fire-offerings with sticks, etc., are also included in fire-offerings.

original: īdisehi kaṇādīhi hute idaṃ nāma hotīti evaṃ pavattivasena pana visuṃ vuttāni.🔽Tattha kaṇoti kuṇḍako. Taṇḍulāti sāliādīnañceva tiṇajātīnañca taṇḍulā. Sappīti gosappiādikaṃ.
analyzed: īdisehi kaṇā ādīhi hute idam nāma hoti iti evam pavatti vasena pana visum vuttāni  tattha kaṇoti kuṇḍakaḥ sāli ādīnam ca iva tiṇa jātīnam ca taṇḍulā sappī iti gosappi ādikam
translated: and so on. But they are mentioned separately because they are used in the way beginning, “When it is burnt with such and such grains, it becomes such and such.”🔽Herein, grains is a kind of grain. Rice is the rice of the kinds of grass. Honey is the honey of bees.

original: Telanti tilatelādikaṃ. Sāsapādīni pana mukhena gahetvā aggimhi pakkhipanaṃ, vijjaṃ
analyzed: telanti tila tela ādikam sāsapa ādīni pana mukhena gahetvā aggimhi pakkhipanam vijjam
translated: Oil is sesame oil and so on. But the use of mustard seed, etc., is the throwing of mustard seed, lentils, kidney beans, etc., into the fire after reciting a spell over them.

original: parijappitvā juhanaṃ vā mukhahomaṃ. Dakkhiṇakkhakajaṇṇulohitādīhi juhanaṃ lohitahomaṃ.
analyzed: parijappitvā juhanam vā mukha homam dakkhiṇa kkhaka jaṇṇu lohita ādīhi juhanam lohita homam
translated: The use of the mouth is the offering of oblations in the mouth. The use of blood is the offering of oblations in the mouth with blood from the right hand’s palm, and so on.

original: Aṅgavijjāti pubbe aṅgameva disvā byākaraṇavasena aṅgaṃ vuttaṃ, idha aṅgulaṭṭhiṃ disvā🔽vijjaṃ parijappitvā ayaṃ kulaputto vā no vā, sirīsampanno vā no vātiādibyākaraṇavasena
analyzed: aṅga vijjā ati pubbe aṅgam eva disvā byākaraṇa vasena aṅgam vuttam idha aṅgu laṭṭhim disvā  vijjam parijappitvā ayam kula putto vā no vā sirīsampannaḥ vā no vā ati ādi byākaraṇa vasena
translated: The use of the limbs is called that because it is mentioned in the texts as “the limbs” . Here, however, it is called the use of the limbs because it is the explanation of the “limb” as a finger bone,

original: aṅgavijjā vuttā. Vatthuvijjāti gharavatthuārāmavatthādīnaṃ guṇadosasallakkhaṇavijjā.
analyzed: aṅga vijjā vuttā vatthu vijjā ati ghara vatthu ārāma vattha ādīnam guṇa dosa sallakkhaṇa vijjā
translated: after reciting a spell over it, as to whether the person to whom it belongs is a male or a female, whether he or she is fortunate or unfortunate, and so on. The use of the site is the knowledge of the good and bad qualities of a site for a house, a monastery, and so on.

original: Mattikādivisesaṃ disvāpi hi vijjaṃ parijappitvā heṭṭhā pathaviyaṃ tiṃsaratanamatte,
analyzed: mattikā ādi visesam disvā api hi vijjam parijappitvā heṭṭhā pathaviyam tiṃsa ratana matte
translated: For after reciting a spell over a particular kind of clay, etc., and looking at it, one can know whether there are thirty treasures beneath the earth at a depth of a fathom,

original: ākāse ca asītiratanamatte padese guṇadosaṃ passanti. Khattavijjāti abbheyyamāsurakkharājasatthādisatthaṃ.🔽Sivavijjāti susāne pavisitvā santikaraṇavijjā, siṅgālarutavijjātipi vadanti. Bhūtavijjāti
analyzed: ākāse ca asīti ratana matte padese guṇa dosam passanti  siva vid jāti su sāne pavisitvā vadanti bhūta vid jāti
translated: and in the sky they see the eighty kinds of faults and virtues in a piece of gold. The art of divination is the art of interpreting dreams, omens, etc.🔽The art of exorcising is the art of dealing with ghosts by entering a charnel ground, which they also call the art of the jackal’s cry. The art of earth spirits is the art of earth spirits’ medicine.

original: bhūtavejjamanto. Bhūrivijjāti bhūrighare vasantena uggahetabbamanto. Ahivijjāti sappadaṭṭhatikicchanavijjā🔽ceva sappāvhāyanavijjā ca. Visavijjāti yāya, purāṇavisaṃ vā rakkhanti, navavisaṃ
analyzed: bhūtavejjamantaḥ bhūri vijjā ati bhūri ghare vasantena uggahetabbam antaḥ ahi vijjā ati sappadaṭṭha tikicchana vijjā  ca iva sappāvhāyana vijjā ca visa vijjāti yāya purāṇa visam vā rakkhanti nava visam
translated: The art of abundance is the art that one should learn by living in a place of abundance. The art of snakes is the art of treating snake bite and the art of driving away snakes.

original: vā karonti visavantameva vā. Vicchikavijjāti vicchikadaṭṭhatikicchanavijjā. Mūsikavijjāyapi
analyzed: vā karonti visavantam eva vā
translated: The art of poison is the art by means of which they protect against old poison, make new poison, or make something poisonous. The art of scorpions is the art of treating scorpion bite.

original: eseva nayo. Sakuṇavijjāti sapakkhakaapakkhakadvipadacatuppadānaṃ rutagatādivasena
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ sakuṇa vijjāti sapakkhaka apakkhaka dvipada catuppadānam ruta gata ādi vasena
translated: The same method applies to the art of mice. The art of birds is the knowledge of birds, that is, of two-footed and four-footed birds, as to their cries, tracks, etc.

original: sakuṇañāṇaṃ. Vāyasavijjāti kākarutañāṇaṃ, taṃ visuññeva satthaṃ, tasmā visuṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sakuṇa ñāṇam vāyasa vijjāti kāka ruta ñāṇam tam visuññeva sattham tasmā visum vuttam
translated: The art of crows is the knowledge of the cries of crows. That is a separate art from the art of birds, so it is mentioned separately.

original: Pakkajjhānanti paripākagatacintā. Idāni “ayaṃ ettakaṃ jīvissati, ayaṃ ettaka”nti🔽evaṃ pavattaṃ ādiṭṭhañāṇanti attho. Saraparittāṇanti sararakkhaṇaṃ, yathā attano🔽upari na āgacchati, evaṃ karaṇavijjā. Migacakkanti idaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ sabbasakuṇacatuppadānaṃ
analyzed: pakkajjhānanti paripāka gata cintā idāni ayam ettakam jīvissati ayam ettakam ti  evam pavattam sara parittāṇam ti sara rakkhaṇam yathā attanaḥ  upari naḥ āgacchati evam karaṇa vijjā miga cakkanti idam sabba saṅgāhikam sabba sakuṇa catu padānam
translated: “Ripe jhana” is thinking that has reached maturity. The meaning is: “This one will live so long, this one so long.”🔽“Complete protection” is complete guarding, the knowledge of how to act so that it does not come upon oneself.

original: rutañāṇavasena vuttaṃ.🔽22. Maṇilakkhaṇādīsu evarūpo maṇi pasattho, evarūpo apasattho, sāmino ārogyaissariyādīnaṃ
analyzed: ruta ñāṇa vasena vuttam  maṇi lakkhaṇa ādīsu evarūpaḥ maṇi pasatthaḥ evarūpaḥ apasatthaḥ sāminaḥ ārogya aissariya ādīnam
translated: “The deer-trap” is a general term for all birds and animals. It is said by way of the knowledge of their cries.

original: hetu hoti, na hotīti, evaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena maṇiādīnaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ anuyuttā viharantīti🔽attho. Tattha āvudhanti ṭhapetvā asiādīni avasesaṃ āvudhaṃ. Itthilakkhaṇādīnipi yamhi
analyzed: hetu hoti na hoti iti evam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena maṇi ādīnam lakkhaṇam anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti  tattha āvudhanti ṭhapetvā asi ādīni avasesam āvudham itthi lakkhaṇa ādīni pi yamhi
translated: As regards gems, marks, etc., the meaning is that they live devoted to the knowledge of the characteristics of gems, etc., in this way: “A gem of such a colour and shape is praiseworthy; one of such a colour and shape is not praiseworthy; it is a cause for the master’s health, prosperity, etc.; it is not a cause.”

original: kule te itthipurisādayo vasanti, tassa vuḍḍhihānivaseneva veditabbāni. Ajalakkhaṇādīsu
analyzed: kule te itthi purisa ādayaḥ vasanti tassa vuḍḍhi hāni vasena iva veditabbāni aja lakkhaṇa ādīsu
translated: Herein, “weapons” are all weapons except swords, etc. The “marks of women” and so on should be understood according to the increase and decrease of the family in which the women, men, etc., live.

original: pana evarūpānaṃ ajādīnaṃ maṃsaṃ khāditabbaṃ, evarūpānaṃ na khāditabbanti ayaṃ viseso veditabbo.🔽Api cettha godhāya lakkhaṇe cittakammapiḷandhanādīsupi evarūpāya godhāya sati idaṃ
analyzed: pana evarūpānam aja ādīnam maṃsam khāditabbam evarūpānam na khāditabbam ti ayam visesaḥ veditabbaḥ  api ca ittha godhāya lakkhaṇe citta kamma piḷandhana ādīsu pi evarūpāya godhāya sati idam
translated: But the difference should be understood that the flesh of such animals as the goat, etc., may be eaten, but not that of such as the camel, etc.🔽And here the difference should be understood that when there is such a goat as has a mark, a patch of white hair, etc., this is what is called “marked” .

original: nāma hotīti ayaṃ viseso veditabbo. Idañcettha vatthu – ekasmiṃ kira vihāre cittakamme
analyzed: nāma hoti iti ayam visesaḥ veditabbaḥ idam ca ittha vatthu ekasmin kira vihāre citta kamme
translated: Here is a story. It seems that in a certain monastery they made a picture of a goat with a mark on the fire-house.

original: godhaṃ aggiṃ dhamamānaṃ akaṃsu. Tato paṭṭhāya bhikkhūnaṃ mahāvivādo jāto. Eko āgantukabhikkhu🔽taṃ disvā makkhesi. Tato paṭṭhāya vivādo mandībhūto hoti. Kaṇṇikalakkhaṇaṃ piḷandhanakaṇṇikāyapi
analyzed: godham aggim dhamamānam akaṃsu tatas paṭṭhāya bhikkhūnam mahā vivādaḥ jātaḥ ekaḥ āgantuka bhikkhu  tam disvā makkhesi tatas paṭṭhāya vivādaḥ mandībhūtaḥ hoti kaṇṇika lakkhaṇam piḷandhana kaṇṇikāya api
translated: After that there was a great dispute among the bhikkhus. A certain visiting bhikkhu saw it

original: gehakaṇṇikāyapi vasena veditabbaṃ. Kacchapalakkhaṇaṃ godhālakkhaṇasadisameva. Migalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: vasena veditabbam kacchapa lakkhaṇam godhā lakkhaṇa sadisam eva miga lakkhaṇam
translated: and laughed. After that the dispute subsided. The characteristic of the “ear-ring” should be understood as the “ear-ring” of a house lizard or the “ear-ring” of a house. The characteristic of the “tortoise” is the same as that of the “goat.” The characteristic of the “deer”

original: sabbasaṅgāhikaṃ sabbacatuppadānaṃ lakkhaṇavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sabba saṅgāhikam sabba catu padānam lakkhaṇa vasena vuttam
translated: is stated in the general sense as the characteristic of all quadrupeds.

original: 23. Raññaṃ niyyānaṃ bhavissatīti asukadivase asukanakkhattena asukassa nāma rañño
analyzed: raññam niyyānam bhavissati iti asuka divase asuka nakkhattena asukassa nāma raññaḥ
translated: “There will be a king’s departure” means that on such and such a day, under such and such a constellation, a king named so and so will depart.

original: niggamanaṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ rājūnaṃ pavāsagamanaṃ byākaroti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: niggamanam bhavissati iti evam rājūnam pavāsa gamanam byākaroti esa nayaḥ sabbattha
translated: He declares the king’s going away on the ground that there will be a coming out. So too in all the other cases.

original: Kevalaṃ panettha aniyyānanti vippavutthānaṃ puna āgamanaṃ. Abbhantarānaṃ raññaṃ upayānaṃ🔽bhavissati, bāhirānaṃ raññaṃ apayānanti antonagare amhākaṃ rājā paṭiviruddhaṃ bahirājānaṃ
analyzed: kevalam pana ittha aniyyānam ti vippavutthānam puna āgamanam abbhantarānam raññam upayānam  bhavissati bāhirānam raññam apayānanti antonagare amhākam rājā paṭiviruddham bahi rājānam
translated: But here the non-issue is the return of the one who has gone out. The coming of the kings within is🔽the king within who is hostile to our king will come out. The going of the kings away is

original: upasaṅkamissati, tato tassa paṭikkamanaṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ raññaṃ upayānāpayānaṃ
analyzed: upasaṅkamissati tatas tassa paṭikkamanam bhavissati iti evam raññam upayāna apayānam
translated: the going away of the king who is outside and hostile to our king. He declares the coming and going of the kings on the ground that there will be a coming and a going.

original: byākaroti. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Jayaparājayā pākaṭāyeva.
analyzed: byākaroti dutiya pade pi eṣa iva nayaḥ jaya parājayā pākaṭāya iva
translated: In the second case too the same method of explanation applies. Victory and defeat are obvious.

original: 24. Candaggāhādayo asukadivase rāhu candaṃ gahessatīti byākaraṇavaseneva veditabbā.🔽Api ca nakkhattassa aṅgārakādigāhasamāyogopi nakkhattagāhoyeva. Ukkāpātoti ākāsato
analyzed: canda gāha ādayaḥ asuka divase rāhu candam gahessati iti byākaraṇa vasena iva veditabbā  api ca nakkhattassa aṅgāraka ādi gāha samāyogaḥ pi nakkhatta gāhaḥ yā iva ukkāpāto ti ākāsataḥ
translated: The moon’s and sun’s eclipses should be understood as the declaration that on such and such a day Rāhu will seize the moon or the sun.

original: ukkānaṃ patanaṃ. Disāḍāhoti disākālusiyaṃ aggisikhadhūmasikhādīhi ākulabhāvo viya.
analyzed: ukkānam patanam aggi sikha dhūma sikha ādīhi ākula bhāvaḥ
translated: Moreover, the seizing of a constellation by Mars or whoever it may be is also a seizing of a constellation. A shooting star is a star that shoots down from the sky. A portent in the directions is the disturbance in the directions, as it were, by flames, smoke, and so on.

original: Devadudrabhīti sukkhavalāhakagajjanaṃ. Uggamananti udayanaṃ. Okkamananti atthaṅgamanaṃ.
analyzed: sukkha valāhaka gajjanam uggamananti udayanaṃ okkamananti atthaṅgamanaṃ
translated: The sound of the rain-cloud is the sound of the rain-cloud that brings drought. Uggamananti udayanaṃ is the rising of the sun. Okkamananti atthaṅgamanaṃ is the setting of the sun.

original: Saṃkilesanti avisuddhatā. Vodānanti visuddhatā. Evaṃ vipākoti lokassa evaṃ vividhasukhadukkhāvaho.🔽25. Suvuṭṭhikāti devassa sammādhārānuppavecchanaṃ. Dubbuṭṭhikāti avaggāho, vassavibandhoti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Muddāti hatthamuddā. Gaṇanā vuccati acchiddakagaṇanā. Saṅkhānanti saṅkalanasaṭuppādanādivasena
analyzed: avisuddha tā vodāna nti visuddha tā evam vipākaḥ ti lokassa evam vividha sukha dukkha āvaho  su vuṭṭhikā ati devassa sammādhāra anuppavecchanam dubbuṭṭhikā ati avaggāhaḥ vassa vibandho ti  vuttam hoti muddā ati hattha muddā gaṇanā vuccati acchiddaka gaṇanā saṅkhānan ti saṅkalana saṭuppādana ādi vasena
translated: Saṃkilesanti avisuddhatā is impurity. Vodānanti visuddhatā is purification. Evaṃ vipākoti lokassa evaṃ vividhasukhadukkhāvaho is the world’s varied ripening of pleasure and pain.

original: piṇḍagaṇanā. Yassa sā paguṇā hoti, so rukkhampi disvā ettakāni ettha paṇṇānīti jānāti.
analyzed: piṇḍa gaṇanā yassa sā paguṇā hoti saḥ rukkham pi disvā ettakāni ettha paṇṇāni iti jānāti
translated: Suvuṭṭhikāti devassa sammādhārānuppavecchanaṃ is the god’s proper distribution of rain. Dubbuṭṭhikāti avaggāho, vassavibandhoti vuttaṃ hoti is the god’s failure to distribute rain. Muddāti hatthamuddā is the counting on the fingers. Gaṇanā vuccati acchiddakagaṇanā is the counting without a break. Saṅkhānanti saṅkalanasaṭuppādanādivasena piṇḍagaṇanā is the counting of the bundles by gathering them together, making them into heaps, etc. One who is skilled in this knows, on seeing a tree, how many leaves there are on it.

original: Kāveyyanti “cattārome, bhikkhave, kavī. Katame cattāro? Cintākavi, sutakavi, atthakavi,
analyzed: kāveyyanti cattāro me bhikkhave kavī katame cattāro cintā kavi suta kavi attha kavi
translated: Kāveyyanti “cattārome, bhikkhave, kavī. Katame cattāro? Cintākavi, sutakavi, atthakavi,

original: paṭibhānakavī”ti. Imesaṃ catunnaṃ kavīnaṃ attano cintāvasena vā; “vessantaro nāma
analyzed: paṭibhāna kavi iti imesam catunnam kavīnam cintā vasena vā vessantaraḥ nāma
translated: paṭibhānakavī”ti. Imesaṃ catunnaṃ kavīnaṃ attano cintāvasena vā; “vessantaro nāma

original: rājā ahosī”tiādīni sutvā sutavasena vā; imassa ayaṃ attho, evaṃ taṃ yojessāmīti evaṃ🔽atthavasena vā; kiñcideva disvā tappaṭibhāgaṃ kattabbaṃ karissāmīti evaṃ ṭhānuppattikapaṭibhānavasena
analyzed: rājā ahosi itiādīni sutvā suta vasena vā imassa ayam atthaḥ evam tam yojessāmi iti evam  attha vasena vā kiñcid eva disvā tad paṭibhāgam kattabbam karissāmi iti evam ṭhāna uppattika paṭibhāna vasena
translated: and the king was ….” Having heard them, he understands them by way of what he has heard,🔽or he understands them by way of their meaning, thinking, “This is the meaning of this, I shall construe it thus,”🔽or he understands them by way of the ingenuity that occurs by way of the place, thinking, “Having seen something, I shall do what is appropriate to it.”🔽

original: vā; jīvikatthāya kabyakaraṇaṃ. Lokāyataṃ vuttameva.🔽26. Āvāhanaṃ nāma imassa dārakassa asukakulato asukanakkhattena dārikaṃ ānethāti🔽āvāhakaraṇaṃ. Vivāhananti imaṃ dārikaṃ asukassa nāma dārakassa asukanakkhattena detha,
analyzed: vā jīvi katthāya kabya karaṇam lokāyatam vuttam eva  āvāhanam nāma imassa dārakassa asuka kulataḥ asuka nakkhattena dārikam ānetha ati  āvāha karaṇam vivāhananti imam dārikam asukassa nāma dārakassa asuka nakkhattena detha
translated: and ‘He was a king’ and so on, then by the method of what is heard; or else ‘This is the meaning of this, I shall construe it thus,’ then by the method of meaning; or else ‘Having seen something or other, I shall do what is appropriate to it,’ then by the method of what is possible; or else ‘I shall compose poetry for the sake of a living,’ then by the method of poetry; and ‘Natural philosophy’ has already been mentioned.🔽‘Invitation’ is the making of an invitation thus: ‘Bring a girl from such and such a family for this boy under such and such a constellation.’🔽‘Marriage’ is the making of a marriage thus: ‘Give this girl to the boy named so-and-so under such and such a constellation,

original: evamassā vuḍḍhi bhavissatīti vivāhakaraṇaṃ. Saṃvaraṇanti saṃvaraṇaṃ nāma ‘ajja nakkhattaṃ
analyzed: evam assāḥ vuḍḍhi bhavissati iti vivāha karaṇam saṃvaraṇanti saṃvaraṇam nāma ajja nakkhattam
translated: and thus her prosperity will be assured.’ ‘Reconciliation’ is the making of reconciliation thus: ‘Today the constellation is a good one,

original: sundaraṃ, ajjeva samaggā hotha, iti vo viyogo na bhavissatī’ti evaṃ samaggakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: sundaram ajja iva samaggāḥ hotha iti vaḥ viyogaḥ na bhavissati iti evam samagga karaṇam
translated: so be reconciled today, and thus there will be no more separation between you.’

original: Vivaraṇaṃ nāma ‘sace viyujjitukāmattha, ajjeva viyujjatha, iti vo puna saṃyogo na
analyzed: vivaraṇam nāma sace viyujjitu kāmattha ajjā iva viyujjatha iti vaḥ punar saṃyogaḥ na
translated: ‘Divorce’ is the making of divorce thus: ‘If you want to be divorced, then be divorced today, and thus there will be no more union between you.

original: bhavissatī’ti evaṃ visaṃyogakaraṇaṃ. Saṅkiraṇanti ‘uṭṭhānaṃ vā iṇaṃ vā dinnaṃ dhanaṃ
analyzed: bhavissati iti evam visaṃyoga karaṇam saṅkiraṇanti uṭṭhānam vā iṇam vā dinnam dhanam
translated: ‘It will be,’ he makes them separate. ‘Let us mix,’ means: ‘Let us mix today the money that has been earned or borrowed or given,

original: ajja saṅkaḍḍhatha, ajja saṅkaḍḍhitañhi taṃ thāvaraṃ hotī’ti evaṃ dhanapiṇḍāpanaṃ.
analyzed: ajja saṅkaḍḍhatha ajja saṅkaḍḍhitam hi tam thāvaram hoti iti evam dhana piṇḍāpanam
translated: for that will be firm.’ Thus he makes them bring together the money.

original: Vikiraṇanti ‘sace payogauddhārādivasena dhanaṃ payojitukāmattha, ajja payojitaṃ diguṇacatugguṇaṃ
analyzed: sace payoga auddhāra ādi vasena dhanam ajja payojitam diguṇa catugguṇam
translated: ‘Let us scatter,’ means: ‘If you want to use the money by way of starting a business, etc., today, it will be doubled or quadrupled

original: hotī’ti evaṃ dhanapayojāpanaṃ. Subhagakaraṇanti piyamanāpakaraṇaṃ vā sassirīkakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti evam dhana payaḥ jāpanam subhaga karaṇam ti piya manāpa karaṇam vā sassirīka karaṇam
translated: by the time it is used.’ Thus he makes them use the money. ‘Let us do what is lucky,’ means: ‘Let us do what is pleasing and lovely.’

original: vā. Dubbhagakaraṇanti tabbiparītaṃ. Viruddhagabbhakaraṇanti viruddhassa vilīnassa
analyzed: vā dubbhaga karaṇam ti tad biparītam viruddha gabbha karaṇam ti viruddhassa vilīnassa
translated: ‘Let us do what is unlucky,’ means: the opposite of that. ‘Let us do what is harmful to the embryo,’ means: the doing of what is harmful to the embryo that is not firm, not settled,

original: aṭṭhitassa matassa gabbhassa karaṇaṃ. Puna avināsāya bhesajjadānanti attho. Gabbho
analyzed: a ṭṭhitassa matassa gabbhassa karaṇam puna a vināsāya bhesajja dānam ti atthaḥ gabbhaḥ
translated: that has not reached the stage of death. The meaning is: ‘Let us give medicine for the non-destruction of the embryo.’

original: hi vātena, pāṇakehi, kammunā cāti tīhi kāraṇehi vinassati. Tattha vātena vinassante
analyzed: hi vātena pāṇakehi kammunā ca ati tīhi kāraṇehi vinassati tattha vātena vinassante
translated: For the embryo is destroyed by three causes: by wind, by germs, and by kamma.

original: nibbāpanīyaṃ sītalaṃ bhesajjaṃ deti, pāṇakehi vinassante pāṇakānaṃ paṭikammaṃ karoti,
analyzed: nibbāpanīyam sītalam bhesajjam deti pāṇakehi vinassante pāṇakānam paṭikammam karoti
translated: There, when it is destroyed by wind, he gives cooling medicine for the cooling of it; when it is destroyed by germs, he does what is necessary for the germs;

original: kammunā vinassante pana buddhāpi paṭibāhituṃ na sakkonti.
analyzed: kammunā vinassante pana buddhāḥ api paṭibāhitum na sakkonti
translated: But when they are destroyed by kamma, even Buddhas cannot prevent it.

original: Jivhānibandhananti mantena jivhāya bandhakaraṇaṃ. Hanusaṃhanananti mukhabandhamantena
analyzed: jivhā nibandhanam iti mantena jivhāya bandha karaṇam hanu saṃhananam iti mukha bandha mantena
translated: Tongue-tying: the binding of the tongue by a spell. Jaw-unhinging: the binding of the mouth by a spell,

original: yathā hanukaṃ cāletuṃ na sakkonti, evaṃ bandhakaraṇaṃ. Hatthābhijappananti hatthānaṃ🔽parivattanatthaṃ mantajappanaṃ. Tasmiṃ kira mante sattapadantare ṭhatvā jappite itaro🔽hatthe parivattetvā khipati. Kaṇṇajappananti kaṇṇehi saddaṃ assavanatthāya vijjāya
analyzed: yathā hanukam cāletum na sakkonti evam bandha karaṇam hattha abhijappanam ti hatthānam  parivattana attham manta jappanam tasmin kira mante satta pada antare jappite itaraḥ  hatthe parivattetvā khipati kaṇṇa jappanam ti kaṇṇehi saddam a ssavana tthāya vijjāya
translated: by which the jaw cannot be moved. Hand-clapping: the muttering of a spell🔽for the purpose of turning the hands. When, it seems, the spell is muttered within a distance of seven steps, the other man’s hands turn over and he drops what he is carrying. Ear-whispering: the muttering of a spell by a man of knowledge

original: jappanaṃ. Taṃ kira jappitvā vinicchayaṭṭhāne yaṃ icchati, taṃ bhaṇati, paccatthiko🔽taṃ na suṇāti, tato paṭivacanaṃ sampādetuṃ na sakkoti. Ādāsapañhanti ādāse devataṃ
analyzed: jappanam tam kira jappitvā vinicchaya ṭṭhāne yam icchati tam bhaṇati paccatthiko  tam na suṇāti tatas paṭivacanam sampādetum na sakkoti ādāsa pañhanti ādāse devatam
translated: for the purpose of making sounds inaudible to the ears. When, it seems, that is muttered, he speaks in an assem-bly what he wishes, but his opponent

original: otāretvā pañhapucchanaṃ. Kumārikapañhanti kumārikāya sarīre devataṃ otāretvā pañhapucchanaṃ.
analyzed: otāretvā pañhapucchanam kumārikapañhanti kumārikāya sarīre devatam otāretvā pañhapucchanam
translated: does not hear it, and so he is unable to reply. Mirror-question: the asking of a question by transferring a deity to a mirror. Maiden-question: the asking of a question by transferring a deity to a maiden’s body.

original: Devapañhanti dāsiyā sarīre devataṃ otāretvā pañhapucchanaṃ. Ādiccupaṭṭhānanti jīvikatthāya🔽ādiccapāricariyā. Mahatupaṭṭhānanti tatheva mahābrahmapāricariyā. Abbhujjalananti
analyzed: deva pañhanti dāsiyā sarīre devatam otāretvā pañha pucchanam jīvika tthāya  ādicca pāricariyāḥ tathā iva mahābrahma pāricariyāḥ
translated: The “divine question” is the asking of a question after transferring a deity into the body of a slave girl. The “sun-worship” is the paying of homage to the sun for the sake of a living.
