analyzed: te ca kho bhonto ti ādinā nayena pucchitvā tāni vatthūni vibhajitvā dassetum santi
translated: Having asked thus, he classified and showed those theses thus: “There are, bhikkhus, certain contemplatives and brahmans

original: bhikkhave”tiādimāha. Tattha vadanti etenāti vādo, diṭṭhigatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sassato🔽vādo etesanti sassatavādā, sassatadiṭṭhinoti attho. Eteneva nayena ito paresampi🔽evarūpānaṃ padānaṃ attho veditabbo. Sassataṃ attānañca lokañcāti rūpādīsu aññataraṃ🔽attāti ca lokoti ca gahetvā taṃ sassataṃ amaraṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ paññapenti. Yathāha
analyzed: bhikkhave tiādim āha tattha vadanti etena ati vādaḥ diṭṭhi gatassa itam adhivacanam sassato  vādaḥ etesanti sassata vādāḥ sassata diṭṭhino ti attho etena iva nayena itas paresam pi  evarūpānam padānam attho veditabbo sassatam attānam ca lokam ca ati rūpa ādīsu aññataram  attā iti ca loko iti ca gahetvā tam sassatam amaram niccam dhuvam paññapenti yathā āha
translated: “They are called ‘speculations’ because they are spoken by means of them. The view of eternalism is what is meant. Those who hold the view of eternalism are ‘eternalists.’ The meaning of the other terms should be understood in the same way. ‘The self and the world are eternal’: having taken some such state as material form, etc., to be the self and the world, they proclaim that it is eternal, immortal, permanent, and stable. As it is said:

original: – “rūpaṃ attā ceva loko ca sassato cāti attānañca lokañca paññapenti tathā vedanaṃ,🔽saññaṃ, saṅkhāre, viññāṇaṃ attā ceva loko ca sassato cāti attānañca lokañca paññapentī”ti.🔽31. Ātappamanvāyātiādīsu vīriyaṃ kilesānaṃ ātāpanabhāvena ātappanti vuttaṃ. Tadeva
analyzed: rūpam attā ca iva loko ca sassato ca ati attānam ca lokañca paññapenti tathā vedanam  saññam saṅkhāre viññāṇam attā ca iva loko ca sassataḥ ca ati attānam ca lokañca paññapenti iti  ātappam anvāyā ati ādīsu vīriyam kilesānam ātāpana bhāvena ātappanti vuttam tat eva
translated: “They are called ‘speculators’ because they speak with views. They are called ‘eternalist speculators’ because they have the view of eternalism. The meaning of the other terms should be understood in the same way. ‘They describe the self and the world as eternal’: having apprehended some such state as material form, etc., as the self and the world, they describe it as eternal, immortal, permanent, and everlasting. As it is said: ‘They describe the self and the world as material form, eternal. They describe the self and the world as feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness, eternal’ .

original: padahanavasena padhānaṃ. Punappunaṃ yuttavasena anuyogoti. Evaṃ tippabhedaṃ vīriyaṃ
analyzed: padahana vasena padhānam punappunam yutta vasena anuyogo ti evam tippabhedam vīriyam
translated: ‘By zeal’ : zeal is so called because it burns up defilements. It is ‘striving’ because it strives . It is ‘endeavour’ because it is applied again and again. Thus zeal, striving, and endeavour are the three aspects of energy.

original: anvāya āgamma paṭiccāti attho. Appamādo vuccati satiyā avippavāso. Sammā manasikāroti
analyzed: anvāyaḥ āgamma paṭicca ati attho appamādaḥ vuccati satiyā a vippavāsaḥ sammā manasikāro ti
translated: “Having approached, having come, having gone to” is the meaning. Non-negligence is called the non-abandoning of mindfulness. Right reflection is

original: upāyamanasikāro, pathamanasikāro, atthato ñāṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Yasmiñhi manasikāre
analyzed: upāya manasikāro patha manasikāro atthataḥ ñāṇan ti vuttam hoti yasmin hi manasikāre
translated: reflection by means of a method, reflection in the right way. Knowledge of meaning is what is meant. For when one stands firm in this reflection,

original: ṭhitassa pubbenivāsānussati ñāṇaṃ ijjhati, ayaṃ imasmiṃ ṭhāne manasikāroti adhippeto.
analyzed: ṭhitassa pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇam ijjhati ayam imasmin ṭhāne manasikāraḥ ti adhippeto
translated: knowledge of the recollection of past lives succeeds. This is the reflection intended here.

original: Tasmā vīriyañca satiñca ñāṇañca āgammāti ayamettha saṅkhepattho. Tathārūpanti tathājātikaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai vīriyam ca satim ca ñāṇam ca āgamma iti ayam ettha saṅkhepa atthaḥ tathārūpanti tathājātikam
translated: Therefore the meaning here in brief is this: “Having approached, having come, having gone to energy, mindfulness, and knowledge.” Such is the kind: of such a kind.

original: Cetosamādhinti cittasamādhiṃ. Phusatīti vindati paṭilabhati. Yathā samāhite citteti
analyzed: cetaḥ samādhim ti citta samādhim phusati iti vindati paṭilabhati yathā samāhite citta iti
translated: Concentration of cognizance: concentration of cognizance. Touches: finds, obtains. When his cognizance is thus concentrated:

original: yena samādhinā sammā āhite suṭṭhu ṭhapite cittamhi anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsantiādīnaṃ
analyzed: yena samādhinā sammā āhite suṭṭhu ṭhapite cittamhi aneka vihitam
translated: when his cognizance is rightly concentrated, well steadied, by means of this concentration. The meaning of “He recollects his manifold past lives … “

original: attho visuddhimagge vutto.
analyzed: atthaḥ visuddhi magge vuttaḥ
translated: is given in the Path of Purity .

original: So evamāhāti so evaṃ jhānānubhāvasampanno hutvā diṭṭhigatiko evaṃ vadati. Vañjhoti
analyzed: saḥ evam āha ati saḥ evam jhāna anubhāva sampannaḥ hutvā diṭṭhi gatikaḥ evam vadati vañjho ti
translated: So he speaks thus: so he, possessing the success of jhana, speaks thus. Barren:

original: vañjhapasuvañjhatālādayo viya aphalo kassaci ajanakoti. Etena “attā”ti ca “loko”ti
analyzed: vañjha pasuvañjha tāla ādayaḥ viya aphalo kassaci ajanako ti etena attā ati ca loko ti
translated: like barren women’s children, a sky-flower, etc., it is fruitless, it does not produce anything for anyone.🔽By this he shows that the self and the world are non-existent.

original: ca gahitānaṃ jhānādīnaṃ rūpādijanakabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati. Pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ṭhitoti
analyzed: ca gahitānam jhāna ādīnam rūpa ādi janaka bhāvam paṭikkhipati pabbata kūṭam viya ṭhitaḥ ti
translated: Like a barren woman’s child, a sky-flower, etc., it is fruitless, not the producer of anything for anyone. By this he denies that the jhanas, etc., which are taken as the self and the world are the producers of material form, etc. He stands firm like the peak of Mount Sineru.🔽The meaning of “peak” is “firmness.” He stands firm like a pillar of the world.

original: kūṭaṭṭho. Esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitoti esikaṭṭhāyī viya hutvā ṭhitoti esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito. Yathā
analyzed: kūṭaṭṭhaḥ esika ṭṭhāyi ṭhitaḥ ti esika ṭṭhāyī viya hutvā ṭhitaḥ ti esika ṭṭhāyi ṭhitaḥ yathā
translated: He stands firm like a pillar of the world. Just as a pillar of the world is firmly set, so he stands firm.

original: sunikhāto esikatthambho niccalo tiṭṭhati, evaṃ ṭhitoti attho. Ubhayenapi lokassa
analyzed: su nikhātaḥ esikatthambhaḥ niccalo tiṭṭhati evam ṭhitaḥ ti atthaḥ ubhayena api lokassa
translated: By both terms he shows that the world does not perish.

original: vināsābhāvaṃ dīpeti. Keci pana īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitoti pāḷiṃ vatvā muñje īsikā viya ṭhitoti🔽vadanti. Tatrāyamadhippāyo – yadidaṃ jāyatīti vuccati, taṃ muñjato īsikā viya vijjamānameva
analyzed: vināsā abhāvam dīpeti keci pana īsika ṭṭhāyi ṭhitā ti pāḷim vatvā muñje īsikā viya ṭhitā ti  vadanti tatra ayam adhippāyaḥ yat idam jāyati iti vuccati tam muñjataḥ īsikā viya vijjamānam eva
translated: But some read the text as īsikaṭṭhayiṭṭhito and explain it as “standing like a reed in a clump of reeds.”

original: nikkhamati. Yasmā ca īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhito, tasmā teva sattā sandhāvanti, ito aññattha gacchantīti attho.
analyzed: nikkhamati yasmā ca tasmā te iva sattā sandhāvanti itas aññattha gacchanti iti attho
translated: The meaning is this: what is called “born” comes forth only as something already existent, like a reed from a clump of reeds. And because he stands firm like a pillar of the world, therefore these beings run on, the meaning is that they go from here to some other place.

original: Saṃsarantīti aparāparaṃ sañcaranti. Cavantīti evaṃ saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Tathā upapajjantīti.
analyzed: saṃsaranti iti apara aparam sañcaranti cavanti iti evam saṅkhyam gacchanti tathā upapajjanti iti
translated: They wander on means they move from one existence to another. They pass away means they die. They reappear means they are reborn.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana pubbe “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti vatvā idāni te ca sattā sandhāvantītiādinā🔽vacanena ayaṃ diṭṭhigatiko attanāyeva attano vādaṃ bhindati, diṭṭhigatikassa dassanaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pana pubbe sassato attā ca loko ca ati vatvā idāni te ca sattā sandhāvanti itiādinā  vacanena ayam diṭṭhigatikaḥ attanāya iva attanaḥ vādam bhindati diṭṭhigatikassa dassanam
translated: But in the commentary it is said that the eternalist first declares that the self and the world are eternal. Then, by the statement “These beings wander on,”

original: nāma na nibaddhaṃ, thusarāsimhi nikhātakhāṇu viya cañcalaṃ, ummattakapacchiyaṃ pūvakhaṇḍagūthagomayādīni
analyzed: nāma na nibaddham thusara asimhi cañcalam pūva khaṇḍa gūtha gomaya ādīni
translated: he contradicts his own statement. For the view of the eternalist is not fixed. It is as unsteady as a post stuck in a heap of chaff. In it, as in a madwoman’s cooking pot, there is no order in the arrangement of the ingredients, which consist of the morsels of views, some pretty, some ugly, thrown in helter-skelter, like rice, curry, fish, meat, sour stuff, milk, oil, etc.

original: viya cettha sundarampi asundarampi hoti yevāti vuttaṃ. Atthitveva sassatisamanti
analyzed: viya ca ittha sundaram pi a sundaram pi hoti yā iva ati vuttam atthitvā iva sassati saman ti
translated: The meaning of the expression “atthi tveva sassatisam” is as follows:

original: ettha sassatīti niccaṃ vijjamānatāya mahāpathaviṃva maññati, tathā sinerupabbatacandimasūriye.
analyzed: ettha sassati iti niccam vijjamāna tāya mahā pathavim iva maññati tathā sineru pabbata candima sūriye
translated: The eternalist thinks that the self is eternal because it exists permanently, just as the great earth, Sineru, the sun, and the moon exist.

original: Tato tehi samaṃ attānaṃ maññamānā atthi tveva sassatisamanti vadanti.
analyzed: tatas tehi samam attānam maññamānāḥ atthi tu eva sassati samanti vadanti
translated: Then, thinking that the self is equal to them, he says, “The self exists eternally.”

original: Idāni sassato attā ca loko cātiādikāya paṭiññāya sādhanatthaṃ hetuṃ dassento “taṃ
analyzed: idāni sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati ādikāya paṭiññāya sādhana attham hetum dassento tam
translated: Now, in order to prove the proposition that the self and the world are eternal, etc., he gives a reason:

original: kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāyā”tiādimāha. Tattha imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmīti iminā🔽visesādhigamena ahaṃ etaṃ paccakkhato jānāmi, na kevalaṃ saddhāmattakeneva vadāmīti
analyzed: kissa hetu aham hi ātappam anvāya ati ādim āha tattha iminām aham etam jānāmi iti iminā  visesa adhigamena aham etam paccakkhataḥ jānāmi na kevalam saddhā mattakena iva vadāmi iti
translated: “Why is it so? Because I know it through my own insight.”🔽Here he shows that he knows this by his own direct knowledge through the attainment of a special distinction, and that he does not speak merely out of faith.

original: dasseti, makāro panettha padasandhikaraṇatthaṃ vutto. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānanti
analyzed: dasseti makāraḥ pana ittha pada sandhi karaṇa attham vuttaḥ idam bhikkhave paṭhamam ṭhānam ti
translated: The syllable ma is used here to form a compound word.

original: catūhi vatthūhīti vatthusaddena vuttesu catūsu ṭhānesu idaṃ paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, idaṃ
analyzed: catūhi vatthūhi iti vatthu saddena vuttesu catūsu ṭhānesu idam paṭhamam ṭhānam idam
translated: “This, bhikkhus, is the first case”: among the four bases stated by the word “bases,” this is the first base.

original: jātisatasahassamattānussaraṇaṃ paṭhamaṃ kāraṇanti attho.
analyzed: jāti sata sahassa matta anussaraṇam paṭhamam kāraṇan ti attho
translated: The meaning is that the recollection of a hundred thousand births is the first reason.

original: 32-33. Upari vāradvayepi eseva nayo. Kevalañhi ayaṃ vāro anekajātisatasahassānussaraṇavasena
analyzed: upari vāra dvaye pi esā iva nayo kevalam hi ayam vāraḥ aneka jāti sata sahassa anussaraṇa vasena
translated: The same method applies to the two subsequent sections.🔽Only this section is stated in terms of the recollection of many hundreds of thousands of births,

original: vutto. Itare dasacattālīsasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappānussaraṇavasena. Mandapañño hi titthiyo
analyzed: vuttaḥ itare dasa cattālīsa saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappa anussaraṇa vasena manda paññaḥ hi titthiyo
translated: while the other two are stated in terms of the recollection of ten and forty world-cycles, respectively. The heretic has little wisdom,

original: anekajātisatasahassamattaṃ anussarati, majjhimapañño dasasaṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappāni,
analyzed: aneka jāti sata sahassa mattam anussarati majjhima paññaḥ dasa saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappāni
translated: He remembers a hundred thousand or more births. One of medium understanding remembers ten or twenty aeons.

original: tikkhapañño cattālīsaṃ, na tato uddhaṃ.
analyzed: cattālīsam na tatas uddham
translated: One of great understanding remembers forty.

original: 34. Catutthavāre takkayatīti takkī, takko vā assa atthīti takkī. Takketvā vitakketvā
analyzed: catuttha vāre takkayati iti takkī takkaḥ vā assa atthi iti takkī takketvā vitakketvā
translated: In the fourth case, he is a theorist because he theorizes, or he is a theorist because he has a theory.🔽This is a term for one who holds a view after having theorized, speculated,

original: diṭṭhigāhino etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vīmaṃsāya samannāgatoti vīmaṃsī. Vīmaṃsā nāma tulanā
analyzed: diṭṭhi gāhino etam adhivacanam vīmaṃsāya samannāgataḥ iti vīmaṃsī vīmaṃsā nāma tulanā
translated: and pondered. He is a speculator because he is endowed with speculation.

original: ruccanā khamanā. Yathā hi puriso yaṭṭhiyā udakaṃ vīmaṃsitvā otarati, evameva yo tulayitvā
analyzed: ruccanā khamanā yathā hi purisaḥ yaṭṭhiyā udakam vīmaṃsitvā otarati evam eva tulayitvā
translated: Speculation is a weighing, a liking, a tolerating. For just as a man goes into the water after having tested it with his foot, so too, one who holds a view after having weighed it,

original: ruccitvā khamāpetvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, so “vīmaṃsī”ti veditabbo. Takkapariyāhatanti
analyzed: ruccitvā khamāpetvā diṭṭhim gaṇhāti so vīmaṃsīti veditabbo takka pariyāhatanti
translated: liked it, and tolerated it should be understood as a “speculator.”

original: takkena pariyāhataṃ, tena tena pariyāyena takketvāti attho. Vīmaṃsānucaritanti tāya
analyzed: takkena pariyāhatam tena tena pariyāyena takketvā ati atthaḥ tāya
translated: He is one who has been carried away by speculation because he has been carried away by this or that speculation.🔽He is one who has gone beyond by speculation because he has gone beyond by the speculation described in the way beginning, “After having tested it with his foot.”

original: vuttappakārāya vīmaṃsāya anucaritaṃ. Sayaṃpaṭibhānanti attano paṭibhānamattasañjātaṃ.
analyzed: vutta ppakārāya vīmaṃsāya anucaritam sayaṃpaṭibhānam ti attanaḥ paṭibhānam atta sañjātam
translated: He is one who has arisen by self-conviction because he has arisen by his own conviction.

original: Evamāhāti sassatadiṭṭhiṃ gahetvā evaṃ vadati.
analyzed: evam āha ati sassata diṭṭhim gahetvā evam vadati
translated: He says thus: he says this after having taken up the eternalist view.

original: Tattha catubbidho takkī – anussutiko, jātissaro, lābhī, suddhatakkikoti. Tattha yo🔽“vessantaro nāma rājā ahosī”tiādīni sutvā “tena hi yadi vessantarova bhagavā, sassato🔽attā”ti takkayanto diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, ayaṃ anussutiko nāma. Dve tisso jātiyo saritvā
analyzed: tattha catubbidhaḥ takkī anussutikaḥ jātissaraḥ lābhī suddhatakkiko ti tattha yo  vessantaraḥ nāma rājā ahosi itiādīni sutvā tena hi yadi vessantaraḥ uva bhagavā sassato  attā ati takkayantaḥ diṭṭhim gaṇhāti ayam anussutikaḥ nāma dve tissaḥ jātiyaḥ saritvā
translated: Herein, the theorist is of four kinds: the theorist who is a traditionalist, the theorist who is a master of speculation, the theorist who is a gainer of knowledge, and the theorist who is a pure theorist.🔽Herein, one who hears it said that there was a king named Vessantara and so on, and who then reasons thus, “If the Blessed One was Vessantara, then the self is permanent, eternal, and everlasting,” and who holds the view that he is that self, is called a traditionalist theorist.

original: – “ahameva pubbe asukasmiṃ nāma ahosiṃ, tasmā sassato attā”ti takkayanto jātissaratakkiko🔽nāma. Yo pana lābhitāya “yathā me idāni attā sukhī hoti, atītepi evaṃ ahosi, anāgatepi🔽bhavissatī”ti takkayitvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, ayaṃ lābhītakkiko nāma. “Evaṃ sati idaṃ
analyzed: aham eva pubbe asukasmin nāma ahosim tasmā sassataḥ attā ati takkayantaḥ jātissara takkiko  nāma yaḥ pana lābhitāya yathā me idāni attā sukhī atīte api evam anāgate api  bhavissati iti takkayitvā diṭṭhim gaṇhāti ayam lābhītakkikaḥ nāma evam sati idam
translated: One who remembers two or three past lives and reasons thus, “I was so and so in the past, therefore the self is permanent,” is called a master of speculation theorist.🔽But one who reasons thus, “Just as my self is happy now, so it was in the past and so it will be in the future,” and who holds the view that he is that self, is called a gainer of knowledge theorist.

original: hotī”ti takkamatteneva gaṇhanto pana suddhatakkiko nāma.
analyzed: hoti iti takka mattena iva gaṇhantaḥ pana suddhatakkikaḥ nāma
translated: But one who holds the view simply by reasoning that “if this is, that comes to be,” is called a pure theorist.

original: 35. Etesaṃ vā aññatarenāti etesaṃyeva catunnaṃ vatthūnaṃ aññatarena ekena vā dvīhi
analyzed: etesam vā aññatarena ati etesam yeva catunnam vatthūnam aññatarena ekena vā dvīhi
translated: By one of these or by another of these four grounds: by one of these four grounds stated or by another of them.

original: vā tīhi vā. Natthi ito bahiddhāti imehi pana vatthūhi bahi aññaṃ ekaṃ kāraṇampi sassatapaññattiyā
analyzed: vā tīhi vā na atthi itas bahiddhā ti imehi pana vatthūhi bahi aññam ekam kāraṇam pi sassata paññattiyā
translated: or by three. There is no other reason outside these for the eternalist view.

original: natthīti appaṭivattiyaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati.
analyzed: natthi iti appaṭivattiyam sīha nādam nadati
translated: He roars his irreversible lion’s roar.

original: 36. Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānātīti bhikkhave, taṃ idaṃ catubbidhampi diṭṭhigataṃ
analyzed: tayidam bhikkhave tathāgataḥ pajānāti iti bhikkhave tam idam catubbidham pi diṭṭhi gatam
translated: “This, bhikkhus, the Tathāgata understands” : the Tathāgata understands these four kinds of views in their variety.

original: tathāgato nānappakārato jānāti. Tato taṃ pajānanākāraṃ dassento ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānātiādimāha.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ nānā pakārataḥ jānāti tatas tam pajānanā ākāram dassentaḥ ime diṭṭhi ṭṭhānā ti ādim āha
translated: Showing the way in which he understands them, he says “These are the standpoints for views” .

original: Tattha diṭṭhiyova diṭṭhiṭṭhānā nāma. Api ca diṭṭhīnaṃ kāraṇampi diṭṭhiṭṭhānameva.
analyzed: tattha diṭṭhiyaḥ uva diṭṭhi ṭṭhānāḥ nāma api ca diṭṭhīnam kāraṇam pi diṭṭhi ṭṭhānam eva
translated: Herein, the views themselves are called “standpoints for views.” But also the reason for the views is a standpoint for views.

original: Yathāha “katamāni aṭṭha diṭṭhiṭṭhānāni? Khandhāpi diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ, avijjāpi, phassopi,
analyzed: yathā āha katamāni aṭṭha diṭṭhi ṭṭhānāni khandhā api diṭṭhi ṭṭhānam avijjā api phassaḥ api
translated: As it is said: “What are the eight standpoints for views? The aggregates are a standpoint for views, ignorance is, contact is,

original: saññāpi, vitakkopi, ayonisomanasikāropi, pāpamittopi, paratoghosopi diṭṭhiṭṭhāna”nti.
analyzed: saññā api vitakko api a yoniso manasikāraḥ api pāpa mittaḥ api paratoghoso api diṭṭhi ṭṭhānam ti
translated: perception is, applied thought is, wrong reflection is, bad friendship is, and hearing wrong teachings is a standpoint for views” .

original: “Khandhā hetu, khandhā paccayo diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ upādāya samuṭṭhānaṭṭhena, evaṃ khandhāpi

translated: “The aggregates are the cause and condition for the standpoint for views in the sense of being the source of the standpoint for views. Thus the aggregates are a standpoint for views.

original: diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ. Avijjā hetu…pe… pāpamitto hetu. Paratoghoso hetu, paratoghoso paccayo
analyzed: diṭṭhi ṭṭhānam avijjā hetu pe pāpa mittaḥ hetu paratoghosaḥ hetu paratoghosaḥ paccayo

original: diṭṭhiṭṭhānaṃ upādāya samuṭṭhānaṭṭhena, evaṃ paratoghosopi diṭṭhiṭṭhāna”nti. Evaṃgahitāti🔽diṭṭhisaṅkhātā tāva diṭṭhiṭṭhānā – “sassato attā ca loko cā”ti evaṃgahitā ādinnā,
analyzed: diṭṭhi ṭhānam upādāya samuṭṭhāna ṭṭhena evam paratoghosaḥ api diṭṭhi ṭhānam ti evaṃgahitā ati  diṭṭhi saṅkhātā tāva diṭṭhi ṭhānā sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati evaṃgahitā ādinnā
translated: that the sources of views called views are grasped, i.e. held to,

original: ‘idameva saccaṃ, moghamañña’nti pariniṭṭhāpitā. Kāraṇasaṅkhātā pana diṭṭhiṭṭhānā

original: evaṃ nirayatiracchānapettivisayagatikānaṃ aññataragatikā. Evaṃ abhisamparāyāti idaṃ

translated: that they have gone to one of the destinies of hell, animal realm, or the realm of hungry ghosts. “Thus come” means🔽that they have come from one of the destinies of hell, animal realm, or the realm of hungry ghosts.

original: purimapadasseva vevacanaṃ, evaṃvidhaparalokāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: purima padassa iva vevacanam evaṃvidha para lokā ti vuttam hoti
translated: It is a synonym for the first phrase. What is meant is: of such a kind as regards the other world.

original: Tañca tathāgato pajānātīti na kevalañca tathāgato sakāraṇaṃ sagatikaṃ diṭṭhigatameva
analyzed: tat ca tathāgataḥ pajānāti iti na kevalam ca tathāgataḥ sa kāraṇam sa gatikam diṭṭhi gatam eva

translated: but he also understands the virtue and the concentration that are higher than that,

analyzed: visesam pajānantaḥ api aham pajānāmi iti taṇhā diṭṭhi māna parāmāsa vasena tat ca na parāmasati  a parāmasato cassa paccattaññā eva nibbuti viditā ati evam a parāmasato cassa a parāmāsa paccayā
translated: and he understands the knowledge of omniscience. original: sayameva attanāyeva tesaṃ parāmāsakilesānaṃ nibbuti viditā. Pākaṭaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa nibbānanti dasseti.🔽Idāni yathāpaṭipannena tathāgatena sā nibbuti adhigatā, taṃ paṭipattiṃ dassetuṃ yāsu
analyzed: sayam eva attanāya iva tesam parāmāsa kilesānam nibbuti viditā pākaṭam bhikkhave tathāgatassa nibbānanti dasseti 🔽idāni yathā paṭipannena tathāgatena sā nibbuti adhigatā tam paṭipattim dassetuṃ yāsu
translated: his penetration of Nibbāna is evident in himself. He shows that Nibbāna is evident to the Tathāgata.

original: vedanāsu rattā titthiyā “idha sukhino bhavissāma, ettha sukhino bhavissāmā”ti diṭṭhigahanaṃ

original: evaṃ niddiṭṭhā sabbaññutaññāṇadhammā gambhīrā duddasā…pe… paṇḍitavedanīyāti veditabbā.

translated: This is the explanation of the dhammas that are deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, profound, understandable (only) by the wise, which the Tathagata, having realised them by his own super-knowledge, proclaims, and which he makes known to others.

translated: So when he asked the question he asked about the knowledge of omniscience, and when he answered he answered about the same thing, but in the interval he expounded the views.

original: Paṭhamabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Ekaccasassatavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  ekacca sassata vāda vaṇṇanā

original: 38. Ekaccasassatikāti ekaccasassatavādā. Te duvidhā honti – sattekaccasassatikā, saṅkhārekaccasassatikāti. Duvidhāpi idha gahitāyeva.🔽39. Yanti nipātamattaṃ. Kadācīti kismiñci kāle. Karahacīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Dīghassa
analyzed: ekacca sassatikā ati ekacca sassata vādā te duvidhā honti satta ekacca sassatikā saṅkhāra ekacca sassatikā ati duvidhā api idha gahitāya iva  yanti nipāta mattam kadāci iti kismiñci kāle tassa iva vevacanam dīghassa
translated: Eternalists are of two kinds, that is to say, eternalists in part and eternalists in a general sense. Both kinds are included here.

original: addhunoti dīghassa kālassa. Accayenāti atikkamena. Saṃvaṭṭatīti vinassati. Yebhuyyenāti
analyzed: addhunoti dīghassa kālassa accayena ati atikkamena saṃvaṭṭati iti vinassati yebhuyyena ati
translated: Yanti is merely a particle. Kadāci is at some time. Karahaci is a synonym for that. Dīghassa addhuno is of long duration. Accayenāti atikkamena is by the passing of. Saṃvaṭṭatīti vinassati is it is destroyed. Yebhuyyenāti is for the most part.

original: ye uparibrahmalokesu vā arūpesu vā nibbattanti, tadavasese sandhāya vuttaṃ. Jhānamanena
analyzed: ye upari brahmalokesu vā arūpesu vā nibbattanti tad avasese sandhāya vuttam jhānam anena
translated: and those who are reborn in the higher Brahmā worlds or in the immaterial world.🔽They are called “mind-made” because they are reborn by means of jhāna.

original: nibbattattā manomayā. Pīti tesaṃ bhakkho āhāroti pītibhakkhā. Attanova tesaṃ pabhāti🔽sayaṃpabhā. Antalikkhe carantīti antalikkhacarā. Subhesu uyyānavimānakapparukkhādīsu
analyzed: nibbatta ttā manaḥ mayā pīti tesam bhakkhaḥ āhāraḥ iti pīti bhakkhāḥ attanā uva tesam  sayaṃpabhāḥ antalikkhe caranti iti antalikkha carāḥ subhesu uyyāna vimāna kappa rukkha ādīsu
translated: They are “fed on rapture” because rapture is their food.🔽They are “self-luminous” because they are self-illumined.🔽They are “moving in the air” because they move in the air.🔽They are “abiding in beauty” because they abide in beautiful parks, palaces, and wish-fulfilling trees, etc.,

original: tiṭṭhantīti, subhaṭṭhāyino subhā vā manorammavatthābharaṇā hutvā tiṭṭhantīti subhaṭṭhāyino.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti iti subha ṭṭhāyino subhā vā manoramma vattha ābharaṇā hutvā tiṭṭhanti iti subha ṭṭhāyino

analyzed: vivaṭṭati iti saṇṭhāti suññam brahma vimānan ti pakatiyā nibbatta sattānam na thitāya  suññam brahmakāyika bhūmi nibbattati iti attho tassa kattā vā kāretā vā natthi visuddhi magge

original: vuttanayena pana kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānā ratanabhūmi nibbattati. Pakatinibbattiṭṭhānesuyeva
