original: cettha uyyānakapparukkhādayo nibbattanti. Atha sattānaṃ pakatiyā vasitaṭṭhāne nikanti
analyzed: ca ittha uyyāna kappa rukkha ādayaḥ nibbattanti atha sattānam pakatiyā vasita ṭṭhāne
translated: and the trees of the pleasure-park, etc., are produced there. Then, in the place where beings naturally live,

original: uppajjati, te paṭhamajjhānaṃ bhāvetvā tato otaranti, tasmā atha kho aññataro sattotiādimāha.🔽Āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vāti ye uḷāraṃ puññakammaṃ katvā yattha katthaci appāyuke
analyzed: uppajjati te paṭhama jhānam bhāvetvā tatas otaranti tasmai atha kho aññataraḥ satto tiādim āha  āyu khayā vā puñña khayā vā ati ye uḷāram puñña kammam katvā yattha katthaci appāyuke
translated: attachment arises. They develop the first jhāna and then come down from it. Therefore he says, “Then a certain being” , etc.

original: devaloke nibbattanti, te attano puññabalena ṭhātuṃ na sakkonti, tassa pana devalokassa🔽āyuppamāṇeneva cavantīti āyukkhayā cavantīti vuccanti. Ye pana parittaṃ puññakammaṃ
analyzed: deva loke nibbattanti te attano puñña balena ṭhātum na sakkonti tassa pana deva lokassa  āyu ppamāṇena iva cavanti iti āyu kkhayā cavanti iti vuccanti ye pana parittam puñña kammaṃ
translated: By the exhaustion of life or by the exhaustion of merit: those who have done abundant meritorious deeds and are reborn in some short-lived divine world cannot remain there by their own power;

original: katvā dīghāyukadevaloke nibbattanti, te yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhātuṃ na sakkonti, antarāva
analyzed: katvā dīgha āyuka deva loke nibbattanti te yāvatā āyukam ṭhātum na sakkonti antarā va
translated: they fall away with the very measure of life of that divine world. Therefore it is said, “They fall away by the exhaustion of life.” But those who have done limited meritorious deeds and are reborn in a divine world of long life cannot remain there for the full life-span;

original: cavantīti puññakkhayā cavantīti vuccanti. Dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭhatīti kappaṃ vā upaḍḍhakappaṃ vā.
analyzed: cavanti iti puñña kkhayā cavanti iti vuccanti dīgham addhānam tiṭṭhati iti kappam vā upaḍḍha kappam vā
translated: they fall away in the meantime. Therefore it is said, “They fall away by the exhaustion of merit.” For a long period: for an eon or for half an eon.

original: 41. Anabhiratīti aparassāpi sattassa āgamanapatthanā. Yā pana paṭighasampayuttā ukkaṇṭhitā,🔽sā brahmaloke natthi. Paritassanāti ubbijjanā phandanā, sā panesā tāsatassanā, taṇhātassanā,🔽diṭṭhitassanā, ñāṇatassanāti catubbidhā hoti. Tattha “jātiṃ paṭicca bhayaṃ bhayānakaṃ🔽chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso cetaso utrāso. Jaraṃ… byādhiṃ… maraṇaṃ paṭicca…pe… utrāso”ti
analyzed: anabhiratī ti aparassa api sattassa āgamana patthanā yā pana paṭigha sampayuttā ukkaṇṭhitā  sā brahma loke natthi paritassanā ati ubbijjanā phandanā sā panesā tāsa tassanā taṇhā tassanā  diṭṭhi tassanā ñāṇa tassanā ti catubbidhā hoti tattha jātim paṭicca bhayam bhayānakam  chambhitattam lomahaṃso jaram byādhim maraṇam paṭiccape utrāsoti
translated: Non-delight is the wish for another being to come. But the discontent associated with resentment is not in the Brahmā-world. Agitation is anxiety, trembling. But this agitation is fourfold as agitation due to fear, agitation due to craving, agitation due to view, and agitation due to knowledge. Herein, “Fear, fearful things,🔽fearfulness, terror, horror, a frightened state, a frightened heart, the hairs of the skin on end, mental disturbance, agitation, a state of mental agitation, occur with birth as condition” ,🔽and so too with ageing, sickness, and death.

original: ayaṃ tāsatassanā nāma. “Aho vata aññepi sattā itthattaṃ āgaccheyyu”nti ayaṃ taṇhātassanā🔽nāma. “Paritassitavipphanditamevā”ti ayaṃ diṭṭhitassanā nāma. “Tepi tathāgatassa🔽dhammadesanaṃ sutvā yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjantī”ti ayaṃ ñāṇatassanā🔽nāma. Idha pana taṇhātassanāpi diṭṭhitassanāpi vaṭṭati. Brahmavimānanti idha pana
analyzed: ayam tāsatassanā nāma aho vata aññe pi sattāḥ itthattam āgaccheyyun ti ayam taṇhātassanā 🔽nāma paritassita vipphanditam eva ati ayam diṭṭhitassanā nāma te pi tathāgatassa 🔽dhamma desanam sutvā yebhuyyena bhayam saṃvegam santāsam āpajjanti iti ayam ñāṇa tassanā 🔽nāma idha pana taṇhā tassanā api diṭṭhi tassanā api vaṭṭati brahma vimānanti idha pana
translated: Anabhirati is the wish for another being to come. But the kind of discontent that is associated with resentment does not exist in the Brahmā-world. Paritassanā is fear, terror, anxiety. It is of four kinds as fear of danger, fear of loss of loved ones, fear of loss of wealth, and fear of loss of life. But here only fear of danger and fear of loss of life are relevant. Herein, fear of danger is this: “Because of birth there is fear, fright, anxiety, agitation, and terror; because of ageing there is fear … because of death there is fear … because of sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair there is fear, fright, anxiety, agitation and terror” . This is called fear of danger. Fear of loss of life is this: “Oh, that I might not exist, that mine might not exist, that I might not come to be in the future” . This is called fear of loss of life. Herein, fear of loss of life is craving fear, and fear of danger is fear of loss of loved ones, fear of loss of wealth, and fear of loss of life. Herein, fear of loss of loved ones is this: “Oh, that my mother and father and kinsmen and relatives might not exist, that they might not come to be in the future” . This is called fear of loss of loved ones. Fear of loss of wealth is this: “Oh, that my fields and lands and gold and silver and jewels and property and possessions might not exist, that they might not come to be in the future” . This is called fear of loss of wealth. Fear of loss of life is this: “Oh, that I might not exist, that I might not come to be in the future” . This is called fear of loss of life. Herein, fear of loss of loved ones and fear of loss of life are relevant here. Brahmavimāna:

original: paṭhamābhinibbattassa atthitāya suññanti na vuttaṃ. Upapajjantīti upapattivasena
analyzed: paṭhama abhinibbattassa atthitāya suññanti na vuttam upapajjanti iti upapatti vasena
translated: because it is the first to be produced, it is not said to be void because of its existence. They are being reborn: they are being reborn by way of rebirth-linking.

original: upagacchanti. Sahabyatanti sahabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: upagacchanti sahabyatanti sahabhāvam
translated: With: with the state of being together.

original: 42. Abhibhūti abhibhavitvā ṭhito jeṭṭhakohamasmīti. Anabhibhūtoti aññehi anabhibhūto.
analyzed: abhibhū ti abhibhavitvā ṭhitaḥ jeṭṭhakaḥ ham asmi iti anabhibhūtaḥ ti aññehi anabhibhūtaḥ
translated: Dominant: standing having dominated, thinking ‘I am the eldest’. Undominated: not dominated by others.

original: Aññadatthūti ekaṃsavacane nipāto. Dassanavasena daso, sabbaṃ passāmīti attho. Vasavattīti🔽sabbaṃ janaṃ vase vattemi. Issaro kattā nimmātāti ahaṃ loke issaro, ahaṃ lokassa
analyzed: ekaṃsavacane nipātaḥ dassana vasena dasaḥ sabbam passāmi iti atthaḥ vasa vattī iti  sabbam janam vase vattemi issaraḥ kattā nimmātā ati aham loke issaraḥ aham lokassa
translated: For another’s sake: the particle is in the singular. By way of seeing: he is ten, the meaning is ‘I see everything’. He is the lord:

original: kattā ca nimmātā ca, pathavī – himavanta-sineru-cakkavāḷa-mahāsamudda-candima-sūriyā
analyzed: kattā ca nimmātā ca pathavī himavanta sineru cakkavāḷa mahā samudda candima sūriyā
translated: I control all people. He is the lord, the maker, the creator: I am the lord of the world, I am the maker and creator of the world, the earth, the Himalayas, Sineru, the Cakkavāḷa, the great ocean, the moon, the sun,

original: mayā nimmitāti. Seṭṭho sajitāti ahaṃ lokassa uttamo ca sajitā ca, “tvaṃ khattiyo
analyzed: mayā nimmitā ati seṭṭhaḥ sajitā ati aham lokassa uttamaḥ ca sajitā ca tvam khattiyo
translated: I am the creator. He is the best, the creator: I am the best and the creator of the world, ‘You are called a warrior,

original: nāma hohi, tvaṃ brāhmaṇo, vesso, suddo, gahaṭṭho, pabbajito nāma. Antamaso tvaṃ oṭṭho
analyzed: nāma hohi tvam brāhmaṇaḥ vessaḥ suddaḥ gahaṭṭho pabbajitaḥ nāma antamaso tvam oṭṭho
translated: you are a brahmin, a merchant, a worker, a householder, a monk. At the very least you are a dog,🔽you are a pig, you are a cat, you are a jackal, you are a snake, you are a rat, you are a worm, you are a gnat, you are a mosquito, you are a fish, you are a bird, you are a deer, you are a wild beast, you are a ghost, you are a demon, you are a human, you are a god, you are a gandhabba, you are a snake, you are a cat, you are a dog, you are a pig, you are a worm, you are a gnat, you are a mosquito, you are a fish, you are a bird, you are a deer, you are a wild beast, you are a ghost, you are a demon, you are a human, you are a god, you are a gandhabba, you are a snake, you are a cat, you are a dog, you are a pig, you are a worm, you are a gnat, you are a mosquito, you are a fish, you are a bird, you are a deer, you are a wild beast, you are a ghost, you are a demon, you are a human, you are a god, you are a gandhabba, you are a snake, you are a cat, you are a dog, you are a pig, you are a worm

original: hohi, goṇo hohī”ti “evaṃ sattānaṃ saṃvisajetā aha”nti maññati. Vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānanti
analyzed: hohi goṇaḥ hohi iti evam sattānam saṃvisajetā ahanti maññati vasī pitā
translated: “Be a bull, be an ox,” he thinks, “I am the one who distributes beings.”

original: ahamasmi ciṇṇavasitāya vasī, ahaṃ pitā bhūtānañca bhabyānañcāti maññati. Tattha aṇḍajajalābujā
analyzed: aham asmi ciṇṇa vasitāya vasī aham pitā bhūtānam ca bhabyānam ca ati maññati tattha aṇḍa ja jalābu jā
translated: “I am the father of what has been and what will be”: he thinks, “I am the one who has mastered the mastery of the past and the future, I am the father of what has been and what will be.” Herein, beings born from eggs and from the womb

original: sattā antoaṇḍakose ceva antovatthimhi ca bhabyā nāma, bahi nikkhantakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: sattā antoaṇḍakose ca iva antovatthimhi ca bhabyā nāma bahi nikkhanta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: are called “what will be” as long as they are inside the egg or the womb,🔽and “what has been” from the time they emerge from the egg or the womb.

original: bhūtā nāma. Saṃsedajā paṭhamacittakkhaṇe bhabyā, dutiyato paṭṭhāya bhūtā. Opapātikā🔽paṭhamairiyāpathe bhabyā, dutiyato paṭṭhāya bhūtāti veditabbā. Te sabbepi mayhaṃ
analyzed: bhūtāḥ nāma saṃseda jā paṭhama cittakkhaṇe bhabyāḥ dutiyataḥ paṭṭhāya bhūtāḥ opapātikā  paṭhama eriyāpathe bhabyāḥ dutiyataḥ paṭṭhāya bhūtā ati veditabbā te sabbe pi mayham
translated: Those born from moisture are “what will be” in the first moment of their rebirth-linking consciousness, and they are “what has been” from the second moment onward. Those born by spontaneous generation

original: puttāti saññāya “ahaṃ pitā bhūtabhabyāna”nti maññati.
analyzed: putta ati saññāya aham pitā bhūta bhabyānan ti maññati
translated: should be understood as “what will be” in the first moment of their first physical manifestation, and as “what has been” from the second moment onward. He thinks, “I am the father of what has been and what will be” with the perception that all these beings are his children.

original: Idāni kāraṇato sādhetukāmo – “mayā ime sattā nimmitā”ti paṭiññaṃ katvā “taṃ kissa
analyzed: idāni kāraṇataḥ sādhetu kāmo mayā ime sattāḥ nimmitāḥ ati paṭiññam katvā tam kissa
translated: Now, wanting to prove his case by reason, he makes the assertion, “I created these beings,” and then says, “For what reason? ”

original: hetū”tiādimāha. Itthattanti itthabhāvaṃ, brahmabhāvanti attho. Iminā mayanti attano
analyzed: hetu iti ādim āha itthattam ittha bhāvam brahma bhāvam ti iminā
translated: “For the sake of this”: for the sake of this state of being a woman, for the sake of this state of being a brahma, is the meaning. “For this purpose”: for the purpose of this.

original: kammavasena cutāpi upapannāpi ca kevalaṃ maññanāmatteneva “iminā mayaṃ nimmitā”ti
analyzed: kamma vasena cutā api upapannā api ca kevalam maññanā mattena iva iminā mayam nimmitā ati
translated: and they were reborn by kamma, but they thought only in terms of conceiving, and they conceived thus: “We have been created by him.”

original: maññamānā vaṅkacchidde vaṅkaāṇī viya onamitvā tasseva pādamūlaṃ gacchantīti.
analyzed: maññamānāḥ vaṅka chidde vaṅka āṇī viyas onamitvā tassa iva pāda mūlam gacchanti iti
translated: and they went to the foot of his tree, bending like a bamboo that has been struck.🔽More comely: more comely, more handsome, more beautiful.

original: 43. Vaṇṇavantataro cāti vaṇṇavantataro, abhirūpo pāsādikoti attho. Mahesakkhataroti issariyaparivāravasena mahāyasataro.
analyzed: vaṇṇavantataro ca ati vaṇṇavantataro abhirūpo pāsādiko ti attho mahesakkhataro ti issariya parivāra vasena mahāyasataro
translated: More illustrious: having greater power and greater retinue.

original: 44. Ṭhānaṃ kho panetanti kāraṇaṃ kho panetaṃ. So tato cavitvā aññatra na gacchati,
analyzed: ṭhānam kho panetanti kāraṇam kho panetanti saḥ tatas cavitvā aññatra na gacchati
translated: There is a reason for this: he does not go elsewhere after he dies,🔽but he comes here. This is said with reference to him. From home: from the house.

original: idheva āgacchati, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Agārasmāti gehā. Anagāriyanti pabbajjaṃ.
analyzed: idha iva āgacchati tam sandhāya itam vuttam agārasma ati gehā anagāriyanti pabbajjam
translated: To homelessness: to the going forth.

original: Pabbajjā hi yasmā agārassa hi taṃ kasigorakkhādikammaṃ tattha natthi, tasmā anagāriyanti
analyzed: pabbajjāḥ hi yasmai agārassa hi tam kasi gorakkha ādi kammam tattha natthi tasmai anagāriyanti
translated: For the going forth is called “homelessness” because it is not at home in such activities as agriculture, trading, and service to the king.

original: vuccati. Pabbajatīti upagacchati. Tato paraṃ nānussaratīti tato pubbenivāsā paraṃ
analyzed: vuccati pabbajati iti upagacchati tatas param na anussarati iti tatas pubbenivāsā param
translated: He goes forth: he undertakes. He does not remember anything beyond that:

original: na sarati, sarituṃ asakkonto tattha ṭhatvā diṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: na sarati saritum a sakkontaḥ tattha ṭhatvā diṭṭhim gaṇhāti
translated: he does not remember anything beyond his rebirth-linking. Unable to remember, he stands there and formulates a view.

original: Niccotiādīsu tassa upapattiṃ apassanto niccoti vadati, maraṇaṃ apassanto dhuvoti,
analyzed: niccaḥ iti ādīsu tassa upapattim a passantaḥ niccaḥ iti vadati maraṇam a passantaḥ dhuvaḥ ti
translated: Not seeing his arising, he says, “It is permanent.” Not seeing his death, he says, “It is stable,”

original: sadābhāvato sassatoti, jarāvasenāpi vipariṇāmassa abhāvato avipariṇāmadhammoti. Sesamettha
analyzed: sadā bhāvato sassatoti jarā vasena api vipariṇāmassa abhāvataḥ avipariṇāma dhammaḥ ti sesam ettha
translated: and “It is eternal” because of its being always, and “It is not subject to change” because of the absence of change by ageing. The rest is clear.

original: paṭhamavāre uttānamevāti.🔽45-46. Dutiyavāre khiḍḍāya padussanti vinassantīti khiḍḍāpadosikā, padūsikātipi pāḷiṃ🔽likhanti, sā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ natthi. Ativelanti atikālaṃ, aticiranti attho. Hassakhiḍḍāratidhammasamāpannāti🔽hassarati dhammañceva khiḍḍāratidhammañca samāpannā anuyuttā, keḷihassasukhañceva
analyzed: paṭhama vāre uttānam eva ati  dutiya vāre khiḍḍāya padussanti vinassanti iti khiḍḍā padosikā padūsikā atipi pāḷim  likhanti sā aṭṭhakathā ayam na atthi ativelam ti atikālam aticiram ti attho hassa khiḍḍā rati dhamma samāpannā ti  hassa rati dhammañca iva khiḍḍā rati dhammañca samāpannā anuyuttā keḷi hassa sukhañca iva
translated: Herein, the first section is straightforward.

original: kāyikavācasikakīḷāsukhañca anuyuttā, vuttappakāraratidhammasamaṅgino hutvā viharantīti attho.
analyzed: kāyika vācasika kīḷā sukham ca anuyuttāḥ vutta ppakāra rati dhamma samaṅginaḥ hutvā viharanti iti atthaḥ
translated: In the second section, they are “prone to take offence” because they are prone to be offended, that is, to be destroyed, by play; the reading padūsikā is written in the texts, but it is not in the commentary. “For a long time” means for a long period, for a long time is the meaning. “They are intent upon indulgence in the pleasures of wandering about and in the pleasures of society” means that they are intent upon the pleasure of wandering about and the pleasure of society, that is, upon the pleasure of wandering about in the various districts and the pleasure of society in the company of others. They live intent upon the pleasure of wandering about and the pleasure of society, is the meaning.

original: Sati sammussatīti khādanīyabhojanīyesu sati sammussati. Te kira puññavisesādhigatena
analyzed: sati sammussati iti khādanīya bhojanīyesu sati sammussati te kira puñña visesa adhigatena
translated: “Their mindfulness is muddled” means that their mindfulness is muddled about what is to be eaten and drunk. It seems that they are intent upon the pleasure of wandering about and the pleasure of society because of the special merit they have acquired.

original: mahantena attano sirivibhavena nakkhattaṃ kīḷantā tāya sampattimahantatāya – “āhāraṃ🔽paribhuñjimha, na paribhuñjimhā”tipi na jānanti. Atha ekāhārātikkamanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: mahantena attano siri vibhavena nakkhattam kīḷantā tāya sampatti mahanta tāya āhāram  na paribhuñjimha atipi na jānanti atha ekāhāra atikkamanataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: They are so great in their glory and wealth that they do not even know whether they have eaten or not. Then, after the lapse of a single meal,

original: nirantaraṃ khādantāpi pivantāpi cavantiyeva, na tiṭṭhanti. Kasmā? Kammajatejassa
analyzed: nirantaram khādantā api pivantā api cavantiyā iva na tiṭṭhanti kasmā kamma ja tejassa
translated: they die, not surviving, even though they continue to eat and drink without interruption. Why is this? Because the power of the kamma-born fire element

original: balavatāya, karajakāyassa mandatāya, manussānañhi kammajatejo mando, karajakāyo balavā.
analyzed: balavatāya karaja kāyassa manda tāya manussānam hi kamma ja tejaḥ mandaḥ karaja kāyaḥ balavā
translated: is strong and the power of the physical body is weak. For in human beings the kamma-born fire element is weak and the physical body is strong.

original: Tesaṃ tejassa mandatāya karajakāyassa balavatāya sattāhampi atikkamitvā uṇhodakaacchayāguādīhi
analyzed: tesam tejassa manda tāya karaja kāyassa balava tāya satta aham pi atikkamitvā uṇha udaka acchayā āgu ādīhi
translated: Because of the weakness of their fire element and the strength of their physical body, beings can survive for seven days after the lapse of food and drink by means of the nourishment provided by the water element in the body.

original: sakkā vatthuṃ upatthambhetuṃ. Devānaṃ pana tejo balavā hoti, karajaṃ mandaṃ. Te ekaṃ🔽āhāravelaṃ atikkamitvāva saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Yathā nāma gimhānaṃ majjhanhike tattapāsāṇe
analyzed: sakkā vatthum upatthambhetum devānam pana tejaḥ balavā hoti kara jam mandam te ekam  āhāra velam atikkamitvā ava saṇṭhātum na sakkonti yathā nāma gimhānam majjhanhike tatta pāsāṇe
translated: But the gods’ fire element is strong and their physical body is weak. They cannot survive after the lapse of a single meal.

original: ṭhapitaṃ padumaṃ vā uppalaṃ vā sāyanhasamaye ghaṭasatenāpi siñciyamānaṃ pākatikaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapitam padumam vā uppalam vā sāyanha samaye ghaṭa satena api pākatikam
translated: Just as a lotus or a water lily growing in the water and coming up to the surface cannot survive even if it is sprinkled with a hundred pots of water at midday in the hot season,

original: na hoti, vinassatiyeva. Evameva pacchā nirantaraṃ khādantāpi pivantāpi cavantiyeva,
analyzed: na hoti vinassatiyā iva evam eva pacchā nirantaram khādantā api pivantā api cavantiyā iva
translated: and it does not exist, it is destroyed. So too, those who eat and drink continuously in this way die,

original: na tiṭṭhanti. Tenāha “satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī”ti. Katame pana te🔽devāti? Ime devāti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vicāraṇā natthi, “devānaṃ kammajatejo balavā hoti,🔽karajaṃ manda”nti avisesena vuttattā pana ye keci kabaḷīkārāhārūpajīvino devā evaṃ
analyzed: na tiṭṭhanti tena āha satiyā sammosā te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti iti katame pana te  devāti ime devāti aṭṭhakathā ayam vicāraṇā natthi devānam kamma ja tejaḥ balavā hoti  kara jam mandanti avisesena vutta ttā pana ye keci kabaḷīkāra āhāra upajīvinaḥ devāḥ evam
translated: and they do not remain. Hence it is said: “Because of the loss of mindfulness those gods fall from that plane” . But which gods are they?🔽There is no discussion in the commentaries as to which gods are meant. But since it is said without distinction that “the fire of kamma-born heat is strong in the gods and the fire of food-born heat is weak,”🔽it may be understood that those gods who live on material food and act in this way fall.

original: karonti, teyeva cavantīti veditabbā. Keci panāhu – “nimmānaratiparanimmitavasavattino
analyzed: karonti teyeva cavanti iti veditabbā keci pana āhu nimmāna rati para nimmita vasa vattino
translated: But some say that the gods meant are the Nimmāṇarati and the Paranimmitavasavatti gods.

original: te devā”ti. Khiḍḍāpadussanamatteneva hete khiḍḍāpadosikāti vuttā. Sesamettha purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: te devā ti khiḍḍāpadussana mattena iva ha ete khiḍḍāpadosikā iti vuttā sesam ettha purima nayena iva veditabbam
translated: They are called “gods who destroy through play” because they destroy themselves through play. The rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: 47-48. Tatiyavāre manena padussanti vinassantīti manopadosikā, ete cātumahārājikā.
analyzed: tatiya vāre manena padussanti vinassanti iti mana upadosikāḥ ete cātumahārājikā
translated: In the third case, “those who destroy through mind” are the gods of the heaven of the Four Great Kings.

original: Tesu kira eko devaputto – nakkhattaṃ kīḷissāmīti saparivāro rathena vīthiṃ paṭipajjati,
analyzed: tesu kira ekaḥ deva puttaḥ nakkhattam kīḷissāmi iti sa parivāraḥ rathena vīthim paṭipajjati
translated: It seems that one of these gods, intending to play a trick on another, sets out in a chariot with his retinue along the road.

original: athañño nikkhamanto taṃ purato gacchantaṃ disvā – ‘bho ayaṃ kapaṇo’, adiṭṭhapubbaṃ
analyzed: athaññaḥ nikkhamantaḥ tam puratas gacchantam disvā bho ayam kapaṇaḥ a diṭṭha pubbam
translated: Then another man, coming out, saw him going along in front and said: ‘Good man, this is a pauper,

original: viya etaṃ disvā – “pītiyā uddhumāto viya bhijjamāno viya ca gacchatī”ti kujjhati.🔽Purato gacchantopi nivattitvā taṃ kuddhaṃ disvā – kuddhā nāma suviditā hontīti kuddhabhāvamassa
analyzed: viyas etam disvā pītiyā uddhu mātaḥ viya bhijjamānaḥ viya ca gacchati iti kujjhati  puratas gacchantaḥ api nivattitvā tam kuddham disvā kuddhāḥ nāma su viditāḥ honti iti kuddha bhāvam assa
translated: Then another one coming out sees him going in front and thinks, “Good Lord! This fellow is a miser,” and seeing him as if he had never been seen before, he is annoyed, thinking, “He goes about as if he were swollen with joy and as if he were bursting.”

original: ñatvā – “tvaṃ kuddho, mayhaṃ kiṃ karissasi, ayaṃ sampatti mayā dānasīlādīnaṃ vasena
analyzed: ñatvā tvam kuddhaḥ mayham kim karissasi ayam mayā dāna sīla ādīnam vasena
translated: And the one going in front, turning round, sees him annoyed. For those who are annoyed are well known. So he knows that he is annoyed and he is annoyed in return, thinking, “You are annoyed, but what can you do to me? This good fortune has been obtained by me through generosity, virtue, etc.,

original: laddhā, na tuyhaṃ vasenā”ti paṭikujjhati. Ekasmiñhi kuddhe itaro akuddho rakkhati,🔽ubhosu pana kuddhesu ekassa kodho itarassa paccayo hoti. Tassapi kodho itarassa paccayo
analyzed: laddhā na tuyham vasena ati paṭikujjhati ekasmin hi kuddhe itaraḥ akuddhaḥ rakkhati  ubhosu pana kuddhesu ekassa kodhaḥ itarassa paccayaḥ hoti tassa api kodhaḥ itarassa paccayaḥ
translated: not through you.” For when one is annoyed and the other is not, the one who is not annoyed protects the other;

original: hotīti ubho kandantānaṃyeva orodhānaṃ cavanti. Ayamettha dhammatā. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti ubho cavanti ayam ettha dhamma tā sesam vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: but when both are annoyed, the annoyance of one becomes a condition for the other’s annoyance, and the other’s annoyance becomes a condition for his own annoyance. So both of them perish like the two quarrelling who fell into the cesspit. This is the nature of things here. The rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: 49-52. Takkīvāde ayaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ bhedaṃ passati, cittaṃ pana yasmā purimaṃ purimaṃ
analyzed: takkīvāde ayam cakkha ādīnam bhedam passati cittam pana yasmā purimam purimam
translated: In the case of the “doctrine of the critic,” the eye, etc., are seen to be destroyed. But the mind is not.

original: pacchimassa pacchimassa paccayaṃ datvāva nirujjhati, tasmā cakkhādīnaṃ bhedato balavatarampi🔽cittassa bhedaṃ na passati. So taṃ apassanto yathā nāma sakuṇo ekaṃ rukkhaṃ jahitvā
analyzed: pacchimassa pacchimassa paccayam nirujjhati tasmā cakkha ādīnam bhedataḥ balavataram pi  cittassa bhedam na passati saḥ tam a passantaḥ yathā nāma sakuṇaḥ ekam rukkham jahitvā
translated: and the last of the last, and so on, it ceases. Therefore he does not see the mind’s dissolution even though it is more obvious than the dissolution of the eye, etc.

original: aññasmiṃ nilīyati, evameva imasmiṃ attabhāve bhinne cittaṃ aññatra gacchatīti gahetvā
analyzed: aññasmin nilīyati evam eva imasmin atta bhāve bhinne cittam aññatra gacchati iti gahetvā
translated: Not seeing it, he concludes that just as a bird leaves one tree and alights in another, so too, when this body breaks up the mind goes elsewhere.🔽So he says,

original: evamāha. Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam āha sesam ettha vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The rest should be understood in the way already described.

original: Antānantavādavaṇṇanā
translated: The doctrine of finitude and infinitude

original: 53. Antānantikāti antānantavādā, antaṃ vā anantaṃ vā antānantaṃ vā nevantānānantaṃ vā ārabbha pavattavādāti attho.🔽54-60. Antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: anta ānantikā ati anta ananta vādā antam vā anantam vā anta anantam vā vā ārabbha pavatta vādā ti attho  anta saññī lokasmim viharati iti paṭibhāga nimittam cakkavāḷa pariyantam a vaḍḍhetvā
translated: The doctrine of finitude and infinitude is the doctrine of finitude, of infinitude, of finitude and infinitude, and of neither finitude nor infinitude.🔽He dwells contemplating finitude in the world: without extending the counterpart sign beyond the horizon, he apprehends it as “the world” and dwells contemplating finitude in the world.

original: taṃ – “loko”ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo
analyzed: tam gahetvā anta saññī lokasmim viharati cakkavāḷa pariyantam katvā vaḍḍhita kasiṇaḥ
translated: Having extended the kasiṇa to the limit of the world,

original: pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī,🔽tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva
analyzed: pana ananta saññī hoti uddham adhas a vaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyam vaḍḍhetvā uddham adhas anta saññī  tiriyam ananta saññī takkīvādaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ ime cattāro api attanā diṭṭha pubba anusārena iva
translated: but he has the perception of an end in the height and depth, and the perception of the infinite in the breadth,

original: diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
analyzed: diṭṭhiyāḥ gahita ttā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā
translated: The theorist’s doctrine should be understood in the way already described. And all four of these are included among the speculators about the past because they are held to by means of a view that has had previous occurrence.

original: Amarāvikkhepavādavaṇṇanā🔽61. Na maratīti amarā. Kā sā? Evantipi me notiādinā nayena pariyantarahitā diṭṭhigatikassa🔽diṭṭhi ceva vācā ca. Vividho khepoti vikkhepo, amarāya diṭṭhiyā vācāya ca vikkhepoti
analyzed: na marati iti amarā kā sā me no ti ādinā nayena diṭṭhigatikassa  diṭṭhi ca iva vācā ca vividho khepo ti vikkhepo amarāya diṭṭhiyā vācāya ca vikkhepo ti
translated: The doctrine of endless equivocation

original: amarāvikkhepo, so etesaṃ atthīti amarāvikkhepikā, aparo nayo – amarā nāma ekā macchajāti,🔽sā ummujjananimujjanādivasena udake sandhāvamānā gahetuṃ na sakkāti, evameva ayampi
analyzed: amarā vikkhepo saḥ etesam atthi iti amarā vikkhepikā aparaḥ nayaḥ amarā nāma ekā maccha jāti  sā ummujjana nimujjana ādi vasena udake sandhāvamānā gahetum na sakkāti evam eva ayam pi
translated: “Endless” : not dying. What is it? The view and speech of one who has gone into the jungle of views in the way beginning, “It may be thus, it may be not thus” , and so on, is “endless equivocation” . The word vikkhepa is derived as follows: vividho khepo etesanti vikkhepakā . Another method: there is a kind of fish called “endless” ;🔽it is not possible to catch it because it keeps darting about in the water by rising to the surface and diving beneath it. So too, this doctrine keeps darting about here and there and does not come to a definite statement;

original: vādo itocito ca sandhāvati, gāhaṃ na upagacchatīti amarāvikkhepoti vuccati. So etesaṃ
analyzed: ca sandhāvati gāham na upagacchati iti amarā vikkhepaḥ ti vuccati saḥ etesam
translated: hence it is called “endless equivocation” .

original: atthīti amarāvikkhepikā.
analyzed: atthi iti amarāvikkhepikā
translated: “It exists” : he is a speculator on the undying.

original: 62. “Idaṃ kusala”nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātīti dasa kusalakammapathe yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: idam kusalanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti iti dasa kusala kammapathe yathābhūtam
translated: “He does not understand as it really is what is wholesome” : he does not understand as it really is the ten courses of wholesome kamma.

original: nappajānātīti attho. Akusalepi dasa akusalakammapathāva adhippetā. So mamassa vighātoti🔽“musā mayā bhaṇita”nti vippaṭisāruppattiyā mama vighāto assa, dukkhaṃ bhaveyyāti
analyzed: na ppajānāti iti attho akusale pi dasa akusala kammapathā adhippetā saḥ mama assa vighāto ti  musā mayā bhaṇitan ti vippaṭisāru ppattiyā mama vighātaḥ assa dukkham bhaveyya ati
translated: “He does not understand as it really is what is unwholesome” : the ten courses of unwholesome kamma are intended.🔽“That would be a vexation for me” : the arising of regret that “I have told a lie” would be a vexation for me. The meaning is: it would be painful for me.

original: attho. So mamassa antarāyoti so mama saggassa ceva maggassa ca antarāyo assa. Musāvādabhayā🔽musāvādaparijegucchāti musāvāde ottappena ceva hiriyā ca. Vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjatīti
analyzed: attho saḥ mama assa antarāyaḥ iti saḥ mama saggassa ca iva maggassa ca antarāyaḥ assa musāvāda bhayā  musāvāda parijegucchā ati musāvāde ottappena ca iva hiriyā ca vācā vikkhepam āpajjati iti
translated: “That would be an obstacle for me” : that would be an obstacle for me to heaven and the path.🔽“Through fear of lying” : through shame and abashment about lying.

original: vācāya vikkhepaṃ āpajjati. Kīdisaṃ? Amarāvikkhepaṃ, apariyantavikkhepanti attho.🔽Evantipi me notiādīsu evantipi me noti aniyamitavikkhepo. Tathātipi me noti “sassato
analyzed: vācāya vikkhepam āpajjati kīdisam amarā vikkhepam apariyanta vikkhepam ti attho  evam pi me no ti ādīsu evam pi me no ti aniyamita vikkhepaḥ tathā atipi me no ti
translated: “He falls into verbal distraction” : he falls into verbal distraction. What kind? “Undying distraction” : distraction without limit, is the meaning.🔽“It might be thus with me” : this is undirected distraction.🔽“It might be like this with me” : he rejects the eternalist doctrine stated thus: “The self and the world are eternal” .

original: attā ca loko cā”ti vuttaṃ sassatavādaṃ paṭikkhipati. Aññathātipi me noti sassatato
analyzed: attā ca loko ca iti vuttam sassata vādam paṭikkhipati aññathā atipi me no ti sassatato
translated: “It might be otherwise with me” : he rejects the doctrine of annihilation stated thus:

original: aññathā vuttaṃ ekaccasassataṃ paṭikkhipati. Notipi me noti – “na hoti tathāgato paraṃ🔽maraṇā”ti vuttaṃ ucchedaṃ paṭikkhipati. No notipi me noti “neva hoti na na hotī”ti🔽vuttaṃ takkīvādaṃ paṭikkhipati. Sayaṃ pana “idaṃ kusala”nti vā “akusala”nti vā puṭṭho🔽na kiñci byākaroti. “Idaṃ kusala”nti puṭṭho “evantipi me no”ti vadati. Tato “kiṃ🔽akusala”nti vutte “tathātipi me no”ti vadati. “Kiṃ ubhayato aññathā”ti vutte “aññathātipi
analyzed: aññathā vuttam ekacca sassatam paṭikkhipati no ti pi me no ti na hoti tathāgataḥ param  maraṇā iti vuttam ucchedam paṭikkhipati no no ti pi me no ti na iva hoti na na hoti iti  vuttam takkīvādam paṭikkhipati sayam pana idam kusalanti vā akusalanti vā puṭṭhaḥ  na kiñci byākaroti idam kusalanti me no ti vadati tato kim  akusalam ti vutte tathā atipi me no ti vadati kim ubhayatas aññathā ati vutte aññathā atipi
translated: “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is not annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is both annihilated and not annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is neither annihilated nor not annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata exists after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata does not exist after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata both exists and does not exist after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is not annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is both annihilated and not annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata is neither annihilated nor not annihilated after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata exists after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata does not exist after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata both exists and does not exist after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death.

original: me no”ti vadati. Tato “tividhenāpi na hoti, kiṃ te laddhī”ti vutte “notipi me no”ti🔽vadati. Tato “kiṃ no noti te laddhī”ti vutte “no notipi me no”ti evaṃ vikkhepameva🔽āpajjati, ekasmimpi pakkhe na tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: me no ti vadati tatas tividhena api na hoti kim te laddhi iti vutte no ti pi me no ti 🔽vadati tatas kim no no ti te laddhi iti vutte no no ti pi me no ti evam vikkhepam eva 🔽āpajjati ekasmim pi pakkhe na tiṭṭhati
translated: “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata does not exist after death. “No” he rejects annihilationism. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata both exists and does not exist after death. “No” he rejects the view that the Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death. But when asked: “Is this good or bad?” he does not answer at all. When asked: “Is it good?” he says: “No, that is not my view.” Then, when asked: “Is it bad?” he says: “No, that is not my view.” When asked: “Is it other than both?” he says: “No, that is not my view.” Then, when asked: “If it is not any of these three, what is your view?” he says: “No, that is not my view.” Then, when asked: “What is your view then?” he says: “No, that is not my view.” Thus he falls into equivocation and does not stand by any position.

original: 63. Chando vā rāgo vāti ajānantopi sahasā kusalameva “kusala”nti vatvā akusalameva🔽“akusala”nti vatvā mayā asukassa nāma evaṃ byākataṃ, kiṃ taṃ subyākatanti aññe paṇḍite
analyzed: chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā ati a jānantaḥ api sahasā kusalam eva kusalanti vatvā a kusalam eva  akusalam ti vatvā mayā asukassa nāma evam byākatam kim tam su byākatanti aññe paṇḍite
translated: Or craving or lust or hate or aversion: if, not knowing, one has called what is wholesome “wholesome” and what is unwholesome “unwholesome,”

original: pucchitvā tehi – “subyākataṃ, bhadramukha, kusalameva tayā kusalaṃ, akusalameva akusalanti🔽byākata”nti vutte natthi mayā sadiso paṇḍitoti evaṃ me tattha chando vā rāgo vā assāti
analyzed: pucchitvā tehi su byākatam bhadra mukha kusalam eva tayā kusalam a kusalam eva a kusalanti  byākatam ti vutte natthi mayā sadisaḥ paṇḍito ti evam me tattha chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā assa ati
translated: and if others ask, “How was this explained by so-and-so? Was it well explained?” and if they say, “Friend, it was well explained. You called what is wholesome wholesome and what is unwholesome unwholesome,”

original: attho. Ettha ca chando dubbalarāgo, rāgo balavarāgo. Doso vā paṭigho vāti kusalaṃ🔽pana “akusala”nti, akusalaṃ vā “kusala”nti vatvā aññe paṇḍite pucchitvā tehi – “dubyākataṃ🔽tayā”ti vutte ettakampi nāma na jānāmīti tattha me assa doso vā paṭigho vāti attho.
analyzed: attho ettha ca chandaḥ dubbala rāgaḥ rāgaḥ balava rāgaḥ dosaḥ vā paṭighaḥ vā ati kusalam  pana akusalanti akusalam vā kusalanti vatvā aññe paṇḍite pucchitvā tehi dubyākatam  tayā iti vutte ettakam pi nāma na jānāmi iti tattha me assa dosaḥ vā paṭighaḥ vā ti attho
translated: then one might think, “There is no one more knowledgeable than I am.” This is the meaning of “craving or lust” and “hate or aversion.” Herein, craving is weak lust, and lust is strong lust.

original: Idhāpi doso dubbalakodho, paṭigho balavakodho.
analyzed: idha api dosaḥ dubbala kodhaḥ paṭighaḥ balava kodhaḥ
translated: Hate is weak anger, and aversion is strong anger.

original: Taṃ mamassa upādānaṃ, so mamassa vighātoti taṃ chandarāgadvayaṃ mama upādānaṃ assa,
analyzed: tam mama assa upādānam saḥ mama assa vighāto ti tam chanda rāga dvayam mama upādānam assa
translated: “That is my clinging, that is my vexation”: that is the pair, desire and lust, my clinging;

original: dosapaṭighadvayaṃ vighāto. Ubhayampi vā daḷhaggahaṇavasena upādānaṃ, vihananavasena
analyzed: dosa paṭigha dvayam vighātaḥ ubhayam pi vā daḷha ggahaṇa vasena upādānam vihanana vasena
translated: the pair, hate and resentment, my vexation. Or else both are clinging in the sense of close attachment,

original: vighāto. Rāgo hi amuñcitukāmatāya ārammaṇaṃ gaṇhāti jalūkā viya. Doso vināsetukāmatāya🔽āsīviso viya. Ubhopi cete santāpakaṭṭhena vihananti yevāti “upādāna”nti ca “vighāto”ti
analyzed: vighātaḥ rāgaḥ hi a muñcitu kāma tāya ārammaṇam gaṇhāti jalūkā viya dosaḥ vinā setu kāma tāya  ubho api ca ite santāpa kaṭṭhena vihananti ca
translated: and vexation in the sense of annoyance. For lust takes hold of an object through the wish to appropriate it, like a leech;

original: ca vuttā. Sesaṃ paṭhamavārasadisameva.
analyzed: ca vuttā sesam paṭhama vāra sadisam eva
translated: and hate through the wish to destroy it, like a poisonous snake. And both of them vex by burning, as it were, through their state of being torment. Thus they are called “clinging” and “vexation.” The rest is as in the first section.

original: 64. Paṇḍitāti paṇḍiccena samannāgatā. Nipuṇāti saṇhasukhumabuddhino sukhumaatthantaraṃ
analyzed: paṇḍitā ati paṇḍiccena samannāgatā nipuṇā ati saṇha sukhuma buddhino sukhuma atthantaram
translated: “Wise”: endowed with wisdom. “Skilled”: having a delicate, subtle understanding, capable of penetrating subtle meanings.

original: paṭivijjhanasamatthā. Kataparappavādāti viññātaparappavādā ceva parehi saddhiṃ katavādaparicayā
analyzed: paṭivijjhana samatthā kata para ppavādā ati viññāta para ppavādā ca iva parehi saddhim kata vāda paricayā
translated: “Conversant with the doctrines of others”: they are acquainted with the doctrines of others and have had discussions with others.🔽“Like a hair’s end on the point of an awl”: like an awl with a hair’s end on its point.

original: ca. Vālavedhirūpāti vālavedhidhanuggahasadisā. Te bhindantā maññeti vālavedhi viya
analyzed: ca vālavedhi rūpā ati vālavedhi dhanuggaha sadisā te bhindantā maññā iti vālavedhi viya
translated: “They think they are piercing”:

original: vālaṃ sukhumānipi paresaṃ diṭṭhigatāni attano paññāgatena bhindantā viya carantīti
analyzed: vālam sukhumāni api paresam diṭṭhi gatāni attano paññāgatena bhindantāḥ viya caranti iti
translated: They go about as if they were breaking up the subtle views of others with their own understanding.

original: attho. Te maṃ tatthāti te samaṇabrāhmaṇā maṃ tesu kusalākusalesu. Samanuyuñjeyyunti
analyzed: attho te mam tattha ati te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ mam tesu kusala akusalesu samanuyuñjeyyun ti
translated: This is the meaning. They would question me there: those ascetics and Brahmins would question me there about what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, saying:

original: “kiṃ kusalaṃ, kiṃ akusalanti attano laddhiṃ vadā”ti laddhiṃ puccheyyuṃ. Samanugāheyyunti
analyzed: kim kusalam kim akusalanti attanaḥ laddhim vadāti laddhim puccheyyum samanugāheyyum
translated: “Tell us your own view as to what is wholesome and what is unwholesome.” They would cross-question me:

original: “idaṃ nāmā”ti vutte “kena kāraṇena etamatthaṃ gāheyyu”nti kāraṇaṃ puccheyyuṃ. Samanubhāseyyunti
analyzed: idam nāma ati vutte kena kāraṇena etam attham gāheyyun ti kāraṇam puccheyyum samanubhāseyyun ti
translated: having been told “It is this,” they would ask the reason for it, saying: “For what reason do you take this to be so?” They would rebuke me:

original: “iminā nāma kāraṇenā”ti vutte kāraṇe dosaṃ dassetvā “na tvaṃ idaṃ jānāsi, idaṃ pana🔽gaṇha, idaṃ vissajjehī”ti evaṃ samanuyuñjeyyuṃ. Na sampāyeyyanti na sampādeyyaṃ,
analyzed: iminā nāma kāraṇena ati vutte kāraṇe dosam dassetvā na tvam idam jānāsi idam pana  gaṇha idam vissajjehi iti evam samanuyuñjeyyum na sampāyeyyanti na sampādeyyam
translated: having been told “For this reason,” they would point out the fault in the reason, saying: “You do not know this,

original: sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkuṇeyyanti attho. So mamassa vighātoti yaṃ taṃ punappunaṃ🔽vatvāpi asampāyanaṃ nāma, so mama vighāto assa, oṭṭhatālujivhāgalasosanadukkhameva
analyzed: sampādetvā kathetum na sakkuṇeyyanti atthaḥ saḥ mama assa vighāto ti yam tam punappunam 🔽vatvā api asampāyanam nāma saḥ mama vighātaḥ assa oṭṭha tālu jivhā gala sosana dukkham eva
translated: you have misunderstood this, you have not grasped this, you have not penetrated this, you have not seen this, you have not known this, you have not fathomed this, you have not reached this, you have not attained this, you have not realized this, you have not experienced this, you have not understood this, you have not comprehended this, you have not discerned this, you have not investigated this, you have not considered this, you have not reflected on this, you have not contemplated this, you have not seen this as it really is, you have not known this as it really is, you have not fathomed this as it really is, you have not penetrated this as it really is, you have not known this as it really is, you have not understood this as it really is, you have not realized this as it really is, you have not experienced this as it really is, you have not comprehended this as it really is, you have not discerned this as it really is, you have not investigated this as it really is, you have not considered this as it really is, you have not reflected on this as it really is, you have not contemplated this as it really is, you have not seen this as it really is, you have not known this as it really is, you have not fathomed this as it really is, you have not penetrated this as it really is, you have not known this as it really is, you have not understood this as it really is, you have not realized this as it really is, you have not experienced this as it really is, you have not comprehended this as it really is, you have not discerned this as it really is, you have not investigated this as it really is, you have not considered this as it really is,

original: assāti attho. Sesametthāpi paṭhamavārasadisameva.
analyzed: assa ati attho sesam ettha api paṭhama vāra sadisam eva
translated: the meaning is, “he is a donkey.” The rest is as in the first section.

original: 65-66. Mandoti mandapañño apaññassevetaṃ nāmaṃ. Momūhoti atisammūḷho. Hoti tathāgatotiādīsu🔽satto “tathāgato”ti adhippeto. Sesamettha uttānameva. Imepi cattāro pubbe pavattadhammānusāreneva
analyzed: mandaḥ iti manda paññaḥ apaññassa iva etam nāmam momūho ti ati sammūḍhaḥ hoti tathāgataḥ tiādīsu  sattaḥ tathāgataḥ ti adhippeto sesam ettha uttānam eva ime pi cattāro pubbe pavatta dhamma anusārena iva
translated: “Dull” : he is of dull understanding, the name for one who is unwise. “Obscured” : he is very much obscured. In the case of the remaining terms,

original: diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
analyzed: diṭṭhiyāḥ gahita ttā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā
translated: “a being” is intended by “a Tathāgata.” The rest is plain. And these four are included among the speculators about the past because they hold their views through having acquired a speculative theory that occurs in the past.

original: Adhiccasamuppannavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: adhicca samuppanna vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the doctrine of fortuitous origination.

original: 67. “Adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko cā”ti dassanaṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ. Taṃ etesaṃ atthīti adhiccasamuppannikā. Adhiccasamuppannanti akāraṇasamuppannaṃ.
analyzed: adhicca samuppannaḥ attā ca loko ca ati dassanam adhicca samuppannam tam etesam atthi iti adhicca samuppannikā adhicca samuppannam ti akāraṇa samuppannam
translated: The view that “the self and the world have arisen by chance” is fortuitous origination. They have that, thus they are fortuitous originationists. Fortuitous origination is origination without a cause.

original: 68-73. Asaññasattāti desanāsīsametaṃ, acittuppādā rūpamattakaattabhāvāti attho. Tesaṃ
analyzed: asaññasattā ati desanā sīsam etam acittuppādāḥ rūpa mattaka atta bhāvā ti attho tesam
translated: “Non-percipient beings” is the peak of the teaching. The meaning is, they have a mere material nature, since there is no arising of consciousness.

original: evaṃ uppatti veditabbā – ekacco hi titthāyatane pabbajitvā vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ
analyzed: evam uppatti veditabbā ekaccaḥ hi titthāyatane pabbajitvā vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ
translated: Their origination should be understood thus. Someone, having gone forth in a sect of ascetics that practices the kasiṇa of air, having attained jhāna by making the air element his object, thinks,

original: katvā catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā jhānā vuṭṭhāya – “citte dosaṃ passati, citte sati
analyzed: katvā catuttha jhānam nibbattetvā jhānā vuṭṭhāya citte dosam passati citte sati
translated: Having done so, he produces the fourth jhāna and emerges from it with the thought: ‘I see danger in consciousness; I see the escape from it thus. ’🔽When there is consciousness, there is the perception of a self;

original: hatthacchedādidukkhañceva sabbabhayāni ca honti, alaṃ iminā cittena, acittakabhāvova
analyzed: hattha cheda ādi dukkham ca iva sabba bhayāni ca honti alam iminā cittena
translated: and there is the suffering due to the cutting off of the hand, etc., and all the fears. Enough with this consciousness!

original: santo”ti, evaṃ citte dosaṃ passitvā aparihīnajjhāno kālaṃ katvā asaññasattesu nibbattati,
analyzed: santo ti evam citte dosam passitvā a parihīna jjhānaḥ kālam katvā asaññasattesu nibbattati
translated: The unconscious state is peaceful. ’ Having thus seen danger in consciousness and having seen the escape from it thus, he attains the destruction of the taints without ever returning from that world.

original: cittamassa cuticittanirodhena idheva nivattati, rūpakkhandhamattameva tattha pātubhavati.
analyzed: cittam assa cuti citta nirodhena idha iva nivattati rūpa kkhandha mattam eva tattha pātubhavati
translated: His consciousness ceases with the cessation of the death consciousness here, and only the material form aggregate reappears there.

original: Te tattha yathā nāma jiyāvegakkhitto saro yattako jiyāvego, tattakameva ākāse gacchati.
analyzed: te tattha yathā nāma jiyāvega khittaḥ saraḥ yattakaḥ jiyāvegaḥ tattakam eva ākāse gacchati
translated: Just as an arrow shot by a strong archer goes through space and falls when its impetus is spent,

original: Evameva jhānavegakkhittā upapajjitvā yattako jhānavego, tattakameva kālaṃ tiṭṭhanti,
analyzed: evam eva jhāna vega khittāḥ upapajjitvā yattakaḥ jhāna vego tattakam eva kālam tiṭṭhanti
translated: so too, when he is reborn by the impetus of jhāna, he remains there for as long as the impetus of jhāna lasts,

original: jhānavege pana parihīne tattha rūpakkhandho antaradhāyati, idha pana paṭisandhisaññā
analyzed: jhāna vege pana parihīne tattha rūpa kkhandho antaradhāyati idha pana paṭisandhi saññā
translated: but when the impetus of jhāna is spent, the material form aggregate disappears there and the rebirth-linking perception arises here.

original: uppajjati. Yasmā pana tāya idha uppannasaññāya tesaṃ tattha cuti paññāyati, tasmā
analyzed: uppajjati yasmā pana tāya idha uppanna saññāya tesam tattha cuti paññāyati tasmā
translated: But because of the perception that arises here, the death of those beings is known there.

original: “saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī”ti vuttaṃ. Santatāyāti santabhāvāya.
analyzed: saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti iti vuttam santa tāya ati santa bhāvāya
translated: “And when perception arises in them, they fall from that state of existence.” “For the sake of continuity”: for the sake of the continuity of the self.

original: Sesamettha uttānameva. Takkīvādopi vuttanayeneva veditabboti.
analyzed: sesam ettha uttānam eva takkīvādaḥ api vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ ti
translated: The rest is clear. The doctrine of the speculators should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Aparantakappikavaṇṇanā🔽74. Evaṃ aṭṭhārasa pubbantakappike dassetvā idāni catucattārīsaṃ aparantakappike
analyzed: evam aṭṭhārasa pubbantakappike dassetvā idāni catucattārīsam aparantakappike
translated: The exposition of the speculators about the future

original: dassetuṃ – “santi, bhikkhave”tiādimāha. Tattha anāgatakoṭṭhāsasaṅkhātaṃ aparantaṃ
analyzed: dassetum santi bhikkhave ti ādim āha tattha anāgata koṭṭhāsa saṅkhātam aparantam
translated: Having thus shown the eighteen speculators about the past, he now said, “Bhikkhus, there are some ascetics and brahmins” in order to show the forty-four speculators about the future.🔽Therein, the future is called the “future limit” .

original: kappetvā gaṇhantīti aparantakappikā, aparantakappo vā etesaṃ atthīti aparantakappikā.
analyzed: kappetvā gaṇhanti iti aparantakappikāḥ aparanta kappaḥ va etesam atthi iti aparantakappikā
translated: They hold the future limit, thus they are “speculators about the future limit” .

original: Evaṃ sesampi pubbe vuttappakāranayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam sesam pi pubbe vutta ppakāra nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Saññīvādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saññī vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the speculators about perception

original: 75. Uddhamāghātanikāti āghātanaṃ vuccati maraṇaṃ, uddhamāghātanā attānaṃ vadantīti uddhamāghātanikā. Saññīti pavatto vādo, saññīvādo, so etesaṃ atthīti saññīvādā.
analyzed: uddham āghātanikā ati āghātanam vuccati maraṇam uddham āghātanā attānam vadanti iti uddham āghātanikā saññī iti pavattaḥ vādaḥ saññīvādo saḥ etesam atthi iti saññīvādā
translated: “Speculators about the future”: “killing” is death. They kill themselves for the sake of the future, thus they are “speculators about the future” . “Perception” is a doctrine. They have the doctrine of perception, thus they are “speculators about perception.”

original: 76-77. Rūpī attātiādīsu kasiṇarūpaṃ “attā”ti tattha pavattasaññañcassa “saññā”ti
analyzed: rūpī attā ati ādīsu kasiṇa rūpam attā ati tattha saññā ti
translated: In the case of the remaining three, the kasiṇa materiality is the “self,” and the perception occurring there is “perception of self.”

original: gahetvā vā ājīvakādayo viya takkamatteneva vā “rūpī attā hoti, arogo paraṃ maraṇā🔽saññī”ti naṃ paññapenti. Tattha arogoti nicco. Arūpasamāpattinimittaṃ pana “attā”ti🔽samāpattisaññañcassa “saññā”ti gahetvā vā nigaṇṭhādayo viya takkamatteneva vā “arūpī
analyzed: gahetvā vā ājīvaka ādayaḥ viya takka mattena iva vā rūpī attā hoti arogaḥ param  saññī iti nam paññapenti tattha arogo ti niccaḥ arūpa samāpatti nimittam pana attā ati  samāpatti saññañcassa saññā ti gahetvā vā nigaṇṭha ādayaḥ viya takka mattena iva vā arūpī
translated: In the case of the first tetrad, the Ājīvakas, for instance, assume the kasiṇa materiality to be the self and the perception occurring there to be “his perception.” Or else they simply assert the self to be material, healthy, and percipient after death, out of mere reasoning. Herein, “healthy” means permanent.

original: attā hoti, arogo paraṃ maraṇā saññī”ti naṃ paññapenti. Tatiyā pana missakagāhavasena
analyzed: attā hoti arogo param maraṇā saññī iti nam paññapenti tatiyā pana missaka gāha vasena
translated: The Nigaṇṭhas, for instance, assume the sign of the immaterial jhānas to be the self and the perception occurring there to be “his perception.” Or else they simply assert the self to be immaterial, healthy, and percipient after death, out of mere reasoning. Herein, the view occurring in the third case is a mixed assumption. That in the fourth case is a mere assumption by reasoning.

original: pavattā diṭṭhi. Catutthā takkagāheneva. Dutiyacatukkaṃ antānantikavāde vuttanayeneva🔽veditabbaṃ. Tatiyacatukke samāpannakavasena ekattasaññī, asamāpannakavasena nānattasaññī,
analyzed: pavattā diṭṭhi catutthā takka gāhena iva dutiya catukkam anta anantika vāde vutta nayena iva  veditabbam tatiya catukke samāpannaka vasena ekatta saññī asamāpannaka vasena nānatta saññī
translated: The second tetrad should be understood in the way stated in the case of the “extremists” .🔽In the third tetrad, the one perceiving unity is one who has attained jhāna; the one perceiving diversity is one who has not attained jhāna.

original: parittakasiṇavasena parittasaññī, vipulakasiṇavasena appamāṇasaññīti veditabbā. Catutthacatukke
analyzed: paritta kasiṇa vasena paritta saññī vipula kasiṇa vasena appamāṇa saññī iti veditabbā catuttha catukke
translated: The one perceiving limitedly is one who has a limited kasiṇa; the one perceiving the immeasurable is one who has an immeasurable kasiṇa. In the fourth tetrad,

original: pana dibbena cakkhunā tikacatukkajjhānabhūmiyaṃ nibbattamānaṃ disvā “ekantasukhī”ti🔽gaṇhāti. Niraye nibbattamānaṃ disvā “ekantadukkhī”ti. Manussesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā
analyzed: pana dibbena cakkhunā tika catukka jjhāna bhūmiyam nibbattamānam disvā ekanta sukhī iti  gaṇhāti niraye nibbattamānam disvā ekanta dukkhī iti manussesu nibbattamānam disvā
translated: but when he sees beings being reborn in the plane of the third and fourth jhānas through the divine eye, he concludes that they are “all happy”;🔽when he sees beings being reborn in hell, he concludes that they are “all miserable”; when he sees beings being reborn among human beings, he concludes that they are “both happy and miserable”;

original: “sukhadukkhī”ti. Vehapphaladevesu nibbattamānaṃ disvā “adukkhamasukhī”ti gaṇhāti.
analyzed: sukha dukkhī iti vehapphala devesu nibbattamānam disvā adukkham asukhī iti gaṇhāti
translated: when he sees beings being reborn among Vehapphala deities, he concludes that they are “neither happy nor miserable.”

original: Visesato hi pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇalābhino pubbantakappikā honti, dibbacakkhukā aparantakappikāti.
analyzed: visesataḥ hi pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa lābhinaḥ pubbanta kappikāḥ honti dibba cakkhukāḥ aparanta kappikā ati
translated: For it is those who have acquired knowledge of the recollection of past lives who are speculators about the past, while those who have acquired the divine eye are speculators about the future.

original: Asaññīvādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: asaññī vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The doctrine of non-percipient immortality

original: 78-83. Asaññīvādo saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena veditabbo.
analyzed: asaññīvādaḥ saññīvāde ādimhi vuttānam dvinnam catukkānam vasena veditabbo
translated: The doctrine of non-percipient immortality should be understood according to the first two of the four doctrines stated in the case of the doctrine of percipient immortality.🔽So too with the doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient immortality. Only the difference in wording should be noted here:

original: Tathā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādo. Kevalañhi tattha “saññī attā”ti gaṇhantānaṃ tā diṭṭhiyo,
analyzed: tathā nevasaññī nāsaññī vādo kevalam hi tattha saññī attā ati gaṇhantānam tāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: “Those who hold the view that the soul is percipient” are those who hold the view that the soul is non-percipient,

original: idha “asaññī”ti ca “nevasaññīnāsaññī”ti ca. Tattha na ekantena kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ.
analyzed: idha asaññī iti ca nevasaññīnāsaññī iti ca tattha na ekantena kāraṇam pariyesitabbam
translated: and those who hold the view that the soul is neither percipient nor non-percipient. There is no need to seek a reason for this in every case.

original: Diṭṭhigatikassa hi gāho ummattakapacchisadisoti vuttametaṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhi gatikassa hi gāhaḥ ummattaka pacchi sadisaḥ ti vuttam etam
translated: For it is said that the way a theorist grasps his view is like the way a madman grasps a weapon.

original: Ucchedavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uccheda vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The doctrine of annihilation

original: 84. Ucchedavāde satoti vijjamānassa. Ucchedanti upacchedaṃ. Vināsanti adassanaṃ.🔽Vibhavanti bhāvavigamaṃ. Sabbānetāni aññamaññavevacanāneva. Tattha dve janā ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: uccheda vāde satoti vijjamānassa upacchedam adassanam  vibhavanti bhāva vigamam tattha dve janāḥ uccheda diṭṭhim
translated: In the annihilationist view, “existing” is existing as a person. “Annihilation” is cutting off. “Destruction” is non-appearance.

original: gaṇhanti, lābhī ca alābhī ca. Lābhī arahato dibbena cakkhunā cutiṃ disvā upapattiṃ
analyzed: gaṇhanti lābhī ca alābhī ca lābhī arahataḥ dibbena cakkhunā cutim disvā upapattim
translated: “Disappearance” is the departure of the state of being. All these are synonyms for each other. Herein, two kinds of people take up the annihilationist view, namely, the gainer and the non-gainer. The gainer is the one who, having seen death with the divine eye, does not see rebirth.

original: apassanto, yo vā cutimattameva daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti, na upapātaṃ; so ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti.🔽Alābhī ca “ko paralokaṃ na jānātī”ti kāmasukhagiddhatāya vā. “Yathā rukkhato paṇṇāni🔽patitāni na puna viruhanti, evameva sattā”tiādinā takkena vā ucchedaṃ gaṇhāti. Idha
analyzed: a passantaḥ yaḥ vā cutimattam eva daṭṭhum sakkoti na upapātam saḥ uccheda diṭṭhim gaṇhāti  alābhī ca kaḥ para lokam na jānāti iti kāma sukha giddha tāya vā yathā rukkhataḥ paṇṇāni  patitāni na punar viruhanti evam eva sattāti ādinā takkena vā ucchedam gaṇhāti idha
translated: Or the one who can see only death and not rebirth takes up the annihilationist view.

original: pana taṇhādiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena tathā ca aññathā ca vikappetvāva imā satta diṭṭhiyo uppannāti veditabbā.
analyzed: pana taṇhā diṭṭhīnam vasena tathā ca aññathā ca vikappetvā ava imāḥ satta diṭṭhiyaḥ uppannā ti veditabbā
translated: And the non-gainer takes up annihilation either through the conceit “Who knows about the next world?” or through the speculation “Just as leaves fall from a tree and do not grow again, so it is with beings” and so on. Herein, however, these seven views should be understood to arise through speculation about the self in various ways by means of craving and views.

original: 85. Tattha rūpīti rūpavā. Cātumahābhūtikoti catumahābhūtamayo. Mātāpitūnaṃ etanti
analyzed: tattha rūpī iti rūpavā cātumahābhūtikaḥ iti catu mahābhūta mayaḥ mātā pitūnam
translated: Herein, “possessed of form” is having form. “Made of the four great elements” is made of the four great entities. “Derived from parents” is born of parents.

original: mātāpettikaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ? Sukkasoṇitaṃ. Mātāpettike sambhūto jātoti mātāpettikasambhavo.
analyzed: mātāpettikam kim tat sukka soṇitam mātāpettike sambhūtaḥ jātaḥ iti mātāpettika sambhavaḥ
translated: “Mother and father”: what is it? Semen and blood. “Born of mother and father”: he is called “born of mother and father” because he is produced from mother and father.

original: Iti rūpakāyasīsena manussattabhāvaṃ “attā”ti vadati. Ittheketi itthaṃ eke evameketi attho.
analyzed: iti rūpa kāya sīsena manussatta bhāvam attā ati vadati itthā ike iti ittham eke evam eke iti attho
translated: Thus he says that the human state is the self by way of the head of the material body. “Some”: thus it is said by some.

original: 86. Dutiyo taṃ paṭikkhipitvā dibbattabhāvaṃ vadati. Dibboti devaloke sambhūto. Kāmāvacaroti cha kāmāvacaradevapariyāpanno. Kabaḷīkāraṃ āhāraṃ bhakkhatīti kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho.
analyzed: dutiyaḥ tam paṭikkhipitvā dibbatta bhāvam vadati dibbaḥ ti deva loke sambhūto kāmāvacaro ti cha kāmāvacara deva pariyāpanno kabaḷīkāram āhāram bhakkhati iti kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkho
translated: The second, after rejecting the first, says that the divine state is the self. “Divine”: produced in the divine world. “Of the sense sphere”: included among the six kinds of sense-sphere gods. “He eats by mouthfuls”: he eats material food.

original: 87. Manomayoti jhānamanena nibbatto. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅgīti sabbaṅgapaccaṅgayutto. Ahīnindriyoti
analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ ti jhāna manena nibbatto sabbaṅga paccaṅgī iti sabbaṅga paccaṅga yuttaḥ ahīn indriyaḥ ti
translated: “Mind-made”: produced by jhāna mind. “Complete in all limbs”: endowed with all limbs. “Not deficient in any faculty”:

original: paripuṇṇindriyo. Yāni brahmaloke atthi, tesaṃ vasena itaresañca saṇṭhānavasenetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paripuṇṇa indriyaḥ yāni brahma loke atthi tesam vasena itaresam ca saṇṭhāna vasena itam vuttam
translated: he is endowed with all faculties. This is said with reference to those that exist in the Brahma-world and to the shape of the others.

original: 88-92. Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagotiādīsu
analyzed: sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkama ati ādīnam attho visuddhi magge vuttaḥ ākāsa anañca āyatana upagaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: The meaning of “having completely transcended material form, the attainment of the base of infinite space, etc., is given in the Visuddhimagga.

original: pana ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatoti, evamattho veditabbo. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: pana ākāsa anañcāyatana bhavam upagataḥ ti evam atthaḥ veditabbo sesam ettha uttānam eva ati

original: Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādavaṇṇanā🔽93. Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavāde diṭṭhadhammoti paccakkhadhammo vuccati, tattha tattha
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vāda vaṇṇanā  diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vāde diṭṭhadhammo ti paccakkha dhammo vuccati tattha tattha
translated: The doctrine of annihilation in this very life🔽In the doctrine of annihilation in this very life, the word “in this very life” is said of a visible state ;

original: paṭiladdhattabhāvassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Diṭṭhadhamme nibbānaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ,
analyzed: adhivacanam diṭṭhadhamme nibbānam diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam
translated: it is a designation for the individual existence obtained here and there. Annihilation in this very life is the annihilation of the individual existence in this very life.

original: imasmiṃyeva attabhāve dukkhavūpasamananti attho. Taṃ vadantīti diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā.
analyzed: imasmin yeva atta bhāve dukkha vūpasamanan ti attho tam vadanti iti diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādāḥ
translated: The meaning is: the stilling of suffering in this very individual existence. They proclaim that, thus they are “proclaimers of annihilation in this very life.”

original: Paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānanti paramaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānaṃ uttamanti attho.
analyzed: parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbānanti paramam diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam uttaman ti attho
translated: The highest annihilation in this very life: the highest annihilation in this very life is the best, is the meaning.

original: 94. Pañcahi kāmaguṇehīti manāpiyarūpādīhi pañcahi kāmakoṭṭhāsehi bandhanehi vā. Samappitoti
analyzed: pañcahi kāmaguṇehi iti manāpiya rūpa ādīhi pañcahi kāma koṭṭhāsehi bandhanehi vā
translated: With the five cords of sense desire: with the five kinds of sense desires beginning with visible forms that are agreeable, or with the five kinds of sense desires as fetters.

original: suṭṭhu appito allīno hutvā. Samaṅgībhūtoti samannāgato. Paricāretīti tesu kāmaguṇesu
analyzed: suṭṭhu appitaḥ allīno hutvā samaṅgībhūto ti samannāgato paricāreti iti tesu kāmaguṇesu
translated: He is bound: he is well bound, he is stuck fast. He is possessed: he is endowed.

original: yathāsukhaṃ indriyāni cāreti sañcāreti itocito ca upaneti. Atha vā laḷati ramati
analyzed: yathāsukham indriyāni cāreti sañcāreti ca upaneti atha vā laḷati ramati
translated: He enjoys himself: he enjoys himself with his faculties in the five kinds of sense desires as he likes, he indulges them, he directs them hither and thither. Or else he dallies, he delights,

analyzed: kīḷati ettha ca duvidhā kāma guṇā mānusakā ca iva dibbā ca mānusakā mandhātu kāma guṇa sadisā

original: daṭṭhabbā, dibbā paranimmitavasavattidevarājassa kāmaguṇasadisāti. Evarūpe kāme upagatānañhi
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā dibbā para nimmita vasavatti devarājassa kāma guṇa sadisā ati evarūpe kāme upagatānam hi

original: te diṭṭhadhammanibbānasampattiṃ paññapenti.🔽95. Dutiyavāre hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccā paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkhā, pakatijahanaṭṭhena🔽vipariṇāmadhammāti veditabbā. Tesaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvāti tesaṃ kāmānaṃ vipariṇāmasaṅkhātā
analyzed: te diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna sampattim paññapenti  dutiya vāre hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccā paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena dukkhā pakati jahana ṭṭhena  vipariṇāma dhammā ti veditabbā tesam vipariṇāma aññathābhāvā ti tesam kāmānam vipariṇāma saṅkhātā
translated: For those who have gone to such sensual desires are declared to have attained extinction in this very life.🔽In the second part, they should be understood as impermanent in the sense of non-existence, painful in the sense of oppressing, and subject to change in the sense of displacing their original nature.

original: aññathābhāvā, yampi me ahosi, tampi me natthīti vuttanayena uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.

original: Tattha antonijjhāyanalakkhaṇo soko, tannissitalālappanalakkhaṇo paridevo, kāyappaṭipīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ

analyzed: dukkham manaḥ vighāta lakkhaṇam domanassam visāda lakkhaṇaḥ upāyāsaḥ vivicca iva kāmehi iti ādīnam attho  visuddhi magge vuttaḥ  vitakkitanti abhiniropana vasena pavattaḥ vitakkaḥ vicāritanti anumajjana vasena

original: pavatto vicāro. Etenetanti etena vitakkitena ca vicāritena ca etaṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ🔽oḷārikaṃ sakaṇḍakaṃ viya khāyati.🔽97-98. Pītigatanti pītiyeva. Cetaso uppilāvitattanti cittassa uppilabhāvakaraṇaṃ.🔽Cetaso ābhogoti jhānā vuṭṭhāya tasmiṃ sukhe punappunaṃ cittassa ābhogo manasikāro

translated: “Contemplated” : applied thought occurs as impulsion. “Discerned” : sustained thought occurs as pressing. “By this” : by this applied thought and this sustained thought, this first jhāna appears “gross” like a lump.🔽“Gladness” : rapture itself. “The mind uplifted” : the making of the mind uplifted.🔽“The mind expanded” : the mind’s expansion by repeatedly directing it to the pleasure after emerging from jhāna.

original: Ettāvatā sabbāpi dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyo kathitā honti. Yāsaṃ satteva ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo.

analyzed: sañjātiyam pavattati attho manorame āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamā ati  samosaraṇe sati kāraṇe arañña āyatane paṇṇa kuṭīsu sammanti iti paṇṇatti matte
translated: It occurs in the arising, thus it is the site of arising. “Birds frequent the delightful site”🔽is in the sense of resort. “In every case, in the case of a site” is in the sense of reason. “They are intent on leaf huts in forest sites” is in the sense of designation.

translated: Here this is applicable in the three senses of arising, etc. For in the eye, etc., the five aggregates with contact as fifth arise,

original: ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso”ti iminā nayena phassasīseneva
analyzed: ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam tiṇṇam saṅgati phasso ti iminā nayena phassa sīsena iva

analyzed: phussa phussa paṭisaṃvedenti iti phusitvā phusitvā paṭisaṃvedenti ettha ca kiñcā api

translated: For the sense bases do not touch; it is contact that touches the respective object. But the sense bases are the physical bases for the arising of contact.

original: upanikkhipitvā dassitāni; tasmā sabbe te cha phassāyatanasambhavena phassena rūpādīni🔽ārammaṇāni phusitvā taṃ diṭṭhivedanaṃ paṭisaṃvedayantīti evamettha attho veditabbo.🔽Tesaṃ vedanāpaccayā taṇhātiādīsu vedanāti cha phassāyatanasambhavā vedanā. Sā rūpataṇhādibhedāya
analyzed: upanikkhipitvā dassitāni tasmā sabbe te cha phassa āyatana sambhavena phassena rūpa ādīni  ārammaṇāni phusitvā tam diṭṭhi vedanam paṭisaṃvedayanti iti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  tesam vedanā paccayā taṇhā tiādīsu vedanā ati cha phassa āyatana sambhavā vedanā sā rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedāya
translated: For the bases do not touch; it is contact that touches the respective object. The bases are shown as the means by which contact touches the object. Therefore the meaning here should be understood as follows: “They experience the feeling born of that contact by touching the objects such as visible forms, etc., with the six kinds of contact that arise through the six bases.”

original: taṇhāya upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – “tesaṃ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā”ti.🔽Sā pana catubbidhassa upādānassa upanissayakoṭiyā ceva sahajātakoṭiyā ca paccayo
analyzed: taṇhāya upanissaya koṭiyā paccayaḥ hoti tena vuttam tesam vedanā paccayā taṇhā ti  sā pana catubbidhassa upādānassa upanissaya koṭiyā ca iva sahajāta koṭiyā ca paccayaḥ
translated: As regards the passage beginning “With feeling as condition, craving,” feeling is the feeling that arises through the six bases and the six kinds of contact. It is a condition for craving, which is classified as craving for visible forms, etc., by way of decisive support. Hence it is said: “With feeling as condition, craving.”

original: hoti. Tathā upādānaṃ bhavassa. Bhavo jātiyā upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti.

translated: But that craving is a condition for the four kinds of clinging by way of decisive support and by way of conascence. Likewise clinging is a condition for becoming. Becoming is a condition for birth by way of decisive support.

original: Jātīti panettha savikārā pañcakkhandhā daṭṭhabbā, jāti jarāmaraṇassa ceva sokādīnañca
analyzed: jāti iti pana ittha sa vikārā pañca kkhandhā daṭṭhabbā jāti jarā maraṇassa ca iva soka ādīnam ca
translated: But here birth should be regarded as the five aggregates with their modifications. Birth is a condition for aging-and-death and for sorrow, etc.

original: upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato pana paṭiccasamuppādakathā
analyzed: upanissaya koṭiyā paccayaḥ hoti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana paṭiccasamuppāda kathā

original: visuddhimagge vuttā. Idha panassa payojanamattameva veditabbaṃ. Bhagavā hi vaṭṭakathaṃ
analyzed: visuddhi magge vuttāḥ idha pana assa payojana mattam eva veditabbam bhagavā hi vaṭṭa katham
translated: Here, however, only the purpose should be understood. For when the Blessed One was expounding the round of existence, he said: “Bhikkhus, the prior limit of things subject to ignorance is not discerned.

original: kathento – “purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya, ‘ito pubbe avijjā nāhosi,
analyzed: kathento purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya itas pubbe avijjā na ahosi
translated: If it were said, ‘Before ignorance there was no ignorance, but afterwards it came into being,’🔽still ignorance would have to be discerned as having a specific condition.🔽In the same way, the prior limit of things subject to craving for being is not discerned.

original: atha pacchā samabhavī’ti evañcetaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati, atha ca pana paññāyati “idappaccayā
analyzed: atha pacchā samabhavīti evañca itam bhikkhave vuccati atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā
translated: If it were said, ‘Before craving for being there was no craving for being, but afterwards it came into being,’ still craving for being would have to be discerned as having a specific condition.

original: avijjā”ti evaṃ avijjāsīsena vā, purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati bhavataṇhāya…pe…🔽“idappaccayā bhavataṇhā”ti evaṃ taṇhāsīsena vā, purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati🔽bhavadiṭṭhiyā…pe… “idappaccayā bhavadiṭṭhī”ti evaṃ diṭṭhisīsena vā kathesi”. Idha
analyzed: evam avijjā sīsena vā purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati bhava taṇhāyape  idappaccayā bhava taṇhā ti evam taṇhā sīsena vā purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati  bhava diṭṭhi yāpe idappaccayā bhava diṭṭhī iti evam diṭṭhi sīsena vā kathesi idha
translated: In the same way, the prior limit of things subject to the view of being is not discerned.🔽If it were said, ‘Before the view of being there was no view of being, but afterwards it came into being,’ still the view of being would have to be discerned as having a specific condition.” Here the Blessed One expounded the round of existence by way of the view of being, after first expounding the views that arise through lust for feeling.

original: pana diṭṭhisīsena kathento vedanārāgena uppajjamānā diṭṭhiyo kathetvā vedanāmūlakaṃ
analyzed: pana diṭṭhi sīsena kathentaḥ vedanā rāgena uppajjamānāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ kathetvā vedanā mūlakam
translated: The round of existence is rooted in feeling.

original: paṭiccasamuppādaṃ kathesi. Tena idaṃ dasseti – “evamete diṭṭhigatikā, idaṃ dassanaṃ
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādam kathesi tena idam dasseti evam ete diṭṭhi gatikāḥ idam dassanam
translated: He spoke of the dependent origination. He thereby shows that these theorists, having taken up this view,

original: gahetvā tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu sattasu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu navasu🔽sattāvāsesu ito ettha etto idhāti sandhāvantā saṃsarantā yante yuttagoṇo viya, thambhe
analyzed: gahetvā tīsu bhavesu catūsu yonīsu pañcasu gatīsu sattasu viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu navasu  sattā vāsesu itas ettha ettas idha ati sandhāvantā saṃsarantā yante viya thambhe
translated: wander and transmigrate in the three realms of existence, the four modes of origin, the five destinations, the seven stations of consciousness, and the nine abodes of beings,🔽from here to there and from there to here, like a yoked ox, like a dog tied to a post, or like a ship on the ocean driven by the wind.

original: upanibaddhakukkuro viya, vātena vippannaṭṭhanāvā viya ca vaṭṭadukkhameva anuparivattanti,
analyzed: upanibaddha kukkuraḥ viya vātena vippanna ṭṭha nāvā viya ca vaṭṭa dukkham eva anuparivattanti
translated: They revolve in the suffering of the round,

original: vaṭṭadukkhato sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ na sakkontī”ti.
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhato sīsam ukkhipitum na sakkonti iti

original: Vivaṭṭakathādivaṇṇanā🔽145. Evaṃ diṭṭhigatikādhiṭṭhānaṃ vaṭṭaṃ kathetvā idāni yuttayogabhikkhuadhiṭṭhānaṃ🔽katvā vivaṭṭaṃ dassento – “yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhū”tiādimāha. Tattha yatoti
analyzed: vivaṭṭa kathā ādi vaṇṇanā  evam diṭṭhigatika adhiṭṭhānam vaṭṭam kathetvā idāni yutta yoga bhikkhu adhiṭṭhānam  katvā vivaṭṭam dassentaḥ yatas kho bhikkhave bhikkhu iti ādim āha tattha yatas ti
translated: The explanation of the section on “reversal”

analyzed: yadā channam yehi chahi phassa āyatanehi phusitvā paṭisaṃvedayamānānam

analyzed: diṭṭhigatikānam vaṭṭam vattati tesam yeva channam phassa āyatanānam
translated: The round of rebirths revolves for those who have views, and it does so by means of the six bases of contact.

analyzed: avijjā samudayā cakkhu samudayo ti ādinā vedanā kammaṭṭhāne vutta nayena phassa āyatanānaṃ
translated: As regards the words “With the arising of ignorance, the arising of the eye” and so on, the arising, etc., of the bases of contact should be understood in the way stated in the meditation subject of feeling .

translated: Free from the five defilements of passion, hatred, delusion, malice, and jealousy,
