analyzed: virahitā ati vuttam hoti tasmā ramaṇīyā atiādīni pañca thomana vacanāni sā hi mahājanassa  manam ramayati iti ramaṇīyā vutta dosa vimuttāya canda ppabhāya surūpā ati
translated: is what is meant. Therefore the five terms of praise beginning with delightful are said. For it delights the minds of the people,🔽therefore it is delightful. Because it is lit up by the moon’s radiance free from the aforementioned faults, it is very beautiful,

original: abhirūpā. Dassituṃ yuttāti dassanīyā. Cittaṃ pasādetīti pāsādikā. Divasamāsādīnaṃ
analyzed: abhirūpā dassitum yuttā ati dassanīyā cittam pasādeti iti pāsādikā divasa māsa ādīnam
translated: therefore it is beautiful. It is fit to be seen, therefore it is lovely to behold. It pleases the mind, therefore it is graceful. It is fit to be the characteristic of a day, a month, etc.,

original: lakkhaṇaṃ bhavituṃ yuttāti lakkhaññā.
analyzed: lakkhaṇam bhavitum yuttā ati lakkhaññā
translated: therefore it is distinguished.

original: Kaṃ nu khvajjāti kaṃ nu kho ajja. Samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vāti samitapāpatāya samaṇaṃ.🔽Bāhitapāpatāya brāhmaṇaṃ. Yaṃ no payirupāsatoti vacanabyattayo esa, yaṃ amhākaṃ pañhapucchanavasena
analyzed: kam nu khvajja ati kam nu kho ajja samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā ati samita pāpa tāya samaṇam  bāhita pāpa tāya brāhmaṇam yam no payiḥ upāsataḥ iti vacana byattayaḥ yam amhākam pañha pucchana vasena
translated: Who today? Who today, either a recluse or a brahmin? A recluse is one who has quieted evil,

original: payirupāsantānaṃ madhuraṃ dhammaṃ sutvā cittaṃ pasīdeyyāti attho. Iti rājā iminā
analyzed: payis upāsantānam madhuram dhammam sutvā cittam pasīdeyya ati attho iti rājā iminā
translated: a brahmin is one who has expelled evil. To whom we should go to wait upon is the expression of his willingness to question. The meaning is: to whom we should go to wait upon, having asked a question, whose mind would be pleased on hearing the sweet Dhamma. Thus the king,

original: sabbenapi vacanena obhāsanimittakammaṃ akāsi. Kassa akāsīti? Jīvakassa. Kimatthaṃ?
analyzed: sabbena api vacanena obhāsa nimitta kammam akāsi kassa akāsi iti jīvakassa kimattham
translated: He did it by means of a message. To whom? To Jīvaka. For what purpose?

original: Bhagavato dassanatthaṃ. Kiṃ bhagavantaṃ sayaṃ dassanāya upagantuṃ na sakkotīti? Āma,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ dassana attham kim bhagavantam sayam dassanāya upagantum na sakkoti iti āma
translated: For the purpose of seeing the Blessed One. Why could he not go himself to see the Blessed One?

original: na sakkoti. Kasmā? Mahāparādhatāya.
analyzed: na sakkoti kasmai mahā aparādha tāya
translated: He could not. Why not? Because of his great guilt.

original: Tena hi bhagavato upaṭṭhāko ariyasāvako attano pitā mārito, devadatto ca tameva nissāya🔽bhagavato bahuṃ anatthamakāsi, iti mahāparādho esa, tāya mahāparādhatāya sayaṃ gantuṃ🔽na sakkoti. Jīvako pana bhagavato upaṭṭhāko, tassa piṭṭhichāyāya bhagavantaṃ passissāmīti
analyzed: tena hi bhagavato upaṭṭhākaḥ ariya sāvako attanaḥ pitā māritaḥ devadatto ca tam eva nissāya  bhagavataḥ bahum anattham akāsi iti mahā aparādhaḥ esa tāya mahā aparādha tāya sayam gantum  na sakkoti jīvakaḥ pana bhagavato upaṭṭhāko tassa piṭṭhi chāyāya bhagavantam passissāmi iti
translated: Then, since his own father, a noble disciple and attendant of the Blessed One, was killed by him, and since Devadatta,

original: obhāsanimittakammaṃ akāsi. Kiṃ jīvako pana – “mayhaṃ idaṃ obhāsanimittakamma”nti
analyzed: obhāsa nimitta kammaṃ akāsi kim jīvakaḥ pana mayham idam obhāsa nimitta kammanti
translated: depending on him, did much harm to the Blessed One, he was a great offender. Because of his great guilt he could not go himself to see the Blessed One. But Jīvaka was the Blessed One’s attendant, and he thought: “I will see the Blessed One in the shadow of Jīvaka’s feet.”🔽So he did it by means of a message. Did Jīvaka know that this was a message?

original: jānātīti? Āma jānāti. Atha kasmā tuṇhī ahosīti? Vikkhepapacchedanatthaṃ.
analyzed: jānāti iti āma jānāti atha kasmā tuṇhī ahosi iti vikkhepa pacchedana attham
translated: Yes, he knew. Then why did he remain silent? In order to cut off his prevarication.

original: Tassañhi parisati channaṃ satthārānaṃ upaṭṭhākā bahū sannipatitā, te asikkhitānaṃ🔽payirupāsanena sayampi asikkhitāva. Te mayi bhagavato guṇakathaṃ āraddhe antarantarā🔽uṭṭhāyuṭṭhāya attano satthārānaṃ guṇaṃ kathessanti, evaṃ me satthu guṇakathā pariyosānaṃ🔽na gamissati. Rājā pana imesaṃ kulūpake upasaṅkamitvā gahitāsāratāya tesaṃ guṇakathāya
analyzed: tassa hi parisati channam satthārānam upaṭṭhākāḥ bahū sannipatitā te a sikkhitānam  payis upāsanena te mayi bhagavataḥ guṇa katham āraddhe antar antarā  uṭṭhāya uṭṭhāya attanaḥ satthārānam guṇam kathessanti evam me satthu guṇa kathā pariyosānam  na gamissati rājā pana imesam kulūpake upasaṅkamitvā gahita asāra tāya tesam guṇa kathāya
translated: For in his retinue were many attendants of the six teachers, and they were themselves unlearned,🔽having paid homage to those who were unlearned. If I were to begin to tell the king the virtues of the Exalted One, they would interrupt me again and again,

original: anattamano hutvā maṃ paṭipucchissati, athāhaṃ nibbikkhepaṃ satthu guṇaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: an atta manaḥ hutvā mam paṭipucchissati atha aham nibbikkhepam satthu guṇam kathetvā
translated: saying, “Our teachers are superior to your teacher in this and that respect.” In this way my discourse on the virtues of the Exalted One would never come to an end. But the king, having approached these royal favorites and having heard their discourse on the virtues of their teachers, would become dissatisfied and would question me. Then I would tell him the virtues of the Exalted One, free from all imperfections,

original: rājānaṃ satthu santikaṃ gahetvā gamissāmīti jānantova vikkhepapacchedanatthaṃ tuṇhī ahosīti.🔽Tepi amaccā evaṃ cintesuṃ – “ajja rājā pañcahi padehi rattiṃ thometi, addhā kiñci
analyzed: rājānam satthu santikam gahetvā gamissāmi iti jānantaḥ eva vikkhepa pacchedana attham tuṇhī ahosi iti  te pi amaccāḥ evam cintesuṃ ajja rājā pañcahi padehi rattim thoma iti addhā kiñci
translated: and I would take the king to the Exalted One and go with him. Knowing this, he remained silent in order to cut off all interruptions.

original: samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchitvā dhammaṃ sotukāmo, yassa cesa
analyzed: samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchitvā dhammam sotu kāmo yassa ca īsa
translated: The ministers thought to themselves, “Today the king is praising the night in five ways. Surely he has approached a recluse or a brahman, has asked a question, and is desirous of hearing the Dhamma. Whoever he has approached,

original: dhammaṃ sutvā pasīdissati, tassa ca mahantaṃ sakkāraṃ karissati, yassa pana kulūpako
analyzed: dhammam sutvā pasīdissati tassa ca mahantam sakkāram karissati yassa pana kulūpako
translated: He will be pleased with the Dhamma he hears, and he will show you great honour. But if a monk is a royal chaplain,

original: samaṇo rājakulūpako hoti, bhaddaṃ tassā”ti.
analyzed: samaṇaḥ rāja kulūpakaḥ hoti bhaddam tassa ati
translated: it will be good for him.”

original: 151-152. Te evaṃ cintetvā – “ahaṃ attano kulūpakasamaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ vatvā rājānaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: te evam cintetvā aham attanaḥ kulūpaka samaṇassa vaṇṇam vatvā rājānam gahetvā
translated: They thought, “I will take the king with me by praising my own chaplain.

original: gamissāmi, ahaṃ gamissāmī”ti attano attano kulūpakānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ kathetuṃ āraddhā. Tenāha
analyzed: gamissāmi aham gamissāmi iti attanaḥ attanaḥ kulūpakānam vaṇṇam kathetum āraddhā tena āha
translated: I will go.” So they began to praise their own chaplains. Therefore it is said:

original: – “evaṃ vutte aññataro rājāmacco”tiādi. Tattha pūraṇoti tassa satthupaṭiññassa nāmaṃ.
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ rājā amacco tiādi tattha pūraṇo ti tassa satthupaṭiññassa nāmaṃ
translated: “When this was said, a certain royal minister” and so on. Herein, Pūraṇa is the name of that teacher.

original: Kassapoti gottaṃ. So kira aññatarassa kulassa ekūnadāsasataṃ pūrayamāno jāto, tenassa
analyzed: kassapaḥ ti gottam so kira aññatarassa kulassa ekūna dāsa satam pūrayamānaḥ jātaḥ tena assa
translated: Kassapa is his clan. It seems that he was born filling up the number of a certain family’s nineteen slaves, and so they gave him the name Pūraṇa .

original: pūraṇoti nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Maṅgaladāsattā cassa “dukkaṭa”nti vattā natthi, akataṃ vā
analyzed: pūraṇaḥ ti nāmam maṅgala dāsa ttā ca ssa dukkaṭam natthi akatam vā
translated: Because he was a lucky slave, there was no one to say “Bad job” to him, and he did not do anything

original: na katanti. So “kimahaṃ ettha vasāmī”ti palāyi. Athassa corā vatthāni acchindiṃsu,
analyzed: na saḥ kim aham ettha vasāmi iti palāyi athassa corāḥ vatthāni acchindiṃsu
translated: bad. He ran away, thinking, “What am I doing here?” Then thieves stripped him of his clothes,

original: so paṇṇena vā tiṇena vā paṭicchādetumpi ajānanto jātarūpeneva ekaṃ gāmaṃ pāvisi.
analyzed: saḥ paṇṇena vā tiṇena vā a jānantaḥ jātarūpena iva ekam gāmam pāvisi
translated: He did not know how to cover himself with leaves or grass. So he went to a village in the same state of nudity.

original: Manussā taṃ disvā “ayaṃ samaṇo arahā appiccho, natthi iminā sadiso”ti pūvabhattādīni
analyzed: manussā tam disvā ayam samaṇaḥ arahā appicchaḥ natthi iminā sadisaḥ iti pūvabhatta ādīni
translated: People saw him and said, “This recluse is an arahat, a man of few wishes. There is no one like him.” And they brought him rice-porridge, boiled rice, etc.,

original: gahetvā upasaṅkamanti. So – “mayhaṃ sāṭakaṃ anivatthabhāvena idaṃ uppanna”nti tato
analyzed: gahetvā upasaṅkamanti saḥ mayham sāṭakam anivattha bhāvena idam tatas
translated: and said, “We give this to you because you have no robe to wear.”

original: paṭṭhāya sāṭakaṃ labhitvāpi na nivāsesi, tadeva pabbajjaṃ aggahesi, tassa santike
analyzed: paṭṭhāya sāṭakam labhitvā api na nivāsesi tat eva pabbajjam aggahesi tassa santike
translated: From that time on, even when he received robes, he would not wear them, but continued to go about in the same state of nudity.

original: aññepi aññepīti pañcasatamanussā pabbajiṃsu. Taṃ sandhāyāha – “pūraṇo kassapo”ti.
analyzed: aññe api aññe api iti pañca sata manussā pabbajiṃsu tam sandhāya āha pūraṇaḥ kassapo ti
translated: Five hundred other people took up the same practice in his company. It was of this that the Exalted One thought when he said, “Pūraṇa Kassapa.”

original: Pabbajitasamūhasaṅkhāto saṅgho assa atthīti saṅghī. Sveva gaṇo assa atthīti gaṇī.
analyzed: pabbajita samūha saṅkhātaḥ saṅghaḥ assa atthi iti saṅghī su eva gaṇaḥ assa atthi iti gaṇī
translated: He is called “one who has a following” because he has a following of those who have gone forth. He is called “one who has a group” because he has a group of those who have gone forth.

original: Ācārasikkhāpanavasena tassa gaṇassa ācariyoti gaṇācariyo. Ñātoti paññāto pākaṭo.
analyzed: ācāra sikkhāpana vasena tassa gaṇassa ācariyaḥ ti gaṇācariyaḥ ñātaḥ ati paññātaḥ pākaṭaḥ
translated: He is called “teacher of a group” because he is the teacher of that group of those who have gone forth. He is called “renowned” because he is well known and famous.

original: “Appiccho santuṭṭho. Appicchatāya vatthampi na nivāsetī”ti evaṃ samuggato yaso assa
analyzed: appicchaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ appiccha tāya vattham pi na nivāseti iti evam samuggataḥ yasaḥ assa
translated: “He is of few wishes and content. Because of his fewness of wishes he does not even wear a robe.”

original: atthīti yasassī. Titthakaroti laddhikaro. Sādhusammatoti ayaṃ sādhu, sundaro, sappurisoti🔽evaṃ sammato. Bahujanassāti assutavato andhabālaputhujjanassa. Pabbajitato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: atthi iti yasassī titthakaro ti laddhikaro sādhu sammato ti ayam sādhu sundaraḥ sappuriso ti  evam sammataḥ bahu janassa ati assutavataḥ andha bāla puthujjanassa pabbajitataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “He is famous” means that he is well known. “A founder of a sect” means that he is the founder of a sect. “Honored by a multitude” means that he is honored by a multitude of people who are unlearned, blind, and foolish. “Since his going forth” means since his going forth from the home life.

original: atikkantā bahū rattiyo jānātīti rattaññū. Ciraṃ pabbajitassa assāti cirapabbajito,
analyzed: atikkantāḥ bahū rattiyaḥ jānāti iti rattaññū ciram pabbajitassa assa ati cira pabbajitaḥ
translated: “He has passed many a night” means that he has passed many nights. “He is of long standing” means that he has been a monk for a long time.

original: acirapabbajitassa hi kathā okappanīyā na hoti, tenāha “cirapabbajito”ti. Addhagatoti
analyzed: acira pabbajitassa hi kathā okappanīyā na hoti tena āha cira pabbajitaḥ ti addha gataḥ ti
translated: For the talk of one who has gone forth recently is not acceptable. Therefore it is said: “He is of long standing.” “He is aged” means that he has reached old age.

original: addhānaṃ gato, dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe atītoti adhippāyo. Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ
analyzed: addhānam gataḥ dve tayo rāja parivaṭṭe atītaḥ iti adhippāyaḥ vayaḥ anuppatto ti pacchima vayam
translated: The meaning is that he has passed two or three royal generations. “He is of ripe old age” means that he has reached the last stage of life.

original: anuppatto. Idaṃ ubhayampi – “daharassa kathā okappanīyā na hotī”ti etaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Tuṇhī ahosīti suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ madhurarasaṃ ambapakkaṃ khāditukāmo puriso āharitvā hatthe
analyzed: idam ubhayam pi daharassa kathā okappanīyā na hoti iti etam sandhāya vuttam  tuṇhī ahosi iti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam madhura rasam amba pakkam khāditu kāmaḥ purisaḥ āharitvā hatthe
translated: Both of these are said with reference to the fact that the talk of one who is young is not acceptable.

original: ṭhapitaṃ kājarapakkaṃ disvā viya jhānābhiññādiguṇayuttaṃ tilakkhaṇabbhāhataṃ madhuraṃ
analyzed: ṭhapitam kājara pakkam disvā viya jhāna abhiññā ādi guṇa yuttam madhuram
translated: “He was silent” means that he was like a person who, desiring to eat a ripe mango, sweet and golden in color, would see a ripe jak-fruit placed in his hand and ignore it.

original: dhammakathaṃ sotukāmo pubbe pūraṇassa dassanenāpi anattamano idāni guṇakathāya suṭṭhutaraṃ🔽anattamano hutvā tuṇhī ahosi. Anattamano samānopi pana “sacāhaṃ etaṃ tajjetvā gīvāyaṃ🔽gahetvā nīharāpessāmi, ‘yo yo kathesi, taṃ taṃ rājā evaṃ karotī’ti bhīto aññopi koci
analyzed: dhamma katham sotu kāmo pubbe pūraṇassa dassanena api anattamanaḥ idāni guṇa kathāya suṭṭhutaram  anattamanaḥ hutvā tuṇhī ahosi anattamano samānaḥ api pana sacā aham etam tat jetvā  gahetvā yaḥ yaḥ kathesi tam tam rājā evam karoti iti bhītaḥ aññaḥ api koci
translated: and he was not at all pleased to hear the praise of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha.🔽He was so displeased that he thought, “If I drive him out by force,🔽then no one else will speak out of fear that the king will do the same to them.”

original: kiñci na kathessatī”ti amanāpampi taṃ kathaṃ adhivāsetvā tuṇhī eva ahosi. Athañño
analyzed: kiñci na kathessati iti amanāpam pi tam katham adhivāsetvā tuṇhī eva ahosi athañño
translated: So he kept silent, though displeased. Then another brahmin thought,

original: – “ahaṃ attano kulūpakassa vaṇṇaṃ kathessāmī”ti cintetvā vattuṃ ārabhi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: aham attanaḥ kulūpakassa vaṇṇam kathessāmi iti cintetvā vattum ārabhi tena vuttam
translated: “I’ll praise my own teacher.” And he started to speak.

original: – aññataropi khotiādi. Taṃ sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: aññataro pi kho tiādi tat sabbam vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The rest is as in the account of the first brahmin.

original: Ettha pana makkhalīti tassa nāmaṃ. Gosālāya jātattā gosāloti dutiyaṃ nāmaṃ. Taṃ kira
analyzed: ettha pana makkhalī iti tassa nāmam gosālāya jāta ttā gosālaḥ iti dutiyam nāmam tam kira
translated: Here Makkhali Gosāla was his name. Because he was born in a cow-shed, he was also called Gosāla.

original: sakaddamāya bhūmiyā telaghaṭaṃ gahetvā gacchantaṃ – “tāta, mā khalī”ti sāmiko āha.
analyzed: sa kaddamāya bhūmiyā tela ghaṭam gahetvā gacchantam tāta mā khalī iti sāmikaḥ āha
translated: It seems that while he was carrying a pot of oil on a slippery surface, his master said to him, “Don’t slip, my good man.”

original: So pamādena khalitvā patitvā sāmikassa bhayena palāyituṃ āraddho. Sāmiko upadhāvitvā
analyzed: saḥ pamādena khalitvā patitvā sāmikassa bhayena palāyitum āraddhaḥ sāmikaḥ upadhāvitvā
translated: He slipped and fell through carelessness. And he started to run away out of fear of his master. His master ran after him

original: dussakaṇṇe aggahesi. So sāṭakaṃ chaḍḍetvā acelako hutvā palāyi. Sesaṃ pūraṇasadisameva.🔽153. Ajitoti tassa nāmaṃ. Kesakambalaṃ dhāretīti kesakambalo. Iti nāmadvayaṃ saṃsanditvā
analyzed: dussa kaṇṇe aggahesi saḥ sāṭakam chaḍḍetvā acelakaḥ hutvā palāyi sesam pūraṇa sadisam eva  ajitaḥ ti tassa nāmam kesa kambalam dhāreti iti kesa kambalaḥ iti nāma dvayam saṃsanditvā
translated: and seized him by the hem of his cloak. He dropped the cloak and ran away naked. The rest is the same as with Pūraṇa.🔽Ajita is his name. He wears a cloak of hair, thus he is Kesakambala. Thus the two names are combined

original: ajito kesakambaloti vuccati. Tattha kesakambalo nāma manussakesehi katakambalo. Tato
analyzed: ajitaḥ kesakambalo ti vuccati tattha kesakambalaḥ nāma manussa kesehi kata kambalo tatas
translated: and he is called Ajita Kesakambala. Herein, a cloak of hair is a cloak made of human hair. There is no cloth more prickly than that,

original: paṭikiṭṭhataraṃ vatthaṃ nāma natthi. Yathāha – “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici🔽tantāvutānaṃ vatthānaṃ, kesakambalo tesaṃ paṭikiṭṭho akkhāyati. Kesakambalo, bhikkhave,
analyzed: paṭikiṭṭhataram vattham nāma natthi yathā āha seyyathā api bhikkhave yāni kānici  tantāvutānam vatthānam kesa kambalo tesam paṭikiṭṭhaḥ akkhāyati kesa kambalaḥ bhikkhave
translated: as is said: “Bhikkhus, a cloak of hair is considered the prickliest of all woven things. A cloak of hair, bhikkhus,

original: sīte sīto, uṇhe uṇho, dubbaṇṇo duggandho dukkhasamphasso”ti.
analyzed: sīte sītaḥ uṇhe uṇhaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ duggandho dukkha samphasso ti
translated: is cold when it is cold, hot when it is hot, ugly, ill-smelling, and unpleasant to touch” .🔽Pakudha is his name. Kaccāyana is his clan. Thus the name and clan are combined

original: 154. Pakudhoti tassa nāmaṃ. Kaccāyanoti gottaṃ. Iti nāmagottaṃ saṃsanditvā pakudho
analyzed: pakudho ti tassa nāmam kaccāyano ti gottam iti nāma gottam saṃsanditvā pakudho
translated: and he is called Pakudha Kaccāyana.

original: kaccāyanoti vuccati. Sītudakapaṭikkhittako esa, vaccaṃ katvāpi udakakiccaṃ na karoti,
analyzed: kaccāyanaḥ ti vuccati sīta udaka paṭikkhittakaḥ esa vaccam katvā api udaka kiccam na karoti
translated: He is called Kaccāyana. He is one who has rejected cold water. He does not perform the water-rite even after defecating.

original: uṇhodakaṃ vā kañjiyaṃ vā labhitvā karoti, nadiṃ vā maggodakaṃ vā atikkamma – “sīlaṃ
analyzed: uṇha udakam vā kañjiyam vā labhitvā karoti nadim vā magga udakam vā atikkamma sīlam
translated: If he gets hot water or gruel, he performs it. If he passes a river or a well on the road, thinking, “My virtue is broken,”

original: me bhinna”nti vālikathūpaṃ katvā sīlaṃ adhiṭṭhāya gacchati. Evarūpo nissirīkaladdhiko esa.
analyzed: me bhinnanti vālika thūpam katvā sīlam adhiṭṭhāya gacchati evarūpaḥ nissirīkaladdhikaḥ esa
translated: he makes a sand-mound and goes on, having resolved on virtue. Such a person is one who is without the shame and compunction that are a sense of shame and compunction.

original: 155. Sañcayoti tassa nāmaṃ. Belaṭṭhassa puttoti belaṭṭhaputto.
analyzed: sañcayaḥ ti tassa nāmam belaṭṭhassa putto ti belaṭṭha putto
translated: Sañcaya is his name. He is the son of Belaṭṭha, thus he is Belaṭṭhaputta.

original: 156. Amhākaṃ gaṇṭhanakileso palibandhanakileso natthi, kilesagaṇṭharahitā mayanti evaṃvāditāya laddhanāmavasena nigaṇṭho. Nāṭassa putto nāṭaputto.
analyzed: amhākam gaṇṭhana kileso palibandhana kileso natthi kilesa gaṇṭha rahitāḥ mayanti evaṃvāditāya laddha nāma vasena nigaṇṭhaḥ nāṭassa putto nāṭa putto
translated: We have no knot of defilement, no bond of defilement. We are free from the knot of defilement. Thus he is called Nigaṇṭha. He is the son of Nāṭa, thus he is Nāṭaputta.

original: Komārabhaccajīvakakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Komārabhacca and Jīvaka

original: 157. Atha kho rājāti rājā kira tesaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā cintesi – “ahaṃ yassa yassa vacanaṃ
analyzed: atha kho rājā ati rājā kira tesam vacanam sutvā cintesi aham yassa yassa vacanam
translated: Then the king: the king, it seems, after hearing their words, thought: “I do not want to hear the words of anyone.

original: na sotukāmo, so so eva kathesi. Yassa panamhi vacanaṃ sotukāmo, esa nāgavasaṃ pivitvā
analyzed: na sotu kāmo so saḥ eva kathesi yassa panamhi vacanam sotu kāmo esa nāga vasam pivitvā
translated: But the one whose words I want to hear has drunk nāgavasa and is asleep.

original: ṭhito supaṇṇo viya tuṇhībhūto, anattho vata me”ti. Athassa etadahosi – “jīvako upasantassa
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ supaṇṇaḥ viya tuṇhībhūto anatthaḥ vata me iti atha assa etat ahosi jīvakaḥ upasantassa
translated: like a supaṇṇa bird, silent,🔽“Alas, I have lost my fortune!” Then this occurred to him: “Jīvaka is the physician of the King, the King’s court, and of the royal family,

original: buddhassa bhagavato upaṭṭhāko, sayampi upasanto, tasmā vattasampanno bhikkhu viya🔽tuṇhībhūtova nisinno, na esa mayi akathente kathessati, hatthimhi kho pana maddante🔽hatthisseva pādo gahetabbo”ti tena saddhiṃ sayaṃ mantetumāraddho. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavato upaṭṭhāko sayam pi upasanto tasmā vatta sampanno bhikkhu viya  tuṇhībhūtaḥ uva nisinnaḥ na esa mayi a kathente kathessati hatthimhi kho pana maddante  hatthissa iva pādaḥ gahetabbaḥ iti tena saddhim sayam mantetum āraddhaḥ tena vuttam atha
translated: He sat down in silence like a supanna, thinking, “I have lost my case.” Then he thought, “Jīvaka is the attendant of the Buddha, the Blessed One, who is peaceful and calm. He himself is peaceful and calm, and so he sits in silence like a monk who has fulfilled his duties. He will not speak unless I speak. When an elephant is to be killed,

original: kho rājā”ti. Tattha kiṃ tuṇhīti kena kāraṇena tuṇhī. Imesaṃ amaccānaṃ attano attano🔽kulūpakasamaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ kathentānaṃ mukhaṃ nappahoti. Kiṃ yathā etesaṃ, evaṃ tava🔽kulūpakasamaṇo natthi, kiṃ tvaṃ daliddo, na te mama pitarā issariyaṃ dinnaṃ, udāhu
analyzed: kho rājā ati tattha kim tuṇhī iti kena kāraṇena tuṇhī imesam amaccānam attanaḥ attanaḥ  kulūpaka samaṇassa vaṇṇam kathentānam mukham nappahoti kim yathā etesam evam tava  kulūpaka samaṇaḥ natthi kim tvam daliddaḥ na te mama pitarā issariyam dinnam
translated: only the elephant’s foot is to be taken.” So he began to discuss the matter with Jīvaka himself. Hence it is said: “Then the king said to Jīvaka Komārabhacca: ‘Why are you silent, Jīvaka? Why don’t you speak to me? Why don’t you open your mouth to me? Why don’t you show your face to me? Why are you silent, Jīvaka?’”

original: assaddhoti pucchati.
analyzed: assaddhā iti pucchati
translated: Here, why are you silent? For what reason are you silent? These ministers are praising the ascetics who are their own supporters. Your face does not open to them. What? Just as they have, so you have no ascetic who is your supporter. What? Are you poor? Was sovereignty not given to you by my father? Or are you faithless? He asks this.

original: Tato jīvakassa etadahosi – “ayaṃ rājā maṃ kulūpakasamaṇassa guṇaṃ kathāpeti, na dāni
analyzed: tatas jīvakassa etat ahosi ayam rājā mam kulūpaka samaṇassa guṇam kathāpeti na dāni
translated: Then Jīvaka thought, “This king is making me praise the qualities of an ascetic who is a supporter. Now is not the time to speak the truth. I will speak a falsehood.”

original: me tuṇhībhāvassa kālo, yathā kho panime rājānaṃ vanditvā nisinnāva attano kulūpakasamaṇānaṃ
analyzed: me tuṇhībhāvassa kālaḥ yathā kho panime rājānam vanditvā nisinnāva attanaḥ kulūpaka samaṇānam
translated: “But the time has come for me to be silent. As these kings, after paying homage to the King, sat down and extolled the virtues of their own family-priest ascetics,

original: guṇaṃ kathayiṃsu, na mayhaṃ evaṃ satthuguṇe kathetuṃ yutta”nti uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavato
analyzed: guṇam kathayiṃsu na mayham evam satthu guṇe kathetum yuttam ti uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavataḥ
translated: so it is not proper for me to extol the virtues of my Teacher.” So he rose from his seat,

original: vihārābhimukho pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā dasanakhasamodhānasamujjalaṃ añjaliṃ sirasi
analyzed: vihāra abhimukhaḥ pañca patiṭṭhitena vanditvā dasa nakha samodhāna samujjalam añjalim sirasi
translated: and facing the Blessed One’s dwelling, he paid homage with the five-part prostration. Then he raised his joined palms to his head,

original: paggahetvā – “mahārāja, mā maṃ evaṃ cintayittha, ‘ayaṃ yaṃ vā taṃ vā samaṇaṃ upasaṅkamatī’ti,
analyzed: paggahetvā mahā rāja mā mama evam cintayittha ayam yam vā tam vā samaṇam upasaṅkamati iti
translated: which was radiant like a collection of ten fingers, and said: “Great king, do not think that I am going to some other ascetic or brahmin.

original: mama satthuno hi mātukucchiokkamane, mātukucchito nikkhamane, mahābhinikkhamane,
analyzed: mama satthunaḥ hi mātukucchi ukkamane mātukucchitaḥ nikkhamane mahā abhinikkhamane
translated: For when my Teacher emerged from his mother’s womb, when he emerged from his mother’s womb, when he renounced the great household,

original: sambodhiyaṃ, dhammacakkappavattane ca, dasasahassilokadhātu kampittha, evaṃ yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ
analyzed: sambodhiyam dhamma cakka ppavattane ca dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampittha evam yamaka pāṭihāriyam
translated: when he attained enlightenment, when he set in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma, the ten-thousand world systems trembled. So too did he perform the Twin Miracle,

original: akāsi, evaṃ devorohaṇaṃ, ahaṃ satthuno guṇe kathayissāmi, ekaggacitto suṇa, mahārājā”ti
analyzed: akāsi evam deva ārohaṇam aham satthunaḥ guṇe kathayissāmi ekagga cittaḥ suṇa mahā rāja iti
translated: so too did he descend from the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, so too did he enter the womb of his mother. I will extol the virtues of my Teacher. Listen, great king, with concentrated mind.”

original: vatvā – “ayaṃ deva, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”tiādimāha. Tattha taṃ kho pana
analyzed: vatvā ayam deva bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ iti ādim āha tattha tam kho pana
translated: and he said: “Sire, this Blessed One is an Arahant, a Perfectly Enlightened One.” Herein, that Blessed One: the word kho is a conjunction; the word pana is to be regarded as a particle; the word tam is for the purpose of showing that what follows refers to the Blessed One, and it has the same meaning as the word tassa .

original: bhagavantanti itthambhūtākhyānatthe upayogavacanaṃ, tassa kho pana bhagavatoti attho.
analyzed: bhagavantan ti itthambhūta ākhyāna tthe upayoga vacanam tassa kho pana bhagavato ti atthaḥ
translated: So: this is a word for inclusion; the Blessed One is so in such a way as will be stated.🔽Virtuous: possessing good qualities, best, is what is meant.🔽His: the Blessed One’s.

original: Kalyāṇoti kalyāṇaguṇasamannāgato, seṭṭhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Kittisaddoti kittiyeva. Thutighoso
analyzed: kalyāṇo ti kalyāṇa guṇa samannāgato seṭṭho ti vuttam hoti kitti saddo ti kittiyā iva thuti ghoso
translated: Fame: it is fame itself.🔽Or it is the sound of praise.

original: vā. Abbhuggatoti sadevakaṃ lokaṃ ajjhottharitvā uggato. Kinti? “Itipi so bhagavā
analyzed: vā abbhuggataḥ iti sa devakam lokam ajjhottharitvā uggataḥ saḥ bhagavā
translated: Has spread: it has arisen after pervading the world with its devas.

original: arahaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… bhagavā”ti.
analyzed: araham sammāsambuddha upe bhagavā iti
translated: What? “Thus indeed that Blessed One is an Arahant, a Perfectly Enlightened One … a Blessed One.”

original: Tatrāyaṃ padasambandho – so bhagavā itipi arahaṃ itipi sammāsambuddho…pe… itipi bhagavāti.
analyzed: tatra ayam pada sambandhaḥ saḥ bhagavā itipi araham itipi itipi bhagavā iti
translated: Herein, this is the word-construction: “That Blessed One is thus an Arahant, thus a Perfectly Enlightened One … thus a Blessed One.”🔽For this reason and for that: what is meant is that it is for these reasons and for those.

original: Iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha ārakattā arīnaṃ, arānañca hatattā,
analyzed: iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇena ati vuttam hoti tattha āraka ttā arīnam arānam ca hata ttā
translated: Herein, firstly, he is an Arahant in the sense of being remote , in the sense of being a destroyer ,

original: paccayādīnaṃ arahattā, pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvāti, imehi tāva kāraṇehi so bhagavā arahanti
analyzed: paccaya ādīnam arahattā pāpa karaṇe raha abhāvā ti imehi tāva kāraṇehi so bhagavā arahanti
translated: and in the sense of being worthy of requisites , and in the sense of being a shelter for evil .

original: veditabbotiādinā nayena mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā sabbāneva cetāni padāni visuddhimagge
analyzed: veditabbā uti ādinā nayena mātikam nikkhipitvā sabbān eva ca itāni padāni visuddhi magge
translated: Having thus set forth the mātikā with the words “should be known,” etc., all these terms are explained in the Visuddhimagga.

original: buddhānussatiniddese vitthāritānīti tato nesaṃ vitthāro gahetabbo.🔽Jīvako pana ekamekassa padassa atthaṃ niṭṭhāpetvā – “evaṃ, mahārāja, arahaṃ mayhaṃ
analyzed: buddhānussati niddese vitthāritāni iti tatas nesam vitthāraḥ gahetabbaḥ  jīvakaḥ pana ekamekassa padassa attham niṭṭhāpetvā evam mahā rāja araham mayham
translated: The whole of this passage is given in the Visuddhimagga in the Description of the Recollection of the Buddha .🔽But Jīvaka, after finishing the meaning of each phrase, said: “Thus, sire, the Blessed One is my teacher, thus the Fully Enlightened One … thus the Blessed One.”

original: satthā, evaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… evaṃ bhagavā”ti vatvā – “taṃ, devo, bhagavantaṃ payirupāsatu,
analyzed: satthā evam sammāsambuddha upe evam bhagavā iti vatvā tam devaḥ bhagavantam payis upāsatu
translated: And he said: “Let your majesty wait upon the Blessed One, sire,

original: appeva nāma devassa taṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti āha. Ettha ca🔽taṃ devo payirupāsatūti vadanto “mahārāja, tumhādisānañhi satenapi sahassenapi satasahassenapi
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa tam bhagavantam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya iti āha ettha ca  tam devaḥ payiḥ upāsatu iti vadantaḥ mahā rāja satena api sahassena api sata sahassena api
translated: perhaps your majesty’s mind may be satisfied by waiting upon the Blessed One.”🔽And here,

original: puṭṭhassa mayhaṃ satthuno sabbesaṃ cittaṃ gahetvā kathetuṃ thāmo ca balañca atthi,
analyzed: puṭṭhassa mayham satthuno sabbesam cittam gahetvā kathetum thāmaḥ ca balam ca atthi
translated: saying “Let your majesty wait upon him,” he meant: “Great king, you have a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand questions to ask, and I have the power and strength to answer them all and satisfy your mind,

original: vissattho upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi mahārājā”ti āha.
analyzed: vissatthaḥ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi mahā rāja iti āha
translated: so go up to him fearlessly and ask your questions, great king.”

original: Raññopi bhagavato guṇakathaṃ suṇantassa sakalasarīraṃ pañcavaṇṇāya pītiyā nirantaraṃ🔽phuṭaṃ ahosi. So taṅkhaṇaññeva gantukāmo hutvā – “imāya kho pana velāya mayhaṃ dasabalassa
analyzed: raññaḥ api bhagavataḥ guṇa katham suṇantassa sakala sarīram pañca vaṇṇāya pītiyā nirantaram  phuṭam ahosi saḥ taṅkhaṇañca iva gantu kāmaḥ hutvā imāya kho pana velāya mayham dasabalassa
translated: And as the king listened to the recital of the virtues of the Exalted One, the whole of his body was suffused with the five kinds of joy.

original: santikaṃ gacchato na añño koci khippaṃ yānāni yojetuṃ sakkhissati aññatra jīvakā”ti
analyzed: santikam gacchataḥ na aññaḥ koci khippam yānāni yojetum sakkhissati aññatra jīvaka ati
translated: At that very moment he became desirous of going to the Exalted One, and he thought to himself: “At this time, there is no one else who can harness the vehicles so quickly as Jīvaka.”

original: cintetvā – “tena hi, samma jīvaka, hatthiyānāni kappāpehī”ti āha.🔽158. Tattha tena hīti uyyojanatthe nipāto. Gaccha, samma jīvakāti vuttaṃ hoti. Hatthiyānānīti🔽anekesu assarathādīsu yānesu vijjamānesupi hatthiyānaṃ uttamaṃ; uttamassa santikaṃ🔽uttamayāneneva gantabbanti ca, assayānarathayānāni sasaddāni, dūratova tesaṃ saddo
analyzed: cintetvā tena hi samma jīvaka hatthi yānāni kappāpehi iti āha  tattha tena hi iti uyyojana atthe nipātaḥ gaccha samma jīvaka ati vuttam hoti hatthi yānāni iti  anekesu assa ratha ādīsu yānesu vijjamānesu pi hatthi yānam uttamam uttamassa santikam  uttama yānena iva gantabbanti ca assa yāna ratha yānāni sa saddāni dūratas va tesam saddo
translated: And he said: “Well then, Jīvaka, have the elephant-chariots made ready.”

original: suyyati, hatthiyānassa padānupadaṃ gacchantāpi saddaṃ na suṇanti. Nibbutassa pana
analyzed: suyyati hatthi yānassa padānupadam gacchantā api saddam na suṇanti nibbutassa pana
translated: Here the word “then” is a particle of exhortation. The meaning is: “Go, Jīvaka.” “Elephant-chariots” — although there are many kinds of vehicles such as horse-chariots, etc., the elephant-chariot is the best. The meaning is: “Go to the Exalted One, the best, by the best vehicle.” Horse-chariots, etc., are noisy. Their sound is heard from afar. But those who go by elephant-chariot do not hear the sound. But the sound of the elephant-chariot of the Silent One

original: kho bhagavato santike nibbuteheva yānehi gantabbanti ca cintayitvā hatthiyānānīti āha.
analyzed: kho bhagavato santike nibbutehi iva yānehi gantabbanti ca cintayitvā hatthi yānāni iti āha
translated: and thinking, “I shall go in the presence of the Blessed One in the same vehicles in which I came,” he said, “with the five hundred elephant-loads.”

original: Pañcamattāni hatthinikāsatānīti pañca kareṇusatāni. Kappāpetvāti ārohaṇasajjāni kāretvā.
analyzed: pañca mattāni hatthi nikā satāni iti pañca kareṇu satāni kappāpetvā ati ārohaṇa sajjāni kāretvā
translated: With the five hundred elephant-loads: with the five hundred female elephants. Having had them prepared: having had them made ready for mounting.

original: Ārohaṇīyanti ārohaṇayoggaṃ, opaguyhanti attho. Kiṃ panesa raññā vuttaṃ akāsi avuttanti?
analyzed: ārohaṇīyanti ārohaṇa yoggam opaguyhanti attho kim pana esa raññā vuttam akāsi a vuttam ti
translated: For mounting: for mounting on; the meaning is, for riding. But did he do what the king said or what he did not say?

original: Avuttaṃ. Kasmā? Paṇḍitatāya. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – rājā imāya velāya gacchāmīti vadati,
analyzed: a vuttam kasmā paṇḍita tāya evam kirassa ahosi rājā imāya velāya gacchāmi iti vadati
translated: He did what he did not say. Why? Because of his wisdom. He thought thus: “The king says, ‘I am going at this time,’

original: rājāno ca nāma bahupaccatthikā. Sace antarāmagge koci antarāyo hoti, mampi garahissanti
analyzed: rājāno ca nāma bahu paccatthikā sace antarāmagge koci antarāyaḥ hoti mam pi garahissanti
translated: and kings have many enemies. If there should be some obstacle on the way, they will blame me too,

original: – “jīvako rājā me kathaṃ gaṇhātīti akālepi rājānaṃ gahetvā nikkhamatī”ti. Bhagavantampi
analyzed: jīvakaḥ rājā me katham gaṇhāti iti akāle api rājānam gahetvā nikkhamati iti bhagavantam pi
translated: saying, ‘Jīvaka took the king away at an improper time, thinking, “The king is mine.”’ And they will blame the Blessed One too, saying,

original: garahissanti “samaṇo gotamo, ‘mayhaṃ kathā vattatī’ti kālaṃ asallakkhetvāva dhammaṃ
analyzed: garahissanti samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ mayham kathā vattati iti kālam a saṃlakkhetvā ava dhammaṃ
translated: ‘The recluse Gotama, without considering the time, preached the Dhamma, thinking, “My talk is going on.”’ Therefore, in order that neither I nor the Blessed One be blamed,

original: kathetī”ti. Tasmā yathā neva mayhaṃ, na bhagavato, garahā uppajjati; rañño ca rakkhā
analyzed: kathā iti iti tasmai yathā na iva mayham na bhagavataḥ garahā uppajjati raññaḥ ca rakkhā
translated: and in order that the king be protected,

original: susaṃvihitā hoti, tathā karissāmī”ti.
analyzed: su saṃvihitā hoti tathā karissāmi iti
translated: “I will do so.”

original: Tato itthiyo nissāya purisānaṃ bhayaṃ nāma natthi, ‘sukhaṃ itthiparivuto gamissāmī’ti
analyzed: tatas itthiyaḥ nissāya purisānam bhayam nāma natthi sukham itthi parivutaḥ gamissāmi iti
translated: Then, since there is no danger for men who are accompanied by women, he thought, “I will go along happily, surrounded by women.”

original: pañca hatthinikāsatāni kappāpetvā pañca itthisatāni purisavesaṃ gāhāpetvā – “asitomarahatthā
analyzed: pañca hatthi nikā satāni kappāpetvā pañca itthi satāni purisa vesam gāhāpetvā asi tomara hatthā
translated: So he had five hundred female elephants caparisoned, and he had five hundred women dressed in men’s clothes and armed with swords and shields

original: rājānaṃ parivāreyyāthā”ti vatvā puna cintesi – “imassa rañño imasmiṃ attabhāve maggaphalānaṃ🔽upanissayo natthi, buddhā ca nāma upanissayaṃ disvāva dhammaṃ kathenti. Handāhaṃ,🔽mahājanaṃ sannipātāpemi, evañhi sati satthā kassacideva upanissayena dhammaṃ desessati,
analyzed: rājānam parivāreyyātha iti vatvā puna cintesi imassa raññaḥ imasmin attabhāve magga phalānam  upanissayaḥ natthi buddhā ca nāma upanissayam disvā ava dhammam kathenti handa aham  mahājanam sannipātā apemi evam hi sati satthā kassacid eva upanissayena dhammam desessati
translated: to surround the king. Then he thought, “This king has no opportunity to attain the paths and fruits in this present existence.🔽But the Buddhas, after seeing the opportunity for conversion, preach the Dhamma. Let me assemble a great multitude.

original: sā mahājanassa upakārāya bhavissatī”ti. So tattha tattha sāsanaṃ pesesi, bheriṃ carāpesi
analyzed: sā mahājanassa upakārāya bhavissati iti saḥ tattha tattha sāsanam pesesi bherim carāpesi
translated: In that case the Teacher will preach the Dhamma to someone who has an opportunity for conversion, and that will be of benefit to the multitude.” So he sent out messengers in all directions, had drums beaten,

original: – “ajja rājā bhagavato santikaṃ gacchati, sabbe attano vibhavānurūpena rañño ārakkhaṃ gaṇhantū”ti.
analyzed: ajja rājā bhagavato santikam gacchati sabbe attanaḥ vibhava anurūpena raññaḥ ārakkham gaṇhantu uti
translated: and proclaimed, “Today the king is going into the presence of the Blessed One. Let all men, according to their means, take up the protection of the king.”

original: Tato mahājano cintesi – “rājā kira satthudassanatthaṃ gacchati, kīdisī vata bho dhammadesanā
analyzed: tatas mahājanaḥ cintesi rājā kira satthu dassana attham gacchati kīdisī vata bho dhamma desanā
translated: Then the thought occurred to the multitude, “The king is going to see the Teacher, we hear. What sort of a sermon will there be?

original: patiṭṭhitasamakālameva pana bhagavato tejo rañño sarīraṃ phari. Athassa tāvadeva
analyzed: patiṭṭhita sama kālam eva pana bhagavato tejaḥ raññaḥ sarīram phari athassa tāvat eva
translated: But the moment he stood on the ground the Blessed One’s radiance pervaded the king’s body. Then immediately

original: sakalasarīrato sedā mucciṃsu, sāṭakā pīḷetvā apanetabbā viya ahesuṃ. Attano aparādhaṃ🔽saritvā mahābhayaṃ uppajji. So ujukaṃ bhagavato santikaṃ gantuṃ asakkonto jīvakaṃ
analyzed: sakala sarīrataḥ sedāḥ mucciṃsu sāṭakā pīḷetvā apanetabbāḥ viya ahesum attanaḥ aparādham  saritvā mahā bhayam uppajji saḥ ujukam bhagavato santikam gantum a sakkontaḥ jīvakam
translated: sweat broke out all over his body, and his clothes became as if they were drenched and had to be wrung out. Remembering his offence,

original: hatthe gahetvā ārāmacārikaṃ caramāno viya “idaṃ te samma jīvaka suṭṭhu kāritaṃ idaṃ🔽suṭṭhu kārita”nti vihārassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamāno anukkamena yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṃ
analyzed: hatthe gahetvā ārāmacārikam caramānaḥ viya idam te samma jīvaka suṭṭhu kāritaṃ idam  suṭṭhu kāritanti vihārassa vaṇṇam bhaṇamāno anukkamena yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāram
translated: great fear arose in him. Unable to go straight to the Blessed One, he took Jīvaka by the hand as if he were walking about the monastery grounds, and saying “This is well done, friend Jīvaka, this is well done,”

original: tenupasaṅkami, sampattoti attho.
analyzed: tena upasaṅkami sampatto ti attho
translated: he praised the monastery, and in due course he approached the door of the circular pavilion. The meaning is: he arrived there.

original: Kahaṃ pana sammāti kasmā pucchīti. Eke tāva “ajānanto”ti vadanti. Iminā kira daharakāle
analyzed: kaham pana sammā ati kasmai pucchi iti eke tāva a jānantaḥ iti vadanti iminā kira dahara kāle
translated: “Where is he, friend?”: why did he ask? Some say: “not knowing.” It is said that when he was a boy

original: pitarā saddhiṃ āgamma bhagavā diṭṭhapubbo, pacchā pana pāpamittasaṃsaggena pitughātaṃ
analyzed: pitarā saddhim āgamma bhagavā diṭṭha pubbaḥ pacchā pana pāpa mitta saṃsaggena pitu ghātam
translated: The king had seen the Blessed One before, but only in the company of his father. Afterwards, however, he had committed patricide,

original: katvā abhimāre pesetvā dhanapālaṃ muñcāpetvā mahāparādho hutvā bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ
analyzed: katvā abhimāre pesetvā dhanapālam muñca apetvā mahā aparādhaḥ hutvā bhagavataḥ sammukhībhāvam
translated: had sent assassins, had had Dhanapala executed, and had become a great criminal. He had never approached the Blessed One in person.

original: na upagatapubboti asañjānanto pucchatīti. Taṃ akāraṇaṃ, bhagavā hi ākiṇṇavaralakkhaṇo🔽anubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍito chabbaṇṇāhi rasmīhi sakalaṃ ārāmaṃ obhāsetvā tārāgaṇaparivuto
analyzed: na upagata pubbaḥ ti a sañjānanto pucchati iti tam akāraṇam bhagavā hi ākiṇṇa vara lakkhaṇo  anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍitaḥ chabbaṇṇāhi rasmīhi sakalam ārāmam obhāsetvā tārā gaṇa parivutaḥ
translated: Not recognizing him, he asked the question. But that was not the reason. For the Blessed One was distinguished by the thirty-two marks of a Great Man,

analyzed: viya puṇṇa candaḥ bhikkhu gaṇa parivutaḥ maṇḍala māḷa majjhe nisinnaḥ tam kaḥ na jāneyya
translated: adorned with the eighty minor characteristics, illuminating the whole monastery with his six-colored rays, surrounded by the company of bhikkhus like the full moon by the constellations. Who would not know him?

original: Ayaṃ pana attano issariyalīlāya pucchati. Pakati hesā rājakulānaṃ, yaṃ jānantāpi
analyzed: ayam pana attanaḥ issariya līlāya pucchati pakati hesāḥ rāja kulānam yam jānantā api
translated: But the king asked the question in the play of his sovereignty. For this is the custom of royal families, that even though they know something,

original: ajānantā viya pucchanti. Jīvako pana taṃ sutvā – ‘ayaṃ rājā pathaviyaṃ ṭhatvā kuhiṃ
analyzed: a jānantāḥ viya pucchanti jīvakaḥ pana tam sutvā  ayam rājā pathaviyam ṭhatvā kuhim
translated: they ask as if they do not know. But Jivaka, hearing this, thought: “This king, standing on the earth, asks, ‘Where is the earth?’

original: pathavīti, nabhaṃ ulloketvā kuhiṃ candimasūriyāti, sinerumūle ṭhatvā kuhiṃ sinerūti
analyzed: pathavī iti nabham ulloketvā kuhim candima sūriyā iti sineru mūle ṭhatvā kuhim sineru iti
translated: Looking up at the sky, he asks, ‘Where is the moon and sun?’ Standing at the foot of Sineru, he asks, ‘Where is Sineru?’

original: vadamāno viya dasabalassa purato ṭhatvā kuhiṃ bhagavā’ti pucchati. “Handassa bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: vadamānaḥ viya dasabalassa puratas ṭhatvā kuhim bhagavā iti pucchati handassa bhagavantam
translated: as if he were standing in front of the Lord of the Ten Powers and asking, “Where is the Blessed One?”

original: dassessāmī”ti cintetvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā “eso mahārājā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dassessāmi iti cintetvā yena bhagavā tena añjalim paṇāmetvā esaḥ mahā rājā atiādim āha
translated: as if he were speaking, he stands before the Ten-Powered One and asks, “Where is the Blessed One?” Thinking, “I will show him the Blessed One,” he raises his joined palms to the Blessed One and says, “Here is the great king.”

original: Purakkhatoti parivāretvā nisinnassa purato nisinno.
analyzed: purakkhataḥ ti parivāretvā nisinnassa puratas nisinnaḥ
translated: Surrounded: sitting in front of those who are sitting in a surrounding position.

original: 161. Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamīti yattha bhagavā tattha gato, bhagavato santikaṃ
analyzed: yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamīti yattha bhagavā tattha gataḥ bhagavatoḥ santikam
translated: He approached the Blessed One: he went to where the Blessed One was; he approached the Blessed One.

original: upagatoti attho. Ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsīti bhagavantaṃ vā bhikkhusaṃghaṃ vā asaṅghaṭṭayamāno
analyzed: upagataḥ ti attho ekamantam aṭṭhāsi iti bhagavantam vā bhikkhu saṃgham vā a saṅghaṭṭayamānaḥ

analyzed: tuṇhībhūtanti yatas yatas tato tuṇhībhūtam eva ati attho tattha hi

original: ekabhikkhussapi hatthakukkuccaṃ vā pādakukkuccaṃ vā khipitasaddo vā natthi, sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: eka bhikkhussa api hattha kukkuccam vā pāda kukkuccam vā khipita saddaḥ vā natthi sabba alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: For there was not even the scratching of the arms or the shuffling of the feet or the sound of a cough from a single bhikkhu. The whole assembly was adorned with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man,

original: nāṭakaparivāraṃ bhagavato abhimukhe ṭhitaṃ rājānaṃ vā rājaparisaṃ vā ekabhikkhupi
analyzed: nāṭaka parivāram bhagavataḥ abhimukhe ṭhitam rājānam vā rāja parisam vā
translated: the actors and actresses, standing in front of the Fortunate One, the King or the King’s retinue, or even one monk

original: na olokesi. Sabbe bhagavantaṃyeva olokayamānā nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: na olokesi sabbe bhagavantaṃ yeva olokayamānāḥ nisīdiṃsu
translated: Not even one bhikkhu looked at the king or the royal retinue standing in front of the Blessed One. All sat looking at the Blessed One.

original: Rājā tesaṃ upasame pasīditvā vigatapaṅkatāya vippasannarahadamiva upasantindriyaṃ
analyzed: rājā tesam upasame pasīditvā vigata paṅka tāya vippasanna rahadam iva upasanti indriyam
translated: The king, having been pleased by their calm, as if by a clear, pure lake,

analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham punappunam anuviloketvā udānam udānesi tattha iminā ati yena kāyikena
translated: and having looked again and again at the bhikkhu-sangha whose faculties were calmed, uttered a solemn utterance. There, “by this” means by what bodily,

analyzed: ca vācasikena ca mānasikena ca sīla upasamena bhikkhu saṅgho upasantaḥ iminā upasamena ati
translated: verbal, and mental virtue the bhikkhu-sangha was calmed, by this calm,

analyzed: dīpeti tattha aho vata me puttaḥ pabbajitvā ime bhikkhū viya upasantaḥ bhaveyya ati

analyzed: dullabham hi laddhā acchariyam vā disvā piyānam ñāti mitta ādīnam anussaraṇam nāma lokassa
translated: For when one has obtained what is difficult to obtain, or seen what is wonderful, the recollection of dear relatives, friends, and so on, is natural to the world.

original: pakatiyeva. Iti bhikkhusaṅghaṃ disvā puttaṃ anussaramāno esa evamāha.
analyzed: pakatiyā iva iti bhikkhu saṅgham disvā puttam anussaramānaḥ esaḥ evam āha
translated: and he said this, remembering his son.

original: Api ca putte āsaṅkāya tassa upasamaṃ icchamāno pesa evamāha. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi,
analyzed: api ca putte āsaṅkāya tassa upasamam icchamāno pesaḥ evam āha evam kirassa ahosi
translated: Moreover, he said this, wishing for his own peace of mind, being anxious about his son. He thought thus:

analyzed: puttaḥ me pucchissati mayham pitā daharaḥ ayyakaḥ me kuhinti saḥ pitarā te ghātito ti
translated: “My son will ask me: ‘My father is young. Where is my grandfather?’ He will say: ‘Your father killed your grandfather.’

analyzed: sutvā aham pi pitaram ghātetvā rajjam kāressāmi iti maññissati iti putte āsaṅkāya
translated: Hearing that, he will think: ‘I too will kill my father and rule the kingdom.’ Thus, being anxious about his son,

analyzed: tassa upasamam icchamāno pesaḥ evam āha kiñca api hi esaḥ evam āha atha kho nam putto
translated: he said this, wishing for his own peace of mind. Although he said this, his son

analyzed: tasmin hi vaṃse pitu vadhaḥ pañca parivaṭṭe gataḥ ajātasattu bimbisāram  ghātesi udayaḥ ajātasattum tassa puttaḥ mahāmuṇḍikaḥ nāma udayam tassa puttaḥ anuruddhaḥ
translated: would still kill him. For in that dynasty the killing of the father had gone on for five generations. Ajatasattu killed Bimbisara,

analyzed: nāma mahāmuṇḍikam tassa puttaḥ nāgadāsaḥ nāma anuruddham nāgadāsam pana vaṃsacchedaka rājāno
translated: Udaya killed Ajatasattu, his son Mahamundika killed Udaya, his son Anuruddha killed Mahamundika, and his son Nagadása killed Anuruddha. But Nagadása was killed by his own subjects,

original: ime, kiṃ imehī”ti raṭṭhavāsino kupitā ghātesuṃ.
analyzed: ime kim imehi iti raṭṭha vāsinaḥ kupitāḥ ghātesuṃ
translated: “What is the use of these?” and they killed them.

original: Agamā kho tvanti kasmā evamāha? Bhagavā kira rañño vacībhede akateyeva cintesi –
analyzed: agamā kho tvanti kasmai evam āha bhagavā kira raññaḥ vacībhede a katā iya iva cintesi
translated: Why did the Exalted One say, “You have come, great king, as you were minded”? The Exalted One, it seems, thought:

analyzed: ayam rājā āgantvā tuṇhī niravaḥ ṭhitaḥ kim nu kho cintesi iti athassa cittam ñatvā
translated: “The king has come and stands silently reflecting. What is he thinking?” And knowing his thought,

original: – “ayaṃ mayā saddhiṃ sallapituṃ asakkonto bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā puttaṃ anussari,
analyzed: ayam mayā saddhim sallapitum a sakkontaḥ bhikkhu saṅgham anuviloketvā puttam anussari
translated: “This king, unable to converse with me, is looking over the community of bhikkhus, remembering his son.

analyzed: na kho pana ayam mayi an ālapante kiñci kathetum sakkhissati karomi tena saddhim kathā sallāpanti
translated: But he will not be able to say anything until I speak to him. I will converse with him.”

analyzed: tasmai raññaḥ vacana anantaram agamā kho tvam mahā rāja yathāpemanti āha tassa atthaḥ
translated: Therefore, immediately after the king’s statement, he said, “You have come, great king, as you were minded.” The meaning is this:

original: – mahārāja, yathā nāma unname vuṭṭhaṃ udakaṃ yena ninnaṃ tena gacchati, evameva tvaṃ
analyzed: mahā rāja yathā nāma unname udakam yena ninnam tena gacchati evam eva tvam
translated: “Great king, just as water that falls on a high place flows down to a low place, so too,

analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham anuviloketvā yena pemam tena gataḥ ti
translated: you, looking over the community of bhikkhus, have come to your son with love.”

analyzed: atha raññaḥ etat ahosi aho acchariyāḥ buddha guṇāḥ mayā sadisaḥ bhagavataḥ aparādha kārakaḥ
translated: Then the king thought: “How wonderful are the Buddha’s qualities! There is no one who has done the Blessed One so much harm as I have.

original: nāma natthi, mayā hissa aggupaṭṭhāko ghātito, devadattassa ca kathaṃ gahetvā abhimārā🔽pesitā, nāḷāgiri mutto, maṃ nissāya devadattena silā paviddhā, evaṃ mahāparādhaṃ🔽nāma maṃ ālapato dasabalassa mukhaṃ nappahoti; aho bhagavā pañcahākārehi tādilakkhaṇe
analyzed: nāma natthi mayā hi ssa aggupaṭṭhākaḥ ghātito devadattassa ca katham gahetvā abhimārā  pesitā nāḷāgiri muttaḥ mam nissāya devadattena silā paviddhā evam mahā aparādham  nāma mam ālapataḥ dasabalassa mukham aho bhagavā pañcahā ākārehi tādi lakkhaṇe
translated: For I had his chief supporter killed, and I sent assassins to Devadatta to get him to kill the Blessed One.🔽I set Nāḷāgiri on him, and I had a rock thrown at him by Devadatta. Yet the Blessed One’s face does not turn away from me, who have done him so much harm.

original: suppatiṭṭhito. Evarūpaṃ nāma satthāraṃ pahāya bahiddhā na pariyesissāmā”ti so somanassajāto
analyzed: suppatiṭṭhitaḥ evarūpam nāma satthāram pahāya bahiddhā na pariyesissāma ati so somanassa jātaḥ
translated: How well established the Blessed One is in the five ways of being greatly compassionate! I will never leave such a teacher and seek another outside.” Delighted,

analyzed: bhagavantam ālapantaḥ piyaḥ me bhanta iti ādim āha
translated: he spoke to the Blessed One, beginning with the words “Dear me, venerable sir!”

original: 162. Bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti evaṃ kirassa ahosi bhagavantaṃ vanditvā
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghassa añjalim paṇāmetvā ati evam kirassa ahosi bhagavantam vanditvā
translated: Having paid homage to the Sangha of bhikkhus: it seems that he thought: “After paying homage to the Blessed One,

analyzed: itocitaḥ ca gantvā bhikkhu saṅgham vandantena ca bhagavā piṭṭhitaḥ kātabbaḥ hoti garukāraḥ api
translated: I should go from here to there and pay homage to the Sangha of bhikkhus. The Blessed One should be placed in the rear.”

original: cesa na hoti. Rājānaṃ vanditvā uparājānaṃ vandantenapi hi rañño agāravo kato hoti.
analyzed: ce isa na hoti rājānam vanditvā uparājānam vandantena api hi raññaḥ agāravaḥ kataḥ hoti
translated: and he is not. For when one pays homage to the king’s viceroy after paying homage to the king, one shows disrespect for the king.

original: Tasmā bhagavantaṃ vanditvā ṭhitaṭṭhāneyeva bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ
analyzed: tasmai bhagavantam vanditvā ṭhita ṭṭhāneyā iva bhikkhu saṅghassa añjalim paṇāmetvā ekamantam
translated: Therefore, after paying homage to the Blessed One, he made añjali to the Community of Bhikkhus in the place where he was standing and sat down at one side.

original: nisīdi. Kañcideva desanti kañci okāsaṃ.
analyzed: nisīdi kañcid eva kañcid okāsam
translated: he made añjali to the Community of Bhikkhus in the place where he was standing and sat down at one side.

original: Athassa bhagavā pañhapucchane ussāhaṃ janento āha – “puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
analyzed: athassa bhagavā pañha pucchane ussāham janentaḥ āha puccha mahā rāja yat ākaṅkhasi iti
translated: Then the Blessed One said this to him, rousing his zeal for asking a question: “Ask, great king, what you wish.”

original: Tassattho – “puccha yadi ākaṅkhasi, na me pañhavissajjane bhāro atthi”. Atha vā “puccha,🔽yaṃ ākaṅkhasi, sabbaṃ te vissajjessāmī”ti sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavāresi, asādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ puccha yadi ākaṅkhasi na me pañha vissajjane bhāraḥ atthi atha vā puccha  yam ākaṅkhasi sabbam te vissajjessāmi iti sabbaññu pavāraṇam pavāresi a sādhāraṇam
translated: The meaning is: “Ask if you wish; there is no burden for me in answering a question.” Or alternatively, “Ask,

original: paccekabuddhaaggasāvakamahāsāvakehi. Te hi yadākaṅkhasīti na vadanti, sutvā vedissāmāti
analyzed: paccekabuddha aggasāvaka mahāsāvakehi te hi yat ākaṅkhasi iti na vadanti sutvā vedissāma ati
translated: what you wish, I shall answer all for you,” he invited him to ask all, which is not shared by Paccekabuddhas, chief disciples, and great disciples. For they do not say “Ask what you wish,” but rather “Ask, friend, what you wish. Having heard, we shall know.”

original: vadanti. Buddhā pana – “puccha, āvuso, yadākaṅkhasī”ti, vā “puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī”ti vā,
analyzed: vadanti buddhāḥ pana pucche āvuso yat ākaṅkhasi iti vā puccha mahā rāja yat ākaṅkhasi iti vā
translated: But Buddhas say “Ask, friend, what you wish” or “Ask, great king, what you wish” or “Ask, brahmin, what you wish.”

original: “Puccha, vāsava, maṃ pañhaṃ, yaṃ kiñci manasicchasi;
analyzed: puccha vāsava mam pañham yam kiñci manasi icchasi
translated: “Ask me, Vāsava, whatever you wish.

original: Tassa tasseva pañhassa, ahaṃ antaṃ karomi te”ti. vā;
analyzed: tassa tassa iva pañhassa aham antam karomi vā

analyzed: tena hi tvam bhikkhu sake āsane nisīditvā puccha yat ākaṅkhasi iti vā

original: “Bāvarissa ca tuyhaṃ vā, sabbesaṃ sabbasaṃsayaṃ;
analyzed: bāvarissa ca tuyham vā sabbesam sabba saṃsayam
translated: “To Bāvari and to you, to all of you without exception,

analyzed: kata avakāsā pucchavhaḥ yam kiñci manasi icchatha ati vā

analyzed: puccha mama sabhiya pañham yam kiñci manasi icchasi

original: Tassa tasseva pañhassa, ahaṃ antaṃ karomi te”ti. vā;
analyzed: tassa tassa iva pañhassa aham antam karomi vā
translated: I will give you an answer to each and every question.”

original: Tesaṃ tesaṃ yakkhanarindadevasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakānaṃ sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavārenti.
analyzed: tesam tesam yakkha narinda deva samaṇa brāhmaṇa paribbājakānam sabbaññu pavāraṇam pavārenti

translated: It is not surprising that the Buddha, having attained the state of Buddhahood, should give such permission. But it is surprising that, while still a Bodhisatta, he should give permission to ask questions of all the yakkhas, humans, devas, ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers.

original: “Koṇḍañña, pañhāni viyākarohi;
analyzed: koṇḍañña pañhāni viyākarohi
translated: “Koṇḍañña, answer the questions

analyzed: yācanti tam sādhu rūpā
translated: Asked by these sages of good character.

original: Koṇḍañña, eso manujesu dhammo;
analyzed: koṇḍaññaḥ esaḥ manujesu dhammo
translated: Koṇḍañña, this is the way of men:

analyzed: yam vuddham āgacchati esa
translated: Whatever comes to the wise is a burden.”

original: Evaṃ sakkādīnaṃ atthāya isīhi yācito –
analyzed: evam sakka ādīnam atthāya isīhi yācitaḥ
translated: Thus requested by the seers for the sake of Sakka and the others,

original: “Katāvakāsā pucchantu bhonto,
analyzed: kata avakāsā pucchantu bhonto

original: Yaṃ kiñci pañhaṃ manasābhipatthitaṃ;
analyzed: yam kiñci pañham manasā abhipatthitam

analyzed: aham hi tam tam vaḥ viyākarissam
translated: For I will answer them, each and every one,

analyzed: ñatvā sayam lokam imam parañca ati

original: Evaṃ sarabhaṅgakāle. Sambhavajātake ca sakalajambudīpaṃ tikkhattuṃ vicaritvā pañhānaṃ🔽antakaraṃ adisvā suciratena brāhmaṇena, pañhaṃ puṭṭhuṃ okāse kārite jātiyā sattavassiko
analyzed: evam sarabhaṅga kāle sambhava jātake ca sakala jambudīpam tikkhattum vicaritvā  antakaram a disvā su ciratena brāhmaṇena pañham puṭṭhum okāse kārite jātiyā satta vassikaḥ
translated: Thus at the time of Sarabhanga, and in the Sambhava Jataka, after wandering through the whole of Jambudīpa three times, not seeing an end to questions,🔽when the wise brahmin Sucitti had made a request to ask a question, sitting cross-legged in the middle of the road, playing in the dust with a cart, at the age of seven years,

original: rathikāya paṃsuṃ kīḷanto pallaṅkamābhujitvā antaravīthiyaṃ nisinnova –
analyzed: rathikāya paṃsum kīḍantaḥ antara vīthiyam nisinnaḥ uva
translated: he answered the question:
