analyzed: tat ha te aham akkhissam yathā api kusalaḥ tathā
translated: “I will answer you, brahmin, as well as I can;

original: Rājā ca kho taṃ jānāti, yadi kāhati vā na vā”ti. ;
analyzed: rājā ca khalu tam jānāti yadi kāhati vā na vāti
translated: The king knows whether I am able or not.”

original: Sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavāresi.
analyzed: sabbaññu pavāraṇam pavāresi
translated: Thus he invited the invitation of omniscience.

original: 163. Evaṃ bhagavatā sabbaññupavāraṇāya pavāritāya attamano rājā pañhaṃ pucchanto
analyzed: evam bhagavatā sabbaññu pavāraṇāya pavāritāya atta manaḥ rājā pañham pucchantaḥ
translated: Thus, when the invitation of omniscience was invited by the Blessed One, the king, being pleased, asked a question:

original: – “yathā nu kho imāni, bhante”tiādimāha. Tattha sippameva sippāyatanaṃ. Puthusippāyatanānīti
analyzed: yathā nu kho imāni bhante ti ādim āha tattha sippam eva sippa āyatanam puthu sippa āyatanāni iti
translated: “How, venerable sir?”

original: bahūni sippāni. Seyyathidanti katame pana te. Hatthārohātiādīhi ye taṃ taṃ sippaṃ
analyzed: bahūni sippāni katame pana te hattha āroha ati ādīhi ye tam tam sippam
translated: Herein, the art itself is the art-source. Many arts are art-sources.

original: nissāya jīvanti, te dasseti. Ayañhi assādhippāyo – “yathā imesaṃ sippūpajīvīnaṃ taṃ🔽taṃ sippaṃ nissāya sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ paññāyati. Sakkā nu kho evaṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ
analyzed: nissāya jīvanti te dassa iti ayam hi assa adhippāyaḥ yathā imesam sippūpajīvīnam tam  tam sippam nissāya sandiṭṭhikam sippa phalam paññāyati sakkā nu kho evam sandiṭṭhikam
translated: What are they? They are shown by the words “elephant-craft” and so on.

original: sāmaññaphalaṃ paññāpetu”nti. Tasmā sippāyatanāni āharitvā sippūpajīvino dasseti.🔽Tattha hatthārohāti sabbepi hatthācariyahatthivejjahatthimeṇḍādayo dasseti. Assārohāti
analyzed: sāmañña phalam paññāpetunti tasmā sippa āyatanāni āharitvā sippu upajīvinaḥ dasseti  tattha hattha āroha ati sabbe pi hattha ācariya hatthi vejja hatthi meṇḍa ādayaḥ dasseti assa āroha ati
translated: For this is the purport: “Just as the fruit of the arts of these art-livings is evident here and now by their depending on this or that art, can the fruit of recluseship be demonstrated in suchwise?” That is why he has brought in the art-sources and shown the art-livings.

original: sabbepi assācariyaassavejjaassameṇḍādayo. Rathikāti sabbepi rathācariyarathayodharatharakkhādayo.
analyzed: sabbe pi rathikā ati sabbe pi rathācariya ratha yodha ratha rakkha ādayo
translated: Herein, “elephant-craft” shows all elephant-trainers, elephant-doctors, elephant-drivers, and so on. “Horse-craft” shows all horse-trainers, horse-doctors, horse- grooms, and so on. “Chariot-craft” shows all chariot-trainers, chariot-warriors, chariot-guards, and so on.

original: Dhanuggahāti dhanuācariyā issāsā. Celakāti ye yuddhe jayadhajaṃ gahetvā purato gacchanti.
analyzed: dhanuggahā ati dhanu ācariyāḥ issāsā celakā ati ye yuddhe jaya dhajam gahetvā puratas gacchanti
translated: Dhanuggaha: archers, bowmen. Celaka: those who go in front of the army carrying the banner of victory.🔽Calaka: those who arrange the battle array, saying, “Here the king should stand, here the minister so-and-so.”

original: Calakāti idha rañño ṭhānaṃ hotu, idha asukamahāmattassāti evaṃ senābyūhakārakā. Piṇḍadāyakāti🔽sāhasikamahāyodhā. Te kira parasenaṃ pavisitvā parasīsaṃ piṇḍamiva chetvā chetvā
analyzed: calakā ati idha rañño ṭhānam hotu idha asuka mahāmattassa ati evam senā byūha kārakā piṇḍa dāyakā ati  sāhasika mahā yodhā te kira para senam pavisitvā para sīsam piṇḍam iva chetvā chetvā
translated: Piṇḍadāyaka:

original: dayanti, uppatitvā uppatitvā niggacchantīti attho. Ye vā saṅgāmamajjhe yodhānaṃ bhattapātiṃ
analyzed: dayanti uppatitvā uppatitvā niggacchanti iti atthaḥ ye vā saṅgāma majjhe yodhānam bhatta pātim
translated: adventurous great warriors. They are said to cut off the heads of the enemy army and give them away, as if giving out morsels of food. The meaning is that they go forth, jumping up again and again. Or they are so called because they serve the warriors in the midst of battle, taking the food-bowl.

original: gahetvā parivisanti, tesampetaṃ nāmaṃ. Uggā rājaputtāti uggatuggatā saṅgāmāvacarā🔽rājaputtā. Pakkhandinoti ye “kassa sīsaṃ vā āvudhaṃ vā āharāmā”ti “vatvā asukassā”ti
analyzed: gahetvā parivisanti tesampetam nāmam uggāḥ rāja puttāḥ ati ugga tugga tā saṅgāma avacarā  rāja puttā pakkhandino ti ye kassa sīsam vā āvudham vā āharāma ati vatvā asukassa ati
translated: Uggā rājaputtā: the sons of kings who are the best of the best, who are skilled in battle.

original: vuttā saṅgāmaṃ pakkhanditvā tadeva āharanti, ime pakkhandantīti pakkhandino. Mahānāgāti
analyzed: vuttā saṅgāmam pakkhanditvā tat eva āharanti ime pakkhandanti iti pakkhandinaḥ mahā nāgā ati
translated: Pakkhandina: those who say, “Whose head or weapon shall we bring?” and when told, “So-and-so’s,” go forth into battle and bring it back. They are called “those who go forth” . Mahānāgā:

original: mahānāgā viya mahānāgā, hatthiādīsupi abhimukhaṃ āgacchantesu anivattitayodhānametaṃ
analyzed: mahā nāgāḥ viya mahā nāgāḥ hatthi ādīsu pi abhimukham āgacchantesu
translated: great warriors like great nāgas. This refers to warriors who do not turn back even when elephants and other warriors come against them.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Sūrāti ekantasūrā, ye sajālikāpi sacammikāpi samuddaṃ tarituṃ sakkonti.
analyzed: adhivacanam sūrāḥ iti ekanta sūrāḥ ye sa jālikā api sa cammikā api samuddam taritum sakkonti
translated: “Terms” : the terms “elephant-riders” and so on. “Good at” : they are good at crossing the ocean, even with nets and rafts.

original: Cammayodhinoti ye cammakañcukaṃ vā pavisitvā saraparittāṇacammaṃ vā gahetvā yujjhanti.🔽Dāsikaputtāti balavasinehā gharadāsayodhā. Āḷārikāti pūvikā. Kappakāti nhāpikā. Nhāpakāti
analyzed: camma yodhinaḥ ti ye camma kañcukam vā pavisitvā sara parittāṇa cammam vā gahetvā yujjhanti  dāsika puttā ati balava sinehāḥ ghara dāsa yodhāḥ āḷārikā ati pūvikā kappakā ati nhāpikā nhāpakā ati
translated: “Leather-clad warriors” : they fight after putting on leather armour or after taking a leather shield.🔽“Sons of slave women” : they are warriors who are slaves in the house and are very devoted. “Farmers” : they are ploughmen. “Gardeners” : they are gardeners. “Bathmen” :

original: ye nhāpenti. Sūdāti bhattakārakā. Mālākārādayo pākaṭāyeva. Gaṇakāti acchiddakapāṭhakā.
analyzed: ye nhāpenti bhatta kārakāḥ mālākāra ādayaḥ acchiddaka pāṭhakā
translated: they are bath attendants. “Servants” : they are cooks. “Garlanded men” and so on are obvious. “Accountants” : they are accountants who do not make mistakes.

original: Muddikāti hatthamuddāya gaṇanaṃ nissāya jīvino. Yāni vā panaññānipīti ayakāradantakāracittakārādīni.
analyzed: muddikā ati hattha muddāya gaṇanam nissāya jīvinaḥ yāni vā pana aññāni pi iti ayakāra dantakāra cittakāra ādīni
translated: “Scribe” : they are those who make a living by counting with their fingers. “Or any other such” : such as ivory-carvers, tailors, and so on.

original: Evaṃgatānīti evaṃ pavattāni. Te diṭṭheva dhammeti te hatthārohādayo tāni puthusippāyatanāni
analyzed: evaṃgatāni iti evam pavattāni te diṭṭhe iva dhamme ti te hattha āroha ādayo tāni puthu sippa āyatanāni
translated: “Such as these” : such as these elephant-riders and so on.

original: dassetvā rājakulato mahāsampattiṃ labhamānā sandiṭṭhikameva sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti.
analyzed: dassetvā rāja kulataḥ mahā sampattim labhamānā sandiṭṭhikam eva sippa phalam upajīvanti
translated: “In this very life” : after showing these various skills, they make a living by enjoying the fruit of their skills, which is the great wealth they receive from the royal family.

original: Sukhentīti sukhitaṃ karonti. Pīṇentīti pīṇitaṃ thāmabalūpetaṃ karonti. Uddhaggikādīsu
analyzed: sukhenti iti sukhitam karonti pīṇenti iti pīṇitam thāma bala upetam karonti uddhaggika ādīsu
translated: They make them happy : they make them happy . They make them glad : they make them glad , endow them with strength and power .🔽As regards the upward-going, etc.,

original: upari phalanibbattanato uddhaṃ aggamassā atthīti uddhaggikā. Saggaṃ arahatīti sovaggikā.🔽Sukho vipāko assāti sukhavipākā. Suṭṭhu agge rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbaāyuvaṇṇasukhayasaādhipateyyasaṅkhāte
analyzed: upari phala nibbattanato uddham aggam assā atthi iti uddhaggikā saggam arahati iti sovaggikā  sukhaḥ vipākaḥ assa ati sukha vipākā suṭṭhu agge rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba āyu vaṇṇa sukha yasa ādhipateyya saṅkhāte
translated: because the fruit is produced above, it has an upward top, thus it is upward-going . It is worthy of heaven, thus it is heaven-ward .🔽Its ripening is pleasant, thus it has pleasant ripening . It brings about, produces, ten things, namely, visible form, sound, odour, flavour, the tangible, life, heart-basis, sex, vitality, and the faculty of unification, thus it is heaven-producing .

original: dasa dhamme saṃvatteti nibbattetīti saggasaṃvattanikā. Taṃ evarūpaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ dānaṃ🔽patiṭṭhapentīti attho. Sāmaññaphalanti ettha paramatthato maggo sāmaññaṃ. Ariyaphalaṃ🔽sāmaññaphalaṃ. Yathāha – “katamañca, bhikkhave, sāmaññaṃ? Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko
analyzed: dasa dhamme saṃvatteti nibbatteti iti saggasaṃvattanikā tam evarūpam dakkhiṇam dānam  patiṭṭhapenti iti attho sāmañña phalam ti ettha paramatthataḥ maggo sāmaññam ariya phalam  sāmañña phalam yathā āha katamat ca bhikkhave sāmaññam ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgiko
translated: They establish such a gift, such a offering, thus is the meaning.🔽As regards the fruit of recluseship, here the path is recluseship in the ultimate sense.

original: maggo. Seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhi. Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sāmaññaṃ.
analyzed: maggo seyyathīdam sammā diṭṭhi pe sammā samādhi idam vuccati bhikkhave sāmaññam
translated: The noble fruit is the fruit of recluseship. As it is said: “And what, bhikkhus, is recluseship? It is this Noble Eightfold Path, namely, right view … right concentration. This is called recluseship” .

original: Katamāni ca, bhikkhave, sāmaññaphalāni? Sotāpattiphalaṃ…pe… arahattaphala”nti. Taṃ
analyzed: katamāni ca bhikkhave sāmañña phalāni sotāpatti phalam pe arahatta phalanti taṃ
translated: And what are the fruits of recluseship? They are the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, and the fruit of arahantship.”

original: esa rājā na jānāti. Upari āgataṃ pana dāsakassakopamaṃ sandhāya pucchati.
analyzed: esa rājā na jānāti upari āgatam pana dāsa kassaka upamam sandhāya pucchati
translated: But the king does not know this. He is asking about the parable of the field and the seeds which the Exalted One has just related.

original: Atha bhagavā pañhaṃ avissajjetvāva cintesi – “ime bahū aññatitthiyasāvakā rājāmaccā🔽idhāgatā, te kaṇhapakkhañca sukkapakkhañca dīpetvā kathīyamāne amhākaṃ rājā mahantena🔽ussāhena idhāgato, tassāgatakālato paṭṭhāya samaṇo gotamo samaṇakolāhalaṃ samaṇabhaṇḍanameva🔽kathetīti ujjhāyissanti, na sakkaccaṃ dhammaṃ sossanti, raññā pana kathīyamāne ujjhāyituṃ🔽na sakkhissanti, rājānameva anuvattissanti. Issarānuvattako hi loko. ‘Handāhaṃ raññova
analyzed: atha bhagavā pañham a vissajjetvā ava cintesi ime bahū añña titthiya sāvakāḥ rāja amaccā  idha āgatā te kaṇha pakkhañca sukka pakkhañca dīpetvā kathīyamāne amhākam rājā mahantena  ussāhena idha āgataḥ tassa āgata kālataḥ paṭṭhāya samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ samaṇa kolāhalam samaṇa bhaṇḍanam eva  katheti iti ujjhāyissanti na sakkaccam dhammam sossanti raññā pana kathīyamāne ujjhāyitum  na sakkhissanti rājānam eva anuvattissanti issara anuvattakaḥ hi lokaḥ handa aham raññā uva
translated: Then the Exalted One thought: “Many of these non-Buddhist ascetics and brahmins, the king’s ministers and vassals, have come here.

original: bhāraṃ karomī’ti rañño bhāraṃ karonto “abhijānāsi no tva”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: bhāram karomi iti raññaḥ bhāram karontaḥ abhijānāsi no tvam tiādim āha
translated: If I were to explain the dark side and the bright side, the king, who has come here with great pomp, would be displeased and would think: ‘Since his arrival, the recluse Gotama has been talking only about quarrels, disputes, and brawls among recluses.’ He would not listen to the Dhamma with full attention and would not be able to understand it. But if the king were to explain the Dhamma, the others would not be able to find fault with him. They would follow the king and would listen to the Dhamma with full attention. For the world follows the powerful. ‘Let me then make the king bear the burden.’ So he said to the king: “Do you remember this or not?”

original: 164. Tattha abhijānāsi no tvanti abhijānāsi nu tvaṃ. Ayañca no-saddo parato pucchitāti🔽padena yojetabbo. Idañhi vuttaṃ hoti – “mahārāja, tvaṃ imaṃ pañhaṃ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe🔽pucchitā nu, abhijānāsi ca naṃ puṭṭhabhāvaṃ, na te sammuṭṭha”nti. Sace te agarūti🔽sace tuyhaṃ yathā te byākariṃsu, tathā idha bhāsituṃ bhāriyaṃ na hoti, yadi na koci
analyzed: tattha abhijānāsi no tvanti abhijānāsi nu tvam ayam ca nosaddo paratas pucchitā ati  padena yojetabbaḥ idam hi vuttam hoti mahā rāja tvam imam pañham aññe samaṇa brāhmaṇe  pucchitā nu abhijānāsi ca nam puṭṭha bhāvam na te sammuṭṭhanti sace te  sace tuyham yathā te byākariṃsu tathā idha bhāsitum na hoti yadi na koci
translated: Herein, do you remember or not? means do you remember or not? And this word or not? should be construed with the question word do you remember?🔽For this is said: “Great king, did you ask this question of other ascetics and brahmans, and do you remember having asked it? It is not that you have forgotten it.”🔽If it is not too much trouble for you,🔽if it is not a burden for you to speak here in accordance with what they have declared, if no one🔽

original: aphāsukabhāvo atthi, bhāsassūti attho. Na kho me bhanteti kiṃ sandhāyāha? Paṇḍitapatirūpakānañhi🔽santike kathetuṃ dukkhaṃ hoti, te pade pade akkhare akkhare dosameva vadanti. Ekantapaṇḍitā🔽pana kathaṃ sutvā sukathitaṃ pasaṃsanti, dukkathitesu pāḷipadaatthabyañjanesu yaṃ🔽yaṃ virujjhati, taṃ taṃ ujukaṃ katvā denti. Bhagavatā ca sadiso ekantapaṇḍito nāma
analyzed: a phāsuka bhāvaḥ atthi bhāsassu iti atthaḥ na kho me bhante iti kim sandhāya āha paṇḍita pati rūpakānam hi 🔽santike kathetum dukkham hoti te pade pade akkhare akkhare dosam eva vadanti ekanta paṇḍitā 🔽pana katham sutvā su kathitam pasaṃsanti dukkathitesu pāḷi pada attha byañjanesu yam 🔽yam virujjhati tam tam ujukam katvā denti bhagavatā ca sadisaḥ ekantapaṇḍitaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, do you remember or not? means do you remember or not? And this word or not? should be construed with the question word do you remember? For this is said: “Great king, have you asked this question of other ascetics and brahmans, and do you remember their answers? You are not confused about it.” If it is not troublesome to you means if it is not difficult for you to speak here in accordance with what they have declared, if there is no discomfort for you, speak, is the meaning. He said, “No, venerable sir,” with reference to what? For it is difficult to speak in the presence of those who seem to be wise, for they find fault with every word and syllable. But those who are entirely wise praise good speech when they hear it, and when there is bad speech they point out what is faulty in the wording, the letter, and the syllables, and they give their own opinion.

original: natthi. Tenāha – “na kho me, bhante, garu; yatthassa bhagavā nisinno bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
analyzed: na atthi tena āha na kho me bhante garu yatthassa bhagavā nisinnaḥ bhagavantarūpaḥ vāti
translated: “No, venerable sir, it is not a heavy burden for me to carry the Lord or one like the Lord.”

original: Pūraṇakassapavādavaṇṇanā
translated: The account of Pūraṇa Kassapa

original: 165. Ekamidāhanti ekaṃ idha ahaṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvāti sammodajanakaṃ saritabbayuttakaṃ kathaṃ pariyosāpetvā.
analyzed: ekam idā aham iti ekam idha aham sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ati sammoda janakam saritabba yuttakam katham pariyosāpetvā
translated: “At one time, great king, I was staying at Vesālī in the Great Grove, in the Gabled Hall.”

original: 166. “Karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato”tiādīsu karototi sahatthā karontassa. Kārayatoti🔽āṇattiyā kārentassa. Chindatoti paresaṃ hatthādīni chindantassa. Pacatoti pare daṇḍena
analyzed: karoto kho mahā rāja kārayato tiādīsu karoto ti sahatthā karontassa kārayato ti  āṇattiyā kārentassa chindato ti paresam hattha ādīni chindantassa pacato ti pare daṇḍena
translated: “Great king, as regards the words ‘one who acts and causes (others) to act,’ one who acts is one who does (the deed) with his own person. One who causes (others) to act is one who does it by ordering (others).

original: pīḷentassa. Socayatoti parassa bhaṇḍaharaṇādīhi socayato. Socāpayatoti sokaṃ sayaṃ
analyzed: pīḷentassa socayato iti parassa bhaṇḍa haraṇa ādīhi socayato socāpayato iti sokam sayam
translated: One who mutilates is one who cuts off the hands, etc., of others. One who tortures is one who torments others with a stick, etc. One who causes grief is one who causes grief to others by confiscating their wealth, etc. One who causes sorrow is one who causes sorrow to others by killing their parents, etc.🔽One who inflicts suffering is one who inflicts suffering on others by imprisoning them, etc. One who causes suffering is one who causes suffering to others by ordering (others) to do these things.

original: karontassapi parehi kārāpentassapi. Kilamatoti āhārupacchedabandhanāgārappavesanādīhi🔽sayaṃ kilamantassapi parehi kilamāpentassapi. Phandato phandāpayatoti paraṃ phandantaṃ
analyzed: karontassa api parehi kārāpentassa api kilamato ti āhāra upaccheda bandhana āgāra ppavesana ādīhi 🔽sayam kilamantassa api parehi kilamāpentassa api phandato phandāpayato ti param phandantam
translated: One who harasses is one who harasses others by confiscating their wives, etc. One who causes harassment is one who causes harassment to others by ordering (others) to do these things.

original: phandanakāle sayampi phandato parampi phandāpayato. Pāṇamatipātāpayatoti pāṇaṃ hanantassapi
analyzed: phandana kāle sayam pi phandataḥ param pi phandāpayataḥ pāṇam atipātāpayataḥ iti pāṇam hanantassa api
translated: At the time of the wind’s blowing, if he blows himself and makes another blow. At the time of the killing of a living being, if he kills himself and makes another kill.

original: hanāpentassapi. Evaṃ sabbattha karaṇakāraṇavaseneva attho veditabbo.
analyzed: evam sabbattha karaṇa kāraṇa vasena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: Thus the meaning should be understood in each case according to the act and the cause of the act.

original: Sandhinti gharasandhiṃ. Nillopanti mahāvilopaṃ. Ekāgārikanti ekameva gharaṃ parivāretvā
analyzed: sandhim ti ghara sandhim ekāgārikam iti ekam eva gharam parivāretvā
translated: “A joint” : a house-joint. “A great theft” : a great robbery. “A single house” : a single house surrounded and

original: viluppanaṃ. Paripantheti āgatāgatānaṃ acchindanatthaṃ magge tiṭṭhato. Karoto na karīyati
analyzed: viluppanam paripanthā iti āgata āgatānam a chindana attham magge tiṭṭhataḥ karotaḥ na
translated: robbed. “A road” : standing on a road for the purpose of robbing those who come along. “If he does, he does not do evil” :

original: pāpanti yaṃ kiñci pāpaṃ karomīti saññāya karotopi pāpaṃ na karīyati, natthi pāpaṃ.
analyzed: pāpanti yam kiñci pāpam karomi iti saññāya karotaḥ api pāpam na karīyati natthi pāpam
translated: if he thinks “I am doing any kind of evil” and does it, he does not do evil, there is no evil.

original: Sattā pana pāpaṃ karomāti evaṃsaññino hontīti dīpeti. Khurapariyantenāti khuraneminā,🔽khuradhārasadisapariyantena vā. Ekaṃ maṃsakhalanti ekaṃ maṃsarāsiṃ. Puñjanti tasseva
analyzed: sattā pana pāpam karoma ati evaṃsaññinaḥ honti iti dīpe ti khura pariyantena ati khura neminā  khura dhāra sadisa pariyantena vā ekam maṃsa khalanti ekam maṃsa rāsim puñjanti tassa iva
translated: But living beings think thus: “He is doing evil.” This is what is shown. “On the edge of a razor” : on the edge of a razor-scraper,

original: vevacanaṃ. Tatonidānanti ekamaṃsakhalakaraṇanidānaṃ.
analyzed: vevacanam eka maṃsa khala karaṇa nidānam
translated: or on the edge of a razor-blade. “A single lump of flesh” : a single mass of flesh. “A heap” : a synonym for that. “On account of that” : on account of the making of a single lump of flesh.

original: Dakkhiṇanti dakkhiṇatīre manussā kakkhaḷā dāruṇā, te sandhāya “hananto”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dakkhiṇanti dakkhiṇa tīre manussā kakkhaḷā dāruṇā te sandhāya hanantaḥ iti ādim āha
translated: “South” : people in the southern region are hard and cruel. With them in mind he says “slayer” , etc.

original: Uttaratīre sattā saddhā honti pasannā buddhamāmakā dhammamāmakā saṅghamāmakā, te
analyzed: uttara tīre sattā saddhāḥ honti pasannāḥ buddha māmakāḥ dhamma māmakā saṅgha māmakā te
translated: On the northern bank the beings are faithful, confident, respectful to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha,

original: sandhāya dadantotiādimāha. Tattha yajantoti mahāyāgaṃ karonto. Damenāti indriyadamena
analyzed: sandhāya dadantaḥ iti ādim āha tattha yajantaḥ iti mahā yāgam karontaḥ damena ati indriya damena
translated: With them in mind he says “giver” , etc. Herein, “worshipper” : one who performs a great sacrifice. “Self-controlled” : by the control of the faculties,

original: uposathakammena vā. Saṃyamenāti sīlasaṃyamena. Saccavajjenāti saccavacanena. Āgamoti
analyzed: uposatha kammena vā saṃyamena ati sīla saṃyamena saccavajjena ati saccavacanena āgamaḥ ti
translated: by the observance-day ceremony, or by the control of virtue. “By the gift of truth” : by a true statement. “Coming” :

original: āgamanaṃ, pavattīti attho. Sabbathāpi pāpapuññānaṃ kiriyameva paṭikkhipati.🔽Ambaṃ puṭṭho labujaṃ byākaroti nāma, yo kīdiso ambo kīdisāni vā ambassa khandhapaṇṇapupphaphalānīti
analyzed: āgamanam pavatti iti attho sabbathā api pāpa puññānam kiriyam eva paṭikkhipati  ambam puṭṭhaḥ labujam byākaroti nāma yaḥ kīdisaḥ ambaḥ kīdisāni vā ambassa khandha paṇṇa puppha phalāni iti
translated: the meaning is “arriving.” He rejects the performance of all evil and good deeds.🔽“When asked about a mango, he answers with a breadfruit” : when asked “What is a mango like? Or what are the trunk, leaves, flowers, and fruit of a mango like?”

original: vutte ediso labujo edisāni vā labujassa khandhapaṇṇapupphaphalānīti byākaroti. Vijiteti
analyzed: vutte edisaḥ labujaḥ edisāni vā labujassa khandha paṇṇa puppha phalāni iti byākaroti vijitā iti
translated: he answers “A breadfruit is like this, or the trunk, leaves, flowers, and fruit of a breadfruit are like this.” “In his own realm” :

original: āṇāpavattidese. Apasādetabbanti viheṭhetabbaṃ. Anabhinanditvāti “sādhu sādhū”ti evaṃ
analyzed: āṇā pavatti dese apasādetabbanti viheṭhetabbam an abhinanditvā ati sādhu sādhu iti evam
translated: in the area where his command prevails. “To be despised” : to be harmed. “Without rejoicing” : without saying “Good, good!”

original: pasaṃsaṃ akatvā. Appaṭikkositvāti bāladubbhāsitaṃ tayā bhāsitanti evaṃ appaṭibāhitvā.
analyzed: pasaṃsam a katvā a paṭikkositvā ati bāla dubbhāsitam tayā bhāsitam ti evam a paṭibāhitvā
translated: Without praising, without censuring: without saying, “What you have said is well said,” and without saying, “What you have said is badly said.”

original: Anuggaṇhantoti sārato aggaṇhanto. Anikkujjantoti sāravaseneva idaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, ayaṃ🔽paramatthoti hadaye aṭṭhapento. Byañjanaṃ pana tena uggahitañceva nikkujjitañca.🔽Makkhaligosālavādavaṇṇanā🔽167-169. Makkhalivāde paccayoti hetuvevacanameva, ubhayenāpi vijjamānameva kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ
analyzed: an uggaṇhantaḥ iti sārataḥ a ggaṇhantaḥ a nikkujjantaḥ iti sāra vasena iva idam nissaraṇam ayam  paramattho ti hadaye aṭṭhapentaḥ byañjanam pana tena uggahitam ca iva nikkujjitam ca  makkhali gosāla vāda vaṇṇanā  makkhali vāde paccayaḥ ti hetu vevacanam eva ubhayena api vijjamānam eva kāya duccarita ādīnam
translated: Accepting, not rejecting: accepting it as the essence, not rejecting it as mere verbiage.

original: saṃkilesapaccayaṃ, kāyasucaritādīnañca visuddhipaccayaṃ paṭikkhipati. Attakāreti
analyzed: saṃkilesa paccayam kāya su carita ādīnam ca visuddhi paccayam paṭikkhipati atta kāreti
translated: As to the doctrine of Makkhali Gosāla, the word paccaya is a synonym for cause. By both terms he denies that there is a cause for the defilement of bodily misconduct, etc., and for the purification of good bodily conduct, etc.🔽He denies that there is any personal effort,

original: attakāro. Yena attanā katakammena ime sattā devattampi mārattampi brahmattampi sāvakabodhimpi
analyzed: atta kāraḥ yena attanā kata kammena ime sattāḥ devattam pi mārattam pi brahmattam pi sāvaka bodhim pi
translated: by which these beings attain the states of a god, a human, Māra, Brahmā, a disciple, a paccekabuddha, or a fully enlightened Buddha.

original: paccekabodhimpi sabbaññutampi pāpuṇanti, tampi paṭikkhipati. Dutiyapadena yaṃ parakāraṃ
analyzed: pacceka bodhim pi sabbaññu tam pi pāpuṇanti tam pi paṭikkhipati dutiya padena yam parakāram
translated: By the second line he denies that there is any other’s effort,

analyzed: parassa ovāda anusāsanim nissāya ṭhapetvā mahāsattam avasesaḥ janaḥ manussa sobhagyatam
translated: Excepting the Great Being, all other people attain the human good fortune,

analyzed: ādim katvā yāva arahattam pāpuṇāti tam parakāram paṭikkhipati evam ayam bālaḥ jina cakke  pahāram deti nāma natthi purisakāreti yena purisakārena sattāḥ vutta ppakārāḥ sampattiyaḥ  pāpuṇanti tam pi paṭikkhipati natthi balanti yamhi attanaḥ bale patiṭṭhitā sattā
translated: and so on, up to the attainment of arahatship, by depending on the advice and instruction of others. Thus he rejects the help of others. In this way, the fool

original: vīriyaṃ katvā tā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti, taṃ balaṃ paṭikkhipati. Natthi vīriyantiādīni🔽sabbāni purisakāravevacanāneva. “Idaṃ no vīriyena idaṃ purisathāmena, idaṃ purisaparakkamena
analyzed: vīriyam katvā tāḥ sampattiyaḥ pāpuṇanti tam balam paṭikkhipati natthi vīriya ntiādīni  sabbāni idam naḥ vīriyena idam purisa thāmena idam purisa parakkamena
translated: deals a blow to the wheel of victory. There is no manly effort: he rejects the manly effort by which beings attain the kinds of prosperity described above. original: pavatta”nti evaṃ pavattavacanapaṭikkhepakaraṇavasena panetāni visuṃ ādiyanti.
analyzed: pavattanti evam pavatta vacana paṭikkhepa karaṇa vasena pana itāni visum ādiyanti
translated: this is due to manly valor, this is due to manly endurance, this is due to manly striving, this is due to manly heroism, this is due to manly toughness, this is due to manly strength, this is due to manly valor” — thus he rejects the statement that these things occur due to manly effort.

original: Sabbe sattāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhādayo anavasese pariggaṇhāti. Sabbe pāṇāti ekindriyo
analyzed: sabbe sattā ati oṭṭha goṇa gadrabha ādayaḥ anavasese pariggaṇhāti sabbe pāṇā ti eka indriyaḥ
translated: All beings: he includes all beings without exception, including oxen, goats, donkeys, and so on. All creatures: he includes all beings without exception, including those with one sense faculty,

analyzed: pāṇaḥ dvindriyaḥ pāṇa iti ādi vasena vadati sabbe bhūtā ati aṇḍa kosa vatthi kosesu bhūte

analyzed: sandhāya vadati sabbe jīvāti sāli yava godhuma ādayo sandhāya vadati tesu hi saḥ virūhana bhāvena
translated: “All living beings”: he speaks with reference to rice, barley, and so on. For he regards these as “living beings” because they grow.

original: Yonipamukhasatasahassānīti pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ cuddasasatasahassāni aññāni
analyzed: yoni pamukha sata sahassāni iti pamukha yonīnam uttama yonīnam cuddasa sata sahassāni aññāni
translated: “A hundred thousand doors of wombs” : a hundred thousand principal wombs, principal doors of birth,

translated: He merely shows a view that is useless, a mere guess. In the case of “five kinds of action and three kinds of action” and so on,

analyzed: paramasukkā abhijātī iti imāḥ cha abhijātiyaḥ vadati tattha orabbhikā sākuṇikā māgavikā

analyzed: kira catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti bhikkhū kaṇṭaka vuttikā ati ayam hissa
translated: They are said to eat after having put thorns into the four requisites. “Monks live on thorns” is the reading.

original: pāḷiyeva. Atha vā kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitāti vadati. Lohitābhijāti nāma🔽nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadati. Ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā. Gihī odātavasanā
analyzed: pāḷiyā iva atha vā kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitā iti vadati lohitābhijāti nāma  nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakā ati vadati ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā gihī odāta vasanā
translated: Or he says that some who have gone forth are called “thorn-eaters.” He says that the red noble birth is🔽the Niganthas who wear a single garment. They are said to be whiter than the two preceding kinds. He says that the yellow noble birth is

original: acelakasāvakā haliddābhijātīti vadati. Evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare
analyzed: acelaka sāvakā haliddā abhijātī iti vadati evam attanaḥ paccaya dāyake nigaṇṭhehi pi jeṭṭhakatare
translated: lay people who wear white. He says that the white noble birth is the naked ascetics’ pupils. Thus he says that the Niganthas, who give him the requisites, are the most senior🔽and the best.

original: karoti. Ājīvakā ājīvakiniyo sukkābhijātīti vadati. Te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā.
analyzed: karoti ājīvakāḥ ājīvakiniyaḥ sukkābhijātī iti vadati te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā
translated: He says that the Ājīvakas and Ājīvakis are the whitest of the white. They are, he says, whiter than the first four.

original: Nando, vaccho, kiso, saṅkiccho, makkhaligosālo, paramasukkābhijātīti vadati. Te kira
analyzed: nandaḥ vacchaḥ kisaḥ saṅkicchaḥ makkhali gosālo paramasukka abhijātī iti vadati te kira
translated: He says that Nanda, Vaccha, Kisa, Saṅkiccha, and Makkhali Gosāla are the whitest of the white. They are, he says,

original: sabbehi paṇḍaratarā.🔽Aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi, khiḍḍābhūmi, padavīmaṃsabhūmi, ujugatabhūmi, sekkhabhūmi,🔽samaṇabhūmi, jinabhūmi, pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadati. Tattha jātadivasato
analyzed: sabbehi paṇḍaratarā  manda bhūmi khiḍḍā bhūmi padavīmaṃsa bhūmi uju gata bhūmi sekkha bhūmi  samaṇa bhūmi jina bhūmi panna bhūmi iti imāḥ aṭṭha purisa bhūmiyo ti vadati tattha jāta divasato
translated: whiter than all the others.🔽He says that there are eight stages of human beings: the stage of the dull, the stage of play, the stage of the flesh of the path, the stage of the straight, the stage of the trainee,🔽the stage of the ascetic, the stage of the victor, and the stage of the enlightened. From the day of their birth,

original: paṭṭhāya sattadivase sambādhaṭṭhānato nikkhantattā sattā mandā honti momūhā, ayaṃ🔽mandabhūmīti vadati. Ye pana duggatito āgatā honti, te abhiṇhaṃ rodanti ceva viravanti
analyzed: paṭṭhāya satta divase sambādha ṭṭhānataḥ nikkhanta ttā sattāḥ mandāḥ honti momūhāḥ ayam  manda bhūmiḥ iti vadati ye pana duggatitaḥ āgatāḥ honti te abhiṇham rodanti ca iva viravanti
translated: for seven days they are dull and stupid because they have come out from a confined place. This, he says,🔽is the stage of the dull. But those who have come from a bad destination cry and wail frequently,

original: ca, sugatito āgatā taṃ anussaritvā hasanti, ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma. Mātāpitūnaṃ hatthaṃ
analyzed: ca sugatitaḥ āgatā tam anussaritvā hasanti ayam khiḍḍābhūmi nāma mātā pitūnam hattham
translated: and those who have come from a good destination laugh, remembering that. This is called the stage of play. When they are able to walk,

original: vā pādaṃ vā mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ padanikkhipanaṃ padavīmaṃsabhūmi🔽nāma. Padasā gantuṃ samatthakāle ujugatabhūmi nāma. Sippāni sikkhitakāle sekkhabhūmi
analyzed: vā pādam vā mañcam vā pīṭham vā gahetvā bhūmiyam pada nikkhipanam padavī maṃsa bhūmi  nāma padasā gantum samattha kāle uju gata bhūmi nāma sippāni sikkhita kāle sekkha bhūmi
translated: or a bed or a chair, and putting down a foot on the ground, is called the stage of the foot-print.🔽When he is able to go on foot, it is called the stage of the straight path.🔽When he learns a craft, it is called the stage of the apprentice.🔽When he goes forth from home into homelessness, it is called the stage of the ascetic.

original: nāma. Gharā nikkhamma pabbajitakāle samaṇabhūmi nāma. Ācariyaṃ sevitvā jānanakāle
analyzed: nāma gharā nikkhamma pabbajita kāle samaṇa bhūmi nāma ācariyam sevitvā jānana kāle
translated: When he learns by attending on a teacher, it is called the stage of the victor.

original: jinabhūmi nāma. Bhikkhu ca pannako jino na kiñci āhāti evaṃ alābhiṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadati.
analyzed: jinabhūmi nāma bhikkhu ca pannakaḥ jinaḥ na kiñci āha ati evam alābhim samaṇam pannabhūmī iti vadati
translated: And when the monk is enlightened, the victor, and says, ‘I have no more craving for anything’, then he is called the ascetic who has reached the stage of the enlightened one.🔽Fifty-nine hundred schools of the Ājīvakas: fifty-nine hundred schools of the Ājīvakas’ way of life.

original: Ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti ekūnapaññāsaājīvakavuttisatāni. Paribbājakasateti paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni.🔽Nāgāvāsasateti nāgamaṇḍalasatāni. Vīse indriyasateti vīsatindriyasatāni. Tiṃse nirayasateti
analyzed: ekūnapaññāsaḥ ājīvaka satā iti ekūnapaññāsa ājīvaka vutti satāni paribbājaka satā iti paribbājaka pabbajjā satāni  nāga āvāsa satā iti nāga maṇḍala satāni vīse indriya satā iti vīsat indriya satāni tiṃse niraya satā iti
translated: A hundred schools of wanderers: a hundred schools of the wanderers’ way of life.🔽A hundred snake-inhabited places: a hundred snake-inhabited places.🔽A hundred and twenty faculties: a hundred and twenty faculties.🔽A hundred and thirty hells: a hundred and thirty hells.

original: tiṃsa nirayasatāni. Rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni, hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni
analyzed: tiṃsa niraya satāni hattha piṭṭhi pāda piṭṭha ādīni
translated: The dust element: the places for the scattering of dust, the backs of the hands, the backs of the feet, and so on.

original: sandhāya vadati. Satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya🔽vadati. Satta asaññīgabbhāti sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: sandhāya vadati satta sandhāya  vadati satta sāli vīhi yava godhūma kaṅgu varaka kudrūsake sandhāya vadati
translated: He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born from a womb, namely, the elephant, the ox, the horse, the mule, the ass, the human being, and the dog.🔽He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are not born from a womb, namely, the lizard, the snake, the crocodile, the cock, the fowl, the pigeon, and the sparrow.🔽He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born from eggs, namely, the hen, the bamboo-parrot, the mynah, the partridge, the tortoise, the crab, and the crocodile.

original: Nigaṇṭhigabbhāti gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati. Satta devāti
analyzed: nigaṇṭhi gabbhā ati gaṇṭhimhi jāta gabbhāḥ ucchu veḷu naḷa ādayaḥ sandhāya vadati satta deva iti
translated: He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born from moisture, namely, the ant, the bee, the mosquito, the louse, the flea, the fly, and the worm.🔽He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born by transformation, namely, the four-footed animals such as the cow, the buffalo, etc., the five-hooded serpents such as the cobra, etc., the trees such as the bamboo, the reed, etc., the creepers such as the pumpkin, the gourd, etc., the grass such as the sugar-cane, the turmeric, etc., the cotton plant, and the sesame plant.

original: bahū devā. So pana sattāti vadati. Manussāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati. Satta pisācāti🔽pisācā mahantamahantā sattāti vadati. Sarāti mahāsarā, kaṇṇamuṇḍarathakāraanotattasīhappapātachaddantamandākinīkuṇāladahe gahetvā vadati.
analyzed: bahū devā so pana sattā ati vadati manussā api anantā so sattā ati vadati satta pisācā ati  pisācā mahanta mahantā sattā ati vadati sarā ati mahāsarā kaṇṇa muṇḍa rathakāra anotatta sīhappapāta chaddanta mandākinī kuṇāla dahe gahetvā vadati
translated: He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born from a womb, namely, the elephant, the ox, the horse, the mule, the ass, the human being, and the dog.🔽He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are not born from a womb, namely, the lizard, the snake, the crocodile, the cock, the fowl, the pigeon, and the sparrow.🔽He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born from eggs, namely, the hen, the bamboo-parrot, the mynah, the partridge, the tortoise, the crab, and the crocodile.🔽He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born from moisture, namely, the ant, the bee, the mosquito, the louse, the flea, the fly, and the worm.

original: Pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā. Papātāti mahāpapātā. Papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni. Supināti🔽mahāsupinā. Supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: pavuṭā ati gaṇṭhikā papātā ati mahā papātā papāta satāni iti khuddaka papāta satāni supinā ati 🔽mahā supinā supina satāni iti khuddaka supina satāni mahākappino ti mahākappānam tattha
translated: He speaks with reference to the seven kinds of animals that are born by transformation, namely, the four-footed animals such as the cow, the buffalo, etc., the five-hooded serpents such as the cobra, etc., the trees such as the bamboo, the reed, etc., the creepers such as the pumpkin, the gourd, etc.,

original: ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ
analyzed: ekamhā mahā sarā vassa sate vassa sate kusaggena ekam udaka bindum nīharitvā satta kkhattum
translated: and after a hundred years had elapsed, a single drop of water was removed by the tip of a blade of grass,🔽and after the lake had been emptied in this way for seven times, one great aeon is said to have elapsed.

original: tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati. Evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni
analyzed: tamhi sare nirudake kate ekaḥ mahā kappaḥ iti vadati evarūpānam mahā kappānam catur asīti sata sahassāni
translated: After a hundred and eighty times as many great aeons as there are grains of sand in the Ganges,

original: khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi. Paṇḍitopi kira
analyzed: khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantam karonti iti ayam assa laddhi paṇḍitaḥ api kira
translated: the fool and the wise man make an end of suffering. The fool, it seems, is unable to attain purity in the interval;

original: antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti. Bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati.
analyzed: antarā visujjhitum na sakkoti bālaḥ api tatas uddham na gacchati
translated: the wise man does not go beyond that measure of time.

original: Sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci. Vatenāti tādiseneva vatena. Tapenāti
analyzed: sīlena ati acelaka sīlena vā aññena vā yena kenacid vatena ati tādisena iva vatena tapena ati
translated: By virtue: by the virtue of the naked ascetics or by some other kind of virtue. By austerity: by the austerity of the naked ascetics or by some other kind of austerity.

original: tapokammena. Aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo “ahaṃ paṇḍito”ti antarā visujjhati.
analyzed: tapo kammena a paripakkam paripāca iti nāma yaḥ aham paṇḍitaḥ iti antarā visujjhati
translated: He brings to maturity what is unmatured: he who, thinking “I am wise,” attains purity in the interval.

original: Paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo “ahaṃ bālo”ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ
analyzed: paripakkam phussa phussa byantim karoti nāma yaḥ aham bālaḥ ti vutta parimāṇam kālam
translated: He makes what is matured subside by degrees: he who, thinking “I am a fool,” goes beyond the measure of time stated and attains purity.

original: atikkamitvā yāti. Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi. Tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti.
analyzed: atikkamitvā yāti ha ivam natthi iti evam natthi tat hi ubhayam pi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti
translated: There is no such possibility: he shows that both are impossible.

original: Doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya. Sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ. Pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena🔽kālena katapariyante. Natthi hāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni. Na saṃsāro
analyzed: doṇa mitā iti doṇena mitam viya sukha dukkhā iti sukha dukkham vutta parimāṇena  kālena kata pariyante na atthi hāyana vaḍḍhanā iti na atthi hāyana vaḍḍhanāni na saṃsāro
translated: “Measured out by a doṇa” means as if measured out by a doṇa. “Pleasure and pain” means pleasure and pain. “With a limited life span” means with a life span that is limited by the time stated. “No increase or decrease” means no increase or decrease.

original: paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā.🔽Hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento “seyyathāpi nāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā
analyzed: paṇḍitassa hāyati na bālassa vaḍḍhati iti attho ukkaṃsa avakaṃsā iti ukkaṃsa avakaṃsā  adhivacanam  idāni tam attham upamāya sādhentaḥ seyyathā api nāma ati ādim āha tattha sutta guḷa iti veṭhetvā
translated: Doṇamite: measured by a doṇa. Sukhadukkhaṃ: pleasure and pain. Pariyantakate: limited by the time stated. Natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane: there is no increase or decrease. Na saṃsāro: the wise man’s does not decrease, the fool’s does not increase. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃse: the increase and decrease. This is a synonym for increase and decrease.

original: katasuttaguḷe. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ
analyzed: kata sutta guḷe nibbeṭhiyamānam eva paleti iti pabbate vā rukkha gge vā ṭhatvā khittam
translated: Now, in order to establish this meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as, bhikkhus, a dog tied up by a leash … ” Here, suttaguḷa means a ball of thread made by twisting together threads. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti: as it is being unrolled, it goes on. If it is thrown on a mountain or on a tree-top,

original: suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati.
analyzed: sutta ppamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānam eva gacchati sutte khīṇe tattha eva tiṭṭhati na gacchati
translated: it goes on being unrolled to the extent of the thread. When the thread is finished, it stops there itself; it does not go on.

original: Evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti.
analyzed: evam eva vutta kālataḥ uddham na gacchati iti dasseti
translated: In the same way, after the stated time, it does not go on. This is what is shown.

original: Ajitakesakambalavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ajita kesa kambala vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the doctrine of Ajita Kesakambala.

original: 170-172. Ajitavāde natthi dinnanti dinnaphalābhāvaṃ sandhāya vadati. Yiṭṭhaṃ vuccati🔽mahāyāgo. Hutanti paheṇakasakkāro adhippeto. Tampi ubhayaṃ phalābhāvameva sandhāya
analyzed: ajita vāde na atthi dinnan ti dinna phala abhāvam sandhāya vadati yiṭṭham vuccati  mahāyāgaḥ hutanti paheṇaka sakkāro adhippeto tat pi ubhayam phala abhāvam eva sandhāya
translated: In the Ajita doctrine he says that there is no giving, etc., referring to the non-existence of the fruit of giving. What is called “given” is

original: paṭikkhipati. Sukatadukkaṭānanti sukatadukkaṭānaṃ, kusalākusalānanti attho. Phalaṃ🔽vipākoti yaṃ phalanti vā vipākoti vā vuccati, taṃ natthīti vadati. Natthi ayaṃ lokoti🔽paraloke ṭhitassa ayaṃ loko natthi, natthi paro lokoti idha loke ṭhitassāpi paro🔽loko natthi, sabbe tattha tattheva ucchijjantīti dasseti. Natthi mātā natthi pitāti🔽tesu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalābhāvavasena vadati. Natthi sattā opapātikāti
analyzed: paṭikkhipati su kata dukkaṭānam ti su kata dukkaṭānam kusala akusalānam attho phalam  vipāko ti yam phalanti vā vipāko ti vā vuccati tam natthi iti vadati na atthi ayam loko ti  para loke ṭhitassa ayam loko natthi natthi paraḥ loko ti idha loke ṭhitassa api paraḥ  lokaḥ natthi sabbe tattha tattha iva ucchijjanti iti dasseti natthi mātā natthi pitā ati  tesu sammā paṭipattim icchā paṭipattīnam phala abhāva vasena vadati natthi sattā opapātikā ti
translated: a great sacrifice. “Offered” refers to the honouring of guests. He denies both of these, referring to the non-existence of their fruit. “Good and bad actions”: good and bad actions are wholesome and unwholesome actions. The fruit

original: cavitvā upapajjanakā sattā nāma natthīti vadati.
analyzed: cavitvā upapajjanakā sattā nāma natthi iti vadati
translated: of good and bad actions is called “ripening.” He says that there is no such thing. “There is no this world”: for one who is in the other world, this world does not exist. “There is no other world”: for one who is in this world, the other world does not exist. He shows that all beings are annihilated right there. “There is no mother, no father”: he says this referring to the non-existence of the fruit of right and wrong conduct towards them. “There are no beings who have arisen by spontaneous generation”: he says that there are no beings who die and are reborn.

original: Cātumahābhūtikoti catumahābhūtamayo. Pathavī pathavikāyanti ajjhattikapathavīdhātu🔽bāhirapathavīdhātuṃ. Anupetīti anuyāyati. Anupagacchatīti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Anugacchatītipi
analyzed: cātumahābhūtikā iti catu mahābhūta mayaḥ pathavī ajjhattika pathavī dhātu  bāhira pathavī dhātum anupeti iti anuyāyati anupagacchati iti tassa iva vevacanam anugacchati iti pi
translated: “Made up of the four great entities” means made up of the four great primaries. “The earth element in the earth body”

original: attho. Ubhayenāpi upeti, upagacchatīti dasseti. Āpādīsupi eseva nayo. Indriyānīti🔽manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti. Āsandipañcamāti nipannamañcena pañcamā,
analyzed: atthaḥ ubhayena api upeti upagacchati iti dasseti āpa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ indriyāni iti  indriyāni ākāsam pakkhandanti āsandi pañcamā ati nipanna mañcena pañcamā
translated: means the internal earth element. “Approaches” means follows. “Comes up to” is a synonym for that. The meaning is “goes along with.” He shows with both that it approaches, comes up to. The same method applies in the case of the other three great entities. “The faculties”🔽means the six faculties with the mind as sixth. “The space element” means the space element in the internal and external. “Penetrates” means enters. “The bed” means the five-part bed. “The five-part bed” means the bed with the fifth part, the lying-down man.

original: mañco ceva cattāro mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā cāti attho. Yāvāḷāhanāti🔽yāva susānā. Padānīti ‘ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā ahosi, evaṃ dussīlo’tiādinā nayena pavattāni🔽guṇāguṇapadāni, sarīrameva vā ettha padānīti adhippetaṃ. Kāpotakānīti kapotavaṇṇāni,
analyzed: mañcaḥ ca iva cattāraḥ mañca pāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā ca ati attho yāvāḷāhanā ati  yāva susānā padāni iti ayam evam sīlavā ahosi evam dussīlaḥ iti ādinā nayena pavattāni  guṇa aguṇa padāni sarīram eva vā ettha padāni iti adhippetam kāpotakāni iti kapota vaṇṇāni
translated: The meaning is: the bed and the four men standing holding the four legs of the bed. “As far as the charnel ground”🔽means as far as the cemetery. “The words” means the words about good qualities and bad qualities that occur in the way beginning, “He was virtuous like this, he was immoral like this,” or else the body itself is intended here by the words “the words.” “The crow-black” means the color of a crow,

original: pārāvatapakkhavaṇṇānīti attho. Bhassantāti bhasmantā, ayameva vā pāḷi. Āhutiyoti
analyzed: pārāvata pakkha vaṇṇāni iti atthaḥ bhassantā ati bhasmantā ayam eva vā pāḷi āhutiyā ti
translated: the meaning is the color of a dove’s neck. “The ashes” means the ashes. This is the reading of the text.

original: yaṃ paheṇakasakkārādibhedaṃ dinnadānaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ chārikāvasānameva hoti, na tato
analyzed: yam paheṇaka sakkāra ādi bhedam dinna dānam sabbam tam chārikā avasānam eva hoti na tatas
translated: Whatever gift is given in the form of a present, etc., all that is only a substitute for the leavings, not

original: paraṃ phaladāyakaṃ hutvā gacchatīti attho. Dattupaññattanti dattūhi bālamanussehi
analyzed: param phala dāyakam hutvā gacchati iti atthaḥ dattu paññattanti dattūhi bāla manussehi
translated: Whatever gift is given in the form of a present, a welcome present, and so on, all that is exhausted in the ashes. The meaning is that it does not go on to give fruit beyond that.

original: paññattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ‘bālehi abuddhīhi paññattamidaṃ dānaṃ, na paṇḍitehi.
analyzed: paññattam idam vuttam hoti bālehi abuddhīhi paññattam idam dānam na paṇḍitehi
translated: ‘Made by givers’: made by givers, by foolish people. This is what is said: ‘This giving is made by fools, not by the wise.

original: Bālā denti, paṇḍitā gaṇhantī’ti dasseti.🔽Tattha pūraṇo “karoto na karīyati pāpa”nti vadanto kammaṃ paṭibāhati. Ajito “kāyassa🔽bhedā ucchijjatī”ti vadanto vipākaṃ paṭibāhati. Makkhali “natthi hetū”ti vadanto
analyzed: bālāḥ denti paṇḍitāḥ gaṇhanti iti dasseti  tattha pūraṇaḥ na karīyati pāpanti vadantaḥ kammam paṭibāhati ajitaḥ kāyassa  bhedāḥ ucchijjati iti vadantaḥ vipākam paṭibāhati makkhali natthi hetu uti vadantaḥ
translated: Fools give, the wise receive.’

original: ubhayaṃ paṭibāhati. Tattha kammaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi vipāko paṭibāhito hoti, vipākaṃ
analyzed: ubhayam paṭibāhati tattha kammam paṭibāhantena api vipākaḥ paṭibāhitaḥ hoti vipākam
translated: Here, Pūraṇa Kassapa, by saying ‘The doer does not do the deed,’ denies kamma. Ajita Kesakambala, by saying ‘On the breakup of the body, the fool as well as the wise man is utterly annihilated,’ denies the result of kamma. Makkhali Gosāla, by saying ‘There is no cause or condition for the defilement of beings,’ denies both.

original: paṭibāhantenāpi kammaṃ paṭibāhitaṃ hoti. Iti sabbepete atthato ubhayappaṭibāhakā
analyzed: paṭibāhantena api kammam paṭibāhitam hoti iti sabbe pi ete atthataḥ ubhaya ppaṭibāhakā
translated: Here, by denying kamma, the result is also denied; by denying the result, kamma is also denied. Thus all of them, in fact, deny both.

original: ahetukavādā ceva akiriyavādā ca natthikavādā ca honti.
analyzed: ahetuka vādā ca iva akiriya vādā ca natthika vādā ca honti
translated: They are, therefore, advocates of no cause, of inaction, and of nihilism.

original: Ye vā pana tesaṃ laddhiṃ gahetvā rattiṭṭhāne divāṭhāne nisinnā sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti,
analyzed: ye vā pana tesam laddhim gahetvā ratti ṭṭhāne divāṭhāne nisinnā sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti
translated: Or else, taking up their doctrine, they sit down in their night quarters and day quarters and recite and review it,

original: tesaṃ “karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ, natthi hetu, natthi paccayo, mato ucchijjatī”ti
analyzed: tesam karotaḥ na karīyati pāpam natthi hetu natthi paccayaḥ mataḥ ucchijjati iti
translated: saying, “No evil is done by one who acts, there is no cause, no reason, when a being is destroyed he is destroyed without remainder” .

original: tasmiṃ ārammaṇe micchāsati santiṭṭhati, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, javanāni javanti, paṭhamajavane
analyzed: tasmin ārammaṇe micchā satī santiṭṭhati cittam ekaggam hoti javanāni javanti paṭhama javane
translated: In this object of perception wrong mindfulness persists, the mind becomes concentrated, impulsions impel.

original: satekicchā honti, tathā dutiyādīsu, sattame buddhānampi atekicchā anivattino ariṭṭhakaṇṭakasadisā.
analyzed: sa tekicchāḥ honti tathā dutiya ādīsu sattame buddhānam pi atekicchāḥ anivattinaḥ ariṭṭha kaṇṭaka sadisāḥ
translated: In the first impulsion they are curable, and so too in the second and the rest. But in the seventh they are incurable, irreversible, like the Ariṭṭhaka thorn and the Kaṇṭaka thorn.

original: Tattha koci ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamati, koci dve, koci tīṇipi, ekasmiṃ okkantepi, dvīsu
analyzed: tattha koci ekam dassanam okkamati koci dve koci tīṇi pi ekasmin okkante pi dvīsu
translated: Herein, some enter upon one seeing, some upon two, some upon three. Even when one has entered upon one,

original: tīsu okkantesupi, niyatamicchādiṭṭhikova hoti; patto saggamaggāvaraṇañceva mokkhamaggāvaraṇañca,
analyzed: tīsu okkantesu pi niyatam icchādiṭṭhikaḥ uva hoti patto sagga magga āvaraṇam ca iva mokkha magga āvaraṇam ca
translated: and two, and three, he is still one who has only wrong view fixed; he has reached the obstacle to the path to heaven and the obstacle to the path to liberation.

original: abhabbo tassattabhāvassa anantaraṃ saggampi gantuṃ, pageva mokkhaṃ. Vaṭṭakhāṇu nāmesa
analyzed: abhabbaḥ tad satta bhāvassa anantaram saggam pi gantum pagā iva mokkham vaṭṭakhāṇu nāma īsa
translated: He is incapable of going to heaven in his next existence, still less of attaining liberation. He is a “tree stump in the round,”

original: satto pathavigopako, yebhuyyena evarūpassa bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ natthi.
analyzed: sattaḥ pathavi gopakaḥ yebhuyyena evarūpassa bhavataḥ vuṭṭhānam natthi
translated: a “guardian of the earth,” and for the most part there is no escape for him from such an existence.

original: “Tasmā akalyāṇajanaṃ, āsīvisamivoragaṃ;
analyzed: tasmai akalyāṇa janam
translated: “Therefore, one who seeks his own good,🔽The wise one should avoid from afar

original: Ārakā parivajjeyya, bhūtikāmo vicakkhaṇo”ti.
analyzed: ārakā parivajjeyya bhūti kāmaḥ vicakkhaṇo ti
translated: The wicked person, like a poisonous snake.”

original: Pakudhakaccāyanavādavaṇṇanā🔽173-175. Pakudhavāde akaṭāti akatā. Akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānā. Evaṃ karohīti kenaci🔽kārāpitāpi na hontīti attho. Animmitāti iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti animmāpitā,🔽keci animmāpetabbāti padaṃ vadanti, taṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ, na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ dissati. Vañjhādipadattayaṃ🔽vuttatthameva. Na iñjantīti esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti. Na vipariṇamantīti
analyzed: evam karohi iti kenacid  kārāpitā api na honti iti atthaḥ a nimmitā ati iddhiyā api na nimmitā a nimmātā ati a nimmāpitā  keci a nimmāpetabbā ati padam vadanti tam na iva pāḷiyam na aṭṭhakathāyam dissati vañjhā ādi pada ttayam  vutta ttham eva na iñjanti iti esikatthambhaḥ viya ṭhita ttāḥ na calanti na vipariṇamanti iti
translated: The exposition of the view of Pakudha Kaccāyana

original: pakatiṃ na jahanti. Na aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti na aññamaññaṃ upahananti. Nālanti🔽na samatthā. Pathavikāyotiādīsu pathavīyeva pathavikāyo, pathavisamūho vā. Tatthāti
analyzed: pakatim na jahanti na aññam aññam byābādhenti iti na aññam aññam upahananti na alanti 🔽na samatthā pathavi kāyā ti ādīsu pathavīyā iva pathavi kāyo pathavi samūhaḥ vā tattha ati
translated: In the Pakudha doctrine, “unmade” means uncreated. “Not made by a maker” means not created by a creator. The meaning is that they are not made by anyone saying, “Do it like this.” “Unconstructed” means not constructed even by supernormal power. “Uncreated” means not created. Some say that the expression is “not to be created,” but that is not found in the text or in the commentaries. The meaning of the three terms beginning with “barren” is the same as that given above. “Do not move” means they do not move, do not waver, like a pillar. “Do not change” means they do not abandon their original nature. “Do not encroach upon each other” means they do not obstruct each other. “Do not overpower each other” means they are not able to. In the terms “earth-body,” etc., “earth” is the same as “earth-body,” or it is a collection of earth. “There” means

original: tesu jīvasattamesu kāyesu. Sattannaṃ tveva kāyānanti yathā muggarāsiādīsu pahataṃ
analyzed: tesu jīva sattamesu kāyesu sattannam tu eva kāyānanti yathā mugga rāsi ādīsu pahatam
translated: in the case of the seven kinds of living beings. In the case of the seven kinds of bodies:🔽

original: satthaṃ muggādīnaṃ antarena pavisati, evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena chiddena vivarena
analyzed: sattham mugga ādīnam antarena pavisati evam sattannam kāyānam antarena chiddena vivarena
translated: in the seven kinds of living beings’ bodies. In the seven kinds of bodies: just as a blow with a weapon enters in between the beans, etc.,

original: satthaṃ pavisati. Tattha ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemīti kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hotīti dasseti.
analyzed: sattham pavisati tattha aham imam jīvitā voropemi iti kevalam saññā mattam eva hoti iti dasseti
translated: so too the weapon enters in between the seven kinds of bodies by a hidden opening. There it is merely a concept, ‘I am depriving this of life,’ that is all.

original: Nigaṇṭhanāṭaputtavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nigaṇṭha nāṭa putta vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The doctrine of the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭa-putta

original: 176-178. Nāṭaputtavāde cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvutoti catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena saṃvuto.🔽Sabbavārivārito cāti vāritasabbaudako paṭikkhittasabbasītodakoti attho. So kira sītodake
analyzed: nāṭa putta vāde cātuyāma saṃvara saṃvuto ti catu koṭṭhāsena saṃvarena saṃvuto  sabba vāri vāritaḥ ca ati vārita sabba odako paṭikkhitta sabba sīta udakaḥ ti attho so kira sīta udake
translated: In the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭa-putta doctrine, “restrained by the fourfold restraint” : restrained by the restraint in the four-cornered .

original: sattasaññī hoti, tasmā na taṃ vaḷañjeti. Sabbavāriyuttoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena yutto.
analyzed: satta saññī hoti tasmā na tam vaḷañjeti sabba vāri yuttaḥ ti sabbena pāpa vāraṇena yuttaḥ
translated: “With all water barred” : with all water barred, all water prohibited, all water rejected, is the meaning. He, it seems, had the perception of water in the seven . Therefore he did not drink it. “With all water bound up” : bound up with all evil.

original: Sabbavāridhutoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena dhutapāpo. Sabbavāriphuṭoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena
analyzed: sabba vāri dhuto ti sabbena pāpa vāraṇena dhuta pāpaḥ sabba vāri phuṭaḥ iti sabbena pāpa vāraṇena
translated: “With all water shaken off” : shaken off with all evil. “With all water covered” : covered with all evil.

original: phuṭṭho. Gatattoti koṭippattacitto. Yatattoti saṃyatacitto. Ṭhitattoti suppatiṭṭhitacitto.
analyzed: phuṭṭhaḥ gatatto ti koṭippatta cittaḥ yatatto ti saṃyata cittaḥ ṭhitatto ti suppatiṭṭhita cittaḥ
translated: He is “touched” by the view. He has “gone to the end” in that his mind has reached the extreme. He is “gone to the state of rest” in that his mind is restrained. He is “stood in the state of rest” in that his mind is well established.

original: Etassa vāde kiñci sāsanānulomampi atthi, asuddhaladdhitāya pana sabbā diṭṭhiyeva jātā.
analyzed: etassa vāde kiñci sāsana anulomam pi atthi asuddha laddhitāya pana sabbā diṭṭhiyā iva jātā
translated: In this doctrine there is something that accords with the Dispensation, but because of his impure insight the whole thing has become a wrong view.

original: Sañcayabelaṭṭhaputtavādavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sañcaya belaṭṭha putta vāda vaṇṇanā
translated: The doctrine of Sañcaya and Belaṭṭhaputta

original: 179-181. Sañcayavādo amarāvikkhepe vuttanayo eva.
analyzed: sañcaya vādaḥ amarā vikkhepe vutta nayaḥ eva
translated: The doctrine of Sañcaya is the same as that of the Amarāvikkhepakas,

original: Paṭhamasandiṭṭhikasāmaññaphalavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama sandiṭṭhika sāmañña phala vaṇṇanā
translated: The first doctrine of the Sandiṭṭhikas

original: 182. Sohaṃ, bhanteti so ahaṃ bhante, vālukaṃ pīḷetvā telaṃ alabhamāno viya titthiyavādesu sāraṃ alabhanto bhagavantaṃ pucchāmīti attho.
analyzed: saḥ ham bhante iti saḥ aham bhante vālukam pīḍetvā telam alabhamānaḥ viya titthiya vādesu sāram alabhantaḥ bhagavantam pucchāmi iti attho
translated: “So I, venerable sir”: the meaning is: just as one who cannot get oil by pressing sand asks the Blessed One, not having found any essence in the doctrines of the sectarians.

original: 183. Yathā te khameyyāti yathā te rucceyya. Dāsoti antojātadhanakkītakaramarānītasāmaṃdāsabyopagatānaṃ🔽aññataro. Kammakāroti analaso kammakaraṇasīloyeva. Dūrato disvā paṭhamameva uṭṭhahatīti
analyzed: yathā te khameyya ati yathā te rucceyya dāsaḥ iti  aññataro kamma kāro ti analasaḥ kamma karaṇa sīlo yā iva dūratas disvā paṭhamam eva uṭṭhahati iti
translated: “As you may think fit”: as you may wish. A “slave” is one of those who have become slaves by the eight forms of slavery,🔽one of the eight kinds of slaves. A “workman” is one who is not lazy, who is of good character in doing his work. “Seeing them from afar, he rises first”:

original: pubbuṭṭhāyī. Evaṃ uṭṭhito sāmino āsanaṃ paññapetvā pādadhovanādikattabbakiccaṃ katvā
analyzed: pubbuṭṭhāyī evam uṭṭhitaḥ sāminaḥ āsanam paññapetvā pāda dhovana ādi kattabba kiccam katvā
translated: he is an “early riser” in that he rises before his master. Having risen, he prepares a seat for him, and having done whatever else needs to be done,

original: pacchā nipatati nisīdatīti pacchānipātī. Sāmikamhi vā sayanato avuṭṭhite pubbeyeva
analyzed: pacchā nipatati nisīdati iti pacchānipātī sāmikamhi vā sayanataḥ a vuṭṭhite pubbe yeva
translated: He lies down after his master, thus he is a “later-sleeper.” Or else he gets up before his master and🔽after lying down in the evening when his master has gone to bed, he gets up before his master in the morning.

original: vuṭṭhātīti pubbuṭṭhāyī. Paccūsakālato paṭṭhāya yāva sāmino rattiṃ niddokkamanaṃ,
analyzed: vuṭṭhāti iti pubbuṭṭhāyī paccūsa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva sāmino rattim niddokkamanam
translated: He lies down after his master, thus he is a “later-sleeper.” From the time of the first watch of the night until his master goes to bed,

original: tāva sabbakiccāni katvā pacchā nipatati, seyyaṃ kappetīti pacchānipātī. Kiṃ karomi,🔽kiṃ karomīti evaṃ kiṃkārameva paṭisuṇanto vicaratīti kiṃ kārapaṭissāvī. Manāpameva
analyzed: tāva sabba kiccāni katvā pacchā nipatati seyyam kappeti iti pacchānipātī kim karomi  kim karomi iti evam kiṃkāram eva paṭisuṇantaḥ vicarati iti kim kāra paṭissāvī manāpam eva
translated: he does all his duties and then lies down. He is a “later-sleeper.” He goes about saying “What shall I do?

original: kiriyaṃ karotīti manāpacārī. Piyameva vadatīti piyavādī. Sāmino tuṭṭhapahaṭṭhaṃ mukhaṃ🔽ullokayamāno vicaratīti mukhullokako.🔽Devo maññeti devo viya. So vatassāhaṃ puññāni kareyyanti so vata ahaṃ evarūpo assaṃ,
analyzed: kiriyam karoti iti manāpa cārī piyam eva vadati iti piya vādī sāmino tuṭṭha pahaṭṭham mukham  ullokayamānaḥ vicarati iti  devaḥ maññeti devaḥ viya saḥ vatassa aham puññāni kareyyanti saḥ vata aham evarūpaḥ assam
translated: What shall I do?” thus he is a “questioner.” He does only what is pleasing, thus he is a “pleaser.” He speaks only what is pleasing, thus he is a “pleasing-speaker.” He goes about looking at his master’s face to see if he is pleased, thus he is a “face-watcher.”

original: yadi puññāni kareyyanti attho. “So vatassa’ssa”ntipi pāṭho, ayamevattho. Yaṃnūnāhanti
analyzed: yadi puññāni kareyyanti saḥ pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ yaṃ nūna ahanti
translated: He thinks “I am like a god,” “I would perform the meritorious deeds if I were such a one,” is the meaning. The reading “so vatassāhaṃ” is also allowable, having the same meaning. “If only I were” :

original: sace dānaṃ dassāmi, yaṃ rājā ekadivasaṃ deti, tato satabhāgampi yāvajīvaṃ na sakkhissāmi
analyzed: sace dānam dassāmi yam rājā eka divasam deti tatas sata bhāgam pi yāvajīvam na sakkhissāmi
translated: If I give gifts, I shall not be able to give even a hundredth part of what the king gives in one day for the rest of my life.

original: dātunti pabbajjāyaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā evaṃ cintanabhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: dātunti ussāham katvā evam cintana bhāvam dasseti
translated: Thus he shows his state of mind in which he has made up his mind to go forth.

original: Kāyena saṃvutoti kāyena pihito hutvā akusalassa pavesanadvāraṃ thaketvāti attho.
analyzed: kāyena saṃvutaḥ ti kāyena pihitaḥ hutvā akusalassa pavesana dvāram thaketvā ati attho
translated: “Restrained in body”: having covered up the body, having closed the door to the entry of the unwholesome.

original: Eseva nayo sesapadadvayepi. Ghāsacchādanaparamatāyāti ghāsacchādanena paramatāya
analyzed: nayo ghāsa chādana parama tāya ati ghāsa chādanena parama tāya
translated: The same method applies to the other two clauses. “With the attainment of mere food and clothing”: with the attainment of mere food and clothing as the highest,

original: uttamatāya, etadatthampi anesanaṃ pahāya aggasallekhena santuṭṭhoti attho. Abhirato
analyzed: uttamatāya etad attham pi anesanam pahāya agga sallekhena santuṭṭhaḥ ti atthaḥ abhirataḥ
translated: as the best. The meaning is: having abandoned the search for more than that, he is satisfied with the foremost selection, and he delights in solitude.

original: paviveketi “kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ, cittaviveko ca nekkhammābhiratānaṃ,
analyzed: kāya viveko ca viveka ṭṭhakāyānam citta viveko ca nekkhamma abhiratānam
translated: “Delighting in the destruction of craving”: delighting in the three kinds of destruction of craving stated thus: “The destruction of craving is for those whose bodies are secluded, the destruction of the defilements of the mind is for those who delight in renunciation,

original: paramavodānappattānaṃ upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ visaṅkhāragatāna”nti
analyzed: parama vodāna pattānam upadhi viveko ca nirupadhīnam puggalānam visaṅkhāra gatānam ti
translated: and the destruction of the substrata is for those who have attained the supreme freedom from bondage” .

original: evaṃ vutte tividhepi viveke rato; gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya kāyena eko viharati, cittakilesasaṅgaṇikaṃ
analyzed: evam vutte tividhe api viveke rataḥ gaṇa saṅgaṇikam pahāya kāyena ekaḥ viharati citta kilesa saṅgaṇikam
translated: Thus he delights in the three kinds of destruction of craving. Having abandoned the company of crowds, he dwells alone in body. Having abandoned the company of the defilements of the mind,

original: pahāya aṭṭhasamāpattivasena eko viharati, phalasamāpattiṃ vā nirodhasamāpattiṃ vā
analyzed: pahāya aṭṭha samāpatti vasena ekaḥ viharati phala samāpattim vā nirodha samāpattim vā
translated: he lives alone, having given up the eight worldly conditions, by means of the eight attainments or by means of the attainment of the fruit or by means of the attainment of cessation,

original: pavisitvā nibbānaṃ patvā viharatīti attho. Yaggheti codanatthe nipāto.
analyzed: pavisitvā nibbānam patvā viharati iti atthaḥ yaggha iti codana atthe nipātaḥ
translated: He lives alone after abandoning the eight worldly conditions, or he lives after entering upon the fruition attainment or the attainment of cessation or after attaining Nibbāna.🔽The word “even” is in the sense of a challenge.

original: 184. Āsanenapi nimanteyyāmāti nisinnāsanaṃ papphoṭetvā idha nisīdathāti vadeyyāma.
analyzed: āsanena api nimanteyyāma ati nisinnāsanam papphoṭetvā idha nisīdatha iti vadeyyāma
translated: We would invite him to a seat: we would invite him to sit down by saying, “Sit here.”🔽We would invite him even to come: we would invite him by going to meet him.

original: Abhinimanteyyāmapi nanti abhiharitvāpi naṃ nimanteyyāma. Tattha duvidho abhihāro🔽– vācāya ceva kāyena ca. Tumhākaṃ icchiticchitakkhaṇe amhākaṃ cīvarādīhi vadeyyātha
analyzed: abhinimanteyyāma api nanti abhiharitvā api nam nimanteyyāma tattha duvidhaḥ abhihāro  vācāya ca iva kāyena ca tumhākam icchiticchita kkhaṇe amhākam cīvara ādīhi vadeyyātha
translated: Here, there are two kinds of invitation:🔽by speech and by body. If he says, “Whenever you want robes, alms food, a dwelling, and medicines for the sick, tell me, and do not be scrupulous,”

original: yenatthoti vadanto hi vācāya abhiharitvā nimanteti nāma. Cīvarādivekallaṃ sallakkhetvā
analyzed: yena attha uti vadantaḥ hi vācāya abhiharitvā nimantā iti nāma cīvara ādi vekallam sallakkhetvā
translated: he invites by speech. But if he sees that they are short of robes, etc.,🔽and gives them, he invites by body.

original: idaṃ gaṇhāthāti tāni dento pana kāyena abhiharitvā nimanteti nāma. Tadubhayampi sandhāya
analyzed: idam gaṇhātha ati tāni kāyena abhiharitvā nimantā iti nāma tat ubhayam pi sandhāya
translated: The Blessed One said “We would invite him even to come” referring to both these kinds of invitation.

original: abhinimanteyyāmapi nanti āha. Ettha ca gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāroti yaṃ kiñci
