analyzed: oratas majjhe pacchimāya disāya thūṇam nāma brāhmaṇa gāmo tatas parā paccantimāḥ janapadā  oratas majjhe uttarāya disāya usiraddhajaḥ nāma pabbato tatas parā paccantimāḥ janapadāḥ
translated: To the east of this central point is the brāhmaṇa village of Thūṇa, beyond which is the frontier region.🔽To the north of this central point is the mountain of Usiraddhaja, beyond which is the frontier region.

original: orato majjhe”ti evaṃ paricchinne āyāmato tiyojanasate, vitthārato aḍḍhateyyayojanasate,🔽parikkhepato navayojanasate majjhimapadese uppajjati. Na kevalañca tathāgato, paccekabuddhā,
analyzed: oratas majjhā iti evam paricchinne āyāmataḥ ti yojana sate vitthārataḥ aḍḍhateyya yojana sate  parikkhepataḥ nava yojana sate majjhima padese uppajjati na kevalañca tathāgataḥ paccekabuddhā
translated: Within this central region, which is three hundred leagues in length and two hundred and fifty leagues in breadth, and which is surrounded by the frontier regions, the Buddha arises.🔽Not only the Buddha, but also Paccekabuddhas,

original: aggasāvakā, asītimahātherā, buddhamātā, buddhapitā, cakkavattī rājā aññe ca sārappattā
analyzed: agga sāvakāḥ asīti mahā therāḥ buddha mātā buddha pitā cakkavattī rājā aññe ca sāra ppattā
translated: Great Disciples, eighty great elders, the Buddha’s mother, the Buddha’s father, a wheel-turning monarch, and other great beings who have attained the essence

original: brāhmaṇagahapatikā etthevuppajjanti.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa gahapatikāḥ ettha iva uppajjanti
translated: are born in the central region.

original: Tattha tathāgato sujātāya dinnamadhupāyāsabhojanato yāva arahattamaggo, tāva uppajjati
analyzed: tattha tathāgataḥ sujātāya dinna madhupa āyāsa bhojanataḥ yāva arahatta maggo tāva uppajjati
translated: There the Buddha arises from the time of his birth to the time of his attainment of the path of arahatship, having partaken of the milk-rice offered by Sujātā.

original: nāma, arahattaphale uppanno nāma. Mahābhinikkhamanato vā yāva arahattamaggo. Tusitabhavanato
analyzed: nāma arahatta phale uppannaḥ nāma mahā abhinikkhamanataḥ vā yāva arahatta maggo tusita bhavanato
translated: He is said to have arisen at the time of the attainment of the fruit of arahatship. Or he is said to have arisen from the time of his Great Departure to the time of his attainment of the path of arahatship.🔽From the time of his descent from the Tusita heaven

original: vā yāva arahattamaggo. Dīpaṅkarapādamūlato vā yāva arahattamaggo, tāva uppajjati
analyzed: vā yāva arahatta maggo dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ vā yāva arahatta maggo tāva uppajjati
translated: or from the time of the path of arahatship. Or from the time of the Blessed One’s going forth, or from the time of his attaining omniscience, or from the time of his setting the Wheel of the Dhamma rolling, or from the time of his attaining the supreme perfect enlightenment, or from the time of his arousing the first aspiration for enlightenment, or from the time of his planting the various roots of kusala, or from the time of his paying homage at the feet of Dīpaṅkara Buddha, or from the time of his path of arahatship, he has been arisen.

original: nāma, arahattaphale uppanno nāma. Idha sabbapaṭhamaṃ uppannabhāvaṃ sandhāya uppajjatīti
analyzed: nāma arahatta phale uppannaḥ nāma idha sabba paṭhamam uppanna bhāvam sandhāya uppajjati iti
translated: He is arisen in the attainment of the fruit of arahatship. Here the meaning intended is the state of being arisen first of all.

original: vuttaṃ. Tathāgato loke uppanno hotīti ayañhettha attho.🔽So imaṃ lokanti so bhagavā imaṃ lokaṃ. Idāni vattabbaṃ nidasseti. Sadevakanti saha
analyzed: vuttam tathāgataḥ loke uppannaḥ hoti iti ayam ha ittha atthaḥ  saḥ imam lokam ti saḥ bhagavā imam lokam idāni vattabbam nidasseti sa devakam ti saha
translated: The meaning here is: ‘The Tathāgata has appeared in the world.’

original: devehi sadevakaṃ. Evaṃ saha mārena samārakaṃ, saha brahmunā sabrahmakaṃ, saha samaṇabrāhmaṇehi
analyzed: devehi sa devakam evam saha mārena sa mārakam saha brahmunā sa brahmakam saha samaṇa brāhmaṇehi
translated: He, the Blessed One, has appeared in this world. Now he shows what is to be said. With the gods: together with the gods, he has appeared in the world with the gods. Thus with Māra, he has appeared in the world with Māra. With Brahmā, he has appeared in the world with Brahmā. With ascetics and brahmins, he has appeared in the world with ascetics and brahmins.

original: sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ. Pajātattā pajā, taṃ pajaṃ. Saha devamanussehi sadevamanussaṃ.
analyzed: sa ssamaṇabrāhmaṇim pajātattā pajā tam pajam saha deva manussehi sa deva manussam
translated: Because of being born, there is a people. He has appeared in the world with that people. With the divine and human beings, he has appeared in the world with the divine and human beings.

original: Tattha sadevakavacanena pañca kāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Samāraka – vacanena
analyzed: tattha sa devaka vacanena pañca kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam veditabbam sa māraka vacanena
translated: Herein, by the words ‘with the gods’ the five classes of gods of the sense-sphere should be understood. By the words ‘with Māra’

original: chaṭṭhakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ. Sabrahmakavacanena brahmakāyikādibrahmaggahaṇaṃ. Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇīvacanena
analyzed: chaṭṭha kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam sa brahmaka vacanena brahmakāyika ādi brahma ggahaṇam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇī vacanena
translated: the six classes of sense-sphere gods are included. By the words ‘with Brahmā’ the Brahmā-world and so on are included. By the words ‘with ascetics and brahmins’

original: sāsanassa paccatthikapaccāmittasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇaṃ, samitapāpabāhitapāpasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇañca.
analyzed: sāsanassa paccatthika pacca amitta samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam samita pāpa bāhita pāpa samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam ca
translated: and the inclusion of ascetics and brahmans who are enemies and adversaries of the Dispensation, and of those who are quiet and those who have expelled evil.

original: Pajāvacanena sattalokaggahaṇaṃ. Sadevamanussavacanena sammutidevaavasesamanussaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pajā vacanena satta loka ggahaṇam sa deva manussa vacanena sammuti deva avasesa manussa ggahaṇam
translated: The word “world” includes the world of beings. The words “with its gods” include the world of men and the world of gods by convention.

original: Evamettha tīhi padehi okāsalokena saddhiṃ sattaloko. Dvīhi pajāvasena sattalokova gahitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha tīhi padehi okāsa lokena saddhim satta lokaḥ dvīhi pajā vasena satta lokaḥ uva gahitaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: So here the world of beings should be understood to be included with the world of location by means of the first three terms, and by means of the word “world” the world of beings alone is included.

original: Aparo nayo, sadevakaggahaṇena arūpāvacaradevaloko gahito. Samārakaggahaṇena cha kāmāvacaradevaloko.🔽Sabrahmakaggahaṇena rūpī brahmaloko. Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇādiggahaṇena catuparisavasena
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ sa devaka ggahaṇena arūpāvacara deva lokaḥ gahitaḥ sa māraka ggahaṇena cha kāmāvacara deva lokaḥ  sa brahmaka ggahaṇena rūpī brahma lokaḥ sa samaṇa brāhmaṇa ādi ggahaṇena catu parisa vasena
translated: Another method: the inclusion of “with its gods” includes the immaterial world of deities. The inclusion of “with Māra” includes the six worlds of sense-sphere deities.🔽The inclusion of “with Brahmā” includes the fine-material world of Brahmās. The inclusion of “with ascetics and brahmans” includes the world of men together with the four assemblies,

original: sammutidevehi vā saha manussaloko, avasesasabbasattaloko vā.
analyzed: sammuti devehi vā saha manussa lokaḥ avasesa sabba satta lokaḥ vā
translated: or else it includes the world of all beings together with the gods by convention.

original: Api cettha sadevakavacanena ukkaṭṭhaparicchedato sabbassa lokassa sacchikatabhāvamāha.
analyzed: api ca ittha sa devaka vacanena ukkaṭṭha paricchedataḥ sabbassa lokassa sacchikata bhāvam āha
translated: And here the word “with its gods” states that the whole world has been penetrated to the limit of its extent.

original: Tato yesaṃ ahosi – “māro mahānubhāvo cha kāmāvacarissaro vasavattī, kiṃ sopi etena
analyzed: tatas yesam ahosi māraḥ mahā anubhāvo vasa vattī kim saḥ api etena
translated: Then those who had thought, “Māra is of great power, the lord of the sensual-desire realm, the wielder of power. Can he too be subject to this bhikkhu?”

original: sacchikato”ti, tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamanto “samāraka”nti āha. Yesaṃ pana ahosi – “brahmā🔽mahānubhāvo ekaṅguliyā ekasmiṃ cakkavāḷasahasse ālokaṃ pharati, dvīhi …pe… dasahi
analyzed: sacchikato ti tesam vimatim vidhamanto āha yesam pana ahosi brahmā  mahā anubhāvaḥ ekaṅguliyā ekasmin cakkavāḷa sahasse ālokam pharati dvīhi pe dasahi
translated: Then, in order to dispel the doubt of those who thought, “Māra is powerful. He is the lord of the six sense-sphere divine worlds. Does he too have to be realized by this bhikkhu?” he said “with Māra and with Brahmā.”

original: aṅgulīhi dasasu cakkavāḷasahassesu ālokaṃ pharati. Anuttarañca jhānasamāpattisukhaṃ
analyzed: aṅgulīhi dasasu cakkavāḷa sahassesu ālokam pharati anuttaram ca jhāna samāpatti sukham
translated: But those who thought, “Brahmā is powerful. With one finger he can illuminate a world system of a thousand worlds. With two fingers he can illuminate two thousand worlds. With three fingers he can illuminate three thousand worlds. With all ten fingers he can illuminate ten thousand worlds. He experiences the bliss of the unsurpassed jhānas and samāpattis. Does he too have to be realized by this bhikkhu?”

original: paṭisaṃvedeti, kiṃ sopi sacchikato”ti, tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamanto sabrahmakanti āha.
analyzed: paṭisaṃveda iti kim saḥ api āha
translated: In order to dispel their doubt, he said “with Brahmā.”

original: Tato ye cintesuṃ – “puthū samaṇabrāhmaṇā sāsanassa paccatthikā, kiṃ tepi sacchikatā”ti,
analyzed: tatas ye cintesuṃ puthū samaṇa brāhmaṇā sāsanassa paccatthikā kim te pi sacchikatā ati
translated: Then, in order to dispel the doubt of those who thought, “There are many ascetics and brahmins who are enemies of the Dispensation. Are they too realized by this bhikkhu?”

original: tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamanto sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajanti āha. Evaṃ ukkaṭṭhukkaṭṭhānaṃ🔽sacchikatabhāvaṃ pakāsetvā atha sammutideve avasesamanusse ca upādāya ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena
analyzed: tesam vimatim vidhamantaḥ sa samaṇa brāhmaṇim pajanti āha evam ukkaṭṭhukkaṭṭhānam 🔽sacchikata bhāvam pakāsetvā atha sammuti deve avasesa manusse ca upādāya ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena
translated: he said “with the world of ascetics and brahmins.” Thus he revealed the realization of the most outstanding of the outstanding.🔽Then, beginning with the gods of the sense-sphere heaven and including the rest of mankind, he said “with the world of men,” referring to the most outstanding of the rest.

original: sesasattalokassa sacchikatabhāvaṃ pakāsento sadevamanussanti āha. Ayamettha bhāvānukkamo.
analyzed: sesa satta lokassa sacchikata bhāvam pakāsento sa deva manussam ti āha ayam ettha bhāva anukkamaḥ
translated: He said “with its gods and men” showing that he had penetrated the rest of the world of beings. This is the order of the terms in the clause.

original: Porāṇā panāhu sadevakanti devehi saddhiṃ avasesalokaṃ. Samārakanti mārena saddhiṃ🔽avasesalokaṃ. Sabrahmakanti brahmehi saddhiṃ avasesalokaṃ. Evaṃ sabbepi tibhavūpage🔽satte tīhākārehi tīsu padesu pakkhipitvā puna dvīhi padehi pariyādiyanto sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ
analyzed: porāṇā pana āhu sa devakanti devehi saddhim avasesa lokam sa mārakanti mārena saddhim  avasesa lokam sabrahmakam ti brahmehi saddhim avasesa lokam evam sabbe pi ti bhava upage  satte tīhi ākārehi tīsu padesu pakkhipitvā puna dvīhi padehi
translated: But the Ancients said: “With its gods” means with the rest of the world that is, with the gods. “With its Māra” means with the rest of the world that is, with Māra.

original: pajaṃ sadevamanussanti āha. Evaṃ pañcahipi padehi tena tenākārena tedhātukameva pariyādinnanti.🔽Sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedetīti ettha pana sayanti sāmaṃ aparaneyyo hutvā. Abhiññāti🔽abhiññāya, adhikena ñāṇena ñatvāti attho. Sacchikatvāti paccakkhaṃ katvā, etena anumānādipaṭikkhepo
analyzed: pajam sa deva manussanti āha evam pañcahi pi padehi tena tena ākārena te dhātukam eva  sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti iti ettha pana sayanti sāmam aparaneyyaḥ hutvā abhiññāti  abhiññāya adhikena ñāṇena ñatvā ati attho sacchikatvā iti paccakkham katvā etena anumāna ādi paṭikkhepo
translated: “With its Brahmā” means with the rest of the world that is, with Brahmā. So he included all beings in the three worlds in these three terms. Then he said “with its contemplatives and brahmans” and “with gods and men” to show that he had penetrated the rest of the world in two terms. So he penetrated the three worlds in all five terms in these ways.

original: kato hoti. Pavedetīti bodheti viññāpeti pakāseti.
analyzed: kataḥ hoti pavedeti iti bodheti viññāpeti pakāseti
translated: As to “having directly known, having realized, he teaches the Dhamma”: here, “having directly known” means having directly known by himself, having made himself the owner of it. “Having realized” means having realized by himself, having made himself the owner of it. “Having directly known, having realized” means having directly known and having realized by himself, having made himself the owner of it. “He teaches the Dhamma” means he teaches, he makes known, he reveals the Dhamma.

original: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ…pe… pariyosānakalyāṇanti so bhagavā sattesu kāruññataṃ
analyzed: saḥ dhammam deseti ādi kalyāṇam pe pariyosāna kalyāṇam ti so bhagavā sattesu kāruññatam
translated: He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.🔽The Blessed One teaches the Dhamma out of compassion for beings, having given up the unsurpassed bliss of seclusion.

original: paṭicca hitvāpi anuttaraṃ vivekasukhaṃ dhammaṃ deseti. Tañca kho appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā🔽desento ādikalyāṇādippakārameva deseti. Ādimhipi, kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva
analyzed: paṭicca hitvā api anuttaram viveka sukham dhammam deseti tat ca kho appam vā bahum vā  desentaḥ ādi kalyāṇa ādi ppakāram eva deseti ādimhi pi kalyāṇam bhaddakam anavajjam eva
translated: And whether he teaches much or little,

original: katvā deseti, majjhepi, pariyosānepi, kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā desetīti
analyzed: katvā deseti majjhe pi pariyosāne pi kalyāṇam bhaddakam anavajjam eva katvā deseti iti
translated: he teaches only what is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.🔽For he teaches, making the Dhamma good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and revealing a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha atthi desanāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ, atthi sāsanassa. Desanāya
analyzed: vuttam hoti tattha atthi desanāya ādi majjha pariyosānam atthi sāsanassa desanāya
translated: Herein, there is a beginning, middle, and end of a teaching, and there is a beginning, middle, and end of the Dispensation.

original: tāva catuppadikāyapi gāthāya paṭhamapādo ādi nāma, tato dve majjhaṃ nāma, ante eko
analyzed: tāva gāthāya paṭhama pādaḥ ādi nāma tatas dve majjham nāma ante ekaḥ
translated: As regards a teaching, the first quarter of a stanza is called the beginning, the two quarters are the middle, and the last quarter is the end.

original: pariyosānaṃ nāma. Ekānusandhikassa suttassa nidānaṃ ādi, idamavocāti pariyosānaṃ,
analyzed: pariyosānam nāma eka anusandhikassa suttassa nidānam ādi idam avoca ati pariyosānam
translated: In a sutta with a single sequence of meaning, the introduction is the beginning, the words “Thus spoke the Exalted One” are the end,🔽and what is in between is the middle. In a sutta with many sequences of meaning, the first sequence of meaning is the beginning,

original: ubhinnamantarā majjhaṃ. Anekānusandhikassa suttassa paṭhamānusandhi ādi, ante anusandhi
analyzed: ubhinnam antarā majjham aneka anusandhikassa suttassa paṭhama anusandhi ādi ante anusandhi
translated: the last sequence of meaning is the end,

original: pariyosānaṃ, majjhe eko vā dve vā bahū vā majjhameva.
analyzed: pariyosānam majjhe ekaḥ vā dve vā bahū vā majjham eva
translated: and the end is either one or two or many in the middle.

original: Sāsanassa pana sīlasamādhivipassanā ādi nāma. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “ko cādi kusalānaṃ
analyzed: sāsanassa pana sīla samādhi vipassanā ādi nāma vuttam pi ca itaṃ
translated: But the beginning of the Dispensation is virtue, concentration, and understanding. And this is said: “What is the beginning of profitable things?

original: dhammānaṃ? Sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ diṭṭhi ca ujukā”ti. “Atthi, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā🔽tathāgatena abhisambuddhā”ti evaṃ vutto pana ariyamaggo majjhaṃ nāma. Phalañceva🔽nibbānañca pariyosānaṃ nāma. “Etadatthamidaṃ, brāhmaṇa, brahmacariyaṃ, etaṃ sāraṃ,🔽etaṃ pariyosāna”nti hi ettha phalaṃ pariyosānanti vuttaṃ. “Nibbānogadhaṃ hi, āvuso🔽visākha, brahmacariyaṃ vussati, nibbānaparāyanaṃ nibbānapariyosāna”nti ettha nibbānaṃ
analyzed: dhammānam sīlam ca su visuddham diṭṭhi ca ujukā ati atthi bhikkhave majjhimā paṭipadā  tathāgatena abhisambuddhā ati evam vuttaḥ pana ariya maggo majjham nāma phalam ca iva  nibbānam ca pariyosānam nāma etad attham idam brāhmaṇa brahmacariyam etam sāram  etam pariyosānam ti hi ettha phalam pariyosānam ti vuttam nibbāna ogadham hi āvuso  visākha brahmacariyam vussati nibbāna parāyanam nibbāna pariyosānam ti ettha nibbānam
translated: Virtue well purified and right view” . And the middle is the Noble Eightfold Path, which is called “the middle practice” in the passage: “Bhikkhus, there is a middle practice

original: pariyosānanti vuttaṃ. Idha desanāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ adhippetaṃ. Bhagavā hi dhammaṃ
analyzed: pariyosānam ti vuttam idha desanāya ādi majjha pariyosānam adhippetam bhagavā hi dhammam
translated: awakened to by the Tathāgata” . And the end is fruition and Nibbāna. For in the passage: “Brāhmaṇa, this is the purpose, this is the goal, this is the fruit, this is the outcome of leading the holy life” , fruition is called the end. And in the passage: “Friend Visākha, the holy life has Nibbāna as its culmination, Nibbāna as its goal, Nibbāna as its destination” , Nibbāna is called the end. translated: still, because of their possessions and impediments, their house life is crowded and dusty.🔽The path is rough: it is said in the Mahā-Aṭṭhakathā that it is the place of origin of the dust of passion, etc.

original: rāgarajādīnaṃ uṭṭhānaṭṭhānanti mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Āgamanapathotipi vadanti.
analyzed: rāgaraja ādīnam uṭṭhāna ṭṭhānanti mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttam āgamana pathaḥ ti pi vadanti
translated: Others say it is the path of coming and going.

original: Alagganaṭṭhena abbhokāso viyāti abbhokāso. Pabbajito hi kūṭāgāraratanapāsādadevavimānādīsu
analyzed: a laggana ṭṭhena abbhokāsaḥ viyāti abbhokāsaḥ pabbajitaḥ hi kūṭāgāra ratana pāsāda deva vimāna ādīsu
translated: “Open-air” in the sense of being unconfined is open-air.

original: pihitadvāravātapānesu paṭicchannesu vasantopi neva laggati, na sajjati, na bajjhati.
analyzed: pihita dvāra vāta pānesu paṭicchannesu vasantaḥ api na iva laggati na sajjati na bajjhati
translated: For one gone forth does not stick, does not adhere, does not get tied up, even when dwelling in a peaked-roofed dwelling, a choice mansion, a divine palace, etc., with doors and windows closed.🔽Hence it was said above: “Open-air is the going forth.”

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “abbhokāso pabbajjā”ti. Api ca sambādho gharāvāso kusalakiriyāya okāsābhāvato.
analyzed: tena vuttam abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā ti api ca sambādhaḥ ghara āvāsaḥ kusala kiriyāya okāsa abhāvato
translated: Moreover, the life of a house- dweller is confined because there is no opportunity for making merit.

original: Rajopatho asaṃvutasaṅkāraṭṭhānaṃ viya rajānaṃ kilesarajānaṃ sannipātaṭṭhānato. Abbhokāso
analyzed: rajopathaḥ asaṃvuta saṅkāra ṭṭhānam viya rajānam kilesa rajānam sannipāta ṭṭhānataḥ abbhokāsaḥ
translated: It is a dust-heap because it is a place for the gathering of the dust of defilements, like a dust-heap that is a place for the gathering of dust.

original: pabbajjā kusalakiriyāya yathāsukhaṃ okāsasabbhāvato.
analyzed: pabbajjā kusala kiriyāya yathāsukham okāsa sabbhāvato
translated: The going forth is open-air because it is a place for the opportunity of making merit as one wishes.

original: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ…pe… pabbajeyyanti etthāyaṃ saṅkhepakathā, yadetaṃ sikkhattayabrahmacariyaṃ🔽ekampi divasaṃ akhaṇḍaṃ katvā carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ, caritabbaṃ
analyzed: na yidam sukaraṃpe pabbajeyyanti ettha ayam saṅkhepa kathā yat etam sikkhattaya brahmacariyam  ekam pi divasam akhaṇḍam katvā carimaka cittam pāpetabba tāya ekanta paripuṇṇam caritabbam
translated: “It is not easy, friend, while living in a home to lead the holy life utterly perfect and pure as a polished shell” : here is a brief treatment of this.🔽The life of one who goes forth is to be lived by making the life of purity perfect and complete in every way by carrying it out without break even for a day.

original: ekadivasampi ca kilesamalena amalīnaṃ katvā carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparisuddhaṃ.
analyzed: eka divasam pi ca kilesa malena a malīnam katvā carimaka cittam pāpetabba tāya ekanta parisuddham
translated: And it is to be lived by making it pure in every way by carrying it out without sullying it with defilements even for a moment.

original: Saṅkhalikhitanti likhitasaṅkhasadisaṃ dhotasaṅkhasappaṭibhāgaṃ caritabbaṃ. Idaṃ na🔽sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā agāramajjhe vasantena ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ…pe… carituṃ, yaṃnūnāhaṃ🔽kese ca massuñca ohāretvā kasāyarasapītatāya kāsāyāni brahmacariyaṃ carantānaṃ anucchavikāni
analyzed: saṅkha likhitam ti likhita saṅkha sadisam dhota saṅkha sappaṭibhāgam caritabbam idam na  sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā agāra majjhe vasantena caritum  kese ca massuñca ohāretvā kasāya rasa pīta tāya kāsāyāni brahmacariyam anucchavikāni
translated: He should live like a written shell, like a polished shell, like a cut-off shell. This is not easy for one who lives in a house, who dwells in the midst of a house, to do completely, in every way, and in all respects. Suppose I shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness?

original: vatthāni acchādetvā paridahitvā agārasmā nikkhamitvā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyanti. Ettha🔽ca yasmā agārassa hitaṃ kasivāṇijjādikammaṃ agāriyanti vuccati, tañca pabbajjāya
analyzed: vatthāni a chādetvā paridahitvā agārasmā nikkhamitvā anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti ettha  ca yasmai agārassa hitam kasi vāṇijja ādi kammaṃ agāriyanti vuccati tat ca pabbajjāya
translated: Herein, since the pursuit of the means of livelihood by agriculture, trade, etc., which is beneficial to a house is called ‘house’, and since that is not found in one gone forth,

original: natthi, tasmā pabbajjā anagāriyanti ñātabbā, taṃ anagāriyaṃ. Pabbajeyyanti paṭipajjeyyaṃ.🔽192-193. Appaṃ vāti sahassato heṭṭhā bhogakkhandho appo nāma hoti, sahassato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: natthi tasmā pabbajjā anagāriyam ti ñātabbā tam anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti paṭipajjeyyam  appam vāti sahassataḥ heṭṭhā bhogakkhandho appaḥ nāma hoti sahassataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: therefore it should be understood that ‘gone forth’ is ‘homeless’. ‘I would go forth from the home life into homelessness’ means I would adopt that.🔽‘Little’: a store of property less than a thousand is called ‘little’;

original: mahā. Ābandhanaṭṭhena ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo. Sopi vīsatiyā heṭṭhā appo nāma hoti,
analyzed: mahā ābandhana ṭṭhena ñātiyā iva ñāti parivaṭṭaḥ saḥ api vīsatiyā heṭṭhā appaḥ nāma hoti
translated: from a thousand upwards it is ‘great’. ‘Family circle’ is just the family itself in the sense of its being the means of binding . That too is called ‘little’ if it is less than twenty-five.

original: vīsatiyā paṭṭhāya mahā. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti pātimokkhasaṃvarena samannāgato.
analyzed: vīsatiyā paṭṭhāya mahā pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvuto ti pātimokkha saṃvarena samannāgato
translated: “Restrained with the restraint of the Pātimokkha”: he is possessed of the restraint of the Pātimokkha.🔽“Endowed with proper conduct and resort”: he is endowed with proper conduct and resort.

original: Ācāragocarasampannoti ācārena ceva gocarena ca sampanno. Aṇumattesūti appamattakesu.
analyzed: ācāra gocara sampannaḥ iti ācārena ca iva gocarena ca sampannaḥ aṇu mattesu iti appamattakesu
translated: “In regard to the most insignificant of faults”: in regard to the most minute.

original: Vajjesūti akusaladhammesu. Bhayadassāvīti bhayadassī. Samādāyāti sammā ādiyitvā.
analyzed: vajjesu ati akusala dhammesu bhaya dassāvī iti bhaya dassī samādāya ati sammā ādiyitvā
translated: “Seeing fear in the slightest fault”: seeing fear in unwholesome states.🔽“Having undertaken the training rules”: having undertaken the training rules.

original: Sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti sikkhāpadesu taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyitvā sikkhati. Ayamettha
analyzed: sikkhati sikkhāpadesu uti sikkhāpadesu tam tam sikkhāpadam samādiyitvā sikkhati ayam ettha
translated: “He trains in them”: he trains in the training rules, having undertaken this or that training rule. This is the

original: saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge vutto.🔽Kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvoti ettha ācāragocaraggahaṇeneva
analyzed: saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge vutto  kāya kamma vacī kammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddha ājīvo ti ettha ācāra gocara ggahaṇena iva
translated: abbreviated meaning. The detailed meaning is given in the Path of Purification.🔽“Endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal kamma, with a purified livelihood”: here,🔽although wholesome bodily and verbal kamma are included by the inclusion of proper conduct and resort,

original: ca kusale kāyakammavacīkamme gahitepi yasmā idaṃ ājīvapārisuddhisīlaṃ nāma na ākāse
analyzed: ca kusale kāya kamma vacī kamme gahite pi yasmai idam ājīva pārisuddhi sīlam nāma naḥ ākāse
translated: since this virtue of purified livelihood does not arise in space🔽or in the tops of trees, etc., but arises only at the doors of the body and speech,

original: vā rukkhaggādīsu vā uppajjati, kāyavacīdvāresuyeva pana uppajjati; tasmā tassa uppattidvāradassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vā rukkha agga ādīsu vā uppajjati kāya vacī dvāresu yeva pana uppajjati tasmā tassa uppatti dvāra dassana attham
translated: therefore, in order to show the doors of its arising,

original: kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalenāti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana tena samannāgato,
analyzed: kāya kamma vacī kammena samannāgataḥ kusalena ati vuttam yasmā pana tena samannāgataḥ
translated: He is endowed with profitable bodily and verbal kamma. But because he is endowed with that,

original: tasmā parisuddhājīvo. Samaṇamuṇḍikaputtasuttantavasena vā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha hi
analyzed: tasmā parisuddha ājīvaḥ samaṇa muṇḍikaputta suttanta vasena vā evam vuttam tattha hi
translated: he has a purified livelihood. Or alternatively, this is said in the way stated in the Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta Sutta,

original: “katame ca, thapati, kusalā sīlā? Kusalaṃ kāyakammaṃ, kusalaṃ vacīkammaṃ, parisuddhaṃ
analyzed: katame ca thapati kusalā sīlā kusalam kāya kammam kusalam vacī kammam parisuddham
translated: where it is said: “What are profitable kinds of virtue, Thapati? Profitable bodily action, profitable verbal action, and a purified

original: ājīvampi kho ahaṃ thapati sīlasmiṃ vadāmī”ti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana tena samannāgato,
analyzed: ājīvam pi kho aham thapati sīlasmim vadāmi iti vuttam yasmā pana tena samannāgato
translated: livelihood. I say that livelihood is included in virtue, Thapati” . But because he is endowed with that,

original: tasmā parisuddhājīvoti veditabbo.
analyzed: tasmā parisuddha ājīvaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: he should be understood as having a purified livelihood.

original: Sīlasampannoti brahmajāle vuttena tividhena sīlena samannāgato hoti. Indriyesu guttadvāroti🔽manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihitadvāro hoti. Satisampajaññena samannāgatoti abhikkante
analyzed: sīla sampannaḥ ti brahmajāle vuttena tividhena sīlena samannāgataḥ hoti indriyesu gutta dvāro ti  manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihita dvāraḥ hoti sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ ti abhikkante
translated: Endowed with virtue: he is endowed with the threefold virtue stated in the Brahmajāla Sutta .🔽Guarded in the doors of the sense faculties: he has closed the doors of the six sense faculties beginning with the eye.

original: paṭikkantetiādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ceva sampajaññena ca samannāgato hoti. Santuṭṭhoti
analyzed: paṭikkanta iti ādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ca iva sampajaññena ca samannāgataḥ hoti santuṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: Possessed of mindfulness and full awareness: he is possessed of mindfulness and full awareness in the seven ways beginning with “on going out and coming back” .

original: catūsu paccayesu tividhena santosena santuṭṭho hoti.
analyzed: catūsu paccayesu tividhena santosena santuṭṭho hoti
translated: Content: he is content with the four requisite conditions in the threefold way.

original: Cūḷasīlavaṇṇanā🔽194-211. Evaṃ mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājento “kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu🔽sīlasampanno hotī”tiādimāha. Tattha idampissa hoti sīlasminti idampi assa bhikkhuno🔽pāṇātipātā veramaṇi sīlasmiṃ ekaṃ sīlaṃ hotīti attho. Paccattavacanatthe vā etaṃ
analyzed: cūḷasīla vaṇṇanā  evam mātikam nikkhipitvā anupubbena bhājentaḥ katham ca mahā rāja bhikkhu  sīla sampannaḥ hoti itiādim āha tattha idam pissa hoti sīlasmin ti idam pi assa bhikkhuno  sīlasmin ekam sīlam hoti iti attho paccatta vacana atthe vā etam
translated: Commentary on the Shorter Section on Morality

original: bhummaṃ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyañhi idampi tassa samaṇassa sīlanti ayameva attho vutto.
analyzed: bhummam mahā aṭṭhakathāyan hi idam pi tassa samaṇassa sīlan ti ayam eva atthaḥ vutto
translated: Having thus set forth the mātikā, the commentator, in the process of explaining it, says: “And how, sire, is a bhikkhu endowed with morality?” Herein, this is his morality means that this one virtue is his morality, the virtue of abstaining from killing breathing things. Or else, this is a locative case in the sense of “belonging to oneself.” For in the Mahā-Aṭṭhakathā the meaning of this is given as follows: “This is the morality of that recluse.”

original: Sesaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idamassa hoti sīlasminti idaṃ assa sīlaṃ hotīti attho.🔽212. Na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvaratoti yāni asaṃvaramūlakāni🔽bhayāni uppajjanti, tesu yaṃ idaṃ bhayaṃ sīlasaṃvarato bhaveyya, taṃ kutoci ekasaṃvaratopi
analyzed: sesam brahmajāle vutta nayena iva veditabbam idam assa hoti sīlasmin ti idam assa sīlam hoti iti attho  na kutocid bhayam samanupassati yat idam sīla saṃvarato ti yāni a saṃvara mūlakāni  bhayāni uppajjanti tesu yam idam bhayam sīla saṃvarataḥ bhaveyya tam kutoci eka saṃvarataḥ pi
translated: The rest can be understood by the method stated in the Brahmajāla. This is his morality means that this is his morality.

original: na samanupassati. Kasmā? Saṃvarato asaṃvaramūlakassa bhayassa abhāvā. Muddhābhisittoti
analyzed: na samanupassati kasmā saṃvarataḥ a saṃvara mūlakassa bhayassa abhāvā muddhābhisitto ti
translated: He sees no danger anywhere from that source, that is, from the restraint of morality. The dangers that arise from lack of restraint are dangers that might arise from the restraint of morality. But he sees no danger from any restraint whatsoever. Why? Because there is no danger from the restraint of morality that might arise from lack of restraint. Crowned with the crest means

original: yathāvidhānavihitena khattiyābhisekena muddhani avasitto. Yadidaṃ paccatthikatoti
analyzed: yathā vidhāna vihitena khattiya abhisekena muddhani avasittaḥ yat idam paccatthikato ti
translated: and he is anointed on the head with the water from the royal pitcher in the manner prescribed by the rules of the Khattiya kings. In other words, he is

original: yaṃ kutoci ekapaccatthikatopi bhayaṃ bhaveyya, taṃ na samanupassati. Kasmā? Yasmā
analyzed: yam kutoci eka paccatthikataḥ api bhayam bhaveyya tam na samanupassati kasmai yasmai
translated: free from fear. He does not see any fear coming from any quarter. Why? Because

original: nihatapaccāmitto. Ajjhattanti niyakajjhattaṃ, attano santāneti attho. Anavajjasukhanti🔽anavajjaṃ aninditaṃ kusalaṃ sīlapadaṭṭhānehi avippaṭisārapāmojjapītipassaddhidhammehi
analyzed: ajjhattanti niyaka jjhattam attanaḥ santāne ti atthaḥ anavajja sukhanti  anavajjam aninditam kusalam sīla padaṭṭhānehi a vippaṭisāra pāmojja pīti passaddhi dhammehi
translated: he has destroyed his enemies. ‘Internally’ means in himself, in his own person. ‘Blameless happiness’ means🔽the happiness of body and mind, which is blameless, uncensured, profitable, and

original: pariggahitaṃ kāyikacetasikasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno🔽hotīti evaṃ nirantaraṃ vitthāretvā dassitena tividhena sīlena samannāgato bhikkhu
analyzed: pariggahitam kāyika cetasika sukham paṭisaṃvedeti evam kho mahā rāja bhikkhu sīla sampannaḥ  hoti iti evam nirantaram vitthāretvā dassitena tividhena sīlena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu
translated: accompanied by the factors of non-remorse, gladness, rapture, tranquillity, and the mental factors. Thus, sire, a bhikkhu is virtuous.

original: sīlasampanno nāma hotīti sīlakathaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: sīla sampannaḥ nāma hoti iti sīla katham niṭṭhāpesi
translated: Thus, having shown the three kinds of virtue in detail, the Blessed One concluded the discourse on virtue with the words: ‘A bhikkhu who is thus endowed with virtue is called virtuous.’

original: Indriyasaṃvarakathā
analyzed: indriya saṃvara kathā
translated: The Discourse on the Restraint of the Senses

original: 213. Indriyesu guttadvārabhājanīye cakkhunā rūpanti ayaṃ cakkhusaddo katthaci buddhacakkhumhi
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāra bhājanīye cakkhunā rūpan ti ayam cakkhu saddo katthaci buddha cakkhumhi
translated: The word ‘eye’ in the passage ‘With the eye one sees forms’ is used in the sense of the Buddha eye in some places,

original: vattati, yathāha – “buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesī”ti. Katthaci sabbaññutaññāṇasaṅkhāte
analyzed: vattati yathā āha buddha cakkhunā lokam volokesi iti katthaci sabbaññuta ññāṇa saṅkhāte
translated: It occurs in the Buddha eye, according as it is said: “He surveyed the world with his Buddha eye” .

original: samantacakkhumhi, yathāha – “tathūpamaṃ dhammamayaṃ, sumedha, pāsādamāruyha samantacakkhū”ti.
analyzed: samantacakkhumhi yathā āha tathā upamam dhamma mayam sumedha pāsādam āruyha samantacakkhu iti
translated: In some places it occurs in the all-seeing eye consisting in the knowledge of omniscience, according as it is said: “Having ascended the palace of Dhamma, wise one, with the all-seeing eye” .

original: Katthaci dhammacakkhumhi “virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādī”ti hi ettha ariyamaggattayapaññā.
analyzed: katthaci dhammacakkhumhi virajam vīta malam dhammacakkhum udapādi iti hi ettha ariya magga ttaya paññā
translated: In some places it occurs in the eye of Dhamma, according as it is said: “The dust-free, stainless eye of Dhamma arose” , where the knowledge of the three paths is called the eye of Dhamma.

original: “Cakkhuṃ udapādi ñāṇaṃ udapādī”ti ettha pubbenivāsādiñāṇaṃ paññācakkhūti vuccati.🔽“Dibbena cakkhunā”ti āgataṭṭhānesu dibbacakkhumhi vattati. “Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe🔽cā”ti ettha pasādacakkhumhi vattati. Idha panāyaṃ pasādacakkhuvohārena cakkhuviññāṇe
analyzed: cakkhum udapādi ñāṇam udapādi iti ettha pubbenivāsa ādi ñāṇam paññā cakkhu iti vuccati  dibbena cakkhunā ati āgata ṭṭhānesu dibba cakkhumhi vattati cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe  ca ati ettha pasāda cakkhumhi vattati idha pana ayam pasāda cakkhu vohārena cakkhu viññāṇe
translated: In some places it occurs in the knowledge of the past, etc., which is called the eye of knowledge, according as it is said: “The eye arose, knowledge arose” .🔽In some places it occurs in the divine eye, according as it is said: “With the divine eye” . In some places it occurs in the physical eye, according as it is said: “With the eye, dependent on the eye and forms” . But here it occurs in eye-consciousness, which is figuratively called the physical eye.

original: vattati, tasmā cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvāti ayametthattho. Sesapadesu yaṃ vattabbaṃ
analyzed: vattati tasmā cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam disvā ati ayam etthatthaḥ sesa padesu yam vattabbam
translated: Therefore the meaning here is: “Having seen a visible object with eye-consciousness.” What is to be said about the other terms has been said in the Path of Purity .

original: siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Abyāsekasukhanti kilesabyāsekavirahitattā
analyzed: siyā tat sabbam visuddhi magge vuttam a byāseka sukhanti kilesa byāseka virahita ttā
translated: Unvexed happiness : unvexed because of the absence of vexation by defilements.

original: abyāsekaṃ asammissaṃ parisuddhaṃ adhicittasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedetīti.
analyzed: a byāsekam a sammissam parisuddham adhi citta sukham paṭisaṃvedeti iti
translated: he experiences the happiness of the higher consciousness that is untainted, unmixed, pure, and luminous.

original: Satisampajaññakathā
analyzed: sati sampajañña kathā
translated: The Discussion of Mindfulness and Full Awareness

original: 214. Satisampajaññabhājanīyamhi abhikkante paṭikkanteti ettha tāva abhikkantaṃ vuccati
analyzed: sati sampajañña bhājanīyamhi abhikkante paṭikkante iti ettha tāva abhikkantam vuccati
translated: As regards the passage beginning, “in going forward and in going back,” etc., “going forward” is said

original: gamanaṃ, paṭikkantaṃ nivattanaṃ, tadubhayampi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati. Gamane
analyzed: gamanam paṭikkantam nivattanam tat ubhayam pi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati gamane
translated: to be going in the forward direction, and “going back” is said to be going in the reverse direction. Both are found in the four postures. In going forward,

original: tāva purato kāyaṃ abhiharanto abhikkamati nāma. Paṭinivattanto paṭikkamati nāma.
analyzed: tāva puratas kāyam abhiharantaḥ abhikkamati nāma paṭinivattantaḥ paṭikkamati nāma
translated: in other words, one goes forward by extending the body in the forward direction. One goes back by turning back.

original: Ṭhānepi ṭhitakova kāyaṃ purato onāmento abhikkamati nāma, pacchato apanāmento paṭikkamati🔽nāma. Nisajjāya nisinnakova āsanassa purimaaṅgābhimukho saṃsaranto abhikkamati nāma,🔽pacchimaaṅgapadesaṃ paccāsaṃsaranto paṭikkamati nāma. Nipajjanepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ṭhāne pi ṭhitakaḥ uva kāyam puratas onāmentaḥ abhikkamati nāma pacchatas apanāmentaḥ paṭikkamati  nāma nisajjāya āsanassa purima aṅga abhimukho saṃsarantaḥ abhikkamati nāma  pacchima aṅga padesam paccā saṃsarantaḥ paṭikkamati nāma nipajjane pi esā iva nayo
translated: In standing, too, one goes forward by bending the body in the forward direction while standing still, and one goes back by withdrawing it in the reverse direction.

original: Sampajānakārī hotīti sampajaññena sabbakiccakārī. Sampajaññameva vā kārī. So hi abhikkantādīsu
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti iti sampajaññena sabba kicca kārī sampajaññam eva vā kārī so hi abhikkanta ādīsu
translated: In sitting, too, one goes forward by moving forward while remaining seated, and one goes back by moving backward. The same method applies to lying down.

original: sampajaññaṃ karoteva. Na katthaci sampajaññavirahito hoti. Tattha sātthakasampajaññaṃ,
analyzed: sampajaññam karotā iva na katthaci sampajañña virahitaḥ hoti tattha sātthaka sampajaññam
translated: he is never without clear comprehension. Herein, clear comprehension of meaning is this:

original: sappāyasampajaññaṃ, gocarasampajaññaṃ asammohasampajaññanti catubbidhaṃ sampajaññaṃ.🔽Tattha abhikkamanacitte uppanne cittavaseneva agantvā – “kinnu me ettha gatena attho
analyzed: sa pāya sampajaññam gocara sampajaññam a sammoha sampajaññanti catubbidham sampajaññam  tattha abhikkamana citte uppanne citta vasena iva a gantvā kinnu me ettha gatena atthaḥ
translated: He is never without the kinds of clear comprehension that are stated. Herein, clear comprehension is fourfold, that is to say, clear comprehension of the meaning, clear comprehension of the factor, clear comprehension of the field, and clear comprehension of the time.

original: atthi natthī”ti atthānatthaṃ pariggahetvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ sātthakasampajaññaṃ.
analyzed: atthi natthi iti attha anattham pariggahetvā attha pariggaṇhanam sa atthaka sampajaññam
translated: Herein, when the mind has arisen to go out, instead of going out with the mind, he should first discern the profitable and unprofitable, the blameable and the blameless, etc., and then he should go out only if he thinks there is something to be done there and not if he thinks there is not.🔽This discernment of what is profitable, etc., is called clear comprehension of the meaning.

original: Tattha ca atthoti cetiyadassanabodhisaṅghatheraasubhadassanādivasena dhammato vuḍḍhi.🔽Cetiyaṃ vā bodhiṃ vā disvāpi hi buddhārammaṇaṃ, saṅghadassanena saṅghārammaṇaṃ, pītiṃ
analyzed: tattha ca attho ti cetiya dassana bodhi saṅgha thera asubha dassana ādi vasena dhammataḥ vuḍḍhi  cetiyam vā bodhim vā disvā api hi buddha ārammaṇam saṅgha dassanena saṅgha ārammaṇam pītim
translated: And here “profitable” is increase in the True Idea,🔽by seeing a shrine, a tree, a bhikkhu, or a bhikkhunī, or by seeing an elder, a youth, or a novice, or by seeing a layman or a laywoman, or by seeing the True Object in the True Object, that is, the Enlightened One, the True Object in the True Object, the True Object in the False Object, and the False Object in the True Object.

original: uppādetvā tadeva khayavayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. There disvā tesaṃ ovāde
analyzed: uppādetvā tat eva khaya vayato sammasantaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti there disvā tesam ovāde
translated: For by seeing a shrine or a tree, he arouses happiness with the Enlightened One as the object,

original: patiṭṭhāya, asubhaṃ disvā tattha paṭhamajjhānaṃ uppādetvā tadeva khayavayato sammasanto
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya asubham disvā tattha paṭhama jhānam uppādetvā tat eva khaya vayato sammasanto
translated: and by seeing the bhikkhu or bhikkhunī, he arouses happiness with the True Object in the True Object, the Community, as the object.🔽By seeing the elder, youth, or novice, he arouses happiness with the True Object in the False Object, the individual, as the object.🔽By seeing the layman or laywoman, he arouses happiness with the False Object in the True Object, the individual, as the object.🔽By seeing the True Object in the True Object, the Enlightened One, he arouses happiness with the Enlightened One as the object.

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā etesaṃ dassanaṃ sātthakanti vuttaṃ. Keci pana āmisatopi
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇāti tasmai etesam dassanam sātthakan ti vuttam keci pana āmisataḥ pi
translated: He reaches Arahantship. That is why it is said that the seeing of these has a useful purpose.

original: vuḍḍhi atthoyeva, taṃ nissāya brahmacariyānuggahāya paṭipannattāti vadanti.
analyzed: vuḍḍhi tam nissāya brahmacariya anuggahāya paṭipanna ttā ti vadanti
translated: But some say that it has a useful purpose in the sense of increase of material support, since it is a means for the support of the life of purity.

original: Tasmiṃ pana gamane sappāyāsappāyaṃ pariggahetvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ.
analyzed: tasmim pana gamane sappāya asappāyam pariggahetvā sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam
translated: But in the case of the undertaking of the journey, the discerning of what is suitable and what is unsuitable is the knowledge of what is suitable.

original: Seyyathidaṃ – cetiyadassanaṃ tāva sātthakaṃ, sace pana cetiyassa mahāpūjāya dasadvādasayojanantare🔽parisā sannipatanti, attano vibhavānurūpā itthiyopi purisāpi alaṅkatapaṭiyattā cittakammarūpakāni🔽viya sañcaranti. Tatra cassa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobho hoti, aniṭṭhe paṭigho, asamapekkhane
analyzed: sā iyyathā idam cetiya dassanam tāva sātthakam sace pana cetiyassa mahā pūjāya dasa dvādasa yojana antare  parisā sannipatanti attanaḥ vibhava anurūpāḥ itthiyaḥ api purisāḥ api alaṅkata paṭiyattā citta kamma rūpakāni  viya sañcaranti tatra ca ssa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobhaḥ hoti aniṭṭhe paṭighaḥ a samapekkhane
translated: Herein, visiting a shrine has a useful purpose, but if crowds of people gather for a great festival at a shrine within a distance of ten or twelve leagues,🔽and men and women come in their finery, like pictures come to life,

original: moho uppajjati, kāyasaṃsaggāpattiṃ vā āpajjati. Jīvitabrahmacariyānaṃ vā antarāyo
analyzed: mohaḥ uppajjati kāya saṃsagga āpattim vā āpajjati jīvita brahmacariyānam vā antarāyaḥ
translated: and lust arises in him for the agreeable objects, or resentment against disagreeable objects, or confusion in the case of objects that are neither agreeable nor disagreeable, or he commits an offence by bodily contact, or he is killed or wounded by an animal or a snake, or he loses his way in the forest and so on, or he is robbed by thieves, or he is attacked by non-human beings, or he dies,

original: hoti, evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti. Vuttappakāraantarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ. Bodhidassanepi🔽eseva nayo. Saṅghadassanampi sātthaṃ. Sace pana antogāme mahāmaṇḍapaṃ kāretvā sabbarattiṃ
analyzed: hoti evam tat ṭhānam asappāyam hoti vutta ppakāra antarāya abhāve sappāyam bodhi dassane pi  esa iva nayaḥ saṅgha dassanam pi sa attham sace pana antogāme mahā maṇḍapam kāretvā sabbarattim
translated: The same method applies to the sight of the Bodhi Tree.🔽The sight of the Community is suitable. But if a large pavilion is erected in a village and people gather there all night listening to the Dhamma,

original: dhammassavanaṃ karontesu manussesu vuttappakāreneva janasannipāto ceva antarāyo ca🔽hoti, evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti. Antarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ. Mahāparisaparivārānaṃ
analyzed: dhammassavanam karontesu manussesu vutta ppakārena iva jana sannipātaḥ ca iva antarāyaḥ ca  hoti evam tam ṭhānam asappāyam hoti antarāya abhāve sappāyam mahā parisa parivārānam
translated: and there is a crowd of people and the kind of obstruction already described,🔽then that place is unsuitable. If there is no obstruction, it is suitable.

original: therānaṃ dassanepi eseva nayo.🔽Asubhadassanampi sātthaṃ, tadatthadīpanatthañca idaṃ vatthu – eko kira daharabhikkhu🔽sāmaṇeraṃ gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gato. Sāmaṇero maggā okkamitvā purato gacchanto
analyzed: therānam dassane pi esa iva nayo  asubha dassanam pi sa attham tad attha dīpana attham ca idam vatthu ekaḥ kira dahara bhikkhu  sāmaṇeram gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gataḥ sāmaṇeraḥ maggā okkamitvā puratas gacchantaḥ
translated: The same method applies to the sight of elder bhikkhus who have a large retinue.

original: asubhaṃ disvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tadeva pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto
analyzed: asubham disvā paṭhamajjhānam nibbattetvā tat eva pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ
translated: The sight of foulness is suitable. And here is a story to illustrate this. A young bhikkhu, it seems, took a novice with him to get tooth wood. The novice went in front on the way and saw some foulness. He then produced the first jhāna. Making that the basis, he comprehended formations and reached Arahantship.

original: tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā uparimaggatthāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi. Daharo
analyzed: tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā upari magga tthāya kammaṭṭhānam pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi daharaḥ
translated: and after realizing the three fruitions he stood there taking up the meditation subject for the attainment of the higher paths. The young bhikkhu

original: taṃ apassanto sāmaṇerāti pakkosi. So ‘mayā pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā saddhiṃ
analyzed: tam a passanto sāmaṇera ati pakkosi so mayā pabbajita divasataḥ paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā saddhim
translated: did not see him. So he called out, “Sāmaṇera! ” He thought, “Since the day I went forth I have never had a conversation with a bhikkhu,

original: dve kathā nāma na kathitapubbā. Aññasmimpi divase upari visesaṃ nibbattessāmī’ti
analyzed: dve kathā nāma na kathita pubbā aññasmim pi divase upari visesam nibbattessāmi iti
translated: not even two words. I shall make sure that I attain distinction today.”

original: cintetvā kiṃ, bhanteti paṭivacanamadāsi. ‘Ehī’ti ca vutte ekavacaneneva āgantvā,
analyzed: cintetvā kim bhante iti paṭivacanam adāsi ehi iti ca vutte ekavacanena iva āgantvā
translated: So he replied, “What is it, venerable sir? ” When the elder said, “Come,” he came at once with the single word “Yes,”

original: ‘bhante, iminā tāva maggeneva gantvā mayā ṭhitokāse muhuttaṃ puratthābhimukho ṭhatvā
analyzed: bhante iminā tāva maggena iva gantvā mayā ṭhita ukāse muhuttam purattha abhimukhaḥ ṭhatvā
translated: and he said, “Venerable sir, go by this path and stand for a moment facing east in the place where I am standing.

original: olokethā’ti āha. So tathā katvā tena pattavisesameva pāpuṇi. Evaṃ ekaṃ asubhaṃ dvinnaṃ🔽janānaṃ atthāya jātaṃ. Evaṃ sātthampi panetaṃ purisassa mātugāmāsubhaṃ asappāyaṃ,
analyzed: āha saḥ tathā katvā tena patta visesam eva pāpuṇi evam ekam asubham dvinnam  janānam atthāya jātam evam sa attham pi pana itam purisassa mātu gāma asubham a sappāyam
translated: Then look up.” He did so and saw only the difference in the bowl. So one foulness arose for the benefit of two people.🔽So too, though this foulness is beneficial, it is unsuitable for a man to meditate upon the foulness of a woman,

original: mātugāmassa ca purisāsubhaṃ asappāyaṃ, sabhāgameva sappāyanti evaṃ sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ
analyzed: mātugāmassa ca purisa asubham a sappāyam sa bhāgam eva sappāyanti evam sappāya pariggaṇhanam
translated: and it is unsuitable for a woman to meditate upon the foulness of a man. Only that which is of the same sex is suitable. This is how he defines its suitability.

original: sappāyasampajaññaṃ nāma.
analyzed: sappāyasampajaññam nāma
translated: and the right reflection is the reflection on what is beneficial.

original: Evaṃ pariggahitasātthakasappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu attano cittaruciyaṃ
analyzed: evam pariggahita sātthaka sappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu attano citta ruciyam
translated: When he has thus taken up the benefit and the right reflection, he should choose one of the thirty-eight meditation subjects suitable for the kind of temperament he has,🔽and he should learn the meditation subject called the “subject of meditation for developing the ways of attending to mindfulness” .

original: kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ gocaraṃ uggahetvā bhikkhācāragocare taṃ gahetvāva gamanaṃ gocarasampajaññaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna saṅkhātam gocaram uggahetvā bhikkhācāra gocare tam gahetvā ava gamanam gocara sampajaññam
translated: He should go to the alms-resort village to get alms food, taking that as his resort,

original: nāma. Tassāvibhāvanatthaṃ idaṃ catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ –🔽Idhekacco bhikkhu harati, na paccāharati; ekacco paccāharati, na harati; ekacco pana
analyzed: nāma tassa a vibhāvana attham idam catukkam veditabbam  idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu harati na paccāharati ekacco paccāharati na harati ekacco pana
translated: and this is called the right reflection on the resort. And in order to explain this, the following fourfold set should be understood:🔽Here one bhikkhu takes out but does not put back; another puts back but does not take out; another neither takes out nor puts back; and another both takes out and puts back.

original: neva harati, na paccāharati; ekacco harati ca, paccāharati cāti. Tattha yo bhikkhu🔽divasaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya ca āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodhetvā tathā rattiyā🔽paṭhamayāme, majjhimayāme seyyaṃ kappetvā pacchimayāmepi nisajjacaṅkamehi vītināmetvā
analyzed: na iva harati na paccāharati ekaccaḥ harati ca paccāharati ca ati tattha yaḥ bhikkhu  divasam caṅkamena nisajjāya ca āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittam parisodhetvā tathā rattiyā  paṭhama yāme majjhima yāme seyyam kappetvā pacchima yāme pi nisajja caṅkamehi vītināmetvā
translated: Herein, the bhikkhu who takes out but does not put back is this one:🔽Having purified his mind from obstructive states by the practice of walking and sitting in the day time, he should do likewise in the first and middle watches of the night.🔽Having risen in the last watch and having expelled the sleep that has overcome him, he should spend the earlier part of the night in walking and sitting and in the latter part he should lie down.

original: pageva cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇavattaṃ katvā bodhirukkhe udakaṃ āsiñcitvā, pānīyaṃ
analyzed: pagā iva cetiyaṅgaṇa bodhiyaṅgaṇa vattam katvā bodhi rukkhe udakam āsiñcitvā pānīyam
translated: Having laid his upper robe over the lower one, and placing one foot on the other, and being mindful and clearly comprehending, he should attain the lion’s reclining posture and lie down on his right side.

original: paribhojanīyaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā ācariyupajjhāyavattādīni sabbāni khandhakavattāni
analyzed: paribhojanīyam paccupaṭṭhapetvā ācariya upajjhāya vatta ādīni sabbāni khandhaka vattāni
translated: and he does all the duties laid down in the Khandhaka, such as attending on the teacher and the preceptor, etc.

original: samādāya vattati. So sarīraparikammaṃ katvā senāsanaṃ pavisitvā dve tayo pallaṅke🔽usumaṃ gāhāpento kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuñjitvā bhikkhācāravelāyaṃ uṭṭhahitvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva
analyzed: samādāya vattati so sarīra parikammam katvā senāsanam pavisitvā dve tayo pallaṅke  usumam gāhāpento kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjitvā bhikkhā cāra velāyam uṭṭhahitvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva
translated: After doing the duties connected with the body, he enters the dwelling, and having two or three mats spread,🔽he sits on them, keeping them warm, and devotes himself to his meditation subject. When it is time to go for alms, he gets up,

original: pattacīvaramādāya senāsanato nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: patta cīvaram ādāya senāsanataḥ nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ uva cetiya ṅgaṇam
translated: taking his meditation subject with him in the forefront, and he goes out from the dwelling, giving his attention to his meditation subject.

original: gantvā, sace buddhānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, taṃ avissajjetvāva cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ pavisati.
analyzed: gantvā sace buddha anussati kammaṭṭhānam hoti tam a vissajjetvā ava cetiya ṅgaṇam pavisati
translated: If his meditation subject is the recollection of the Buddha, he enters the shrine terrace without putting it aside.

original: Aññaṃ ce kammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, sopānamūle ṭhatvā hatthena gahitabhaṇḍaṃ viya taṃ ṭhapetvā🔽buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ āruyha, mahantaṃ cetiyaṃ ce, tikkhattuṃ
analyzed: aññam ce kammaṭṭhānam hoti sopāna mūle ṭhatvā hatthena gahita bhaṇḍam viya tam ṭhapetvā  buddha ārammaṇam pītim gahetvā cetiyaṅgaṇam āruyha mahantam cetiyam ce tikkhattum
translated: If it is some other meditation subject, he sets it aside as though it were a deposit placed in his hand,🔽and after taking up the happiness of the jhāna that has the Buddha as its object, he goes into the shrine terrace.

original: padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ. Khuddakaṃ cetiyaṃ ce, tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbam khuddakam cetiyam ce tathā iva padakkhiṇam
translated: If the shrine is a large one, he should circumambulate it three times, paying homage at the four places where homage is paid. If the shrine is a small one, he should circumambulate it once, paying homage at the two places where homage is paid.

original: katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ. Cetiyaṃ vanditvā bodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ pattenāpi buddhassa🔽bhagavato sammukhā viya nipaccākāraṃ dassetvā bodhi vanditabbā. So evaṃ cetiyañca🔽bodhiñca vanditvā paṭisāmitaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā paṭisāmitabhaṇḍakaṃ hatthena gaṇhanto🔽viya nikkhittakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā gāmasamīpe kammaṭṭhānasīseneva cīvaraṃ pārupitvā
analyzed: katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbam cetiyam vanditvā bodhi yaṅgaṇam pattena api buddhassa  bhagavato sammukhā viya nipacca ākāram dassetvā bodhi vanditabbā so evam cetiyam ca  bodhim ca vanditvā paṭisāmita ṭṭhānam gantvā paṭisāmita bhaṇḍakam hatthena gaṇhantaḥ  viya nikkhitta kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā gāma samīpe kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva cīvaram pārupitvā
translated: and he should pay homage in the eight places. After paying homage at the shrine, he should enter the Bodhi Shrine and, even if he has to crawl on his knees and elbows, he should pay homage at the Bodhi Tree, showing as much respect as if he were paying homage to the Blessed Lord face to face. Having paid homage in this way at the shrine and the Bodhi Tree, he should go to the place where the relics are deposited and, as if holding the casket of relics in his hands, he should take up the meditation subject and, after putting on his robe in the usual way,🔽he should go to the village for alms.

original: gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisati. Atha naṃ manussā disvā ayyo no āgatoti paccuggantvā pattaṃ🔽gahetvā āsanasālāya vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāguṃ datvā yāva bhattaṃ na niṭṭhāti,🔽tāva pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā purato te nisīditvā pañhaṃ vā pucchanti, dhammaṃ🔽vā sotukāmā honti. Sacepi na kathāpenti, janasaṅgahatthaṃ dhammakathā nāma kātabbā
analyzed: gāmam piṇḍāya pavisati atha nam manussāḥ disvā ayyaḥ naḥ āgataḥ iti paccuggantvā pattaṃ 🔽gahetvā āsana sālāya vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāgum datvā yāva bhattam na niṭṭhāti 🔽tāva pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā puratas te nisīditvā pañham vā pucchanti dhammaṃ 🔽vā sotu kāmāḥ honti sace pi na kathāpenti jana saṅga hattham dhammakathā nāma kātabbā
translated: and he should pay homage at the eight shrines. After paying homage at the shrine, he should enter the Bodhi shrine and, as though in the presence of the Blessed One, he should show his respect by bowing down with his head at the Blessed One’s feet. Having paid homage thus to the shrine and the Bodhi tree, he should go to the place where he has left his bowl and robe. Taking the bowl and robe as though he were taking the meditation subject, he should put on his sarong evenly all round, covering the navel and the knees. Then, after arranging his upper robe over one shoulder, he should take his bowl and set out on his alms round. He should enter the village confidently, with a mind like a stump, with his sense faculties restrained, with his eyes cast down, with his body guarded, with a mind not turned to outward things, with his steps measured, taking his bowl straight, not looking at the stars. Translation: aṭṭhaṭṭhānesu vanditvā cetiyaṃ vanditvā bodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ pattenāpi buddhassa bhagavato sammukhā viya nipaccākāraṃ dassetvā bodhi vanditabbā | so evaṃ cetiyañca bodhiñca vanditvā paṭisāmitaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā paṭisāmitabhaṇḍakaṃ hatthena gaṇhanto viya nikkhittakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā gāmasamīpe kammaṭṭhānasīseneva cīvaraṃ pārupitvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisati | atha naṃ manussā disvā “āyasmā amhākaṃ āgato”ti paccuggantvā pattaṃ gahetvā āsanasālāya vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāguṃ datvā yāva bhattaṃ na niṭṭhāti, tāva pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā purato te nisīditvā pañhaṃ vā pucchanti, dhammaṃ vā sotukāmā honti | sacepi na kathāpenti, janasaṅgahatthaṃ dhammakathā nāma kātabbā |

original: yevāti aṭṭhakathācariyā vadanti. Dhammakathā hi kammaṭṭhānavinimuttā nāma natthi,
analyzed: yā iva ati aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ vadanti dhammakathā hi kammaṭṭhāna vinimuttā nāma natthi
translated: For there is no Dhamma talk apart from the meditation subject.

original: tasmā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva dhammakathaṃ kathetvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva āhāraṃ paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: tasmai kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva dhamma katham kathetvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva āhāram paribhuñjitvā
translated: Therefore he taught the Dhamma with the meditation subject as the starting point, and he took his meal with the meditation subject as the starting point.

original: anumodanaṃ katvā nivattiyamānehipi manussehi anugatova gāmato nikkhamitvā tattha
analyzed: anumodanam katvā manussehi anugataḥ uva gāmataḥ nikkhamitvā tattha
translated: And when the people were departing after giving the benediction, he went out of the village with them.

original: te nivattetvā maggaṃ paṭipajjati.
analyzed: te nivattetvā maggam paṭipajjati
translated: But when they had turned back, he went on by the path.

original: Atha naṃ puretaraṃ nikkhamitvā bahigāme katabhattakiccā sāmaṇeradaharabhikkhū disvā🔽paccuggantvā pattacīvaramassa gaṇhanti. Porāṇakabhikkhū kira amhākaṃ upajjhāyo ācariyoti
analyzed: atha nam puretaram nikkhamitvā bahigāme kata bhatta kiccā sāmaṇera dahara bhikkhū disvā  paccuggantvā patta cīvaram assa gaṇhanti porāṇaka bhikkhū kira amhākam upajjhāyaḥ ācariyo ti
translated: Then young bhikkhus and probationers who had gone out earlier and had finished their meal saw him outside the village.

original: na mukhaṃ oloketvā vattaṃ karonti, sampattaparicchedeneva karonti. Te taṃ pucchanti
analyzed: na mukham oloketvā vattam karonti sampatta paricchedena iva karonti te tam pucchanti
translated: They went to meet him and took his bowl and robe. It seems that the senior bhikkhus did not look at the face to see who it was but rendered service according to the rule for the one who arrived first. They asked him:

original: – “bhante, ete manussā tumhākaṃ kiṃ honti, mātipakkhato sambandhā pitipakkhato”ti?
analyzed: bhante ete manussā tumhākam kim honti māti pakkhataḥ sambandhā piti pakkhataḥ ti
translated: “Venerable sir, what are these people to you? Are they relatives on your mother’s or father’s side?”

original: Kiṃ disvā pucchathāti? Tumhesu etesaṃ pemaṃ bahumānanti. Āvuso, yaṃ mātāpitūhipi
analyzed: kim disvā pucchatha ati tumhesu etesam āvuso yam
translated: “What have you seen that you ask?” “We have affection and respect for them.” “Friends, they do what is hard to do even by mothers and fathers.

original: dukkaraṃ, taṃ ete amhākaṃ karonti, pattacīvarampi no etesaṃ santakameva, etesaṃ ānubhāvena
analyzed: dukkaram tam ete amhākam karonti pattacīvaram pi no etesam santakam eva etesam ānubhāvena
translated: Our bowl and robe are theirs. Through their power

original: neva bhaye bhayaṃ, na chātake chātakaṃ jānāma. Īdisā nāma amhākaṃ upakārino natthīti
analyzed: na iva bhaye bhayam na chātake chātakam jānāma īdisāḥ nāma amhākam upakārinaḥ natthi iti
translated: we know no fear in the fearful season, no heat in the hot season. We have no one to help us like them.”

original: tesaṃ guṇe kathento gacchati. Ayaṃ vuccati harati na paccāharatīti.
analyzed: tesam guṇe kathentaḥ gacchati ayam vuccati harati na paccāharati iti
translated: So he goes about telling their virtues. This is called “he carries but does not bring back.”

original: Yassa pana pageva vuttappakāraṃ vattapaṭipattiṃ karontassa kammajatejodhātu pajjalati,🔽anupādinnakaṃ muñcitvā upādinnakaṃ gaṇhāti, sarīrato sedā muñcanti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vīthiṃ nārohati, so pageva pattacīvaramādāya vegasā cetiyaṃ vanditvā gorūpānaṃ nikkhamanavelāyameva
analyzed: yassa pana pagā iva vutta ppakāram vatta paṭipattim karontassa kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu pajjalati  an upādinnakam muñcitvā upādinnakam gaṇhāti sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muñcanti kammaṭṭhānam  vīthim na ārohati saḥ pagā iva patta cīvaram ādāya vegasā cetiyam vanditvā go rūpānam nikkhamana velāyam eva
translated: But when one who is already doing the proper duties described above finds that the fire element in his body blazes up,🔽he should let go of the unapprehended and apprehend the apprehended, shake off the sweat from his body, and then🔽go to the shrine and worship it. Then he should go out of the monastery grounds and enter a village for alms.

original: gāmaṃ yāgubhikkhāya pavisitvā yāguṃ labhitvā āsanasālaṃ gantvā pivati, athassa dvattikkhattuṃ
analyzed: gāmam yāgu bhikkhāya pavisitvā yāgum labhitvā āsana sālam gantvā pivati athassa dvatti khattum
translated: When he has got alms, he should go to the refectory and drink the rice porridge. Then he should do the washing up and go to the sauna.

original: ajjhoharaṇamatteneva kammajatejodhātu upādinnakaṃ muñcitvā anupādinnakaṃ gaṇhāti,
analyzed: ajjhoharaṇa mattena iva kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu upādinnakam muñcitvā an upādinnakam gaṇhāti
translated: As soon as he has swallowed it, the fire element that is born of kamma lets go of what is clung to and seizes what is not clung to.

original: ghaṭasatena nhāto viya tejodhātu pariḷāhanibbānaṃ patvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena yāguṃ paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: ghaṭa satena nhātaḥ viya tejodhātu pariḷāha nibbānam patvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena yāgum paribhuñjitvā
translated: Like one who has bathed with a hundred pots of water, the fire element reaches the state of non-thirst and enters upon the bliss of jhāna with the head of the meditation subject.

original: pattañca mukhañca dhovitvā antarābhatte kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikatvā avasesaṭṭhāne piṇḍāya
analyzed: pattam ca mukham ca dhovitvā antarābhatte kammaṭṭhānam manasikatvā avasesa ṭṭhāne piṇḍāya
translated: After he has drunk the rice gruel and washed the bowl and his mouth, he should give attention to the meditation subject during the middle watch and🔽go for alms in the remaining part of the night.

original: caritvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena āhārañca paribhuñjitvā tato paṭṭhāya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ upaṭṭhahamānaṃ
analyzed: caritvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena āhārañca paribhuñjitvā tatas paṭṭhāya poṅkha anupoṅkham upaṭṭhahamānam
translated: After he has drunk the food and eaten the alms food, he should go to the place where he is staying, taking the meditation subject with him as he goes,

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā āgacchati, ayaṃ vuccati paccāharati na haratīti. Edisā ca bhikkhū
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā āgacchati ayam vuccati paccāharati na harati iti edisā ca bhikkhū
translated: and he should give attention to it there. This is called “he does not take it in the morning but he takes it in the evening.”

original: yāguṃ pivitvā vipassanaṃ ārabhitvā buddhasāsane arahattappattā nāma gaṇanapathaṃ🔽vītivattā. Sīhaḷadīpeyeva tesu tesu gāmesu āsanasālāyaṃ vā na taṃ āsanamatthi, yattha
analyzed: yāgum pivitvā vipassanam ārabhitvā buddha sāsane arahattappattāḥ nāma gaṇanapatham  tesu tesu gāmesu āsana sālāyam vā na tat āsanam atthi
translated: Bhikkhus who have drunk rice gruel in this way and begun insight have reached Arahantship in the Dispensation of the Buddha beyond counting.

original: yāguṃ pivitvā arahattappattā bhikkhū natthīti.
analyzed: yāgum pivitvā arahatta pattā bhikkhū na atthi iti
translated: In the Island of Sri Lanka there is no sitting mat in any village monastery in the sitting hall where there has not sat bhikkhus who have drunk rice gruel and reached Arahantship.

original: Yo pana pamādavihārī hoti, nikkhittadhuro sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidhacetokhīlavinibandhacitto
analyzed: yaḥ pana pamāda vihārī hoti nikkhitta dhuraḥ sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidha cetaḥ khīla vinibandha citto
translated: But one who is negligent, who has given up striving, who has broken the rules of training, who has a mind full of the five hindrances and the five corruptions of insight,

original: viharanto – “kammaṭṭhānaṃ nāma atthī”ti saññampi akatvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena
analyzed: viharantaḥ kammaṭṭhānam nāma atthi iti saññam pi a katvā gāmam piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena
translated: and who does not even think, “There is a meditation subject,” but enters the village for alms without making a meditation subject his principal object,

original: gihisaṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭho caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tuccho nikkhamati, ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: gihi saṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tucchaḥ nikkhamati ayam vuccati
translated: and who, after associating with householders in an unfitting way, after eating what is not suitable, after returning with an empty stomach, is called

original: neva harati na paccāharatīti.
analyzed: na iva harati na paccāharati iti
translated: “one who neither carries out nor reverts.”

original: Yo panāyaṃ – “harati ca paccāharati cā”ti vutto, so gatapaccāgatavattavaseneva veditabbo.
analyzed: yaḥ pana ayam harati ca paccāharati ca ati vutto saḥ gata paccāgata vatta vasena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: But the one who is said to “carry out and revert” should be understood as follows:

original: Attakāmā hi kulaputtā sāsane pabbajitvā dasapi vīsampi tiṃsampi cattālīsampi paññāsampi
analyzed: atta kāmā hi kula puttā sāsane pabbajitvā dasa pi vīsam pi tiṃsam pi cattālīsam pi paññāsam pi
translated: For young men who have gone forth in the Dispensation out of desire for their own welfare live together in groups of ten, twenty, thirty, forty,

original: satampi ekato vasantā katikavattaṃ katvā viharanti, “āvuso, tumhe na iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā,
analyzed: satam pi ekatas vasantā katikavattam katvā viharanti āvuso tumhe na iṇaṭṭā na bhayaṭṭā
translated: fifty, or a hundred, and they live in conformity with the rules of the community life, saying: “Friends, you have not gone forth,🔽leaving the world out of fear of punishment or out of fear of want, or because you are unable to earn a living, or because you are in debt, or out of fear of thieves, or because you are afraid of being punished by the king, or because you are sick of your wife’s scolding.

original: na jīvikāpakatā pabbajitā, dukkhā muccitukāmā panettha pabbajitā, tasmā gamane uppannakilesaṃ
analyzed: na jīvikā pakatā pabbajitā dukkhā muccitu kāmā pana ittha pabbajitā tasmā gamane uppanna kilesam
translated: You have gone forth out of desire for welfare, for freedom from bondage, for the extinction of suffering.

original: gamaneyeva niggaṇhatha, tathā ṭhāne, nisajjāya, sayane uppannakilesaṃ sayaneva niggaṇhathā”ti.🔽Te evaṃ katikavattaṃ katvā bhikkhācāraṃ gacchantā aḍḍhausabhausabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutantaresu
analyzed: niggaṇhatha tathā ṭhāne nisajjāya sayane uppanna kilesam sayanā iva niggaṇhatha ati  te evam katikavattam katvā bhikkhācāram gacchantā aḍḍhausabha ausabha aḍḍhagāvutagāvuta antaresu
translated: and when you are standing, sitting, or lying down, you should suppress the defilement that arises then while you are standing, sitting, or lying down.”

original: pāsāṇā honti, tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontāva gacchanti. Sace kassaci gamane
analyzed: pāsāṇāḥ honti tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontā ava gacchanti sace kassaci gamane
translated: When they had made this agreement, they went on their alms round. On the way there were boulders, and they went on contemplating their meditation subject with the perception of the boulders.

original: kileso uppajjati, tattheva naṃ niggaṇhāti. Tathā asakkonto tiṭṭhati, athassa pacchato🔽āgacchantopi tiṭṭhati. So “ayaṃ bhikkhu tuyhaṃ uppannavitakkaṃ jānāti, ananucchavikaṃ
analyzed: kilesaḥ uppajjati tattha eva nam niggaṇhāti tathā a sakkontaḥ tiṭṭhati atha assa pacchatas  āgacchantaḥ api tiṭṭhati saḥ ayam bhikkhu tuyham uppanna vitakkam jānāti ananucchavikam
translated: If defilement arose in any one while he was walking, he suppressed it there and then. If he was unable to do so, he stood downwind from the others.🔽Then the one who was following him also stood downwind from him.

original: te eta”nti attānaṃ paṭicodetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā tattheva ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati;
analyzed: te etanti attānam paṭicodetvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā tattha iva ariya bhūmim okkamati
translated: The first bhikkhu rebuked himself, “This bhikkhu knows the thought that has arisen in you. It is not proper for you to do so,” and he increased his insight and entered upon the supramundane states right there.

original: tathā asakkonto nisīdati. Athassa pacchato āgacchantopi nisīdatīti soyeva nayo. Ariyabhūmiṃ
analyzed: tathā a sakkontaḥ nisīdati atha assa pacchatas āgacchantaḥ api nisīdati iti saḥ yā iva nayaḥ ariya bhūmiṃ
translated: If he was unable to do so, he sat down. Then the one who was following him also sat down. The same method applies here too.

original: okkamituṃ asakkontopi taṃ kilesaṃ vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova gacchati,
analyzed: okkamitum a sakkontaḥ api tam kilesam vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ iva gacchati
translated: If he cannot do so, he should still go on with his meditation subject in mind, suppressing the defilement.

original: na kammaṭṭhānavippayuttena cittena pādaṃ uddharati, uddharati ce, paṭinivattitvā
analyzed: na kammaṭṭhāna vippayuttena cittena pādam uddharati uddharati ce paṭinivattitvā
translated: He should not lift up his foot with mind unconcentrated. If he does so, he should return to his starting point and

original: purimapadesaṃyeva eti. Ālindakavāsī mahāphussadevatthero viya.
analyzed: purima padesam yā iva eti ālindaka vāsī mahāphussadeva ttheraḥ
translated: go on from there. He should be like the Elder Mahā-Phussadeva of Āḷavaka.

original: So kira ekūnavīsativassāni gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento eva vihāsi, manussāpi addasaṃsu
analyzed: saḥ kira ekūnavīsati vassāni gata paccāgata vattam pūrentaḥ eva vihāsi manussā api addasaṃsu
translated: It seems that he lived for nineteen years keeping to his practice of going out and returning. People saw him

original: antarāmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā theraṃ tathāgacchantaṃ
analyzed: antara āmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā theram tathāgacchantam
translated: and while they were ploughing, sowing, and working in the fields they said,

original: disvā – “ayaṃ thero punappunaṃ nivattitvā gacchati, kinnu kho maggamūḷho, udāhu kiñci
analyzed: disvā ayam thero punappunam nivattitvā gacchati kinnu kho magga mūḷhaḥ udāhu kiñci
translated: “This elder goes out and returns again. Is he lost in the path? Or is he confused about something? ”

original: pamuṭṭho”ti samullapanti. So taṃ anādiyitvā kammaṭṭhānayuttacitteneva samaṇadhammaṃ
analyzed: pamuṭṭhaḥ iti samullapanti saḥ tam an ādiyitvā kammaṭṭhāna yutta cittena iva samaṇa dhammam
translated: But he paid no attention to them. He went on doing his ascetic practice with mind concentrated on his meditation subject.

original: karonto vīsativassabbhantare arahattaṃ pāpuṇi, arahattappattadivase cassa caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ
analyzed: karontaḥ vīsati vassa abbhantare arahattam pāpuṇi arahatta patta divase ca ssa caṅkamana koṭiyam
translated: Within twenty years he reached Arahantship. On the day he reached Arahantship,

original: adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpaṃ ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi. Cattāropi mahārājāno sakko ca
analyzed: adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpam ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi cattāro api mahā rājāno sakko ca
translated: The deities who had taken up residence there lit up the lamp with their fingers and stood there. The Four Great Kings, Sakka,

original: devānamindo brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānaṃ agamaṃsu. Tañca obhāsaṃ disvā vanavāsī
analyzed: devānamindaḥ brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānam agamaṃsu tat ca obhāsam disvā vana vāsī
translated: the Lord of the Devas, and Brahma Sahampati all came to wait on him. And when the Elder Maha Tissa, who lived in the forest,

original: mahātissatthero taṃ dutiyadivase pucchi – “rattibhāge āyasmato santike obhāso ahosi,
analyzed: mahātissa theraḥ tam dutiya divase pucchi ratti bhāge āyasmato santike obhāsaḥ ahosi
translated: saw the light, he asked the Elder on the following day, “Last night there was a light in your presence.🔽What was that light?” The Elder, trying to cover up, said,

original: kiṃ so obhāso”ti? Thero vikkhepaṃ karonto obhāso nāma dīpobhāsopi hoti, maṇiobhāsopīti
analyzed: kim saḥ obhāsaḥ ti theraḥ vikkhepam karonto obhāsaḥ nāma dīpa ubhāsaḥ api hoti maṇi obhāsaḥ api iti
translated: “There are lights called ‘lamp lights’ and ‘jewel lights.’ ”

original: evamādimāha. Tato ‘paṭicchādetha tumhe’ti nibaddho ‘āmā’ti paṭijānitvā ārocesi. Kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsī
analyzed: evamādim āha tatas tumhā iti nibaddhaḥ paṭicchādetha tumhā iti nibaddhaḥ paṭijānitvā ārocesi kāḷavalli maṇḍapa vāsī
translated: But when pressed, “Conceal it no longer,” he admitted it and told him.

original: mahānāgatthero viya ca.
analyzed: mahānāga ttheraḥ ca
translated: And he was like the Elder Maha Naga who lived in the Black Rock Cave.

original: Sopi kira gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento – paṭhamaṃ tāva bhagavato mahāpadhānaṃ pūjessāmīti
analyzed: saḥ api kira gata paccāgata vattam pūrentaḥ paṭhamam tāva bhagavataḥ mahā padhānam pūjessāmi iti
translated: It seems that he was fulfilling the duties of going and coming thus: “First I will worship the Blessed One’s Great Pagoda.”

original: sattavassāni ṭhānacaṅkamameva adhiṭṭhāsi. Puna soḷasavassāni gatapaccāgatavattaṃ
analyzed: satta vassāni ṭhāna caṅkamam eva adhiṭṭhāsi puna soḷasa vassāni gata paccāgata vattam
translated: So he resolved to stand for seven years in the place where the pagoda was to be built. Then for sixteen years he fulfilled the duties of going and coming.

original: pūretvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. So kammaṭṭhānayutteneva cittena pādaṃ uddharanto, viyuttena
analyzed: pūretvā arahattam pāpuṇi so kammaṭṭhāna yuttena iva cittena pādam uddharantaḥ viyuttena
translated: and he reached Arahantship. He lifted his foot with a consciousness intent on the meditation subject,

original: uddhaṭe paṭinivattento gāmasamīpaṃ gantvā “gāvī nu pabbajito nū”ti āsaṅkanīyapadese
analyzed: uddhaṭe paṭinivattentaḥ gāma samīpam gantvā gāvī nu pabbajitaḥ nu iti āsaṅkanīya padese
translated: and he turned back with a consciousness intent on the meditation subject. When he had gone near to the village, he stood in a place where people might suspect him of being either a cow or an ascetic,

original: ṭhatvā cīvaraṃ pārupitvā kacchakantarato udakena pattaṃ dhovitvā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ karoti.🔽Kiṃ kāraṇā? Mā me bhikkhaṃ dātuṃ vā vandituṃ vā āgate manusse ‘dīghāyukā hothā’ti🔽vacanamattenāpi kammaṭṭhānavikkhepo ahosīti. “Ajja, bhante, katimī”ti divasaṃ vā
analyzed: ṭhatvā cīvaram pārupitvā kaccha kantarataḥ udakena pattam dhovitvā udaka gaṇḍūsam karoti  kim kāraṇā mā me bhikkham dātum vā vanditum vā āgate manusse dīgha āyukāḥ hotha ati  vacana mattena api kammaṭṭhāna vikkhepaḥ ahosi iti ajja bhante katimī iti divasam vā
translated: and he put on his robe, and after washing his bowl in the water in his water-carrying pot, he made a water strainer.🔽Why did he do this? So that there should be no distraction of his consciousness from the meditation subject by the words ‘May you live long’ when people came to give him alms or to pay homage to him.

original: bhikkhugaṇanaṃ vā pañhaṃ vā pucchito pana udakaṃ gilitvā āroceti. Sace divasādīni
analyzed: bhikkhu gaṇanam vā pañham vā pucchitaḥ pana udakam gilitvā āroceti sace divasa ādīni
translated: When asked, ‘What is today, venerable sir? ’ or ‘What is the number of the day? ’ or ‘How many bhikkhus are there? ’ he would answer after swallowing water.

original: pucchakā na honti, nikkhamanavelāya gāmadvāre niṭṭhubhitvāva yāti.
analyzed: pucchakāḥ na honti nikkhamana velāya gāma dvāre niṭṭhubhitvā ava yāti
translated: If there were no one to ask the day and so on, he would go out through the village gate after trumpeting.

original: Kalambatitthavihāre vassūpagatā paññāsabhikkhū viya ca. Te kira āsaḷhipuṇṇamāyaṃ
analyzed: kalamba tittha vihāre paññāsa bhikkhū viya ca te kira āsaḷhipuṇṇamāyam
translated: And he was like the fifty bhikkhus who went into residence for the Rains in the Kalambatittha monastery.

original: katikavattaṃ akaṃsu – “arahattaṃ appatvā aññamaññaṃ nālapissāmā”ti, gāmañca piṇḍāya
analyzed: katikavattam akaṃsu arahattam a patvā aññam aññam na ālapissāma ati gāmam ca piṇḍāya
translated: They made a rule that they would not speak to each other until they had attained perfection, and they went to the village for alms.

original: pavisantā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ katvā pavisiṃsu. Divasādīsu pucchitesu vuttanayeneva paṭipajjiṃsu.
analyzed: pavisantāḥ udaka gaṇḍūsam katvā pavisiṃsu divasa ādīsu pucchitesu vutta nayena iva paṭipajjiṃsu
