translated: They made a rule among themselves, saying, “We will not speak to one another until we have attained Arahatship.” So they entered the village for alms, carrying their bowls and robes, and they entered the village in silence.🔽When the people asked them questions, they answered in the same manner as before.

original: Tattha manussā niṭṭhubhanaṃ disvā jāniṃsu – “ajjeko āgato, ajja dve”ti. Evañca cintesuṃ
analyzed: tattha manussāḥ niṭṭhubhanam disvā jāniṃsu ajja ekaḥ āgataḥ ajja dve iti evam ca cintesuṃ
translated: The people observed the manner in which they entered the village and concluded, “Yesterday one came, today two.” And they thought to themselves,

original: – “kinnu kho ete amhehiyeva saddhiṃ na sallapanti, udāhu aññamaññampi. Sace aññamaññampi
analyzed: kinnu kho ete amhehiyeva saddhim na sallapanti udāhu aññam aññam pi sace aññam aññam pi
translated: “Do they not speak to us because we are strangers, or do they not speak to one another? If they do not speak to one another,

original: na sallapanti, addhā vivādajātā bhavissanti. Etha ne aññamaññaṃ khamāpessāmā”ti,
analyzed: na sallapanti addhā vivāda jātāḥ bhavissanti etha ne aññamaññam khamāpessāma ati
translated: they must be engaged in a dispute. Well, we will cause them to make peace with one another.”

original: sabbe vihāraṃ gantvā paññāsāya bhikkhūsu dvepi bhikkhū ekokāse nāddasaṃsu. Tato yo🔽tesu cakkhumā puriso, so āha – “na bho kalahakārakānaṃ vasanokāso īdiso hoti, susammaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: sabbe vihāram gantvā paññāsāya bhikkhūsu dve api bhikkhū ekokāse na addasaṃsu tatas yo  tesu cakkhumā puriso saḥ āha na bho kalahakārakānam vasanokāsaḥ īdisaḥ hoti su sammaṭṭham
translated: So they all went to the monastery, and in the company of fifty monks they did not see two monks sitting in the same place. Then one of the men,

original: cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ, sunikkhittā sammajjaniyo, sūpaṭṭhapitaṃ pānīyaṃ paribhojanīya”nti,
analyzed: cetiya aṅgaṇa bodhiya aṅgaṇam su nikkhittā sammajjaniyaḥ su upaṭṭhapitam pānīyam paribhojanīyanti
translated: who was a man of discernment, said, “The place where disputants live is not like this. The shrine terrace and the Bodhi Tree terrace are well swept, the brooms are well placed, and the water for drinking and the water for washing are well placed.”

original: te tatova nivattā. Tepi bhikkhū anto temāseyeva arahattaṃ patvā mahāpavāraṇāya visuddhipavāraṇaṃ pavāresuṃ.
analyzed: te tatas va nivattā te pi bhikkhū anto te māseya iva arahattam patvā mahāpavāraṇāya visuddhi pavāraṇam pavāresuṃ
translated: and they turned back from there. And those bhikkhus attained Arahantship within the time taken for eating a meal of rice and curry, and they performed the Invitation ceremony of purification on the day of the Great Invitation.🔽So too the Elder Mahānāga who lived in the Kāḷavellināga-grove,

original: Evaṃ kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsī mahānāgatthero viya, kalambatitthavihāre vassūpagatabhikkhū
analyzed: evam kāḷavalli maṇḍapa vāsī mahā nāga ttheraḥ kalamba tittha vihāre vassu upagata bhikkhū
translated: and the bhikkhus who had entered for the rains in the Kalambakassa Hermitage,

original: viya ca kammaṭṭhānayutteneva cittena pādaṃ uddharanto gāmasamīpaṃ gantvā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ
analyzed: viya ca kammaṭṭhāna yuttena iva cittena pādam uddharantaḥ gāma samīpam gantvā udaka gaṇḍūsam
translated: lifting up his foot with a consciousness intent on the meditation subject, he went to the village. Having taken a water-spittoon,

original: katvā vīthiyo sallakkhetvā, yattha surāsoṇḍadhuttādayo kalahakārakā caṇḍahatthiassādayo🔽vā natthi, taṃ vīthiṃ paṭipajjati. Tattha ca piṇḍāya caramāno na turitaturito viya🔽javena gacchati. Na hi javena piṇḍapātiyadhutaṅgaṃ nāma kiñci atthi. Visamabhūmibhāgappattaṃ
analyzed: katvā vīthiyaḥ sallakkhetvā yattha surā soṇḍa dhutta ādayo kalahakārakā caṇḍahatthiassa ādayo  vā na atthi tam vīthim paṭipajjati tattha ca piṇḍāya caramānaḥ na turita turitaḥ viya  javena gacchati na hi javena piṇḍapātiya dhutaṅgam nāma kiñci atthi visama bhūmi bhāga ppattam
translated: he surveyed the streets to see if there were any brawlers, drunkards, harlots, and so on, or any fierce bulls, etc., that might cause trouble,🔽and he took the street where there were none of these. And while he was walking for alms there, he did not go quickly as though in a race;🔽for there is no such ascetic practice as “going quickly” among the alms-food ascetic practices. But he went as steadily as a water- drawing wheel.

original: pana udakasakaṭaṃ viya niccalo hutvā gacchati. Anugharaṃ paviṭṭho ca dātukāmaṃ vā
analyzed: pana udaka sakaṭam viya niccalaḥ hutvā gacchati ca dātu kāmam vā
translated: And when he had entered a house, he did not sit down on a seat without first asking permission of the owners;

original: adātukāmaṃ vā sallakkhetvā tadanurūpaṃ kālaṃ āgamento bhikkhaṃ paṭilabhitvā ādāya
analyzed: a dātu kāmam vā sallakkhetvā tad anurūpam kālam āgamentaḥ bhikkham paṭilabhitvā ādāya
translated: Or else, if he sees that the alms-giver is not willing to give, he should wait until he gets alms after the lapse of a suitable time.

original: antogāme vā bahigāme vā vihārameva vā āgantvā yathā phāsuke patirūpe okāse nisīditvā
analyzed: antogāme vā bahigāme vā vihāram eva vā āgantvā yathā phāsuke pati rūpe okāse nisīditvā
translated: Then, after he has brought it, he should go to the monastery, to a place outside the village or to his own lodging, and sit down on a suitable seat in a suitable place.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikaronto āhāre paṭikūlasaññaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā akkhabbhañjana – vaṇalepanaputtamaṃsūpamavasena
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ āhāre paṭikūla saññam upaṭṭhapetvā akkhabbhañjana vaṇa lepana putta maṃsūpama vasena
translated: Then he should bring to mind the meditation subject and establish mindfulness by giving attention to repulsiveness in nutriment.🔽He should review the food as “Feces” in the way beginning “This rice, when it is digested” .

original: paccavekkhanto aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ āhāraṃ āhāreti, neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya
analyzed: paccavekkhantaḥ aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam āhāram āhāreti na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya
translated: He should eat the food possessed of the eight factors, not for sport, not for indulgence, not for smartening, not for embellishment,🔽but only for the support and continuance of this body, for ending discomfort, and for assisting the holy life, considering “I shall terminate this old feeling and not produce another, and I shall maintain myself, be blameless, and live in comfort.”

original: na vibhūsanāya…pe… bhuttāvī ca udakakiccaṃ katvā muhuttaṃ bhattakilamathaṃ paṭippassambhetvā
analyzed: na vibhūsanāyape bhuttāvī ca udaka kiccam katvā muhuttam bhatta kilamatham paṭippassambhetvā
translated: After he has eaten and has disposed of his bowl, he should cool his heated face by washing it, and after he has removed any fatigue due to eating,

original: yathā purebhattaṃ, evaṃ pacchābhattaṃ purimayāmaṃ pacchimayāmañca kammaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: yathā purebhattam evam pacchābhattam purima yāmam pacchima yāmam ca kammaṭṭhānam eva
translated: he should bring his meditation subject to mind in the way already described, both before and after his meal, during the first and last watches of the night.

original: manasi karoti, ayaṃ vuccati harati ca paccāharati cāti.
analyzed: manasi karoti ayam vuccati harati ca paccāharati ca ati
translated: This is called “he both takes and brings back.”

original: Idaṃ pana haraṇapaccāharaṇasaṅkhātaṃ gatapaccāgatavattaṃ pūrento yadi upanissayasampanno
analyzed: idam pana haraṇa paccāharaṇa saṅkhātam gata paccāgata vattam pūrentaḥ yadi upanissaya sampannaḥ
translated: Now, while he is fulfilling the practice of going and coming, which is called “taking and bringing back,” if he has the requisite faculties,

original: hoti, paṭhamavaye eva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. No ce paṭhamavaye pāpuṇāti, atha majjhimavaye;
analyzed: hoti paṭhama vaye eva arahattam pāpuṇāti no ce paṭhama vaye pāpuṇāti atha majjhima vaye
translated: he attains it in the first stage of life. If he does not attain it in the first stage of life, then in the middle stage of life;

original: no ce majjhimavaye pāpuṇāti, atha maraṇasamaye; no ce maraṇasamaye pāpuṇāti, atha
analyzed: no ce majjhima vaye pāpuṇāti atha maraṇa samaye no ce maraṇa samaye pāpuṇāti atha
translated: if he does not attain it in the middle stage of life, then at the time of death; if he does not attain it at the time of death, then

original: devaputto hutvā; no ce devaputto hutvā pāpuṇāti, anuppanne buddhe nibbatto paccekabodhiṃ
analyzed: deva puttaḥ hutvā no ce deva puttaḥ hutvā pāpuṇāti anuppanne buddhe nibbattaḥ paccekabodhim
translated: as a god; if he does not attain it as a god, when the Buddhas have not arisen he is reborn and realizes the Paccekabodhi.

original: sacchikaroti. No ce paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti, atha buddhānaṃ sammukhībhāve khippābhiñño
analyzed: sacchikaroti no ce paccekabodhim sacchikaroti atha buddhānam sammukhībhāve khippa abhiññaḥ
translated: If he does not realize the Paccekabodhi, then when the Buddhas have arisen he is quick to penetrate;

original: hoti; seyyathāpi thero bāhiyo dārucīriyo mahāpañño vā, seyyathāpi thero sāriputto
analyzed: hoti seyyathāpi theraḥ bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ mahā pañño vā seyyathāpi thero sāriputto
translated: just as the Elder Bāhiya Dārucīriya was of great wisdom, or just as the Elder Sāriputta

original: mahiddhiko vā, seyyathāpi thero mahāmoggallāno dhutavādo vā, seyyathāpi thero mahākassapo
analyzed: mahiddhikaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ mahāmoggallānaḥ dhuta vādaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ mahākassapo
translated: was of great psychic power, or just as the Elder Mahāmoggallāna was a proponent of the ascetic practices, or just as the Elder Mahākassapa

original: dibbacakkhuko vā, seyyathāpi thero anuruddho vinayadharo vā, seyyathāpi thero upāli
analyzed: dibba cakkhukaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ anuruddhaḥ vinaya dharaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ upāli
translated: had the divine eye, or just as the Elder Anuruddha was a master of the Vinaya, or just as the Elder Upāli

original: dhammakathiko vā, seyyathāpi thero puṇṇo mantāṇiputto āraññiko vā, seyyathāpi thero
analyzed: dhamma kathikaḥ vā seyyathāpi thero puṇṇaḥ mantāṇi putto āraññikaḥ vā seyyathāpi thero
translated: was a preacher of the Dhamma, or just as the Elder Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta was a forest-dweller, or just as the Elder

original: revato bahussuto vā, seyyathāpi thero ānando bhikkhākāmo vā, seyyathāpi thero rāhulo
analyzed: revataḥ bahussutaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ ānandaḥ bhikkhākāmaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ rāhulo
translated: and Revata, who was learned, and like the elder Ānanda, who was devoted to the bhikkhus, and like the elder Rāhula,

original: buddhaputtoti. Iti imasmiṃ catukke yvāyaṃ harati ca paccāharati ca, tassa gocarasampajaññaṃ sikhāpattaṃ hoti.
analyzed: buddha putto ti iti imasmim catukke yvā ayam harati ca paccāharati ca tassa gocara sampajaññam sikhāpattam hoti
translated: who was the Enlightened One’s son. So in this tetrad the one who both takes and returns has the kind of mindfulness of resort that is like the crest-jewel.

original: Abhikkamādīsu pana asammuyhanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ, taṃ evaṃ veditabbaṃ – idha bhikkhu
analyzed: abhikkama ādīsu pana a sammuyhanam a sammoha sampajaññam tam evam veditabbam idha bhikkhu
translated: But the non-delusion about going forward, etc., is mindfulness of non-delusion. That should be understood as follows. Here a bhikkhu,

original: abhikkamanto vā paṭikkamanto vā yathā andhabālaputhujjanā abhikkamādīsu – “attā abhikkamati,
analyzed: abhikkamantaḥ vā paṭikkamantaḥ vā yathā andha bāla puthujjanāḥ abhikkama ādīsu attā abhikkamati
translated: when going forward or returning, does not go about confused as to the four noble truths do the foolish, ignorant, confused ordinary people who go about confused as to the four noble truths, thinking, “It is the self that goes forward or returns,”

original: attanā abhikkamo nibbattito”ti vā, “ahaṃ abhikkamāmi, mayā abhikkamo nibbattito”ti
analyzed: attanā abhikkamaḥ nibbattito ti vā aham abhikkamāmi mayā abhikkamaḥ nibbattito ti
translated: or “The self is the one that goes forward or returns,” or “The self is the one in whom the going forward or returning occurs,” or “It is the self that is confused or not confused,” or “The self is the one who is confused or not confused,” or “It is the self that is deluded or undeluded,” or “The self is the one who is deluded or undeluded,”

original: vā sammuyhanti, tathā asammuyhanto “abhikkamāmī”ti citte uppajjamāne teneva cittena
analyzed: vā sammuyhanti tathā a sammuyhantaḥ abhikkamāmi iti citte uppajjamāne tena iva cittena
translated: but he goes forward or returns with a mind that is not confused, thinking, “It is a mental process that goes forward or returns,” or “A mental process is the one that goes forward or returns,” or “A mental process is the one in whom the going forward or returning occurs,” or “It is a mental process that is confused or not confused,” or “A mental process is the one that is confused or not confused,” or “It is a mental process that is deluded or undeluded,” or “A mental process is the one that is deluded or undeluded.”

original: saddhiṃ cittasamuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattiṃ janayamānā uppajjati. Iti cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāravasena
analyzed: saddhim citta samuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattim janayamānā uppajjati iti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena
translated: So when the mind arises thus, the air element that is its forerunner and is derived from the four primary elements arises generating the intimation. Thus it is by the distension of the air element that is the function of consciousness that

original: ayaṃ kāyasammato aṭṭhisaṅghāto abhikkamati. Tassevaṃ abhikkamato ekekapāduddharaṇe
analyzed: ayam kāya sammataḥ aṭṭhi saṅghātaḥ abhikkamati tassa ivam abhikkamataḥ ekeka pāda uddharaṇe
translated: The skeleton, which is called the body, is carried out.

original: pathavīdhātu āpodhātūti dve dhātuyo omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā honti🔽balavatiyo; tathā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesu. Vossajjane tejodhātu vāyodhātūti dve dhātuyo
analyzed: pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu uti dve dhātuyaḥ omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ honti  tathā atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu vossajjane tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu iti dve
translated: When it is carried out, the earth element and the water element are diminished and weak in the two elements that are carried out,🔽while the other two are dominant and strong. So too in the case of the carrying away and the throwing away.🔽In the case of the throwing down, the fire element and the wind element are diminished and weak in the two elements that are thrown down,

original: omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā balavatiyo, tathā sannikkhepanasannirujjhanesu.🔽Tattha uddharaṇe pavattā rūpārūpadhammā atiharaṇaṃ na pāpuṇanti, tathā atiharaṇe
analyzed: omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ balavatiyaḥ tathā sannikkhepana sannirujjhanesu  tattha uddharaṇe pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ atiharaṇam na pāpuṇanti tathā atiharaṇe
translated: while the other two are dominant and strong. So too in the case of the laying down and the settling down.🔽Herein, the material and immaterial states occurring in the carrying out do not reach the carrying away,

original: pavattā vītiharaṇaṃ, vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanaṃ, vossajjane pavattā sannikkhepanaṃ,
analyzed: pavattā vītiharaṇam vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanam vossajjane pavattā sannikkhepanam
translated: and so too the states occurring in the carrying away do not reach the throwing away, those occurring in the throwing away do not reach the throwing down, those occurring in the throwing down do not reach the laying down,

original: sannikkhepane pavattā sannirujjhanaṃ na pāpuṇanti. Tattha tattheva pabbaṃ pabbaṃ
analyzed: sannikkhepane pavattā sannirujjhanam na pāpuṇanti tattha tattha iva pabbam pabbam
translated: and those occurring in the laying down do not reach the settling down. There, in each case, the bone breaks with a snap like a bamboo splint,

original: sandhi sandhi odhi odhi hutvā tattakapāle pakkhittatilāni viya paṭapaṭāyantā bhijjanti.
analyzed: sandhi sandhi odhi odhi hutvā tatta kapāle pakkhitta tilāni viya paṭapaṭāyantā bhijjanti
translated: with the bone-end at the place where the fracture occurs becoming like a peg or like a bolt.

original: Tattha ko eko abhikkamati, kassa vā ekassa abhikkamanaṃ? Paramatthato hi dhātūnaṃyeva
analyzed: tattha kaḥ ekaḥ abhikkamati kassa vā ekassa abhikkamanam paramatthataḥ hi dhātūnam yeva
translated: Herein, who is it that goes forward or back? Whose going forward or back is it? For in the ultimate sense🔽it is the elements that go forward or back,

original: gamanaṃ, dhātūnaṃ ṭhānaṃ, dhātūnaṃ nisajjanaṃ, dhātūnaṃ sayanaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ koṭṭhāse saddhiṃ rūpena.
analyzed: gamanam dhātūnam ṭhānam dhātūnam nisajjanam dhātūnam sayanam tasmin tasmin koṭṭhāse saddhim rūpena
translated: the elements that stand still, sit down, or lie down, in such and such a place together with the material form.🔽“Another consciousness arises,

original: Aññaṃ uppajjate cittaṃ, aññaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati;
analyzed: aññam uppajjate cittam aññam cittam nirujjhati
translated: Another ceases, in constant flux;🔽The stream of consciousness flows on,

original: Avīcimanusambandho, nadīsotova vattatīti.
analyzed: avīci manu sambandhaḥ nadī sotaḥ uva vattati iti
translated: Like water down a steep hill slide.”

original: Evaṃ abhikkamādīsu asammuyhanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ nāmāti.🔽Niṭṭhito abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hotīti padassa attho.
analyzed: evam abhikkama ādīsu a sammuyhanam a sammoha sampajaññam nāma ati  niṭṭhitaḥ abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti iti padassa attho
translated: So non-confusion about going forward and back is called “clear comprehension of non-delusion.”🔽The meaning of the clause “he is one who acts with clear comprehension in looking forward and behind” has now been stated.

original: Ālokite vilokiteti ettha pana ālokitaṃ nāma purato pekkhaṇaṃ. Vilokitaṃ nāma anudisāpekkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ālokite vilokita iti ettha pana ālokitam nāma puratas pekkhaṇam vilokitam nāma anudisā apekkhaṇam
translated: As regards the clause “in looking straight on and in looking away,” looking straight on is looking in front,🔽and looking away is looking to the left and right.

original: Aññānipi heṭṭhā upari pacchato pekkhaṇavasena olokitaullokitāpalokitāni nāma honti,🔽tāni idha na gahitāni. Sāruppavasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni, iminā vā mukhena
analyzed: aññāni api heṭṭhā upari pacchatas pekkhaṇa vasena olokita aullokita apalokitāni nāma honti  tāni idha na gahitāni sāruppa vasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni iminā vā mukhena
translated: There are also looking up, looking down, and looking sideways,🔽but these are not included here. However, these two are included by implication,

original: sabbānipi tāni gahitānevāti.
analyzed: sabbāni api tāni gahitāni eva ati
translated: or all of them are included by these two.

original: Tattha “ālokessāmī”ti citte uppanne cittavaseneva anoloketvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ sātthakasampajaññaṃ,
analyzed: tattha ālokessāmi iti citte uppanne citta vasena iva anoloketvā attha pariggaṇhanam sa atthaka sampajaññam
translated: Herein, the discerning of the meaning by the mind’s being set on the meaning when the thought “I shall look” has arisen, without looking by the eye faculty, is the act of clear comprehension of purpose.

original: taṃ āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ kāyasakkhiṃ katvā veditabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā – “sace,🔽bhikkhave, nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti, sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā
analyzed: tam āyasmantam nandam kāya sakkhim katvā veditabbam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā sace  bhikkhave nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā
translated: That should be understood as referring to the venerable Nanda as a bodily witness. For this is said by the Blessed One: “If, bhikkhus, the eastern direction were to be ablaze, I should tell Nanda to look at it;🔽and if, after looking, evil, unprofitable states should increase in him and profitable states should diminish, then he should look away again;

original: nando puratthimaṃ disaṃ āloketi – ‘evaṃ me puratthimaṃ disaṃ ālokayato na abhijjhādomanassā🔽pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. Sace, bhikkhave,
analyzed: nando puratthimam disam āloketi evam me puratthimam disam ālokayataḥ na abhijjhā domanassā  pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ anvāssavissanti iti iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti sace bhikkhave
translated: but if he finds that, after looking, evil, unprofitable states diminish in him and profitable states increase, then he may look as much as he wants;🔽and if, bhikkhus, the western direction … the northern direction … the southern direction … the direction below … the direction above …

original: nandassa pacchimā disā…pe… uttarā disā…pe… dakkhiṇā disā…pe… uddhaṃ…pe… adho…pe…🔽anudisā anuviloketabbā hoti, sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā nando anudisaṃ anuviloketi
analyzed: nandassa pacchimā disāpe uttarā disāpe dakkhiṇā disāpe uddhaṃpe adhope 🔽anudisā anuviloketabbā hoti sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā nandaḥ anudisam anuviloketi
translated: the intermediate directions were to be ablaze, I should tell Nanda to look at it;🔽and if, after looking, evil, unprofitable states should increase in him and profitable states should diminish, then he should look away again;🔽but if he finds that, after looking, evil, unprofitable states diminish in him and profitable states increase, then he may look as much as he wants;

original: – ‘evaṃ me anudisaṃ anuvilokayato na abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti.
analyzed: evam me anudisam anuvilokayataḥ na abhijjhā domanassāḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ anvāssavissanti iti
translated: ‘As I look up, down, sideways, etc., evil unwholesome states of covetousness and grief will not invade me.’

original: Itiha tattha sampajāno hotī”ti.
analyzed: iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti iti
translated: Thus he is aware of it therein.”

original: Api ca idhāpi pubbe vuttacetiyadassanādivaseneva sātthakatā ca sappāyatā ca veditabbā,
analyzed: api ca idha api pubbe vutta cetiya dassana ādi vasena iva sātthaka tā ca sappāya tā ca veditabbā
translated: And here too the meaning of “with reference to” should be understood as already stated in the case of seeing the relic shrine, and so on.🔽But the mere fact of not abandoning the meditation subject is the mindfulness concerned with the present.

original: kammaṭṭhānassa pana avijahanameva gocarasampajaññaṃ. Tasmā ettha khandhadhātuāyatanakammaṭṭhānikehi
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānassa pana a vijahanam eva gocara sampajaññam tasmai ettha khandha dhātu āyatana kammaṭṭhānikehi
translated: So those who have the meditation subjects of the aggregates, sense bases, and elements🔽should look straight on and look away from the front only with their meditation subject,

original: attano kammaṭṭhānavaseneva, kasiṇādikammaṭṭhānikehi vā pana kammaṭṭhānasīseneva ālokanaṃ
analyzed: attano kammaṭṭhāna vasena iva kasiṇa ādi kamma ṭṭhānikehi vā pana kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva ālokanam
translated: or those who have the kasiṇa, etc., only with their meditation subject.

original: vilokanaṃ kātabbaṃ. Abbhantare attā nāma āloketā vā viloketā vā natthi, ‘ālokessāmī’ti🔽pana citte uppajjamāne teneva cittena saddhiṃ cittasamuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattiṃ
analyzed: vilokanam kātabbam abbhantare attā nāma āloketā vā viloketā vā natthi ālokessāmi iti  pana citte uppajjamāne tena iva cittena saddhim citta samuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattim
translated: There is no self at all that looks straight on or looks away from the front. But when the thought occurs, “I shall look straight on,”🔽the mind-born air element that arises together with that thought generates intimation.

original: janayamānā uppajjati. Iti cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāravasena heṭṭhimaṃ akkhidalaṃ
analyzed: janayamānā uppajjati iti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena heṭṭhimam akkhi dalam
translated: So the upper eyelid moves up and the lower eyelid moves down through the impact of the current of air that arises spreading out from the air element that is the function of consciousness.

original: adho sīdati, uparimaṃ uddhaṃ laṅgheti. Koci yantakena vivaranto nāma natthi. Tato
analyzed: adhas sīdati uparimam uddham laṅgheti koci yantakena vivarantaḥ nāma natthi tatas
translated: it sinks below and the upper part rises up. There is no one who opens it with a lever.🔽From that

original: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ sādhentaṃ uppajjatīti evaṃ pajānanaṃ panettha asammohasampajaññaṃ🔽nāma. Api ca mūlapariññā āgantukatāva kālikabhāvavasena pettha asammohasampajaññaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam sādhentam uppajjati iti evam pajānanam pana ittha asammoha sampajaññam  nāma api ca mūla pariññā kālika bhāva vasena pettha asammoha sampajaññam
translated: eye-consciousness arises accomplishing the function of seeing. The knowledge of this is called knowledge of comprehension of non-delusion.🔽Moreover, knowledge of comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here as the knowledge of the root, the knowledge of the adventitious, and the knowledge of the state of being present.

original: veditabbaṃ. Mūlapariññāvasena tāva –🔽Bhavaṅgāvajjanañceva, dassanaṃ sampaṭicchanaṃ;
analyzed: veditabbam mūla pariññā vasena tāva  dassanam sampaṭicchanam
translated: As to the knowledge of the root:🔽The life-continuum, adverting, Seeing, receiving,

original: Santīraṇaṃ voṭṭhabbanaṃ, javanaṃ bhavati sattamaṃ.
analyzed: santīraṇam voṭṭhabbanam javanam bhavati sattamam
translated: Investigating, determining, Impulsion, and registration.

original: Tattha bhavaṅgaṃ upapattibhavassa aṅgakiccaṃ sādhayamānaṃ pavattati, taṃ āvaṭṭetvā🔽kiriyamanodhātu āvajjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, taṃnirodhā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ
analyzed: tattha bhavaṅgam upapatti bhavassa aṅga kiccam sādhayamānam pavattati tam āvaṭṭetvā  kiriya manaḥ dhātu āvajjana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam
translated: Herein, the life-continuum occurs accomplishing the function of a link in the continuity of becoming. It is followed by

original: sādhayamānaṃ, taṃnirodhā vipākamanodhātu sampaṭicchanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, taṃnirodhā
analyzed: sādhayamānam vipāka manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchana kiccam sādhayamānā taṃnirodhā
translated: the functional mind element accomplishing the function of adverting. That ceases and is followed by eye-consciousness accomplishing the function of seeing. That ceases and is followed by resultant mind element accomplishing the function of receiving. That ceases and is followed by

original: vipākamanoviññāṇadhātu santīraṇakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, taṃnirodhā kiriyamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: vipāka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇa kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā kiriya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: The resultant mind-consciousness element accomplishes the function of adverting, and on its cessation the functional mind-consciousness element

original: voṭṭhabbanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, taṃnirodhā sattakkhattuṃ javanaṃ javati. Tattha paṭhamajavanepi🔽– “ayaṃ itthī, ayaṃ puriso”ti rajjanadussanamuyhanavasena ālokitavilokitaṃ nāma na
analyzed: voṭṭhabbana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā satta kkhattum javanam javati tattha paṭhama javane pi  ayam itthī ayam purisaḥ iti rajjana dussana muyhana vasena ālokitavilokitam nāma na
translated: accomplishes the function of determining. On its cessation, impulsion occurs seven times. Herein, in the first impulsion

original: hoti. Dutiyajavanepi…pe… sattamajavanepi. Etesu pana yuddhamaṇḍale yodhesu viya heṭṭhupariyavasena🔽bhijjitvā patitesu – “ayaṃ itthī, ayaṃ puriso”ti rajjanādivasena ālokitavilokitaṃ
analyzed: hoti sattama javane pi etesu pana yuddha maṇḍale yodhesu viya heṭṭhu pariya vasena  bhijjitvā patitesu ayam itthī ayam purisaḥ iti rajjana ādi vasena ālokita vilokitam
translated: there is no looking and so on with lust, hate, or delusion, as there is in the case of the thought “This is a woman,” “This is a man.” In the second impulsion … In the seventh impulsion …

original: hoti. Evaṃ tāvettha mūlapariññāvasena asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Cakkhudvāre pana rūpe āpāthamāgate bhavaṅgacalanato uddhaṃ sakakiccanipphādanavasena
analyzed: hoti evam tāva ittha mūla pariññā vasena asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  cakkhu dvāre pana rūpe āpātham āgate bhavaṅga calanato uddham saka kicca nipphādana vasena
translated: But when they have broken up and fallen as in a battle, then looking and so on with lust and so on occurs as the thought “This is a woman,” “This is a man.” This, in the first place, is how non-delusion should be understood here as knowledge of the beginning.🔽But when the visible-data object has come into the eye’s focus, after the wavering of the life-continuum,

original: āvajjanādīsu uppajjitvā niruddhesu avasāne javanaṃ uppajjati, taṃ pubbe uppannānaṃ
analyzed: āvajjana ādīsu uppajjitvā niruddhesu avasāne javanam uppajjati tam pubbe uppannānam
translated: the adverting, etc., occur and cease, producing their respective functions, and finally impulsion occurs. That impulsion arises in the way beginning “On cessation of what is arisen … ” .

original: āvajjanādīnaṃ gehabhūte cakkhudvāre āgantukapuriso viya hoti. Tassa yathā paragehe🔽kiñci yācituṃ paviṭṭhassa āgantukapurisassa gehassāmikesu tuṇhīmāsinesu āṇākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: āvajjana ādīnam geha bhūte cakkhu dvāre āgantuka purisaḥ viya hoti tassa yathā para gehe  kiñci yācitum paviṭṭhassa āgantuka purisassa geha sāmikesu tuṇhī māsinesu āṇākaraṇam
translated: They are like a visitor who comes to the eye door, which is like a house.🔽Just as it is not proper for a visitor who has come to a house to give orders to the owners of the house who are silent and do not speak,

original: na yuttaṃ, evaṃ āvajjanādīnaṃ gehabhūte cakkhudvāre āvajjanādīsupi arajjantesu adussantesu
analyzed: na yuttam evam āvajjana ādīnam geha bhūte cakkhu dvāre āvajjana ādīsu pi a rajjantesu a dussantesu
translated: so too, it is not proper for the adverting, etc., to be greedy, hate, or deluded, when the eye door, which is like a house, and the adverting, etc., which are like the owners of the house, are not greedy, hate, or deluded.

original: amuyhantesu ca rajjanadussanamuyhanaṃ ayuttanti evaṃ āgantukabhāvavasena asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: a muyhantesu ca rajjana dussana muyhanam ayuttan ti evam āgantuka bhāva vasena asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: Thus non-delusion in being mindful should be understood as the state of being a visitor.

original: Yāni panetāni cakkhudvāre voṭṭhabbanapariyosānāni cittāni uppajjanti, tāni saddhiṃ
analyzed: yāni pana etāni cakkhu dvāre voṭṭhabbana pariyosānāni cittāni uppajjanti tāni saddhim
translated: But the consciousnesses that arise in the eye door, ending with the determining,

original: sampayuttadhammehi tattha tattheva bhijjanti, aññamaññaṃ na passantīti, ittarāni🔽tāvakālikāni honti. Tattha yathā ekasmiṃ ghare sabbesu mānusakesu matesu avasesassa
analyzed: sampayutta dhammehi tattha tattha iva bhijjanti aññam aññam na passanti iti ittarāni  tāvakālikāni honti tattha yathā ekasmin ghare sabbesu mānusakesu matesu avasesassa
translated: break up there and then with their associated states, and they do not see each other. They are few,

original: ekassa taṅkhaṇaññeva maraṇadhammassa na yuttā naccagītādīsu abhirati nāma. Evameva
analyzed: ekassa maraṇa dhammassa na yuttā nacca gīta ādīsu abhirati nāma evam eva
translated: and they are momentary. Just as it is not proper for one who is about to die at that moment to take delight in dancing, singing, etc., when all the human beings in a certain house have died and only he is left,🔽so too, it is not proper for the consciousnesses that arise in the eye door to take delight in visible data, etc.

original: ekadvāre sasampayuttesu āvajjanādīsu tattha tattheva matesu avasesassa taṅkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: eka dvāre sa sampayuttesu āvajjana ādīsu tattha tattha iva matesu avasesassa
translated: and when one or other of the associated states beginning with adverting has ceased, the rest, which are subject to death at that very moment,

original: maraṇadhammassa javanassāpi rajjanadussanamuyhanavasena abhirati nāma na yuttāti.
analyzed: maraṇa dhammassa javanassa api rajjana dussana muyhana vasena abhirati nāma na yuttā ati
translated: cannot be called delight because of the absence of greed, hate and delusion in impulsion.

original: Evaṃ tāvakālikabhāvavasena asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam tāvakālika bhāva vasena asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: This is how it should be understood as non-delusion through being the opposite of the three roots.

original: Api ca khandhāyatanadhātupaccayapaccavekkhaṇavasena petaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ettha hi cakkhu
analyzed: api ca khandha āyatana dhātu paccaya paccavekkhaṇa vasena petam veditabbam ettha hi cakkhu
translated: And it should be understood as non-delusion through reviewing the aggregates, bases, and elements, for here

original: ceva rūpā ca rūpakkhandho, dassanaṃ viññāṇakkhandho, taṃsampayuttā vedanā vedanākkhandho,
analyzed: ca iva rūpā ca rūpa kkhandho dassanam viññāṇa kkhandho tad sampayuttā vedanā vedanā kkhandho
translated: the eye and the visible data are the form aggregate, seeing is the consciousness aggregate, the feeling associated with that is the feeling aggregate,🔽the perception is the perception aggregate, and the contact, etc., are the formations aggregate.

original: saññā saññākkhandho, phassādikā saṅkhārakkhandho. Evametesaṃ pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ
analyzed: saññā saññā kkhandho phassa ādikā saṅkhāra kkhandho evam etesam pañcannam khandhānam
translated: So when there is a combination of these five aggregates,

original: samavāye ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati. Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi?
analyzed: samavāye ālokana vilokanam paññāyati tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi
translated: looking straight on and looking away are evident. Here, who is it that looks straight on? Who is it that looks away?🔽Similarly, the eye is the eye base, visible data are the form base, seeing is the mind base,

original: Tathā cakkhu cakkhāyatanaṃ, rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ, dassanaṃ manāyatanaṃ, vedanādayo sampayuttadhammā
analyzed: tathā cakkhu cakkha āyatanam rūpam rūpa āyatanam dassanam manāyatanam vedanā ādayo sampayutta dhammā
translated: and the associated states of feeling, etc.,

original: dhammāyatanaṃ. Evametesaṃ catunnaṃ āyatanānaṃ samavāye ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati.
analyzed: dhammāyatanam evam etesam catunnam āyatanānam samavāye ālokana vilokanam paññāyati
translated: So it is by the concurrence of these four bases that looking straight on and looking away are manifested.

original: Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi?🔽Tathā cakkhu cakkhudhātu, rūpaṃ rūpadhātu, dassanaṃ cakkhuviññāṇadhātu, taṃsampayuttā
analyzed: tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloka iti kaḥ viloka iti  tathā cakkhu cakkhu dhātu rūpam rūpa dhātu dassanam cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu tad sampayuttā
translated: Herein, who is it that looks straight on and who that looks away?

original: vedanādayo dhammā dhammadhātu. Evametāsaṃ catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ samavāye ālokanavilokanaṃ
analyzed: vedanā ādayaḥ dhammāḥ dhamma dhātu evam etāsam catunnam dhātūnam samavāye ālokana vilokanam
translated: The eye is the eye element, the visible data are the form element, seeing is eye-consciousness element, and the associated feeling, etc., are the mental-data element. So it is by the concurrence of these four elements that looking straight on and looking away are manifested.

original: paññāyati. Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi?
analyzed: paññāyati tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi
translated: Herein, who is it that looks straight on and who that looks away?

original: Tathā cakkhu nissayapaccayo, rūpā ārammaṇapaccayo, āvajjanaṃ anantarasamanantarūpanissayanatthivigatapaccayo,🔽āloko upanissayapaccayo, vedanādayo sahajātapaccayo. Evametesaṃ paccayānaṃ samavāye
analyzed: tathā cakkhu nissaya paccayaḥ rūpāḥ ārammaṇa paccayaḥ āvajjanam anantara samananta rūpa nissaya natthi vigata paccayaḥ  ālokaḥ upanissaya paccayaḥ vedanā ādayo sahajāta paccayaḥ evam etesam paccayānam samavāye
translated: The eye is the support condition, the visible data are the object condition, adverting is the condition consisting in decisive support, prenascence, absence, and disappearance,

original: ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati. Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketīti? Evamettha khandhāyatanadhātupaccayapaccavekkhaṇavasenapi🔽asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ālokana vilokanam paññāyati tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi iti evam ettha khandha āyatana dhātu paccaya paccavekkhaṇa vasena pi 🔽a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: light is the proximity condition, feeling, etc., are the conascence condition. So it is by the concurrence of these conditions that looking straight on and looking away are manifested. Herein, who is it that looks straight on and who that looks away? So firstly, right understanding should be known as non-delusion by the method of reviewing the aggregates, bases, and elements.

original: Samiñjite pasāriteti pabbānaṃ samiñjanapasāraṇe. Tattha cittavaseneva samiñjanapasāraṇaṃ
analyzed: samiñjite pasāritā iti pabbānam samiñjana pasāraṇe tattha citta vasena iva samiñjana pasāraṇam
translated: In the flexing and extending of the knees: in the flexing and extending of the thighs. Herein, the flexing and extending are by the mind’s agency.

original: akatvā hatthapādānaṃ samiñjanapasāraṇapaccayā atthānatthaṃ pariggaṇhitvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ
analyzed: a katvā hattha pādānam samiñjana pasāraṇa paccayā attha anattham pariggaṇhitvā attha pariggaṇhanam
translated: In flexing and extending: in the flexing and extending of the limbs. Herein, the discerning of the useful is the discerning of the useful as the condition for the flexing and extending of the limbs, not for the flexing and extending by mere movement of the mind.

original: sātthakasampajaññaṃ. Tattha hatthapāde aticiraṃ samiñjetvā vā pasāretvā vā ṭhitassa
analyzed: sātthaka sampajaññam tattha hattha pāde aticiram samiñjetvā vā pasāretvā vā ṭhitassa
translated: For when one stands with the limbs flexed or extended too long,

original: khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjati, cittaṃ ekaggataṃ na labhati, kammaṭṭhānaṃ paripatati,
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjati cittam ekagga tam na labhati kammaṭṭhānam paripatati
translated: pain arises every moment and the mind does not become concentrated, the meditation subject does not come to growth, maturity and fulfilment,

original: visesaṃ nādhigacchati. Kāle samiñjentassa kāle pasārentassa pana tā vedanā nuppajjanti,
analyzed: visesam na adhigacchati kāle samiñjentassa kāle pasārentassa pana tāḥ vedanāḥ nuppajjanti
translated: but when one flexes and extends at the proper time, that pain does not arise,

original: cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ phātiṃ gacchati, visesamadhigacchatīti, evaṃ atthānatthapariggaṇhanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: cittam ekaggam hoti kammaṭṭhānam phātim gacchati visesam adhigacchati iti evam attha anattha pariggaṇhanam veditabbam
translated: the mind becomes concentrated, the meditation subject comes to growth, maturity and fulfilment. This is how the discerning of the useful should be understood.

original: Atthe pana satipi sappāyāsappāyaṃ pariggaṇhitvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ nayo –
analyzed: atthe pana sati pi sappāya a sappāyam pariggaṇhitvā sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam tatra ayam nayaḥ
translated: But when there is the useful, the discerning of what is suitable and unsuitable should be undertaken by discerning what is suitable after rejecting what is unsuitable. The discerning of what is suitable is the knowledge of what is suitable. Here is the explanation of it.

original: Mahācetiyaṅgaṇe kira daharabhikkhū sajjhāyaṃ gaṇhanti, tesaṃ piṭṭhipassesu daharabhikkhuniyo
analyzed: mahā cetiyaṅgaṇe kira dahara bhikkhū sajjhāyam gaṇhanti tesam piṭṭhi passesu dahara bhikkhuniyo
translated: It seems that young bhikkhus were reciting in the courtyard of the Great Relic Shrine. Young bhikkhunīs were listening to the Dhamma sitting behind them.

original: dhammaṃ suṇanti. Tatreko daharo hatthaṃ pasārento kāyasaṃsaggaṃ patvā teneva kāraṇena🔽gihī jāto. Aparo bhikkhu pādaṃ pasārento aggimhi pasāresi, aṭṭhimāhacca pādo jhāyi.
analyzed: dhammam suṇanti tatra ekaḥ daharaḥ hattham pasārentaḥ kāya saṃsaggam patvā tena iva kāraṇena  gihī jātaḥ aparaḥ bhikkhu pādam pasārentaḥ aggimhi pasāresi aṭṭhima ahacca pādaḥ jhāyi
translated: A certain young bhikkhu, while stretching his arm, made bodily contact with one of them. For that reason he became a layman.🔽Another bhikkhu, while stretching his foot, stretched it into a fire. His foot was burned to the bone.

original: Aparo vammike pasāresi, so āsīvisena ḍaṭṭho. Aparo cīvarakuṭidaṇḍake pasāresi, taṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ vammike pasāresi saḥ āsīvisena ḍaṭṭhaḥ aparaḥ cīvara kuṭi daṇḍake pasāresi tam
translated: Another stretched his foot into an ant-hill. He was bitten by a poisonous snake. Another stretched his foot into a bamboo walking-stick. A gem-snake bit him.

original: maṇisappo ḍaṃsi. Tasmā evarūpe asappāye apasāretvā sappāye pasāretabbaṃ. Idamettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ.🔽Gocarasampajaññaṃ pana mahātheravatthunā dīpetabbaṃ – mahāthero kira divāṭhāne nisinno
analyzed: maṇi sappaḥ tasmai evarūpe a sappāye apasāretvā sappāye pasāretabbam idam ettha sappāya sampajaññam  gocara sampajaññam pana mahā thera vatthunā dīpetabbam mahā theraḥ kira divāṭhāne nisinnaḥ
translated: So he should not stretch his limbs in an unsuitable place, but only in a suitable place. This is the knowledge of right and wrong occasions.🔽The knowledge of the right and wrong way should be illustrated by the story of the Elder Maha Tissa. It seems that the elder was sitting in the day-time hall talking with his pupils.

original: antevāsikehi saddhiṃ kathayamāno sahasā hatthaṃ samiñjetvā puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā
analyzed: antevāsikehi saddhim kathayamānaḥ sahasā hattham samiñjetvā puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā
translated: He suddenly drew in his arm and then put it back as it was.

original: saṇikaṃ samiñjesi. Taṃ antevāsikā pucchiṃsu – “kasmā, bhante, sahasā hatthaṃ samiñjitvā🔽puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā saṇikaṃ samiñjiyitthā”ti? Yato paṭṭhāyāhaṃ, āvuso, kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽manasikātuṃ āraddho, na me kammaṭṭhānaṃ muñcitvā hattho samiñjitapubbo, idāni pana🔽me tumhehi saddhiṃ kathayamānena kammaṭṭhānaṃ muñcitvā samiñjito. Tasmā puna yathāṭhāne
analyzed: saṇikam samiñjesi tam antevāsikā pucchiṃsu kasmai bhante sahasā hattham samiñjitvā  puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā saṇikam samiñjiyittha ati yatas paṭṭhāya aham āvuso kammaṭṭhānam  manasikātum āraddhaḥ na me kammaṭṭhānam muñcitvā hatthaḥ samiñjita pubbaḥ idāni pana  me tumhehi saddhim kathayamānena kammaṭṭhānam muñcitvā tasmai puna yathāṭhāne
translated: and slowly withdrew it. His pupils asked him, “Why, venerable sir, did you suddenly withdraw your hand and then slowly withdraw it after putting it back as it was?”🔽“Since I began to attend to the meditation subject, friends, I have never withdrawn my hand without first giving up the meditation subject. But now,🔽while I was talking with you, I gave up the meditation subject and withdrew my hand. That is why I put it back as it was and slowly withdrew it.”🔽

original: ṭhapetvā samiñjesinti. Sādhu, bhante, bhikkhunā nāma evarūpena bhavitabbanti. Evametthāpi🔽kammaṭṭhānāvijahanameva gocarasampajaññanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma koci samiñjento vā pasārento vā natthi, vuttappakāracittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena🔽pana suttākaḍḍhanavasena dāruyantassa hatthapādalacalanaṃ viya samiñjanapasāraṇaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetvā samiñjesinti sādhu bhante bhikkhunā nāma evarūpena bhavitabbanti evam ettha api 🔽kammaṭṭhāna avijahanam eva gocara sampajaññam ti veditabbam 🔽abbhantare attā nāma koci samiñjentaḥ vā pasārentaḥ vā natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena 🔽pana sutta ākaḍḍhana vasena dāruyantassa hattha pādala calanam viya samiñjana pasāraṇam
translated: and drew it in slowly. His pupils asked him, “Why, venerable sir, did you draw in your hand quickly and then draw it in slowly after putting it back in its former place?” —“Friends, since I began to give attention to the meditation subject, I have never drawn in my hand without first giving attention to the meditation subject. But now, while I was talking with you, I drew it in without first giving attention to it. That is why I put it back in its former place and drew it in after giving attention to the meditation subject. ” —“It is good, venerable sir, that a bhikkhu should be like this.” So here too it should be understood that the meditation subject is not to be abandoned even in the case of a bodily function.

original: hotīti evaṃ parijānanaṃ panettha asammohasampajaññanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇeti ettha saṅghāṭicīvarānaṃ nivāsanapārupanavasena pattassa🔽bhikkhāpaṭiggahaṇādivasena paribhogo dhāraṇaṃ nāma. Tattha saṅghāṭicīvaradhāraṇe
analyzed: hoti iti evam parijānanam pana ittha asammoha sampajaññan ti veditabbam  saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇā iti ettha saṅghāṭi cīvarānam nivāsana pārupana vasena pattassa  bhikkhā paṭiggahaṇa ādi vasena paribhogaḥ dhāraṇam nāma tattha saṅghāṭi cīvara dhāraṇe
translated: The understanding of this should be known as unconfused clear comprehension.🔽As to wearing the outer robe, bowl, and so on: here the use of the outer robe and the inner robe is the wearing of them; the use of the bowl is the receiving of alms, and so on.

original: tāva nivāsetvā vā pārupitvā vā piṇḍāya carato āmisalābho sītassa paṭighātāyātiādinā
analyzed: tāva nivāsetvā vā pārupitvā vā piṇḍāya carato āmisa lābho sītassa paṭighātāya ati ādinā
translated: Herein, the meaning stated by the Blessed One thus: “The outer robe is for the purpose of warding off cold” and so on is the meaning of wearing the outer robe and the inner robe.

original: nayena bhagavatā vuttappakāroyeva ca attho attho nāma. Tassa vasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nayena bhagavatā vutta ppakārā yā iva ca atthaḥ atthaḥ nāma tassa vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: The clear comprehension of this meaning should be understood as clear comprehension of purpose.🔽But a thin robe is suitable for one who is hot-natured or weak,

original: Uṇhapakatikassa pana dubbalassa ca cīvaraṃ sukhumaṃ sappāyaṃ, sītālukassa ghanaṃ
analyzed: uṇha pakatikassa pana dubbalassa ca cīvaram sukhumam sappāyam sītālukassa ghanam
translated: and a thick one is suitable for one who is cold-natured.

original: dupaṭṭaṃ. Viparītaṃ asappāyaṃ. Yassa kassaci jiṇṇaṃ asappāyameva, aggaḷādidānena
analyzed: dupaṭṭam viparītam asappāyam yassa kassaci jiṇṇam asappāyam eva aggaḷa ādi dānena
translated: The opposite is unsuitable. Any that is old is unsuitable. And if it has a button-slit or a patch it is obstructive.

original: hissa taṃ palibodhakaraṃ hoti. Tathā paṭṭuṇṇadukūlādibhedaṃ lobhanīyacīvaraṃ. Tādisañhi
analyzed: hissa tam palibodha karam hoti tathā paṭṭuṇṇa dukūla ādi bhedam lobhanīya cīvaram tādisam hi
translated: So too, a robe that is arousing is of the kind called “fine linen” and so on. For such a robe

original: araññe ekakassa nivāsantarāyakaraṃ jīvitantarāyakarañcāpi hoti. Nippariyāyena pana🔽yaṃ nimittakammādimicchājīvavasena uppannaṃ, yañcassa sevamānassa akusalā dhammā
analyzed: araññe ekakassa nivāsa antarāya karam jīvita antarāya karam ca api hoti nippariyāyena pana  yam nimitta kamma ādim icchājīva vasena uppannam yam ca assa sevamānassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: But in the ultimate sense,

original: abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, taṃ asappāyaṃ. Viparītaṃ sappāyaṃ. Tassa
analyzed: abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti tam a sappāyam viparītam sa ppāyam tassa
translated: what is unbeneficial is that which arises through the means of a sign, etc., and by wrong livelihood, and by the practice of which unwholesome states increase and wholesome states diminish in a man. The opposite of that is beneficial.

original: vasenettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: The understanding of what is beneficial should be understood here as the understanding of what is beneficial in the sense of that. The understanding of the surrounding district should be understood as the understanding of the surrounding district in the sense of not abandoning the meditation subject.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci cīvaraṃ pārupento natthi, vuttappakārena cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva🔽pana cīvarapārupanaṃ hoti. Tattha cīvarampi acetanaṃ, kāyopi acetano. Cīvaraṃ na🔽jānāti – “mayā kāyo pārupito”ti. Kāyopi na jānāti – “ahaṃ cīvarena pārupito”ti. Dhātuyova
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci cīvaram pārupentaḥ natthi vutta ppakārena citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva  pana cīvara pārupanam hoti tattha cīvaram pi acetanam kāyaḥ api acetanaḥ cīvaram na  jānāti mayā kāyaḥ pārupitaḥ iti kāyaḥ api na jānāti aham cīvarena pārupitaḥ iti
translated: There is no such thing as a self inside that puts on a robe. It is only by the diffusion of the air element that the action of the mind in the form of in-breaths and out-breaths occurs.🔽And the putting on of the robe is only by the diffusion of the mind-made air element of the kind already described. Herein, the robe is without consciousness, and the body is without consciousness. The robe does not know, “A body is clothed by me,”

original: dhātusamūhaṃ paṭicchādenti paṭapilotikāyapotthakarūpapaṭicchādane viya. Tasmā neva
analyzed: dhātu samūham paṭicchādenti tasmāt na iva
translated: nor does the body know, “I am clothed in a robe.” It is only elements that envelop a mass of elements, as a piece of cloth does a mass of cotton wool or as a skin does meat.🔽So,

original: sundaraṃ cīvaraṃ labhitvā somanassaṃ kātabbaṃ, na asundaraṃ labhitvā domanassaṃ.
analyzed: sundaram cīvaram labhitvā somanassam kātabbam na a sundaram labhitvā domanassam
translated: When he gets a fine robe, he should be glad, not displeased if he gets an inferior one.

original: Nāgavammikacetiyarukkhādīsu hi keci mālāgandhadhūmavatthādīhi sakkāraṃ karonti, keci🔽gūthamuttakaddamadaṇḍasatthappahārādīhi asakkāraṃ. Na tehi nāgavammikarukkhādayo🔽somanassaṃ vā domanassaṃ vā karonti. Evameva neva sundaraṃ cīvaraṃ labhitvā somanassaṃ
analyzed: nāga vammika cetiya rukkha ādīsu hi keci mālā gandha dhūma vattha ādīhi sakkāram karonti keci  gūtha muttaka ddama daṇḍa sattha ppahāra ādīhi asakkāram na tehi nāga vammika rukkha ādayaḥ  somanassam vā domanassam vā karonti evam eva na iva sundaram cīvaram labhitvā somanassam
translated: For some people honor the ant-hill, the tree, the shrine, etc., with garlands, scents, incense, cloth, etc.,🔽while others do not honor them in this way. But the ant-hill, the tree, the shrine, etc.,

original: kātabbaṃ, na asundaraṃ labhitvā domanassanti, evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: kātabbam na asundaram labhitvā evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: are not glad at the honors or displeased at the lack of them. So too, the bhikkhu should not be glad at getting a fine robe or displeased at getting an inferior one.

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: Thus the knowledge of non-delusion should be understood here in the sense of reflection in this way.

original: Pattadhāraṇepi pattaṃ sahasāva aggahetvā imaṃ gahetvā piṇḍāya caramāno bhikkhaṃ labhissāmīti, evaṃ pattaggahaṇapaccayā paṭilabhitabbaṃ atthavasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: patta dhāraṇe pi pattam sahasāva aggahetvā imam gahetvā piṇḍāya caramānaḥ bhikkham labhissāmi iti evam patta ggahaṇa paccayā paṭilabhitabbam attha vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: In the case of carrying the bowl, the knowledge of the beneficial should be understood in the sense of the benefit that is obtained by carrying the bowl in the way described, thinking, “I shall go for alms with this bowl and get almsfood.”

original: Kisadubbalasarīrassa pana garupatto asappāyo, yassa kassaci catupañcagaṇṭhikāhato🔽dubbisodhanīyo asappāyova. Duddhotapattopi na vaṭṭati, taṃ dhovantasseva cassa palibodho
analyzed: kisa dubbala sarīrassa pana garu pattaḥ asappāyaḥ yassa kassaci catu pañca gaṇṭhikā hato  dubbisodhanīyaḥ asappāyaḥ iva na vaṭṭati tam dhovantassa iva ca ssa palibodhaḥ
translated: But a heavy cloak is unsuitable for one whose body is weak from disease. Any cloak that has to be washed every four or five days is unsuitable,

original: hoti. Maṇivaṇṇapatto pana lobhanīyo, cīvare vuttanayeneva asappāyo, nimittakammādivasena
analyzed: hoti maṇi vaṇṇa patto pana lobhanīyaḥ cīvare vutta nayena iva asappāyaḥ nimitta kamma ādi vasena
translated: as it is too much trouble to wash. A cloak that is hard to wash is unsuitable. One that is dyed is tempting, and so it is unsuitable in the way already stated under robes.

original: laddho pana yañcassa sevamānassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti,
analyzed: laddhaḥ pana yat cassa sevamānassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti
translated: But if he gets one as a present and finds that unwholesome states increase and wholesome states diminish while he is using it,

original: ayaṃ ekantaasappāyova. Viparīto sappāyo. Tassa vasenettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva
analyzed: ayam ekanta asappāyaḥ iva viparīto sappāyo tassa vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva
translated: it is definitely unsuitable. The opposite kind is suitable. The clear comprehension of suitability here should be understood as the suitability for the meditation subject.

original: ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: And the clear comprehension of resort should be understood as the suitability for the meditation subject.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci pattaṃ gaṇhanto natthi, vuttappakārena cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāravaseneva
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci pattam gaṇhantaḥ natthi vutta ppakārena citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena iva
translated: There is no such thing as a self or being that takes the bowl. It is merely a term for a particular combination of elements, as stated.

original: pattaggahaṇaṃ nāma hoti. Tattha pattopi acetano, hatthāpi acetanā. Patto na jānāti
analyzed: patta gahaṇam nāma hoti tattha pattaḥ api acetanaḥ hatthā api acetanā pattaḥ na jānāti
translated: The bowl is not conscious, the hand is not conscious,

original: – “ahaṃ hatthehi gahito”ti. Hatthāpi na jānanti – “amhehi patto gahito”ti. Dhātuyova
analyzed: aham hatthehi gahito ti hatthā api na jānanti amhehi pattaḥ gahito ti
translated: “I am seized by the hands.” And the hands do not know, “The patient is seized by us.”

original: dhātusamūhaṃ gaṇhanti, saṇḍāsena aggivaṇṇapattaggahaṇe viyāti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: dhātu samūham gaṇhanti saṇḍāsena aggi vaṇṇa patta ggahaṇe viyā ti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: It is only the elements that seize the aggregate of elements, as a stick seizes a bird.

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Api ca yathā chinnahatthapāde vaṇamukhehi paggharitapubbalohitakimikule nīlamakkhikasamparikiṇṇe
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  api ca yathā chinna hattha pāde vaṇa mukhehi paggharita pubba lohita kimi kule nīla makkhika samparikiṇṇe
translated: So the clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here in the way stated by the method of reflection.

original: anāthasālāyaṃ nipanne anāthamanusse disvā, ye dayālukā purisā, te tesaṃ vaṇamattacoḷakāni
analyzed: anātha sālāyam nipanne anātha manusse disvā ye dayālukā purisā te tesam vaṇa matta coḷakāni
translated: Moreover, when people who are kind see a helpless man lying in a public hospital ward, his limbs cut off, his body covered with maggots and festering sores, swarming with flies,🔽they bring him cloth bandages and medicinal leaves, etc., and they give him food.

original: ceva kapālādīhi ca bhesajjāni upanāmenti. Tattha coḷakānipi kesañci saṇhāni, kesañci
analyzed: ca iva kapāla ādīhi ca bhesajjāni upanāmenti tattha coḷakāni pi kesañci saṇhāni kesañci
translated: Herein, some of the bandages are smooth and some are rough.

original: thūlāni pāpuṇanti. Bhesajjakapālakānipi kesañci susaṇṭhānāni, kesañci dussaṇṭhānāni
analyzed: thūlāni pāpuṇanti bhesajja kapālakāni pi kesañci su saṇṭhānāni kesañci dussaṇṭhānāni
translated: And some of the medicinal leaves are well-formed and some are misshapen.

original: pāpuṇanti, na te tattha sumanā vā dummanā vā honti. Vaṇapaṭicchādanamatteneva hi
analyzed: pāpuṇanti na te tattha sumanāḥ vā dummanāḥ vā honti vaṇa paṭicchādana mattena iva hi
translated: But the kind people do not become glad at the thought that he gets a smooth bandage or sorry at the thought that he gets a rough one, or glad at the thought that he gets well-formed medicinal leaves or sorry at the thought that he gets misshapen ones.🔽For they are intent only on the healing of his wounds.

original: coḷakena, bhesajjapaṭiggahaṇamatteneva ca kapālakena tesaṃ attho. Evameva yo bhikkhu
analyzed: coḷakena bhesajja paṭiggahaṇa mattena iva ca kapālakena tesam atthaḥ evam eva yaḥ bhikkhu
translated: And they had no further use for the rag-robe or the bowl.

original: vaṇacoḷakaṃ viya cīvaraṃ, bhesajjakapālakaṃ viya ca pattaṃ, kapāle bhesajjamiva ca
analyzed: vaṇa coḷakam viya cīvaram bhesajja kapālakam viya ca pattam kapāle bhesajjam iva ca
translated: So too, when a bhikkhu considers the robe as a rag-robe, the bowl as a bowl for alms, and the alms food as medicine taken in a bowl,

original: patte laddhaṃ bhikkhaṃ sallakkheti, ayaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe asammohasampajaññena🔽uttamasampajānakārīti veditabbo.
analyzed: patte laddham bhikkham sallakkheti ayam saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe a sammoha sampajaññena  uttama sampajāna kārī iti veditabbaḥ
translated: he is called one who has reached the consummation of clear comprehension in wearing the triple robe, carrying the bowl, and receiving alms food.🔽As to the words “eating, drinking, tasting, and sucking,” “eating” is eating staple foods such as rice;

original: Asitādīsu asiteti piṇḍapātabhojane. Pīteti yāguādipāne. Khāyiteti piṭṭhakhajjādikhādane.
analyzed: asita ādīsu asita iti piṇḍapāta bhojane pīta iti yāgu ādi pāne khāyita iti piṭṭha khajja ādi khādane
translated: “drinking” is drinking beverages such as sugar-cane juice; “tasting” is tasting non-staple foods such as fresh meat; “sucking” is sucking sugar cane, molasses, etc.,

original: Sāyiteti madhuphāṇitādisāyane. Tattha neva davāyātiādinā nayena vutto aṭṭhavidhopi
analyzed: sāyita iti madhu phāṇita ādi sāyane tattha na iva davāya ati ādinā nayena vutto aṭṭhavidhaḥ api
translated: The eight kinds of meaning stated in the way beginning, “Not for the purpose of amusement” are called “meaning.”

original: attho attho nāma. Tasseva vasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Lūkhapaṇītatittamadhurarasādīsu pana yena bhojanena yassa phāsu na hoti, taṃ tassa
analyzed: atthaḥ atthaḥ nāma tassa iva vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam veditabbam  lūkha paṇīta titta madhura rasa ādīsu pana yena bhojanena yassa phāsu na hoti tam tassa
translated: The clear comprehension of what is beneficial should be understood as the beneficial itself.🔽But what is unsuitable for one is not suitable for another, according as one is of sharp or sluggish temperament, etc.,

original: asappāyaṃ. Yaṃ pana nimittakammādivasena paṭiladdhaṃ, yañcassa bhuñjato akusalā dhammā
analyzed: asappāyam yam pana nimitta kamma ādi vasena paṭiladdham yat ca assa bhuñjato akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: and what is suitable for one at one time is unsuitable for him at another time, according as he is in a healthy or unhealthy condition, etc.

original: abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, taṃ ekantaasappāyameva, viparītaṃ sappāyaṃ.
analyzed: abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti tam ekanta a sappāyam eva viparītam sa ppāyam
translated: and unwholesome states increase and wholesome states diminish, then that is entirely unbeneficial. The opposite of that is beneficial.

original: Tassa vasenettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma koci bhuñjako natthi, vuttappakāracittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: tassa vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam  abbhantare attā nāma koci bhuñjakaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva
translated: And here the knowledge of what is beneficial should be understood as the knowledge of what is beneficial in the sense of the meditation subject, and the knowledge of what is not beneficial in the sense of the resort.🔽There is no such thing as a “consumer” called a “person” inside.🔽It is only by the diffusion of the air element that there comes to be what is called “receiving the almsfood in the bowl,”

original: pattappaṭiggahaṇaṃ nāma hoti. Cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva hatthassa patte otāraṇaṃ
analyzed: patta paṭiggahaṇam nāma hoti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva hatthassa patte otāraṇam
translated: and by the diffusion of the air element that there comes to be what is called “lowering the bowl,”

original: nāma hoti. Cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva ālopakaraṇaṃ ālopauddhāraṇaṃ mukhavivaraṇañca
analyzed: nāma hoti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva ālopa karaṇam ālopa auddhāraṇam mukha vivaraṇam ca
translated: and by the diffusion of the air element that there comes to be what is called “taking up the lump,” “opening the mouth,”

original: hoti, na koci kuñcikāya yantakena vā hanukaṭṭhīni vivarati. Cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: na koci kuñcikāya yantakena vā hanu kaṭṭhīni citta kiriya vāyaḥ dhātu vipphārena iva
translated: and no one opens the jawbones with a key or a winch.

original: ālopassa mukhe ṭhapanaṃ, uparidantānaṃ musalakiccasādhanaṃ, heṭṭhimadantānaṃ udukkhalakiccasādhanaṃ,
analyzed: ālopassa mukhe ṭhapanam upari dantānam musala kicca sādhanam heṭṭhima dantānam udukkhala kicca sādhanam
translated: By the diffusion of the air element there comes to be what is called “placing the lump in the mouth,” and the upper teeth perform the function of a mortar,

original: jivhāya hatthakiccasādhanañca hoti. Iti tattha aggajivhāya tanukakheḷo mūlajivhāya
analyzed: jivhāya hattha kicca sādhanam ca hoti iti tattha agga jivhāya tanuka kheḷaḥ mūla jivhāya
translated: and the tongue does the work of the hand. So the thin spittle is on the tip of the tongue and the thick spittle on the root of the tongue.

original: bahalakheḷo makkheti. Taṃ heṭṭhādantaudukkhale jivhāhatthaparivattakaṃ kheḷodakena
analyzed: bahala kheḷaḥ makkheti tam heṭṭhā danta odukkhale jivhā hattha parivattakam kheḷa udakena
translated: He moistens with the spittle the two lower teeth that are the place for the spittle.

original: temitaṃ uparidantamusalasañcuṇṇitaṃ koci kaṭacchunā vā dabbiyā vā antopavesento nāma🔽natthi, vāyodhātuyāva pavisati. Paviṭṭhaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ koci palālasanthāraṃ katvā dhārento
analyzed: temitam upari danta musala sañcuṇṇitam koci kaṭacchunā vā dabbiyā vā nāma  natthi vāyodhātuyā ava pavisati paviṭṭham paviṭṭham koci palāla santhāram katvā dhārento
translated: There is no one who puts it inside with a spoon or a ladle.🔽It enters by means of the air element. There is no one who carries it along by making a bed of straw, as it were, for it to lie on.

original: nāma natthi, vāyodhātuvaseneva tiṭṭhati. Ṭhitaṃ ṭhitaṃ koci uddhanaṃ katvā aggiṃ🔽jāletvā pacanto nāma natthi, tejodhātuyāva paccati. Pakkaṃ pakkaṃ koci daṇḍakena
analyzed: nāma natthi vāyo dhātu vasena iva tiṭṭhati ṭhitam ṭhitam koci uddhanam katvā aggim  jāletvā pacantaḥ nāma natthi tejodhātuyā ava paccati pakkam pakkam koci daṇḍakena
translated: It remains by means of the air element. There is no one who makes a furnace and lights a fire under it and bakes it, as it were.🔽It ripens by means of the fire element. There is no one who takes it out with a stick or a rod.

original: vā yaṭṭhiyā vā bahi nīhārako nāma natthi, vāyodhātuyeva nīharati. Iti vāyodhātu paṭiharati
analyzed: vā yaṭṭhiyā vā bahi nīhārakaḥ nāma natthi vāyodhātuyā iva nīharati iti vāyodhātu paṭiharati
translated: It is the air element that takes it out. Thus the air element takes it out,

original: ca, vītiharati ca, dhāreti ca, parivatteti ca, sañcuṇṇeti ca, visoseti ca, nīharati
analyzed: ca vītiharati ca dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇā iti ca visosā iti ca nīharati
translated: and it carries it off, and it holds it, and it turns it over, and it grinds it up, and it sorts it, and it takes it out,

original: ca. Pathavīdhātu dhāreti ca, parivatteti ca, sañcuṇṇeti ca, visoseti ca. Āpodhātu
analyzed: ca pathavī dhātu dhārā iti ca parivattā iti ca sañcuṇṇā iti ca visosā iti ca āpaḥ dhātu
translated: The earth element supports, turns, compresses and scatters them. The water element

original: sineheti ca, allattañca anupāleti. Tejodhātu antopaviṭṭhaṃ paripāceti. Ākāsadhātu🔽añjaso hoti. Viññāṇadhātu tattha tattha sammāpayogamanvāya ābhujatīti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: sineha iti ca allattam ca anupāla iti tejaḥ dhātu anta upaviṭṭham paripāca iti ākāsa dhātu  añjasas hoti viññāṇa dhātu tattha tattha sammā apayogam anvāya ābhujati iti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: cohesives and causes them to be waterlogged. The fire element ripens what is inside. The air element

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Api ca gamanato pariyesanato paribhogato āsayato nidhānato aparipakkato paripakkato
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  api ca gamanataḥ pariyesanataḥ paribhogataḥ āsayataḥ nidhānataḥ a paripakkataḥ paripakkataḥ
translated: gives them room. The consciousness element is the condition for their occurrence here and there. This is how the knowledge of non-confusion should be understood here as the means of discerning the elements.

original: phalato nissandato sammakkhanatoti, evaṃ dasavidhapaṭikūlabhāvapaccavekkhaṇato pettha
analyzed: phalataḥ nissandataḥ sammakkhanato ti evam dasavidha paṭikūla bhāva paccavekkhaṇato pa ittha
translated: Moreover, it should be understood as the knowledge of non-confusion here in the contemplation of repulsiveness in the ten aspects of repulsiveness, that is to say, as to going, as to seeking, as to using, as to receptacle, as to source, as to ripening, as to

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ. Vitthārakathā panettha visuddhimagge āhārapaṭikūlasaññāniddesato gahetabbā.
analyzed: asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam vitthāra kathā pana ittha visuddhi magge āhāra paṭikūla saññā niddesato gahetabbā
translated: consequence, as to smearing, and as to outcome. The detailed explanation should be understood according to the description of the perception of repulsiveness in nutriment in the Path of Purity.

original: Uccārapassāvakammeti uccārassa ca passāvassa ca karaṇe. Tattha pattakāle uccārapassāvaṃ
analyzed: uccāra passāva kamma iti uccārassa ca passāvassa ca karaṇe tattha patta kāle uccāra passāvam
translated: In the process of evacuation: in the process of defecation and urination. Herein, when it is time to defecate and urinate,

original: akarontassa sakalasarīrato sedā muccanti, akkhīni bhamanti, cittaṃ na ekaggaṃ hoti,
analyzed: a karontassa sakala sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti akkhīni bhamanti cittam na ekaggam hoti
translated: When he does not, sweat breaks out all over his body, his eyes roll, his mind does not become unified,

original: aññe ca rogā uppajjanti. Karontassa pana sabbaṃ taṃ na hotīti ayamettha attho. Tassa
analyzed: aññe ca rogā uppajjanti karontassa pana sabbam tam na hoti iti ayam ettha attho tassa
translated: and other diseases arise. But when he does, none of this happens. This is the meaning here.

original: vasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vasena sātthaka sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: Understanding of what is beneficial should be understood as the understanding of the meaning of that.

original: Aṭṭhāne uccārapassāvaṃ karontassa pana āpatti hoti, ayaso vaḍḍhati, jīvitantarāyo
analyzed: aṭṭhāne uccāra passāvam karontassa pana āpatti hoti ayasaḥ vaḍḍhati jīvita antarāyo
translated: But when he does it in an unsuitable place, he commits an offense, his disrepute increases, and he may lose his life.

original: hoti, patirūpe ṭhāne karontassa sabbaṃ taṃ na hotīti idamettha sappāyaṃ tassa vasena
analyzed: hoti patirūpe ṭhāne karontassa sabbam tam na hoti iti idam ettha sappāyam tassa vasena
translated: But when he does it in a suitable place, none of this happens. This is the suitable here. Understanding of what is suitable should be understood as the understanding of the meaning of that.

original: sappāyasampajaññaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma uccārapassāvakammaṃ karonto natthi, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: sa ppāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam  abbhantare attā nāma uccāra passāva kammam karontaḥ natthi citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva
translated: And understanding of the resort should be understood as the non-abandoning of the meditation subject.🔽There is no self inside that does the action of defecating or urinating.🔽It is only by the diffusion of the air element set in motion by mind-action that the action of defecating or urinating is done.

original: pana uccārapassāvakammaṃ hoti. Yathā vā pana pakke gaṇḍe gaṇḍabhedena pubbalohitaṃ
analyzed: pana uccāra passāva kammam hoti yathā vā pana pakke gaṇḍe gaṇḍa bhedena pubba lohitam
translated: Or just as when a boil is ripe, its bursting is due to the boil itself, not by the action of anything else,

original: akāmatāya nikkhamati. Yathā ca atibharitā udakabhājanā udakaṃ akāmatāya nikkhamati.🔽Evaṃ pakkāsayamuttavatthīsu sannicitā uccārapassāvā vāyuvegasamuppīḷitā akāmatāyapi
analyzed: akāmatāya nikkhamati yathā ca ati bharitā udaka bhājanā udakam akāmatāya nikkhamati  evam sannicitāḥ uccāra passāvāḥ vāyu vega samuppīḍitāḥ
translated: and it comes out unwillingly, just as water comes out unwillingly from a water-pot that is overfull.🔽So too, when the receptacle for digested food and the receptacle for excrement are full, the feces and urine come out unwillingly,

original: nikkhamanti. So panāyaṃ evaṃ nikkhamanto uccārapassāvo neva tassa bhikkhuno attano
analyzed: nikkhamanti so pana ayam evam nikkhamantaḥ uccāra passāvaḥ na iva tassa bhikkhuno attano
translated: pressed by the force of the wind. But when they come out in this way, these feces and urine do not belong to that bhikkhu,

original: hoti, na parassa, kevalaṃ sarīranissandova hoti. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā udakatumbato purāṇudakaṃ
analyzed: hoti na parassa kevalam sarīra nissandaḥ uva hoti yathā kim yathā udaka tumbataḥ purāṇ udakam
translated: nor to anyone else; they are just a secretion of the body. How so? Just as when someone throws away old water from a water-pot,

original: chaḍḍentassa neva taṃ attano hoti, na paresaṃ; kevalaṃ paṭijagganamattameva hoti;
analyzed: chaḍḍentassa na iva tam attanaḥ hoti na paresam kevalam paṭijagganam attam eva hoti
translated: it does not belong to himself nor to anyone else; he just gets rid of it.

original: evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Gatādīsu gateti gamane. Ṭhiteti ṭhāne. Nisinneti nisajjāya. Sutteti sayane. Jāgariteti
analyzed: evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  gata ādīsu gatā iti gamane ṭhitā iti ṭhāne nisinnā iti nisajjāya suttā iti sayane jāgaritā iti
translated: So too, here the clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood to be the occurrence of reflection in this way.

original: jāgaraṇe. Bhāsiteti kathane. Tuṇhībhāveti akathane. “Gacchanto vā gacchāmīti pajānāti,
analyzed: jāgaraṇe bhāsitā iti kathane tuṇhībhāva iti a kathane gacchantaḥ vā gacchāmi iti pajānāti
translated: As to “going” and so on: “going” is walking, “standing” is standing, “sitting” is sitting, “lying down” is lying down. “Being awake” is being awake. “Speaking” is talking. “Keeping silent” is not talking. “I am going” he knows when he is going,

original: ṭhito vā ṭhitomhīti pajānāti, nisinno vā nisinnomhīti pajānāti, sayāno vā sayānomhīti🔽pajānātī”ti imasmiñhi sutte addhānairiyāpathā kathitā. “Abhikkante paṭikkante ālokite
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ vā ṭhitaḥ umhi iti pajānāti nisinnaḥ vā nisinnaḥ umhi iti pajānāti sa yānaḥ vā sa yānaḥ umhi iti  pajānāti iti imasmin hi sutte addhā nairiyāpathā kathitā abhikkante paṭikkante ālokite
translated: and when standing he knows “I am standing.” When sitting he knows “I am sitting.” When lying down he knows “I am lying down.”

original: vilokite samiñjite pasārite”ti imasmiṃ majjhimā. “Gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite”ti
analyzed: vilokite samiñjite pasāritā iti imasmin majjhimā gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgaritā iti
translated: In this sutta the postures of standing and so on are mentioned. In the Majjhima Nikāya, the postures of walking, standing, sitting, lying down, sleeping, and waking are mentioned.

original: idha pana khuddakacuṇṇiyairiyāpathā kathitā. Tasmā tesupi vuttanayeneva sampajānakāritā veditabbā.🔽Tipiṭakamahāsivatthero panāha – yo ciraṃ gantvā vā caṅkamitvā vā aparabhāge ṭhito
analyzed: idha pana khuddaka cuṇṇiya eriyā pathā kathitā tasmā tesu pi vutta nayena iva sampajāna kāri tā veditabbā  tipiṭakamahāsiva theraḥ pana āha yaḥ ciram gantvā vā caṅkamitvā vā apara bhāge ṭhitaḥ
translated: Here the postures of the small child are mentioned. Therefore, the practice of clear comprehension should be understood in the same way as stated above.

original: iti paṭisañcikkhati – “caṅkamanakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva niruddhā”ti.
analyzed: iti paṭisañcikkhati caṅkamana kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha iva niruddhā ati
translated: The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa-Abhaya said: “One who has been walking or pacing up and down for a long time and who later stands and reflects thus: ‘The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred while I was pacing up and down have ceased right here,’

original: Ayaṃ gate sampajānakārī nāma.
analyzed: ayam gate sampajānakārī nāma
translated: is called one who is clear about the posture at the time of walking.🔽One who recites the scriptures, answers questions, or attends to the meditation subject for a long time

original: Yo sajjhāyaṃ vā karonto, pañhaṃ vā vissajjento, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā manasikaronto ciraṃ
analyzed: yaḥ sajjhāyam vā karontaḥ pañham vā vissajjentaḥ kammaṭṭhānam vā manasikarontaḥ ciram
translated: and

original: ṭhatvā aparabhāge nisinno iti paṭisañcikkhati – “ṭhitakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā🔽ettheva niruddhā”ti. Ayaṃ ṭhite sampajānakārī nāma.
analyzed: ṭhatvā apara bhāge nisinnaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati ṭhita kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammā  etthā iva ayam ṭhite sampajānakārī nāma
translated: and later on, when he is sitting, he reflects thus: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was standing have been stopped.” He is called “one who is clearly aware of the state of being while standing.”

original: Yo sajjhāyādikaraṇavaseneva ciraṃ nisīditvā aparabhāge uṭṭhāya iti paṭisañcikkhati – “nisinnakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva niruddhā”ti. Ayaṃ nisinne sampajānakārī nāma.🔽Yo pana nipannako sajjhāyaṃ vā karonto kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā manasikaronto niddaṃ okkamitvā
analyzed: yaḥ sajjhāya ādi karaṇa vasena iva ciram nisīditvā apara bhāge uṭṭhāya iti paṭisañcikkhati nisinna kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha iva niruddhā ati ayam nisinne sampajānakārī nāma  yaḥ pana nipannakaḥ sajjhāyam vā karontaḥ kammaṭṭhānam vā manasikarontaḥ niddam okkamitvā
translated: After sitting for a long time, he reflects thus: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was sitting have been stopped.” He is called “one who is clearly aware of the state of being while sitting.”

original: aparabhāge uṭṭhāya iti paṭisañcikkhati – “sayanakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva🔽niruddhā”ti. Ayaṃ sutte jāgarite ca sampajānakārī nāma. Kiriyamayacittānañhi appavattanaṃ
analyzed: aparabhāge uṭṭhāya iti paṭisañcikkhati sayana kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha eva  niruddhā ati ayam sutte jāgarite ca sampajāna kārī nāma kiriya maya cittānam hi a pavattanam
translated: After lying down, he reflects thus: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was reciting or while I was attending to the meditation subject have been stopped.” He is called “one who is clearly aware of the state of being while lying down.”

original: soppaṃ nāma, pavattanaṃ jāgaritaṃ nāma.
analyzed: soppam nāma pavattanam jāgaritam nāma
translated: For the non-occurrence of the functional consciousnesses is called “sleep,” and their occurrence is called “being awake.”🔽When he is speaking, he reflects thus: “This sound occurs dependent on the throat, teeth, tongue, palate,

original: Yo pana bhāsamāno – “ayaṃ saddo nāma oṭṭhe ca paṭicca, dante ca jivhañca tāluñca
analyzed: yaḥ pana bhāsamānaḥ ayam saddaḥ nāma oṭṭhe ca paṭicca dante ca jivhañca tāluñca
translated: and lips.

original: paṭicca, cittassa ca tadanurūpaṃ payogaṃ paṭicca jāyatī”ti sato sampajānova bhāsati.
analyzed: paṭicca cittassa ca tad anurūpam payogam paṭicca jāyati iti sataḥ sampajānā uva bhāsati
translated: and it arises in dependence on the mind and the appropriate effort.

original: Ciraṃ vā pana kālaṃ sajjhāyaṃ vā katvā, dhammaṃ vā kathetvā, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā pavattetvā,🔽pañhaṃ vā vissajjetvā, aparabhāge tuṇhībhūto iti paṭisañcikkhati – “bhāsitakāle uppannā
analyzed: ciram vā pana kālam sajjhāyam vā katvā dhammam vā kathetvā kammaṭṭhānam vā pavattetvā  pañham vā vissajjetvā apara bhāge tuṇhībhūtaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati bhāsita kāle uppannā
translated: Or else, after he has recited for a long time or taught the Dhamma or given a meditation subject or answered a question,

original: rūpārūpadhammā ettheva niruddhā”ti. Ayaṃ bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma.
analyzed: rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha iva niruddhā ati ayam bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma
translated: he reflects afterwards when he is silent: “The material and immaterial phenomena that arose at the time when I was speaking have ceased there. ” This is called “fully aware of the spoken.”

original: Yo tuṇhībhūto ciraṃ dhammaṃ vā kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā manasikatvā aparabhāge iti paṭisañcikkhati
analyzed: yaḥ tuṇhībhūtaḥ ciram dhammam vā kammaṭṭhānam vā manasikatvā aparabhāge iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: But when he has given attention for a long time to the Dhamma or a meditation subject and afterwards reflects:

original: – “tuṇhībhūtakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva niruddhā”ti. Upādārūpappavattiyañhi
analyzed: tuṇhībhūta kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha iva niruddhā ati upādā rūpa ppavattiyam hi
translated: “The material and immaterial phenomena occurring at the time when I was silent have ceased there,”

original: sati bhāsati nāma, asati tuṇhī bhavati nāmāti. Ayaṃ tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī nāmāti.
analyzed: sati bhāsati nāma asati tuṇhī bhavati nāma ati ayam tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī nāma ati
translated: then, since it is only when there is occurrence of the material and immaterial that there is speaking and silence, this is called “fully aware of the silent.”

original: Tayidaṃ mahāsivattherena vuttaṃ asammohadhuraṃ mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutte adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: tayā idam mahāsivattherena vuttam asammoha dhuram mahā sati paṭṭhāna sutte adhippetam
translated: This is what the Elder Maha Siva said, and it is the meaning intended in the Maha-Satipatthana Sutta .

original: Imasmiṃ pana sāmaññaphale sabbampi catubbidhaṃ sampajaññaṃ labbhati. Tasmā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: imasmim pana sāmañña phale sabbam pi catubbidham sampajaññam labbhati tasmā vutta nayena iva
