translated: But in this fruit of recluseship all the four kinds of full awareness are included. So it is said:

original: cettha catunnaṃ sampajaññānaṃ vasena sampajānakāritā veditabbā. Sampajānakārīti ca
analyzed: ca ittha catunnam sampajaññānam vasena sampajāna kāri tā veditabbā sampajāna kārī iti ca
translated: But in this fruit of recluseship all the four kinds of clear comprehension are found. So here the performance of clear comprehension should be understood in the way already stated.

original: sabbapadesu satisampayuttasseva sampajaññassa vasena attho veditabbo. Satisampajaññena🔽samannāgatoti etassa hi padassa ayaṃ vitthāro. Vibhaṅgappakaraṇe pana – “sato sampajāno
analyzed: sabba padesu sati sampayuttassa iva sampajaññassa vasena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ sati sampajaññena  samannāgataḥ ti etassa hi padassa ayam vitthāraḥ vibhaṅga pakaraṇe pana sato sampajāno
translated: And the meaning of the words “he is one who acts with clear comprehension” should be understood in all instances as follows:🔽he is one who possesses clear comprehension associated with mindfulness.🔽For this is the detailed explanation of the words “possessed of clear comprehension and mindfulness”:

original: abhikkamati, sato sampajāno paṭikkamatī”ti evaṃ etāni padāni vibhattāneva. Evaṃ,🔽kho mahārājāti evaṃ satisampayuttassa sampajaññassa vasena abhikkamādīni pavattento
analyzed: abhikkamati sataḥ sampajānaḥ paṭikkamati iti evam etāni padāni evam  kho mahā rāja ati evam sati sampayuttassa sampajaññassa vasena abhikkama ādīni pavattento
translated: “Mindful he goes forward, mindful he returns, looking straight ahead and not looking about,🔽unhurried in going, standing, sitting, and lying down,🔽thus, great king, he is possessed of clear comprehension and mindfulness.”

original: satisampajaññena samannāgato nāma hotīti attho.
analyzed: sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ nāma hoti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that he is one who possesses clear comprehension associated with mindfulness when he acts in this way by means of clear comprehension associated with mindfulness.

original: Santosakathā
analyzed: santosa kathā
translated: The Discussion of Contentment

original: 215. Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hotīti ettha santuṭṭhoti itarītarapaccayasantosena
analyzed: idha mahā rāja bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti ettha santuṭṭhaḥ ti itarītara paccaya santosena
translated: Here, great king, a bhikkhu is content” . Herein, content is the contentment with whatever robe, alms food, resting place, and medicinal requisites is proper for a bhikkhu.

original: samannāgato. So panesa santoso dvādasavidho hoti, seyyathidaṃ – cīvare yathālābhasantoso,
analyzed: samannāgato so pana isa santosaḥ dvādasavidhaḥ hoti sā iyyathidam  cīvare yathā lābha santoso
translated: This contentment is of twelve kinds, being threefold in each case thus: In regard to robes, he is content with whatever is obtained,

original: yathābalasantoso, yathāsāruppasantosoti tividho. Evaṃ piṇḍapātādīsu. Tassāyaṃ pabhedavaṇṇanā –🔽Idha bhikkhu cīvaraṃ labhati, sundaraṃ vā asundaraṃ vā. So teneva yāpeti, aññaṃ na
analyzed: yathā bala santoso yathā sāruppa santoso ti tividhaḥ evam piṇḍapāta ādīsu tassa ayam pabheda vaṇṇanā  idha bhikkhu cīvaram labhati sundaram vā asundaram vā so tena iva yāpeti aññam na
translated: or with what is easy to obtain, or with what is in accordance with what he is used to. So too in regard to alms food, etc. The explanation of the analysis is this:

original: pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhati. Ayamassa cīvare yathālābhasantoso. Atha pana pakatidubbalo🔽vā hoti, ābādhajarābhibhūto vā, garucīvaraṃ pārupanto kilamati. So sabhāgena bhikkhunā
analyzed: pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhati ayam assa cīvare yathā lābha santosaḥ atha pana pakati dubbalaḥ  vā hoti ābādha jarā abhibhūtaḥ vā garu cīvaram pārupanto kilamati saḥ sabhāgena bhikkhunā
translated: Here a bhikkhu gets a robe, whether it be fine or coarse. He makes do with that and does not seek another or, if he gets another, he does not use it. This is his contentment with what is obtained in regard to robes.

original: saddhiṃ taṃ parivattetvā lahukena yāpentopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa cīvare yathābalasantoso.
analyzed: saddhim tam parivattetvā lahukena yāpentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa cīvare yathābala santoso
translated: But if he is naturally weak in health or is overcome by illness or old age and finds it painful to wear a heavy robe, then he exchanges it for a light one with a bhikkhu of similar conditions. And he is still content. This is his contentment with what is easy to obtain.

original: Aparo paṇītapaccayalābhī hoti. So pattacīvarādīnaṃ aññataraṃ mahagghapattacīvaraṃ
analyzed: aparo paṇīta paccaya lābhī hoti so patta cīvara ādīnam aññataram mahaggha patta cīvaram
translated: Another gets valuable bowl and robe, etc.,

original: bahūni vā pana pattacīvarāni labhitvā idaṃ therānaṃ cirapabbajitānaṃ, idaṃ bahussutānaṃ
analyzed: bahūni vā pana patta cīvarāni labhitvā idam therānam cira pabbajitānam idam bahu sutānam
translated: Or else, having received many robes, he thinks, “This is suitable for the elders who have long gone forth, and this is suitable for those who are learned,

original: anurūpaṃ, idaṃ gilānānaṃ, idaṃ appalābhīnaṃ hotūti datvā tesaṃ purāṇacīvaraṃ vā gahetvā
analyzed: anurūpam idam idam hotu uti da tvā purāṇa cīvaram vā gahetvā
translated: and this is suitable for the sick, and this is for those who get little,” and he gives them his old robes.

original: saṅkārakūṭādito vā nantakāni uccinitvā tehi saṅghāṭiṃ katvā dhārentopi santuṭṭhova
analyzed: saṅkāra kūṭa āditaḥ vā nantakāni uccinitvā tehi saṅghāṭim katvā dhārentaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva
translated: Or else he takes cast-off rags from a rubbish heap or a shop and makes himself a triple robe. He is content with that.

original: hoti. Ayamassa cīvare yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: hoti ayam assa cīvare yathā sāruppa santosaḥ
translated: This is his contentment with regard to robes as regards kind.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu piṇḍapātaṃ labhati lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so teneva yāpeti, aññaṃ🔽na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhati. Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathālābhasantoso. Yo pana
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu piṇḍapātam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā so tena iva yāpeti aññam  na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhati ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā lābha santosaḥ yaḥ pana
translated: Here a bhikkhu gets almsfood whether it is coarse or fine, and he makes do with that.

original: attano pakativiruddhaṃ vā byādhiviruddhaṃ vā piṇḍapātaṃ labhati, yenassa paribhuttena
analyzed: attanaḥ pakati viruddham vā byādhi viruddham vā piṇḍapātam labhati yena assa paribhuttena
translated: He does not seek for more. If he gets more, he does not accept it. This is his contentment with regard to almsfood as regards amount. But if he gets almsfood that is unsuitable for him because it is contrary to his normal diet or because it is contrary to his illness,

original: aphāsu hoti. So sabhāgassa bhikkhuno taṃ datvā tassa hatthato sappāyabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: a phāsu hoti saḥ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno tam da tvā tassa hatthato sappāya bhojanam bhuñjitvā
translated: and by eating it he would suffer, then he should give it to a fellow monk who is in communion and eat suitable food that he gets from him.

original: samaṇadhammaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathābalasantoso. Aparo
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathābala santosaḥ aparaḥ
translated: and he is content with that. This is his contentment with almsfood in moderation.

original: bahuṃ paṇītaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ labhati. So taṃ cīvaraṃ viya theracirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhīgilānānaṃ
analyzed: bahum paṇītam piṇḍapātam labhati saḥ tam cīvaram viya thera cira pabbajita bahu ssuta appa lābhī gilānānam
translated: Another gets much fine almsfood. He gives that to elders, long- ordained ones, learned ones, and those who are sick,

original: datvā tesaṃ vā sesakaṃ piṇḍāya vā caritvā missakāhāraṃ bhuñjantopi santuṭṭhova hoti.
analyzed: datvā tesam vā sesakam piṇḍāya vā caritvā missaka āhāram bhuñjantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti
translated: and he eats what remains after that, or he goes on his round for alms and eats the mixed almsfood.

original: Ayamassa piṇḍapāte yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: ayam assa piṇḍapāte yathā sāruppa santosaḥ
translated: And he is content with that. This is his contentment with almsfood in accordance with what is acquired.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu senāsanaṃ labhati, manāpaṃ vā amanāpaṃ vā, so tena neva somanassaṃ,🔽na domanassaṃ uppādeti; antamaso tiṇasanthārakenapi yathāladdheneva tussati. Ayamassa
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu senāsanam labhati manāpam vā amanāpam vā so tena na iva somanassam  na domanassam uppādeti antamasaḥ tiṇa santhārakena api yathā laddhena iva tussati
translated: Herein, when a bhikkhu gets a resting place, whether good or bad, he does not arouse gladness or sorrow,🔽but he is content with whatever is acquired. This is his contentment with resting places in accordance with what is acquired.

original: senāsane yathālābhasantoso. Yo pana attano pakativiruddhaṃ vā byādhiviruddhaṃ vā
analyzed: senāsane yathā lābha santosaḥ yaḥ pana pakati viruddham vā byādhi viruddham vā
translated: But if he gets a resting place that is contrary to his normal habit or contrary to his illness,

original: senāsanaṃ labhati, yatthassa vasato aphāsu hoti, so taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā
analyzed: senāsanam labhati yatthassa vasataḥ a phāsu hoti saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhunaḥ da tvā
translated: where he is not comfortable, he gives it to a fellow-bhikkhu,

original: tassa santake sappāyasenāsane vasantopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa senāsane yathābalasantoso.🔽Aparo mahāpuñño leṇamaṇḍapakūṭāgārādīni bahūni paṇītasenāsanāni labhati. So tāni
analyzed: tassa santake sappāya senāsane vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathābala santoso  aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ leṇa maṇḍapa kūṭāgāra ādīni bahūni paṇīta senāsanāni labhati saḥ tāni
translated: and he is content with that. This is his contentment with regard to resting places according to his strength.🔽Another, though he has acquired many fine resting places such as caves, huts, and stilt houses,

original: cīvaraṃ viya theracirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhīgilānānaṃ datvā yattha katthaci🔽vasantopi santuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa senāsane yathāsāruppasantoso. Yopi – “uttamasenāsanaṃ
analyzed: cīvaram viya thera cira pabbajita bahu ssuta appa lābhī gilānānam da tvā yattha katthaci  vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ayam assa senāsane yathā sāruppa santosaḥ yaḥ api uttama senāsanam
translated: gives them to the elders, the long-standing monks, the learned, the affluent, and the sick, as though they were robes,

original: nāma pamādaṭṭhānaṃ, tattha nisinnassa thinamiddhaṃ okkamati, niddābhibhūtassa puna
analyzed: nāma pamāda ṭṭhānam tattha nisinnassa thinamiddham okkamati niddā abhibhūtassa puna
translated: and he is content to live anywhere at all. This is his contentment with regard to resting places according to his means. Another, thinking, “A fine resting place is a basis for negligence; when I sit in it, I fall into indolence and drowsiness; and when I am overcome by sleepiness,

original: paṭibujjhato kāmavitakkā pātubhavantī”ti paṭisañcikkhitvā tādisaṃ senāsanaṃ pattampi🔽na sampaṭicchati. So taṃ paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsarukkhamūlādīsu vasantopi santuṭṭhova
analyzed: paṭibujjhataḥ kāma vitakkāḥ pātubhavanti iti paṭisañcikkhitvā tādisam senāsanam pattam pi  na sampaṭicchati saḥ tam paṭikkhipitvā abbhokāsa rukkha mūla ādīsu vasantaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ va
translated: thoughts of sensual desire become manifest in me,” refuses to accept such a resting place even if he finds it ready to use.

original: hoti. Ayampissa senāsane yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: hoti ayam pissa senāsane yathā sāruppa santosaḥ
translated: Rejecting it, he is content to live in the open air, at the foot of a tree, etc. This is his contentment with regard to resting places according to his means.

original: Idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjaṃ labhati, lūkhaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, so yaṃ labhati, teneva
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhu bhesajjam labhati lūkham vā paṇītam vā saḥ yam labhati tena iva
translated: Here a bhikkhu obtains medicine, whether coarse or excellent.🔽

original: tussati, aññaṃ na pattheti, labhantopi na gaṇhati. Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathālābhasantoso.
analyzed: tussati aññam na pattheti labhantaḥ api na gaṇhati ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathā lābha santoso
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu gets a medicine, whether coarse or refined, and he is satisfied with whatever he gets and does not seek anything else. If he gets it, he does not take it. This is his contentment with what he gets in regard to requisite medicine.

original: Yo pana telena atthiko phāṇitaṃ labhati. So taṃ sabhāgassa bhikkhuno datvā tassa
analyzed: yaḥ pana telena atthikaḥ phāṇitam labhati saḥ tam sabhāgassa bhikkhunaḥ da tvā tassa
translated: But one who needs oil gets molasses and gives it to a fellow-bhikkhu who has need of it and gets oil from him

original: hatthato telaṃ gahetvā aññadeva vā pariyesitvā bhesajjaṃ karontopi santuṭṭhova hoti.
analyzed: hatthato telam gahetvā aññatra deva vā pariyesitvā bhesajjam karontaḥ api santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti
translated: or seeks it by some means or other and makes up the medicine. Still he is content.

original: Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathābalasantoso.🔽Aparo mahāpuñño bahuṃ telamadhuphāṇitādipaṇītabhesajjaṃ labhati. So taṃ cīvaraṃ viya
analyzed: ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathābala santoso  aparaḥ mahā puññaḥ bahum tela madhu phāṇita ādi paṇīta bhesajjam labhati saḥ tam cīvaram viya
translated: This is his contentment with what he gains in regard to requisite medicine.

original: theracirapabbajitabahussutaappalābhīgilānānaṃ datvā tesaṃ ābhatena yena kenaci yāpentopi
analyzed: thera cira pabbajita bahussuta appa lābhī gilānānam da tvā tesam ābhatena yena kenaci yāpentaḥ api
translated: Another, who has great merit, gets much refined medicine such as oil, honey, molasses, etc., and he gives that to those bhikkhus who are senior, who have long ordained, who are learned, who are poor, and who are sick, and he makes do with whatever he gets from the medicine brought by them.

original: santuṭṭhova hoti. Yo pana ekasmiṃ bhājane muttaharīṭakaṃ ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ catumadhuraṃ
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ uva hoti yaḥ pana ekasmin bhājane mutta harīṭakam ṭhapetvā ekasmin catu madhuram
translated: He is content. But one who puts a gallnut in one vessel and the four-flavored compound in another and

original: – “gaṇhāhi, bhante, yadicchasī”ti vuccamāno sacassa tesu aññatarenapi rogo vūpasammati,🔽atha muttaharīṭakaṃ nāma buddhādīhi vaṇṇitanti catumadhuraṃ paṭikkhipitvā muttaharīṭakeneva
analyzed: gaṇhāhi bhante yat icchasi iti vuccamāno saca assa tesu aññatarena api rogaḥ vūpasammati  atha muttaharīṭakam nāma buddha ādīhi vaṇṇitan ti catu madhuram paṭikkhipitvā mutta harīṭakena iva
translated: “Take what you like, venerable sir,” and if his disease is cured by any one of them,

original: bhesajjaṃ karonto paramasantuṭṭhova hoti. Ayamassa gilānapaccaye yathāsāruppasantoso.
analyzed: bhesajjam karonto parama santuṭṭhaḥ eva hoti ayam assa gilāna paccaye yathā sāruppa santoso
translated: then he makes medicine with only the urine and dung, thinking, “The four things compounded with honey, etc., are commended by the Enlightened One, etc.,” and he is satisfied with that. This is his satisfaction with the requisite of medicine in accordance with what is proper.

original: Iminā pana dvādasavidhena itarītarapaccayasantosena samannāgatassa bhikkhuno aṭṭha
analyzed: iminā pana dvādasavidhena itarītara paccaya santosena samannāgatassa bhikkhuno aṭṭha
translated: When a bhikkhu possesses this twelve-fold satisfaction with the other requisite, the eight requisites

original: parikkhārā vaṭṭanti. Tīṇi cīvarāni, patto, dantakaṭṭhacchedanavāsi, ekā sūci, kāyabandhanaṃ
analyzed: parikkhārāḥ vaṭṭanti tīṇi cīvarāni pattaḥ danta kaṭṭha chedana vāsi ekā sūci kāya bandhanam
translated: are allowable for him: the three robes, the bowl, the razor, the needle, the waistband,

original: parissāvananti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: parissāvanam ti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: and the water filter. And this is said:🔽“The three robes, and the bowl,

original: “Ticīvarañca patto ca, vāsi sūci ca bandhanaṃ;
analyzed: ti cīvaram ca patto ca vāsi sūci ca bandhanam
translated: The razor, needle, waistband,🔽And water filter—these are allowed

original: Parissāvanena aṭṭhete, yuttayogassa bhikkhuno”ti.
analyzed: parissāvanena aṭṭhete yutta yogassa bhikkhuno ti
translated: For the bhikkhu who is rightly diligent.”

original: Te sabbe kāyaparihārikāpi honti kucchiparihārikāpi. Kathaṃ? Ticīvaraṃ tāva nivāsetvā
analyzed: te sabbe kāya parihārikāḥ api honti kucchi parihārikāḥ api katham ti cīvaram nivāsetvā
translated: All these are both for the body’s use and for the stomach’s.

original: ca pārupitvā ca vicaraṇakāle kāyaṃ pariharati, posetīti kāyaparihārikaṃ hoti. Cīvarakaṇṇena
analyzed: ca ca vicaraṇa kāle kāyam pariharati posa iti iti kāya parihārikam hoti cīvara kaṇṇena
translated: and when he moves about wearing it, it is a body-covering.

original: udakaṃ parissāvetvā pivanakāle khāditabbaphalāphalagahaṇakāle ca kucchiṃ pariharati;🔽posetīti kucchiparihārikaṃ hoti.
analyzed: udakam parissāvetvā pivana kāle khāditabba phala a phala gahaṇa kāle ca kucchim pariharati  posā iti iti kucchi parihārikam hoti
translated: When he wets the edge of the robe with water and drinks it, and when he picks up the various fruits to eat, it is a stomach-covering.

original: Pattopi tena udakaṃ uddharitvā nhānakāle kuṭiparibhaṇḍakaraṇakāle ca kāyaparihāriko hoti. Āhāraṃ gahetvā bhuñjanakāle kucchiparihāriko.
analyzed: pattaḥ api tena udakam uddharitvā nhāna kāle kuṭi paribhaṇḍa karaṇa kāle ca kāya parihārikaḥ hoti āhāram gahetvā bhuñjana kāle kucchi parihārikaḥ
translated: The bowl is a body-covering when he uses it to scoop up water for bathing, and when he uses it as a tool for the hut. It is a stomach-covering when he uses it to eat after taking his food.

original: Vāsipi tāya dantakaṭṭhacchedanakāle mañcapīṭhānaṃ aṅgapādacīvarakuṭidaṇḍakasajjanakāle ca kāyaparihārikā hoti. Ucchuchedananāḷikerāditacchanakāle kucchiparihārikā.
analyzed: danta kaṭṭha chedana kāle aṅga pāda cīvara kuṭi daṇḍaka sajjana kāle ca kāya parihārikā ucchu chedana nāḷikera ādi tacchana kāle kucchi parihārikā
translated: The knife is a body-covering when he uses it to cut a tooth-stick, and when he uses it to sharpen the legs of beds and benches, the edges of robes, and the points of hut-props. It is a stomach-covering when he uses it to cut sugarcane, coconuts, etc.

original: Sūcipi cīvarasibbanakāle kāyaparihārikā hoti. Pūvaṃ vā phalaṃ vā vijjhitvā khādanakāle kucchiparihārikā.
analyzed: sūcipi cīvara sibbana kāle kāya parihārikā hoti pūvam vā phalam vā vijjhitvā khādana kāle kucchi parihārikā
translated: The needle is a body-covering when he uses it to sew robes. It is a stomach-covering when he uses it to sew a cake or a fruit to eat.

original: Kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā vicaraṇakāle kāyaparihārikaṃ. Ucchuādīni bandhitvā gahaṇakāle kucchiparihārikaṃ.🔽Parissāvanaṃ tena udakaṃ parissāvetvā nhānakāle, senāsanaparibhaṇḍakaraṇakāle ca
analyzed: kāya bandhanam bandhitvā vicaraṇa kāle kāya parihārikam ucchu ādīni bandhitvā gahaṇa kāle kucchi parihārikam  parissāvanam tena udakam parissāvetvā nhāna kāle senāsana paribhaṇḍa karaṇa kāle ca
translated: When he is walking about with the waist-band fastened, it is a personal requisite. When he is taking it up after fastening it to the hip, it is a requisite for the stomach.

original: kāyaparihārikaṃ. Pānīyaṃ parissāvanakāle, teneva tilataṇḍulaputhukādīni gahetvā khādanakāle
analyzed: kāya parihārikam pānīyam parissāvana kāle tena iva tila taṇḍula puthuka ādīni gahetvā khādana kāle
translated: When he is bathing after straining the water with it, it is a personal requisite. When he is eating after taking it up and putting in it sesamum flour, rice, etc.,

original: ca kucchiparihāriyaṃ. Ayaṃ tāva aṭṭhaparikkhārikassa parikkhāramattā. Navaparikkhārikassa🔽pana seyyaṃ pavisantassa tatraṭṭhakaṃ paccattharaṇaṃ vā kuñcikā vā vaṭṭati. Dasaparikkhārikassa🔽nisīdanaṃ vā cammakhaṇḍaṃ vā vaṭṭati. Ekādasaparikkhārikassa pana kattarayaṭṭhi vā
analyzed: ca kucchi parihāriyam ayam tāva aṭṭha parikkhārikassa parikkhāra mattā nava parikkhārikassa  pana seyyam pavisantassa tatraṭṭhakam paccattharaṇam vā kuñcikā vā vaṭṭati dasa parikkhārikassa  nisīdanam vā camma khaṇḍam vā vaṭṭati ekādasa parikkhārikassa pana kattara yaṭṭhi vā
translated: it is a requisite for the stomach. This is the mere requisite of the eight requisites.🔽But for one with nine requisites, a mat or a key is allowable for the place where he is staying. For one with ten requisites,🔽a sitting-cloth or a piece of leather is allowable. For one with eleven requisites, a bamboo walking-stick

original: telanāḷikā vā vaṭṭati. Dvādasaparikkhārikassa chattaṃ vā upāhanaṃ vā vaṭṭati. Etesu
analyzed: tela nāḷikā vā vaṭṭati dvādasa parikkhārikassa chattam vā upāhanam vā vaṭṭati etesu
translated: or an oil tube is allowable. For one with twelve requisites, an umbrella or a sandal is allowable.

original: ca aṭṭhaparikkhārikova santuṭṭho, itare asantuṭṭhā mahicchā mahābhārāti na vattabbā.🔽Etepi hi appicchāva santuṭṭhāva subharāva sallahukavuttinova. Bhagavā pana na yimaṃ
analyzed: ca aṭṭhaparikkhārikaḥ iva santuṭṭhaḥ itare asantuṭṭhāḥ mahicchāḥ mahābhārā ti na vattabbā  ete api hi santuṭṭhāva subharāva sat lahuka vuttinaḥ uva bhagavā pana na
translated: and the one who is satisfied with the eight requisites should not be called “one who has few wishes, is content, easily supports, and is secluded” while the others should be called “one who has great wishes, is discontented, difficult to support, and is not secluded.”

original: suttaṃ tesaṃ vasena kathesi, aṭṭhaparikkhārikassa vasena kathesi. So hi khuddakavāsiñca
analyzed: suttam tesam vasena kathesi aṭṭhaparikkhārikassa vasena kathesi saḥ hi khuddaka vāsin ca
translated: For these bhikkhus too are “one who has few wishes, is content, easily supports, and is secluded.” But the Exalted One did not teach this discourse on the basis of these bhikkhus; he taught it on the basis of the bhikkhu who has the eight requisites.

original: sūciñca parissāvane pakkhipitvā pattassa anto ṭhapetvā pattaṃ aṃsakūṭe laggetvā ticīvaraṃ🔽kāyapaṭibaddhaṃ katvā yenicchakaṃ sukhaṃ pakkamati. Paṭinivattetvā gahetabbaṃ nāmassa
analyzed: sūciñca parissāvane pakkhipitvā pattassa antaḥ ṭhapetvā pattam aṃsakūṭe laggetvā ticīvaram  kāya paṭibaddham katvā yenicchakam sukham pakkamati paṭinivattetvā gahetabbam nāmassa
translated: For the latter, after placing his small knife and needle in his carrying-net, puts them inside his bowl, hangs the bowl over his shoulder, and, having made his three robes into a bundle, fastens it with his waistband.🔽Then he can go wherever he likes in comfort. There is nothing for him to turn back for.

original: na hoti. Iti imassa bhikkhuno sallahukavuttitaṃ dassento bhagavā – “santuṭṭho hoti
analyzed: na hoti iti imassa bhikkhuno sallahuka vutti tam dassentaḥ bhagavā santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: Thus, showing the ease of this bhikkhu’s life, the Exalted One says: “He is satisfied with robes to protect his body and with almsfood to sustain his belly.”

original: kāyaparihārikena cīvarenā”tiādimāha. Tattha kāyaparihārikenāti kāyapariharaṇamattakena.
analyzed: kāya parihārikena cīvarena ati ādim āha tattha kāya parihārikena ati kāya pariharaṇa mattakena
translated: Herein, to protect his body means to protect it merely from contact with mosquitoes, etc.🔽To sustain his belly means to sustain it merely from hunger.

original: Kucchiparihārikenāti kucchipariharaṇamattakena. Samādāyeva pakkamatīti aṭṭhaparikkhāramattakaṃ
analyzed: kucchiparihārikena ati kucchi pariharaṇa mattakena samādāya iva pakkamati iti aṭṭha parikkhāra mattakam
translated: Having taken up means having taken up the eight requisites.

original: sabbaṃ gahetvāva kāyapaṭibaddhaṃ katvāva gacchati. “Mama vihāro pariveṇaṃ upaṭṭhāko”ti
analyzed: sabbam gahetvā ava kāya paṭibaddham katvā ava gacchati mama vihāraḥ pariveṇam upaṭṭhāko ti
translated: and he goes away taking everything with him, making it his very body.

analyzed: āsaṅgaḥ vā bandhaḥ vā na hoti saḥ jiyā muttaḥ saraḥ viya yūthā apakkantaḥ mada hatthī  viya ca icchiticchitam senāsanam vana saṇḍam rukkha mūlam vana pabbhāram paribhuñjantaḥ  ekaḥ iva tiṭṭhati ekaḥ iva nisīdati sabbiriyāpathesu ekaḥ iva adutiyaḥ  cātuddisaḥ appaṭighaḥ ca hoti  itarītarena
translated: There is no clinging or bondage in him such as “My dwelling, my cell, my attendant.”

analyzed: padese rukkho paripakka phalo ti ñatvā nānā disāhi āgantvā nakha patta tuṇḍa ādīhi tassa
translated: “In such and such a place there is a tree with ripe fruit.” Then they came from all directions and with their claws and beaks

original: phalāni vijjhantā vidhunantā khādanti. ‘Idaṃ ajjatanāya, idaṃ svātanāya bhavissatī’ti🔽tesaṃ na hoti. Phale pana khīṇe neva rukkhassa ārakkhaṃ ṭhapenti, na tattha pattaṃ
analyzed: phalāni vijjhantā vidhunantā khādanti idam ajjatanāya idam svātanāya bhavissati iti  tesam na hoti phale pana khīṇe na iva rukkhassa ārakkham ṭhapenti na tattha pattam
translated: Knowing that the tree was in a place where the fruit was ripe, they came from various directions and ate the fruit, piercing and splitting it with their claws, beaks, etc.🔽They did not think, “This is for today, that is for tomorrow.”🔽When the fruit was finished, they did not set a guard over the tree, nor did they leave a claw, a beak, or a leaf as a sign.

original: vā nakhaṃ vā tuṇḍaṃ vā ṭhapenti. Atha kho tasmiṃ rukkhe anapekkho hutvā, yo yaṃ disābhāgaṃ
analyzed: vā nakham vā tuṇḍam vā ṭhapenti atha kho tasmin rukkhe anapekkhaḥ hutvā yaḥ yam disā bhāgam
translated: Then, without any concern for the tree, they flew away in whatever direction they wished, with their beaks full of fruit.

original: icchati, so tena sapattabhārova uppatitvā gacchati. Evameva ayaṃ bhikkhu nissaṅgo
analyzed: icchati saḥ tena sa patta bhāraḥ uva uppatitvā gacchati evam eva ayam bhikkhu nissaṅgaḥ
translated: In the same way, this bhikkhu goes wherever he likes without any attachment or concern.

original: nirapekkho yena kāmaṃ pakkamati. Tena vuttaṃ “samādāyeva pakkamatī”ti.
analyzed: nirapekkhaḥ yena kāmam pakkamati tena vuttam samādāya iva pakkamati iti
translated: That is why it is said: “he goes forth taking nothing with him.”

original: Nīvaraṇappahānakathā
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ppahāna kathā
translated: The explanation of the abandoning of the hindrances

original: 216. So iminā cātiādinā kiṃ dasseti? Araññavāsassa paccayasampattiṃ dasseti. Yassa
analyzed: so iminā ca ati ādinā kim dasseti arañña vāsassa paccaya sampattim dasseti yassa
translated: What does the passage beginning, “He is content with any old alms and with any old resting place” show? It shows the possession of the requisites for living in the forest.🔽For one who does not have these four requisites, living in the forest is not possible.

original: hi ime cattāro paccayā natthi, tassa araññavāso na ijjhati. Tiracchānagatehi vā vanacarakehi
analyzed: hi ime cattāro paccayā natthi tassa arañña vāso na ijjhati tiracchāna gatehi vā vana carakehi
translated: He is not afraid of wild beasts such as tigers, etc.,

original: vā saddhiṃ vattabbataṃ āpajjati. Araññe adhivatthā devatā – “kiṃ evarūpassa pāpabhikkhuno
analyzed: vā saddhim vattabbatam āpajjati araññe adhivatthā devatā kim evarūpassa pāpa bhikkhuno
translated: or he falls into conversation with them. The deities who live in the forest think,🔽“What kind of a monk is this, who,🔽

original: araññavāsenā”ti bheravasaddaṃ sāventi, hatthehi sīsaṃ paharitvā palāyanākāraṃ karonti.
analyzed: arañña vāsena ati bherava saddam sāventi hatthehi sīsam paharitvā palāyana ākāram karonti
translated: and he is not fit to be spoken to. The deities who live in the forest make a fearful noise, saying, “What is the use of this evil bhikkhu’s living in the forest?” They beat their arms and make a commotion.

original: “Asuko bhikkhu araññaṃ pavisitvā idañcidañca pāpakammaṃ akāsī”ti ayaso pattharati.🔽Yassa panete cattāro paccayā atthi, tassa araññavāso ijjhati. So hi attano sīlaṃ🔽paccavekkhanto kiñci kāḷakaṃ vā tilakaṃ vā apassanto pītiṃ uppādetvā taṃ khayavayato
analyzed: asukaḥ bhikkhu araññam pavisitvā idam ca idam ca pāpa kammam akāsi iti ayasaḥ pattharati  yassa pana ete cattāro paccayāḥ atthi tassa arañña vāsaḥ ijjhati saḥ hi attanaḥ sīlaṃ  paccavekkhanto kiñci kāḷakam vā tilakam vā a passanto pītim uppādetvā tam khaya vayato
translated: And a bad report goes round: “So-and-so, it seems, has gone into the forest and done this and that evil deed.”

original: sammasanto ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati. Araññe adhivatthā devatā attamanā vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanti.
analyzed: sammasantaḥ ariya bhūmiṃ okkamati araññe adhivatthāḥ devatāḥ atta manāḥ vaṇṇam bhaṇanti
translated: But when a man has these four things, his forest life succeeds. For when he reviews his own virtue and sees nothing wrong or blotched in it, he arouses gladness. And when he comprehends that gladness with insight as liable to destruction and to fall away, he enters upon the way to the deathless. The deities who live in the forest are pleased and speak praise of him.

original: Itissa udake pakkhittatelabindu viya yaso vitthāriko hoti.
analyzed: iti ssa udake pakkhitta tela bindu viya yasaḥ vitthārikaḥ hoti
translated: And so his fame spreads in all directions like a drop of oil in water.

original: Tattha vivittanti suññaṃ, appasaddaṃ, appanigghosanti attho. Etadeva hi sandhāya
analyzed: tattha vivittam ti suññam appa saddam appa nigghosam ti attho etat eva hi sandhāya
translated: Herein, secluded means empty, quiet, with little noise and little disturbance. For this is said:

original: vibhaṅge – “vivittanti santike cepi senāsanaṃ hoti, tañca anākiṇṇaṃ gahaṭṭhehi pabbajitehi.🔽Tena taṃ vivitta”nti vuttaṃ. Seti ceva āsati ca etthāti senāsanaṃ mañcapīṭhādīnametaṃ
analyzed: vibhaṅge vivittanti santike ce pi senāsanam hoti tat ca an ākiṇṇam gahaṭṭhehi pabbajitehi  tena tam vivittam ti vuttam seti ca iva āsati ca ettha ati senāsanam mañca pīṭha ādīnam etam
translated: In the Vibhaṅga it is said: “Secluded: even if a dwelling is near inhabited areas, if it is not crowded with householders and monks,🔽it is secluded because of that.” A dwelling is that in which there is both sitting and lying down. This is a term for a bed, a chair, etc.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Tenāha – “senāsananti mañcopi senāsanaṃ, pīṭhampi, bhisipi, bimbohanampi,
analyzed: adhivacanam tena āha senāsanam ti mañcaḥ pi senāsanam pīṭham pi bhisi pi bimbohanam pi
translated: Therefore it is said: “A dwelling is a bed, a chair, a mattress, a pillow,

original: vihāropi, aḍḍhayogopi, pāsādopi, hammiyampi, guhāpi, aṭṭopi, māḷopi leṇampi, veḷugumbopi,
analyzed: vihāraḥ api aḍḍhayogaḥ api pāsādaḥ api hammiyampi guhā api aṭṭaḥ pi māḷaḥ pi leṇampi veḷugumbaḥ pi
translated: a monastery, a meeting hall, a multi-storied building, a cell, a cave, a shed, a leaf hut,

original: rukkhamūlampi, maṇḍapopi, senāsanaṃ, yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti, sabbametaṃ senāsana”nti.
analyzed: rukkha mūlam pi maṇḍapaḥ pi senāsanam yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti sabbam etam senāsananti
translated: the foot of a tree, a pavilion. A dwelling is wherever monks go for shelter. All this is a dwelling.”

original: Api ca – “vihāro aḍḍhayogo pāsādo hammiyaṃ guhā”ti idaṃ vihārasenāsanaṃ nāma. “Mañco
analyzed: api ca vihāraḥ aḍḍhayogo pāsādaḥ hammiyam guhā ati idam vihāra senāsanam nāma mañco
translated: Moreover, “a monastery, a meeting hall, a multi-storied building, a cell, a cave” are called monastery dwellings. “A bed,🔽a chair, a mattress, a pillow” are called bed-and-chair dwellings. “A straw mat, a hide, a spread of grass,

original: pīṭhaṃ bhisi bimbohana”nti idaṃ mañcapīṭhasenāsanaṃ nāma. “Cimilikā cammakhaṇḍo tiṇasanthāro
analyzed: pīṭham bhisi bimbohanam ti idam mañcapīṭha senāsanam nāma cimilikā cammakhaṇḍaḥ tiṇa santhāraḥ
translated: a spread of leaves, a spread of straw, a spread of cowdung, a spread of clay, a spread of grass and clay, a spread of cowdung and clay” are called spread dwellings.

original: paṇṇasanthāro”ti idaṃ santhatasenāsanaṃ nāma. “Yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamantī”ti
analyzed: paṇṇa santhāraḥ ti idam santhata senāsanam nāma yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti iti
translated: This is what is called a “bed and chair.” “Or where bhikkhus gather”

original: idaṃ okāsasenāsanaṃ nāmāti. Evaṃ catubbidhaṃ senāsanaṃ hoti, taṃ sabbaṃ senāsanaggahaṇena saṅgahitameva.
analyzed: idam okāsa senāsanam nāma ati evam catubbidham senāsanam hoti tat sabbam senāsana ggahaṇena saṅgahitam eva
translated: This is what is called a “site.” So there are four kinds of resting places. All of them are included in the “resting place” mentioned in the training precept.

original: Idha panassa sakuṇasadisassa cātuddisassa bhikkhuno anucchavikasenāsanaṃ dassento
analyzed: idha panassa sakuṇa sadisassa cātuddisassa bhikkhuno anucchavika senāsanam dassento
translated: But here the Blessed One, in pointing out a resting place suitable for a bhikkhu who is like a bird,

original: araññaṃ rukkhamūlantiādimāha. Tattha araññanti nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā sabbametaṃ🔽araññanti. Idaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ vasena āgataṃ. “Āraññakaṃ nāma senāsanaṃ pañcadhanusatikaṃ
analyzed: araññam rukkha mūlam ti ādim āha tattha araññam ti nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā sabbam etam  araññanti idam bhikkhunīnam vasena āgatam āraññakam nāma senāsanam pañca dhanusatikam
translated: said, “in the forest, at the root of a tree.” Herein, “in the forest” is any place outside the zone of cultivation, beyond the boundary fence.

original: pacchima”nti idaṃ pana imassa bhikkhuno anurūpaṃ. Tassa lakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge dhutaṅganiddese
analyzed: pacchiman ti idam pana imassa bhikkhuno anurūpam tassa lakkhaṇam visuddhimagge dhutaṅga niddese
translated: This is stated with reference to bhikkhunīs. But “a forest-dwelling place is one a half-league distant” is suitable for this bhikkhu. The definition of this is given in the Visuddhimagga in the description of the forest-dweller’s practice .

original: vuttaṃ. Rukkhamūlanti yaṃ kiñci sandacchāyaṃ vivittarukkhamūlaṃ. Pabbatanti selaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam rukkha mūlam ti yam kiñci sanda chāyam vivitta rukkha mūlam pabbatam ti selam
translated: “At the root of a tree” is any place with shade and seclusion at the root of a tree. “In a mountain cave” is a rock cave.

original: Tattha hi udakasoṇḍīsu udakakiccaṃ katvā sītāya rukkhacchāyāya nisinnassa nānādisāsu🔽khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Kandaranti kaṃ vuccati
analyzed: tattha hi udaka soṇḍīsu udaka kiccam katvā sītāya rukkha chāyāya nisinnassa nānā disāsu  khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittam ekaggam hoti kandaranti kam vuccati
translated: Here, after doing the water-duty in the water-basins, he sits down in the cool shade of the trees.🔽As he sits there, the breezes blowing from the different directions fan him and refresh him.🔽As a result, his mind becomes concentrated. “A mountain cleft” is a place in a mountain that is split open by water.

original: udakaṃ, tena dāritaṃ, udakena bhinnaṃ pabbatapadesaṃ. Yaṃ nadītumbantipi, nadīkuñjantipi
analyzed: udakam tena dāritam udakena bhinnam pabbata padesam yam
translated: It is also called a “mountain hollow” and a “mountain cave.”

original: vadanti. Tattha hi rajatapaṭṭasadisā vālikā hoti, matthake maṇivitānaṃ viya vanagahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: vadanti tattha hi rajata paṭṭa sadisā vālikā hoti matthake maṇi vitānam viya vana gahaṇam
translated: Here the sand is like a silver plate, the forest trees are like a canopy of gems,

original: maṇikhandhasadisaṃ udakaṃ sandati. Evarūpaṃ kandaraṃ oruyha pānīyaṃ pivitvā gattāni
analyzed: maṇi khandha sadisam udakam sandati evarūpam kandaram oruyha pānīyam pivitvā gattāni
translated: and the water flows like a mass of gems. After going down into such a mountain cleft, drinking the water, refreshing his limbs,

original: sītāni katvā vālikaṃ ussāpetvā paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ paññapetvā nisinnassa samaṇadhammaṃ
analyzed: sītāni katvā vālikam ussāpetvā paṃsukūla cīvaram paññapetvā nisinnassa samaṇa dhammaṃ
translated: spreading out the cast-off hempen rag-robe, and sitting down, he practices the ascetic duties.

original: karoto cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Giriguhanti dvinnaṃ pabbatānaṃ antare, ekasmiṃyeva vā
analyzed: karotaḥ cittam ekaggam hoti giri guhanti dvinnam pabbatānam antare ekasmiṃ yā iva vā
translated: As a result, his mind becomes concentrated. “A mountain hollow” is a large opening in one or two mountains, like a natural tunnel.

original: umaggasadisaṃ mahāvivaraṃ susānalakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Vanapatthanti gāmantaṃ
analyzed: umagga sadisam mahā vivaram su sāna lakkhaṇam visuddhi magge vuttam vana patthanti gāmantam
translated: The characteristics of a charnel ground are given in the Visuddhimagga .🔽“A forest” is a place that is not within a village or town.

original: atikkamitvā manussānaṃ anupacāraṭṭhānaṃ, yattha na kasanti na vapanti, tenevāha –
analyzed: atikkamitvā manussānam an upacāra ṭhānam yattha na kasanti na vapanti tena iva āha
translated: and beyond the place where people go for their needs. Since it is not cultivated or sown, he said:

original: “vanapatthanti dūrānametaṃ senāsanānaṃ adhivacana”ntiādi. Abbhokāsanti acchannaṃ.🔽Ākaṅkhamāno panettha cīvarakuṭiṃ katvā vasati. Palālapuñjanti palālarāsi. Mahāpalālapuñjato
analyzed: senāsanānam acchannam  ākaṅkhamānaḥ pana ittha cīvara kuṭim katvā vasati palāla puñjanti palāla rāsi mahā palāla puñjataḥ
translated: “The forest: this is a designation for a dwelling place that is far away.”🔽Open air: uncovered.🔽But if he wishes, he can make a hut of leaves there and live in it. A heap of straw: a pile of straw.

original: hi palālaṃ nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇasadise ālaye karonti, gacchagumbhādīnampi upari
analyzed: hi palālam nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇa sadise ālaye karonti gaccha gumbha ādīnam pi upari
translated: For from a big heap of straw they take the straw and make a shelter like a cave in a rock,

original: palālaṃ pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇadhammaṃ karonti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: palālam pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇa dhammam karonti tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: and they sit underneath it and do the ascetic’s duties. That is what is meant here.

original: Pacchābhattanti bhattassa pacchato. Piṇḍapātapaṭikkantoti piṇḍapātapariyesanato paṭikkanto.
analyzed: pacchābhattanti bhattassa pacchatas piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto ti piṇḍapāta pariyesanataḥ paṭikkanto
translated: After eating: after the meal. Having returned from the alms round: having finished seeking alms food.

original: Pallaṅkanti samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ. Ābhujitvāti bandhitvā. Ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyāti
analyzed: samantataḥ ūru baddha āsanam ābhujitvā ati bandhitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya ati
translated: A cross-legged posture: a posture with the legs crossed, bound together. Having folded: having bound. Having straightened up the body:

original: uparimaṃ sarīraṃ ujuṃ ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṭṭhike koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādetvā.
analyzed: uparimam sarīram ujum ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṭṭhike koṭiyā koṭim paṭipādetvā
translated: having set the upper part of the body straight, having brought the tip of the nose opposite the navel.

original: Evañhi nisinnassa cammamaṃsanhārūni na paṇamanti. Athassa yā tesaṃ paṇamanapaccayā
analyzed: evam hi nisinnassa camma maṃsa nhārūni na paṇamanti athassa yā tesam paṇamana paccayā
translated: for when he sits thus, his skin, flesh and sinews do not become flabby.🔽Then, because of the absence of flabbiness,

original: khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjeyyuṃ, tā nuppajjanti. Tāsu anuppajjamānāsu cittaṃ ekaggaṃ
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe vedanāḥ uppajjeyyum tāḥ na uppajjanti tāsu an uppajjamānāsu cittam ekaggam
translated: For when he sits in this way, his skin, flesh and sinews do not become flabby. And the pain that would arise from their flabbiness does not arise. When that does not arise, his mind becomes concentrated,

original: hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ na paripatati, vuḍḍhiṃ phātiṃ vepullaṃ upagacchati. Parimukhaṃ
analyzed: hoti kammaṭṭhānam na paripatati vuḍḍhim phātim vepullam upagacchati parimukham
translated: his meditation subject does not disintegrate, he gets progress and improvement, and he reaches distinction.

original: satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ satiṃ ṭhapayitvā. Mukhasamīpe vā katvāti🔽attho. Teneva vibhaṅge vuttaṃ – “ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti sūpaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā
analyzed: satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati kammaṭṭhāna abhimukham satim ṭhapayitvā mukha samīpe vā katvā iti  atthaḥ tena iva vibhaṅge vuttam ayam sati upaṭṭhitā hoti su upaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā
translated: Having established mindfulness in front of him: having placed mindfulness in the object of concentration, which is in front. Or the meaning is: having placed it in the vicinity of the face.🔽That is why it is said in the Vibhaṅga: “Mindfulness is established in him to the extent necessary just for the vision of the sign at the tip of the nose or in the face” .

original: mukhanimitte vā, tena vuccati parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”ti. Athavā parīti pariggahaṭṭho.
analyzed: mukha nimitte vā tena vuccati parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā ati athavā pari iti pariggaha aṭṭhaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, pari is a prefix in the sense of around;🔽mukha is a noun in the sense of outlet;

original: Mukhanti niyyānaṭṭho. Satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho. Tena vuccati – “parimukhaṃ sati”nti.
analyzed: mukham ti niyyāna aṭṭho satī iti upaṭṭhāna aṭṭho tena vuccati parimukham sati nti
translated: and sati is a noun in the sense of establishing.🔽So it is said: “mindfulness in front of him.”

original: Evaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayenapettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepo – “pariggahitaniyyānasatiṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: evam paṭisambhidā ayam vutta nayena pa ittha attho daṭṭhabbo tatra ayam saṅkhepaḥ pariggahita niyyāna satim katvā iti
translated: The meaning should be regarded here in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā. The brief meaning is this: “having established the outlet mindfulness around.”

original: 217. Abhijjhaṃ loketi ettha lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena pañcupādānakkhandhā loko, tasmā
analyzed: abhijjham loka iti ettha lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ tasmā
translated: “Covetousness in the world” : the world is the five aggregates as objects of clinging in the sense of being worn away and being worn away again. Therefore

original: pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu rāgaṃ pahāya kāmacchandaṃ vikkhambhetvāti ayametthattho.
analyzed: pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu rāgam pahāya kāmacchandam vikkhambhetvā ati ayam etthatthaḥ
translated: the meaning is: having abandoned greed for the five aggregates as objects of clinging, having suppressed sensual desire.

original: Vigatābhijjhenāti vikkhambhanavasena pahīnattā vigatābhijjhena, na cakkhuviññāṇasadisenāti
analyzed: vigata abhijjhena ati vikkhambhana vasena pahīna ttā vigata abhijjhena na cakkhu viññāṇa sadisena ati
translated: “With a mind free from covetousness” : with a mind free from covetousness by way of suppression. The meaning is: not like eye-consciousness.

original: attho. Abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodhetīti abhijjhāto cittaṃ parimoceti. Yathā taṃ sā🔽muñcati ceva, muñcitvā ca na puna gaṇhati, evaṃ karotīti attho. Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāyātiādīsupi
analyzed: atthaḥ abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti iti abhijjhātaḥ cittam parimoceti yathā tam sā  muñcati ca iva muñcitvā ca na puna gaṇhati evam karoti iti atthaḥ byāpāda padosam
translated: “He purifies his mind from covetousness” : he liberates his mind from covetousness. The meaning is: he acts in such a way that it is liberated and, having been liberated, it is not grasped again.🔽The same method applies to the passages beginning “having abandoned ill will and anger” .

original: eseva nayo. Byāpajjati iminā cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo viya purimapakatiṃ vijahatīti
analyzed: eṣa iva nayaḥ byāpajjati iminā cittam pūti kummāsa ādayaḥ purima pakatim vijahati iti
translated: Ill will is so called because it causes the mind to become ill, just as the things such as the rotten fish cause the body to become ill, and make it lose its original condition.

original: byāpādo. Vikārāpattiyā padussati, paraṃ vā padūseti vināsetīti padoso. Ubhayametaṃ
analyzed: byāpādaḥ vikāra āpattiyā padussati param vā padūseti vināseti iti padosaḥ ubhayam etam
translated: Anger is so called because it causes one to become angry or because it causes another to become angry and be destroyed. Both terms are synonyms for hatred.

original: kodhassevādhivacanaṃ. Thinaṃ cittagelaññaṃ. Middhaṃ cetasikagelaññaṃ, thinañca middhañca
analyzed: kodhassa iva adhivacanam thinam citta gelaññam middham cetasika gelaññam thinam ca middham ca
translated: Dullness is sluggishness of the mind. Sleepiness is sluggishness of the mind and body.

original: thinamiddhaṃ. Ālokasaññīti rattimpi divādiṭṭhālokasañjānanasamatthāya vigatanīvaraṇāya
analyzed: thinam iddham āloka saññī iti rattimpi divā diṭṭha āloka sañjānana samatthāya vigata nīvaraṇāya
translated: Percipient of light: endowed with a perception that is quite clear and free from hindrances, being capable of perceiving the light seen by day even at night.

original: parisuddhāya saññāya samannāgato. Sato sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgato.
analyzed: parisuddhāya saññāya samannāgato sataḥ sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgato
translated: Mindful and fully aware: endowed with mindfulness and knowledge.

original: Idaṃ ubhayaṃ ālokasaññāya upakārattā vuttaṃ. Uddhaccañca kukkuccañca uddhaccakukkuccaṃ.
analyzed: idam ubhayam āloka saññāya upakāra ttā vuttam uddhaccam ca kukkuccam ca uddhacca kukkuccam
translated: This pair is mentioned because they assist the perception of light.🔽Restless and remorseful: restlessness and remorse.

original: Tiṇṇavicikicchoti vicikicchaṃ taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhito. “Kathamidaṃ kathamida”nti🔽evaṃ nappavattatīti akathaṃkathī. Kusalesu dhammesūti anavajjesu dhammesu. “Ime nu
analyzed: tiṇṇa vicikiccho ti vicikiccham taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ katham idam katham idam ti  evam na ppavattati iti akathaṃkathī kusalesu dhammesu ati anavajjesu dhammesu ime nu
translated: Crossed over doubt: having crossed over and gone beyond doubt.🔽He does not have doubt in this way: “How is this? What is this?”🔽He is not doubtful. He is not perplexed about wholesome states,

original: kho kusalā kathamime kusalā”ti evaṃ na vicikicchati. Na kaṅkhatīti attho. Ayamettha🔽saṅkhepo. Imesu pana nīvaraṇesu vacanatthalakkhaṇādibhedato yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ
analyzed: kho kusalā katham ime kusalā ati evam na vicikicchati na kaṅkhati iti atthaḥ ayam ettha  saṅkhepaḥ imesu pana nīvaraṇesu vacana attha lakkhaṇa ādi bhedataḥ yat vattabbam siyā tat
translated: thinking, “Are these wholesome? How are they wholesome?” The meaning is that he does not hesitate.🔽This is the brief treatment here.

original: sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sabbam visuddhi magge vuttam
translated: But the explanation of the meaning of the terms, the characteristics, etc., of the hindrances should be understood according to the Visuddhimagga.

original: 218. Yā panāyaṃ seyyathāpi mahārājāti upamā vuttā. Tattha iṇaṃ ādāyāti vaḍḍhiyā dhanaṃ🔽gahetvā. Byantiṃ kareyyāti vigatantaṃ kareyya, yathā tesaṃ kākaṇikamattopi pariyanto🔽nāma nāvasissati, evaṃ kareyya; sabbaso paṭiniyyāteyyāti attho. Tato nidānanti āṇaṇyanidānaṃ.🔽So hi “aṇaṇomhī”ti āvajjanto balavapāmojjaṃ labhati, somanassaṃ adhigacchati, tena
analyzed: yā pana ayam sā iyyathā api mahā rāja iti upamā vuttā tattha iṇam ādāya ati vaḍḍhiyā dhanam  gahetvā byantim kareyya ati vigata antam kareyya yathā tesam kākaṇika mattaḥ api pariyantaḥ  nāma na avasissati evam kareyya sabbaso paṭiniyyāteyya ti attho tatas nidānam ti āṇaṇya nidānam  saḥ hi āvajjantaḥ balava pāmojjam labhati somanassam adhigacchati tena
translated: The simile of the great king, etc., is given in order to show the kind of happiness that is the fruit of the kind of faith in the Three Jewels described in the preceding stanza. Herein, having borrowed money on interest means having taken money on interest. He would pay it off means he would pay it off completely, so that not even the smallest part of the interest would remain unpaid; he would pay it off entirely is the meaning. From that cause means from the cause of being free from debt. For when he adverts to himself as “I am free from debt,” he obtains strong joy and gladness,

original: vuttaṃ – “labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassa”nti.
analyzed: vuttam labhetha pāmojjam adhigaccheyya somanassanti
translated: The simile of the great king, etc., is stated in order to show the meaning of the words “he would be glad and satisfied” . Herein, having borrowed money on interest means having taken money on interest. He would make it disappear means he would make it disappear without remainder, so that not even the amount of a sesame seed would remain, he would make it disappear completely: the meaning is, he would hand it all back. From that cause means from the cause of being free from debt. For when he adverts thus, “I am free from debt,” he obtains strong joy, he attains gladness. Hence it was said above: “He would be glad and satisfied” .

original: 219. Visabhāgavedanuppattiyā kakaceneva catuiriyāpathaṃ chindanto ābādhatīti ābādho,
analyzed: visa bhāga vedanā uppattiyā kakacena iva catu iriyāpatham chindantaḥ ābādhati iti ābādhaḥ
translated: It cuts the four postures as if with a saw because it produces an alien feeling, thus it is sickness .

original: svāssa atthīti ābādhiko. Taṃ samuṭṭhānena dukkhena dukkhito. Adhimattagilānoti bāḷhagilāno.
analyzed: atthi iti ābādhiko tam samuṭṭhānena dukkhena dukkhitaḥ adhimatta gilānaḥ ti bāḷha gilānaḥ
translated: He has that, thus he is sick . He is afflicted by the pain that arises from that. He is very ill means he is extremely ill.

original: Nacchādeyyāti adhimattabyādhiparetatāya na rucceyya. Balamattāti balameva, balañcassa
analyzed: na chādeyya ati adhimatta byādhi pareta tāya na rucceyya bala mattā ati balam eva balam ca assa
translated: He would not care means he would not be interested because he is overwhelmed by extreme sickness. Strength means just strength. He has strength, thus he has strength .

original: kāye na bhaveyyāti attho. Tatonidānanti ārogyanidānaṃ. Tassa hi – “arogomhī”ti āvajjayato
analyzed: kāye na bhaveyya ati tatonidānam ti ārogya nidānam tassa hi arogo aham iti āvajjayato
translated: the meaning is, there would be no sickness in the body. ‘For that reason’: for the reason of health. For when he adverts thus, ‘I am healthy,’

original: tadubhayaṃ hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – “labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassa”nti.
analyzed: tat ubhayam hoti tena vuttam labhetha pāmojjam adhigaccheyya somanassanti
translated: both of these are present. Hence it was said above, ‘He would obtain gladness and joy.’

original: 220. Na cassa kiñci bhogānaṃ vayoti kākaṇikamattampi bhogānaṃ vayo na bhaveyya. Tatonidānanti bandhanāmokkhanidānaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva sabbapadesu yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: na ca assa kiñci bhogānam vayaḥ ti kākaṇika mattam pi bhogānam vayaḥ na bhaveyya tatonidānam ti bandha nāmokkha nidānam sesam vutta nayena iva sabba padesu yojetabbam
translated: ‘There would be no loss of any of his wealth’: there would be no loss of even a mere fraction of his wealth. ‘For that reason’: for the reason of release from bondage. The rest should be construed in the same way in all the passages.

original: 221-222. Anattādhīnoti na attani adhīno, attano ruciyā kiñci kātuṃ na labhati. Parādhīnoti🔽paresu adhīno parasseva ruciyā vattati. Na yena kāmaṃ gamoti yena disābhāgenassa
analyzed: an atta adhīnaḥ iti na attani adhīnaḥ attano ruciyā kiñci kātum na labhati para adhīnaḥ iti  paresu adhīnaḥ parassa iva ruciyā vattati na yena kāmam gamaḥ uti yena disābhāgena assa
translated: ‘Not self-dependent’: not dependent on himself, not able to do anything by his own wish. ‘Dependent on others’:

original: gantukāmatā hoti, icchā uppajjati gamanāya, tena gantuṃ na labhati. Dāsabyāti dāsabhāvā.
analyzed: gantu kāma tā hoti icchā uppajjati gamanāya tena gantum na labhati dāsa byāti dāsa bhāvā
translated: dependent on others, he lives by the wish of others. ‘He could not go where he wants’: he cannot go in the direction in which he wants to go, in which he has a desire to go, in which he has a wish to go. ‘Slavery’: the state of being a slave.

original: Bhujissoti attano santako. Tatonidānanti bhujissanidānaṃ. Kantāraddhānamagganti kantāraṃ
analyzed: bhujissaḥ ti attanaḥ santakaḥ tatonidānam ti bhujissa nidānam kantāra ddhānam agganti kantāram
translated: ‘His own’: belonging to himself. ‘For that reason’: for the reason of being his own. ‘The road through the wilderness’:

original: addhānamaggaṃ, nirudakaṃ dīghamagganti attho. Tatonidānanti khemantabhūminidānaṃ.
analyzed: addhānamaggam nirudakam dīgha maggam ti attho tatonidānam ti khemanta bhūmi nidānam
translated: the road to the far end, the meaning being the long road to the end of the water. ‘And that was the occasion for it’: the occasion for it was the land of the Khema people.

original: 223. Ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīneti ettha bhagavā appahīnakāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ iṇasadisaṃ,
analyzed: ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīnā iti ettha bhagavā appahīna kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam iṇa sadisam
translated: ‘He has not abandoned the five hindrances’: here the Blessed One shows the hindrance of lust for sensual desires as being like a debt,

original: sesāni rogādisadisāni katvā dasseti. Tatrāyaṃ sadisatā. Yo hi paresaṃ iṇaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: sesāni roga ādi sadisāni katvā dasseti tatra ayam sadisa tā yaḥ hi paresam iṇam gahetvā
translated: and the remaining hindrances as being like diseases, etc., and this is the similarity. For when someone has borrowed a debt from others

original: vināseti, so tehi iṇaṃ dehīti vuccamānopi pharusaṃ vuccamānopi bajjhamānopi vadhīyamānopi
analyzed: vināseti saḥ tehi iṇam dehi iti vuccamānaḥ api pharusam vuccamānaḥ api bajjhamānaḥ api vadhīyamānaḥ api
translated: and then goes bankrupt, he is told to pay up, and when he is told, he is abused, beaten, and threatened,

original: kiñci paṭibāhituṃ na sakkoti, sabbaṃ titikkhati. Titikkhākāraṇaṃ hissa taṃ iṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kiñci paṭibāhitum na sakkoti sabbam titikkhati titikkhā kāraṇam hi ssa tat iṇam hoti
translated: and he is unable to ward it off in any way; he endures it all. For the reason that he has to pay it back, that debt is to him

original: Evameva yo yamhi kāmacchandena rajjati, taṇhāsahagatena taṃ vatthuṃ gaṇhati, so tena
analyzed: evam eva yaḥ yamhi kāma chandena rajjati taṇhā sahagatena tam vatthum gaṇhati saḥ tena
translated: like endurance. So too, when someone is greedy for something through lust, he takes it up with craving, and when he is told, he is abused, beaten, and threatened,

original: pharusaṃ vuccamānopi bajjhamānopi vadhīyamānopi sabbaṃ titikkhati, titikkhākāraṇaṃ
analyzed: pharusam vuccamānaḥ api bajjhamānaḥ api vadhīyamānaḥ api sabbam titikkhati titikkhā kāraṇam
translated: and he endures it all. For the reason that he has to endure it,🔽that lust is to him like endurance. It is like the case of women who are beaten by their masters.

original: hissa so kāmacchando hoti, gharasāmikehi vadhīyamānānaṃ itthīnaṃ viyāti, evaṃ iṇaṃ
analyzed: hissa saḥ kāmacchandaḥ hoti ghara sāmikehi vadhīyamānānam itthīnam viyāti evam iṇam
translated: So he has not abandoned the hindrance of lust for sensual desires.

original: viya kāmacchando daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: viya kāmacchandaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: and lust should be regarded as the man’s desire for the woman.

original: Yathā pana pittarogāturo madhusakkarādīsupi dinnesu pittarogāturatāya tesaṃ rasaṃ🔽na vindati, “tittakaṃ tittaka”nti uggiratiyeva. Evameva byāpannacitto hitakāmehi🔽ācariyupajjhāyehi appamattakampi ovadiyamāno ovādaṃ na gaṇhati. “Ati viya me tumhe
analyzed: yathā pana pitta roga āturaḥ dinnesu pitta roga āturatāya rasam  na vindati tittakam tittakanti eva evam eva byāpanna cittaḥ hita kāmehi  ācariya upajjhāyehi appamattakam pi ovadiyamānaḥ ovādam na gaṇhati ati viya me tumhe
translated: But just as a man with jaundice, even when given such sweetmeats as are mixed with sugar, honey, etc., does not find their sweetness because of his jaundice,🔽and he only finds bile and vomits, so too, when a man is ill-natured, even when he is advised by well-meaning teachers and preceptors, he does not accept their advice,

original: upaddavethā”tiādīni vatvā vibbhamati. Pittarogāturatāya so puriso madhusakkarādīnaṃ
analyzed: upaddavetha atiādīni vatvā vibbhamati pitta roga ātura tāya saḥ purisaḥ madhu sakkara ādīnam
translated: saying, “You are doing me too much harm,” and he goes away from them. And just as the man with jaundice does not find the sweetness of the sweetmeats,

original: viya kodhāturatāya jhānasukhādibhedaṃ sāsanarasaṃ na vindatīti. Evaṃ rogo viya byāpādo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: viya kodha ātura tāya jhāna sukha ādi bhedam sāsana rasam na vindati iti evam rogaḥ viya byāpādaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: so too, because of his ill-nature, he does not find the taste of the good of the good doctrine, which is of the nature of jhāna-happiness, etc. So ill-nature should be regarded as a disease.

original: Yathā pana nakkhattadivase bandhanāgāre baddho puriso nakkhattassa neva ādiṃ na majjhaṃ
analyzed: yathā pana nakkhatta divase bandhanāgāre baddhaḥ purisaḥ nakkhattassa na iva ādim na majjham
translated: But just as a man imprisoned on a day of the festival of lights cannot see the lights because of being shut up in prison,

original: na pariyosānaṃ passati. So dutiyadivase mutto aho hiyyo nakkhattaṃ manāpaṃ, aho naccaṃ,
analyzed: na pariyosānam passati so dutiya divase muttaḥ aho hiyyas nakkhattam manāpam aho naccam
translated: and on the following day when he is released he says, “Oh, what a pity that I could not see the lights because I was shut up in prison,”

original: aho gītantiādīni sutvāpi paṭivacanaṃ na deti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Nakkhattassa ananubhūtattā.
analyzed: aho gīta nti ādīni sutvā api paṭivacanam na deti kim kāraṇā nakkhattassa an anubhūta ttā
translated: and he does not reply, “Oh, what a song!” and so on. Why not? Because he has not experienced the star.

original: Evameva thinamiddhābhibhūto bhikkhu vicittanayepi dhammassavane pavattamāne neva
analyzed: evam eva thinamiddha abhibhūtaḥ bhikkhu vicitta naye pi dhammassavane pavattamāne na iva
translated: So too, when a bhikkhu is overcome and oppressed by sloth and torpor, even though the Dhamma is being taught to him in various ways,

original: tassa ādiṃ na majjhaṃ na pariyosānaṃ jānāti. Sopi uṭṭhite dhammassavane aho dhammassavanaṃ,🔽aho kāraṇaṃ, aho upamāti dhammassavanassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānānaṃ sutvāpi paṭivacanaṃ
analyzed: tassa ādim na majjham na pariyosānam jānāti saḥ api uṭṭhite dhammassavane aho dhammassavanam  aho kāraṇam aho upamā ati dhammassavanassa vaṇṇam bhaṇamānānam sutvā api paṭivacanam
translated: he does not know the beginning, the middle, or the end of that Dhamma talk. And when the Dhamma talk is over and others are praising the Dhamma,🔽he does not reply, “Oh, what a Dhamma talk!

original: na deti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Thinamiddhavasena dhammakathāya ananubhūtattā. Evaṃ bandhanāgāraṃ🔽viya thinamiddhaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na deti kim kāraṇā thinam iddha vasena dhamma kathāya an anubhūta ttā evam bandhanāgāram  viya thinamiddham daṭṭhabbam
translated: Oh, what an explanation! Oh, what a simile!” Why not? Because he has not experienced the Dhamma talk owing to sloth and torpor. So sloth and torpor should be seen as like a prison.🔽But just as the slave who is playing truant from the star festival, even though he is enjoying himself,

original: Yathā pana nakkhattaṃ kīḷantopi dāso – “idaṃ nāma accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ atthi, sīghaṃ
analyzed: yathā pana nakkhattam kīḷantaḥ pi dāsaḥ idam nāma accāyikam karaṇīyam atthi sīgham
translated: does not reply, “There is this urgent task to be done; go there quickly,”

original: tattha gacchāhi. No ce gacchasi, hatthapādaṃ vā te chindāmi kaṇṇanāsaṃ vā”ti vutto
analyzed: tattha gacchāhi no ce gacchasi hattha pādam vā te chindāmi kaṇṇa nāsam vā iti vuttaḥ
translated: when told, “If you do not go, I shall have your hands and feet or your ears and nose cut off,”

original: sīghaṃ gacchatiyeva. Nakkhattassa ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ anubhavituṃ na labhati, kasmā?
analyzed: sīgham gacchatiyā iva nakkhattassa ādi majjha pariyosānam anubhavitum na labhati kasmā
translated: and it goes on its way. He does not get to experience the beginning, middle, and end of the constellation. Why is this?

original: Parādhīnatāya, evameva vinaye apakataññunā vivekatthāya araññaṃ paviṭṭhenāpi kismiñcideva🔽antamaso kappiyamaṃsepi akappiyamaṃsasaññāya uppannāya vivekaṃ pahāya sīlavisodhanatthaṃ
analyzed: para adhīna tāya evam eva vinaye apakataññunā viveka tthāya araññam paviṭṭhena api kismiñcid eva  antamaso kappiya maṃse pi akappiya maṃsa saññāya uppannāya vivekam pahāya sīla visodhana ttham
translated: Because he is dependent on another. So too, when one who is ungrateful for the solitude enters the forest for the sake of solitude,🔽then, if a perception of what is not allowable arises in him about what is allowable, even if it is only about meat, he has to abandon the solitude

original: vinayadharassa santikaṃ gantabbaṃ hoti, vivekasukhaṃ anubhavituṃ na labhati, kasmā?
analyzed: vinaya dharassa santikam gantabbam hoti viveka sukham anubhavitum na labhati kasmā
translated: and go to one who knows the Discipline for the sake of purifying his virtue. He does not get to experience the bliss of solitude. Why is this?

original: Uddhaccakukkuccābhibhūtatāyāti. Evaṃ dāsabyaṃ viya uddhaccakukkuccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Yathā pana kantāraddhānamaggappaṭipanno puriso corehi manussānaṃ viluttokāsaṃ pahatokāsañca
analyzed: uddhacca kukkucca abhibhūta tāya ati evam dāsabyam viya uddhacca kukkuccam daṭṭhabbam  yathā pana kantāra dhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ purisaḥ corehi manussānam vilutta ukāsam pahata ukāsam ca
translated: Because he is overcome by agitation and worry. So agitation and worry should be regarded as slavery.🔽Just as when a man is travelling along a desert path and he sees a place where men have been robbed and a place where they have been killed,

original: disvā daṇḍakasaddenapi sakuṇasaddenapi “corā āgatā”ti ussaṅkitaparisaṅkitova hoti,
analyzed: disvā daṇḍaka saddena api sakuṇa saddena api corāḥ āgatā ati ussaṅkita parisaṅkitaḥ uva hoti
translated: and then, suspecting danger from bandits, he is anxious and fearful even at the sound of a harmless stump or bush,

original: gacchatipi tiṭṭhatipi nivattatipi, gataṭṭhānato agataṭṭhānameva bahutaraṃ hoti. So
analyzed: gacchati ipi tiṭṭhati ipi nivattati ipi gata ṭṭhānataḥ a gata ṭṭhānam eva bahutaram hoti so
translated: and he goes on his way, and he stands, and he turns back, and the places he has gone to are more than the places he has not gone to,

original: kicchena kasirena khemantabhūmiṃ pāpuṇāti vā na vā pāpuṇāti. Evameva yassa aṭṭhasu
analyzed: kicchena kasirena khemanta bhūmim pāpuṇāti vā na vā pāpuṇāti evam eva yassa aṭṭhasu
translated: and he may or may not reach the place of safety. So too, when doubt has arisen in him in the eight cases beginning with the Buddha,

original: ṭhānesu vicikicchā uppannā hoti, so – “buddho nu kho, no nu kho buddho”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: ṭhānesu vicikicchā uppannā hoti saḥ buddhaḥ nu kho no nu kho buddha iti ādinā nayena
translated: he is doubtful thus, “Is the Buddha …? or is he not? ”

original: vicikicchanto adhimuccitvā saddhāya gaṇhituṃ na sakkoti. Asakkonto maggaṃ vā phalaṃ
analyzed: vicikicchantaḥ adhimuccitvā saddhāya gaṇhitum na sakkoti a sakkontaḥ maggam vā phalam
translated: and he is unable to take up the true state of faith by resolving the doubt. Being unable to do that, he does not reach the path and fruition.

original: vā na pāpuṇātīti. Yathā kantāraddhānamagge – “corā atthi natthī”ti punappunaṃ āsappanaparisappanaṃ
analyzed: vā na pāpuṇāti iti yathā kantāraddhāna magge corāḥ atthi natthi iti punappunam āsappana parisappanam
translated: Just as, on a journey through the desert, the repeated thinking and pondering thus, “Are there or are there not bandits on this road? ”

original: apariyogāhanaṃ chambhitattaṃ cittassa uppādento khemantapattiyā antarāyaṃ karoti,
analyzed: a pariyogāhanam chambhita ttam cittassa uppādento khemanta pattiyā antarāyam karoti
translated: causes anxiety and agitation in the mind and is an obstacle to reaching the place of safety,

original: evaṃ vicikicchāpi – “buddho nu kho, na buddho”tiādinā nayena punappunaṃ āsappanaparisappanaṃ
analyzed: evam vicikicchā api buddhaḥ nu kho na buddhaḥ iti ādinā nayena punappunam āsappana parisappanam
translated: so too, doubt, by causing anxiety and agitation in the mind through the repeated thinking and pondering thus, “Is the Buddha …? or is he not? ”

original: apariyogāhanaṃ chambhitattaṃ cittassa uppādayamānā ariyabhūmippattiyā antarāyaṃ karotīti🔽kantāraddhānamaggo viya vicikicchā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: a pariyogāhanam chambhita ttam cittassa uppādayamānā ariya bhūmi ppattiyā antarāyam karoti iti 🔽viya vicikicchā daṭṭhabbā
translated: is an obstacle to reaching the noble plane.

original: 224. Idāni – “seyyathāpi, mahārāja, āṇaṇya”nti ettha bhagavā pahīnakāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: idāni sā iyyathā api mahā rāja āṇaṇyanti ettha bhagavān pahīna kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam
translated: Now, in the passage beginning “Suppose, sire, a man were free from debt” the Blessed One is showing the removal of the hindrance of sensual desire.

original: āṇaṇyasadisaṃ, sesāni ārogyādisadisāni katvā dasseti. Tatrāyaṃ sadisatā, yathā hi
analyzed: sesāni ārogya ādi sadisāni katvā tatra ayam sadisa tā yathā hi
translated: Now, in the passage beginning, “As, sire, a man free from debt,” the Blessed One shows the hindrance of lust for sensual desires as similar to debt, and the other hindrances as similar to the others beginning with sickness. Here is the similarity:

original: puriso iṇaṃ ādāya kammante payojetvā samiddhataṃ patto – “idaṃ iṇaṃ nāma palibodhamūla”nti🔽cintetvā savaḍḍhikaṃ iṇaṃ niyyātetvā paṇṇaṃ phālāpeyya. Athassa tato paṭṭhāya neva
analyzed: purisaḥ iṇam ādāya kammante payojetvā samidh hatam patto idam iṇam nāma palibodha mūlanti  cintetvā savaḍḍhikam iṇam niyyātetvā paṇṇam phālāpeyya athassa tatas paṭṭhāya na iva
translated: Suppose a man, having borrowed a sum of money on interest, has become prosperous and thinks, “This debt is a hindrance to me,”

original: koci dūtaṃ peseti, na paṇṇaṃ. So iṇasāmike disvāpi sace icchati, āsanā uṭṭhahati,
analyzed: koci dūtam peseti na paṇṇam saḥ iṇa sāmike disvā api sace icchati āsanā uṭṭhahati
translated: and he pays off the principal and interest and has the bond burned in fire, after which no one can send him a message or a bill. If he sees the man to whom he owed the money, he need not get up from his seat if he does not want to,

original: no ce na uṭṭhahati, kasmā? Tehi saddhiṃ nillepatāya alaggatāya. Evameva bhikkhu –🔽“ayaṃ kāmacchando nāma palibodhamūla”nti cintetvā cha dhamme bhāvetvā kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: no ce na uṭṭhahati kasmā tehi saddhim nillepa tāya a lagga tāya evam eva bhikkhu  ayam kāmacchandaḥ nāma palibodha mūlanti cintetvā dhamme bhāvetvā kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam
translated: and why is that? Because he is not entangled with him, is not tied to him. So too, a bhikkhu thinks,🔽“This lust for sensual desires is a hindrance to me,” and he abandons the hindrance of lust for sensual desires by developing the six ideas. We shall deal with the six ideas in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta .

original: pajahati. Te pana cha dhamme mahāsatipaṭṭhāne vaṇṇayissāma. Tassevaṃ pahīnakāmacchandassa
analyzed: pajahati te pana cha dhamme mahāsati paṭṭhāne vaṇṇayissāma tassa ivam pahīna kāmacchandassa
translated: When he has abandoned the hindrance of lust for sensual desires in this way,

original: yathā iṇamuttassa purisassa iṇassāmike disvā neva bhayaṃ na chambhitattaṃ hoti. Evameva
analyzed: yathā iṇamuttassa purisassa disvā na iva bhayam na chambhitattam hoti evam eva
translated: just as when a man who is free from debt sees the creditor, he has no fear or terror.

original: paravatthumhi neva saṅgo na baddho hoti. Dibbānipi rūpāni passato kileso na samudācarati.
analyzed: para vatthumhi nā iva saṅgaḥ na baddhaḥ hoti dibbāni api rūpāni passato kilesaḥ na samudācarati
translated: So too, he is not attached to or bound to the object of another’s mind. And when he sees even divine forms, defilements do not invade him.

original: Tasmā bhagavā āṇaṇyamiva kāmacchandappahānaṃ āha.
analyzed: tasmai bhagavān āṇaṇyam iva kāmacchanda ppahānam āha
translated: That is why the Blessed One said that the abandoning of lust is like being free from debt.

original: Yathā pana so pittarogāturo puriso bhesajjakiriyāya taṃ rogaṃ vūpasametvā tato paṭṭhāya🔽madhusakkarādīnaṃ rasaṃ vindati. Evameva bhikkhu “ayaṃ byāpādo nāma mahā anatthakaro”ti
analyzed: yathā pana saḥ pitta roga āturaḥ purisaḥ bhesajja kiriyāya tam rogam vūpasametvā tatas paṭṭhāya  madhu sakkara ādīnam rasam vindati evam eva bhikkhu ayam byāpādaḥ nāma mahā anattha karoti
translated: But just as the man suffering from bile, after the treatment has quieted the bile,🔽finds the taste of honey, sugar, etc., to be good, so too, the bhikkhu, after he has abandoned the defilements by developing the six ideas beginning with the contemplation of the unattractive, abandons the hindrance of ill will.

original: cha dhamme bhāvetvā byāpādanīvaraṇaṃ pajahati. Sabbanīvaraṇesu cha dhamme mahāsatipaṭṭhāneyeva🔽vaṇṇayissāma. Na kevalañca teyeva, yepi thinamiddhādīnaṃ pahānāya bhāvetabbā, tepi
analyzed: cha dhamme bhāvetvā byāpāda nīvaraṇam pajahati sabba nīvaraṇesu cha dhamme  vaṇṇayissāma na kevalam ca te ye iva ye pi thinamiddha ādīnam pahānāya bhāvetabbā te pi
translated: We shall deal with the six ideas in the Great Forty.🔽And not only with those, but also with all the ideas that should be developed for the abandoning of stiffness and torpor, etc.,🔽we shall deal with in the same place.

original: sabbe tattheva vaṇṇayissāma. So evaṃ pahīnabyāpādo yathā pittarogavimutto puriso
analyzed: sabbe tattha eva vaṇṇayissāma saḥ evam pahīna byāpādaḥ yathā pitta roga vimuttaḥ purisaḥ
translated: So when he has abandoned ill will in this way, he is like the man free from the bile disease,

original: madhusakkarādīnaṃ rasaṃ sampiyāyamāno paṭisevati, evameva ācārapaṇṇattiādīni sikkhāpadāni
analyzed: madhu sakkara ādīnam rasam sampiyāyamānaḥ paṭisevati evam eva ācāra paṇṇatti ādīni sikkhāpadāni
translated: and he enjoys the taste of honey, sugar, etc., so too the bhikkhu enjoys the training precepts such as the rules of conduct, etc.,

original: sirasā sampaṭicchitvā sampiyāyamāno sikkhati. Tasmā bhagavā ārogyamiva byāpādappahānaṃ āha.
analyzed: sirasā sampaṭicchitvā sampiyāyamānaḥ sikkhati tasmai bhagavā ārogyam iva byāpāda ppahānam āha
translated: and he trains in them with relish after accepting them on his head. That is why the Blessed One said that the abandoning of ill will is like health.

original: Yathā so nakkhattadivase bandhanāgāraṃ pavesito puriso aparasmiṃ nakkhattadivase🔽– “pubbepi ahaṃ pamādadosena baddho, tena nakkhattaṃ nānubhaviṃ. Idāni appamatto
analyzed: yathā saḥ nakkhatta divase bandhanāgāram pavesitaḥ purisaḥ aparasmin nakkhatta divase  pubbe api aham pamāda dosena baddhaḥ tena nakkhattam na anubhavim idāni appamatto
translated: Just as the man who was put in prison on the day of the full moon of the lunar month and who🔽on the day of the full moon of the lunar month🔽after he had been released from prison,

original: bhavissāmī”ti yathāssa paccatthikā okāsaṃ na labhanti, evaṃ appamatto hutvā nakkhattaṃ
analyzed: bhavissāmi iti yathā assa paccatthikāḥ okāsam na labhanti evam appamattaḥ hutvā nakkhattaṃ
translated: being careful not to give his enemies an opportunity,🔽enjoyed the full moon of the lunar month,

original: anubhavitvā – ‘aho nakkhattaṃ, aho nakkhatta’nti udānaṃ udānesi, evameva bhikkhu🔽– “idaṃ thinamiddhaṃ nāma mahāanatthakara”nti cha dhamme bhāvetvā thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: anubhavitvā aho nakkhattam aho nakkhattam ti udānam udānesi evam eva bhikkhu  idam thinamiddham nāma cha dhamme bhāvetvā thinamiddha nīvaraṇam
translated: and exclaimed: “What a full moon! What a full moon!”🔽so too the bhikkhu, after he has developed the six things beginning with the recollection of the Buddha and has abandoned the hindrance of sloth and torpor,

original: pajahati, so evaṃ pahīnathinamiddho yathā bandhanā mutto puriso sattāhampi nakkhattassa
analyzed: pajahati saḥ evam pahīna thinamiddhaḥ yathā bandhanā mutto puriso satta aham pi nakkhattassa
translated: and after he has thus abandoned sloth and torpor,

original: ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ anubhavati, evameva dhammanakkhattassa ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ🔽anubhavanto saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā bhagavā bandhanā mokkhamiva
analyzed: ādi majjha pariyosānam anubhavati evam eva dhammanakkhattassa ādi majjha pariyosānam  anubhavantaḥ saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam pāpuṇāti tasmai bhagavā bandhanā mokkham iva
translated: and he experiences the beginning, middle and end of the moon’s phases, so too, experiencing the beginning, middle and end of the constellation of the Dhamma,

original: thinamiddhappahānaṃ āha.
analyzed: āha
translated: he reaches Arahantship together with the analytical knowledges. Therefore the Blessed One said that the abandoning of sloth and torpor is like the release from bondage.

original: Yathā pana dāso kiñcideva mittaṃ upanissāya sāmikānaṃ dhanaṃ datvā attānaṃ bhujissaṃ🔽katvā tato paṭṭhāya yaṃ icchati, taṃ karoti. Evameva bhikkhu – “idaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ
analyzed: yathā pana dāsaḥ kiñcid eva mittam upanissāya sāmikānam dhanam da tvā attānam bhujissam  katvā tatas paṭṭhāya yam icchati tam karoti evam eva bhikkhu idam uddhacca kukkuccaṃ
translated: But just as a slave, having taken a loan from his master and having made himself free by repaying it,🔽then does what he wants, so too, the bhikkhu, having developed the six ideas, abandons sloth and torpor.

original: nāma mahā anatthakara”nti cha dhamme bhāvetvā uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pajahati. So evaṃ🔽pahīnauddhaccakukkucco yathā bhujisso puriso yaṃ icchati, taṃ karoti, na taṃ koci
analyzed: nāma mahā anattha karanti cha dhamme bhāvetvā uddhacca kukkuccam pajahati saḥ evam  pahīna auddhacca kukkuccaḥ yathā bhujissaḥ purisaḥ yam icchati tam karoti na tam koci
translated: And he, having abandoned sloth and torpor,

original: balakkārena tato nivatteti, evameva yathā sukhaṃ nekkhammapaṭipadaṃ paṭipajjati,
analyzed: balakkārena tatas nivatteti evam eva yathā sukham nekkhamma paṭipadam paṭipajjati
translated: does what he wants, and no one can turn him back by force from doing it, just as a free man does what he wants and no one can turn him back by force from doing it. So too, the bhikkhu, having abandoned sloth and torpor,

original: na taṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ balakkārena tato nivatteti. Tasmā bhagavā bhujissaṃ viya
analyzed: na tam uddhacca kukkuccam balakkārena tatas nivatteti tasmai bhagavā bhujissam viya
translated: practices the way to renunciation as he wishes, and no one can turn him back by force from doing it. Therefore the Blessed One said that the abandoning of sloth and torpor is like a free man.

original: uddhaccakukkuccappahānaṃ āha.
analyzed: āha
translated: and the abandoning of agitation and worry.

original: Yathā balavā puriso hatthasāraṃ gahetvā sajjāvudho saparivāro kantāraṃ paṭipajjeyya,🔽taṃ corā dūratova disvā palāyeyyuṃ. So sotthinā taṃ kantāraṃ nittharitvā khemantaṃ🔽patto haṭṭhatuṭṭho assa. Evameva bhikkhu “ayaṃ vicikicchā nāma mahā anatthakārikā”ti🔽cha dhamme bhāvetvā vicikicchaṃ pajahati. So evaṃ pahīnavicikiccho yathā balavā puriso🔽sajjāvudho saparivāro nibbhayo core tiṇaṃ viya agaṇetvā sotthinā nikkhamitvā khemantabhūmiṃ🔽pāpuṇāti, evameva bhikkhu duccaritakantāraṃ nittharitvā paramaṃ khemantabhūmiṃ amataṃ
analyzed: yathā balavā purisaḥ hattha sāram gahetvā sajjāvudhaḥ sa parivāraḥ kantāram paṭipajjeyya  tam corāḥ dūratas va disvā palāyeyyum saḥ sa utthinā tam kantāram nittharitvā khemantam  pattaḥ haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ assa evam eva bhikkhu ayam vicikicchā nāma mahā anattha kārikā ti  cha dhamme bhāvetvā vicikiccham pajahati saḥ evam pahīna vicikicchaḥ yathā balavā purisaḥ  sajjāvudhaḥ sa parivāraḥ nibbhayaḥ core tiṇam viya a gaṇetvā sa utthinā nikkhamitvā khemanta bhūmiṃ  pāpuṇāti evam eva bhikkhu duccarita kantāram nittharitvā paramam khemanta bhūmim amatam
translated: Just as a strong man, taking a sharp knife, were to enter a cow-pen,

original: mahānibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā bhagavā khemantabhūmiṃ viya vicikicchāpahānaṃ āha.
analyzed: mahā nibbānam pāpuṇāti tasmai bhagavā khemanta bhūmim viya vicikicchā apahānam āha

original: 225. Pāmojjaṃ jāyatīti tuṭṭhākāro jāyati. Pamuditassa pīti jāyatīti tuṭṭhassa sakalasarīraṃ🔽khobhayamānā pīti jāyati. Pītimanassa kāyo passambhatīti pītisampayuttacittassa puggalassa🔽nāmakāyo passambhati, vigatadaratho hoti. Sukhaṃ vedetīti kāyikampi cetasikampi sukhaṃ
analyzed: pāmojjam jāyati iti tuṭṭha ākāraḥ jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati iti tuṭṭhassa sakala sarīram  khobhayamānā pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati iti pīti sampayutta cittassa puggalassa  nāmakāyaḥ passambhati vigata darathaḥ hoti sukham vedeti iti kāyikam pi cetasikam pi sukham
translated: He feels rapture: the state of being glad arises. When he is rapturous, his body is tranquil: glad, his whole body is thrilled with bliss.

original: vedayati. Cittaṃ samādhiyatīti iminā nekkhammasukhena sukhitassa upacāravasenapi
analyzed: vedayati cittam samādhiyati iti iminā nekkhamma sukhena sukhitassa upacāra vasena api
translated: When his body is tranquil, he feels pleasure: in the person whose mind is associated with rapture, his material body is tranquil, being freed from disquiet. He meditates: he attends, he devotes himself, he exerts his will, he strives, he makes an effort, he strives with all his mind, he exerts his energy, he exerts his mind, he makes an effort with his teeth clenched and his lips closed.

original: appanāvasenapi cittaṃ samādhiyati.🔽Paṭhamajjhānakathā
analyzed: appanā vasena api cittam
translated: He is equanimous, mindful, and clearly comprehending: he is equanimous through equanimity of mind, mindful through equanimity of mindfulness, clearly comprehending through equanimity of knowledge.🔽The first jhāna: for the explanation of the first jhāna, which begins with the words, “Quite secluded from sensual desires, secluded from unwholesome states,” should be understood as given in the Description of the Jhanas .

original: 226. So vivicceva kāmehi…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatītiādi pana upacārasamādhinā

He meditates: he attends, he devotes himself, he exerts his will, he strives, he makes an effort, he strives with all his mind, he exerts his energy, he exerts his mind, he makes an effort with his teeth clenched and his lips closed.

original: samāhite citte uparivisesadassanatthaṃ appanāsamādhinā samāhite citte tassa samādhino
analyzed: samāhite citte upari visesa dassana attham appanā samādhinā samāhite citte tassa samādhino

translated: He makes it wet: he makes it sticky. He makes it thoroughly soaked: he makes it thoroughly sticky. He makes it steamed: he makes it steamed with the heat of the water. He evenly smooths it: he evenly smooths it with his hands. He evenly handles it: he evenly handles it with his hands.

original: Sanneyyāti vāmahatthena kaṃsathālaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇahatthena pamāṇayuttaṃ udakaṃ
analyzed: sanneyya ati vāma hatthena kaṃsa thālam gahetvā dakkhiṇa hatthena pamāṇa yuttam udakam
