He makes it well burnished: he makes it well burnished with his hands. He makes it well consolidated: he makes it well consolidated with his hands. He makes it well pliable: he makes it well pliable with his hands. He makes it well tempered: he makes it well tempered with his hands. He makes it well ready for working: he makes it well ready for working with his hands. He makes it well workable: he makes it well workable with his hands. He makes it well workable in every way: he makes it well workable in every way with his hands. He makes it well workable in every direction and in every part and in every way: he makes it well workable in every direction and in every part and in every way with his hands.🔽He makes it well workable in every direction and in every part and in every way: he makes it well workable in every direction and in every part and in every way with his hands. He makes it well workable in every direction

analyzed: kātum attho
translated: or it can be made into a ring.

original: Dutiyajjhānakathā
analyzed: dutiya jhāna kathā
translated: The Second Jhana

original: 228-229. Dutiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ ubbhidodakoti ubbhinnaudako, na heṭṭhā ubbhijjitvā
analyzed: dutiya jhāna sukha upamā ayam ubbhida udakaḥ iti ubbhinna odakaḥ na heṭṭhā ubbhijjitvā
translated: In the simile for the pleasure of the second jhana the ‘springing well’ is a well that springs up, not one dug below.

original: uggacchanakaudako. Antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti attho. Āyamukhanti āgamanamaggo.
analyzed: uggacchanaka odakaḥ anto yā iva pana ubbhijjanaka odakaḥ ti attho āya mukham ti āgamana maggo
translated: The meaning is, it is a well that springs up inside. ‘The path it comes up by’: the path by which it comes up.

original: Devoti megho. Kālena kālanti kāle kāle, anvaddhamāsaṃ vā anudasāhaṃ vāti attho. Dhāranti
analyzed: devo ti megho kālena kālanti kāle kāle anvaddha māsam vā anudasāham vā attho dhāranti
translated: ‘God’: a cloud. ‘In time’: from time to time; the meaning is, every half-month or every month. ‘Rains down’:

analyzed: vuṭṭhim na anuppaveccheyya ati na ca paveseyya na vasseyya ati attho sītā vāri dhārā
translated: and the rain. He would not let it in: he would not let it enter, he would not let it rain, is the meaning. A cool stream of water

analyzed: uggantvā uggantvā bhijjantam udakam khobheti catūhi disāhi pavisana odakam purāṇa paṇṇa tiṇa kaṭṭha daṇḍaka ādīhi  udakam khobheti vuṭṭhi udakam dhārā nipāta pubbuḷakehi udakam khobheti sannisinnam eva
translated: churns the water that is rising and breaking up. Water entering from the four quarters churns the water with old leaves, grass, sticks, branches, etc.,

analyzed: pana hutvā iddhi nimmitam iva uppajjamānam udakam imam padesam pharati imam padesam
translated: and the rain-water churns the water with the bubbles formed by the downpour. But the water that wells up, as it were, by appearing while remaining evenly distributed,

original: na pharatīti natthi, tena aphuṭokāso nāma na hotīti. Tattha rahado viya karajakāyo.
analyzed: na pharati iti natthi tena aphuṭokāsaḥ nāma na hoti iti tattha rahadaḥ viya karaja kāyo
translated: does not do so in one place and not in another. So there is no such thing as a place that is not covered by it. Herein, the physical body is like the pool.

original: Udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: udakam viya dutiya jhāna sukham sesam purima nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The pleasure of the second jhāna is like the water. The rest can be understood in the way already described.

original: Tatiyajjhānakathā
analyzed: tatiya jhāna kathā
translated: The third jhāna

original: 230-231. Tatiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī. Sesapadadvayepi
analyzed: uppalāni ettha santi iti uppalinī sesa pada dvaye pi
translated: In the simile of the third-jhāna pleasure, “It has lotuses in it” is “lotusy.” So too with the other two terms.

original: eseva nayo. Ettha ca setarattanīlesu yaṃ kiñci uppalaṃ uppalameva. Ūnakasatapattaṃ🔽puṇḍarīkaṃ, satapattaṃ padumaṃ. Pattaniyamaṃ vā vināpi setaṃ padumaṃ, rattaṃ puṇḍarīkanti🔽ayamettha vinicchayo. Udakānuggatānīti udakato na uggatāni. Anto nimuggaposīnīti
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ettha ca seta ratta nīlesu yam kiñci uppalam uppalam eva ūnaka sata pattam  puṇḍarīkam sata pattam padumam patta niyamam vā vinā api setam padumam rattam puṇḍarīkanti  ayam ettha vinicchayaḥ udaka anuggatāni iti udakataḥ na uggatāni antar nimugga posīni iti
translated: In the simile for the third jhāna the words “with its water-lilies and lotuses” are a collective term for the various kinds of water-lilies and lotuses. The rest is as already stated. And here any kind of water-lily or lotus that is white is a “white water-lily or lotus,” and one with less than a hundred petals is a “white water-lily,”

original: udakatalassa anto nimuggāniyeva hutvā posīni, vaḍḍhīnīti attho. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.🔽Catutthajjhānakathā🔽232-233. Catutthajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātenāti ettha nirupakkilesaṭṭhena
analyzed: udaka talassa antar nimuggāniyā iva hutvā posīni vaḍḍhīni iti attho sesam purima nayena iva veditabbam         catuttha jhāna sukha upamā ayam parisuddhena cetasā ettha nirupakkilesaṭṭhena
translated: while one with a hundred petals is a “white lotus.” Or alternatively, any white lotus without reference to the number of petals is a “white water-lily,” while a red lotus is a “red water-lily.” This is the method of explanation here. “With water-lilies and lotuses that have not blossomed”: they have not risen above the water. “With water-lilies and lotuses that have blossomed”: they have risen above the water. “With water-lilies and lotuses in blossom”: they are in full flower. The rest is as already stated.🔽In the simile for the fourth jhāna the words “with his heart … suffused with radiance” are a collective term for the various kinds of radiance. Herein, “suffused” is continuity; “with radiance” is with the radiance of happiness. The rest is as already stated.

original: parisuddhaṃ, pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātanti veditabbaṃ. Odātena vatthenāti idaṃ utupharaṇatthaṃ
analyzed: parisuddham pabhassara ṭṭhena pariyodātanti veditabbam odātena vatthena ati idam utu pharaṇa attham
translated: In the passage “with a mind well established in the four establishments of mindfulness” the “four establishments of mindfulness” are a collective term for the various kinds of mindfulness. Herein, “mindfulness” is recollection ; “establishment” is steadying . The rest is as already stated.

original: vuttaṃ. Kiliṭṭhavatthena hi utupharaṇaṃ na hoti, taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena utupharaṇaṃ
analyzed: vuttam kiliṭṭha vatthena hi utu pharaṇam na hoti utu pharaṇam
translated: For when the cloth is dirty, the oil does not spread on it;

original: balavaṃ hoti. Imissāya hi upamāya vatthaṃ viya karajakāyo, utupharaṇaṃ viya catutthajjhānasukhaṃ.
analyzed: balavam hoti imissāya hi upamāya vattham viya karaja kāyaḥ utu pharaṇam viya catuttha jhāna sukham
translated: but when it is washed clean, the oil spreads on it well. And here the body is like the cloth in the simile, and the pleasure of the fourth jhāna is like the oil.

original: Tasmā yathā sunhātassa purisassa parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa🔽sarīrato utu sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati. Na koci vatthassa aphuṭokāso hoti. Evaṃ catutthajjhānasukhena
analyzed: tasmai yathā sunhātassa purisassa parisuddham vattham sa sīsam pārupitvā nisinnassa  sarīrataḥ utu sabbam eva vattham pharati na koci vatthassa aphuṭa ukāsaḥ hoti evam catuttha jhāna sukhena
translated: So just as when a man who has bathed and is well anointed with oil sits down wrapped from head to foot in a clean cloth,🔽then the oil spreads over the whole of the cloth and there is no part of the body uncovered by the cloth, so too, with the bhikkhu’s body pervaded by the pleasure divested of rapture,

original: bhikkhuno karajakāyassa na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti. Evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Imesaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhuno karaja kāyassa na koci okāsaḥ a phuṭaḥ hoti iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ imesam
translated: there is no external part of his body that is not suffused by the pleasure born of concentration. This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ anupadavaṇṇanā ca bhāvanānayo ca visuddhimagge vuttoti idha na vitthārito.
analyzed: pana catunnam jhānānam anupada vaṇṇanā ca bhāvanā nayo ca visuddhi magge vutto ti idha na vitthāritaḥ
translated: But the explanation of the succession of the four jhānas and the method of their development have been given in the Visuddhimagga, so I shall not weary my hand further here.

original: Ettāvatā cesa rūpajjhānalābhīyeva, na arūpajjhānalābhīti na veditabbo. Na hi aṭṭhasu
analyzed: ettāvatā ca isa rūpa jhāna lābhīya iva na arūpa jhāna lābhī iti na veditabbaḥ na hi aṭṭhasu
translated: So far it should not be supposed that he has only attained the jhāna in the form realm and not that in the formless realm.

original: samāpattīsu cuddasahākārehi ciṇṇavasībhāvaṃ vinā upari abhiññādhigamo hoti. Pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: samāpattīsu cuddasahākārehi ciṇṇavasībhāvam vinā upari abhiññā adhigamaḥ hoti pāḷiyam
translated: He has attained mastery in the eight attainments in the fourteen ways. Without that he cannot reach the higher direct knowledges.

original: pana rūpajjhānāniyeva āgatāni. Arūpajjhānāni āharitvā kathetabbāni.
analyzed: pana rūpa jhānāni yeva āgatāni arūpa jhānāni āharitvā kathetabbāni
translated: But only the form jhana attainments are mentioned in the text. The formless attainments should be included by implication.

original: Vipassanāñāṇakathā
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇa kathā
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of insight

original: 234. So evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatteti so cuddasahākārehi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citta īpe so cuddasahākārehi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu
translated: So when his concentrated mind, purified and bright, is malleable, wieldy and steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints. He is a bhikkhu who has attained mastery in the eight attainments in the fourteen ways.

original: ciṇṇavasībhāvo bhikkhūti dasseti. Sesamettha visuddhimagge vuttanayena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ciṇṇavasībhāvaḥ bhikkhū ti dasseti sesam ettha visuddhi magge vutta nayena veditabbam
translated: The rest should be understood in the way already stated in the Description of the Path of Purification.

original: Ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharatīti ettha ñāṇadassananti maggañāṇampi, vuccati phalañāṇampi,
analyzed: ñāṇa dassanāya cittam abhinīharati iti ettha ñāṇa dassanam ti magga ñāṇam pi vuccati phala ñāṇam pi
translated: He directs, bends, and inclines his mind to the knowledge and vision of what things are wholesome and what are unwholesome: here “knowledge and vision” is the path knowledge, and it is also fruit knowledge,

original: sabbaññutaññāṇampi, paccavekkhaṇañāṇampi, vipassanāñāṇampi. “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, ñāṇadassanavisuddhatthaṃ
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇam pi paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam pi vipassanā ñāṇam pi kim nu kho āvuso ñāṇa dassana visuddha attham
translated: and it is also the knowledge of omniscience, and it is also reviewing knowledge, and it is also knowledge of insight. For in the passage, “Friends, is the life of purity lived for the sake of knowledge and vision? ”

original: bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti ettha hi maggañāṇaṃ ñāṇadassananti vuttaṃ. “Ayamañño
analyzed: bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati iti ettha hi magga ñāṇam ñāṇa dassanam ti vuttam ayam aññaḥ
translated: it is path knowledge that is called “knowledge and vision.” And in the passage, “This is the only straight path, friends, the path not going awry, the path to be followed by one who sees, namely, the four factors of stream-entry” ,

original: uttarimanussadhammo alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti ettha phalañāṇaṃ.
analyzed: uttari manussa dhammaḥ alam ariya ñāṇa dassana visesaḥ adhigataḥ phāsu vihāro ti ettha phala ñāṇam
translated: “I have attained a superhuman state, a distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones” , the knowledge of fruition.

original: “Bhagavatopi kho ñāṇadassanaṃ udapādi sattāhakālaṅkato āḷāro kālāmo”ti ettha sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ api kho ñāṇa dassanam udapādi satta aha kālaṅkataḥ āḷāraḥ kālāmaḥ ti ettha sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: “Knowledge and vision arose in me: ‘Arahantship has been attained by me’ ” , the knowledge of omniscience.

original: “Ñāṇañca pana me dassanaṃ udapādi akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jātī”ti ettha paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam ca pana me dassanam udapādi akuppā me vimutti ayam antimā jāti iti ettha paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam
translated: “Knowledge and vision arose in me: ‘My deliverance is unshakeable; this is my last birth; now there is no renewal of being’ ” , the knowledge of reviewing.

original: idha pana ñāṇadassanāya cittanti idaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ ñāṇadassananti vuttanti.
analyzed: idha pana ñāṇa dassanāya cittan ti idam vipassanā ñāṇam ñāṇa dassananti vuttanti
translated: But here the knowledge and vision of the way is called “knowledge and vision” .

original: Abhinīharatīti vipassanāñāṇassa nibbattanatthāya tanninnaṃ tappoṇaṃ tappabbhāraṃ
analyzed: abhinīharati iti vipassanā ñāṇassa nibbattana thāya tat ninnam tad poṇam tad pabbhāram
translated: He directs: he makes it tend, incline, and slope towards the arising of insight knowledge.🔽The meaning of “possessed of form” and so on has already been given.

original: karoti. Rūpīti ādīnamattho vuttoyeva. Odanakummāsūpacayoti odanena ceva kummāsena
analyzed: karoti rūpī iti ādīnam atthaḥ odana kummāsu upacayo ti odanena ca iva kummāsena
translated: He is nourished with rice and gruel: he is nourished, fed, with rice and with the various kinds of gruel.

original: ca upacito vaḍḍhito. Aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammoti hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena
analyzed: ca upacitaḥ vaḍḍhitaḥ anicca chādana parimaddana bhedana viddhaṃsana dhammaḥ ti hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena
translated: He is subject to destruction, fall, and dissolution: he is subject to destruction as arising, to fall as ageing, and to dissolution as impermanence.

original: aniccadhammo. Duggandhavighātatthāya tanuvilepanena ucchādanadhammo. Aṅgapaccaṅgābādhavinodanatthāya
analyzed: anicca dhammaḥ duggandha vighāta tthāya tanu vilepanena ucchādana dhammaḥ aṅga paccaṅga ābādha vinodana tthāya
translated: It is subject to being massaged with unguents for the purpose of removing the discomfort of the limbs and minor parts.

original: khuddakasambāhanena parimaddanadhammo. Daharakāle vā ūrūsu sayāpetvā gabbhāvāsena
analyzed: khuddaka sambāhanena parimaddana dhammaḥ dahara kāle vā ūrūsu gabbha āvāsena
translated: Or, in youth, it is subject to being massaged by being made to lie between the breasts for the purpose of developing the limbs and minor parts that have been cramped by the discomfort of the womb.

original: dussaṇṭhitānaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ aṅgānaṃ saṇṭhānasampādanatthaṃ añchanapīḷanādivasena parimaddanadhammo.
analyzed: dussaṇṭhitānam tesam tesam aṅgānam saṇṭhāna sampādana attham añchana pīḷana ādi vasena parimaddana dhammaḥ
translated: It is subject to being massaged by being anointed with oil, rubbed, and so on, for the purpose of developing the limbs and minor parts that have been cramped by the discomfort of the womb.

original: Evaṃ pariharitopi bhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo bhijjati ceva vikirati ca, evaṃ sabhāvoti
analyzed: evam pariharitaḥ api bhedana viddhaṃsana dhammo bhijjati ca iva vikirati ca evam sabhāvaḥ ti
translated: And even when it is thus maintained, it is subject to breaking up and destruction, for it breaks up and is destroyed. This is the meaning.

original: attho. Tattha rūpī cātumahābhūtikotiādīsu chahi padehi samudayo kathito. Aniccapadena🔽saddhiṃ pacchimehi dvīhi atthaṅgamo. Ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddhanti ettha cātumahābhūtike
analyzed: attho tattha rūpī cātumahābhūtika ūti ādīsu chahi padehi samudayaḥ kathitaḥ anicca padena  saddhim pacchimehi dvīhi atthaṅgamaḥ ettha sitam ettha ettha cātumahābhūtike
translated: Herein, the six terms beginning with “material” and “derived from the four great primaries” describe the origin. The term “impermanent”

original: kāye nissitañca paṭibaddhañca.
analyzed: kāye nissitañca paṭibaddhañca
translated: together with the last two describes the disappearance. “Herein is the fair and here the foul” : it is dependent and bound up with this material body derived from the four great primaries.

original: 235. Subhoti sundaro. Jātimāti parisuddhākarasamuṭṭhito. Suparikammakatoti suṭṭhu
analyzed: subhaḥ ti sundaraḥ jātimā ati parisuddha ākara samuṭṭhito su parikamma katoti suṭṭhu
translated: “Fair” : beautiful. “Pure” : arisen from pure white semen. “Well-formed” : well-developed,

original: kataparikammo apanītapāsāṇasakkharo. Acchoti tanucchavi. Vippasannoti suṭṭhu pasanno.
analyzed: kata parikammaḥ apanīta pāsāṇa sakkharo acchaḥ ti tanu chavi vippasannaḥ ti suṭṭhu pasanno
translated: Well purified: well cleansed.🔽Complete in every aspect: complete in every aspect such as washing, piercing, etc.

original: Sabbākārasampannoti dhovanavedhanādīhi sabbehi ākārehi sampanno. Nīlantiādīhi vaṇṇasampattiṃ
analyzed: sabba ākāra sampannaḥ ti dhovana vedhana ādīhi sabbehi ākārehi sampannaḥ nīla anti ādīhi vaṇṇa sampattim
translated: The words “blue” and the rest show the perfection of its color.🔽For when it is wound up, it is obvious.

original: dasseti. Tādisañhi āvutaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti. Evameva khoti ettha evaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ
analyzed: dasseti tādisam hi āvutam pākaṭam hoti evam eva kho ti ettha evam upamā saṃsandanam
translated: Just so, too, in the case of the simile:

original: veditabbaṃ. Maṇi viya hi karajakāyo. Āvutasuttaṃ viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Cakkhumā puriso🔽viya vipassanālābhī bhikkhu, hatthe karitvā paccavekkhato ayaṃ kho maṇīti maṇino
analyzed: veditabbam maṇi viya hi karaja kāyaḥ āvuta suttam viya vipassanā ñāṇam cakkhumā puriso  viya vipassanā lābhī bhikkhu hatthe karitvā paccavekkhataḥ ayam kho maṇī iti maṇinaḥ
translated: The simile should be understood in this way. For the physical body is like the gem, insight knowledge is like the string,🔽the bhikkhu who has attained insight is like the man with eyes,

original: āvibhūtakālo viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ, abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno cātumahābhūtikakāyassa
analyzed: āvi bhūta kālaḥ viya vipassanā ñāṇam abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno cātumahābhūtika kāyassa
translated: the time when the gem becomes obvious to him as he examines it in his hand is like the time when insight knowledge becomes obvious to the bhikkhu sitting cross-legged after he has brought it to bear;🔽the time when the four-fold physical body becomes obvious to the bhikkhu is like the time when the string becomes obvious to the man with eyes;

original: āvibhūtakālo, tatridaṃ suttaṃ āvutanti suttassāvibhūtakālo viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ, abhinīharitvā
analyzed: tatra idam suttaṃ āvutaṃ ti suttassa avibhūta kālaḥ viya vipassanā ñāṇam abhinīharitvā
translated: the time when the string is wound up is like the time when insight knowledge becomes obvious to the bhikkhu sitting cross-legged after he has brought it to bear;

original: nisinnassa bhikkhuno tadārammaṇānaṃ phassapañcamakānaṃ vā sabbacittacetasikānaṃ vā
analyzed: nisinnassa bhikkhuno tad ārammaṇānam phassa pañcamakānam vā sabba citta cetasikānam vā
translated: the time when the five aggregates affected by clinging with contact as fifth become obvious to him or all states of consciousness and its concomitants become obvious to him is like the time when the string is wound up.

original: vipassanāñāṇasseva vā āvibhūtakāloti.
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇassa iva vā āvibhūta kālaḥ ti
translated: or the time of the manifestation of the knowledge of insight.🔽And this knowledge of insight comes next to the knowledge of the path.

original: Idañca vipassanāñāṇaṃ maggañāṇānantaraṃ. Evaṃ santepi yasmā abhiññāvāre āraddhe etassa
analyzed: idam ca vipassanā ñāṇam magga ñāṇa anantaram evam sante pi yasmai abhiññā vāre āraddhe etassa
translated: Even though that is so, since there is no interruption to this knowledge when the section on direct-knowledge is begun,

original: antarāvāro natthi tasmā idheva dassitaṃ. Yasmā ca aniccādivasena akatasammasanassa🔽dibbāya sotadhātuyā bheravaṃ saddaṃ suṇato, pubbenivāsānussatiyā bherave khandhe
analyzed: antarāvāraḥ natthi tasmai idha iva dassitam yasmai ca anicca ādi vasena a kata sammasanassa  dibbāya sotadhātuyā bheravam saddam suṇato pubbenivāsa anussatiyā bherave khandhe
translated: it is therefore shown here. And since fear arises in one who has not already done the contemplation of impermanence, etc.,

original: anussarato, dibbena cakkhunā bheravampi rūpaṃ passato bhayasantāso uppajjati, na
analyzed: anussarataḥ dibbena cakkhunā bheravam pi rūpam passataḥ bhaya santāsaḥ uppajjati na
translated: when he hears a terrible sound with the divine ear element, or when he recollects terrible aggregates with the recollection of past lives, or when he sees a terrible visible object with the divine eye,

original: aniccādivasena katasammasanassa tasmā abhiññaṃ pattassa bhayavinodanahetusampādanatthampi
analyzed: anicca ādi vasena kata sammasanassa tasmai abhiññam pattassa bhaya vinodana hetu sampādana attham pi
translated: but fear does not arise in one who has done the contemplation of impermanence, etc., therefore this knowledge is shown here also in order to provide a cause for the dispelling of fear in one who has attained direct-knowledge.

original: idaṃ idheva dassitaṃ. Api ca yasmā vipassanāsukhaṃ nāmetaṃ maggaphalasukhasampādakaṃ
analyzed: idam idhā iva dassitam api ca yasmai vipassanā sukham nāma etam magga phala sukha sampādakam
translated: Besides, since this is not the bliss of the path and fruition but is a separate fruit of recluseship to be seen here and now,

original: pāṭiyekkaṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ tasmāpi āditova idaṃ idha dassitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pāṭiyekkam sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam tasmā api āditas va idam idha dassitan ti veditabbam
translated: it should be understood that it is shown here at the very beginning.

original: Manomayiddhiñāṇakathā
analyzed: manaḥ maya iddhi ñāṇa kathā
translated: The discussion of the knowledge of the mind-made body

original: 236-237. Manomayanti manena nibbattitaṃ. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅginti sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi
analyzed: manaḥ mayanti manena nibbattitam sabbaṅga paccaṅgin ti sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi
translated: “Mentally created” means created by mind. “Complete in all its parts” means complete in all the major and minor parts.

original: ca samannāgataṃ. Ahīnindriyanti saṇṭhānavasena avikalindriyaṃ. Iddhimatā nimmitarūpañhi
analyzed: ca samannāgatam saṇṭhāna vasena avikalindriyam iddhimatā nimmita rūpam hi
translated: “Mentally created”: created by mind. “Complete in all its parts”: complete in all the major and minor parts. “With no deficiency in its faculties”: with its faculties not deficient in shape. For the material form created by one possessing supernormal power

original: sace iddhimā odāto tampi odātaṃ. Sace aviddhakaṇṇo tampi aviddhakaṇṇanti evaṃ sabbākārehi🔽tena sadisameva hoti. Muñjamhā īsikantiādi upamāttayampi hi sadisabhāvadassanatthameva🔽vuttaṃ. Muñjasadisā eva hi tassa anto īsikā hoti. Kosisadisoyeva asi, vaṭṭāya kosiyā🔽vaṭṭaṃ asimeva pakkhipanti, patthaṭāya patthaṭaṃ. Karaṇḍāti idampi ahikañcukassa
analyzed: sace iddhimā odāto tam pi odātam sace a viddha kaṇṇo tam pi a viddha kaṇṇam ti evam sabba ākārehi  tena sadisam eva hoti muñjamhā īsikanti ādi upamāt tayam pi hi sadisa bhāva dassana ttham eva  vuttam muñja sadisā eva hi tassa antaḥ īsikā hoti kosi sadisaḥ yā iva asi vaṭṭāya kosiyā  vaṭṭam asim eva pakkhipanti patthaṭāya patthaṭam karaṇḍā ti idam pi ahi kañcukassa
translated: is like him in all respects. If the possessor of supernormal power is fair, then that created is also fair. If he is dark, then that created is also dark. If he is one-eyed, then that created is also one-eyed.🔽The similes beginning with “like a reed from the middle of a clump of reeds” are given

original: nāmaṃ, na vilīvakaraṇḍakassa. Ahikañcuko hi ahinā sadisova hoti. Tattha kiñcāpi “puriso
analyzed: nāmam na vilīva karaṇḍakassa ahi kañcukaḥ hi ahinā sadisaḥ uva hoti tattha kiñcā api puriso
translated: to show the similarity. For the reed inside the clump of reeds is just like the reed outside. The sword is just like the scabbard. They put the sword in the scabbard, the round sword in the round scabbard, the straight sword in the straight scabbard. “A snake’s slough” is the name for a snake’s skin. It is not the name for a Vilva fruit. For the snake’s skin is just like the snake. Although it is shown as if it were being pulled out by the hand with the words “a man would pull out a snake from its slough,”

original: ahiṃ karaṇḍā uddhareyyā”ti hatthena uddharamāno viya dassito, atha kho cittenevassa
analyzed: ahim karaṇḍā uddhareyya iti hatthena uddharamānaḥ viya dassitaḥ atha kho
translated: it is only by the mind.

original: uddharaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ayañhi ahi nāma sajātiyaṃ ṭhito, kaṭṭhantaraṃ vā rukkhantaraṃ🔽vā nissāya, tacato sarīraṃ nikkaḍḍhanappayogasaṅkhātena thāmena, sarīraṃ khādayamānaṃ
analyzed: uddharaṇam veditabbam ayam hi ahi nāma sajātiyam ṭhitaḥ kaṭṭhantaram vā rukkhantaram  vā nissāya tacataḥ sarīram nikkaḍḍhana ppayoga saṅkhātena thāmena sarīram khādayamānam
translated: and the meaning of “extraction” should be understood. For this snake, when it is standing on its own kind, resorts to a piece of wood or a tree stump or a termite-mound or a rock or a wall or a tree or a creeper or a piece of ground, and then it casts off its old skin by the effort of contracting and stretching its limbs, as if it were casting off its body, and it does so because it is disgusted with the old skin.

original: viya purāṇatacaṃ jigucchantoti imehi catūhi kāraṇehi sayameva kañcukaṃ pajahati,
analyzed: viya purāṇatacam jigucchantaḥ iti imehi catūhi kāraṇehi sayam eva kañcukam pajahati
translated: So it casts off its slough for these four reasons.

original: na sakkā tato aññena uddharituṃ, tasmā cittena uddharaṇaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttanti
analyzed: na sakkā tatas aññena uddharitum tasmā cittena uddharaṇam sandhāya idam vuttan ti
translated: And since it cannot be extracted by anyone else, the meaning of “extraction” should be understood as referring to the mind’s casting off the old skin.

original: veditabbaṃ. Iti muñjādisadisaṃ imassa bhikkhuno sarīraṃ, īsikādisadisaṃ nimmitarūpanti.🔽Idamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ. Nimmānavidhānaṃ panettha parato ca iddhividhādipañcaabhiññākathā🔽sabbākārena visuddhimagge vitthāritāti tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Upamāmattameva hi idha adhikaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam iti muñja ādi sadisam imassa bhikkhuno sarīram īsikā ādi sadisam nimmita rūpan ti  idam ettha opamma saṃsandanam nimmāna vidhānam pana ittha paratas ca iddhividha ādi pañca abhiññā kathā  sabba ākārena visuddhi magge vitthāritā ti tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbā upamā mattam eva hi idha adhikam
translated: So the bhikkhu’s body is like the reed, and the created materiality is like the snake.🔽This is the correlation of the similes here.🔽But the explanation of the kinds of supernormal power, etc., and the five kinds of direct-knowledge, which is relevant here, has been given in the Path of Purification in the Description of the Kinds of Direct- Knowledge, and so we shall deal with it there too, since it is there that the context lies. Only the similes are additional here.

original: Iddhividhañāṇādikathā
analyzed: iddhi vidha ñāṇa ādi kathā
translated: The explanation of the kinds of supernormal power, etc.,

original: 238-239. Tattha chekakumbhakārādayo viya iddhividhañāṇalābhī bhikkhu daṭṭhabbo. Suparikammakatamattikādayo
analyzed: tattha cheka kumbhakāra ādayaḥ viya iddhividha ñāṇa lābhī bhikkhu daṭṭhabbo su parikamma kata mattika ādayo
translated: Herein, the bhikkhu who has acquired the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power should be regarded as the potter,

original: viya iddhividhañāṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Icchiticchitabhājanavikatiādikaraṇaṃ viya tassa
analyzed: viya iddhividha ñāṇam daṭṭhabbam icchiti chita bhājana vikati ādi karaṇam viya tassa
translated: the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power as the well-prepared clay,

original: bhikkhuno vikubbanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhuno vikubbanam daṭṭhabbam
translated: and the transformation of the bhikkhu as the making of the various kinds of pots according to the potter’s wish.

original: 240-241. Dibbasotadhātuupamāyaṃ yasmā kantāraddhānamaggo sāsaṅko hoti sappaṭibhayo.
analyzed: dibba sota dhātu upamā ayam yasmai sa āsaṅkaḥ hoti sa paṭibhayaḥ
translated: In the Simile of the Divine Ear Element, the desert road is dangerous and frightening,

original: Tattha ussaṅkitaparisaṅkitena ‘ayaṃ bherisaddo’, ‘ayaṃ mudiṅgasaddo’ti na sakkā vavatthapetuṃ,
analyzed: tattha ussaṅkita parisaṅkitena ayam bheri saddo ayam mudiṅga saddo ti na sakkā vavatthapetum
translated: and there one cannot distinguish sounds by saying, “This is the sound of a drum,” “This is the sound of a tabor,” because of the fear and terror.

original: tasmā kantāraggahaṇaṃ akatvā khemamaggaṃ dassento addhānamaggappaṭipannoti āha. Appaṭibhayañhi
analyzed: tasmā kantāra ggahaṇam a katvā khema maggam dassentaḥ addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ ti āha appaṭibhayam hi
translated: So, instead of mentioning the desert, he said “travelling by a road” in order to show a safe road. For one travelling by a safe road,

original: khemamaggaṃ sīse sāṭakaṃ katvā saṇikaṃ paṭipanno vuttappakāre sadde sukhaṃ vavatthapeti.
analyzed: khema maggam sīse sāṭakam katvā saṇikam paṭipannaḥ vutta ppakāre sadde sukham vavatthapeti
translated: having put a cloth on his head, can easily distinguish the sounds mentioned if he travels slowly.

original: Tassa savanena tesaṃ tesaṃ saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo viya yogino dūrasantikabhedānaṃ
analyzed: tassa savanena tesam tesam saddānam āvibhūta kālaḥ viya yoginaḥ dūra santika bhedānam
translated: And just as the time when the various sounds become evident to him through his hearing,

original: dibbānañceva mānussakānañca saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo veditabbo.
analyzed: dibbānam ca iva mānussakānam ca saddānam āvibhūta kālaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: and the time when divine and human sounds become manifest.

original: 242-243. Cetopariyañāṇūpamāyaṃ daharoti taruṇo. Yuvāti yobbannena samannāgato. Maṇḍanakajātikoti
analyzed: daharoti taruṇaḥ yuvā ati yobbannena samannāgataḥ maṇḍanaka jātiko ti
translated: In the simile of the knowledge of others’ minds, young means inexperienced. Youthful means endowed with youth. One who is fond of adornment means

original: yuvāpi samāno na ālasiyo na kiliṭṭhavatthasarīro, atha kho maṇḍanapakatiko, divasassa🔽dve tayo vāre nhāyitvā suddhavatthaparidahanaalaṅkārakaraṇasīloti attho. Sakaṇikanti🔽kāḷatilakavaṅgamukhadūsipīḷakādīnaṃ aññatarena sadosaṃ. Tattha yathā tassa mukhanimittaṃ🔽paccavekkhato mukhe doso pākaṭo hoti, evaṃ cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā
analyzed: yuvā api samānaḥ na ālasiyaḥ na kiliṭṭha vattha sarīraḥ atha kho maṇḍana pakatikaḥ divasassa  dve tayaḥ vāre nhāyitvā suddhavattha paridahana alaṅkāra karaṇa sīlaḥ ti attho sa kaṇikanti  kāḷa tilaka vaṅga mukha dūsi pīḷaka ādīnam aññatarena sa dosam tattha yathā tassa mukha nimittam  paccavekkhataḥ mukhe doso pākaṭaḥ hoti evam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharitvā
translated: that even though he is young, he is not lazy, nor is his body and clothes dirty, but rather he is by nature fond of adornment, and he has the habit of bathing

original: nisinnassa bhikkhuno paresaṃ soḷasavidhaṃ cittaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nisinnassa bhikkhuno paresam soḷasavidham cittam pākaṭam hoti iti veditabbam
translated: twice or thrice a day and adorning himself with clean clothes and ornaments. One with a pimple means one who has a blemish of some kind, such as a black mole, a freckle, a birthmark, or a pimple. Herein, just as when he looks at the reflection of his face he sees the blemish on his face clearly, so too, when a bhikkhu sits down and directs his mind to the knowledge of others’ minds, he sees the other’s sixteen kinds of consciousness clearly.

original: 244-245. Pubbenivāsañāṇūpamāyaṃ taṃ divasaṃ katakiriyā pākaṭā hotīti taṃ divasaṃ
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇu upamā ayam tam divasam kata kiriyā pākaṭā hoti iti tam divasam
translated: In the simile of the knowledge of past lives, the action done on that day becomes manifest means that the action done on that day becomes evident.

original: gatagāmattayameva gahitaṃ. Tattha gāmattayagatapuriso viya pubbenivāsañāṇalābhī daṭṭhabbo,🔽tayo gāmā viya tayo bhavā daṭṭhabbā, tassa purisassa tīsu gāmesu taṃ divasaṃ katakiriyāya
analyzed: gata gāmattayam eva gahitam tattha gāmattaya gata purisaḥ viya pubbenivāsa ñāṇa lābhī daṭṭhabbo  tayaḥ gāmāḥ viya tayaḥ bhavāḥ daṭṭhabbā tassa purisassa tīsu gāmesu tam divasam kata kiriyāya
translated: and only the three villages are taken. The one who has acquired knowledge of past lives should be regarded as the man who went to the three villages.🔽The three kinds of becoming should be regarded as the three villages.

original: āvibhāvo viya pubbenivāsāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu🔽katakiriyāya pākaṭabhāvo daṭṭhabbo.🔽246-247. Dibbacakkhūpamāyaṃ vīthiṃ sañcaranteti aparāparaṃ sañcarante. Vīthiṃ carantetipi🔽pāṭho. Ayamevattho. Tattha nagaramajjhe siṅghāṭakamhi pāsādo viya imassa bhikkhuno
analyzed: āvi bhāvaḥ viya pubbenivāsāya cittam abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu  kata kiriyāya pākaṭa bhāvaḥ daṭṭhabbo  dibba cakkhu upamāyam vīthim sañcarantā iti apara aparam sañcarante vīthim carantā iti pi  pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ tattha nagara majjhe siṅghāṭakamhi pāsādaḥ viya imassa bhikkhuno
translated: The man’s making his report on the business done that day in the three villages should be regarded as the bhikkhu’s making the past become as evident as something in front by directing his mind to it and then sitting and surveying the three kinds of becoming.🔽-. In the simile of the divine eye, “moving along the path” is “moving along in succession.” The reading “moving along the path” is also found. The meaning is the same. Herein, the bhikkhu’s physical body should be regarded as the palace in the middle of the city in the crossroads.

original: karajakāyo daṭṭhabbo, pāsāde ṭhito cakkhumā puriso viya ayameva dibbacakkhuṃ patvā
analyzed: karaja kāyaḥ daṭṭhabbo pāsāde ṭhito cakkhumā puriso viya ayam eva dibba cakkhum patvā
translated: The bhikkhu who has attained the divine eye and is standing there should be regarded as the man standing in the palace with the divine eye.

original: ṭhito bhikkhu, gehaṃ pavisantā viya paṭisandhivasena mātukucchiyaṃ pavisantā, gehā
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ bhikkhu geham pavisantā viya paṭisandhi vasena mātukucchiyam pavisantā gehā
translated: Those entering a house by rebirth-linking should be regarded as those entering the mother’s womb.

original: nikkhamantā viya mātukucchito nikkhamantā, rathikāya vīthiṃ sañcarantā viya aparāparaṃ
analyzed: nikkhamantā viya mātukucchitaḥ nikkhamantā rathikāya vīthim sañcarantā viya apara aparam
translated: As though emerging from a house, they emerge from the mother’s womb. As though going along a street in a chariot, they go along the earth in vehicles, etc.,

original: sañcaraṇakasattā, purato abbhokāsaṭṭhāne majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnā viya tīsu bhavesu🔽tattha tattha nibbattasattā, pāsādatale ṭhitapurisassa tesaṃ manussānaṃ āvibhūtakālo
analyzed: sañcaraṇaka sattā puratas abbhokāsa ṭṭhāne majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnā viya tīsu bhavesu  tattha tattha nibbatta sattā pāsāda tale ṭhita purisassa tesam manussānam āvibhūta kālaḥ
translated: as creatures that move about here and there. As though sitting in the middle of a cross-roads in an open space in front, they sit in the three kinds of becoming as creatures reborn there.

original: viya dibbacakkhuñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu nibbattasattānaṃ
analyzed: viya dibba cakkhu ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu nibbatta sattānam
translated: As though the time of the appearance of those people is seen by a man standing on the top of a palace, so the time of the appearance of creatures reborn in the three kinds of becoming should be seen by a bhikkhu who has directed his mind to the knowledge of the divine eye and is sitting .

original: āvibhūtakālo daṭṭhabbo. Idañca desanāsukhatthameva vuttaṃ. Āruppe pana dibbacakkhussa gocaro natthīti.
analyzed: āvi bhūta kālaḥ daṭṭhabbo idam ca desanā sukha attham eva vuttam āruppe pana dibba cakkhussa gocaro natthi iti
translated: But this is said merely for the sake of a simile. There is no scope for the divine eye in the immaterial world.

original: Āsavakkhayañāṇakathā
analyzed: āsava khaya ñāṇa kathā
translated: The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers

original: 248. So evaṃ samāhite citteti idha vipassanāpādakaṃ catutthajjhānacittaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citta iti idha vipassanā pādakam catuttha jhāna cittam veditabbam
translated: So when his concentrated mind: here the mind of the fourth jhāna, which is the forerunner of insight, should be understood.

original: Āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāyāti āsavānaṃ khayañāṇanibbattanatthāya. Ettha ca āsavānaṃ khayo
analyzed: āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya ati āsavānam khaya ñāṇa nibbattana atthāya ettha ca āsavānam khayaḥ
translated: For the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers: for the purpose of producing the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers. And here the destruction of the cankers is the cankers’ being abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: nāma maggopi phalampi nibbānampi bhaṅgopi vuccati. “Khaye ñāṇaṃ, anuppāde ñāṇa”nti
analyzed: nāma maggaḥ api phalam pi nibbānam pi bhaṅgo api vuccati khaye ñāṇam anuppāde ñāṇam ti
translated: and the path, the fruition, and Nibbāna, and also cessation, are called “destruction.”🔽For in the passage, “Knowledge of destruction, knowledge of non-arising” ,

original: ettha hi maggo āsavānaṃ khayoti vutto. “Āsavānaṃ khayā samaṇo hotī”ti ettha phalaṃ.
analyzed: ettha hi maggaḥ āsavānam khayo ti vuttaḥ āsavānam khayā samaṇo hoti iti ettha phalam
translated: the path is called the destruction of the cankers. In the passage, “By the destruction of the cankers one is a recluse” , it is the fruition.

original: “Paravajjānupassissa, niccaṃ ujjhānasaññino;
analyzed: paravajja anupassissa niccam ujjhāna saññinaḥ
translated: “One who is ever intent on seeing faults in others🔽and who is always on the lookout for mistakes,

original: Āsavā tassa vaḍḍhanti, ārā so āsavakkhayā”ti. ;🔽Ettha nibbānaṃ. “Āsavānaṃ khayo vayo bhedo aniccatā antaradhāna”nti ettha bhaṅgo. Idha pana nibbānaṃ adhippetaṃ. Arahattamaggopi vaṭṭatiyeva.
analyzed: āsavā tassa vaḍḍhanti ārā saḥ āsava kkhayāti  ettha nibbānam āsavānam khayaḥ vayaḥ bhedaḥ anicca tā antaradhānan ti ettha bhaṅgaḥ idha pana nibbānam adhippetam arahatta maggaḥ api vaṭṭatiyā iva
translated: his cankers increase; he is far from their destruction” .

original: Cittaṃ abhinīharatīti vipassanā cittaṃ tanninnaṃ tappoṇaṃ tappabbhāraṃ karoti. So🔽idaṃ dukkhantiādīsu “ettakaṃ dukkhaṃ, na ito bhiyyo”ti sabbampi dukkhasaccaṃ sarasalakkhaṇapaṭivedhena🔽yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti attho. Tassa ca dukkhassa nibbattikaṃ taṇhaṃ “ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo”ti.
analyzed: cittam abhinīharati iti vipassanā cittam tat ninnam tad poṇam tad pabbhāram karoti so 🔽idam dukkham ti ādīsu ettakam dukkham na itas bhiyyas ti sabbam pi dukkha saccam sa rasa lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena 🔽yathābhūtam pajānāti iti attho tassa ca dukkhassa nibbattikam taṇham ayam dukkha samudayaḥ ti
translated: Here it is Nibbāna. In the passage, “The destruction of the cankers, their fading away, their cessation, their non-appearance again” , it is cessation. But here Nibbāna is intended. The Arahant path is also appropriate.

original: Tadubhayampi yaṃ ṭhānaṃ patvā nirujjhati, taṃ tesaṃ appavattiṃ nibbānaṃ “ayaṃ dukkhanirodho”ti;
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi yam ṭhānam patvā nirujjhati tam tesam appavattim nibbānam ayam dukkha nirodho ti
translated: And he understands as it really is: “This is the cessation of suffering” — the non-occurrence of both of these things when they have reached their limit.

original: tassa ca sampāpakaṃ ariyamaggaṃ “ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā”ti sarasalakkhaṇapaṭivedhena
analyzed: tassa ca sampāpakam ariya maggam ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati sa rasa lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena
translated: And he understands as it really is: “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering” — the noble path that causes that cessation.

original: yathābhūtaṃ pajānātīti attho.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he understands as it really is by penetrating the specific characteristics of the three truths.

original: Evaṃ sarūpato saccāni dassetvā puna kilesavasena pariyāyato dassento “ime āsavā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: evam sarūpataḥ saccāni dassetvā puna kilesa vasena pariyāyataḥ dassentaḥ ime āsavā ti ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the truths in their individual aspects, he now shows them in their general aspect by way of defilement, saying “These taints” .

original: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passatoti tassa bhikkhuno evaṃ jānantassa evaṃ passantassa,
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passato ti tassa bhikkhuno evam jānantassa evam passantassa
translated: To him who knows and sees thus: to the bhikkhu who knows thus and sees thus.🔽He shows the path that has reached the summit together with insight.

original: saha vipassanāya koṭippattaṃ maggaṃ kathesi. Kāmāsavāti kāmāsavato. Vimuccatīti iminā
analyzed: saha vipassanāya koṭippattam maggam kathesi kāma āsavā ati kāma āsavataḥ vimuccati iti iminā
translated: He is liberated from the taint of sensual desire: by this he shows the moment of the path.🔽He is liberated: by this he shows the moment of fruition.

original: maggakkhaṇaṃ dasseti. Vimuttasminti iminā phalakkhaṇaṃ. Vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hotīti
analyzed: magga kkhaṇam dasseti vimuttasmin ti iminā phala kkhaṇam vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti iti
translated: The knowledge that “My deliverance is unshakeable” occurs to him: by this he shows the knowledge of reviewing.

original: iminā paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ. Khīṇā jātītiādīhi tassa bhūmiṃ. Tena hi ñāṇena khīṇāsavo🔽paccavekkhanto khīṇā jātītiādīni pajānāti.
analyzed: iminā paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam khīṇā jātī iti ādīhi tassa bhūmim tena hi ñāṇena khīṇa āsavaḥ 🔽paccavekkhantaḥ khīṇā jātī iti ādīni pajānāti
translated: With the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes an attainer of Nibbana in this very life: by this he shows his plane.🔽For one whose taints are destroyed, reviewing, he understands thus: “Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.”

original: Katamā panassa jāti khīṇā? Kathañca naṃ pajānātīti? Na tāvassa atītā jāti khīṇā,
analyzed: katamā pana assa jāti khīṇā katham ca nam pajānāti iti na tāva assa atītā jāti khīṇā
translated: What is his birth that is destroyed? And how does he understand it? His past birth is not destroyed,

original: pubbeva khīṇattā. Na anāgatā, anāgate vāyāmābhāvato. Na paccuppannā, vijjamānattā.
analyzed: pubbā iva khīṇa ttā na anāgatāḥ anāgate vāyāma abhāvataḥ na paccuppannāḥ vijjamāna ttā
translated: because it was destroyed before. His future birth is not destroyed, because he has no more future becoming. His present birth is not destroyed, because it has already arisen.

original: Yā pana maggassa abhāvitattā uppajjeyya ekacatupañcavokārabhavesu ekacatupañcakkhandhappabhedā
analyzed: yā pana maggassa abhāvita ttā uppajjeyya eka catu pañca vokāra bhavesu eka catu pañca khandha ppabhedā
translated: But the kind of birth that would arise through the un-developedness of the path in the one-constituent, four-constituent, or five-constituent becoming, divided into the one, four, or five aggregates,

original: jāti, sā maggassa bhāvitattā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammataṃ āpajjanena khīṇā. Taṃ so maggabhāvanāya
analyzed: sā maggassa bhāvita ttā āyatim an uppāda dhamma tam āpajjanena khīṇā tam saḥ magga bhāvanāya
translated: is destroyed in him through the non-arising of that in the future by the development of the path. He understands that by reviewing the defilements abandoned through the development of the path.🔽“ Lived the life” : lived the life of the path. “ The holy life” : the holy life of the path.

original: pahīnakilese paccavekkhitvā “kilesābhāve vijjamānampi kammaṃ āyatiṃ appaṭisandhikaṃva
analyzed: pahīna kilese paccavekkhitvā kilesa abhāve vijjamānam api kammam āyatim appaṭisandhikam va
translated: For the seven trainees live the holy life together with the good worldling, but the one with cankers destroyed has lived the life,

original: hotī”ti jānanto pajānāti.🔽Vusitanti vutthaṃ parivutthaṃ. Brahmacariyanti maggabrahmacariyaṃ. Puthujjanakalyāṇakena🔽hi saddhiṃ satta sekkhā brahmacariyavāsaṃ vasanti nāma, khīṇāsavo vutthavāso, tasmā
analyzed: hoti iti jānantaḥ pajānāti 🔽vusitanti vuttham parivuttham brahmacariyanti magga brahmacariyam puthujjana kalyāṇakena 🔽hi saddhim satta sekkhāḥ brahmacariya vāsam vasanti nāma khīṇa asavaḥ tasmā
translated: therefore he is called “one who has lived the life.”

original: so attano brahmacariyavāsaṃ paccavekkhanto vusitaṃ brahmacariyanti pajānāti. Kataṃ
analyzed: so attanaḥ brahmacariya vāsam paccavekkhantaḥ vusitam brahmacariyanti pajānāti katam
translated: He understands thus: “The spiritual life has been lived” : he understands thus: “The spiritual life has been lived out” .

original: karaṇīyanti catūsu saccesu catūhi maggehi pariññāpahānasacchikiriyābhāvanāvasena
analyzed: karaṇīyanti catūsu saccesu catūhi maggehi pariññā apahāna sacchikiriyā bhāvanā vasena
translated: He understands thus: “What had to be done has been done” : the task of the four paths and four fruitions has been completed by him through full understanding, abandoning, full comprehension, and developing,

original: soḷasavidhaṃ kiccaṃ niṭṭhāpitaṃ. Tena tena maggena pahātabbakilesā pahīnā, dukkhamūlaṃ
analyzed: soḷasavidham kiccam niṭṭhāpitam tena tena maggena pahātabba kilesāḥ pahīnāḥ dukkha mūlam
translated: respectively. The defilements to be abandoned by each path have been abandoned. The root of suffering has been uprooted, is the meaning.

original: samucchinnanti attho. Puthujjanakalyāṇakādayo hi taṃ kiccaṃ karonti, khīṇāsavo katakaraṇīyo.
analyzed: puthujjana kalyāṇaka ādayaḥ hi tam kiccam karonti khīṇa āsavaḥ kata karaṇīyaḥ
translated: For the good persons of the world and others do this task, but the one with cankers destroyed has done what had to be done.

original: Tasmā so attano karaṇīyaṃ paccavekkhanto kataṃ karaṇīyanti pajānāti. Nāparaṃ itthattāyāti🔽idāni puna itthabhāvāya evaṃ soḷasakiccabhāvāya kilesakkhayabhāvāya vā kattabbaṃ🔽maggabhāvanākiccaṃ me natthīti pajānāti. Atha vā itthattāyāti itthabhāvato imasmā
analyzed: tasmā saḥ attanaḥ karaṇīyam paccavekkhanto katam karaṇīyanti pajānāti na aparam itthattāya ati  idāni puna ittha bhāvāya evam soḷasa kicca bhāvāya kilesa kkhaya bhāvāya vā kattabbam  magga bhāvanā kiccam me natthi iti pajānāti atha vā itthattāya ati ittha bhāvataḥ imasmā
translated: Therefore, reflecting on what he has done, he understands thus: “What had to be done has been done.”🔽He understands thus: “There is no more for this state of being” : he understands thus: “There is no more task of developing the path that has to be done by me for the sake of the destruction of defilements, for the sake of the state of being consisting of the sixteen tasks, or for the sake of the state of being consisting of the destruction of defilements.”🔽Or alternatively, “There is no more for this state of being” : there is no more for this state of being, for this kind of state of being, for this kind of continuity of aggregates.

original: evaṃ pakārā. Idāni vattamānakhandhasantānā aparaṃ khandhasantānaṃ mayhaṃ natthi.
analyzed: evam pakārā idāni vattamāna khandha santānāḥ aparam khandha santānam mayham na atthi
translated: There is no more continuity of aggregates for me in the future.

original: Ime pana pañcakkhandhā pariññātā tiṭṭhanti chinnamūlakā rukkhā viya, te carimakacittanirodhena
analyzed: ime pana pañca kkhandhā pariññātā tiṭṭhanti chinna mūlakāḥ rukkhāḥ viya te carimaka citta nirodhena
translated: But these five aggregates are known, they stand as though their roots were cut,🔽and with the cessation of the last consciousness,

original: anupādāno viya jātavedo nibbāyissanti apaṇṇattikabhāvañca gamissantīti pajānāti.🔽249. Pabbatasaṅkhepeti pabbatamatthake. Anāviloti nikkaddamo. Sippiyo ca sambukā🔽ca sippisambukaṃ. Sakkharā ca kathalāni ca sakkharakathalaṃ. Macchānaṃ gumbā ghaṭāti
analyzed: anupādānaḥ viya jātavedaḥ nibbāyissanti apaṇṇattika bhāvañca gamissanti iti pajānāti  pabbata saṅkhepeti pabbata matthake anāvilaḥ ca sambukā  ca sippisambukam sakkharā ca kathalāni ca sakkhara kathalam macchānam gumbā ghaṭāti
translated: But he understands that these five aggregates are fully understood, like trees with their roots cut off, and that with the cessation of the last consciousness they will be extinguished like a fire without a new supply of sticks, and that they will have reached the unconditioned.

original: macchagumbaṃ. Tiṭṭhantampi carantampīti ettha sakkharakathalaṃ tiṭṭhatiyeva, itarāni🔽carantipi tiṭṭhantipi. Yathā pana antarantarā ṭhitāsupi nisinnāsupi vijjamānāsupi🔽“etā gāvo carantī”ti carantiyo upādāya itarāpi carantīti vuccanti. Evaṃ tiṭṭhantameva
analyzed: maccha gumbam tiṭṭhantam pi carantam pi iti ettha sakkharakathalam itarāni  tiṭṭhantipi yathā pana antar antarā ṭhitā supi nisinnā supi vijjamānā  etāḥ gāvaḥ caranti iti carantiyaḥ upādāya itarā api carantī iti vuccanti evam tiṭṭhantam eva
translated: On the peak of the mountain: on the top of the mountain. Unclouded: unobscured. And the Sippiya and the Sambuka: the Sippiya and the Sambuka together make the Sippisambuka. And the gravel and the pebbles: the gravel and the pebbles together make the Sakkharakathala. And the fish-traps: the fish-traps are called the Macchogumba. Standing and walking: here the Sakkharakathala is only standing, the other two🔽are both standing and walking. But just as when cows are being driven along, those that are standing and sitting and lying down are also called “cows,” so too, taking the Sakkharakathala as standing, the other two are called “standing”

original: sakkharakathalaṃ upādāya itarampi dvayaṃ tiṭṭhantanti vuttaṃ. Itarañca dvayaṃ carantaṃ
analyzed: sakkharakathalam upādāya itaram pi dvayam tiṭṭhantam ti vuttam itaram ca dvayam carantam
translated: by implication. And the other two, which are walking, are called “walking” by implication.

original: upādāya sakkharakathalampi carantanti vuttaṃ. Tattha cakkhumato purisassa tīre ṭhatvā🔽passato sippikasambukādīnaṃ vibhūtakālo viya āsavānaṃ khayāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā
analyzed: upādāya sakkhara kathalam pi carantanti vuttam tattha cakkhumato purisassa tīre ṭhatvā  passataḥ sippika sambuka ādīnam vibhūta kālaḥ viya āsavānam khayāya cittam abhinīharitvā
translated: and so on down to a lump of earth and a clod.

original: nisinnassa bhikkhuno catunnaṃ saccānaṃ vibhūtakālo daṭṭhabboti.
analyzed: nisinnassa bhikkhuno catunnam saccānam vibhūta kālo daṭṭhabbaḥ ti
translated: The time when the bhikkhu sits with his mind resolved upon the destruction of cankers should be regarded as like the time when the man with good sight stands on the bank and sees the fish, turtles, and crocodiles, or has them pointed out to him.

original: Ettāvatā vipassanāñāṇaṃ, manomayañāṇaṃ, iddhividhañāṇaṃ, dibbasotañāṇaṃ, cetopariyañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: ettāvatā vipassanā ñāṇam manaḥ maya ñāṇam iddhividha ñāṇam dibba sota ñāṇam cetas upariya ñāṇam
translated: So far the following ten kinds of knowledge have been demonstrated: insight knowledge, knowledge of the mind-made body, knowledge of the kinds of psychic power, knowledge of the divine ear element, knowledge of penetration of hearts,

original: pubbenivāsañāṇaṃ, dibbacakkhuvasena nipphannaṃ anāgataṃsañāṇayathākammūpagañāṇadvayaṃ,🔽dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ, āsavakkhayañāṇanti dasa ñāṇāni niddiṭṭhāni honti. Tesaṃ ārammaṇavibhāgo
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇam dibba cakkhu vasena nipphannam anāgataṃsa ñāṇa yathā kammūpaga ñāṇa dvayam  dibba cakkhu ñāṇam āsava kkhaya ñāṇan ti dasa ñāṇāni niddiṭṭhāni honti tesam ārammaṇa vibhāgaḥ
translated: knowledge of recollecting past lives, the two kinds of knowledge of the future, which are classed as knowledge of the divine eye,🔽knowledge of the divine eye, and knowledge of the destruction of cankers. The classification of their objects should be understood as follows:

original: sattavidhārammaṇaṃ. Manomayañāṇaṃ nimmitabbarūpāyatanamattameva ārammaṇaṃ karotīti
analyzed: sattavidha ārammaṇam manaḥ maya ñāṇam nimmitabba rūpa āyatana mattam eva ārammaṇam karoti iti
translated: Knowledge of the mind-made body has only the visible-data base of the object that can be created by the mind.

original: parittapaccuppannabahiddhārammaṇaṃ. Āsavakkhayañāṇaṃ appamāṇabahiddhānavattabbārammaṇaṃ.🔽Avasesānaṃ ārammaṇabhedo visuddhimagge vutto. Uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vāti yena
analyzed: paritta paccuppanna bahiddha ārammaṇam āsava kkhaya ñāṇam appamāṇa bahiddhā anavattabba ārammaṇam  avasesānam ārammaṇa bhedaḥ visuddhi magge vuttaḥ uttaritaram vā paṇītataram vā ati yena
translated: and the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers has an immeasurable external object that is not to be fathomed.🔽The classification of the remaining fruits has been given in the Visuddhimagga.🔽Or, “higher” and “more sublime” can be taken as a mere alternative way of saying that there is no other fruit of recluseship superior to the arahatta fruit.

original: kenaci pariyāyena ito seṭṭhataraṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ nāma natthīti bhagavā arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi.

analyzed: ciram ime pañhe puthū samaṇa brāhmaṇe pucchanto thuse koṭṭento viya kiñci  sāram na alattham aho vata bhagavataḥ guṇa sampadā yaḥ me dīpa sahassam jālentaḥ viya

analyzed: dissati abhikkantā bhante ratti nikkhantaḥ paṭhhamaḥ yāmaḥ cira nisinnaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti ādīsu  hi khaye dissati ayam me puggalo khamati imesam catunnam puggalānam abhikkantataraḥ

translated: “Who is it that worships my feet, shining with psychic power and glory,

analyzed: ettha ekena abhikkanta saddena desanam thometi ekena attanaḥ pasādam ayan ha ittha adhippāyaḥ  abhikkantam bhante yat idam bhagavataḥ dhamma desanā abhikkantam yat idam bhagavataḥ

analyzed: dhamma desanam āgamma mama pasādaḥ iti vā vacanam dve dve atthe sandhāya
translated: “Good, venerable sir, is the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma, good is the venerable one’s teaching of the Dhamma, good is the venerable one’s elucidation of the Dhamma. original: thometi. Bhagavato vacanaṃ abhikkantaṃ dosanāsanato, abhikkantaṃ guṇādhigamanato.

analyzed: tathā saddhā jananataḥ paññā jananataḥ sa atthataḥ sa byañjanataḥ uttāna padataḥ gambhīra tthataḥ

translated: And after that he extols the teaching by means of the four similes. Herein, overturned is what is lying face down,🔽or what has its mouth turned downwards. He would put it right: he would make it face upwards. Covered: hidden by grass, leaves, etc.,

original: Vivareyyāti ugghāṭeyya. Mūḷhassa vāti disāmūḷhassa. Maggaṃ ācikkheyyāti hatthe gahetvā
analyzed: vivareyya ati ugghāṭeyya mūḷhassa vā ati disā mūḷhassa maggam ācikkheyya ati hatthe gahetvā

translated: Just as someone might uncover what is covered, so the Blessed One uncovered the True Idea after the Blessed One Kassapa’s Dispensation had disappeared and wrong view had covered the True Idea.🔽Just as someone might show the path to one who is lost, so the Blessed One revealed to me the path to heaven and to liberation after I had gone by a wrong path and a bad path.

original: apassato tappaṭicchādakamohandhakāraviddhaṃsakadesanāpajjotadhārakena mayhaṃ bhagavatā

original: Diṭṭhisīlasaṃghātena saṃhatoti saṅgho, so atthato aṭṭha ariyapuggalasamūho. Vuttañhetaṃ tasmiññeva vimāne –
analyzed: diṭṭhi sīla saṃghātena saṃhataḥ ti saṅgho so atthataḥ aṭṭha ariya puggala samūho vuttam ha etam tasmin ñeva vimāne
translated: The state of the Dhamma, the state of the Vinaya, the state of the Teacher’s Dispensation—🔽The state of the Dhamma, the state of the Vinaya, the state

original: “Yattha ca dinnamahapphalamāhu, catūsu sucīsu purīsayugesu;
analyzed: ca dinna mahapphalam āhu catūsu sucīsu purīsa yugesu
translated: “Where they say the gift is very fruitful, in the four pure pairs of men,

original: Aṭṭha ca puggaladhammadasā te, saṅghamimaṃ saraṇatthamupehī”ti. ;
analyzed: aṭṭha ca puggala dhamma dasā te saṅgham imam saraṇa attham upehi iti
translated: And the eight persons who are disciples of the Buddha, to that Saṅgha I go for refuge for life.”

original: Bhikkhūnaṃ saṅgho bhikkhusaṅgho. Ettāvatā rājā tīṇi saraṇagamanāni paṭivedesi.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam saṅghaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ettāvatā rājā tīṇi saraṇa gamanāni paṭivedesi
translated: The Saṅgha of bhikkhus is the bhikkhu Saṅgha. So far the king had declared the three kinds of going for refuge.

original: Saraṇagamanakathā
analyzed: saraṇa gamana kathā
translated: The Discussion of Going for Refuge

original: Idāni tesu saraṇagamanesu kosallatthaṃ saraṇaṃ, saraṇagamanaṃ, yo ca saraṇaṃ gacchati,
analyzed: idāni tesu saraṇa gamanesu kosallattham saraṇam saraṇa gamanam yaḥ ca saraṇam gacchati
translated: Now, in order to be skilled in these kinds of going for refuge, the following should be understood: what is a refuge, what is going for refuge, who goes for refuge,

original: saraṇagamanappabhedo, saraṇagamanaphalaṃ, saṅkileso, bhedoti, ayaṃ vidhi veditabbo.🔽Seyyathidaṃ – saraṇatthato tāva hiṃsatīti saraṇaṃ. Saraṇagatānaṃ teneva saraṇagamanena🔽bhayaṃ santāsaṃ dukkhaṃ duggatiparikilesaṃ hanati vināsetīti attho, ratanattayassevetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: saraṇa gamana pabhedaḥ saraṇa gamana phalam saṅkilesaḥ bhedaḥ ti ayam vidhi veditabbo  sā iyyathidam hiṃsati iti saraṇam saraṇa gatānam tena iva saraṇa gamanena  bhayam santāsam dukkham duggati parikilesam hanati vināseti iti atthaḥ adhivacanam
translated: the classification of going for refuge, the benefits of going for refuge, defilement and purification, and the breach of the training precepts.🔽What is a refuge? It is a refuge in the sense of destroying fear . It destroys and removes the fear, terror, pain, and defilement of unhappy destiny that beings have by means of the going for refuge itself. This is a term for the Triple Gem.

original: Atha vā hite pavattanena ahitā ca nivattanena sattānaṃ bhayaṃ hiṃsati buddho. Bhavakantārā
analyzed: atha vā hite pavattanena ahitā ca nivattanena sattānam bhayam hiṃsati buddhaḥ bhava kantārā
translated: Or alternatively, the Buddha destroys the fear of beings by engaging them in what is beneficial and by turning them away from what is unbeneficial. The Dhamma destroys the fear of the wilderness of becoming. The Saṅgha destroys the fear of loneliness.

original: uttāraṇena assāsadānena ca dhammo; appakānampi kārānaṃ vipulaphalapaṭilābhakaraṇena🔽saṅgho. Tasmā imināpi pariyāyena ratanattayaṃ saraṇaṃ. Tappasādataggarutāhi vihatakileso
analyzed: uttāraṇena assāsa dānena ca dhammaḥ appakānam pi kārānam vipula phala paṭilābha karaṇena  saṅghaḥ tasmai iminā api pariyāyena saraṇam vihata kilesaḥ
translated: and the Community by making it possible for even a little giving to have a vast fruit.🔽So the Triple Gem is a refuge in this way too.🔽The going for refuge is the arising of consciousness accompanied by faith, which occurs in the aspect of devotion to the Triple Gem and in the mode of cleaving to it,

original: tapparāyaṇatākārappavatto cittuppādo saraṇagamanaṃ. Taṃ samaṅgīsatto saraṇaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: tad parāyaṇa tā ākāra ppavatto citta uppādaḥ saraṇa gamanam tam samaṅgī satto saraṇam gacchati
translated: because the defilements are dispelled by the greatness of the faith in the Triple Gem.

original: Vuttappakārena cittuppādena etāni me tīṇi ratanāni saraṇaṃ, etāni parāyaṇanti evaṃ
analyzed: vutta ppakārena cittuppādena etāni me tīṇi ratanāni saraṇam etāni evam
translated: The meaning is that the being who possesses that goes for refuge by the arising of consciousness of that kind, thinking, “I go for refuge to these three gems, I cleave to these.”

original: upetīti attho. Evaṃ tāva saraṇaṃ, saraṇagamanaṃ, yo ca saraṇaṃ gacchati, idaṃ tayaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: upeti iti attho evam tāva saraṇam saraṇa gamanam yaḥ ca saraṇam gacchati idam veditabbam
translated: This, firstly, is how the refuge, the going for refuge, and he who goes for refuge should be understood.

original: Saraṇagamanappabhede pana duvidhaṃ saraṇagamanaṃ – lokuttaraṃ lokiyañca. Tattha lokuttaraṃ
analyzed: saraṇa gamana pabhede pana duvidham saraṇa gamanam lokuttaram lokiyam ca tattha lokuttaram
translated: As regards the classification of the going for refuge, the going for refuge is twofold, namely, mundane and supramundane. Herein,

original: diṭṭhasaccānaṃ maggakkhaṇe saraṇagamanupakkilesasamucchedena ārammaṇato nibbānārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭha saccānam magga kkhaṇe saraṇa gamana upakkilesa samucchedena ārammaṇataḥ nibbāna ārammaṇam
translated: the supramundane going for refuge is the act of a noble disciple’s consciousness that occurs at the moment of the path, which, by the severance of the defilements’ access, has Nibbāna as its object🔽through the act of cleaving to it.

original: hutvā kiccato sakalepi ratanattaye ijjhati. Lokiyaṃ puthujjanānaṃ saraṇagamanupakkilesavikkhambhanena
analyzed: hutvā kiccataḥ sakale api rata nattaye ijjhati lokiyam puthujjanānam saraṇa gamana upakkilesa vikkhambhanena
translated: and it succeeds by its function of resolving the doubts of those who are undecided about the three jewels.

original: ārammaṇato buddhādiguṇārammaṇaṃ hutvā ijjhati. Taṃ atthato buddhādīsu vatthūsu saddhāpaṭilābho
analyzed: ārammaṇataḥ buddha ādi guṇa ārammaṇam hutvā ijjhati tam atthataḥ buddha ādīsu vatthūsu saddhā paṭilābhaḥ
translated: It succeeds by its object as the object of the special qualities of the Buddha, and so on. That is the obtaining of faith in the Buddha, and so on, as the special qualities of the Buddha, and so on.

original: saddhāmūlikā ca sammādiṭṭhi dasasu puññakiriyavatthūsu diṭṭhijukammanti vuccati.
analyzed: saddhāmūlikā ca sammādiṭṭhi dasasu puñña kiriya vatthūsu diṭṭhijukammanti vuccati
translated: It is called right view rooted in faith in the ten profitable courses of action.

original: Tayidaṃ catudhā vattati – attasanniyyātanena, tapparāyaṇatāya, sissabhāvūpagamanena, paṇipātenāti.🔽Tattha attasanniyyātanaṃ nāma – “ajjādiṃ katvā ahaṃ attānaṃ buddhassa niyyātemi,🔽dhammassa, saṅghassā”ti evaṃ buddhādīnaṃ attapariccajanaṃ. Tapparāyaṇatā nāma “ajjādiṃ
analyzed: tayā idam catudhā vattati atta sanniyyātanena tad parāyaṇa tāya sissa bhāva upagamanena paṇipātena ati  tattha attasanniyyātanam nāma ajja ādim katvā aham attānam buddhassa niyyātemi  dhammassa saṅghassa ati evam buddha ādīnam atta pariccajanam tad parāyaṇa tā nāma ajja ādim
translated: It occurs in four ways: by surrender of self, by reliance, by acceptance of the state of a disciple, and by paying homage.🔽Herein, surrender of self is the handing over of oneself in this way: “From today onwards I surrender myself to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha.”

original: katvā ‘ahaṃ buddhaparāyaṇo, dhammaparāyaṇo, saṅghaparāyaṇo’ti. Maṃ dhārethā”ti evaṃ
analyzed: katvā aham buddha parāyaṇaḥ dhamma parāyaṇaḥ saṅgha parāyaṇaḥ iti mamam dhāretha ati evam
translated: Reliance is the reliance in this way: “From today onwards I rely on the Buddha, I rely on the Dhamma, I rely on the Saṅgha.”

original: tapparāyaṇabhāvo. Sissabhāvūpagamanaṃ nāma – “ajjādiṃ katvā – ‘ahaṃ buddhassa antevāsiko,
analyzed: tad parāyaṇa bhāvaḥ sissa bhāva upagamanam nāma ajja ādim katvā aham buddhassa antevāsikaḥ
translated: The state of being one who has gone for refuge is the state of being one who has gone for refuge by means of the going forth of the three kinds of refuge-going.🔽The state of being a disciple is the undertaking of discipleship thus: “From today onwards Buddha is my Master, Dhamma … Saṅgha …

original: dhammassa, saṅghassa antevāsiko’ti maṃ dhārethā”ti evaṃ sissabhāvūpagamo. Paṇipāto🔽nāma – “ajjādiṃ katvā ahaṃ abhivādanapaccuṭṭhānaañjalikammasāmīcikammaṃ buddhādīnaṃyeva
analyzed: dhammassa saṅghassa antevāsikaḥ iti mam dhāretha ati evam sissa bhāva upagamaḥ paṇipātaḥ  nāma ajja ādim katvā aham abhivādana paccuṭṭhāna añjalikamma sāmīcikammam buddha ādīnam yeva
translated: is my Master.” The state of being a pupil is the undertaking of pupilship thus: “From today onwards Buddha is my chief, Dhamma … Saṅgha …

original: tiṇṇaṃ vatthūnaṃ karomī’ti maṃ dhārethā”ti evaṃ buddhādīsu paramanipaccākāro. Imesañhi
analyzed: tiṇṇam vatthūnam karomi iti mamam dhāretha ati evam buddha ādīsu parama nipacca ākāraḥ imesam hi
translated: is my chief.” The state of being a devotee is the undertaking of devotion thus: “From today onwards I regard Buddha as the best, Dhamma … Saṅgha …

original: catunnaṃ ākārānaṃ aññatarampi karontena gahitaṃyeva hoti saraṇaṃ.
analyzed: catunnam ākārānam aññataram pi karontena gahitam yā iva hoti saraṇam
translated: is the best.” For one who does any one of these four things takes refuge.

original: Api ca bhagavato attānaṃ pariccajāmi, dhammassa, saṅghassa, attānaṃ pariccajāmi,
analyzed: api ca bhagavataḥ attānam pariccajāmi dhammassa saṅghassa attānam pariccajāmi
translated: Moreover, the state of being one who has gone for refuge is the state of one who has given himself up to the Triple Gem thus: “I give myself up to Buddha, I give myself up to Dhamma, I give myself up to Saṅgha.

original: jīvitaṃ pariccajāmi, pariccattoyeva me attā, pariccattaṃyeva jīvitaṃ, jīvitapariyantikaṃ
analyzed: jīvitam pariccajāmi pariccattaḥ yā iva me attā pariccattam yā iva jīvitam jīvita pariyantikam
translated: I give up my life to them. I am given up to them. My life is given up to them. I am in their hands.

original: buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, buddho me saraṇaṃ leṇaṃ tāṇanti; evampi attasanniyyātanaṃ
analyzed: buddham saraṇam gacchāmi buddhaḥ me saraṇam leṇam evam pi atta sanniyyātanam
translated: I go to the Buddha for refuge as long as I am alive. The Buddha is my refuge and my shelter as long as I am alive. The Dhamma … The Saṅgha …🔽is my refuge and my shelter as long as I am alive.”

original: veditabbaṃ. “Satthārañca vatāhaṃ passeyyaṃ, bhagavantameva passeyyaṃ, sugatañca vatāhaṃ
analyzed: veditabbam satthāram ca vata aham passeyyam bhagavantam eva passeyyam sugatam ca vata aham
translated: should be understood. “If I could only see the Teacher, the Blessed One,🔽if I could only see the One of Good Conduct,

original: passeyyaṃ, bhagavantameva passeyyaṃ, sammāsambuddhañca vatāhaṃ passeyyaṃ, bhagavantameva
analyzed: passeyyam bhagavantam eva passeyyam sammāsambuddham ca vata aham passeyyam bhagavantam eva
translated: the Blessed One, if I could only see the Fully Enlightened One,

original: passeyya”nti. Evampi mahākassapassa saraṇagamanaṃ viya sissabhāvūpagamanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: passeyya nti evam pi mahākassapassa saraṇa gamanam viya sissa bhāva upagamanam veditabbam
translated: the Blessed One” . Thus the acceptance of discipleship should be understood as the going for refuge of the great Kas-sapa.

original: “So ahaṃ vicarissāmi, gāmā gāmaṃ purā puraṃ;
analyzed: saḥ aham vicarissāmi gāmā gāmam purā puram
translated: “I will wander from village to village, from town to town,

original: Namassamāno sambuddhaṃ, dhammassa ca sudhammata”nti. ;
analyzed: namassamānaḥ sambuddham dhammassa ca su dhamma tanti
translated: Paying homage to the Enlightened One and to the Dhamma’s truth” .

original: Evampi āḷavakādīnaṃ saraṇagamanaṃ viya tapparāyaṇatā veditabbā. Atha kho brahmāyu🔽brāhmaṇo uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā
analyzed: evam pi āḷavaka ādīnam saraṇa gamanam viya tad parāyaṇa tā veditabbā atha kho brahma āyu  brāhmaṇaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā ekaṃsam uttarāsaṅgam karitvā bhagavataḥ pādesu sirasā nipatitvā
translated: Thus the being one whose faith has been purified should be understood as the going for refuge of Al-lavaka and the others. Then the brahmin Brahmadatta

original: bhagavato pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati, pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati, nāmañca sāveti
analyzed: bhagavataḥ pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati nāmañca sāva iti
translated: rose from his seat, and after arranging his upper robe on one shoulder, he prostrated himself with his head at the Blessed One’s feet, and he covered the Blessed One’s feet with kisses and caressed them with his hands, pronouncing his name,🔽saying:

original: – “brahmāyu ahaṃ, bho gotama brāhmaṇo, brahmāyu ahaṃ, bho gotama brāhmaṇo”ti evampi paṇipāto daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: brahmāyu aham bho gotama brāhmaṇaḥ brahmāyu aham bho gotama brāhmaṇaḥ iti evam pi paṇipātaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: This is how the act of paying homage should be understood.

original: So panesa ñātibhayācariyadakkhiṇeyyavasena catubbidho hoti. Tattha dakkhiṇeyyapaṇipātena
analyzed: so pana esa ñāti bhaya ācariya dakkhiṇeyya vasena catubbidhaḥ hoti tattha dakkhiṇeyya paṇipātena
translated: This act of paying homage is of four kinds as paying homage out of kinship, out of fear, to one worthy of homage, and as the best.🔽Herein, the going for refuge is by the act of paying homage that is worthy of homage,

original: saraṇagamanaṃ hoti, na itarehi. Seṭṭhavaseneva hi saraṇaṃ gaṇhāti, seṭṭhavasena ca
analyzed: saraṇa gamanam hoti na itarehi seṭṭha vasena iva hi saraṇam gaṇhāti seṭṭha vasena ca
translated: not by the other three. For one goes for refuge by the best, and one falls away by the best.

original: bhijjati. Tasmā yo sākiyo vā koliyo vā – “buddho amhākaṃ ñātako”ti vandati, aggahitameva🔽hoti saraṇaṃ. Yo vā – “samaṇo gotamo rājapūjito mahānubhāvo avandīyamāno anatthampi
analyzed: bhijjati tasmai yaḥ sākiyaḥ vā koliyaḥ vā buddhaḥ amhākam ñātako ti vandati aggahitam eva  hoti saraṇam yaḥ vā samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ rāja pūjitaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ a vandīyamānaḥ anattham pi
translated: So when a Sakyan or a Koḷiyan pays homage, thinking “The Enlightened One is our kinsman,”🔽his going for refuge is not really taken up.🔽Or when one pays homage out of fear, thinking “The recluse Gotama is honoured and revered by kings, has great influence, and if he were not honoured by me he might do me harm,”

original: kareyyā”ti bhayena vandati, aggahitameva hoti saraṇaṃ. Yo vā bodhisattakāle bhagavato
analyzed: kareyya iti bhayena vandati agga hitam eva hoti saraṇam yaḥ vā bodhisatta kāle bhagavataḥ
translated: his going for refuge is not really taken up.

original: santike kiñci uggahitaṃ saramāno buddhakāle vā –
analyzed: santike kiñci uggahitam saramānaḥ buddha kāle vā
translated: Or when one pays homage, thinking “I have learned something from the Enlightened One,”

original: “Catudhā vibhaje bhoge, paṇḍito gharamāvasaṃ;
analyzed: catudhā vibhaje bhoge paṇḍitaḥ gharam āvasam
translated: “The wise man who lives in the house Should divide his gifts fourfold.

original: Ekena bhogaṃ bhuñjeyya, dvīhi kammaṃ payojaye;
analyzed: ekena bhogam bhuñjeyya dvīhi kammam payojaye
translated: With one part he should use what he has For his own enjoyment and pleasure;

original: Catutthañca nidhāpeyya, āpadāsu bhavissatī”ti. ;
analyzed: catuttham ca nidhāpeyya āpadāsu bhavissati iti
translated: and the fourth he should keep for times of need.

original: Evarūpaṃ anusāsaniṃ uggahetvā – “ācariyo me”ti vandati, aggahitameva hoti saraṇaṃ. Yo pana – “ayaṃ loke aggadakkhiṇeyyo”ti vandati, teneva gahitaṃ hoti saraṇaṃ.🔽Evaṃ gahitasaraṇassa ca upāsakassa vā upāsikāya vā aññatitthiyesu pabbajitampi ñātiṃ
analyzed: evarūpam anusāsanim uggahetvā ācariyaḥ mā iti vandati agga hitam eva hoti saraṇam yaḥ pana ayam loke agga dakkhiṇeyyaḥ ti vandati tena iva gahitam hoti saraṇam  evam gahita saraṇassa ca upāsakassa vā upāsikāya vā añña titthiyesu pabbajitam pi ñātim
translated: If he does so and then pays homage to the teacher saying “You are my teacher,” his refuge in the Buddha is not rightly gone to. But if he pays homage saying “You are the most worthy person in the world,” his refuge in the Buddha is rightly gone to.

original: – “ñātako me aya”nti vandato saraṇagamanaṃ na bhijjati, pageva apabbajitaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: ñātakaḥ me vandato saraṇa gamanam na bhijjati pagā iva a pabbajitam tathā
translated: And if a lay devotee who has gone for refuge in this way pays homage to a relative who has gone forth among the sectarians, thinking “He is my relative,” his refuge in the Buddha is not broken. Still less is it broken if he pays homage to one who has not gone forth.

original: rājānaṃ bhayavasena vandato. So hi raṭṭhapūjitattā avandīyamāno anatthampi kareyyāti.🔽Tathā yaṃ kiñci sippaṃ sikkhāpakaṃ titthiyampi – “ācariyo me aya”nti vandatopi na
analyzed: rājānam bhaya vasena vandato saḥ hi raṭṭha pūjita ttā a vandīyamānaḥ anattham pi kareyyāti  tathā yam kiñci sippam sikkhāpakam titthiyam pi ācariyaḥ me ayanti vandataḥ api na
translated: And if he pays homage to a king out of fear of punishment, his refuge in the Buddha is not broken. For the king, being honoured by the people, might do him harm if he did not pay homage.

original: bhijjati, evaṃ saraṇagamanappabhedo veditabbo.
analyzed: bhijjati evam saraṇa gamana ppabhedaḥ veditabbo
translated: And if he pays homage to a heretic who teaches him a craft, thinking “He is my teacher,” his refuge in the Buddha is not broken. This is how the classification of going for refuge should be understood.

original: Ettha ca lokuttarassa saraṇagamanassa cattāri sāmaññaphalāni vipākaphalaṃ, sabbadukkhakkhayo ānisaṃsaphalaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ettha ca lokuttarassa saraṇa gamanassa cattāri sāmañña phalāni vipāka phalam sabba dukkha kkhayaḥ ānisaṃsa phalam vuttam ha etam
translated: And here the four fruits of asceticism are the fruit of outcome, and the exhaustion of all suffering is the fruit of reward. For this is said:

original: “Yo ca buddhañca dhammañca, saṅghañca saraṇaṃ gato;
analyzed: yaḥ ca buddhañca dhammañca saṅghañca saraṇam gataḥ
translated: “He who has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha,🔽Seeing with right wisdom

original: Cattāri ariyasaccāni, sammappaññāya passati.
analyzed: cattāri ariya saccāni sammappaññāya passati
translated: The four noble truths,🔽Suffering, the arising of suffering,

original: Dukkhaṃ dukkhasamuppādaṃ, dukkhassa ca atikkamaṃ;
analyzed: dukkham dukkha samuppādam dukkhassa ca atikkamam
translated: The cessation of suffering,

original: Ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ, dukkhūpasamagāminaṃ.
analyzed: ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam dukkha upasama gāminam
translated: And the noble eightfold path that leads to the cessation of suffering,🔽This is the safe refuge, this is the supreme refuge,

original: Etaṃ kho saraṇaṃ khemaṃ, etaṃ saraṇamuttamaṃ;
analyzed: etam khalu saraṇam khemam etam saraṇam uttamam
translated: Having gone to this refuge,

original: Etaṃ saraṇamāgamma, sabbadukkhā pamuccatī”ti. ;
analyzed: etam saraṇam āgamma sabba dukkhā pamuccati iti
translated: One is freed from all suffering.”🔽And further, the fruit of reward of the going for refuge should be understood as the non-abandoning of the eternal, etc., and so on. For this is said:

analyzed: pātarāsa bhattam karontā kuhim bhante bhagavā gacchati iti dahara bhikkhū pucchiṃsu
translated: and prepared a meal for him. When they had finished their work, they asked the young bhikkhus, “Where is the Blessed One going, venerable sirs?”

analyzed: upāsakāḥ na bhagavā aññattha gacchati idha iva tissa sāmaṇerassa dassana tthāya āgataḥ ti

analyzed: te amhākam kulūpakassa kira therassa dassana tthāya satthā āgataḥ no vata no thero
translated: The young bhikkhus said, “The Teacher has come to see our elder, who is a benefactor of our family. But our elder

analyzed: somanassa jātāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: and were delighted.

analyzed: atha kho bhagavataḥ bhatta kicca pariyosāne sāmaṇeraḥ gāme piṇḍāya caritvā upāsakā

analyzed: mahā bhikkhu saṅghaḥ iti pucchi athassa te satthā bhante āgataḥ iti ārocesuṃ saḥ bhagavantam  upasaṅkamitvā piṇḍapātena āpucchi satthā tassa pattam hatthena gahetvā alam  tissa niṭṭhitam bhatta kiccanti āha tatas upajjhāyam āpucchitvā attano pattāsane
translated: he asked, “where is the great community of monks?” They told him, “The Teacher has come, venerable sir.”🔽He approached the Blessed One and invited him with his bowl. The Teacher took his bowl in his hand and said, “Enough, Tissa, the meal is finished.”

original: nisīditvā bhattakiccamakāsi. Athassa bhattakiccapariyosāne satthā maṅgalaṃ vatvā
analyzed: nisīditvā bhatta kiccam akāsi atha assa bhatta kicca pariyosāne satthā maṅgalam vatvā
translated: Then, after asking his preceptor’s permission, he sat down on his own seat and ate his meal. After he had finished his meal, the Teacher told him an inspiring

original: nikkhamitvā gāmadvāre ṭhatvā – “kataro te, tissa, vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gatamaggo”ti āha.
analyzed: nikkhamitvā gāma dvāre ṭhatvā kataro te tissa vasana ṭhānam gata maggo ti āha
translated: story and then left. Standing at the village gate, he asked, “Tissa, which is the way to your dwelling place?”

original: Ayaṃ bhagavāti. Maggaṃ desayamāno purato yāhi tissāti. Bhagavā kira sadevakassa lokassa
analyzed: ayam bhagavā ati maggam desayamāno puratas yāhi tissā iti bhagavā kira sa devakassa lokassa
translated: “This is the way, Blessed One.” “Go on in front, Tissa, showing me the way.” The Blessed One, it seems,

analyzed: magga desakaḥ api samānaḥ sakale tigāvute magge sāmaṇeram daṭṭhum lacchāmi iti tam magga desakam akāsi  so attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhānam gantvā bhagavataḥ vattam akāsi atha nam bhagavā kataraḥ  te tissa caṅkamā iti pucchitvā tattha gantvā sāmaṇerassa nisīdana pāsāṇe nisīditvā
translated: and he made the man his guide, saying, “I want to see the novice.”🔽When he had gone to his own dwelling place, he did the duties to the Exalted One. Then the Exalted One asked him, “Tissa, which is your walking place?”

original: – “tissa, imasmiṃ ṭhāne sukhaṃ vasī”ti pucchi. So āha – “āma, bhante, imasmiṃ ṭhāne

original: te dassāmī”ti vatvā sannipatite bhikkhusaṅghe upasampādetvā attano vasanaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: te dassāmi iti vatvā sannipatite bhikkhu saṅghe upasampādetvā attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānam eva
translated: After the community of bhikkhus had assembled, he gave him the full admission. Then he went to his own dwelling place. This is called “swift conduct.”

translated: While wandering thus, the Blessed One wanders in one of three kinds of regions: the great region, the medium region, and the small region.

analyzed: nikkhamati samantā yojana satam eka kolāhalam hoti purimam purimam āgatāḥ nimantetum  labhanti itaresu dvīsu maṇḍalesu sakkāraḥ mahā maṇḍale osarati tattha bhagavā tesu

analyzed: tesu gāma nigamesu ekāham dvīham vasantaḥ mahā janam āmisa paṭiggahena anuggaṇhantaḥ
translated: staying for one day or two days in this or that village or town, helps the people by receiving their gifts of almsfood,

translated: and by the gift of the Dhamma he increases the merit of those who are dependent on him. He finishes his tour in nine months.

analyzed: itaresu dvīsu maṇḍalesu sakkāraḥ majjhima maṇḍale osarati bhagavā purima nayena iva lokam  an uggaṇhantaḥ aṭṭhahi māsehi cārikam pariyosāpeti sace pana catu māsam vuttha vassassa api

analyzed: pañcahi kāraṇehi buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ cārikam caranti pāṇa atipātāḥ viramissanti iti vā 🔽a dinna ādānā kāmesum icchā ācārā musā vādā surā meraya majja pamāda ṭṭhānā viramissanti iti

analyzed: vā aparehi pi aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ cārikam caranti paṭhamam jhānam

analyzed: paṭilabhissanti iti vā dutiyam jhānam pe na ivasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim paṭilabhissanti iti
