translated: and the “fixed tour.” Herein, the “unfixed tour” is that which is undertaken by going to a village, town, or city in no particular direction.

original: nāma. Yaṃ panekasseva bodhaneyyasattassatthāya gacchati, ayaṃ nibaddhacārikā nāma. Esā idha adhippetā.
analyzed: nāma yam pana ekassa iva bodhaneyya sattassa atthāya gacchati ayam nibaddhacārikā nāma esā idha adhippetā
translated: The “fixed tour” is that undertaken for the sake of a particular being to be trained. It is this that is intended here.

original: Tadā kira bhagavato pacchimayāmakiccapariyosāne dasasahassilokadhātuyā ñāṇajālaṃ
analyzed: tadā kira bhagavato pacchima yāma kicca pariyosāne dasa sahassi lokadhātuyāḥ ñāṇa jālam
translated: It seems that at the end of the last watch of the night, the Blessed One, having extended the net of his knowledge over the ten thousand world systems,

original: pattharitvā bodhaneyyabandhave olokentassa pokkharasātibrāhmaṇo sabbaññutaññāṇajālassa
analyzed: pattharitvā bodhaneyya bandhave olokentassa pokkharasāti brāhmaṇo sabbaññuta ññāṇa jālassa
translated: was surveying the world to see who was to be converted. The brahmin Pokkharasati came within the range of the net of omniscience.

original: anto paviṭṭho. Atha bhagavā ayaṃ brāhmaṇo mayhaṃ ñāṇajāle paññāyati, “atthi nu khvassa🔽upanissayo”ti vīmaṃsanto sotāpattimaggassa upanissayaṃ disvā – “eso mayi etaṃ janapadaṃ🔽gate lakkhaṇapariyesanatthaṃ ambaṭṭhaṃ antevāsiṃ pahiṇissati, so mayā saddhiṃ vādapaṭivādaṃ
analyzed: antar paviṭṭhaḥ atha bhagavā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ mayham ñāṇa jāle paññāyati atthi nu khvassa  upanissayaḥ ti vīmaṃsantaḥ sotāpatti maggassa upanissayam disvā esaḥ mayi etam janapadam  gate lakkhaṇa pariyesana attham ambaṭṭham antevāsim pahiṇissati saḥ mayā saddhim vāda paṭivādam
translated: The Blessed One thought: “This brahmin is within the range of my knowledge. Is there a proximate cause for his attainment of the noble fruit?

original: katvā nānappakāraṃ asabbhivākyaṃ vakkhati, tamahaṃ dametvā nibbisevanaṃ karissāmi.
analyzed: katvā nānappakāram asabbhivākyam vakkhati tam aham dametvā nibbisevanam karissāmi
translated: ” He saw that there was a proximate cause for his attainment of the stream-entry fruit. He thought: “This brahmin will send his pupil Ambattha to me when I go to the country of the Mallas to search for the thirty-two marks of a Great Man. Ambattha will engage in a discussion with me and will speak many harsh words. I will then subdue him and make him a non-doer of harm.

original: So ācariyassa kathessati, athassācariyo taṃ kathaṃ sutvā āgamma mama lakkhaṇāni pariyesissati,
analyzed: saḥ ācariyassa kathessati atha assa ācariyaḥ tam katham sutvā āgamma mama lakkhaṇāni pariyesissati
translated: He will tell his teacher, and when the teacher hears his account he will come to me and will search for the marks.

original: tassāhaṃ dhammaṃ desessāmi. So desanāpariyosāne sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahissati. Desanā
analyzed: tassa aham dhammam desessāmi saḥ desanā pariyosāne sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahissati desanā
translated: I will then teach him the Dhamma. At the conclusion of the teaching he will attain the fruit of stream-entry.

original: mahājanassa saphalā bhavissatī”ti pañcabhikkhusataparivāro taṃ janapadaṃ paṭipanno.
analyzed: mahājanassa saphalā bhavissati iti pañca bhikkhu sata parivāraḥ tam janapadam paṭipannaḥ
translated: it will be fruitful for the multitude.” Surrounded by five hundred bhikkhus, he set out for that district.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehī”ti.🔽Yena icchānaṅgalanti yena disābhāgena icchānaṅgalaṃ avasaritabbaṃ. Yasmiṃ vā padese
analyzed: tena vuttam kosalesu cārikam caramānaḥ mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi iti  yena icchā anaṅgalanti yena disā bhāgena icchā anaṅgalam avasaritabbam yasmin vā padese
translated: Hence it is said: “Wandering by stages in the Kosala country, he eventually arrived at Icchānangala with a large number of bhikkhus, with five hundred bhikkhus.”🔽Yena icchānangalaṃ: in the direction in which Icchānangala was situated. Or in the place

original: icchānaṅgalaṃ. Ijjhānaṅgalantipi pāṭho. Tadavasarīti tena avasari, taṃ vā avasari.
analyzed: tad avasari iti tena avasari tam vai avasari
translated: where Icchānangala was situated. The reading ijjhānangalaṃ is also correct. Avasari: he went to, he reached.🔽The meaning is: he went in that direction, he went to that place.

original: Tena disābhāgena gato, taṃ vā padesaṃ gatoti attho. Icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍeti
analyzed: tena disā bhāgena gataḥ tam vā padesam gataḥ iti attho icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍā iti
translated: Icchānangale viharati icchānangala-vanasaṇḍe:

original: icchānaṅgalaṃ upanissāya icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe sīlakhandhāvāraṃ bandhitvā samādhikontaṃ
analyzed: icchānaṅgalam upanissāya icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍe sīla khandhāvāram bandhitvā
translated: having established the guard of virtue, having raised the guard of concentration,

original: ussāpetvā sabbaññutaññāṇasaraṃ parivattayamāno dhammarājā yathābhirucitena vihārena viharati.
analyzed: ussāpetvā sabbaññuta ññāṇa saram parivattayamānaḥ dhamma rājā yathā abhirucitena vihārena viharati
translated: and having turned the arrow of omniscient knowledge, the King of the Dhamma dwells in whatever dwelling he desires.

original: Pokkharasātivatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pokkharasāti vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Pokkharasāti

original: 255. Tena kho pana samayenāti yena samayena bhagavā tattha viharati, tena samayena,🔽tasmiṃ samayeti ayamattho. Brahmaṃ aṇatīti brāhmaṇo, mante sajjhāyatīti attho. Idameva
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena ati yena samayena bhagavā tattha viharati tena samayena  tasmin samaye iti ayam atthaḥ brahmaṃ aṇati iti brāhmaṇaḥ mante sajjhāyati iti atthaḥ idam eva
translated: 1. Now at that time: at the time when the Lord was living there, at that time.🔽In that place: the meaning is, in that place. A brahmin is one who is purified by Brahma; the meaning is, he recites the mantras.

original: hi jātibrāhmaṇānaṃ niruttivacanaṃ. Ariyā pana bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇāti vuccanti.
analyzed: hi jāti brāhmaṇānam nirutti vacanam ariyāḥ pana brāhmaṇā ati vuccanti
translated: For this is the expression in use for those of the brahmin caste. But the noble ones, who have expelled evil, are called brahmins.

original: Pokkharasātīti idaṃ tassa nāmaṃ. Kasmā pokkharasātīti vuccati. Tassa kira kāyo setapokkharasadiso,
analyzed: pokkharasātī iti idam tassa nāmam kasmā pokkharasātī iti vuccati tassa kira kāyo seta pokkhara sadiso
translated: Pokkharasati: this is his name. Why is he called Pokkharasati? It seems that his body was like a white lotus,

original: devanagare ussāpitarajatatoraṇaṃ viya sobhati. Sīsaṃ panassa kāḷavaṇṇaṃ indanīlamaṇimayaṃ🔽viya. Massupi candamaṇḍale kāḷamegharāji viya khāyati. Akkhīni nīluppalasadisāni.
analyzed: deva nagare ussāpita rajata toraṇam viya sobhati sīsam panassa kāḷa vaṇṇam inda nīla maṇi mayam  viya canda maṇḍale kāḷa megha rāji viya khāyati akkhīni nīla uppala sadisāni
translated: and shone like a silver triumphal arch erected in the city of the gods. But his head was black, like a sapphire,🔽and his eyebrows were like a black rain-cloud in the moon’s disk.

original: Nāsā rajatapanāḷikā viya suvaṭṭitā suparisuddhā. Hatthapādatalāni ceva mukhadvārañca
analyzed: nāsā su vaṭṭitā su parisuddhā hattha pāda talāni ca iva mukha dvāram ca
translated: His eyes were like blue lotuses. His nose was well-shaped and very clean, like a silver spoon. The palms of his hands and the soles of his feet,

original: katalākhārasaparikammaṃ viya sobhati, ativiya sobhaggappatto brāhmaṇassa attabhāvo.
analyzed: kata lākhā rasa parikammam viya sobhati ati viya sobhagga ppattaḥ brāhmaṇassa atta bhāvo
translated: and the door of his mouth, shone like a polished mirror. The brahmin’s body was endowed with the utmost beauty.

original: Arājake ṭhāne rājānaṃ kātuṃ yuttamimaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ. Evamesa sassiriko. Iti naṃ pokkharasadisattā
analyzed: arājake ṭhāne rājānam kātum yuttam imam brāhmaṇam evam esa iti nam pokkhara sadisa ttā
translated: “This brahmin is fit to be king in a place where there is no king.” Thus he became a king.

original: pokkharasātīti sañjānanti.
analyzed: pokkharasātī iti sañjānanti
translated: Because he was like a lotus, they called him Pokkharasāti.

original: Ayaṃ pana kassapasammāsambuddhakāle tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū dasabalassa dānaṃ datvā
analyzed: ayam pana kassapa sammāsambuddha kāle tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū dasabalassa dānam da tvā
translated: But in the time of the Perfectly Awakened One Kassapa, he had mastered the three Vedas, and he gave a gift to the One of Ten Powers.

original: dhammadesanaṃ sutvā devaloke nibbatti. So tato manussalokamāgacchanto mātukucchivāsaṃ
analyzed: dhamma desanam sutvā deva loke nibbatti so tatas manussa lokam āgacchantaḥ mātukucchi vāsam
translated: After hearing a teaching of the Dhamma, he was reborn in the world of the gods. When he came down from there to the human world, he was disgusted with the womb of a mother.

original: jigucchitvā himavantapadese mahāsare padumagabbhe nibbatti. Tassa ca sarassa avidūre
analyzed: jigucchitvā himavanta padese mahā sare paduma gabbhe nibbatti tassa ca sarassa avidūre
translated: He was reborn in a great lake in the Himalayas, in the calyx of a lotus. Not far from that lake,

original: tāpaso paṇṇasālāya vasati. So tīre ṭhito taṃ padumaṃ disvā – “idaṃ padumaṃ avasesapadumehi
analyzed: tāpasaḥ paṇṇasālāya vasati saḥ tīre ṭhitaḥ tam padumam disvā idam padumam avasesa padumehi
translated: a forest-dweller lived in a leaf-hut. Standing on the bank, he saw that lotus. “This lotus is bigger than the other lotuses.

original: mahantataraṃ. Pupphitakāle naṃ gahessāmī”ti cintesi. Taṃ sattāhenāpi na pupphati.
analyzed: mahantataram pupphita kāle nam gahessāmi iti cintesi tam satta ahena api na pupphati
translated: When it is in bloom, I will take it,” he thought. Even after seven days it did not bloom.

original: Tāpaso kasmā nu kho idaṃ sattāhenāpi na pupphati. Handa naṃ gahessāmīti otaritvā
analyzed: tāpaso kasmā nu kho idam satta ahena api na pupphati handa nam gahessāmi iti otaritvā
translated: The forest-dweller thought, “Why does it not bloom even after seven days? Well, I will take it.” He got down into the water,🔽and

original: gaṇhi. Taṃ tena nāḷato chinnamattaṃyeva pupphitaṃ. Athassabbhantare suvaṇṇacuṇṇapiñjaraṃ🔽viya rajatabimbakaṃ padumareṇupiñjaraṃ setavaṇṇaṃ dārakaṃ addasa. So mahāpuñño esa🔽bhavissati. Handa naṃ paṭijaggāmīti paṇṇasālaṃ netvā paṭijaggitvā sattavassakālato🔽paṭṭhāya tayo vede uggaṇhāpesi. Dārako tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāraṃ gantvā paṇḍito byatto
analyzed: gaṇhi tam tena nāḷataḥ chinna mattam yā iva pupphitam athassa abbhantare suvaṇṇa cuṇṇa piñjaram  viya rajata bimbakam paduma reṇu piñjaram seta vaṇṇam dārakam addasa saḥ mahā puññaḥ esa  bhavissati handa nam paṭijaggāmi iti paṇṇa sālam netvā paṭijaggitvā satta vassa kālataḥ  paṭṭhāya tayaḥ vede uggaṇhāpesi dārakaḥ tiṇṇam vedānam pāram gantvā paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ
translated: He took it, and it was just then in flower. Then he saw in it a boy, as white as a silver mirror or a lotus flower, as if he were a paste of white lead. He thought: “This boy will be of great merit. Well, I will look after him.” He took him to his leaf-hut, looked after him, and from the time he was seven years old had him learn the Three Vedas. When the boy had mastered the Three Vedas, he was clever and skilled.

original: jambudīpe aggabrāhmaṇo ahosi. So aparena samayena rañño kosalassa sippaṃ dassesi.
analyzed: jambudīpe agga brāhmaṇaḥ ahosi saḥ aparena samayena rañño kosalassa sippam dassesi
translated: He took it, and it was just then in flower. And he saw in it a boy, as white as a silver mirror or a lotus-flower, as if filled with silver dust. He thought: “This boy must be of great merit. I will look after him.” He took him to his leaf-hut, looked after him, and from the time he was seven years old had him learn the Three Vedas. The boy, having mastered the Three Vedas, became wise and clever, and was the chief of the Brahmins in the Rose-Apple Island. Later he showed his skill to the King of Kosala.

original: Athassa sippe pasanno rājā ukkaṭṭhaṃ nāma mahānagaraṃ brahmadeyyaṃ adāsi. Iti naṃ
analyzed: athassa sippe pasannaḥ rājā ukkaṭṭham nāma mahā nagaram brahmadeyyam adāsi iti naṃ
translated: The King, being pleased with his skill, gave him the great city called Ukkaṭṭha as a gift from the King. Thus

original: pokkhare sayitattā pokkharasātīti sañjānanti.
analyzed: pokkhare sayitattā pokkhara sāti iti sañjānanti
translated: they know him as Pokkharasāti because he lay in a lotus-pool.

original: Ukkaṭṭhaṃ ajjhāvasatīti ukkaṭṭhanāmake nagare vasati. Abhibhavitvā vā āvasati. Tassa
analyzed: ukkaṭṭham ajjhāvasati iti ukkaṭṭha nāmake nagare vasati abhibhavitvā vā āvasati tassa
translated: He lives in Ukkaṭṭha: he lives in the city called Ukkaṭṭha, or he lives having overcome (others).

original: nagarassa sāmiko hutvā yāya mariyādāya tattha vasitabbaṃ, tāya mariyādāya vasi. Tassa🔽kira nagarassa vatthuṃ ukkā ṭhapetvā ukkāsu jalamānāsu aggahesuṃ, tasmā taṃ ukkaṭṭhanti🔽vuccati. Okkaṭṭhantipi pāṭho, soyevattho. Upasaggavasena panettha bhummatthe upayogavacanaṃ
analyzed: nagarassa sāmikaḥ hutvā yāya mariyādāya tattha vasitabbam tāya mariyādāya vasi tassa  kira nagarassa vatthum ukkā ṭhapetvā ukkāsu jalamānāsu tasmā tam ukkaṭṭhanti  vuccati okkaṭṭhanti pi pāṭhaḥ upasagga vasena pana ittha bhumma tthe upayogavacanam
translated: He lived within the bounds of the city as its lord.🔽It is said that the site of the city was marked out by a line of fire, and that they took possession of it while the fire was burning. Therefore it is called Ukkatthā.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tassa anupayogattā ca sesapadesu. Tattha lakkhaṇaṃ saddasatthato pariyesitabbaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam tassa anupayoga ttā ca sesa padesu tattha lakkhaṇam sadda satthataḥ pariyesitabbam
translated: The reading okkaṭṭhā is also allowable, and the meaning is the same. But here the word ukkatthā should be understood in the sense of “ground” in the sense of “abundance,”🔽because it is not used in the other senses. The characteristic of the word should be sought in the grammatical treatises.

original: Sattussadanti sattehi ussadaṃ, ussannaṃ bahujanaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ. Posāvaniyahatthiassamoramigādianekasattasamākiṇṇañcāti
analyzed: sattussadanti sattehi ussadam ussannam bahu janam ākiṇṇa manussam posa avaniya hatthi assama ura miga ādi aneka satta samākiṇṇam ca ati
translated: Sattussada: “Abundant with beings,” “full of beings,” “crowded with people.” The meaning is that it is crowded with many kinds of beings such as elephants, horses, cattle, deer, etc.

original: attho. Yasmā panetaṃ nagaraṃ bahi āvijjhitvā jātena hatthiassādīnaṃ ghāsatiṇena ceva
analyzed: atthaḥ yasmā pana itam nagaram bahi āvijjhitvā jātena hatthi assa ādīnam ghāsa tiṇena ca iva
translated: But this city is supplied with grass for feeding the elephants, horses, etc., and with grass for roofing the houses, which grow outside the city and spread over it.

original: gehacchādanatiṇena ca sampannaṃ. Tathā dārukaṭṭhehi ceva gehasambhārakaṭṭhehi ca.
analyzed: geha chādana tiṇena ca sampannam tathā dāru kaṭṭhehi ca iva geha sambhāra kaṭṭhehi ca
translated: And it is supplied with timber for building houses and with timber for house-props.

original: Yasmā cassabbhantare vaṭṭacaturassādisaṇṭhānā bahū pokkharaṇiyo jalajakusumavicittāni🔽ca bahūni anekāni taḷākāni udakassa niccabharitāneva honti, tasmā satiṇakaṭṭhodakanti
analyzed: yasmā cassa abbhantare vaṭṭa caturassa ādi saṇṭhānāḥ bahū pokkharaṇiyaḥ jala ja kusuma vicittāni  ca bahūni anekāni taḷākāni udakassa honti tasmā sa tiṇa kaṭṭha udakanti
translated: And because there are many lotus-ponds inside it, shaped like a circle, a square, etc., and adorned with water-flowers,🔽and because there are many different kinds of lakes always full of water, it is said that it has grass, timber, and water.

original: vuttaṃ. Saha dhaññenāti sadhaññaṃ pubbaṇṇāparaṇṇādibhedaṃ bahudhaññasannicayanti🔽attho. Ettāvatā yasmiṃ nagare brāhmaṇo setacchattaṃ ussāpetvā rājalīlāya vasati,
analyzed: vuttam saha dhaññena ati sa dhaññam pubbaṇṇa aparaṇṇa ādi bhedam bahu dhañña sannicayanti  attho ettāvatā yasmin nagare brāhmaṇaḥ seta chattam rāja līlāya vasati
translated: With grain means with much stored grain of various kinds such as the autumn and summer harvests.

original: tassa samiddhisampatti dīpitā hoti.🔽Rājato laddhaṃ bhoggaṃ rājabhoggaṃ. Kena dinnanti ce? Raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ.🔽Rājadāyanti rañño dāyabhūtaṃ, dāyajjanti attho. Brahmadeyyanti seṭṭhadeyyaṃ, chattaṃ
analyzed: tassa samiddhi sampatti dīpitā hoti  rājataḥ laddham bhoggam rāja bhoggam kena dinnan ti ce raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnam  rājadāyanti raññaḥ dāya bhūtam dāyajjanti attho brahmadeyyanti seṭṭha deyyam chattam
translated: This is the meaning. So far the prosperity of the city in which the brahmin lives, having raised the white parasol, in the enjoyment of royal pleasures, has been revealed.🔽The enjoyment given by the king is royal enjoyment. By whom given? Given by King Pasenadi of Kosala.

original: ussāpetvā rājasaṅkhepena bhuñjitabbanti attho. Atha vā rājabhogganti sabbaṃ chejjabhejjaṃ
analyzed: ussāpetvā rāja saṅkhepena bhuñjitabbanti attho atha vā rāja bhoggam ti sabbam chejja bhejjam
translated: The king’s grant is land given by the king, a grant, is the meaning. The brahmin’s fee is the best gift. The meaning is, having raised the parasol, he should enjoy it with the royal pomp. Or else, the royal enjoyment is all that can be cut down or destroyed.

original: anusāsantena nadītitthapabbatādīsu suṅkaṃ gaṇhantena setacchattaṃ ussāpetvā raññā
analyzed: anusāsantena nadī tittha pabbata ādīsu suṅkam gaṇhantena seta chattam ussāpetvā raññā
translated: When he is instructing, he should have a corpse taken to a river bank, a rock, etc., and have a white parasol held over it, and then

original: hutvā bhuñjitabbaṃ. Raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyanti ettha taṃ nagaraṃ🔽raññā dinnattā rājadāyaṃ dāyakarājadīpanatthaṃ panassa “raññā pasenadinā kosalena🔽dinna”nti idaṃ vuttaṃ. Brahmadeyyanti seṭṭhadeyyaṃ. Yathā dinnaṃ na puna gahetabbaṃ
analyzed: hutvā bhuñjitabbam raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnam rājadāyanti ettha tam nagaram  raññā dinnattā rāja dāyam dāyaka rāja dīpana attham panassa raññā pasenadinā kosalena  dinnam ti idam vuttam brahma deyyam ti seṭṭha deyyam yathā dinnam na puna gahetabbam
translated: he should eat. “The king’s grant” : the city was given by King Pasenadi of Kosala.

original: hoti, nissaṭṭhaṃ pariccattaṃ. Evaṃ dinnanti attho.
analyzed: hoti nissaṭṭham pariccattam evam dinnam ti attho
translated: Since it was given by the king, it is a “king’s grant.” But in order to show that the king who gave it was King Pasenadi of Kosala, it is said, “given by King Pasenadi of Kosala.” “Brahma’s grant” : the best grant. It is given in such a way that it cannot be taken back, that it is relinquished and given up. This is the meaning.

original: Assosīti suṇi upalabhi, sotadvārasampattavacananigghosānusārena aññāsi. Khoti avadhāraṇatthe🔽padapūraṇamatte vā nipāto. Tattha avadhāraṇatthena assosi eva, nāssa koci savanantarāyo
analyzed: assosi iti suṇi upalabhi sota dvāra sampatta vacana nigghosa anusārena aññāsi kho ti avadhāraṇa atthe  vā nipātaḥ tattha avadhāraṇa atthena eva na assa koci
translated: “Heard” : he heard, he understood, he knew by the sound of the words that reached the ear door. “Kho” is a particle in the sense of limitation,🔽or it is merely to fill out the line. Here, in the sense of limitation, it should be understood to mean that he heard it without any hindrance to his hearing.

original: ahosīti ayamattho veditabbo. Padapūraṇena pana padabyañjanasiliṭṭhatāmattameva.
analyzed: ahosi iti ayam attho veditabbo pada pūraṇena pana pada byañjana siliṭṭha tā mattam eva
translated: In the sense of filling out the line, it merely serves to complete the syllables and words.

original: Idāni yamatthaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti assosi, taṃ pakāsento – “samaṇo khalu bho gotamo”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha samitapāpattā samaṇoti veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ – “samitāssa honti pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: idāni yam attham brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti assosi tam pakāsento samaṇaḥ khalu bho gotama iti ādim āha  tattha samita pāpattā samaṇaḥ ti veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam samitā assa honti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: Now, in order to make clear the matter which the brahmin Pokkharasati had heard about, he said: “The recluse Gotama, brahmin, is a noble, a Khattiya.”

original: dhammā”tiādi. Bhagavā ca anuttarena ariyamaggena samitapāpo. Tenassa yathābhūtaguṇādhigatametaṃ🔽nāmaṃ, yadidaṃ samaṇoti. Khalūti anussavanatthe nipāto. Bhoti brāhmaṇajātisamudāgataṃ
analyzed: bhagavā ca anuttarena ariya maggena samita pāpo tena assa yathā bhūta guṇa adhigatam etam  nāmam yat idam samaṇa uti khalu iti anussavana atthe nipātaḥ bhoti brāhmaṇa jāti samudāgatam
translated: Herein, he should be known as a recluse because he has quieted evil things. For this is said: “Evil, unprofitable things are quieted in him” and so on. And the Blessed One has quieted evil things by means of the unsurpassed Noble Path. So this name, namely, “recluse,” is established in him by discovery of his true qualities.

original: ālapanamattaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “bhovādī nāma so hoti, sace hoti sakiñcano”ti. Gotamoti🔽bhagavantaṃ gottavasena parikitteti. Tasmā samaṇo khalu bho gotamoti ettha samaṇo
analyzed: ālapana mattam bho vādī nāma saḥ hoti sace hoti gotama iti  bhagavantam gotta vasena parikitta iti tasmā samaṇaḥ khalu bho gotamaḥ ti ettha samaṇaḥ
translated: “Khalu” is a particle for calling up. “Brahmin” is an address based on the brahmin caste. For this is said: “He is one who says ‘bho’ and is a possessor of something” .🔽“Gotama” is the Blessed One’s clan name.

original: kira bho gotamagottoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: kira bho gotama gotto ti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: So in the phrase “The recluse Gotama, brahmin, is a noble, a Khattiya,” the meaning should be regarded as follows: “The recluse, brahmin, is of the Gotama clan.”

original: Sakyaputtoti idaṃ pana bhagavato uccākulaparidīpanaṃ. Sakyakulā pabbajitoti saddhāpabbajitabhāvaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: sakya putto ti idam pana bhagavataḥ uccā kula paridīpanam sakya kulā pabbajito ti saddhā pabbajita bhāva paridīpanam
translated: “A Sakyan son” is a description of the Blessed One’s high birth. “Gone forth from the Sakyan clan” is a description of his going forth in faith.

original: Kenaci pārijuññena anabhibhūto aparikkhīṇaṃyeva taṃ kulaṃ pahāya saddhāya pabbajitoti
analyzed: kenaci pārijuññena an abhibhūtaḥ a parikkhīṇam yeva tam kulam pahāya saddhāya pabbajitaḥ ti
translated: He went forth from the home life into homelessness with faith alone, without being overwhelmed by any worldly gain.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tato paraṃ vuttatthameva. Taṃ kho panātiādi sāmaññaphale vuttameva.
analyzed: vuttam hoti tatas param vutta ttham eva tam kho pana ātiādi sāmañña phale vuttam eva
translated: The rest is as stated in the Fruits of the Homeless Life.

original: Sādhu kho panāti sundaraṃ kho pana. Atthāvahaṃ sukhāvahanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathārūpānaṃ
analyzed: sādhu kho pana ati sundaram kho pana attha āvaham sukha āvahanti vuttam hoti tathārūpānam
translated: It is good: it is beautiful. It is productive of welfare and pleasure: it is productive of welfare and pleasure here and now and in the life to come.

original: arahatanti yathārūpo so bhavaṃ gotamo, evarūpānaṃ yathābhūtaguṇādhigamena loke arahantoti
analyzed: saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ yathā bhūta guṇa adhigamena loke
translated: Such arahants: such arahants who have attained the true nature of things and have thus become arahants in the world.

original: laddhasaddhānaṃ arahataṃ. Dassanaṃ hotīti pasādasommāni akkhīni ummīletvā dassanamattampi
analyzed: laddha saddhānam arahatam dassanam hoti iti pasāda sommāni akkhīni ummīletvā dassana mattam pi
translated: To see: to see with eyes that are clear and bright through faith.

original: sādhu hotīti, evaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ katvā.
analyzed: sādhu hoti iti evam ajjhāsayam katvā
translated: It is good: it is good to have such a desire.

original: Ambaṭṭhamāṇavakathā🔽256. Ajjhāyakoti idaṃ – “na dānime jhāyanti, na dānime jhāyantīti kho, vāseṭṭha,
analyzed: ambaṭṭha māṇava kathā  ajjhāyakaḥ uti idam na dāni ime jhāyanti na dāni ime jhāyanti iti kho vāseṭṭha
translated: The Discussion with Ambattha

original: ajjhāyakā ajjhāyakā tveva tatiyaṃ akkharaṃ upanibbatta”nti, evaṃ paṭhamakappikakāle
analyzed: ajjhāyakāḥ ajjhāyakā tu eva tatiyam akkharam upanibbattanti evam paṭhama kappika kāle
translated: The reciters say this: “They did not meditate, they did not meditate,” and so the third syllable was added to make the word ajjhāyaka .

original: jhānavirahitānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ garahavacanaṃ. Idāni pana taṃ ajjhāyatīti ajjhāyako.
analyzed: jhāna virahitānam brāhmaṇānam garaha vacanam idāni pana tam ajjhāyati iti ajjhāyakaḥ
translated: and it is a term of disparagement for brahmins who are devoid of jhāna. But now it is one who has mastered that, thus he is a master of the Three Vedas.

original: Mante parivattetīti iminā atthena pasaṃsāvacanaṃ katvā voharanti. Mante dhāretīti mantadharo.🔽Tiṇṇaṃ vedānanti iruvedayajuvedasāmavedānaṃ. Oṭṭhapahatakaraṇavasena pāraṃ gatoti
analyzed: mante parivatteti iti iminā atthena pasaṃsā vacanam katvā voharanti mante dhāreti iti mantadharo  tiṇṇam iru veda yaju veda sāma vedānam oṭṭha apahata karaṇa vasena pāram gataḥ ti
translated: They speak in praise of him with the words “He turns the mantras,” and he is a bearer of mantras, thus he is a bearer of mantras.🔽As to the three Vedas: the Rg Veda, the Yajur Veda, and the Sāma Veda. He has gone to the end by the method of the O and the U, thus

original: pāragū. Saha nighaṇḍunā ca keṭubhena ca sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ. Nighaṇḍūti nighaṇḍurukkhādīnaṃ
analyzed: pāragū saha nighaṇḍunā ca keṭubhena ca sa nighaṇḍu keṭubhānam nighaṇḍu uti nighaṇḍu rukkha ādīnam
translated: he is one who has gone to the end of the three Vedas. Together with the Nighaṇṭu and the Keṭu, thus with the Nighaṇṭu and the Keṭu. The Nighaṇṭu is a text that reveals the synonyms of trees, etc.,

original: vevacanapakāsakaṃ satthaṃ. Keṭubhanti kiriyākappavikappo kavīnaṃ upakārāvahaṃ satthaṃ.
analyzed: vevacana pakāsakam sattham keṭubhanti kiriyā kappa vikappo kavīnam upakāra āvaham sattham
translated: and the Keṭu is a text that is helpful to poets by the method of the composition of verses.

original: Saha akkharappabhedena sākkharappabhedānaṃ. Akkharappabhedoti sikkhā ca nirutti ca.
analyzed: saha akkharappabhedena sa akkharappabhedānam akkharappabhedaḥ ti sikkhā ca nirutti ca
translated: Together with the analysis of the phonemes, thus with the analysis of the phonemes. The analysis of the phonemes is the training and the language.

original: Itihāsapañcamānanti āthabbaṇavedaṃ catutthaṃ katvā itiha āsa, itiha āsāti īdisavacanapaṭisaṃyutto
analyzed: itihāsa pañcamānanti āthabbaṇa vedam catuttham katvā iti ha āsa iti ha āsa ati īdisa vacana paṭisaṃyuttaḥ
translated: The Itihasa is the fifth, thus it is so called because it is connected with such expressions as “It was thus in the past” and “It was thus in the past.”

original: purāṇakathāsaṅkhāto itihāso pañcamo etesanti itihāsapañcamā, tesaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ vedānaṃ.🔽Padaṃ tadavasesañca byākaraṇaṃ adhīyati vedeti cāti padako veyyākaraṇo. Lokāyataṃ
analyzed: purāṇa kathā saṅkhātaḥ itihāsaḥ pañcamaḥ etesanti itihāsa pañcamā tesam itihāsa pañcamānam vedānam  padam tad avasesam ca byākaraṇam adhīyati veda iti ca ati padakaḥ veyyākaraṇaḥ lokāyatam
translated: The fifth is the Itihasa, which is a collection of old stories.🔽The one who studies the Vedas together with the rest of the words is a Padaka grammarian.🔽The Lokayata is said to be the treatise of sophistry.

original: vuccati vitaṇḍavādasatthaṃ. Mahāpurisalakkhaṇanti mahāpurisānaṃ buddhādīnaṃ lakkhaṇadīpakaṃ
analyzed: vuccati vitaṇḍa vāda sattham mahāpurisa lakkhaṇan ti mahā purisānam buddha ādīnam lakkhaṇa dīpakam
translated: The Great Man’s Marks is the treatise which describes the marks of the Great Men, the Buddhas, etc.

original: dvādasasahassaganthapamāṇaṃ satthaṃ. Yattha soḷasasahassagāthāparimāṇā buddhamantā
analyzed: dvādasa sahassa gantha pamāṇam sattham soḷasa sahassa gāthā parimāṇāḥ buddha mantā
translated: It is a treatise of twelve thousand sections. In it there are sixteen thousand verses called the Buddha’s Mantras,

original: nāma ahesuṃ, yesaṃ vasena iminā lakkhaṇena samannāgatā buddhā nāma honti, iminā paccekabuddhā,
analyzed: nāma ahesum yesam vasena iminā lakkhaṇena samannāgatāḥ buddhāḥ nāma honti iminā paccekabuddhā
translated: by means of which it is known that those who possess these marks are Buddhas, those who possess these are Paccekabuddhas,

original: iminā dve aggasāvakā, asīti mahāsāvakā, buddhamātā, buddhapitā, aggupaṭṭhāko, aggupaṭṭhāyikā,
analyzed: iminā dve agga sāvakāḥ asīti mahāsāvakāḥ buddha mātā buddha pitā aggupaṭṭhākaḥ aggupaṭṭhāyikā
translated: those who possess these are the two chief disciples, the eighty great disciples, the Buddha’s mother, the Buddha’s father, the chief attendant, the chief female attendant,

original: rājā cakkavattīti ayaṃ viseso paññāyati.
analyzed: rājā cakkavattī iti ayam visesaḥ paññāyati
translated: and the universal monarch.

original: Anavayoti imesu lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anūno paripūrakārī, avayo na hotīti
analyzed: anavayo ti imesu lokāyata mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu anūno paripūra kārī avayaḥ na hoti iti
translated: The one who is not lacking is the one who is not lacking in, who is complete in, these Lokayata and Great Man’s Marks. He is not lacking,

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Avayo nāma yo tāni atthato ca ganthato ca sandhāretuṃ na sakkoti. Anuññātapaṭiññātoti🔽anuññāto ceva paṭiññāto ca. Ācariyenassa “yaṃ ahaṃ jānāmi, taṃ tvaṃ jānāsī”tiādinā
analyzed: vuttam hoti avayaḥ nāma yaḥ tāni atthataḥ ca ganthataḥ ca sandhāretum na sakkoti anuññāta paṭiññātaḥ ti  anuññātaḥ ca iva paṭiññātaḥ ca yam aham jānāmi tam tvam jānāsi itiādinā
translated: One who is agreed upon and acknowledged:🔽he is agreed upon by the teacher, “What I know, you know,”

original: anuññāto. “Āma ācariyā”ti attanā tassa paṭivacanadānapaṭiññāya paṭiññātoti attho.
analyzed: anuññātaḥ āmaḥ ācariyā ti attanā tassa paṭivacana dāna paṭiññāya paṭiññātaḥ ti attho
translated: and he is acknowledged by himself through the giving of the reply, “Yes, teacher,” i.e. he is acknowledged by his own reply.

original: Katarasmiṃ adhikāre? Sake ācariyake tevijjake pāvacane. Esa kira brāhmaṇo cintesi
analyzed: katarasmin adhikāre sake ācariyake tevijjake esa kira brāhmaṇaḥ cintesi
translated: In what matter? In the matter of his own teacher’s doctrine, the three Vedas. The brahmin, it seems, thought:

original: “imasmiṃ loke ‘ahaṃ buddho, ahaṃ buddho’ti uggatassa nāmaṃ gahetvā bahū janā vicaranti.
analyzed: imasmin loke aham buddhaḥ aham buddhaḥ iti uggatassa nāmam gahetvā bahū janāḥ vicaranti
translated: “In this world many people go about claiming to be Buddhas, saying, ‘I am a Buddha, I am a Buddha.’

original: Tasmā na me anussavamatteneva upasaṅkamituṃ yuttaṃ. Ekaccañhi upasaṅkamantassa apakkamanampi
analyzed: tasmā na me anussava mattena iva upasaṅkamitum yuttam ekaccan hi upasaṅkamantassa a pakkamanam pi
translated: Therefore it is not proper for me to approach him merely on hearsay. For if I approach one, it will be difficult for me to withdraw,

original: garu hoti, anatthopi uppajjati. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ mama antevāsikaṃ pesetvā – ‘buddho vā,
analyzed: garu hoti anatthaḥ api uppajjati yat nūna aham mama antevāsikam pesetvā buddhaḥ vā
translated: and harm may arise. Suppose I send my pupil to find out whether he is a Buddha

original: no vā’ti jānitvāva upasaṅkameyya”nti, tasmā māṇavaṃ āmantetvā ayaṃ tātātiādimāha.
analyzed: na u vāti jānitvā upasaṅkameyyanti tasmai māṇavam āmantetvā ayam tāta atiādim āha
translated: or not, and then I will approach him.” So he addressed the student and said, “My dear, … ”

original: 257. Taṃ bhavantanti tassa bhoto gotamassa. Tathā santaṃ yevāti tathā satoyeva. Idhāpi hi itthambhūtākhyānatthavaseneva upayogavacanaṃ.🔽258. Yathā kathaṃ panāhaṃ, bho, tanti ettha kathaṃ panāhaṃ bho taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ
analyzed: tam bhavantam ti tassa bhoto gotamassa tathā santam tathā idha api hi itthambhūta ākhyāna ttha vasena iva upayoga vacanam  yathā katham pana aham bho tanti ettha katham pana aham bho tam bhavantam gotamam
translated: “That Master Gotama”: that Master Gotama, Bhavanto. “Being so”: being thus. Here too the word “so” is used in the sense of “being thus.”

original: jānissāmi, yathā sakkā so ñātuṃ, tathā me ācikkhāhīti attho. Yathāti vā nipātamattamevetaṃ.
analyzed: jānissāmi yathā sakkā saḥ ñātum tathā me ācikkhāhi iti atthaḥ yathā iti vā nipāta mattam eva etam
translated: “But how, Master Bharadvaja?” Here, “but how” means “how shall I know him?” The meaning is: “Explain to me how he can be known.” Or the word “yathā” is merely a particle.

original: Kathanti ayaṃ ākārapucchā. Kenākārenāhaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ jānissāmīti attho.
analyzed: katham ti ayam ākāra pucchā kena ākārena aham tam bhavantam gotamam jānissāmi iti attho
translated: “Kathaṃ” is a question about the mode. The meaning is: “By what mode shall I know that Master Gotama?”

original: Evaṃ vutte kira naṃ upajjhāyo “kiṃ tvaṃ, tāta, pathaviyaṃ ṭhito, pathaviṃ na passāmīti
analyzed: evam vutte kira nam upajjhāyo kim tvam tāta pathaviyam ṭhitaḥ pathavim na passāmi iti
translated: When this was said, it seems, his preceptor said to him: “My dear, are you like one who, standing on the earth, says, ‘I do not see the earth,’

original: viya; candimasūriyānaṃ obhāse ṭhito, candimasūriye na passāmīti viya vadasī”tiādīni
analyzed: candima sūriyānaṃ obhāse ṭhito candima sūriye na passāmi iti viya vadasi itiādīni
translated: or like one who, standing in the light of the sun and moon, says, ‘I do not see the sun and moon’? “

original: vatvā jānanākāraṃ dassento āgatāni kho, tātātiādimāha.
analyzed: vatvā jānana ākāram dassentaḥ āgatāni kho tāta ati ādim āha
translated: and so on. Then, showing him the mode of knowing, he said: “My dear, those who come here” and so on.

original: Tattha mantesūti vedesu. Tathāgato kira uppajjissatīti paṭikacceva suddhāvāsā devā🔽vedesu lakkhaṇāni pakkhipitvā buddhamantā nāmeteti brāhmaṇaveseneva vede vācenti.🔽Tadanusārena mahesakkhā sattā tathāgataṃ jānissantīti. Tena pubbe vedesu mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni
analyzed: tattha mantesu iti vedesu tathāgataḥ kira uppajjissati iti paṭikacca iva suddhāvāsāḥ devā  vedesu lakkhaṇāni pakkhipitvā buddha mantāḥ nāma ete iti brāhmaṇa vesena iva vede vācenti  tad anusārena mahesakkhāḥ sattāḥ tathāgatam jānissanti iti tena pubbe vedesu mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni
translated: Herein, in the scriptures means in the Vedas. The gods of the Pure Abodes, it seems, had already proclaimed: “The Tathāgata will arise.”

original: āgacchanti. Parinibbute pana tathāgate anukkamena antaradhāyanti. Tenetarahi natthīti.🔽Mahāpurisassāti paṇidhisamādānañāṇakaruṇādiguṇamahato purisassa. Dveyeva gatiyoti🔽dveyeva niṭṭhā. original: Tattha kiñcāpi yehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato rājā cakkavattī hoti, na teheva buddho
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api yehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgataḥ rājā cakkavattī hoti na tehi iva buddhaḥ
translated: Herein, although a Buddha is endowed with the characteristics possessed by a Wheel-Turning Monarch, he is not a Wheel-Turning Monarch.

original: hoti; jātisāmaññato pana tāniyeva tānīti vuccanti. Tena vuttaṃ – “yehi samannāgatassā”ti.🔽Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasatīti yadi agāre vasati. Rājā hoti cakkavattīti catūhi acchariyadhammehi,🔽saṅgahavatthūhi ca lokaṃ rañjanato rājā, cakkaratanaṃ vatteti, catūhi sampatticakkehi
analyzed: hoti jāti sāmaññato pana tāni yeva tāni iti vuccanti tena vuttam yehi samannāgatassa ati  sace agāram ajjhāvasati iti yadi agāre vasati rājā hoti cakkavattī iti catūhi acchariya dhammehi  saṅgaha vatthūhi ca lokam rañjanataḥ rājā cakka ratanam vatteti catūhi sampatti cakkehi
translated: Herein, although a Buddha is not a Wheel-turning Monarch in the same way that one is so by possessing the characteristics of a Wheel-turning Monarch, still he is called that by the similarity of the births, and so it is said: “by possessing which characteristics he is a Wheel-turning Monarch.”

original: vattati, tehi ca paraṃ vatteti, parahitāya ca iriyāpathacakkānaṃ vatto etasmiṃ atthīti🔽cakkavattī. Ettha ca rājāti sāmaññaṃ. Cakkavattīti visesaṃ. Dhammena caratīti dhammiko.
analyzed: vattati tehi ca param vattā iti para hitāya ca iriyāpatha cakkānam vatto etasmin atthi iti  cakkavattī ettha ca rājā ati sāmaññam cakkavattī iti visesam dhammena carati iti dhammikaḥ
translated: If he does not go forth from the home life: if he lives at home. He becomes a Wheel-turning Monarch: he is a king because he delights the world with the four kinds of good friendship as bases for association , and he turns the wheel because he moves with the four kinds of success as wheels , and he makes others move with them, and he has the turning of the wheels of deportment for the benefit of others.🔽Herein, king is a general term; Wheel-turning Monarch is a particular; he acts righteously is righteous; he acts by means of what is right, is the meaning. He is a king because he has obtained kingship righteously, thus he is a righteous king;

original: Ñāyena samena vattatīti attho. Dhammena rajjaṃ labhitvā rājā jātoti dhammarājā. Parahitadhammakaraṇena
analyzed: ñāyena samena vattati iti atthaḥ dhammena rajjam labhitvā rājā jātaḥ iti dhammarājā para hita dhamma karaṇena
translated: he is a king because he acts righteously for the benefit of others,

original: vā dhammiko. Attahitadhammakaraṇena dhammarājā. Caturantāya issaroti cāturanto, catusamuddaantāya,🔽catubbidhadīpavibhūsitāya pathaviyā issaroti attho. Ajjhattaṃ kopādipaccatthike bahiddhā🔽ca sabbarājāno vijetīti vijitāvī. Janapadatthāvariyappattoti janapade dhuvabhāvaṃ🔽thāvarabhāvaṃ patto, na sakkā kenaci cāletuṃ. Janapado vā tamhi thāvariyappatto anuyutto
analyzed: vā dhammikaḥ atta hita dhamma karaṇena dhamma rājā catur antāya issaroti cāturanto catu samudda antāya  catubbidha dīpa vibhūsitāya pathaviyā issaraḥ ti atthaḥ ajjhattam kopa ādi paccatthike bahiddhā  ca sabba rājānaḥ vijeti iti vijitāvī janapada tthau ariya ppatto ti janapade dhuva bhāvam  thāvara bhāvam pattaḥ na sakkā kenacid cāletum janapadaḥ vā tamhi thāvariya pattaḥ anuyuttaḥ
translated: or he is righteous. He is a righteous king because he acts righteously for his own benefit. He is the lord of the four continents: the four continents are the four great oceans.🔽The meaning is: he is the lord of the earth adorned with four kinds of continents. He conquers internally the enemies such as anger, and externally all kings.🔽He is a conqueror. He has attained stability in the country: he has attained stability, permanence, in the country, and no one can move him. Or the country has attained stability in him: it is devoted to him.

original: sakammanirato acalo asampavedhīti janapadatthāvariyappatto.🔽Seyyathidanti nipāto, tassa cetāni katamānīti attho. Cakkaratanantiādīsu cakkañca,🔽taṃ ratijananaṭṭhena ratanañcāti cakkaratanaṃ. Esa nayo sabbattha. Imesu pana ratanesu
analyzed: sa kamma nirataḥ acalaḥ a sampavedhī iti janapadatthāvariya ppatto  nipātaḥ tassa ca itāni katamāni iti attho cakkaratana ntiādīsu cakkam ca  tam rati janana ṭṭhena ratanam ca ati cakkaratanam esa nayo sabbattha imesu pana ratanesu
translated: or he is righteous. He is a righteous king because he acts righteously for his own benefit. He is the lord of the four continents, thus he is a “four-continent lord” . The meaning is: he is the lord of the earth adorned with four kinds of islands, the four oceans. He conquers internally the enemies such as anger, and externally all kings, thus he is a “conqueror” . He has attained stability in the country, thus he is “one who has attained stability in the country” . The meaning is: he has attained a firm state in the country, and no one can move him. Or the country has attained stability in him, it is devoted to him, it is engaged in its own work, it is unshaken, and it is undisturbed, thus he is “one who has attained stability in the country” .

original: ayaṃ cakkavattirājā cakkaratanena ajitaṃ jināti, hatthiassaratanehi vijite yathāsukhaṃ
analyzed: ayam cakkavatti rājā cakka ratanena ajitam jināti hatthi assa ratanehi vijite yathāsukham
translated: Seyyathidaṃ = “such as this.” The meaning is: what are these? In the passage beginning with “the wheel-treasure” , the wheel is also a treasure because it generates delight . The same method of explanation applies in all cases. But among these treasures, this wheel-turning king conquers what has not been conquered by means of the wheel-treasure. He enjoys what has been conquered by means of the elephant and horse treasures.

original: anucarati, pariṇāyakaratanena vijitamanurakkhati, avasesehi upabhogasukhamanubhavati.🔽Paṭhamena cassa ussāhasattiyogo, pacchimena mantasattiyogo, hatthiassagahapatiratanehi🔽pabhusattiyogo suparipuṇṇo hoti, itthimaṇiratanehi tividhasattiyogaphalaṃ. So itthimaṇiratanehi🔽bhogasukhamanubhavati, sesehi issariyasukhaṃ. Visesato cassa purimāni tīṇi adosakusalamūlajanitakammānubhāvena🔽sampajjanti, majjhimāni alobhakusalamūlajanitakammānubhāvena, pacchimamekaṃ amohakusalamūlajanitakammānubhāvenāti
analyzed: anucarati pariṇāyaka ratanena vijitam anurakkhati avasesehi upabhoga sukham anubhavati  paṭhamena ca assa ussāha satti yogo pacchimena manta satti yogo hatthi assa gahapati ratanehi  pabhu satti yogaḥ su paripuṇṇaḥ hoti itthi maṇi ratanehi tividha satti yoga phalam saḥ itthi maṇi ratanehi  bhoga sukham anubhavati sesehi issariya sukham visesataḥ cassa purimāni tīṇi adosa kusala mūla janita kamma anubhāvena  sampajjanti majjhimāni alobha kusala mūla janita kamma anubhāvena pacchimam ekam amoha kusala mūla janita kamma anubhāvena ati
translated: He enjoys the happiness of use with the rest.

original: veditabbaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana bojjhaṅgasaṃyutte ratanasuttassa upadesato gahetabbo.🔽Parosahassanti atirekasahassaṃ. Sūrāti abhīrukajātikā. Vīraṅgarūpāti devaputtasadisakāyā.
analyzed: veditabbam ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana bojjhaṅga saṃyutte ratana suttassa upadesataḥ gahetabbo 🔽atireka sahassam sūrā ati abhīruka jātikā vīraṅga rūpā ati deva putta sadisa kāyā

original: Evaṃ tāva eke vaṇṇayanti. Ayaṃ panettha sabbhāvo. Vīrāti uttamasūrā vuccanti, vīrānaṃ
analyzed: evam tāva eke vaṇṇayanti ayam pana ittha sabbhāvaḥ uttama sūrāḥ vuccanti
translated: This is how some commentators explain it. But the true explanation is as follows. They are called “heroes” because they are supreme in courage.🔽“Heroic” is “heroic-limbed” . What is meant is: “the cause of heroism, energy.”

original: aṅgaṃ vīraṅgaṃ, vīrakāraṇaṃ vīriyanti vuttaṃ hoti. Vīraṅgarūpaṃ etesanti vīraṅgarūpā,
analyzed: aṅgam vīraṅgam vīra kāraṇam vīriyanti vuttam hoti vīraṅga rūpam etesanti vīraṅga rūpā
translated: They are “endowed with heroic bodies” because they have bodies consisting of energy.

original: vīriyamayasarīrā viyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Parasenappamaddanāti sace paṭimukhaṃ tiṭṭheyya🔽parasenā taṃ parimaddituṃ samatthāti adhippāyo. Dhammenāti “pāṇo na hantabbo”tiādinā
analyzed: vīriya maya sarīrā viya iti vuttam hoti sace paṭimukham tiṭṭheyya  para senā tam parimadditum samatthā ati adhippāyaḥ dhammena ati pāṇaḥ na hantabbā uti ādinā
translated: What is meant is: “as if they were alive.” “To crush the armies of the foe”: the intention is that if it were to stand face to face with them, it would be able to crush the armies of the foe.🔽“By the Dhamma”: by the five precepts of virtue beginning with “Abstinence from killing living beings.”🔽“The Blessed One is an Accomplished One, a Fully Enlightened One, who has made known heaven and escape from the world,

original: pañcasīladhammena. Arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchadoti ettha rāgadosamohamānadiṭṭhiavijjāduccaritachadanehi
analyzed: pañca sīla dhammena araham hoti sammāsambuddhaḥ loke vivaṭṭa chado ti ettha rāga dosa moha māna diṭṭhi avijjā duccarita chadanehi
translated: having realized them by his own super-knowledge” . Herein, in the world the darkness of defilements is concealed by seven concealments, that is, by greed, hatred, delusion, conceit, false view, the underlying tendency to conceit, and wrong practice.

original: sattahi paṭicchanne kilesandhakāre loke taṃ chadanaṃ vivaṭṭetvā samantato sañjātāloko
analyzed: sattahi paṭicchanne kilesandhakāre loke tam chadanam vivaṭṭetvā samantataḥ sañjāta ālokaḥ
translated: Having removed that concealment, he stands illuminating it all around with the light of his super-knowledge,

original: hutvā ṭhitoti vivaṭṭacchado. Tattha paṭhamena padena pūjārahatā. Dutiyena tassā hetu,
analyzed: hutvā ṭhito ti vivaṭṭa chadaḥ tattha paṭhamena padena pūjā rahatā dutiyena tassā hetu
translated: thus he is “one who has removed the concealment” . Herein, by the first phrase he is worthy of offerings of the requisites of robes, etc.,

original: yasmā sammāsambuddhoti, tatiyena buddhattahetubhūtā vivaṭṭacchadatā vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: yasmai sammāsambuddhaḥ iti tatiyena buddha tta hetu bhūtā vivaṭṭacchada tā vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: and since the Fully Enlightened One is the one who has emerged from the round, the third is said to be the emergence from the round.🔽Or alternatively, “the round and the covering” is “the round and the covering” .

original: Atha vā vivaṭṭo ca vicchado cāti vivaṭṭacchado, vaṭṭarahito chadanarahito cāti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Tena arahaṃ vaṭṭābhāvena, sammāsambuddho chadanābhāvenāti evaṃ purimapadadvayasseva
analyzed: atha vā vivaṭṭaḥ ca vicchadaḥ ca ati vivaṭṭa chadaḥ vaṭṭa rahito chadana rahito ca ati vuttam  hoti tena araham vaṭṭa abhāvena sammāsambuddho chadana abhāvena ati evam purima pada dvayassa iva
translated: He is the One who has emerged from the round and the One who has emerged from the covering, is what is meant.🔽So the two terms “the round” and “the covering” are stated as the two reasons for his being the Enlightened One.

original: hetudvayaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, dutiyena vesārajjena cettha purimasiddhi, paṭhamena dutiyasiddhi,🔽tatiyacatutthehi tatiyasiddhi hoti. Purimañca dhammacakkhuṃ, dutiyaṃ buddhacakkhuṃ,
analyzed: hetu dvayam vuttam hoti dutiyena vesārajjena ca ittha purima siddhi paṭhamena dutiya siddhi  tatiya catutthehi hoti purimam ca dhammacakkhum dutiyam buddhacakkhum
translated: Herein, the first is established by the second fearlessness, and the second is established by the first,🔽and the third and fourth are established by the third. The first should be understood as establishing the eye of Dhamma, the second the eye of omniscience,

original: tatiyaṃ samantacakkhuṃ sādhetīti veditabbaṃ. Tvaṃ mantānaṃ paṭiggahetāti iminā’ssa
analyzed: tatiyam samanta cakkhum sādheti iti veditabbam tvam mantānam paṭiggaheta ati iminā assa
translated: and the third the all-seeing eye. By “You have received the mantras”

original: mantesu sūrabhāvaṃ janeti.
analyzed: mantesu sūra bhāvam jana iti
translated: he generates in him the idea that he is fragrant with mantras.

original: 259. Sopi tāya ācariyakathāya lakkhaṇesu vigatasammoho ekobhāsajāte viya buddhamante
analyzed: saḥ api tāya ācariya kathāya lakkhaṇesu vigata sammohaḥ eka ubhāsa jāte viya buddha mante
translated: And he, by that teacher’s talk, becomes free from doubt about the characteristics, and he is like one who has been born in the Buddha’s mantras.

original: sampassamāno evaṃ bhoti āha. Tassattho – ‘yathā, bho, tvaṃ vadasi, evaṃ karissāmī’ti.🔽Vaḷavārathamāruyhāti vaḷavāyuttaṃ rathaṃ abhirūhitvā. Brāhmaṇo kira yena rathena
analyzed: sampassamānaḥ evam bho ti āha tassa atthaḥ yathā bho tvam vadasi evam karissāmi iti  vaḷavā ratham āruyha ati vaḷavā yuttam ratham abhirūhitvā brāhmaṇaḥ kira yena rathena
translated: and seeing him, he said thus. Its meaning is: ‘As you say, Sir, I will do so.’🔽Having mounted the chariot yoked with oxen: having mounted the chariot yoked with oxen. The brahmin, it seems, gave him the very chariot

original: sayaṃ vicarati, tameva rathaṃ datvā māṇavaṃ pesesi. Māṇavāpi pokkharasātisseva antevāsikā.
analyzed: sayam vicarati tam eva ratham da tvā māṇavam pesesi māṇavā api pokkharasātissa iva antevāsikā
translated: by which he himself moved about. The young men were also the pupils of Pokkharasāti.

original: So kira tesaṃ – “ambaṭṭhena saddhiṃ gacchathā”ti saññaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: saḥ kira tesam ambaṭṭhena saddhim gacchatha iti saññam adāsi
translated: He, it seems, gave them the idea thus: “Go together with Ambattha.”

original: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmīti yattakaṃ sakkā hoti yānena gantuṃ, ayaṃ yānassa bhūmi nāma. Yānā paccorohitvāti ayānabhūmiṃ, dvārakoṭṭhakasamīpaṃ gantvā yānato paṭiorohitvā.
analyzed: yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi iti yattakam sakkā hoti yānena gantum ayam yānassa bhūmi nāma yānā paccorohitvā ati a yāna bhūmim dvāra koṭṭhaka samīpam gantvā yānataḥ paṭiorohitvā
translated: As far as the conveyance can go: as much as it is possible to go by conveyance, this is the ground for a conveyance. Having alighted from the conveyance: having gone to the vicinity of the gate-house, the ground for a conveyance, and having got down from the conveyance.

original: Tena kho pana samayenāti yasmiṃ samaye ambaṭṭho ārāmaṃ pāvisi. Tasmiṃ pana samaye,
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena ati yasmin samaye ambaṭṭhaḥ ārāmam pāvisi tasmin pana samaye
translated: At that time: at the time when Ambattha entered the monastery. At that time,

original: ṭhitamajjhanhikasamaye. Kasmā pana tasmiṃ samaye caṅkamantīti? Paṇītabhojanapaccayassa
analyzed: ṭhita majjhanhika samaye kasmai pana tasmin samaye caṅkamanti iti paṇīta bhojana paccayassa
translated: at the time of the middle watch. But why were they walking up and down at that time? Because of the condition of the excellent meal

original: thinamiddhassa vinodanatthaṃ, divāpadhānikā vā te. Tādisānañhi pacchābhattaṃ caṅkamitvā
analyzed: thinamiddhassa vinodana attham divāpadhānikāḥ vā te pacchābhattam caṅkamitvā
translated: For the purpose of dispelling sloth and torpor, they were either those who practice walking meditation during the day or those who practice walking meditation at night. For the minds of such monks become concentrated when they have walked up and down after the meal,

original: nhāyitvā sarīraṃ utuṃ gāhāpetvā nisajja samaṇadhammaṃ karontānaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti.
analyzed: nhāyitvā sarīram utum gāhāpetvā nisajja samaṇa dhammam karontānam cittam ekaggam hoti
translated: bathed, dried their bodies, and sat down to do their meditation.

original: Yena te bhikkhūti so kira – “kuhiṃ samaṇo gotamo”ti pariveṇato pariveṇaṃ anāgantvā🔽“pucchitvāva pavisissāmī”ti vilokento araññahatthī viya mahācaṅkame caṅkamamāne paṃsukūlike
analyzed: yena te bhikkhu iti saḥ kira kuhim samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ iti pariveṇataḥ pariveṇam an āgantvā  pucchitvā ava pavisissāmi iti vilokento arañña hatthī viya mahā caṅkame caṅkamamāne paṃsukūlike
translated: “The monks with whom the wanderer Ambattha will associate”: it seems that he did not go from monastery to monastery asking, “Where is the recluse Gotama?”

original: bhikkhū disvā tesaṃ santikaṃ agamāsi. Taṃ sandhāya yena te bhikkhūtiādi vuttaṃ. Dassanāyāti
analyzed: bhikkhū disvā tesam santikam agamāsi tam sandhāya yena te bhikkhu iti ādi vuttam dassanāya ati
translated: but, like a forest elephant, he looked about while walking up and down in the Great Monastery, and when he saw the refuse-rag- wearing monks, he approached them. This is the meaning of the words, “The monks with whom the wanderer Ambattha will associate.”

original: daṭṭhuṃ, passitukāmā hutvāti attho.🔽260. Abhiññātakolaññoti pākaṭakulajo. Tadā kira jambudīpe ambaṭṭhakulaṃ nāma pākaṭakulamahosi.
analyzed: daṭṭhum passitu kāmāḥ hutvā iti atthaḥ  abhiññāta kolañño ti pākaṭa kula jo tadā kira jambudīpe ambaṭṭha kulam nāma pākaṭa kulam ahosi
translated: “To see”: the meaning is, “being desirous of seeing, of looking.”🔽“The king’s chief counsellor, the brahmin Pokkharasati, well known and famous”: he was well known as a clansman. At that time, it seems, the Ambattha clan was well known in the Rose-Apple Island.

original: Abhiññātassāti rūpajātimantakulāpadesehi pākaṭassa. Agarūti abhāriko. Yo hi ambaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: abhiññātassa ati rūpa jātimanta kula apadesehi pākaṭassa a garu ti a bhārikaḥ yaḥ hi ambaṭṭham
translated: “Well known”: well known by his appearance, his name, and his family. “Not mean”: not stingy. For one who is mean

original: ñāpetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya, tassa tena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo garu bhaveyya. Bhagavato pana🔽tādisānaṃ māṇavānaṃ satenāpi sahassenāpi pañhaṃ puṭṭhassa vissajjane dandhāyitattaṃ
analyzed: ñāpetum na sakkuṇeyya tassa tena saddhim kathā sallāpaḥ garu bhaveyya bhagavataḥ pana  tādisānam māṇavānam satena api sahassena api pañham puṭṭhassa vissajjane dandhāyi tattam
translated: If he were unable to make them understand, then conversation with him would be difficult. But the Blessed One

original: natthīti maññamānā – “agaru kho panā”ti cintayiṃsu. Vihāroti gandhakuṭiṃ sandhāya āhaṃsu.
analyzed: natthi iti maññamānā agaru kho pana ati cintayiṃsu vihāraḥ iti gandhakuṭim sandhāya āhaṃsu
translated: has no hesitation in answering a question put by a hundred or a thousand such young men. Thinking, “It will not be difficult for him,” they thought, “Let us go to the dwelling.” By “dwelling” they meant the Fragrant Cell.

original: Ataramānoti aturito, saṇikaṃ padappamāṇaṭṭhāne padaṃ nikkhipanto vattaṃ katvā susammaṭṭhaṃ🔽muttādalasinduvārasantharasadisaṃ vālikaṃ avināsentoti attho. Āḷindanti pamukhaṃ.🔽Ukkāsitvāti ukkāsitasaddaṃ katvā. Aggaḷanti dvārakavāṭaṃ. Ākoṭehīti agganakhehi saṇikaṃ
analyzed: a taramānaḥ ti a turitaḥ saṇikam pada ppamāṇa ṭhāne padam nikkhipantaḥ vattam katvā su sammaṭṭham  muttā dala sinduvāra santhara sadisam vālikam a vināsento ti attho āḷindanti pamukham  ukkāsitvā iti ukkāsita saddam katvā aggaḷanti dvāra kavāṭam ākoṭehi iti agga nakhehi saṇikam
translated: “Without hurrying”: not hurriedly, placing the foot slowly in the place where it should be placed, acting with due consideration,🔽without destroying the sand which was like a bed of shells or a bed of moonstones. “At the door”: at the front door.🔽“After coughing”: after making a sound by coughing. “Knock”: with the tips of the fingers, slowly knock near the keyhole.

original: kuñcikacchiddasamīpe ākoṭehīti vuttaṃ hoti. Dvāraṃ kira atiupari amanussā, atiheṭṭhā
analyzed: kuñcika chidda samīpe ākoṭehi iti vuttam hoti dvāram kira ati upari amanussāḥ ati heṭṭhā
translated: This is what is meant. It seems that non-human beings are above the door and human beings below it.

original: dīghajātikā koṭenti. Tathā anākoṭetvā majjhe chiddasamīpe koṭetabbanti idaṃ dvārākoṭanavattanti dīpentā vadanti.
analyzed: dīgha jātikā koṭenti tathā an ākoṭetvā majjhe chidda samīpe koṭetabbanti idam dvāra ākoṭana vattanti dīpentāḥ vadanti

translated: “While lying down, Master Gotama, I will lie down with my teacher.”

original: sayāno sayānenācariyena saddhiṃ kathesi, kiṃ te ācariyo gorūpaṃ, udāhu tva”nti āha.🔽So kujjhitvā – “ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muṇḍakā”tiādimāha. Tattha muṇḍe muṇḍāti🔽samaṇe ca samaṇāti vattuṃ vaṭṭeyya. Ayaṃ pana hīḷento muṇḍakā samaṇakāti āha. Ibbhāti

original: gahapatikā. Kaṇhāti kaṇhā, kāḷakāti attho. Bandhupādāpaccāti ettha bandhūti brahmā

original: adhippeto. Tañhi brāhmaṇā pitāmahoti voharanti. Pādānaṃ apaccā pādāpaccā, brahmuno🔽piṭṭhipādato jātāti adhippāyo. Tassa kira ayaṃ laddhi – brāhmaṇā brahmuno mukhato
