analyzed: gahetvā gacchatha mamaccayena āgantvā rajjam kareyyātha ati aṭṭhahi amaccehi saddhim uyyojesi  te nānappakāram roditvā kanditvā tāta amhākam dosam khamatha ati rājānam ca iva rāja rodhe
translated: “Take them and go. When I am dead, come back and rule the kingdom.”🔽After weeping and lamenting in many ways, they asked the king and the royal concubines

original: ca khamāpetvā, “mayampi bhātūhi saddhiṃ gacchāmā”ti rājānaṃ āpucchitvā nagarā nikkhantā
analyzed: ca khamāpetvā mayam pi bhātūhi saddhim gacchāma iti rājānam āpucchitvā nagarā nikkhantā
translated: for forgiveness, saying, “Dear, forgive us for our faults.” After asking the king for permission to go with their brothers, they left the city.

original: bhaginiyo ādāya caturaṅginiyā senāya parivutā nagarā nikkhamiṃsu. “Kumārā pituaccayena
analyzed: bhaginiyaḥ ādāya caturaṅginiyā senāya parivutāḥ nagarā nikkhamiṃsu kumārā pitu accayena
translated: Taking their sisters with them, they left the city surrounded by an army of four divisions. “When the princes return after their father’s death,

original: āgantvā rajjaṃ kāressanti, gacchāma ne upaṭṭhahāmā”ti cintetvā bahū manussā anubandhiṃsu.
analyzed: āgantvā rajjam kāressanti gacchāma ne upaṭṭhahāma ati cintetvā bahū manussāḥ anubandhiṃsu
translated: we will go and serve them,” many people thought and followed them.

original: Paṭhamadivase yojanamattā senā ahosi, dutiye dviyojanamattā, tatiye tiyojanamattā.
analyzed: paṭhama divase yojana mattā senā ahosi dutiye dvi yojana mattā tatiye ti yojana mattā
translated: On the first day the army extended for a league, on the second for two leagues, and on the third for three leagues.

original: Kumārā mantayiṃsu – “mahā balakāyo, sace mayaṃ kañci sāmantarājānaṃ madditvā janapadaṃ
analyzed: kumārāḥ mantayiṃsu mahā balakāyaḥ sace mayam kañci sāmanta rājānam madditvā janapadam
translated: The princes discussed the matter, saying, “This is a great army. If we were to conquer some neighboring king and make him our vassal,

original: gaṇheyyāma, sopi no nappasaheyya. Kiṃ paresaṃ pīḷāya katāya, mahā ayaṃ jambudīpo,
analyzed: gaṇheyyāma saḥ upi naḥ na pasaheyya kim paresam pīḷāya katāya mahā ayam jambudīpaḥ
translated: we would not be able to support them. What is the use of oppressing others? This great island of Jambu,

original: araññe nagaraṃ māpessāmā”ti himavantābhimukhā gantvā nagaravatthuṃ pariyesiṃsu.
analyzed: araññe nagaram māpessāma ati himavanta abhimukhāḥ gantvā nagara vatthum pariyesiṃsu
translated: let us build a city in the forest.” Having said this, they went towards the Himalayas and surveyed the site for the city.

original: Tasmiñca samaye amhākaṃ bodhisatto brāhmaṇamahāsālakule nibbattitvā kapilabrāhmaṇo
analyzed: tasmin ca samaye amhākam bodhisattaḥ brāhmaṇa mahāsāla kule nibbattitvā kapila brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: At that time, our Bodhisatta was born in a great brahmin family. Having gone forth as an ascetic, he became known as Kapila the brahmin.

original: nāma hutvā nikkhamma isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā himavantapasse pokkharaṇiyā tīre sākavanasaṇḍe
analyzed: nāma hutvā nikkhamma isipabbajjam pabbajitvā himavanta passe pokkharaṇiyā tīre sāka vana saṇḍe
translated: He built a leaf-hut on the bank of a lotus pond at the foot of the Himalayas, in a thicket of sāka trees,

original: paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā vasati. So kira bhummajālaṃ nāma vijjaṃ jānāti, yāya uddhaṃ asītihatthe🔽ākāse, heṭṭhā ca bhūmiyampi guṇadosaṃ passati. Etasmiṃ padese tiṇagumbalatā dakkhiṇāvaṭṭā
analyzed: paṇṇa sālam māpetvā vasati saḥ kira bhummajālam nāma vijjam jānāti yāya uddham asīti hatthe  ākāse heṭṭhā ca bhūmiyam pi guṇa dosam passati etasmin padese tiṇa gumba latā dakkhiṇa avaṭṭā
translated: and lived there. It is said that he knew a knowledge called the “earth-net,” by which he could see the good and bad qualities of the ground above eighty leagues,🔽and below, even of the earth. In this place, the grass, shrubs, and creepers grew clockwise,

original: pācīnābhimukhā jāyanti. Sīhabyagghādayo migasūkare sappabiḷārā ca maṇḍūkamūsike anubandhamānā
analyzed: pācīna abhimukhāḥ jāyanti sīha byaggha ādayaḥ miga sūkare sappa biḷārā ca maṇḍūka mūsike anubandhamānā
translated: turning to the right, facing east. Lions, tigers, and other animals, as well as pigs, snakes, frogs, and mice, followed each other,

original: taṃ padesaṃ patvā na sakkonti te anubandhituṃ. Tehi te aññadatthu santajjitā nivattantiyeva.
analyzed: tam padesam patvā na sakkonti te anubandhitum tehi te añña datthu santajjitāḥ
translated: and they were unable to follow him. They were frightened and turned back.

original: So – “ayaṃ pathaviyā aggapadeso”ti ñatvā tattha attano paṇṇasālaṃ māpesi.
analyzed: saḥ ayam pathaviyāḥ agga padesaḥ ti ñatvā tattha attanaḥ paṇṇa sālam māpesi
translated: “This is the best place in the land,” he thought, and he had a leaf-hut built there.

original: Atha te kumāre nagaravatthuṃ pariyesamāne attano vasanokāsaṃ āgate disvā pucchitvā
analyzed: atha te kumāre nagara vatthum pariyesamāne attanaḥ vasana ukāsam āgate disvā pucchitvā
translated: Then the princes, looking for a site for a city, came to the place where the Bodhisatta was living.

original: taṃ pavattiṃ ñatvā tesu anukampaṃ janetvā avoca – “imasmiṃ paṇṇasālaṭṭhāne māpitaṃ🔽nagaraṃ jambudīpe agganagaraṃ bhavissati. Ettha jātapurisesu ekeko purisasatampi
analyzed: tam pavattim ñatvā tesu anukampam janetvā avoca imasmin paṇṇasāla ṭṭhāne māpitam  nagaram jambudīpe agga nagaram bhavissati ettha jāta purisesu ekekaḥ purisa satam pi
translated: When they had found out what had happened, they took pity on him and said, “On this site where your leaf-hut is built🔽a city will arise which will be the chief city in India. In the men born there each one will be able to overcome a hundred men,

original: purisasahassampi abhibhavituṃ sakkhissati. Ettha nagaraṃ māpetha, paṇṇasālaṭṭhāne
analyzed: purisa sahassam pi abhibhavitum sakkhissati ettha nagaram māpetha paṇṇasāla ṭṭhāne
translated: or even a thousand. Build your city here. On the site of your leaf-hut

original: rañño gharaṃ karotha. Imasmiñhi okāse ṭhatvā caṇḍālaputtopi cakkavattibalena atiseyyo”ti.
analyzed: raññaḥ gharam karotha imasmin hi okāse ṭhatvā caṇḍāla puttaḥ api cakkavatti balena atiseyyaḥ ti
translated: build the king’s palace. For standing on this spot even a caṇḍāla’s son will be superior to a universal monarch.”

original: Nanu, bhante, ayyassa vasanokāsoti? “Mama vasanokāso”ti mā cintayittha. Mayhaṃ ekapasse
analyzed: nanu bhante ayyassa vasanokāsaḥ ti mama vasanokāsaḥ ti mā cintayittha mayham ekapasse
translated: “But, Reverend Sir, is this your dwelling-place?” “Do not think that this is my dwelling-place. On one side of me

original: paṇṇasālaṃ katvā nagaraṃ māpetvā kapilavatthunti nāmaṃ karothā”ti. Te tathā katvā
analyzed: paṇṇasālam katvā nagaram māpetvā kapilavatthunti nāmam karotha ati te tathā katvā
translated: “Build a leaf-hut and found a city, and name it Kapilavatthu.” They did so,

original: tattha nivāsaṃ kappesuṃ.🔽Athāmaccā – “ime dārakā vayappattā, sace nesaṃ pitā santike bhaveyya, so āvāhavivāhaṃ🔽kareyya. Idāni pana amhākaṃ bhāro”ti cintetvā kumārehi saddhiṃ mantayiṃsu. Kumārā
analyzed: tattha nivāsam kappesuṃ  atha amaccāḥ ime dārakāḥ vaya pattā sace na isam pitā santike bhaveyya saḥ āvāha vivāham  kareyya idāni pana amhākam bhāro ti cintetvā kumārehi saddhim mantayiṃsu kumārā
translated: and settled there.

original: amhākaṃ sadisā khattiyadhītaro nāma na passāma, nāpi bhaginīnaṃ sadise khattiyakumārake,
analyzed: amhākam sadisāḥ khattiya dhītaraḥ nāma na passāma na api bhaginīnam sadise khattiya kumārake
translated: Then the ministers thought, “These boys are now grown up. If their father were alive, he would arrange their marriages. But now it is our responsibility.” They discussed the matter with the boys, who said, “We do not see any khattiya girls who are our equals. Nor do we see any khattiya boys who are the equals of our sisters.

original: asadisasaṃyoge ca no uppannā puttā mātito vā pitito vā aparisuddhā jātisambhedaṃ
analyzed: a sadisa saṃyoge ca no uppannā puttā mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ vā a parisuddhā jāti sambhedam
translated: If we were to marry with those who are not our equals, our children, whether daughters or sons, would be of mixed birth and would be looked down upon.

original: pāpuṇissanti. Tasmā mayaṃ bhaginīhiyeva saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ rocemāti. Te jātisambhedabhayena🔽jeṭṭhakabhaginiṃ mātuṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā avasesāhi saṃvāsaṃ kappesuṃ.
analyzed: pāpuṇissanti tasmai mayam bhaginīhiyā iva saddhim saṃvāsam rocema ati te jāti sambheda bhayena  jeṭṭhaka bhaginim mātu ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā avasesāhi saṃvāsam kappesuṃ
translated: Therefore we prefer to live with our sisters.” Out of fear of being of mixed birth,🔽they made the eldest sister their mother and arranged for the others to live with their brothers.

original: Tesaṃ puttehi ca dhītāhi ca vaḍḍhamānānaṃ aparena samayena jeṭṭhakabhaginiyā kuṭṭharogo
analyzed: tesam puttehi ca dhītāhi ca vaḍḍhamānānam aparena samayena jeṭṭhaka bhaginiyā kuṭṭha rogaḥ
translated: As their sons and daughters increased, after some time the eldest sister developed a skin disease.

original: udapādi, koviḷārapupphasadisāni gattāni ahesuṃ. Rājakumārā imāya saddhiṃ ekato nisajjaṭṭhānabhojanādīni
analyzed: udapādi koviḷāra puppha sadisāni gattāni ahesum rāja kumārāḥ imāya saddhim ekatas nisajja ṭṭhāna bhojana ādīni
translated: Her body became like a cluster of koviḷāra flowers. The princes thought, “This disease is contagious. Even those who sit, stand, eat, etc., with her contract this disease.”

original: karontānampi upari ayaṃ rogo saṅkamatīti cintetvā ekadivasaṃ uyyānakīḷaṃ gacchantā🔽viya taṃ yāne āropetvā araññaṃ pavisitvā bhūmiyaṃ pokkharaṇiṃ khaṇāpetvā tattha khādanīyabhojanīyena
analyzed: upari ayam rogaḥ saṅkamati iti cintetvā eka divasam uyyāna kīḷam gacchantā  viya tam yāne āropetvā araññam pavisitvā bhūmiyam pokkharaṇim khaṇāpetvā tattha khādanīya bhojanīyena
translated: One day, as they were going to the pleasure garden,🔽they placed her on a vehicle, took her to the forest, had a pond dug in the ground, placed her in it together with food and drink,

original: saddhiṃ taṃ pakkhipitvā gharasaṅkhepena upari padaraṃ paṭicchādetvā paṃsuṃ datvā pakkamiṃsu.
analyzed: saddhim tam pakkhipitvā ghara saṅkhepena upari padaram paṭicchādetvā paṃsum datvā pakkamiṃsu
translated: covered it with a roof, and left, having filled it in with earth.

original: Tena ca samayena rāmo nāma bārāṇasirājā kuṭṭharogo nāṭakitthīhi ca orodhehi ca jigucchiyamāno
analyzed: tena ca samayena rāmaḥ nāma bārāṇasi rājā kuṭṭha rogaḥ nāṭakitthīhi ca orodhehi ca jigucchiyamānaḥ
translated: At that time, there was a king of Bārāṇasī named Rāma. He was suffering from leprosy and was disgusted with the dancing girls and the eunuchs.

original: tena saṃvegena jeṭṭhaputtassa rajjaṃ datvā araññaṃ pavisitvā tattha paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā
analyzed: tena saṃvegena jeṭṭha puttassa rajjam da tvā araññam pavisitvā tattha paṇṇa sālam māpetvā
translated: Out of disgust, he gave the kingdom to his eldest son, entered the forest, had a leaf hut built,

original: mūlaphalāni paribhuñjanto nacirasseva arogo suvaṇṇavaṇṇo hutvā ito cito ca vicaranto
analyzed: mūla phalāni paribhuñjantaḥ nacirassa iva arogaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ hutvā itas citas ca vicarantaḥ
translated: and, eating roots and fruits, soon became healthy and golden-colored. Wandering here and there,

original: mahantaṃ susirarukkhaṃ disvā tassabbhantare soḷasahatthappamāṇaṃ okāsaṃ sodhetvā
analyzed: mahantam susira rukkham disvā tassa abbhantare soḷasa hattha ppamāṇam okāsam sodhetvā
translated: He saw a large hollow tree, cleared out the inside to a space sixteen cubits long,

original: dvārañca vātapānañca yojetvā nisseṇiṃ bandhitvā tattha vāsaṃ kappesi. So aṅgārakaṭāhe
analyzed: dvāram ca vāta pānañca yojetvā nisseṇim bandhitvā tattha vāsam kappesi saḥ aṅgāra kaṭāhe
translated: made a door and a window, fastened a ladder to it, and made his home there. He kept a fire burning in a charcoal pan,

original: aggiṃ katvā rattiṃ migasūkarādīnaṃ sadde suṇanto sayati. So – “asukasmiṃ padese sīho🔽saddamakāsi, asukasmiṃ byaggho”ti sallakkhetvā pabhāte tattha gantvā vighāsamaṃsaṃ
analyzed: aggim katvā rattim miga sūkara ādīnam sadde suṇantaḥ sayati saḥ asukasmin padese sīhaḥ  asukasmin byaggho ti sallakkhetvā pabhāte tattha gantvā vighāsa maṃsam
translated: and slept at night listening to the cries of deer, wild boars, and so on. He could tell by the cries where each animal was,

original: ādāya pacitvā khādati.🔽Athekadivasaṃ tasmiṃ paccūsasamaye aggiṃ jāletvā nisinne rājadhītāya sarīragandhena
analyzed: ādāya pacitvā khādati  atha eka divasam tasmin paccūsa samaye aggim jāletvā nisinne rāja dhītāya sarīra gandhena
translated: and in the morning he went there and got the entrails and flesh, cooked them, and ate them.

original: āgantvā byaggho tasmiṃ padese paṃsuṃ viyūhanto padare vivaramakāsi, tena ca vivarena
analyzed: āgantvā byagghaḥ tasmin padese paṃsum viyūhantaḥ padare vivaram akāsi tena ca vivarena
translated: One day, as he was sitting there keeping the fire burning at dawn, a tigress came there, and as she was scratching the ground with her paw, she opened up a crevice in the earth with her paw.

original: sā byagghaṃ disvā bhītā vissaramakāsi. So taṃ saddaṃ sutvā – “itthisaddo eso”ti ca
analyzed: sā byaggham disvā bhītā vissaram akāsi saḥ tam saddam sutvā itthi saddo esaḥ iti ca
translated: The tigress saw the man and was frightened. She gave a loud cry. He heard the cry and thought, “That was a woman’s cry.”

original: sallakkhetvā pātova tattha gantvā – “ko etthā”ti āha. Mātugāmo sāmīti. Kiṃ jātikāsīti?
analyzed: sallakkhetvā pātova tattha gantvā kaḥ ettha ati āha mātugāmo sāmī iti kim jātikā asi iti
translated: He went there in the morning and asked, “Who is there?” “A woman, my lord.” “What kind of woman?”

original: Okkākamahārājassa dhītā sāmīti. Nikkhamāti? Na sakkā sāmīti. Kiṃ kāraṇāti? Chavirogo
analyzed: okkāka mahārājassa dhītā sāmi iti nikkhamāti na sakkā sāmi iti kim kāraṇā ati chavi rogaḥ
translated: “The daughter of the great king Okkāka is my wife.” “Is she out?” “She cannot come out.” “What is the reason?” “I have a disease of the head.”

original: me atthīti. So sabbaṃ pavattiṃ pucchitvā khattiyamānena anikkhamantiṃ – “ahampi khattiyo”ti
analyzed: me atthi iti saḥ sabbam pavattim pucchitvā khattiya mānena a nikkhamantim  aham pi khattiyaḥ ti
translated: He asked the whole story, and when he found that she would not come out because she was a Khattiya, he said, “I too am a Khattiya.”

original: attano khattiyabhāvaṃ jānāpetvā nisseṇiṃ datvā uddharitvā attano vasanokāsaṃ netvā🔽sayaṃ paribhuttabhesajjāniyeva datvā nacirasseva arogaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ katvā tāya
analyzed: attanaḥ khattiya bhāvam jānāpetvā nisseṇim datvā uddharitvā attanaḥ vasana ukāsam netvā  sayam da tvā nacirassa iva arogam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam katvā tāya
translated: And he showed her his Khattiya status, gave her a litter, had her carried out, took her to his own dwelling,

original: saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappesi. Sā paṭhamasaṃvāseneva gabbhaṃ gaṇhitvā dve putte vijāyi,
analyzed: saddhim saṃvāsam kappesi sā paṭhama saṃvāsena iva gabbham gaṇhitvā dve putte vijāyi
translated: and gave her his own medicines. In a short time he made her well and fair of complexion, and he lived with her. She conceived at the first intercourse, and gave birth to two sons.🔽Again she conceived, and again gave birth to twins. Thus she gave birth to sixteen sets of twins.

original: punapi dveti, evaṃ soḷasakkhattumpi vijāyi. Evaṃ dvattiṃsa bhātaro ahesuṃ. Te anupubbena
analyzed: puna api dve iti evam soḷasa khattum pi evam dvattiṃsa bhātaraḥ ahesum te anupubbena
translated: Thus there were thirty-two brothers. As they grew up,

original: vuḍḍhippatte pitā sabbasippāni sikkhāpesi.
analyzed: vuḍḍhi patte pitā sabba sippāni sikkhāpesi
translated: their father taught them all the arts.

original: Athekadivasaṃ eko rāmarañño nagaravāsī vanacarako pabbate ratanāni gavesanto rājānaṃ
analyzed: atha eka divasam ekaḥ rāmaraññaḥ nagara vāsī vana carakaḥ pabbate ratanāni gavesantaḥ rājānam
translated: One day a forester who lived in the city of the king of the Rājas, while searching for gems in the mountains, saw the king.

original: disvā sañjānitvā āha – “jānāmahaṃ, deva, tumhe”ti. Tato naṃ rājā sabbaṃ pavattiṃ
analyzed: disvā sañjānitvā āha jānāmaham deva tumhā iti tatas nam rājā sabbam pavattim
translated: When he saw them he recognized them, and said, “I know you, your majesty.” Then the king asked him the whole story.

original: pucchi. Tasmiṃyeva ca khaṇe te dārakā āgamiṃsu. So te disvā – “ke ime”ti āha. “Puttā🔽me”ti ca vutte tesaṃ mātikavaṃsaṃ pucchitvā – “laddhaṃ dāni me pābhata”nti nagaraṃ
analyzed: pucchi tasmiṃyā iva ca khaṇe te dārakāḥ āgamiṃsu saḥ te disvā ke ime iti āha puttā  mā iti ca vutte tesam mātika vaṃsam pucchitvā laddham dāni me pābhatanti nagaram
translated: At that very moment the boys came. When he saw them he asked, “Who are they?” “They are my sons.”🔽When he had asked about their genealogy, he said, “Now I have obtained my inheritance.” He went to the city

original: gantvā rañño ārocesi. So ‘pitaraṃ ānayissāmī’ti caturaṅginiyā senāya tattha gantvā🔽pitaraṃ vanditvā – “rajjaṃ, deva, sampaṭicchā”ti yāci. So – “alaṃ, tāta, na tattha
analyzed: gantvā raññaḥ ārocesi saḥ pitaram ānayissāmi iti caturaṅginiyā senāya tattha gantvā  pitaram vanditvā rajjam deva sampaṭiccha ati yāci saḥ alam tāta na tattha
translated: and announced to the king. The king said, “I will bring my father.” He went there with a fourfold army,

original: gacchāmi, idheva me imaṃ rukkhaṃ apanetvā nagaraṃ māpehī”ti āha. So tathā katvā tassa
analyzed: gacchāmi idha iva me imam rukkham apanetvā nagaram mā apehi iti āha saḥ tathā katvā tassa
translated: and after paying homage to his father, he asked him, “Your majesty, accept the kingdom.” “Enough, my son, I will not go there. Have this tree removed right here and build a city.” He did so.

original: nagarassa kolarukkhaṃ apanetvā katattā kolanagaranti ca byagghapathe katattā byagghapathanti
analyzed: nagarassa kola rukkham apanetvā katattā ca byaggha pathe katattā byaggha pathanti
translated: After removing the Kolar tree of that city, he gave it two names, Kolar City because it was made by removing the Kolar tree, and Byagghapabbata because it was made by Byagghapabbata.

original: cāti dve nāmāni āropetvā pitaraṃ vanditvā attano nagaraṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: ca ati dve nāmāni āropetvā pitaram vanditvā nagaram agamāsi
translated: After paying homage to his father, he went to his own city.

original: Tato vayappatte kumāre mātā āha – “tātā, tumhākaṃ kapilavatthuvāsino sakyā mātulā
analyzed: tatas vaya ppatte kumāre mātā āha tātā tumhākam kapilavatthu vāsinaḥ sakyāḥ mātulā
translated: When the boys had grown up, their mother said to them, “Dears, you have Sakyan uncles living at Kapilavatthu.

original: santi. Mātuladhītānaṃ pana vo evarūpaṃ nāma kesaggahaṇaṃ hoti, evarūpaṃ dussagahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: santi mātula dhītānam pana vaḥ evarūpam nāma kesa ggahaṇam hoti evarūpam dussa gahaṇam
translated: But the Sakyan girls have their hair done in such and such a style and wear such and such clothes.

original: Yadā tā nhānatitthaṃ āgacchanti, tadā gantvā yassa yā ruccati, so taṃ gaṇhatū”ti.
analyzed: yadā tāḥ nhāna tittham āgacchanti tadā gantvā yassa yā ruccati saḥ tam gaṇhatu uti
translated: When they come to the bathing place, go there and let each of you take the one he likes.”

original: Te tatheva gantvā tāsu nhatvā sīsaṃ sukkhāpayamānāsu yaṃ yaṃ icchiṃsu, taṃ taṃ gahetvā
analyzed: te tathā iva gantvā tāsu nhatvā sīsam sukkhāpayamānāsu yam yam icchiṃsu tam tam gahetvā
translated: They did so, and when the girls had bathed and were drying their hair, they took each the one he liked,

original: nāmaṃ sāvetvā agamiṃsu. Sakyarājāno sutvā “hotu, bhaṇe, amhākaṃ ñātakā eva te”ti
analyzed: nāmam sā avetvā agamiṃsu sakya rājānaḥ sutvā hotu bhaṇe amhākam ñātakāḥ eva te iti
translated: and after telling their names, they returned. When the Sakyan princes heard about it, they said, “Well then, they are our relatives.”

original: tuṇhī ahesuṃ. Ayaṃ sakyakoliyānaṃ uppatti. Evaṃ tesaṃ sakyakoliyānaṃ aññamaññaṃ āvāhavivāhaṃ🔽karontānaṃ yāva buddhakālā anupacchinnova vaṃso āgato. Tattha bhagavā sakyavaṃsaṃ
analyzed: tuṇhī ahesuṃ sakya koliyānam uppatti evam tesam sakya koliyānam aññamaññam āvāha vivāham  yāva buddha kālāḥ anupacchinnaḥ uva vaṃsaḥ āgataḥ tattha bhagavā sakya vaṃsam
translated: So they kept quiet. This is how the Sakyans and the Koliyas came into existence. Thus the line of the Sakyans and the Koliyas, who intermarried,🔽continued unbroken down to the time of the Buddha. There the Blessed One said, “They were banished from the kingdom and settled on the bank of a lotus pond on the slopes of the Himalayas,”

original: dassetuṃ – “te raṭṭhasmā pabbājitā himavantapasse pokkharaṇiyā tīre”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: dassetum te raṭṭhasmā pabbājitāḥ himavanta passe pokkharaṇiyā tīre ti ādim āha tattha
translated: in order to show the line of the Sakyans.

original: sammantīti vasanti. Sakyā vata bhoti raṭṭhasmā pabbājitā araññe vasantāpi jātisambhedamakatvā🔽kulavaṃsaṃ anurakkhituṃ sakyā, samatthā, paṭibalāti attho. Tadaggeti taṃ aggaṃ katvā,
analyzed: vasanti sakyāḥ vata bhoti raṭṭhasmā pabbājitāḥ araññe vasantā api jāti sambhedam a katvā  kula vaṃsam anurakkhitum sakyā samatthā paṭibalā ati tad aggā iti tam aggam katvā
translated: “They live” means they dwell. “They are able to preserve the clan lineage” means they are able, they are capable, they are powerful, without breaking the clan lineage.🔽“Having made him their chief” means having made him their head.🔽“From that time on” means from that time.

original: tato paṭṭhāyāti attho. So ca nesaṃ pubbapurisoti so okkāko rājā etesaṃ pubbapuriso.
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya ati attho so ca nesam pubba puriso ti so okkākaḥ rājā etesam pubba puriso
translated: “And he was their ancestor” means that king Okkāka was their ancestor.

original: Natthi etesaṃ gahapativaṃsena sambhedamattampīti.
analyzed: natthi etesam gahapati vaṃsena sambheda mattam pi iti
translated: “There is not even a breach in their clan lineage.”

original: Evaṃ sakyavaṃsaṃ pakāsetvā idāni ambaṭṭhavaṃsaṃ pakāsento – “rañño kho panā”tiādimāha.🔽Kaṇhaṃ nāma janesīti kāḷavaṇṇaṃ antokucchiyaṃyeva sañjātadantaṃ parūḷhamassudāṭhikaṃ
analyzed: evam sakya vaṃsam pakāsetvā idāni ambaṭṭha vaṃsam pakāsentaḥ raññaḥ kho pana iti ādim āha  kaṇham nāma janesi iti kāḷavaṇṇam sañjāta dantam parūḍha massu dāṭhikam
translated: Having thus shown the lineage of the Sakyans, he now shows the lineage of Ambattha, saying “But the king,” etc.🔽“He begot a son named Kaṇha” means he gave birth to a son who was black in color, who had teeth, bone, and gums that had already grown inside the womb.

original: puttaṃ vijāyi. Pabyāhāsīti yakkho jātoti bhayena palāyitvā dvāraṃ pidhāya ṭhitesu
analyzed: puttam vijāyi pabyāhāsi iti yakkhaḥ jātaḥ ti bhayena palāyitvā dvāram pidhāya ṭhitesu
translated: “He cried out” means that because of the fear that “a demon has been born,” the householders who had closed the door and stood there,

original: gharamānusakesu ito cito ca vicaranto dhovatha mantiādīni vadanto uccāsaddamakāsi.
analyzed: ghara mānusakesu itas citas ca vicarantaḥ dhovatha manti ādīni vadantaḥ
translated: wandering here and there, made a loud noise, saying “Wash it! Take it away!” and so on.

original: 268. Te māṇavakā bhagavantaṃ etadavocunti attano upārambhamocanatthāya – “etaṃ mā
analyzed: te māṇavakāḥ bhagavantam etat avocunti attanaḥ upārambha mocana thāya etam mā
translated: The young men said to the Blessed One: in order to get out of their own predicament.

original: bhava”ntiādivacanaṃ avocuṃ. Tesaṃ kira etadahosi – “ambaṭṭho amhākaṃ ācariyassa jeṭṭhantevāsī,🔽sace mayaṃ evarūpe ṭhāne ekadvevacanamattampi na vakkhāma, ayaṃ no ācariyassa santike
analyzed: bhavanti ādi vacanam avocum tesam kira etat ahosi ambaṭṭhaḥ amhākam ācariyassa jeṭṭha antevāsī  sace mayam evarūpe ṭhāne eka dvevacana mattam pi na vakkhāma ayam no ācariyassa santike
translated: 268. The brahmin students said to the Blessed One: they said this in order to avoid a rebuke, thinking: “Ambattha is a pupil of our teacher’s teacher.

original: amhe paribhindissatī”ti upārambhamocanatthaṃ evaṃ avocuṃ. Cittena panassa nimmadabhāvaṃ
analyzed: amhe paribhindissati iti upārambha mocana attham evam avocum cittena panassa nimmada bhāvam
translated: If we do not say something here, he will rebuke us in the presence of our teacher.” They said this in order to avoid a rebuke. But they were anxious to find out whether he was really as stupid as he looked.

original: ākaṅkhanti. Ayaṃ kira mānanissitattā tesampi appiyova. Kalyāṇavākkaraṇoti madhuravacano.
analyzed: ākaṅkhanti ayam kira māna nissita ttā tesam pi appiyaḥ uva madhura vacanaḥ
translated: He was unpopular with them because he was so conceited. He was a good speaker: he had a sweet voice.

original: Asmiṃ vacaneti attanā uggahite vedattayavacane. Paṭimantetunti pucchitaṃ pañhaṃ paṭikathetuṃ,
analyzed: asmim vacane iti attanā uggahite vedattaya vacane paṭimantetum ti pucchitam pañham paṭikathetum
translated: In this matter: in the three Vedas that he had learnt. To recite: to answer a question,

original: vissajjetunti attho. Etasmiṃ vā dāsiputtavacane. Paṭimantetunti uttaraṃ kathetuṃ.
analyzed: vissajjetunti attho etasmim vā dāsi putta vacane paṭimantetun ti uttaram kathetum
translated: to give a reply, is the meaning. Or in this matter of the son of a slave-girl: to recite is to give an answer.

original: 269. Atha kho bhagavāti atha kho bhagavā – “sace ime māṇavakā ettha nisinnā evaṃ
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavān ati atha khalu bhagavān sace ime māṇavakāḥ ettha nisinnāḥ evam
translated: Then the Blessed One: then the Blessed One, thinking: “If these brahmin students sit here and

original: uccāsaddaṃ karissanti, ayaṃ kathā pariyosānaṃ na gamissati. Handa, ne nissadde katvā🔽ambaṭṭheneva saddhiṃ kathemī”ti te māṇavake etadavoca. Tattha mantavhoti mantayatha.
analyzed: uccāsaddam karissanti ayam kathā pariyosānam na gamissati handa ne nissadde katvā  ambaṭṭhena iva saddhim kathemi iti te māṇavake etat avoca tattha mantavha iti mantayatha
translated: “They will make a great noise, and the discussion will not come to an end. Let me send them away and🔽discuss the matter with Ambattha alone.” And he said to the young men, “Think it over,🔽gentlemen.🔽Discuss the matter with me.”

original: Mayā saddhiṃ paṭimantetūti mayā saha kathetu. Evaṃ vutte māṇavakā cintayiṃsu – “ambaṭṭho
analyzed: mayā saddhim paṭimantetu uti mayā saha kathetu evam vutte māṇavakāḥ cintayiṃsu ambaṭṭhaḥ
translated: When this had been said, the young men thought, “When Ambattha was told,

original: tāva dāsiputtosīti vutte puna sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ nāsakkhi. Ayaṃ kho jāti nāma dujjānā,
analyzed: tāva dāsi puttā asi iti vutte puna sīsam ukkhipitum na asakkhi ayam kho jāti nāma dujjānā
translated: ‘You are a slave-born son of a slave-born woman,’ he could not raise his head again. This business of birth is a difficult matter.

original: sace aññampi kiñci samaṇo gotamo ‘tvaṃ dāso’ti vakkhati, ko tena saddhiṃ aḍḍaṃ karissati.
analyzed: sace aññam pi kiñci samaṇaḥ gotamo tvam dāso ti vakkhati kaḥ tena saddhim aḍḍam karissati
translated: If the recluse Gotama says anything else about him, ‘You are a slave,’ who will take his part?

original: Ambaṭṭho attanā baddhaṃ puṭakaṃ attanāva mocetū”ti attānaṃ parimocetvā tasseva upari
analyzed: ambaṭṭhaḥ attanā baddham puṭakam attanā ava mocetu uti attānam parimocetvā tassa iva upari
translated: Let Ambattha untie the knot he has tied himself.” And they let him go,

original: khipantā – “sujāto ca bho gotamā”tiādimāhaṃsu.
analyzed: khipantā sujāto ca bho gotama atiādim āhaṃsu
translated: and throwing the blame on him, they said, “The Gotama is well born on both sides, of pure maternal and paternal descent seven generations back, unassailable and impeccable with respect to birth.”

original: 270. Sahadhammikoti sahetuko sakāraṇo. Akāmā byākātabboti attanā anicchantenapi byākaritabbo,
analyzed: sahadhammiko ti sa hetuko sa kāraṇo akāmā byākātabbo ti attanā an icchantena api byākaritabbo
translated: “With reason” means “with cause,” “with ground.” “He must be declared unwillingly” means “he must be declared even though he does not wish it.”

original: avassaṃ vissajjetabboti attho. Aññena vā aññaṃ paṭicarissasīti aññena vacanena aññaṃ🔽vacanaṃ paṭicarissasi ajjhottharissasi, paṭicchādessasīti attho. Yo hi “kiṃ gotto🔽tva”nti evaṃ puṭṭho – “ahaṃ tayo vede jānāmī”tiādīni vadati, ayaṃ aññena aññaṃ paṭicarati
analyzed: avassam vissajjetabbaḥ iti atthaḥ aññena vā aññam paṭicarissasi iti aññena vacanena aññam  vacanam paṭicarissasi ajjhottharissasi paṭicchādessasi iti atthaḥ yaḥ hi kim gotto  evam puṭṭhaḥ aham tayaḥ vede jānāmi iti ādīni vadati ayam aññena aññam paṭicarati
translated: The meaning is: he should not be allowed to go away. Or else: you will evade the question by another, i.e. you will evade the question by another statement, you will cover it up, is the meaning. For when one asked “What is your family?” replies “I know the three Vedas,” etc., he is said to evade the question by another.

original: nāma. Pakkamissasi vāti pucchitaṃ pañhaṃ jānantova akathetukāmatāya uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamissasi vā.
analyzed: nāma pakkamissasi vā ati pucchitam pañham jānantaḥ iva a kathetu kāma tāya uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkamissasi vā
translated: You will go away, i.e. you will get up from your seat and go away, though knowing the answer to the question asked, because you do not want to speak.

original: Tuṇhī ahosīti samaṇo gotamo maṃ sāmaṃyeva dāsiputtabhāvaṃ kathāpetukāmo, sāmaṃ kathite
analyzed: tuṇhī ahosi iti samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ mam sāmaṃyā iva dāsi putta bhāvam kathā petu kāmaḥ sāmam kathite
translated: You will remain silent, i.e. the ascetic Gotama wants to have me declared a son of a slave woman by myself. When it is declared by myself,

original: ca dāso nāma jātoyeva hoti. Ayaṃ pana dvatikkhattuṃ codetvā tuṇhī bhavissati, tato
analyzed: ca dāsaḥ nāma jātaḥ yā iva hoti ayam pana dvatikkhattum codetvā tuṇhī bhavissati tatas
translated: I will be a slave. But he will remain silent after admonishing me twice. Then

original: ahaṃ parivattitvā pakkamissāmīti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: aham parivattitvā pakkamissāmi iti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi
translated: I will turn around and go away. Thinking thus, he remained silent.

original: 271. Vajiraṃ pāṇimhi assāti vajirapāṇi. Yakkhoti na yo vā so vā yakkho, sakko devarājāti
analyzed: vajiram pāṇimhi assa ati vajira pāṇi yakkho iti na yaḥ vā saḥ vā yakkho sakkaḥ deva rājā ati
translated: Vajirapāṇi means “having a thunderbolt in the hand.” Yakkha does not mean any yakkha, but Sakka, the king of the gods.

original: veditabbo. Ādittanti aggivaṇṇaṃ. Sampajjalitanti suṭṭhu pajjalitaṃ. Sajotibhūtanti
analyzed: veditabbo ādittanti aggi vaṇṇam sampajjalitanti suṭṭhu pajjalitam sajoti bhūtanti
translated: Well ablaze: well ablaze all round.🔽The meaning is: become a single mass of flames.

original: samantato jotibhūtaṃ, ekaggijālabhūtanti attho. Ṭhito hotīti mahantaṃ sīsaṃ, kandalamakuḷasadisā
analyzed: samantataḥ joti bhūtam ekaggi jāla bhūtanti attho ṭhitaḥ hoti iti mahantam sīsam kandala makuḷa sadisā
translated: Standing: having had made a huge head, and fearful tusks like the bulb of a kadali plant,

original: dāṭhā bhayānakāni akkhināsādīni evaṃ virūparūpaṃ māpetvā ṭhito.🔽Kasmā panesa āgatoti? Diṭṭhivissajjāpanatthaṃ. Api ca – “ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ
analyzed: dāṭhā bhayānakāni akkhi nāsā ādīni evam virūpa rūpam māpetvā ṭhitaḥ  kasmā pana esa āgataḥ ti diṭṭhi vissajjāpana attham api ca aham ca iva kho pana dhammam
translated: and fearful eyes, nose, etc., in such a way that it was a hideous form.🔽But why did he come?🔽In order to make the view clear.

original: deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyu”nti evaṃ dhammadesanāya appossukkabhāvaṃ āpanne
analyzed: deseyyam pare ca me naḥ ājāneyyun ti evam dhamma desanāya appossukka bhāvam āpanne
translated: Moreover, when the Exalted One had become disinclined to teach the Dhamma, thinking, “If I were to teach the Dhamma, others would not understand me,”

original: bhagavati sakko mahābrahmunā saddhiṃ āgantvā – “bhagavā dhammaṃ desetha, tumhākaṃ
analyzed: bhagavati sakkaḥ mahābrahmunā saddhim āgantvā bhagavā dhammam desetha tumhākam
translated: Sakka, together with the Great Brahma, came and said, “Let the Exalted One teach the Dhamma.

original: āṇāya avattamāne mayaṃ vattāpessāma, tumhākaṃ dhammacakkaṃ hotu, amhākaṃ āṇācakka”nti
analyzed: āṇāya a vattamāne mayam vattāpessāma tumhākam dhamma cakkam hotu amhākam āṇācakkam ti
translated: We will proclaim it at your command. Let the wheel of the Dhamma be yours; let the wheel of authority be ours.”

original: paṭiññaṃ akāsi. Tasmā – “ajja ambaṭṭhaṃ tāsetvā pañhaṃ vissajjāpessāmī”ti āgato.
analyzed: paṭiññam akāsi tasmai ajja ambaṭṭham tāsetvā pañham vissajjāpessāmi iti āgataḥ
translated: Thus he made a promise. Therefore he came, thinking, “Today I will make Ambattha clear the view and then answer his question.”

original: Bhagavā ceva passati ambaṭṭho cāti yadi hi taṃ aññepi passeyyuṃ, taṃ kāraṇaṃ agaru🔽assa, “ayaṃ samaṇo gotamo ambaṭṭhaṃ attano vāde anotarantaṃ ñatvā yakkhaṃ āvāhetvā
analyzed: bhagavā ca iva passati ambaṭṭhaḥ ca ati yadi hi tam aññe pi passeyyum tam kāraṇam agaru  assa ayam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ambaṭṭham attanaḥ vāde anotarantam ñatvā yakkham āvāhetvā
translated: The Blessed One and Ambattha saw it. If others had seen it, the reason would not have been concealed.🔽If the Blessed One had known that Ambattha would not be able to answer him, he would have summoned a yakkha and shown him to Ambattha.

original: dassesi, tato ambaṭṭho bhayena kathesī”ti vadeyyuṃ. Tasmā bhagavā ceva passati ambaṭṭho
analyzed: dassesi tatas ambaṭṭhaḥ bhayena kathesi iti vadeyyum tasmā bhagavā ca iva passati ambaṭṭho
translated: Then Ambattha would have told the story out of fear. Therefore the Blessed One and Ambattha saw it.

original: ca. Tassa taṃ disvāva sakalasarīrato sedā mucciṃsu. Antokucchi viparivattamānā mahāravaṃ
analyzed: ca tassa tam sakala sarīrataḥ sedāḥ antokucchi viparivattamānāḥ mahā ravam
translated: When he saw it, sweat broke out all over his body. Rolling about in his stomach, it made a great noise.

original: viravi. So “aññepi nu kho passantī”ti olokento kassaci lomahaṃsamattampi nāddasa.🔽Tato – “idaṃ bhayaṃ mameva uppannaṃ, sacāhaṃ yakkhoti vakkhāmi, ‘kiṃ tavameva akkhīni
analyzed: viravi so aññe pi nu kho passanti iti olokento kassaci lomahaṃsa mattam pi na addasa  tatas idam bhayam mama eva uppannam sacā aham yakkho ti vakkhāmi kim
translated: Looking around to see if anyone else saw it, he did not see anyone else’s hair standing on end.

original: atthi, tvameva yakkhaṃ passasi, paṭhamaṃ yakkhaṃ adisvā samaṇena gotamena vādasaṅghaṭṭe
analyzed: atthi tvam eva yakkham passasi paṭhamam yakkham a disvā samaṇena gotamena vāda saṅghaṭṭe
translated: Then he thought, “This fear has arisen for me alone. If I say ‘yakkha,’ they will say, ‘Why do you alone see it? You alone see the yakkha. Before seeing the yakkha, you were defeated by the ascetic Gotama in the debate.

original: pakkhittova yakkhaṃ passasī’ti vadeyyu”nti cintetvā “na dāni me idha aññaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ
analyzed: pakkhittaḥ iva yakkham passasi iti vadeyyun ti cintetvā na dāni me idha aññam paṭisaraṇam
translated: You see the yakkha after you have been defeated.’ I have no other recourse here.

original: atthi, aññatra samaṇā gotamā”ti maññamāno atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo…pe… bhagavantaṃ etadavoca.
analyzed: atthi aññatra samaṇāḥ gotamā iti maññamānaḥ atha kho ambaṭṭhaḥ māṇavope bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side🔽and said: “Master Gotama, I am seeking refuge in Master Gotama, the Dhamma, and the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: 272. Tāṇaṃ gavesīti tāṇaṃ gavesamāno. Leṇaṃ gavesīti leṇaṃ gavesamāno. Saraṇaṃ gavesīti🔽saraṇaṃ gavesamāno. Ettha ca tāyati rakkhatīti tāṇaṃ. Nilīyanti etthāti leṇaṃ. Saratīti
analyzed: tāṇam gavesīti tāṇam gavesamānaḥ leṇam gavesīti leṇam gavesamānaḥ saraṇam gavesīti  saraṇam gavesamāno ettha ca tāyati rakkhati iti tāṇam nilīyanti ettha ati leṇam sarati iti
translated: I would receive the going forth under Master Gotama, I would receive the full admission.”🔽“Ambattha, one who was formerly of another sect and desires the going forth and the full admission in this Dhamma and Discipline lives on probation for four months.

original: saraṇaṃ, bhayaṃ hiṃsati, viddhaṃsetīti attho. Upanisīditvāti upagamma heṭṭhāsane
analyzed: saraṇam bhayam hiṃsati viddhaṃseti iti atthaḥ upanisīditvā ati upagamma heṭṭhāsane
translated: At the end of four months, if the bhikkhus are satisfied with him, they give him the going forth and the full admission to the bhikkhus’ state.

original: nisīditvā. Bravitūti vadatu.
analyzed: nisīditvā bravitu uti vadatu
translated: But I will give you the going forth right now.”

original: Ambaṭṭhavaṃsakathā
analyzed: ambaṭṭha vaṃsa kathā
translated: The Discussion of the Ambattha Family

original: 273-274. Dakkhiṇajanapadanti dakkhiṇāpathoti pākaṭaṃ. Gaṅgāya dakkhiṇato pākaṭajanapadaṃ.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa janapadanti dakkhiṇāpathā iti pākaṭam gaṅgāya dakkhiṇatas pākaṭa janapadam
translated: The Southern Region: the country south of the Ganges is well known as the Southern Region.

original: Tadā kira dakkhiṇāpathe bahū brāhmaṇatāpasā honti, so tattha gantvā ekaṃ tāpasaṃ
analyzed: tadā kira dakkhiṇāpathe bahū brāhmaṇa tāpasāḥ honti saḥ tattha gantvā ekam tāpasam
translated: At that time there were many brahmin ascetics in the Southern Region. He went there and pleased one of the ascetics

original: vattapaṭipattiyā ārādhesi. So tassa upakāraṃ disvā āha – “ambho, purisa, mantaṃ te
analyzed: vatta paṭipattiyā ārādhesi saḥ tassa upakāram disvā āha ambho purisa mantam te
translated: with his conduct. The ascetic, seeing that he was helpful, said: “My dear, I will teach you🔽the mantras.

analyzed: catu apāya mukha kathā vaṇṇanā

original: 280. Apāyamukhānīti vināsamukhāni. Anabhisambhuṇamānoti asampāpuṇanto, avisahamāno🔽vā. Khārividhamādāyāti ettha khārīti araṇī kamaṇḍalu sujādayo tāpasaparikkhārā. Vidhoti
analyzed: apāya mukhāni iti vināsa mukhāni an abhisambhuṇamānaḥ iti a sampāpuṇantaḥ a visahamānaḥ  vā khāri vidham ādāya ati ettha khārī iti araṇī kamaṇḍalu tāpasa parikkhārā
translated: “Doors to the states of loss”: doors to destruction. “He could not master”: he could not reach, or he could not endure.

original: kājo. Tasmā khāribharitaṃ kājamādāyāti attho. Ye pana khārivividhanti paṭhanti, te
analyzed: tasmā khāri bharitam kājam ādāya ati atthaḥ ye pana khāri vividhanti paṭhanti te
translated: “Taking a load of salt in a bag”: here khāri is a kind of container, and vidha is a kind of salt. So the meaning is: “taking a load of vidha salt in a khāri.” But those who read khārividha take it as a compound word meaning “a load of salt.”

original: “khārīti kājassa nāmaṃ, vividhanti bahukamaṇḍaluādiparikkhāra”nti vaṇṇayanti. Pavattaphalabhojanoti
analyzed: khārī iti kājassa nāmam vividhanti bahu kamaṇḍalu ādi parikkhāranti vaṇṇayanti pavatta phala bhojanā ti
translated: “A water-pot is a name for a water-jar. Various is a term for the various requisites such as a bowl, a water- strainer, etc.”🔽He lived on fallen fruits:🔽he lived on fruits that had fallen of their own accord.

original: patitaphalabhojano. Paricārakoti kappiyakaraṇapattapaṭiggahaṇapādadhovanādivattakaraṇavasena🔽paricārako. Kāmañca guṇādhikopi khīṇāsavasāmaṇero puthujjanabhikkhuno vuttanayena
analyzed: patita phala bhojano paricārako ti kappiya karaṇa patta paṭiggahaṇa pāda dhovana ādi vatta karaṇa vasena  paricārako kāmam ca guṇa adhikaḥ api khīṇāsava sāmaṇero puthujjana bhikkhunaḥ vutta nayena
translated: He was his attendant: he was his attendant by doing what was proper, by receiving his bowl and robe, by massaging his limbs, and so on.

original: paricārako hoti, ayaṃ pana na tādiso guṇavasenapi veyyāvaccakaraṇavasenapi lāmakoyeva.
analyzed: paricārakaḥ hoti ayam pana na tādisaḥ guṇa vasena api veyyāvacca karaṇa vasena api
translated: And a novice with cankers destroyed who was superior in special qualities could be an attendant in the way stated for an ordinary bhikkhu. But this one was not like that. He was only a novice and was inferior in special qualities and in service too.🔽But why is it said that the wanderer’s life is the forerunner of the Dispensation’s destruction?

original: Kasmā pana tāpasapabbajjā sāsanassa vināsamukhanti vuttāti? Yasmā gacchantaṃ gacchantaṃ🔽sāsanaṃ tāpasapabbajjāvasena osakkissati. Imasmiñhi sāsane pabbajitvā tisso sikkhā
analyzed: kasmā pana tāpasa pabbajjā sāsanassa vināsa mukhan ti vuttā ati yasmā gacchantam gacchantam  sāsanam tāpasa pabbajjā vasena osakkissati imasmin hi sāsane pabbajitvā tissaḥ sikkhā
translated: Because the Dispensation will decline through the wanderer’s life.

original: pūretuṃ asakkontaṃ lajjino sikkhākāmā – “natthi tayā saddhiṃ uposatho vā pavāraṇā
analyzed: pūretum a sakkontam lajjinaḥ sikkhā kāmā na atthi tayā saddhim uposathaḥ vā pavāraṇā
translated: For those who have gone forth in this Dispensation and are unable to fulfil the three trainings, who are ashamed of the training, and who desire the training, avoid him, despising him thus: “There is no Uposatha or Pavāraṇā or legal act of the Community with you.”

original: vā saṅghakammaṃ vā”ti jigucchitvā parivajjenti. So “dukkaraṃ khuradhārūpamaṃ sāsane
analyzed: vā saṅgha kammam vāti jigucchitvā parivajjenti saḥ dukkaram khura dhāru upamam sa āsane
translated: He is difficult to associate with, like a razor’s edge, in the Dispensation

original: paṭipattipūraṇaṃ dukkhaṃ, tāpasapabbajjā pana sukarā ceva bahujanasammatā cā”ti vibbhamitvā
analyzed: paṭipatti pūraṇam dukkham tāpasa pabbajjā pana sukarā ca iva bahu jana sammatā ca ati vibbhamitvā
translated: The practice of the ascetic life is difficult, but the going forth of the wanderers is easy and is approved by the multitude.”

original: tāpaso hoti. Aññe taṃ disvā – “kiṃ tayā kata”nti pucchanti. So – “bhāriyaṃ tumhākaṃ🔽sāsane kammaṃ, idha pana sachandacārino maya”nti vadati. Sopi, yadi evaṃ ahampi ettheva
analyzed: tāpasaḥ hoti aññe tam disvā kim tayā katanti pucchanti so bhāriyam tumhākam  sāsane kammaṃ idha pana sa chanda cārinaḥ vadati saḥ api yadi evam aham pi ettha iva
translated: and he becomes an ascetic. Others, seeing him, ask, “What have you done?” He replies, “The practice of your Dispensation is difficult, but here we live in comfort.”

original: pabbajāmīti tassa anusikkhanto tāpaso hoti. Evamaññepi aññepīti kamena tāpasāva bahukā🔽honti. Tesaṃ uppannakāle sāsanaṃ osakkitaṃ nāma bhavissati. Loke evarūpo buddho nāma
analyzed: pabbajāmi iti tassa anusikkhantaḥ tāpasaḥ hoti evam aññe pi aññe pi iti kamena tāpasā ava bahukā  honti tesam uppanna kāle sāsanam osakkitam nāma bhavissati loke evarūpaḥ buddhaḥ nāma
translated: If it is so, then I too will go forth right here.” He becomes an ascetic by following his example. And so it happens that in this way and that way many become ascetics.

original: uppajji, tassa īdisaṃ nāma sāsanaṃ ahosīti sutamattameva bhavissati. Idaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: uppajji tassa īdisam nāma sāsanam ahosi iti suta mattam eva bhavissati idam sandhāya
translated: When they arise, the Dispensation is said to be declining. In the world there will be only the mere report: “Such a Buddha arose; his Dispensation was like this.”

original: bhagavā tāpasapabbajjaṃ sāsanassa vināsamukhanti āha.
analyzed: bhagavā tāpasa pabbajjam sāsanassa vināsa mukham ti āha
translated: With reference to this, the Blessed One said: “The going forth of the ascetics is the forerunner of the destruction of the Dispensation.”

original: Kudālapiṭakanti kandamūlaphalaggahaṇatthaṃ kudālañceva piṭakañca. Gāmasāmantaṃ vāti
analyzed: kudāla piṭakanti kanda mūla phala ggahaṇa attham kudālam ca iva piṭakam ca gāma sāmantam vāti
translated: “A spade and a basket”: a spade and a basket for the purpose of gathering roots, tubers, and fruits. “To the edge of a village” means

original: vijjācaraṇasampadādīni anabhisambhuṇanto, kasikammādīhi ca jīvitaṃ nipphādetuṃ dukkhanti
analyzed: vijjā caraṇa sampad ādīni an abhisambhuṇanto kasi kamma ādīhi ca jīvitam nipphādetum dukkhanti
translated: not being able to master the perfection of knowledge and conduct, and thinking it difficult to earn a living by agriculture, etc.,

original: maññamāno bahujanakuhāpanatthaṃ gāmasāmante vā nigamasāmante vā aggisālaṃ katvā sappiteladadhimadhuphāṇitatilataṇḍulādīhi
analyzed: maññamānaḥ bahu jana kuhāpana ttham gāma sāmante vā nigama sāmante vā aggi sālam katvā sappi tela dadhi madhu phāṇita tila taṇḍula ādīhi
translated: he builds a fire-house near a village or town for the purpose of deceiving the multitude. He maintains a fire there by means of ghee, oil, curd, honey, molasses, sesamum, rice, etc.,

original: ceva nānādārūhi ca homakaraṇavasena aggiṃ paricaranto acchati.
analyzed: ca iva nānā dārūhi ca homa karaṇa vasena aggim paricarantaḥ acchati
translated: and by means of various kinds of wood, by the performance of fire oblations.

original: Catudvāraṃ agāraṃ karitvāti catumukhaṃ pānāgāraṃ katvā tassa dvāre maṇḍapaṃ katvā
analyzed: catu dvāram agāram karitvā ati catu mukham pānāgāram katvā tassa dvāre maṇḍapam katvā
translated: Having built a four-doored house, having built a tavern with four entrances, having built a pavilion at its door,

original: tattha pānīyaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā āgatāgate pānīyena āpucchati. Yampissa addhikā kilantā
analyzed: tattha pānīyam upaṭṭhapetvā āgata āgate pānīyena āpucchati yam pissa addhikā kilantā
translated: and having placed drinking water there, he offers water to those who come. Those who are thirsty and exhausted

original: pānīyaṃ pivitvā parituṭṭhā bhattapuṭaṃ vā taṇḍulādīni vā denti, taṃ sabbaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: pānīyam pivitvā parituṭṭhāḥ bhatta puṭam vā taṇḍula ādīni vā denti tam sabbam gahetvā
translated: drink the water and, being satisfied, give him a basket of food or rice, etc. He takes all that

original: ambilayāguādīni katvā bahutaraṃ āmisagahaṇatthaṃ kesañci annaṃ deti, kesañci bhattapacanabhājanādīni.
analyzed: ambila yāgu ādīni katvā bahutaram āmisa gahaṇa attham kesañci annam deti kesañci bhatta pacana bhājana ādīni
translated: and, having prepared sour gruel, etc., he gives food to some for the purpose of receiving more material things, and to some he gives cooking vessels, etc.

original: Tehipi dinnaṃ āmisaṃ vā pubbaṇṇādīni vā gaṇhati, tāni vaḍḍhiyā payojeti. Evaṃ vaḍḍhamānavibhavo
analyzed: tehi api dinnam āmisam vā pubbaṇṇa ādīni vā gaṇhati tāni vaḍḍhiyā evam vaḍḍhamāna vibhavaḥ
translated: Thus his wealth increases.

original: gomahiṃsadāsīdāsapariggahaṃ karoti, mahantaṃ kuṭumbaṃ saṇṭhapeti. Imaṃ sandhāyetaṃ
analyzed: go mahiṃsa dāsī dāsa pariggaham karoti mahantam kuṭumbam saṇṭhapeti imam sandhāya itam
translated: He acquires cattle, goats, sheep, slaves, slave-girls, and fields, and he builds himself a great house with doors opening east and west.

original: vuttaṃ – “catudvāraṃ agāraṃ karitvā acchatī”ti. “Tamahaṃ yathāsatti yathābalaṃ paṭipūjessāmī”ti
analyzed: vuttam catu dvāram agāram karitvā acchati iti tam aham yathāsatti yathābalam paṭipūjessāmi iti
translated: “I will honour him according to my means and strength”

original: idaṃ panassa paṭipattimukhaṃ. Iminā hi mukhena so evaṃ paṭipajjatīti. Ettāvatā ca
analyzed: idam panassa paṭipatti mukham iminā hi mukhena saḥ evam paṭipajjati iti ettāvatā ca
translated: is the door to his practice. For it is through this door that he practises thus.

original: bhagavatā sabbāpi tāpasapabbajjā niddiṭṭhā honti.
analyzed: bhagavatā sabbā api tāpasa pabbajjāḥ niddiṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: And so far the Blessed One has shown all the kinds of asceticism.

original: Kathaṃ? Aṭṭhavidhā hi tāpasā – saputtabhariyā, uñchācariyā, anaggipakkikā, asāmapākā,🔽asmamuṭṭhikā, dantavakkalikā, pavattaphalabhojanā, paṇḍupalāsikāti. Tattha ye keṇiyajaṭilo
analyzed: katham aṭṭhavidhāḥ hi tāpasāḥ sa putta bhariyāḥ uñchā cariyāḥ an aggi pakkikāḥ a sāma pākā  dantavakkalikā pavattaphalabhojanā paṇḍupalāsikā ti tattha ye
translated: How? There are eight kinds of ascetics: those with a wife and children, those who go about begging for alms food, those who do not keep fire, those who do not cook for themselves,🔽those who do not look at anything thrown away and taken up, those who use the tooth-stick, those who eat fallen food, and those who eat grass-tips.

original: viya kuṭumbaṃ saṇṭhapetvā vasanti, te saputtabhariyā nāma.
analyzed: kuṭumbam saṇṭhapetvā vasanti te sa putta bhariyāḥ nāma
translated: Herein, those who live having established a household like Keṇiya the ex-caṇḍāla are called “those with a wife and children.”

original: Ye pana “saputtadārabhāvo nāma pabbajitassa ayutto”ti lāyanamaddanaṭṭhānesu vīhimuggamāsatilādīni saṅkaḍḍhitvā pacitvā paribhuñjanti, te uñchācariyā nāma.
analyzed: ye pana sa putta dāra bhāvaḥ nāma pabbajitassa ayuttaḥ ti lāyana maddana ṭhānesu vīhi mugga māsa tila ādīni saṅkaḍḍhitvā pacitvā paribhuñjanti te uñchācariyāḥ nāma
translated: But those who think that it is unsuitable for one gone forth to have sons and a wife and who, after collecting rice, beans, sesame, etc., in places where they are stored for the purpose of distribution, cook them and eat them, are those who live on gleanings.

original: Ye “khalena khalaṃ vicaritvā vīhiṃ āharitvā koṭṭetvā paribhuñjanaṃ nāma ayutta”nti gāmanigamesu taṇḍulabhikkhaṃ gahetvā pacitvā paribhuñjanti, te anaggipakkikā nāma.
analyzed: ye khalena khalam vicaritvā vīhim āharitvā koṭṭetvā paribhuñjanam nāma ayuttanti gāma nigamesu taṇḍula bhikkham gahetvā pacitvā paribhuñjanti te an aggipakkikāḥ nāma
translated: Those who think that it is unsuitable to go about here and there and to gather rice and so on, thresh it, and eat it, but who go to villages and towns and after getting a begging bowlful of rice cook it and eat it, are those who do not cook for themselves.

original: Ye pana “kiṃ pabbajitassa sāmapākenā”ti gāmaṃ pavisitvā pakkabhikkhameva gaṇhanti, te asāmapākā nāma.🔽Ye “divase divase bhikkhāpariyeṭṭhi nāma dukkhā pabbajitassā”ti muṭṭhipāsāṇena ambāṭakādīnaṃ rukkhānaṃ tacaṃ koṭṭetvā khādanti, te asmamuṭṭhikā nāma.
analyzed: ye pana kim pabbajitassa sāma pākena ati gāmam pavisitvā pakka bhikkham eva gaṇhanti te a sāmapākāḥ nāma  ye divase divase bhikkhā pariyeṭṭhi nāma dukkhā pabbajitassa ati muṭṭhi pāsāṇena ambāṭaka ādīnam rukkhānam tacam koṭṭetvā khādanti te asmamuṭṭhikāḥ nāma
translated: But those who think that it is unsuitable for one gone forth to cook for himself and who go into the village and get cooked food and eat it, are those who do not cook for themselves.🔽Those who think that it is troublesome to go on a daily alms round and who, after breaking the bark of such trees as the bread-fruit, jack-fruit, and so on, with a stone, eat the inner bark, are those who use the bark-robe.

original: Ye pana “pāsāṇena tacaṃ koṭṭetvā vicaraṇaṃ nāma dukkha”nti danteheva ubbāṭetvā khādanti, te dantavakkalikā nāma.
analyzed: ye pana pāsāṇena tacam koṭṭetvā vicaraṇam nāma dukkhanti dantehi iva ubbāṭetvā khādanti te dantavakkalikāḥ nāma
translated: But those who think that it is troublesome to go about breaking the bark with a stone and who eat the inner bark after scraping it off with their teeth, are those who use the tooth-stick.

original: Ye “dantehi ubbāṭetvā khādanaṃ nāma dukkhaṃ pabbajitassā”ti leḍḍudaṇḍādīhi paharitvā patitāni phalāni paribhuñjanti, te pavattaphalabhojanā nāma.
analyzed: ye dantehi ubbāṭetvā khādanam nāma dukkham pabbajitassa ati leḍḍu daṇḍa ādīhi paharitvā patitāni phalāni paribhuñjanti te pavatta phala bhojanāḥ nāma
translated: Those who eat fallen fruits, thinking, “It is painful to climb a tree and pick the fruit, and it is painful to be a monk,” are called “eaters of fallen fruits.”

original: Ye pana “leḍḍudaṇḍādīhi pātetvā paribhogo nāma asāruppo pabbajitassā”ti sayaṃ patitāneva pupphaphalapaṇḍupalāsādīni khādantā yāpenti, te paṇḍupalāsikā nāma.🔽Te tividhā – ukkaṭṭhamajjhimamudukavasena. Tattha ye nisinnaṭṭhānato anuṭṭhāya hatthena🔽pāpuṇanaṭṭhāneva patitaṃ gahetvā khādanti, te ukkaṭṭhā. Ye ekarukkhato aññaṃ rukkhaṃ
analyzed: ye pana leḍḍu daṇḍa ādīhi pātetvā paribhogaḥ nāma a sāruppaḥ pabbajitassa ati sayam patitān eva puppha phala paṇḍu palāsa ādīni khādantā yāpenti te paṇḍupalāsikāḥ nāma  te tividhā ukkaṭṭha majjhima muduka vasena tattha ye nisinna ṭṭhānataḥ anuṭṭhāya hatthena  pāpuṇana ṭṭhānā iva patitam gahetvā khādanti te ukkaṭṭhāḥ ye eka rukkhataḥ aññam rukkham
translated: But those who, thinking, “It is not seemly for a monk to knock down fruits with sticks and such things,” live on what has fallen spontaneously, such as flowers, fruits, leaves, and shoots, are called “eaters of what ripens in water and on dry land.”

original: na gacchanti, te majjhimā. Ye taṃ taṃ rukkhamūlaṃ gantvā pariyesitvā khādanti, te mudukā.
analyzed: na gacchanti te majjhimāḥ ye tam tam rukkha mūlam gantvā pariyesitvā khādanti te mudukā
translated: They are of three kinds as “strict,” “moderate,” and “mild.” Herein, those who eat only what has fallen into the place where they are sitting without getting up and going after it are “strict.” Those who do not go from tree to tree are “moderate.” Those who go to the foot of a tree and eat after seeking are “mild.”

original: Imā pana aṭṭhapi tāpasapabbajjā imāhi catūhiyeva saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Kathaṃ? Etāsu
analyzed: imā pana aṭṭha api tāpasa pabbajjāḥ imāhi saṅgaham gacchanti katham etāsu
translated: These eight kinds of ascetics’ dwellings are included in these four only. How?

original: hi saputtabhariyā ca uñchācariyā ca agāraṃ bhajanti. Anaggipakkikā ca asāmapākā ca🔽agyāgāraṃ bhajanti. Asmamuṭṭhikā ca dantavakkalikā ca kandamūlaphalabhojanaṃ bhajanti.
analyzed: hi sa putta bhariyā ca uñchā cariyā ca agāram bhajanti an aggi pakkikā ca a sāma pākā ca  agyāgāram bhajanti ca dantavakkalikā ca kanda mūla phala bhojanam bhajanti
translated: for they live on gleanings with their children and wives, and they frequent the house-holders’ fire-places, and they frequent the fire-sanctuaries, and they are ash-rubbers and chewers of tooth-wood, and they frequent the eating of roots, tubers, and fruits,

original: Pavattaphalabhojanā ca paṇḍupalāsikā ca pavattaphalabhojanaṃ bhajanti. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: pavatta phala bhojanā ca paṇḍu palāsikā ca pavatta phala bhojanam bhajanti tena vuttam
translated: and they frequent the eating of fallen fruits, and they frequent the eating of fallen fruits and withered leaves.

original: – “ettāvatā ca bhagavatā sabbāpi tāpasapabbajjā niddiṭṭhā hontī”ti.🔽281-282. Idāni bhagavā sācariyakassa ambaṭṭhassa vijjācaraṇasampadāya apāyamukhampi
analyzed: ettāvatā ca bhagavatā sabbā api tāpasa pabbajjāḥ niddiṭṭhāḥ honti iti  idāni bhagavā sa ācariyakassa ambaṭṭhassa vijjā ācaraṇa sampadāya apāya mukham pi
translated: Thus far the Blessed One has shown all the kinds of asceticism that exist.

original: appattabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ taṃ kiṃ maññasi ambaṭṭhātiādimāha. Taṃ uttānatthameva. Attanā
analyzed: appatta bhāvam dassetum tam kim maññasi ambaṭṭha ati ādim āha tam uttāna attham eva attanā
translated: Now the Blessed One said, “What do you think, Ambattha? ” in order to show that even the way to the Downfall is not beyond the reach of one who is endowed with the development of knowledge and conduct, together with his disciples. The meaning is plain.

original: āpāyikopi aparipūramānoti attanā vijjācaraṇasampadāya āpāyikenāpi aparipūramānena.
analyzed: āpāyikaḥ api a paripūramānaḥ ti attanā vijjā caraṇa sampadāya āpāyikena api a paripūramānena
translated: Even one who is bound for the Downfall, if he is not fully satisfied,

original: Pubbakaisibhāvānuyogavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Practice of the First Arahants

original: 283. Dattikanti dinnakaṃ. Sammukhībhāvampi na dadātīti kasmā na dadāti? So kira sammukhā
analyzed: dattikam ti dinnakam sammukhībhāvam pi na dadāti iti kasmai na dadāti sā u kira sammukhā
translated: Dattika: one who gives. He does not even give him a chance to meet him: why does he not give him a chance? It seems that he did not give him a chance because he was afraid that if he did, Ambattha would be able to find fault with him.

original: āvaṭṭaniṃ nāma vijjaṃ jānāti. Yadā rājā mahārahena alaṅkārena alaṅkato hoti, tadā
analyzed: āvaṭṭanim nāma vijjam jānāti yadā rājā mahā rahena alaṅkārena alaṅkataḥ hoti tadā
translated: He knew the spell called the “turn-about.” When the king was adorned with costly ornaments,

original: rañño samīpe ṭhatvā tassa alaṅkārassa nāmaṃ gaṇhati. Tassa rājā nāme gahite na demīti
analyzed: rañño samīpe ṭhatvā tassa alaṅkārassa nāmam gaṇhati tassa rājā nāme gahite na demi iti
translated: the brahman stood near the king and took the name of the ornaments. The king, when the name was taken, could not say, “I will not give it.”

original: vattuṃ na sakkoti. Datvā puna chaṇadivase alaṅkāraṃ āharathāti vatvā, natthi, deva,
analyzed: vattum na sakkoti da tvā puna chaṇa divase alaṅkāram āharatha ati vatvā natthi deva
translated: After giving it, on the day of the gift, he said, “Bring the ornaments.” They said, “There are no ornaments, your majesty.

original: tumhehi brāhmaṇassa dinnoti vutto, “kasmā me dinno”ti pucchi. Te amaccā ‘so brāhmaṇo

translated: Having said this, he thought: “No one can seek out the marks of Buddhas who are sitting or lying down. But they can do so of those who are standing or walking. Therefore it was said: ‘Then the Blessed One rose from his seat’ , and so on.

translated: He searches here and there, but he cannot find them. He does not accept: he does not come to a decision through that doubt. He does not have confidence: he does not attain confidence in the Blessed One as one who possesses the characteristics in their entirety. Or else, doubt is said to be weak, non-acceptance middling, and lack of confidence strong, with the mind’s lack of clarity due to these three states. He is covered: he is covered by the covering of the defilements.

original: paṭicchanne. Vatthaguyheti aṅgajāte bhagavato hi varavāraṇasseva kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ🔽suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ padumagabbhasamānaṃ. Taṃ so vatthapaṭicchannattā apassanto, antomukhagatāya🔽ca jivhāya pahūtabhāvaṃ asallakkhento tesu dvīsu lakkhaṇesu kaṅkhī ahosi vicikicchī.
analyzed: paṭicchanne vattha guyhā iti aṅga jāte bhagavataḥ hi vara vāraṇassa iva kosohitam vattha guyham 🔽suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam paduma gabbha samānam tam saḥ vattha paṭicchanna ttā a passantaḥ antomukha gatāya 🔽ca jivhāya pahūta bhāvam tesu dvīsu lakkhaṇesu kaṅkhī ahosi vicikicchī
translated: He is perplexed, he is unable to see them. He does not believe: he does not come to a decision through that perplexity. He does not have full confidence: he does not attain confidence in the Blessed One as one whose characteristics are complete. Or else perplexity is said to be weak doubt, perplexity is medium doubt, and lack of belief is strong doubt. Lack of confidence is the state of the mind’s being obscured by these three states. Covered up: concealed by a cloth. Sheathed: the Blessed One’s organ is sheathed like that of a noble stallion, golden-coloured, like the interior of a lotus. He did not see it because it was concealed by the cloth, and he was doubtful and perplexed about these two characteristics because he did not notice the abundance of the tongue that was inside his mouth.

original: 288. Tathārūpanti taṃ rūpaṃ. Kimettha aññena vattabbaṃ? Vuttametaṃ nāgasenatthereneva
