The rest is clear except for the words “the four noble lineages” , which are given in the text in the singular.

original: Iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: Thus in the Sumangalavilāsini, the commentary on the Long Discourses,

original: Ambaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ambaṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Ambattha Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Soṇadaṇḍasuttavaṇṇanā🔽300. Evaṃ me sutaṃ…pe… aṅgesūti soṇadaṇḍasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Aṅgesūti
analyzed: soṇadaṇḍa sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me aṅgesu iti soṇadaṇḍa suttam tatra ayam apubba pada vaṇṇanā aṅgesu iti
translated: The Sonadanda Sutta

original: aṅgā nāma aṅgapāsādikatāya evaṃ laddhavohārā jānapadino rājakumārā, tesaṃ nivāso
analyzed: aṅgāḥ nāma aṅga pāsādika tāya evam laddha vohārāḥ jānapadinaḥ rāja kumārā tesam nivāso
translated: Thus I heard. … In the Angas: the Sonadanda Sutta . Herein, the exposition of the unfamiliar terms is this. The Angas were the name of a country in the Magadha country, and the Angas were the princes of that country who were so called because they were the limbs of King Mahāpaduma.🔽Their capital was Campā.🔽The country is called the Anga country.

original: ekopi janapado rūḷhisaddena aṅgāti vuccati, tasmiṃ aṅgesu janapade. Cārikanti idhāpi🔽aturitacārikā ceva nibaddhacārikā ca adhippetā. Tadā kira bhagavato dasasahassilokadhātuṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ api janapadaḥ rūḷhi saddena aṅgā ati vuccati tasmin aṅgesu janapade cārikam ti idha api  aturita cārikā ca iva nibaddha cārikā ca adhippetā tadā kira bhagavataḥ dasa sahassi lokadhātum
translated: Herein, the word “going” is intended to include both a hurried journey and a regular visit.🔽For at that time the Blessed One was surveying the ten-thousandfold world-system and the brahmin Sonadanda appeared within the net of his knowledge.

original: olokentassa soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo ñāṇajālassa anto paññāyittha. Atha bhagavā ayaṃ brāhmaṇo
analyzed: olokentassa soṇadaṇḍaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ñāṇa jālassa antaḥ paññāyittha atha bhagavā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: Then the Blessed One thought: “This brahmin appears within the net of my knowledge.

original: mayhaṃ ñāṇajāle paññāyati. ‘Atthi nu khvassupanissayo’ti vīmaṃsanto addasa. ‘Mayi
analyzed: mayham ñāṇa jāle paññāyati atthi nu khvassupanissayaḥ ti vīmaṃsantaḥ addasa mayi
translated: Is there any dependence on me? ” And considering, he saw that there was.

original: tattha gate etassa antevāsino dvādasahākārehi brāhmaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitvā mama santike
analyzed: tattha gate etassa antevāsinaḥ dvādasahā ākārehi brāhmaṇassa vaṇṇam bhāsitvā mama santike
translated: “If I go there,” he thought, “his pupils will praise the brahmin in twelve respects and then come to me.

original: āgantuṃ na dassanti. So pana tesaṃ vādaṃ bhinditvā ekūnatiṃsa ākārehi mama vaṇṇaṃ🔽bhāsitvā maṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchissati. So pañhavissajjanapariyosāne saraṇaṃ
analyzed: āgantum na dassanti saḥ pana tesam vādam bhinditvā ekūnatiṃse ākārehi mama vaṇṇam  bhāsitvā mam upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchissati saḥ pañha vissajjana pariyosāne saraṇam
translated: they will not allow him to come. But he will break their doctrine, and after praising me in twenty-nine ways,🔽he will come to me and ask me a question. At the end of my answer to his question he will go for refuge. ’

original: gamissatī’ti, disvā pañcasatabhikkhuparivāro taṃ janapadaṃ paṭipanno. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: gamissati iti disvā pañca sata bhikkhu parivāraḥ tam janapadam paṭipannaḥ tena vuttam
translated: Having seen this, he set out for that country, surrounded by five hundred bhikkhus. Hence it was said:

original: – aṅgesu cārikaṃ caramāno…pe… yena campā tadavasarīti.🔽Gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti tassa campānagarassa avidūre gaggarāya nāma rājaggamahesiyā
analyzed: aṅgesu cārikam yena campā tad avasarī iti  gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīrā iti tassa campā nagarassa avidūre gaggarāya nāma rājagga mahesiyā
translated: ‘Wandering by stages in the Angas … he eventually arrived at Campā.’🔽‘On the bank of the Gaggarā Tank’: not far from the city of Campā there is a tank called Gaggarā, which was dug by King Bimbisāra’s chief queen, Gaggarā.

original: khaṇitattā gaggarāti laddhavohārā pokkharaṇī atthi. Tassā tīre samantato nīlādipañcavaṇṇakusumapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: khaṇita attā gaggarā ati laddha vohārā pokkharaṇī atthi tassāḥ tīre samantataḥ nīla ādi pañca vaṇṇa kusuma paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: It is known as the Gaggarā Tank because it was dug by Gaggarā. On its bank, surrounded by blue, red, and white lotuses,

original: mahantaṃ campakavanaṃ. Tasmiṃ bhagavā kusumagandhasugandhe campakavane viharati.
analyzed: mahantam campaka vanam tasmin bhagavā kusuma gandha sugandhe campaka vane viharati
translated: there is a large campaka grove. The Blessed One was living in that fragrant, sweet-smelling campaka grove.🔽This is the meaning of the words ‘on the bank of the Gaggarā Tank.’

original: Taṃ sandhāya gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti vuttaṃ. Māgadhena seniyena bimbisārenāti
analyzed: tam sandhāya gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti vuttam māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena ati
translated: ‘With Magadha’s King Seniya Bimbisāra’:

original: ettha so rājā magadhānaṃ issarattā māgadho. Mahatiyā senāya samannāgatattā seniyo.
analyzed: ettha saḥ rājā magadhānam issa rattā māgadhaḥ mahatiyā senāya samannāgata ttā seniyaḥ
translated: Herein, he was a Magadhan because of his sovereignty over Magadha. He was Seniya because he was endowed with a great army.

original: Bimbīti suvaṇṇaṃ. Tasmā sārasuvaṇṇasadisavaṇṇatāya bimbisāroti vuccati.
analyzed: bimbī iti suvaṇṇam tasmā sāra suvaṇṇa sadisa vaṇṇa tāya bimbisāro ti vuccati
translated: Bimba is gold. Therefore he is called Bimbisāra because of his complexion like fine gold.🔽They are Saṅghas because of being a multitude, many being together.

original: 301-302. Bahū bahū hutvā saṃhatāti saṅghā. Ekekissāya disāya saṅgho etesaṃ atthīti
analyzed: bahū bahū hutvā saṃhatā ati saṅghāḥ ekekissāya disāya saṅghaḥ etesam atthi iti
translated: They are Saṅghīs because of having a Saṅgha in each direction.

original: saṅghī. Pubbe nagarassa anto agaṇā bahi nikkhamitvā gaṇataṃ pattāti gaṇībhūtā. Khattaṃ
analyzed: saṅghī pubbe nagarassa antar agaṇā bahi nikkhamitvā gaṇatam pattā ati gaṇībhūtā khattam
translated: They are Gaṇīs because of having become a multitude after previously being a multitude inside the city and outside the city and then going forth and becoming a multitude.

original: āmantesīti. Khattā vuccati pucchitapañhe byākaraṇasamattho mahāmatto, taṃ āmantesi
analyzed: āmantesi iti khattā vuccati pucchita pañhe byākaraṇa samatthaḥ mahāmatto tam āmantesi
translated: He addressed the Khattiya. A Khattiya is a minister capable of answering questions when asked. He addressed him.

original: āgamentūti muhuttaṃ paṭimānentu, mā gacchantūti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: āgamentu uti muhuttam paṭimānentu mā gacchantu iti vuttam hoti
translated: Let them come means let them wait a moment, let them not go, is what is said.

original: Soṇadaṇḍaguṇakathā🔽303. Nānāverajjakānanti nānāvidhesu rajjesu, aññesu aññesu kāsikosalādīsu rajjesu
analyzed: soṇa daṇḍa guṇa kathā  nānā verajjakānanti nānāvidhesu rajjesu aññesu aññesu kāsi kosala ādīsu rajjesu
translated: The Story of Soṇadaṇḍa’s Qualities🔽In various countries means in various kinds of countries, in various other countries such as Kāsi, Kosala, etc.

original: jātā, tāni vā tesaṃ nivāsā, tato vā āgatāti nānāverajjakā, tesaṃ nānāverajjakānaṃ.
analyzed: jātā tāni vā tesam nivāsā tatas vai āgatā ati nānā verajjakā tesam nānā verajjakānam
translated: They are born, or their abodes are there, or they have come from there, thus they are from various countries. Of those from various countries.

original: Kenacideva karaṇīyenāti tasmiṃ kira nagare dvīhi karaṇīyehi brāhmaṇā sannipatanti
analyzed: kenacid eva karaṇīyena ati tasmin kira nagare brāhmaṇāḥ sannipatanti
translated: “For some business or other”: it seems that in that city the brahmins assembled for two reasons:

original: – yaññānubhavanatthaṃ vā mantasajjhāyanatthaṃ vā. Tadā ca tasmiṃ nagare yamaññā natthi.
analyzed: yañña anubhavana attham vā manta sajjhāyana attham vā tadā ca tasmin nagare yamaññā na atthi
translated: either to enjoy a sacrifice or to recite the mantras. At that time there was no sacrifice in that city.

original: Soṇadaṇḍassa pana santike mantasajjhāyanatthaṃ ete sannipatitā. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ
analyzed: soṇadaṇḍassa pana santike manta sajjhāyana attham ete sannipatitā tam sandhāya vuttam
translated: But they had assembled in the presence of Sonadanda for the purpose of reciting the mantras. With reference to that it was said:

original: – “kenacideva karaṇīyenā”ti. Te tassa gamanaṃ sutvā cintesuṃ – “ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo uggatabrāhmaṇo
analyzed: kenacid eva karaṇīyena ati te tassa gamanam sutvā cintesuṃ ayam soṇadaṇḍaḥ uggata brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: “for some business or other.” Having heard of his going, they thought: “This Sonadanda is a brahmin of high birth.

original: yebhuyyena ca aññe brāhmaṇā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā, ayameva na gato. Svāyaṃ
analyzed: yebhuyyena ca aññe brāhmaṇā samaṇam gotamam saraṇam gatāḥ ayam eva na gataḥ svāyam
translated: And most of the other brahmins have gone for refuge to the recluse Gotama, but he has not done so.

original: sace tattha gamissati, addhā samaṇassa gotamassa āvaṭṭaniyā māyāya āvaṭṭito, taṃ
analyzed: sace tattha gamissati addhā samaṇassa gotamassa āvaṭṭaniyā māyāya āvaṭṭitaḥ tam
translated: If he goes there, he will certainly be captivated by the recluse Gotama’s wiles and tricks, and he will go for refuge to him.

original: saraṇaṃ gamissati. Tato etassāpi gehadvāre brāhmaṇānaṃ sannipāto na bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: saraṇam gamissati tatas etassa api geha dvāre brāhmaṇānam sannipātaḥ na bhavissati iti
translated: Then there will be no more assemblies of brahmins at his house either.”

original: “Handassa gamanantarāyaṃ karomā”ti sammantayitvā tattha agamaṃsu. Taṃ sandhāya –
analyzed: handassa gamana antarāyam karoma iti sammantayitvā tattha agamaṃsu tam sandhāya
translated: “Let us create an obstacle to his going,” they decided, and they went there. With reference to that it was said:

original: atha kho te brāhmaṇātiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: atha kho te brāhmaṇa atiādi vuttam
translated: Then the brahmans said to him, “Sir, please do not go to see the recluse Gotama.🔽Herein, with this reason is with this cause.

original: Tattha imināpaṅgenāti imināpi kāraṇena. Evaṃ etaṃ kāraṇaṃ vatvā puna – “attano vaṇṇe
analyzed: tattha iminā apaṅgena ati iminā api kāraṇena evam etam kāraṇam vatvā puna attanaḥ vaṇṇe
translated: Having stated this cause, they thought, “There is no one who does not rejoice when his own praise is being spoken.

original: bhaññamāne atussanakasatto nāma natthi. Handassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanena gamanaṃ nivāressāmā”ti
analyzed: bhaññamāne atussanakasatto nāma natthi handassa vaṇṇam bhaṇanena gamanam nivāressāma ati
translated: So let us prevent his going by speaking his praise.”

original: cintetvā bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo ubhato sujātotiādīni kāraṇāni āhaṃsu.
analyzed: cintetvā bhavan hi soṇa daṇḍaḥ ubhatas sujātaḥ iti ādīni kāraṇāni āhaṃsu
translated: And so they said, “Sir, you are well born on both sides,” etc., giving reasons.🔽Both sides : by two sides.

original: Ubhatoti dvīhi pakkhehi. Mātito ca pitito cāti bhoto mātā brāhmaṇī, mātumātā brāhmaṇī,
analyzed: ubhatas ti dvīhi pakkhehi mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca ati bhotaḥ mātā brāhmaṇī mātu mātā brāhmaṇī
translated: By mother and by father : your mother is a brahmin, your mother’s mother was a brahmin,

original: tassāpi mātā brāhmaṇī; pitā brāhmaṇo, pitupitā brāhmaṇo, tassāpi pitā brāhmaṇoti,
analyzed: tassa api mātā brāhmaṇī pitā brāhmaṇo pitu pitā brāhmaṇo tassa api pitā brāhmaṇo ti
translated: your mother’s mother’s mother was a brahmin; your father is a brahmin, your father’s father was a brahmin,

original: evaṃ bhavaṃ ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca. Saṃsuddhagahaṇikoti saṃsuddhā te mātugahaṇī
analyzed: evam ubhatas su jātaḥ mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca saṃsuddha gahaṇikā iti saṃsuddhā te mātu gahaṇī
translated: your father’s father’s father was a brahmin. Thus you are well born on both sides, by mother and by father.🔽Of pure maternal descent for seven generations : pure is their maternal descent for seven generations.🔽The meaning is that their wombs are pure.

original: kucchīti attho. Samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyāti ettha pana kammajatejodhātu “gahaṇī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: kucchī iti attho sama vepākiniyā gahaṇiyā ti ettha pana kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu gahaṇī iti vuccati
translated: Of pure paternal descent for seven generations : here the fire element that is born of kamma is called “descent.”

original: Yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti ettha pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṃ pitāmahayugaṃ.
analyzed: yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā ti ettha pitu pitā pitāmahaḥ pitāmahassa yugam pitāmaha yugam
translated: “As far back as the seventh generation of ancestors”: here the father’s father is the grandfather, and the grandfather’s pair is the grandfather’s generation.

original: Yuganti āyuppamāṇaṃ vuccati. Abhilāpamattameva cetaṃ. Atthato pana pitāmahoyeva pitāmahayugaṃ.
analyzed: yugam ti āyu ppamāṇam vuccati abhilāpa mattam eva atthato pana pitāmaha uyā iva pitāmaha yugam
translated: “Pair” is said to be a measure of life-span. But this is merely a conventional expression. In the sense of the matter, however, the grandfather’s generation is the grandfather himself.

original: Tato uddhaṃ sabbepi pubbapurisā pitāmahaggahaṇeneva gahitā. Evaṃ yāva sattamo puriso,
analyzed: tatas uddham sabbe pi pubba purisāḥ pitāmaha ggahaṇena iva gahitāḥ evam yāva sattamaḥ puriso
translated: Beyond that, all the ancestors are included by the word “grandfather.” Thus as far as the seventh person,

original: tāva saṃsuddhagahaṇiko. Atha vā akkhitto anupakuṭṭho jātivādenāti dassenti. Akkhittoti
analyzed: tāva saṃsuddha gahaṇikaḥ atha vā akkhittaḥ anupakuṭṭhaḥ jāti vādena ati dassenti akkhittaḥ ti
translated: the lineage is pure. Or else they show that he was not slighted, not despised, by the charge of low birth. “Not slighted” means

original: – “apanetha etaṃ, kiṃ iminā”ti evaṃ akkhitto anavakkhitto. Anupakuṭṭhoti na upakuṭṭho,
analyzed: apanetha etam kim iminā ati evam akkhittaḥ an avakkhittaḥ an upakuṭṭhaḥ ti na upakuṭṭhaḥ
translated: not despised by the words “Get rid of him, what is he doing here?” “Not despised” means🔽not despised, not reproached.🔽By what reason? By the charge of low birth. Thus—

original: na akkosaṃ vā nindaṃ vā laddhapubbo. Kena kāraṇenāti? Jātivādena. Itipi – “hīnajātiko
analyzed: na akkosam vā nindam vā laddha pubbo kena kāraṇena ati jāti vādena iti pi hīna jātiko
translated: “He is of low birth,🔽he is of low birth,”

original: eso”ti evarūpena vacanenāti attho.
analyzed: eso ti evarūpena vacanena ati attho
translated: such words.

original: Aḍḍhoti issaro. Mahaddhanoti mahatā dhanena samannāgato. Bhavato hi gehe pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: issaraḥ mahat dhanoti mahatā dhanena samannāgataḥ bhavataḥ hi gehe pathaviyam
translated: “Rich” means powerful. “Greatly wealthy” means endowed with great wealth. For in the house of the rich

original: paṃsuvālikā viya bahudhanaṃ, samaṇo pana gotamo adhano bhikkhāya udaraṃ pūretvā yāpetīti
analyzed: paṃsuvālikā viya bahu dhanam samaṇaḥ pana gotamaḥ adhanaḥ bhikkhāya udaram pūretvā yāpeti iti
translated: He is poor, like a man of straw or sand, but the recluse Gotama is poor, he fills his belly with alms and gets by.

original: dassenti. Mahābhogoti pañcakāmaguṇavasena mahāupabhogo. Evaṃ yaṃ yaṃ guṇaṃ vadanti,
analyzed: mahā bhogo ti pañca kāmaguṇa vasena mahā upabhogaḥ evam yam yam guṇam vadanti
translated: They show him to be poor. He is wealthy means he has great enjoyment through the five strands of sense pleasure. Thus whatever qualities they proclaim,

original: tassa tassa paṭipakkhavasena bhagavato aguṇaṃyeva dassemāti maññamānā vadanti.
analyzed: tassa tassa paṭipakkha vasena bhagavataḥ aguṇam yā iva dassema iti maññamānāḥ vadanti
translated: thinking, “We will show the Blessed One to be devoid of those qualities by the opposite qualities,” they speak.

original: Abhirūpoti aññehi manussehi abhirūpo adhikarūpo. Dassanīyoti divasampi passantānaṃ
analyzed: abhirūpaḥ ti aññehi manussehi abhirūpaḥ adhikarūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ ti divasam pi passantānam
translated: He is handsome means he is handsome, he has a superior form. He is lovely to look at means he is lovely to look at

original: atittikaraṇato dassanayoggo. Dassaneneva cittapasādajananato pāsādiko. Pokkharatā🔽vuccati sundarabhāvo, vaṇṇassa pokkharatā vaṇṇapokkharatā, tāya vaṇṇasampattiyā yuttoti
analyzed: a titti karaṇataḥ dassana yoggaḥ dassanena iva citta pasāda jananataḥ pāsādikaḥ pokkhara tā  vuccati sundara bhāvaḥ vaṇṇassa pokkhara tā vaṇṇa pokkhara tā tāya vaṇṇa sampattiyā yuttaḥ ti
translated: even for one who looks at him for a whole day. He is pleasing means he is pleasing to the mind by being seen. Pokkharasāti

original: attho. Porāṇā panāhu – “pokkharanti sarīraṃ vadanti, vaṇṇaṃ vaṇṇamevā”ti. Tesaṃ matena
analyzed: porāṇā pana āhu pokkharanti sarīram vadanti vaṇṇam vaṇṇam eva ati tesam matena
translated: is said to be a beautiful state, the beauty of his complexion is the beauty of his complexion, he is endowed with that, is the meaning. But the ancients said: “Pokkharasāti is said to be a body, a complexion, a complexion itself.” According to their view,

original: vaṇṇañca pokkharañca vaṇṇapokkharāni. Tesaṃ bhāvo vaṇṇapokkharatā. Iti paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāyāti
analyzed: vaṇṇam ca pokkharam ca vaṇṇa pokkharāni tesam bhāvaḥ vaṇṇa pokkhara tā iti paramāya vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya ati
translated: a complexion and a pokkhara are a vaṇṇapokkhara. The state of those is vaṇṇapokkharatā. Thus he has the highest beauty of complexion,🔽is the meaning.

original: uttamena parisuddhena vaṇṇena ceva sarīrasaṇṭhānasampattiyā cāti attho. Brahmavaṇṇīti🔽seṭṭhavaṇṇī. Parisuddhavaṇṇesupi seṭṭhena suvaṇṇavaṇṇena samannāgatoti attho. Brahmavacchasīti
analyzed: uttamena parisuddhena vaṇṇena ca iva sarīra saṇṭhāna sampattiyā ca ati atthaḥ brahma vaṇṇī iti  seṭṭha vaṇṇī parisuddha vaṇṇesu pi seṭṭhena suvaṇṇa vaṇṇena samannāgataḥ ti atthaḥ brahma vacchasi iti
translated: the meaning is, with the most excellent purity of complexion and perfection of bodily form. He has the beauty of Brahmā:🔽he has the beauty of the best, the meaning is, he is endowed with the best beauty, a golden beauty. He has the voice of Brahmā:

original: mahābrahmuno sarīrasadiseneva sarīrena samannāgato. Akhuddāvakāso dassanāyāti “bhoto
analyzed: mahābrahmuno sarīra sadisena iva sarīrena samannāgataḥ akhudda avakāsaḥ dassanāya ati bhoto
translated: he is endowed with a body like that of the Great Brahmā. He is one whose appearance it is good to see:

original: sarīre dassanassa okāso na khuddako mahā, sabbāneva te aṅgapaccaṅgāni dassanīyāneva,
analyzed: sarīre dassanassa okāsaḥ na khuddakaḥ mahā sabbān eva te aṅga paccaṅgāni dassanīyān eva
translated: they show that the opportunity to see his body is not small but great, that all his limbs and minor limbs are fit to be seen,

original: tāni cāpi mahantānevā”ti dīpenti.
analyzed: tāni ca api mahantān eva ati dīpenti
translated: and that they are great too.

original: Sīlamassa atthīti sīlavā. Vuddhaṃ vaddhitaṃ sīlamassāti vuddhasīlī. Vuddhasīlenāti
analyzed: sīlam assa atthi iti sīlavā vuddham vaddhitam sīlam assa ati vuddha sīlī vuddha sīlena ati
translated: He has virtue, thus he is virtuous. His virtue is grown, developed, thus he is of grown virtue. He has grown virtue:

original: vuddhena vaddhitena sīlena. Samannāgatoti yutto. Idaṃ vuddhasīlīpadasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: vuddhena vaddhitena sīlena samannāgataḥ iti yuttaḥ idam vuddha sīlī padassa iva vevacanam
translated: he is endowed with grown, developed virtue. Thus he is furnished. This is a synonym for the phrase “of grown virtue.”

original: Sabbametaṃ pañcasīlamattameva sandhāya vadanti.
analyzed: sabbam etam pañca sīla mattam eva sandhāya vadanti
translated: All this is said with reference to the five training precepts only.

original: Kalyāṇavācotiādīsu kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā vācā assāti kalyāṇavāco.
analyzed: kalyāṇa vācaḥ iti ādīsu kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍala pada byañjanā vācā assa ati kalyāṇa vācaḥ
translated: He is of good speech: he has good, beautiful, well-rounded words and syllables.

original: Kalyāṇaṃ madhuraṃ vākkaraṇaṃ assāti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo. Vākkaraṇanti udāharaṇaghoso.
analyzed: kalyāṇam madhuram vāc karaṇam assa ati kalyāṇa vāc karaṇaḥ udāharaṇa ghosaḥ
translated: He is one who speaks pleasantly, sweetly, and agreeably, thus he is a pleasant speaker. Pleasant speaking is a term for the voice.

original: Guṇaparipuṇṇabhāvena pure bhavāti porī. Pure vā bhavattā porī. Poriyā nāgarikitthiyā
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa bhāvena pure bhavāti porī pure vā bhavattā porī poriyā nāgarikitthiyā
translated: He is one who was formerly, i.e., in the past, full of good qualities, thus he is a former full-of-good-qualities man. Or alternatively, he is a former full-of-good-qualities man because he was full of good qualities in the past.🔽He is like the courtesan Pukkusa, thus he is a Pukkusa. With that Pukkusa,

original: sukhumālattanena sadisāti porī, tāya poriyā. Vissaṭṭhāyāti apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭhavilambitādidosarahitāya.
analyzed: sukhumā ālattanena sadisā ati porī tāya poriyā vissaṭṭhāya ati apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭha vilambita ādi dosa rahitāya
translated: he is one who is not obstructed, not delayed, not slow, in his speech, thus he is not slow in speech.

original: Anelagalāyāti elagaḷenavirahitāya. Yassa kassaci hi kathentassa elā gaḷanti, lālā
analyzed: anelagalāya ati yassa kassaci hi kathentassa elāḥ gaḷanti lālā
translated: He is one who is not stammering, thus he is not stammering. For when anyone speaks, his tongue may stammer,

original: vā paggharanti, kheḷaphusitāni vā nikkhamanti, tassa vācā elagaḷaṃ nāma hoti, tabbiparitāyāti
analyzed: vā paggharanti kheḷa phusitāni vā nikkhamanti tassa vācā elagaḷam nāma hoti tat biparitāya ati
translated: his saliva may drip, or his mouth may water, and then his speech is called stammering. The meaning is that he is the opposite of that.

original: attho. Atthassa viññāpaniyāti ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā bhāsitatthassa viññāpanasamatthāya.
analyzed: atthaḥ atthassa viññāpaniyā ti ādi majjha pariyosānam pākaṭam katvā bhāsita tthassa viññāpana samatthāya
translated: He is one who is able to make known the meaning, thus he is able to make known the meaning, by speaking so that the beginning, middle, and end are clear.

original: Jiṇṇoti jarājiṇṇatāya jiṇṇo. Vuddhoti aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ vuddhibhāvamariyādappatto.
analyzed: jiṇṇaḥ ti jarā jiṇṇa tāya jiṇṇaḥ vuddhaḥ ti aṅga paccaṅgānam vuddhi bhāva mariyāda patto
translated: He is one who is aged, thus he is aged, by reason of his agedness. He is one who is advanced in years, thus he is advanced in years, by reason of his having reached the limit of the growth of his limbs and faculties.

original: Mahallakoti jātimahallakatāya samannāgato. Cirakālappasutoti vuttaṃ hoti. Addhagatoti
analyzed: mahallako ti jāti mahallaka tāya samannāgato cira kāla ppasuto ti vuttam hoti addha gato ti
translated: He is old in the sense of being long-lived, that is, he has lived a long time. He is advanced in age:

original: addhānaṃ gato, dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe atītoti adhippāyo. Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ
analyzed: addhānam gataḥ dve tayo rāja parivaṭṭe atītaḥ iti adhippāyaḥ vayaḥ anuppatto ti pacchima vayam
translated: he has reached the end of his life, that is, he has passed through two or three royal generations. He has reached the last stage of life:

original: sampatto, pacchimavayo nāma vassasatassa pacchimo tatiyabhāgo.
analyzed: sampatto pacchimavayaḥ nāma vassa satassa pacchimaḥ tatiya bhāgo
translated: he has reached the last third of his life. He is aged:🔽he is old, that is, he has lived a long time in the family lineage. He is mature:

original: Api ca jiṇṇoti porāṇo, cirakālappavattakulanvayoti vuttaṃ hoti. Vuddhoti sīlācārādiguṇavuddhiyā🔽yutto. Mahallakoti vibhavamahantāya samannāgato. Addhagatoti maggappaṭipanno brāhmaṇānaṃ
analyzed: api ca jiṇṇo ti porāṇo cira kāla ppavatta kula anvayo ti vuttam hoti vuddhaḥ iti sīla ācāra ādi guṇa vuddhiyā  yuttaḥ mahallako ti vibhava mahantāya samannāgataḥ addhagato ti magga ppaṭipannaḥ brāhmaṇānaṃ
translated: he is endowed with the maturity of such qualities as virtue and conduct. He is venerable:🔽he is endowed with the greatness of wealth. He is advanced in years:

original: vatacariyādimariyādaṃ avītikkamma caraṇasīlo. Vayoanuppattoti jātivuddhabhāvampi
analyzed: a vītikkamma caraṇa sīlaḥ vayaḥ anuppatto ti jāti vuddha bhāvam pi
translated: he is endowed with the virtue of conduct in accordance with the rules of the brahmins, without transgressing the bounds of the brahmins’ conduct. He has reached the last stage of life:

original: antimavayaṃ anuppatto.
analyzed: antima vayam an uppatto
translated: he has reached the last stage of life, the last third of his life.

original: Buddhaguṇakathā
analyzed: buddha guṇa kathā
translated: The Buddha’s Qualities

original: 304. Evaṃ vutteti evaṃ tehi brāhmaṇehi vutte. Soṇadaṇḍo – “ime brāhmaṇā jātiādīhi
analyzed: evam vuttā iti evam tehi brāhmaṇehi vutte soṇadaṇḍaḥ ime brāhmaṇāḥ jāti ādīhi
translated: When this was said: when this was said by those brahmins.

original: mama vaṇṇaṃ vadanti, na kho pana metaṃ yuttaṃ attano vaṇṇe rajjituṃ. Handāhaṃ etesaṃ
analyzed: mama vaṇṇam vadanti na kho pana mā etam yuttam attanaḥ vaṇṇe rajjitum handa aham etesam
translated: They praise me, but it is not proper for me to be conceited about my own praise. Let me rather🔽

original: vādaṃ bhinditvā samaṇassa gotamassa mahantabhāvaṃ ñāpetvā etesaṃ tattha gamanaṃ karomī”ti
analyzed: vādam bhinditvā samaṇassa gotamassa mahanta bhāvam ñāpetvā etesam tattha gamanam karomi iti
translated: “They praise me, but it is not proper for me to be conceited about my own praise. Let me break their argument and make them understand the greatness of the recluse Gotama and make them go to him.”

original: cintetvā tena hi – bho mamapi suṇāthātiādimāha. Tattha yepi ubhato sujātoti ādayo
analyzed: cintetvā tena hi bho mama api suṇātha ati ādim āha tattha ye pi ubhatas ādayaḥ
translated: Thinking thus, he said: “Well then, listen to me too.” Herein, the qualities beginning with “born on both sides of a pure family,”

original: attano guṇehi sadisā guṇā tepi; “ko cāhaṃ ke ca samaṇassa gotamassa jātisampattiādayo
analyzed: attanaḥ guṇehi sadisāḥ guṇā te api kaḥ ca aham ke ca samaṇassa gotamassa jāti sampatti ādayaḥ
translated: are similar to his own qualities. “Who am I and what are the qualities of the recluse Gotama’s noble birth, etc.,

original: guṇā”ti attano guṇehi uttaritareyeva maññamāno, itare pana ekanteneva bhagavato mahantabhāvadīpanatthaṃ pakāseti.
analyzed: attanaḥ guṇehi maññamānaḥ itare pana ekantena iva bhagavataḥ mahanta bhāva dīpana attham pakāseti
translated: thinking thus, he considers his own qualities to be superior to those of the recluse Gotama. The other qualities are proclaimed by him to show the greatness of the Blessed One alone.

original: Mayameva arahāmāti evaṃ niyāmentovettha idaṃ dīpeti – “yadi guṇamahantatāya upasaṅkamitabbo
analyzed: mayam eva arahāma iti evam idam dīpeti yadi guṇa mahanta tāya upasaṅkamitabbaḥ
translated: “We alone are worthy of offerings” – thus, he is bent on this. Herein, this is shown: “If one is to be approached because of the greatness of his qualities,

original: nāma hoti. Yathā hi sineruṃ upanidhāya sāsapo, mahāsamuddaṃ upanidhāya gopadakaṃ,
analyzed: nāma hoti yathā hi sinerum upanidhāya sāsapaḥ mahā samuddam upanidhāya go padakam
translated: just as a jujube tree in comparison with Sineru, a drop of water in comparison with the great ocean,

original: sattasu mahāsaresu udakaṃ upanidhāya ussāvabindu paritto lāmako. Evameva samaṇassa
analyzed: sattasu mahā saresu udakam upanidhāya ussāva bindu parittaḥ lāmakaḥ evam eva samaṇassa
translated: and the water in the seven great lakes is but a little mouthful compared with the water in the great ocean. So it is with the good deeds of a monk.

original: gotamassa jātisampattiādayopi guṇe upanidhāya amhākaṃ guṇā parittā lāmakā; tasmā
analyzed: gotamassa jāti sampatti ādayaḥ api guṇe upanidhāya amhākam guṇā parittā lāmakā tasmā
translated: In the same way, when our qualities are compared with the qualities of the ascetic Gotama, such as his perfect birth, etc., our qualities are few and insignificant. Therefore

original: mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitu”nti.
analyzed: mayam eva arahāma tam bhavantam gotamam dassanāya upasaṅkamitun ti
translated: we alone are worthy to go and see the Lord Gotama.”

original: Mahantaṃ ñātisaṃghaṃ ohāyāti mātipakkhe asītikulasahassāni, pitipakkhe asītikulasahassānīti evaṃ saṭṭhikulasatasahassaṃ ohāya pabbajito.
analyzed: mahantam ñāti saṃgham ohāya ati māti pakkhe asīti kula sahassāni piti pakkhe asīti kula sahassāni iti evam saṭṭhi kula sata sahassam ohāya pabbajitaḥ
translated: “Having abandoned a great retinue of kinsmen”: he went forth having abandoned a retinue of kinsmen on his mother’s side consisting of eighty thousand families and a retinue of kinsmen on his father’s side consisting of eighty thousand families, thus having abandoned a retinue of six hundred and forty thousand families.

original: Bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhañcāti ettha rājaṅgaṇe ceva uyyāne ca sudhāmaṭṭhapokkharaṇiyo
analyzed: bhūmi gatañca vehāsaṭṭhañca ati ettha rājaṅgaṇe ca iva uyyāne ca sudhā maṭṭha pokkharaṇiyo
translated: “Both on the ground and in the air”: here, the wealth placed on the ground in the royal compound and in the pleasure park,

original: sattaratanānaṃ pūretvā bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapitaṃ dhanaṃ bhūmigataṃ nāma. Pāsādaniyūhādayo
analyzed: pūretvā bhūmiyam ṭhapitam dhanam bhūmigatam nāma pāsāda niyūha ādayaḥ
translated: in the lotus ponds filled with the seven kinds of precious substances, is called “on the ground.” The wealth placed in the palaces, etc.,

original: paripūretvā ṭhapitaṃ vehāsaṭṭhaṃ nāma. Etaṃ tāva kulapariyāyena āgataṃ. Tathāgatassa
analyzed: paripūretvā ṭhapitam vehāsaṭṭham nāma etam tāva kula pariyāyena āgatam tathāgatassa
translated: after filling them up, is called “in the air.” This is the wealth that came to him by way of his family. The wealth that came to him by way of his Tathāgata-hood

original: pana jātadivaseyeva saṅkho, elo, uppalo, puṇḍarīkoti cattāro nidhayo uggatā. Tesu
analyzed: pana jāta divasā iya iva saṅkhaḥ elaḥ uppalo puṇḍarīkaḥ iti cattāro nidhayaḥ uggatā tesu
translated: but on the day of his birth four treasures appeared, called Saṅkha, Eḷaka, Uppala, and Puṇḍarīka.

original: saṅkho gāvutiko, elo aḍḍhayojaniko, uppalo tigāvutiko, puṇḍarīko yojaniko. Tesupi
analyzed: saṅkhaḥ gāvutikaḥ elaḥ aḍḍha yojanikaḥ uppalaḥ ti gāvutikaḥ puṇḍarīkaḥ yojanikaḥ tesu pi
translated: The Saṅkha treasure was worth a hundred thousand, the Eḷaka treasure a hundred leagues, the Uppala treasure a thousand leagues, and the Puṇḍarīka treasure fifty leagues.🔽And whatever was taken out of them was replenished,

original: gahitaṃ gahitaṃ pūratiyeva, iti bhagavā pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajitoti veditabbo.🔽Daharova samānoti taruṇova samāno. Susukāḷakesoti suṭṭhu kāḷakeso, añjanavaṇṇasadisakeso
analyzed: gahitam gahitam pūratiyā iva iti bhagavā pahūtam hirañña suvaṇṇam ohāya pabbajito ti veditabbaḥ  daharaḥ uva samāno ti taruṇaḥ uva samāno susu kāḷa keso ti suṭṭhu kāḷa keso añjana vaṇṇa sadisa keso
translated: and so it should be understood that the Blessed One went forth leaving behind him abundant gold and silver.🔽While still young: while still a youth. With beautiful black hair: with hair the colour of collyrium.

original: hutvā vāti attho. Bhadrenāti bhaddakena. Paṭhamena vayasāti tiṇṇaṃ vayānaṃ paṭhamavayena.
analyzed: hutvā vā ati attho bhadrena ati bhaddakena paṭhamena vayasā ati tiṇṇam vayānam paṭhama vayena
translated: The meaning is: having become. With a good complexion: with a good colour. In the first stage of life: in the first of the three stages of life.

original: Akāmakānanti anicchamānānaṃ. Anādaratthe sāmivacanaṃ. Assūni mukhe etesanti assumukhā,
analyzed: a kāmakānam an icchamānānam an ādara atthe sāmi vacanam assūni mukhe assu mukhā
translated: Of those who did not want: of those who did not wish. The word “master” is in the locative case. With tears on their faces: with tears in their eyes.

original: tesaṃ assumukhānaṃ, assūhi kilinnamukhānanti attho. Rudantānanti kanditvā rodamānānaṃ.
analyzed: tesam assu mukhānam assūhi kilinna mukhānam ti attho rudantānam ati kanditvā rodamānānam
translated: The meaning is: with their faces wet with tears. Of those who were weeping: of those who were weeping, having wept.

original: Akhuddāvakāsoti ettha bhagavato aparimāṇoyeva dassanāya okāsoti veditabbo.
analyzed: ettha bhagavataḥ aparimāṇaḥ yeva dassanāya okāsaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: Without having left a trace: here it should be understood that there was no opportunity for anyone to see the Blessed One.

original: Tatridaṃ vatthu – rājagahe kira aññataro brāhmaṇo samaṇassa gotamassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ
analyzed: tatra idam vatthu rājagahe kira aññataraḥ brāhmaṇaḥ samaṇassa gotamassa pamāṇam gahetum
translated: Here is the story. In Rājagaha, it seems, a certain brahman had heard that he was unable to measure the Blessed One.🔽So when the Blessed One entered the city for alms, he took a bamboo pole sixty cubits long,

original: na sakkotīti sutvā bhagavato piṇḍāya pavisanakāle saṭṭhihatthaṃ veḷuṃ gahetvā nagaradvārassa🔽bahi ṭhatvā sampatte bhagavati veḷuṃ gahetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi. Veḷu bhagavato jāṇukamattaṃ
analyzed: na sakkoti iti sutvā bhagavato piṇḍāya pavisana kāle saṭṭhi hattham veḷum gahetvā nagara dvārassa  bahi ṭhatvā sampatte bhagavati veḷum gahetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi veḷu bhagavataḥ jāṇuka mattam
translated: stood outside the city gate,🔽and when the Blessed One arrived, he took the bamboo pole and stood near him. The bamboo pole reached only to the Blessed One’s knee.

original: pāpuṇi. Puna divase dve veḷū ghaṭetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi. Bhagavāpi dvinnaṃ veḷūnaṃ upari
analyzed: pāpuṇi puna divase dve veḷū ghaṭetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi bhagavā api dvinnam veḷūnam upari
translated: The next day he joined two bamboo poles together and stood near him. The Blessed One appeared to be only as high as the two bamboo poles.

original: kaṭimattameva paññāyamāno – “brāhmaṇa, kiṃ karosī”ti āha. Tumhākaṃ pamāṇaṃ gaṇhāmīti.
analyzed: kaṭimattam eva paññāyamānaḥ brāhmaṇa kim karosi iti āha tumhākam pamāṇam gaṇhāmi iti
translated: “Brahman, what are you doing?” “I am measuring you.”

original: “Brāhmaṇa, sacepi tvaṃ sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ pūretvā ṭhite veḷū ghaṭetvā āgamissasi,🔽neva me pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ sakkhissasi. Na hi mayā cattāri asaṅkhyeyāni kappasatasahassañca
analyzed: brāhmaṇa sace api tvam sakala cakkavāḷa gabbham pūretvā ṭhite veḷū ghaṭetvā āgamissasi  na iva me pamāṇam gahetum sakkhissasi na hi mayā cattāri asaṅkhyeyāni kappa sata sahassam ca
translated: “Brahman, even if you came with bamboo poles filling the whole womb of the world joined together,🔽you would not be able to measure me. For, brahman, I have fulfilled the perfections for four incalculable ages and a hundred thousand aeons

original: tathā pāramiyo pūritā, yathā me paro pamāṇaṃ gaṇheyya, atulo, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato
analyzed: tathā pāramiyaḥ pūritā yathā me paras pamāṇam gaṇheyya atulaḥ brāhmaṇa tathāgataḥ
translated: in such a way that no one can measure me. The Tathāgata is incomparable, brahman,

original: appameyyo”ti vatvā dhammapade gāthamāha –
analyzed: appameyyā iti vatvā dhammapade gātham āha
translated: and he spoke this verse in the Dhammapada:

original: “Te tādise pūjayato, nibbute akutobhaye;
analyzed: te tādise pūjayataḥ nibbute akutobhaye
translated: “For one who worships such as these, the extinguished, the fearless,

original: Na sakkā puññaṃ saṅkhātuṃ, imettamapi kenacī”ti. ;
analyzed: na sakkā puññam saṅkhātum kenaci iti
translated: No one can calculate the merit, even with a portion of it.”

original: Gāthāpariyosāne caturāsītipāṇasahassāni amataṃ piviṃsu.
analyzed: gāthā pariyosāne catur asīti pāṇa sahassāni amatam piviṃsu
translated: At the conclusion of the verse, eighty-four thousand beings drank the deathless.

original: Aparampi vatthu – rāhu kira asurindo cattāri yojanasahassāni aṭṭha ca yojanasatāni
analyzed: aparam pi vatthu rāhu kira asurindo cattāri yojana sahassāni aṭṭha ca yojana satāni
translated: Another story: Rāhu, it seems, the lord of the asuras, was four thousand and eight hundred leagues high,

original: ucco. Bāhantaramassa dvādasayojanasatāni. Bahalantarena cha yojanasatāni. Hatthatalapādatalānaṃ
analyzed: uccas dvādasa yojana satāni bahalantarena cha yojana satāni
translated: and his mouth was twelve hundred leagues wide. Inside his mouth it was six hundred leagues. The palms of his hands and the soles of his feet were

original: puthulato tīṇi yojanasatāni. Aṅgulipabbāni paṇṇāsayojanāni. Bhamukantaraṃ paṇṇāsayojanaṃ.
analyzed: puthulataḥ tīṇi yojana satāni aṅguli pabbāni paṇṇāsa yojanāni bhamuka ntaram paṇṇāsa yojanam
translated: three hundred leagues across. His fingers and toes were fifty leagues long. The space between his jaws was fifty leagues.

original: Mukhaṃ dviyojanasataṃ tiyojanasatagambhīraṃ tiyojanasataparimaṇḍalaṃ. Gīvā tiyojanasataṃ.
analyzed: mukham dvi yojana satam ti yojana sata gambhīram ti yojana sata parimaṇḍalam gīvā ti yojana satam
translated: His mouth was two hundred leagues wide and three hundred leagues deep and three hundred leagues in circumference. His neck was three hundred leagues.

original: Nalāṭaṃ tiyojanasataṃ. Sīsaṃ navayojanasataṃ. “So ahaṃ uccosmi, satthāraṃ onamitvā
analyzed: nalāṭam ti yojana satam sīsam nava yojana satam saḥ aham uccā asmi satthāram onamitvā
translated: His forehead was three hundred leagues. His head was nine hundred leagues. “I am tall,” he thought, “and I can bow down to the Teacher and

original: oloketuṃ na sakkhissāmī”ti cintetvā nāgacchi. So ekadivasaṃ bhagavato vaṇṇaṃ sutvā
analyzed: oloketum na sakkhissāmi iti cintetvā na agacchi saḥ eka divasam bhagavataḥ vaṇṇam sutvā
translated: “I shall not be able to look at him.” And he did not go. But one day he heard the Exalted One being praised,

original: – “yathākathañca olokessāmī”ti āgato.
analyzed: yathā kathañca olokessāmi iti āgataḥ
translated: and he thought, “I shall look at him somehow or other.” And he came.

original: Atha bhagavā tassajjhāsayaṃ viditvā – “catūsu iriyāpathesu katarena dassessāmī”ti
analyzed: atha bhagavā tassa ajjhāsayam viditvā catūsu iriyāpathesu katarena dassessāmi iti
translated: Then the Exalted One, knowing his intention, thought, “In which of the four postures shall I show myself to him?”

original: cintetvā “ṭhitako nāma nīcopi ucco viya paññāyati. Nipannovassa attānaṃ dassessāmī”ti
analyzed: cintetvā ṭhitakaḥ nāma nīcaḥ api uccaḥ viya paññāyati attānam dassessāmi iti
translated: And he thought, “One who stands seems to be too lofty. I shall show myself to him while lying down.”

original: “ānanda, gandhakuṭipariveṇe mañcakaṃ paññāpehī”ti vatvā tattha sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi.
analyzed: ānanda gandhakuṭi pariveṇe mañcakam paññāpehi iti vatvā tattha sīha seyyam kappesi
translated: “Ānanda,” he said, “have a couch prepared in the courtyard of the Perfumed Chamber.” And he lay down on his right side in the lion posture.

original: Rāhu āgantvā nipannaṃ bhagavantaṃ gīvaṃ unnāmetvā nabhamajjhe puṇṇacandaṃ viya ullokesi.
analyzed: rāhu āgantvā nipannam bhagavantam gīvam unnāmetvā nabha majjhe puṇṇa candam viya ullokesi
translated: Rāhu came and looked at the Exalted One lying down, his neck upraised, like the full moon in the middle of the sky.🔽“What is this, lord of the asuras?”

original: Kimidaṃ asurindāti ca vutte – “bhagavā onamitvā oloketuṃ na sakkhissāmī”ti nāgacchinti.
analyzed: kim idam asurinda iti ca vutte bhagavā onamitvā oloketum na sakkhissāmi iti na āgacchinti
translated: “I came because I thought, ‘I shall not be able to look at the Exalted One while he is lying down with his head lowered.’“

original: Na mayā, asurinda, adhomukhena pāramiyo pūritā. Uddhaggameva katvā dānaṃ dinnanti.
analyzed: na mayā asurinda adhomukhena pāramiyaḥ pūritāḥ uddhaggam eva katvā dānam dinnanti
translated: “Lord of the asuras, I did not perfect the pāramīs with my head lowered. I gave gifts only after raising them up.”

original: Taṃ divasaṃ rāhu saraṇaṃ agamāsi. Evaṃ bhagavā akhuddāvakāso dassanāya.🔽Catupārisuddhisīlena sīlavā, taṃ pana sīlaṃ ariyaṃ uttamaṃ parisuddhaṃ. Tenāha –
analyzed: tam divasam rāhu saraṇam agamāsi evam bhagavā a khudda avakāsaḥ dassanāya  catu pārisuddhi sīlena sīlavā tam pana sīlam ariyam uttamam parisuddham tena āha
translated: On that day Rāhu went for refuge. Thus the Blessed One is not lacking in opportunities to be seen.

original: “ariyasīlī”ti. Tadetaṃ anavajjaṭṭhena kusalaṃ. Tenāha – “kusalasīlī”ti. Kusalasīlenāti idamassa vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: ariya sīlī iti tat etam anavajja ṭṭhena kusalam tena āha kusala sīlī iti kusala sīlena ati idam assa vevacanam
translated: He is virtuous in virtue purified by the fourfold purity. But that virtue is noble and supreme. Therefore he is called “virtuous in noble virtue.” That virtue is skillful in the sense of being blameless. Therefore he is called “virtuous in skillful virtue.” Virtuous in skillful virtue is a synonym for that.

original: Bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyoti bhagavato ekekāya dhammadesanāya caturāsītipāṇasahassāni
analyzed: bahūnam bhagavato ekekāya dhamma desanāya catur āsīti pāṇa sahassāni
translated: He is the teacher of many, the trainer of many. In each discourse of the Blessed One, 84,000 beings

original: aparimāṇāpi devamanussā maggaphalāmataṃ pivanti, tasmā bahūnaṃ ācariyo. Sāvakaveneyyānaṃ pana pācariyoti.
analyzed: deva manussāḥ magga phala amatam pivanti tasmā bahūnam ācariyo sāvaka veneyyānam pana pācariyo ti
translated: and countless gods and men drink the taste of the paths and fruits. Therefore he is the teacher of many. But he is the trainer of many disciples who are to be trained.

original: Khīṇakāmarāgoti ettha kāmaṃ bhagavato sabbepi kilesā khīṇā. Brāhmaṇo pana te na jānāti.
analyzed: khīṇa kāma rāgaḥ ti ettha kāmam bhagavato sabbe pi kilesā khīṇā brāhmaṇaḥ pana te na jānāti
translated: He has destroyed the lusts. Herein, although all the defilements of the Blessed One are destroyed, the brahmin does not know that.

original: Attano jānanaṭṭhāneyeva guṇaṃ katheti. Vigatacāpalloti – “pattamaṇḍanā cīvaramaṇḍanā
analyzed: attanaḥ jānana ṭṭhāneyā iva guṇam kathā iti vigata cāpallā iti patta maṇḍanā cīvara maṇḍanā

original: senāsanamaṇḍanā imassa vā pūtikāyassa…pe… kelanā paṭikelanā”ti evaṃ vuttacāpallā virahito.

translated: He is free from the vanity of adorning a dwelling, etc., which is described in the way beginning, “When he sees a lodging, a bhikkhu is not excited by it … he does not adorn it or have it adorned” .

analyzed: apāpa purekkhāro ti apāpe nava lokuttara dhamme puratas katvā vicarati brahmaññāya pajāyāti
translated: He goes with the thought of good: he goes with the thought of the nine supramundane states that are good .

translated: With the thought of the brahmin class: with the thought of the brahmin class consisting of such men as Sariputta, Moggallana, Kassapa, etc. He goes with the thought of that class and with the thought of the class of brahmins.

analyzed: khattiya paṇḍita ādayo ca iva deva brahma nāga gandhabba ādayo ca pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā  pucchissāma ati āgacchanti tattha keci pucchāya vā dosam vissajjana sampaṭicchane
translated: and the wise of the warrior-nobles, etc., and the gods, Brahmas, serpents, and gandhabbas, etc., came to ask questions after having prepared them.

original: vā asamatthataṃ sallakkhetvā apucchitvāva tuṇhī nisīdanti. Keci pucchanti. Kesañci🔽bhagavā pucchāya ussāhaṃ janetvā vissajjeti. Evaṃ sabbesampi tesaṃ vimatiyo tīraṃ
analyzed: vā a samatthatam sallakkhetvā a pucchitvā ava tuṇhī nisīdanti keci pucchanti kesañci  bhagavā pucchāya ussāham janetvā vissajjeti evam sabbesam pi tesam vimatiyaḥ tīram
translated: There some, after having discerned the fault in the question or their own inability to answer, sat down in silence without asking a question. Some asked questions.

original: patvā mahāsamuddassa ūmiyo viya bhagavantaṃ patvā bhijjanti.
analyzed: patvā mahā samuddassa ūmiyaḥ viya bhagavantam patvā bhijjanti
translated: The Blessed One answered some after arousing their enthusiasm. Thus all their doubts were broken up by the Blessed One, like the waves of the great ocean that have reached the shore.

original: Ehi svāgatavādīti devamanussapabbajitagahaṭṭhesu taṃ taṃ attano santikaṃ āgataṃ –🔽“ehi svāgata”nti evaṃ vadatīti attho. Sakhiloti tattha katamaṃ sākhalyaṃ? “Yā sā
analyzed: ehi svāgata vādī iti deva manussa pabbajita gahaṭṭhesu tam tam attanaḥ santikam āgatam  ehi svāgatam ti evam vadati iti attho tattha katamam sākhalyam yā sā
translated: He who speaks kindly, welcoming: the meaning is, he who speaks thus, “Come, you are welcome,” to those who come to him from among the gods, men, those gone forth, and householders.

original: vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā”tiādinā nayena vuttasākhalyena samannāgato, muduvacanoti attho.
analyzed: vācā na ilā kaṇṇa sukhā ati ādinā nayena vutta sākhalyena samannāgataḥ mudu vacanā ti attho
translated: He is gentle: what is gentleness here? It is gentleness possessed of the gentleness stated in the way beginning, “Speech that is polished, that is refined” . The meaning is, he is one who speaks softly.

original: Sammodakoti paṭisanthārakusalo, āgatāgatānaṃ catunnaṃ parisānaṃ – “kacci, bhikkhave,
analyzed: sammodakaḥ ti paṭisanthāra kusalaḥ āgata āgatānam catunnam parisānam kacci bhikkhave
translated: Sammodako : skilled in welcoming, skilled in counter-speech, skilled in making all who come to him, the four assemblies, feel at ease by saying, “I trust it is well with you, bhikkhus,

original: khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīya”ntiādinā nayena sabbaṃ addhānadarathaṃ vūpasamento viya🔽paṭhamataraṃ sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ kattāti attho. Abbhākuṭikoti yathā ekacce parisaṃ🔽patvā thaddhamukhā saṅkuṭitamukhā honti, na ediso, parisadassanena panassa bālātapasamphassena🔽viya padumaṃ mukhapadumaṃ vikasati puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ hoti. Uttānamukhoti yathā
analyzed: khamanīyam kacci yāpanīya nti ādinā nayena sabbam addhānada ratham vūpasamentaḥ viya  paṭhamataram sammodanīyam katham kattā ati attho abbhākuṭikā iti yathā ekacce parisam  saṅkuṭita mukhāḥ honti na edisaḥ parisa dassanena panassa bāla ātapa samphassena  viya padumam mukha padumam vikasati puṇṇa canda sassirikam hoti yathā
translated: I trust you are all quite comfortable,” and so on.🔽Abbhākuṭiko : unlike some who, when they come to an assembly, are stiff-faced and downcast, he is not like that. When he sees an assembly, his lotus face, like a lotus touched by the rays of the sun, opens up and becomes radiant like the full moon.

original: ekacce nikujjitamukhā viya sampattāya parisāya na kiñci kathenti, atidullabhakathā🔽honti, na evarūpo. Samaṇo pana gotamo sulabhakatho. Na tassa santikaṃ āgatāgatānaṃ
analyzed: ekacce nikujjita mukhāḥ sampattāya parisāya na kiñci kathenti ati dullabha kathā  honti na evarūpaḥ samaṇaḥ pana gotamo sulabha katho na tassa santikam āgata āgatānam
translated: Uttānamukho : unlike some who, when an assembly has come, do not say anything, as if their faces were bent down, and are very difficult to talk to, he is not like that.

original: – “kasmā mayaṃ idhāgatā”ti vippaṭisāro uppajjati dhammaṃ pana sutvā attamanāva hontīti
analyzed: kasmai mayam idha āgatā ati vippaṭisāraḥ uppajjati dhammam pana sutvā atta manāḥ va honti iti
translated: The recluse Gotama is easy to talk to. When people come to him, they do not feel remorse, thinking, “Why did we come here?” but after hearing the Dhamma they are satisfied.

original: dasseti. Pubbabhāsīti bhāsanto ca paṭhamataraṃ bhāsati, tañca kho kālayuttaṃ pamāṇayuttaṃ
analyzed: dasseti pubbabhāsī iti bhāsantaḥ ca paṭhamataram bhāsati tat ca kho kāla yuttam pamāṇa yuttam
translated: He shows. He speaks first: when he speaks, he speaks first, and he speaks at the right time, in a way that is appropriate,

original: atthanissitameva bhāsati, na niratthakakathaṃ.🔽Na tasmiṃ gāme vāti yattha kira bhagavā paṭivasati, tattha mahesakkhā devatā ārakkhaṃ
analyzed: attha nissitam eva bhāsati na niratthaka katham  na tasmin gāme vāti yattha kira bhagavā paṭivasati tattha mahesakkhāḥ devatāḥ ārakkham
translated: and he speaks with reference to the meaning, not with meaningless talk.

original: gaṇhanti, taṃ nissāya manussānaṃ upaddavo na hoti, paṃsupisācakādayoyeva hi manusse🔽viheṭhenti, te tāsaṃ ānubhāvena dūraṃ apakkamanti. Api ca bhagavato mettābalenapi
analyzed: gaṇhanti tam nissāya manussānam upaddavaḥ na hoti hi manusse  viheṭhenti te tāsam ānubhāvena dūram apakkamanti api ca bhagavataḥ mettā balena api
translated: There is no danger for the people there, due to that, and because of the powerful deities who take up their position there where the Blessed One is staying. For it is only pisāca spirits and so on that harass people,

original: na amanussā manusse viheṭhenti.🔽Saṅghītiādīsu anusāsitabbo sayaṃ vā uppādito saṅgho assa atthīti saṅghī. Tādiso cassa🔽gaṇo atthīti gaṇī. Purimapadasseva vā vevacanametaṃ. Ācārasikkhāpanavasena gaṇassa
analyzed: na amanussā manusse viheṭhenti  saṅghī iti ādīsu anusāsitabbaḥ sayam vā uppādito saṅghaḥ assa atthi iti saṅghī tādiso cassa  gaṇaḥ atthi iti gaṇī purima padassa iva vā vevacanam etam ācāra sikkhāpana vasena gaṇassa
translated: and they go far away because of the power of those deities. Moreover, it is because of the Blessed One’s power of loving-kindness that non-human beings do not harass human beings.

original: ācariyoti gaṇācariyo. Puthutitthakarānanti bahūnaṃ titthakarānaṃ. Yathā vā tathā
analyzed: ācariyo ti bahūnam titthakara ānam yathā vā tathā
translated: In the case of the words saṅghī, etc., he has a saṅgha that is to be advised or that he has himself aroused, thus he is saṅghī. He has such a following, thus he is gaṇī. Or this is a synonym for the preceding word. He is a teacher of the following in the sense of training it in the practice of proper conduct, thus he is a gaṇācariya. Of many founders of sects: of many founders of other sects.

original: pucchati, idānissāhaṃ cittaṃ paritosetvā vissajjituṃ sakkuṇeyyaṃ vā na vā? Sace na

original: sakkhissaṃ paṭhamaṃ uppannāpi me lajjā bhijjissati. Asakkontassa pana na sakkomīti🔽vacane doso natthī”ti puna nivattitvā bhagavatoyeva bhāraṃ karonto “ettakaparamāva
analyzed: sakkhissam paṭhamam uppannā api me lajjā bhijjissati a sakkontassa pana na sakkomi iti  vacane dosaḥ natthi iti puna nivattitvā bhagavataḥ yā iva bhāram karontaḥ

original: maya”ntiādimāha. Tattha ettakaparamāti ettakaṃ sīlapaññāṇanti vacanameva paramaṃ
analyzed: maya nti ādim āha tattha ettaka paramā ti ettakam sīla paññāṇam ti vacanam eva paramam

original: amhākaṃ, te mayaṃ ettakaparamā, ito paraṃ etassa bhāsitassa atthaṃ na jānāmāti attho.🔽Athassa bhagavā sīlapaññāya mūlabhūtassa tathāgatassa uppādato pabhuti sīlapaññāṇaṃ
analyzed: amhākam te mayam ettaka paramāḥ itas param etassa bhāsitassa attham na jānāma ati attho  atha assa bhagavā sīla paññāya mūla bhūtassa tathāgatassa uppādataḥ pabhuti sīla paññāṇam
translated: We know no more than this. We do not know the meaning of the words spoken beyond this.

original: dassetuṃ – “idha brāhmaṇa, tathāgato”tiādimāha. Tassattho sāmaññaphale vuttanayeneva
analyzed: dassetum idha brāhmaṇa tathāgataḥ tiādim āha tassa atthaḥ sāmañña phale vutta nayena iva
translated: Then the Exalted One said, “Here, brahmin, the Tathagata,” etc., in order to show him the morality and wisdom that have existed since the arising of the Tathagata, which are the root of morality and wisdom. The meaning of this should be understood in the way already stated in the Fruits of asceticism .

original: veditabbo, ayaṃ pana viseso, idha tividhampi sīlaṃ – “idampissa hoti sīlasmi”nti
analyzed: veditabbaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ idha tividham pi sīlam idam pissa hoti sīlasmin ti

original: evaṃ sīlamicceva niyyātitaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīni cattāri jhānāni atthato paññāsampadā.
analyzed: evam sīlam iccā iva niyyātitam paṭhamajjhāna ādīni cattāri jhānāni atthato paññā sampadā

original: Evaṃ paññāvasena pana aniyyātetvā vipassanāpaññāya padaṭṭhānabhāvamattena dassetvā
analyzed: evam paññā vasena pana a niyyātetvā vipassanā paññāya padaṭṭhāna bhāva mattena dassetvā

original: vipassanāpaññāto paṭṭhāya paññā niyyātitāti.
analyzed: vipassanā paññātaḥ paṭṭhāya paññā niyyātitā ati

original: vijjamānaguṇehi sampahaṃsetvā dhammaratanavassaṃ vassitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi. Brāhmaṇo

analyzed: nāma tiṇṇam ṭhānānam aññatarasmim calanti handa aham imam rājānam tesu ṭhānesu paṭhamatarañca eva  niccalam karomi iti tena assa tissaḥ vidhāḥ desesi iti saḥ bhoto rañño ti idam karaṇa atthe  sāmi vacanam bhotā raññā ati vā pāṭhaḥ vippaṭisāraḥ na karaṇīyo ti bhogānam vigama hetuko  pacchā anutāpaḥ na kattabbaḥ pubba cetanā pana acalā patiṭṭhapetabbā evam hi dānam mahapphalam  hoti iti dasseti itaresu pi dvīsu ṭhānesu esā iva nayaḥ muñca cetanā api hi pacchā samanussaraṇa cetanā
translated: “They move in one of three ways. Let me make the king unmoving in these three ways before anyone else does.” So he taught him the three ways. “Your Majesty’s” : this is a genitive of purpose. Or the reading is “bhotā raññā” . “No regret” : he shows that “no regret, which is the cause for the loss of wealth, should be done, but the unmoving intention should be established beforehand. For in this way the giving becomes fruitful. “ The same method applies in the other two cases. For the intention to give is the intention to give at a later time.

original: ca niccalāva kātabbā. Tathā akarontassa dānaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti, nāpi uḷāresu bhogesu🔽cittaṃ namati, mahāroruvaṃ upapannassa seṭṭhigahapatino viya.
analyzed: ca niccalā ava kātabbā tathā a karontassa dānam na mahapphalam hoti nā api uḷāresu bhogesu  cittam namati mahā roruvam upapannassa seṭṭhi gahapatino viya
translated: “They waver in three places. Let me make the king unwaveringly fixed in these three places from the very beginning.” So he taught him the three conditions. So your majesty should not have regret: the expression “so your majesty” is a vocative used in the sense of the instrumental. Or the reading may be “bhotā raññā” . “You should not have regret” means that you should not have subsequent remorse as the cause for the loss of your wealth. But your original intention should be made unwaveringly firm, for in this way your giving will be fruitful and will bring great benefit. The same method applies to the other two places. For even the intention to give and the intention to remember should be made unwaveringly firm. If one does not do so, one’s giving will not be fruitful, and one’s mind will not incline to great wealth, as in the case of the treasurer who was reborn in the Mahāroruva hell.

original: 343. Dasahākārehīti dasahi kāraṇehi. Tassa kira evaṃ ahosi – sacāyaṃ rājā dussīle

translated: and seeing them he will think: “My gift will be lost, for such immoral people are eating it.” And he will be sorry even for the virtuous people who eat it. That is why he said, “He removed the remorse of the recipients by means of the ten aspects.”

translated: “Hired workers” are those who do the work after receiving wages. “Threatened workers” are those who are threatened with sticks, cudgels, etc., and are made to work with the words, “Work! For there is no one there who addresses another as “slave,” “hired worker,” or “threatened worker.” They address each other with endearment and respect, according to their age and seniority.

analyzed: hoti sampatta virati samādāna virati setughāta virati iti tattha yaḥ sikkhāpadāni a gahetvā api  kevalam attanaḥ jāti gotta kula apadesa ādīni anussaritvā na me idam patirūpanti pāṇa atipāta ādīni
translated: It is abstinence from killing living beings, etc., that has come about through the attainment of jhāna, and abstinence from killing living beings, etc., that has come about through undertaking precepts. Herein, abstinence from killing living beings, etc., that has come about through the attainment of jhāna is called “abstinence” only in the sense of non-transgression,🔽and abstinence from killing living beings, etc., that has come about through undertaking precepts is called “abstinence” in the sense of non-transgression and in the sense of restraint.🔽

original: na karoti, sampattavatthuṃ pariharati. Tato ārakā viramati. Tassa sā virati sampattaviratīti veditabbā.
analyzed: na karoti sampatta vatthum pariharati tatas ārakā viramati tassa sā virati sampatta viratī iti veditabbā
translated: It is abstinence from what is unwholesome by reason of attainment, by reason of undertaking, and by reason of crossing over the flood. Herein, abstinence from what is unwholesome by reason of attainment is abstinence from taking life, etc., in one who, without undertaking the precepts, abstains from them by reason of his own good dispositions, his own kindliness, his own gentleness, his own skillfulness, his own sense of conscience, his own sense of shame, his own nongreed, his own non-hate, his own non-delusion, his own wisdom, his own fear of wrongdoing, his own contentment, his own habit of using few things, his own habit of associating with good people, his own habit of listening to the True Idea, his own habit of wise attention, his own habit of the development of understanding, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ life, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ tradition, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ counsel, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ training, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ practice, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ state, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ attainment, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ realization, his own habit of the Noble Ones’ gnosis and his own habit of the Noble Ones’ penetration. He abstains from taking life, etc., because he thinks “This is not proper for me,” and he avoids the occasion for doing so. He abstains from a far. His abstinence should be understood as abstinence by reason of attainment.

original: “Ajjatagge jīvitahetupi pāṇaṃ na hanāmī”ti vā “pāṇātipātā viramāmī”ti vā “veramaṇiṃ samādiyāmī”ti vā evaṃ sikkhāpadāni gaṇhantassa pana virati samādānaviratīti veditabbā.
analyzed: pāṇam na hanāmi iti vā pāṇa atipātā viramāmi iti vā veramaṇim samādiyāmi iti vā evam sikkhāpadāni gaṇhantassa pana virati samādāna viratī iti veditabbā
translated: Abstinence by reason of undertaking is abstinence in one who undertakes the precepts thus “From this day forth life will be dear to me even as it is to others” or “I will abstain from taking life” or “I will undertake the training rule.”🔽Abstinence by crossing over the flood is the abstinence associated with the path in noble disciples.

original: Ariyasāvakānaṃ pana maggasampayuttā virati setughātavirati nāma. Tattha purimā dve
analyzed: ariya sāvakānam pana magga sampayuttā virati setughātavirati nāma tattha purimā dve
translated: Herein, the first two kinds of abstinence

original: viratiyo yaṃ voropanādivasena vītikkamitabbaṃ jīvitindriyādivatthu, taṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: viratiyaḥ yam voropana ādi vasena vītikkamitabbam jīvitindriya ādi vatthu tam ārammaṇam
translated: are concerned with the same physical basis as the life faculty, etc., that is to say, the material body, which is what is to be transgressed by such means as digging it up, etc.

original: katvā pavattanti. Pacchimā nibbānārammaṇāva. Ettha ca yo pañca sikkhāpadāni ekato
analyzed: katvā pavattanti pacchimā ettha ca yo pañca sikkhāpadāni ekatas
translated: and the last is the one that has Nibbāna as its object.

original: gaṇhati, tassa ekasmiṃ bhinne sabbāni bhinnāni honti. Yo ekekaṃ gaṇhati, so yaṃ vītikkamati,🔽tadeva bhijjati. Setughātaviratiyā pana bhedo nāma natthi, bhavantarepi hi ariyasāvako
analyzed: gaṇhati tassa ekasmin bhinne sabbāni bhinnāni honti yaḥ ekekam gaṇhati saḥ yam vītikkamati  tat eva bhijjati setu ghāta viratiyā pana bhedaḥ nāma natthi bhavantare pi hi ariya sāvako
translated: And here, if a man takes the five precepts all together, then if one is broken all are broken. If he takes them one by one, then whichever one he transgresses, that one is broken.

original: jīvitahetupi neva pāṇaṃ hanati na suraṃ pivati. Sacepissa surañca khīrañca missetvā🔽mukhe pakkhipanti, khīrameva pavisati, na surā. Yathā kiṃ? Koñcasakuṇānaṃ khīramissake
analyzed: na iva pāṇam hanati na suram pivati sace pissa suram ca khīram ca missetvā  mukhe pakkhipanti khīram eva pavisati na surā yathā kim koñca sakuṇānam khīra missake
translated: But there is no breaking of the abstention from taking intoxicants, for even in another existence a noble disciple does not kill a living thing or drink intoxicants even if it costs his life.🔽Even if they were to pour into his mouth a mixture of alcohol and milk, only the milk would enter him, not the alcohol.

original: udake khīrameva pavisati? Na udakaṃ. Idaṃ yonisiddhanti ce, idaṃ dhammatāsiddhanti
analyzed: udake khīram eva pavisati na udakam idam yoni siddhanti ce idam dhamma tā siddhanti
translated: Why is this? Because it is a natural law that the milk enters but the alcohol does not, just as in the case of the kapiñjala bird.🔽If you say that this is established by reasoning, it should be understood as established by the natural law of dhammas.🔽But since the making of the view decisive in the case of going for refuge is a weighty matter,

original: ca veditabbaṃ. Yasmā pana saraṇagamane diṭṭhiujukakaraṇaṃ nāma bhāriyaṃ. Sikkhāpadasamādāne
analyzed: ca veditabbam yasmā pana saraṇa gamane diṭṭhiujuka karaṇam nāma bhāriyam sikkhāpada samādāne
translated: and since the undertaking of the precepts is merely an abstention,

original: pana viratimattakameva. Tasmā etaṃ yathā vā tathā vā gaṇhantassāpi sādhukaṃ gaṇhantassāpi
analyzed: pana viratimattakam eva tasmai etam yathā vā tathā vā gaṇhantassa api sādhukam gaṇhantassa api
translated: therefore it is good for one who takes them thus or otherwise to take them well.

original: appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca. Pañcasīlasadisassa pana dānassa abhāvato ettha
analyzed: appaṭṭhataram ca pañca sīla sadisassa pana dānassa abhāvato ettha
translated: and it is less trouble and less of an effort. But because there is no gift equal to the Five Precepts,

original: mahapphalatā mahānisaṃsatā ca veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, dānāni mahādānāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni
analyzed: mahapphala tā mahā nisaṃsa tā ca veditabbā vuttam ha etam  pañcimāni bhikkhave dānāni mahādānāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni
translated: the great fruit and great advantage of this gift should be understood. For this is said:

original: asaṃkiṇṇāni asaṃkiṇṇapubbāni na saṅkiyanti na saṅkiyissanti appaṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi
analyzed: a saṃkiṇṇāni a saṃkiṇṇa pubbāni na saṅkiyanti na saṅkiyissanti a paṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these five gifts, great gifts, primal, of long standing, traditional, ancient, unadulterated, which are not open to suspicion, will never be open to suspicion, and are unfaulted by knowledgeable brahmans and contemplatives.

original: brāhmaṇehi viññūhi. Katamāni pañca? Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya🔽pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti. Pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako aparimāṇānaṃ🔽sattānaṃ abhayaṃ deti, averaṃ deti abyāpajjhaṃ deti. Aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ abhayaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇehi viññūhi katamāni pañca idha bhikkhave ariya sāvako pāṇātipātam pahāya  pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ bhikkhave ariyasāvako aparimāṇānam  sattānam abhayam deti a veram deti a byāpajjham deti aparimāṇānam sattānam abhayam
translated: What five? Here, bhikkhus, a noble disciple, having abandoned the destruction of life,🔽abides with his rod laid down, his weapon cast away, mindful, compassionate, and sympathetic for the welfare of all living beings.🔽By his giving them freedom from danger, freedom from animosity, and freedom from oppression,

original: datvā averaṃ datvā abyāpajjhaṃ datvā aparimāṇassa abhayassa averassa abyāpajjhassa
analyzed: datvā a veram datvā a byāpajjham datvā aparimāṇassa abhayassa a verassa a byāpajjhassa
translated: he gives to immeasurable beings freedom from danger, freedom from animosity, and freedom from oppression.

original: bhāgī hoti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ dānaṃ mahādānaṃ…pe… viññūhīti.
analyzed: bhāgī hoti idam bhikkhave paṭhamam dānam mahādānam pe viññūhi iti
translated: he is a partaker of the great giving. This, bhikkhus, is the first kind of giving, a great giving, … by the wise.

original: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako adinnādānaṃ pahāya…pe… kāmesumicchācāraṃ pahāya…pe…
analyzed: puna ca param bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ adinnādānam pahāyape kāmesu micchā ācāram pahāyape
translated: “Again, a noble disciple, abandoning false speech, abstains from false speech; … abandoning malicious speech, abstains from malicious speech; …

original: musāvādaṃ pahāya…pe… surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānaṃ pahāya…pe… imāni kho, bhikkhave,
analyzed: musāvādam pahāyape surā meraya majja pamāda ṭṭhānam pahāyape imāni kho bhikkhave
translated: abandoning harsh speech, abstains from harsh speech; … abandoning gossip, abstains from gossip; … abandoning covetousness, is uncovetous; … abandoning ill will and hatred, is without ill will and hatred; … abandoning wrong view, has right view.🔽These, bhikkhus, are the five kinds of giving, great gifts, foremost gifts, pure and lovely, untainted by the conceits,

original: pañca dānāni mahādānāni aggaññāni…pe… viññūhī”ti.
analyzed: pañca dānāni mahādānāni aggaññānipe viññūhi iti
translated: by the wise.”

original: Idañca pana sīlapañcakaṃ – “attasinehañca jīvitasinehañca pariccajitvā rakkhissāmī”ti
analyzed: idam ca pana sīla pañcakam atta sinehañca jīvita sinehañca pariccajitvā rakkhissāmi iti
translated: And this fivefold virtue is called a sacrifice because it is undertaken with the thought, “I shall keep it by relinquishing both self-love and love of the world.”

original: samādinnatāya yaññoti vuccati. Tattha kiñcāpi pañcasīlato saraṇagamanameva jeṭṭhakaṃ,
analyzed: samādinna tāya yaññā uti vuccati tattha kiñcā api pañca sīlato saraṇa gamanam eva jeṭṭhakam
translated: Herein, although the going for refuge is the most important thing in the five training precepts,

original: idaṃ pana saraṇagamaneyeva patiṭṭhāya rakkhitasīlavasena mahapphalanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam pana patiṭṭhāya rakkhita sīla vasena mahapphalanti vuttam
translated: it is said that this sacrifice is fruitful because of the virtue guarded by the support of the going for refuge.

original: 353. Idampi sutvā brāhmaṇo cintesi – “pañcasīlaṃ nāma rakkhituṃ garukaṃ, atthi nu
analyzed: idam pi sutvā brāhmaṇaḥ cintesi pañcasīlam nāma rakkhitum garukam atthi nu
translated: And when the brahmin heard this, he thought, “The five training precepts are difficult to keep. Are there any other precepts that are fruitful though easy to practice?”

original: kho aññaṃ kiñci īdisameva hutvā ito appaṭṭhatarañca mahapphalatarañcā”ti. Tato taṃ
analyzed: kho aññam kiñci īdisam eva hutvā itas appaṭṭhataram ca mahapphalataram ca ati tatas tam
translated: and there is nothing more fruitful than this, and nothing more profitable than this.”

original: pucchanto punapi – “atthi pana, bho gotamā”tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā tividhasīlapāripūriyaṃ
analyzed: pucchanto puna api atthi pana bho gotama ati ādim āha atha assa bhagavā tividha sīla pāripūriyam
translated: Then he asked, “But is there, Master Gotama?”

original: ṭhitassa paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ yaññānaṃ appaṭṭhatarañca mahapphalatarañca dassetukāmo
analyzed: ṭhitassa paṭhamajjhāna ādīnam yaññānam appaṭṭhatarañca mahapphalatarañca dassetu kāmo
translated: Then the Blessed One, desiring to show that the fulfilment of the threefold morality is more fruitful and less troublesome than the sacrifices,

original: buddhuppādato paṭṭhāya desanaṃ ārabhanto “idha brāhmaṇā”tiādimāha. Tattha yasmā heṭṭhā
analyzed: buddha uppādataḥ paṭṭhāya desanam ārabhantaḥ idha brāhmaṇa ati ādim āha tattha yasmā heṭṭhā
translated: began his teaching from the time of the Buddha Kassapa. He said, “Here, brahmin,”

original: vuttehi guṇehi samannāgato paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, paṭhamajjhānādīsu ṭhito dutiyajjhānādīni
analyzed: vuttehi guṇehi samannāgataḥ paṭhamam jhānam paṭhama jhāna ādīsu ṭhitaḥ dutiya jhāna ādīni
translated: Herein, since the first jhāna possesses the qualities stated above, and since one who is established in the first jhāna does not tire in producing the second jhāna, etc.,

original: nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā tāni appaṭṭhāni appasamārambhāni. Yasmā panettha paṭhamajjhānaṃ
analyzed: nibbattentaḥ na kilamati tasmā tāni appaṭṭhāni appasamārambhāni yasmā pana ittha paṭhamajjhānam
translated: therefore they are not troublesome, not requiring much effort. But since the first jhāna

original: ekaṃ kappaṃ brahmaloke āyuṃ deti. Dutiyaṃ aṭṭhakappe. Tatiyaṃ catusaṭṭhikappe. Catutthaṃ
analyzed: ekam kappam brahma loke āyum deti dutiyam aṭṭha kappe tatiyam catur aṭṭhi kappe catuttham
translated: gives life in the Brahmā-world for an eon, the second for eight eons, the third for sixty-four eons, the fourth

original: pañcakappasatāni. Tadeva ākāsānañcāyatanādisamāpattivasena bhāvitaṃ vīsati, cattālīsaṃ,
analyzed: pañca kappa satāni tat eva ākāsa anañcāyatana ādi samāpatti vasena bhāvitam vīsati cattālīsam
translated: and five hundred eons.🔽The same, when developed as the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space, gives a life-span of twenty thousand eons,

original: saṭṭhi, caturāsīti ca kappasahassāni āyuṃ deti; tasmā mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañca.
analyzed: ca kappa sahassāni āyum deti tasmai mahapphalataram ca mahā nisaṃsataram ca
translated: of forty thousand eons, of sixty thousand eons, and of eighty thousand eons. So it is more fruitful and more profitable.

original: Nīvaraṇādīnaṃ pana paccanīkānaṃ dhammānaṃ pariccattattā taṃ yaññanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ādīnam pana paccanīkānam dhammānam pariccatta ttā tam veditabbam
translated: And it should be understood that it is a sacrifice because it surrenders the opposing states beginning with the hindrances.

original: Vipassanāñāṇampi yasmā catutthajjhānapariyosānesu guṇesu patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇam pi yasmā catuttha jhāna pariyosānesu guṇesu patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na
translated: Also insight knowledge, when it arises established upon the special qualities that end in the fourth jhāna,

original: kilamati, tasmā appaṭṭhaṃ appasamārambhaṃ; vipassanāsukhasadisassa pana sukhassa
analyzed: kilamati tasmai appaṭṭham appa samārambham vipassanā sukha sadisassa pana sukhassa
translated: does not tire, thus it is not strenuous, not much to be done. But because there is no pleasure like that of insight,🔽it is fruitful. And it is a sacrifice because it surrenders the opposing states of defilement.

original: abhāvā mahapphalaṃ. Paccanīkakilesapariccāgato yaññoti. Manomayiddhipi yasmā vipassanāñāṇe
analyzed: abhāvā mahapphalam paccanīka kilesa pariccāgataḥ yasmai vipassanā ñāṇe
translated: Also the supernormal power of the mind-made body, when it arises established upon insight knowledge,

original: patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā appaṭṭhā appasamārambhā; attano sadisarūpanimmānasamatthatāya
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya nibbattentaḥ na kilamati tasmai appaṭṭhāḥ appa samārambhāḥ attano sadisa rūpa nimmāna samattha tāya
translated: does not tire, thus it is not strenuous, not much to be done. And because it is capable of creating a body like itself,

original: mahapphalā. Attano paccanīkakilesapariccāgato yañño. Iddhividhañāṇādīnipi yasmā manomayañāṇādīsu🔽patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā appaṭṭhāni appasamārambhāni, attano attano
analyzed: mahapphalāḥ attano paccanīka kilesa pariccāgataḥ iddhividha ñāṇa ādīni pi yasmā manas maya ñāṇa ādīsu  patiṭṭhāya nibbattentaḥ na kilamati tasmai appaṭṭhāni appa samārambhāni attanaḥ attanaḥ
translated: and it is fruitful. The sacrifice of giving up one’s own opposing defilements. The kinds of supernormal power, etc., are not dependent on anything else and do not require much effort, and they are a sacrifice in that they are the abandoning of one’s own opposing defilements,

original: paccanīkakilesappahānato yañño. Iddhividhaṃ panettha nānāvidhavikubbanadassanasamatthatāya.
analyzed: paccanīka kilesa ppahānataḥ iddhi vidham pana ittha nānāvidha vikubbana dassana samattha tāya
translated: because they are successful in the various kinds of transformation,

original: Dibbasotaṃ devamanussānaṃ saddasavanasamatthatāya; cetopariyañāṇaṃ paresaṃ soḷasavidhacittajānanasamatthatāya;🔽pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ icchiticchitaṭṭhānasamanussaraṇasamatthatāya; dibbacakkhu
analyzed: dibba sotam deva manussānam sadda savana samattha tāya cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam paresam soḷasavidha citta jānana samattha tāya  pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇam icchiti chita ṭṭhāna samanussaraṇa samattha tāya dibba cakkhu
translated: in hearing the sounds of devas and human beings, in knowing the sixteen kinds of other-mind,🔽in recollecting the place wished for, in seeing the visible objects wished for,

original: icchiticchitarūpadassanasamatthatāya; āsavakkhayañāṇaṃ atipaṇītalokuttaramaggasukhanipphādanasamatthatāya
analyzed: icchiticchita rūpa dassana samattha tāya āsava kkhaya ñāṇam ati paṇīta lokuttara magga sukha nipphādana samattha tāya
translated: and in producing the bliss of the very refined supramundane path,

original: mahapphalanti veditabbaṃ. Yasmā pana arahattato visiṭṭhataro añño yañño nāma natthi,
analyzed: mahapphalanti veditabbam yasmā pana arahattataḥ visiṭṭhataraḥ aññaḥ yaññaḥ nāma natthi
translated: it should be understood that they are fruitful. But since there is no other sacrifice superior to that of an Arahant,

original: tasmā arahattanikūṭeneva desanaṃ samāpento – “ayampi kho, brāhmaṇā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tasmai arahatta nikūṭena iva desanam samāpentaḥ ayam pi kho brāhmaṇa ati ādim āha
translated: So he concluded the teaching with the peak of arahantship: “Brahmin, this is how you should understand it.”

original: Kūṭadantaupāsakattapaṭivedanāvaṇṇanā🔽354-358. Evaṃ vutteti evaṃ bhagavatā vutte desanāya pasīditvā saraṇaṃ gantukāmo kūṭadanto
analyzed: kūṭadanta aupāsaka tta paṭivedanā vaṇṇanā  evam vuttā iti evam bhagavatā vutte desanāya pasīditvā saraṇam gantu kāmaḥ kūṭa dantaḥ
translated: The brahmin’s declaration of his state as a lay follower

original: brāhmaṇo – ‘etaṃ abhikkantaṃ bho, gotamā’tiādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca. Upavāyatūti upagantvā🔽sarīradarathaṃ nibbāpento tanusītalo vāto vāyatūti. Idañca pana vatvā brāhmaṇo purisaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ etam abhikkantam bho gotama ati ādikam vacanam avoca upavāyatu iti upagantvā  sarīrada ratham nibbāpento tanu sītalaḥ vātaḥ vāyatu iti idam ca pana vatvā brāhmaṇaḥ purisam
translated: When this was said, the brahmin Kūṭadanta, having been satisfied with the Blessed One’s teaching, and desiring to go for refuge, said: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent, Master Gotama!”🔽Let the Master Gotama accept me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge from this day forth for as long as life lasts.

original: pesesi – “gaccha, tāta, yaññavāṭaṃ pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayo bandhanā mocehī”ti.
analyzed: pesesi gaccha tāta yaññavāṭam pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayaḥ bandhanā mocehi iti
translated: And after saying this, the brahmin sent a man, saying: “Go, my good man, enter the sacrificial compound and release all the living creatures from their bonds.”

original: So “sādhū”ti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā “muttā bho, te pāṇayo”ti ārocesi. Yāva
analyzed: saḥ sādhu iti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā muttāḥ bho te pāṇayaḥ iti ārocesi yāva
translated: “Very well, sir,” he replied, and after doing so, he returned and announced: “Sir, the living creatures have been released.”

original: brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi, na tāva bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi. Kasmā? “Brāhmaṇassa
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ tam pavattim na suṇi na tāva bhagavā dhammam desesi kasmā brāhmaṇassa
translated: But as long as the brahmin did not hear of this, the Blessed One did not teach the Dhamma. Why was that? “The brahmin Kūṭadanta has come to me for the sake of the living creatures, not for the sake of the Dhamma.

original: citte ākulabhāvo atthī”ti. Sutvā panassa “bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā”ti cittacāro vippasīdati.🔽Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Taṃ sandhāya – “atha🔽kho bhagavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi ānupubbikathānubhāvena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇataṃ
analyzed: citte ākula bhāvaḥ atthi iti sutvā panassa bahū vata me pāṇāḥ mocitā ati citta cāraḥ vippasīdati  bhagavā tassa vippasanna manatam ñatvā dhamma desanam ārabhi tam sandhāya atha  kho bhagavā itiādi vuttam puna kalla citta ntiādi ānupubbi kathā anubhāvena vikkhambhita nīvaraṇa tam
translated: and there is agitation in his mind. ” But when he hears that, his mind is calmed by the thought, “Many creatures have been saved by me. ”

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.🔽Iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ

original: Kūṭadantasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
