translated: or for the purpose of hearing divine sounds. “Tiriyā” means “in the intermediate directions.” “He is developed for both sides”:

original: ubhayaṃsāya ubhayakoṭṭhāsāya bhāvitoti attho. Ayaṃ kho mahāli hetūti ayaṃ dibbānaṃyeva🔽rūpānaṃ dassanāya ekaṃsabhāvito samādhi hetu. Imamatthaṃ sutvā so licchavī cintesi
analyzed: ubhaya aṃsāya ubhaya koṭṭhāsāya bhāvito ti attho ayam kho mahāli hetu uti ayam 🔽rūpānam dassanāya ekaṃsa bhāvito samādhi hetu imam attham sutvā saḥ licchavī cintesi
translated: he is developed for both parts. “This is the reason”: this concentration developed for the purpose of seeing divine forms only is the reason.

original: – “idaṃ dibbasotena saddasuṇanaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane uttamatthabhūtaṃ maññe imassa nūna
analyzed: idam dibba sotena sadda suṇanam imasmim sāsane uttamattha bhūtam maññe imassa nūna
translated: “This hearing of the sound with the divine ear is, I think, the highest good in this Dispensation. This is surely

original: atthāya ete bhikkhū paññāsampi saṭṭhipi vassāni apaṇṇakaṃ brahmacariyaṃ caranti,
analyzed: atthāya ete bhikkhū paññāsam pi saṭṭhi pi vassāni apaṇṇakam brahmacariyam caranti
translated: “This hearing of sounds by means of the divine ear is surely the highest good in this Dispensation. Surely these bhikkhus live the holy life a full fifty or sixty years for the sake of this.

original: yaṃnūnāhaṃ dasabalaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyya”nti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham dasabalam etam attham puccheyyanti
translated: Suppose I were to ask the One of Ten Powers about this matter.”

original: 372. Tato tamatthaṃ pucchanto “etāsaṃ nūna, bhante”tiādimāha. Samādhibhāvanānanti
analyzed: tatas tam attham pucchantaḥ etāsam nūna bhante iti ādim āha
translated: Then, asking about that matter, he said: “Surely, venerable sir, for the sake of these … .”

original: ettha samādhiyeva samādhibhāvanā, ubhayaṃsabhāvitānaṃ samādhīnanti attho. Atha yasmā🔽sāsanato bāhirā etā samādhibhāvanā, na ajjhattikā. Tasmā tā paṭikkhipitvā yadatthaṃ
analyzed: ettha samādhiyā iva samādhi bhāvanā atthaḥ atha yasmai  sāsanataḥ bāhirāḥ etā samādhi bhāvanā na ajjhattikā tasmā tā paṭikkhipitvā yadattham
translated: In the phrase “the development of concentration” , concentration itself is the development of concentration. The meaning is that the concentrations are developed in both ways.

original: bhikkhū brahmacariyaṃ caranti, taṃ dassento bhagavā “na kho mahālī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhikkhū brahmacariyam caranti tam dassentaḥ bhagavā na kho mahālī iti ādim āha
translated: But since these are the development of concentration outside the Dispensation, not inside it, he rejects them and then, showing what the bhikkhus live the holy life for, the Blessed One said: “Mahali, those who … do not live the holy life for the sake of these attainments.”

original: Catuariyaphalavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catuariya phala vaṇṇanā
translated: The four noble fruitions

original: 373. Tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānanti sakkāyadiṭṭhiādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ bandhanānaṃ. Tāni hi vaṭṭadukkhamaye
analyzed: tiṇṇam saṃyojanānan ti sakkāya diṭṭhi ādīnam tiṇṇam bandhanānam tāni hi vaṭṭa dukkha maye
translated: “Three fetters”: the three bonds consisting of personality view, etc.

original: rathe satte saṃyojenti, tasmā saṃyojanānīti vuccanti. Sotāpanno hotīti maggasotaṃ
analyzed: rathe satte saṃyojenti tasmā saṃyojanāni iti vuccanti sotāpannaḥ hoti iti magga sotam
translated: They are called fetters because they are yoked to the vehicle of the round of rebirths. He becomes one who has entered the stream: he has entered the stream of the path. He is not subject to destruction: he is not subject to falling into the four states of deprivation. He is bound : he is bound for the state of the highest ; or he is bound to attain the highest .

Orambhāgiyānanti

original: heṭṭhābhāgiyānaṃ, ye hi baddho upari suddhāvāsabhūmiyaṃ nibbattituṃ na sakkoti. Opapātikoti🔽sesayonipaṭikkhepavacanametaṃ. Tattha parinibbāyīti tasmiṃ uparibhaveyeva parinibbānadhammo.🔽Anāvattidhammoti tato brahmalokā puna paṭisandhivasena anāvattanadhammo. Cetovimuttinti
analyzed: heṭṭhābhāgiyānam ye hi baddhaḥ upari suddhāvāsa bhūmiyam nibbattitum na sakkoti opapātiko ti 🔽sesa yoni paṭikkhepa vacanam etam tattha parinibbāyi iti tasmin upari bhaveyya iva parinibbāna dhammo 🔽anāvatti dhammo ti tatas brahmalokā puna paṭisandhi vasena cetaḥ vimutti nti
translated: He is one who has entered the stream: he has entered the stream of the path. He is not subject to destruction: he is not subject to falling into the four states of deprivation. He is bound : he is bound for the state of the highest ; or he is bound to

original: cittavisuddhiṃ, sabbakilesabandhanavimuttassa arahattaphalacittassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: citta visuddhim sabba kilesa bandhana vimuttassa arahatta phala cittassa itam adhivacanaṃ
translated: Purification of mind: this is a term for the mind of the Arahant’s fruition attainment that is freed from all the fetters.

original: Paññāvimuttinti etthāpi sabbakilesabandhanavimuttā arahattaphalapaññāva paññāvimuttīti
analyzed: paññā vimuttiṃ ti ettha api sabba kilesa bandhana vimuttā arahatta phala paññā va paññā vimutti iti
translated: Wisdom-deliverance: here too it is the Arahant’s fruition knowledge that is freed from all the fetters that should be understood as the wisdom-deliverance.🔽In this very life: in this very individual existence.🔽They enter upon and abide in: they enter and they cause to enter.

original: veditabbā. Diṭṭheva dhammeti imasmiṃyeva attabhāve. Sayanti sāmaṃ. Abhiññāti abhijānitvā.🔽Sacchikatvāti paccakkhaṃ katvā. Atha vā abhiññā sacchikatvāti abhiññāya abhivisiṭṭhena
analyzed: veditabbā diṭṭhā iva dhammā iti imasmin yeva atta bhāve sayanti sāmam abhiññāti abhijānitvā  sacchikatvā iti paccakkham katvā atha vā abhiññā sacchikatvā iti abhiññāya abhivisiṭṭhena
translated: They realize: they make evident.🔽Or alternatively, the meaning can be regarded as follows: they enter upon and realize by direct knowledge: they enter upon and realize by direct knowledge that is distinguished by the higher understanding.

original: ñāṇena sacchikaritvātipi attho. Upasampajjāti patvā paṭilabhitvā. Idaṃ sutvā licchavirājā
analyzed: ñāṇena sacchikaritvā atipi attho upasampajjāti patvā paṭilabhitvā idam sutvā licchavi rājā
translated: They enter upon and attain: they enter upon and reach.

original: cintesi – “ayaṃ pana dhammo na sakuṇena viya uppatitvā, nāpi godhāya viya urena gantvā
analyzed: cintesi ayam pana dhammaḥ na sakuṇena viya uppatitvā na api godhāya viya urena gantvā
translated: Having heard this, the Licchavi king thought: “But this Dhamma cannot be penetrated by flying up like a bird or by going with the chest like a porpoise.

original: sakkā paṭivijjhituṃ, addhā pana imaṃ paṭivijjhantassa pubbabhāgappaṭipadāya bhavitabbaṃ,
analyzed: sakkā paṭivijjhitum addhā pana imam paṭivijjhantassa pubbabhāga paṭipadāya bhavitabbam
translated: Surely it must be that one who penetrates it has to do so by means of the preliminary work of the practice.

original: pucchāmi tāva na”nti.
analyzed: pucchāmi tāva nanti
translated: I shall ask him.”

original: Ariyaaṭṭhaṅgikamaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ariya aṭṭhaṅgika magga vaṇṇanā
translated: The Noble Eightfold Path

original: 374-375. Tato bhagavantaṃ pucchanto “atthi pana bhante”tiādimāha. Aṭṭhaṅgikoti pañcaṅgikaṃ🔽turiyaṃ viya aṭṭhaṅgiko gāmo viya ca aṭṭhaṅgamattoyeva hutvā aṭṭhaṅgiko, na aṅgato
analyzed: tatas bhagavantam pucchantaḥ atthi pana bhante ti ādim āha aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ iti pañcaṅgikam  turiyam viya aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ gāmaḥ viya ca hutvā aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ na aṅgataḥ
translated: Then, asking the Blessed One, he said, “But, venerable sir, is there any other path or method or way of practice owing to which … there comes to be the full understanding of suffering? ”

original: añño maggo nāma atthi. Tenevāha – “seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhī”ti.
analyzed: aññaḥ maggaḥ nāma atthi tena iva āha seyyathīdam sammādiṭṭhi pe sammāsamādhi iti
translated: The eightfold path: just as a village has eight boundaries, so the path is eightfold in the sense of having eight factors. It is not that there is a path called “eightfold” apart from the eight factors. That is why he said “right view … right concentration” .

original: Tattha sammādassanalakkhaṇā sammādiṭṭhi. Sammā abhiniropanalakkhaṇo sammāsaṅkappo.
analyzed: tattha sammā dassana lakkhaṇā sammā diṭṭhi sammā abhiniropana lakkhaṇaḥ sammā saṅkappo
translated: Herein, right view has the characteristic of right seeing. Right thought has the characteristic of right directing of thought.

original: Sammā pariggahaṇalakkhaṇā sammāvācā. Sammā samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇo sammākammanto. Sammā
analyzed: sammā pariggahaṇa lakkhaṇā sammā vācā sammā samuṭṭhāpana lakkhaṇo sammā kammanto sammā
translated: Right speech has the characteristic of right embracing. Right action has the characteristic of right origination.

original: vodāpanalakkhaṇo sammāājīvo. Sammā paggahalakkhaṇo sammāvāyāmo. Sammā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇā
analyzed: vodāpana lakkhaṇo sammāājīvaḥ sammā paggaha lakkhaṇo sammāvāyāmaḥ sammā upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇā
translated: Right livelihood has the characteristic of right purification. Right effort has the characteristic of right exertion.

original: sammāsati. Sammā samādhānalakkhaṇo sammāsamādhi. Etesu ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi kiccāni🔽honti. Seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehipi attano paccanīkakilesehi saddhiṃ micchādiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: sammā sati sammā samādhāna lakkhaṇo sammāsamādhi etesu ekekassa tīṇi tīṇi kiccāni 🔽honti sā iyyathidam sammādiṭṭhi tāva aññehi pi attanaḥ paccanīka kilesehi saddhim micchādiṭṭhiṃ
translated: Right mindfulness has the characteristic of right establishment. Right concentration has the characteristic of right unification. Each one of these has three functions and three characteristics.🔽Right view, for instance, has three functions: it abandons wrong view, it prevents the kinds of wrongness connected with wrong view from occurring, and it is the forerunner of the rightness consisting in the path.

original: pajahati, nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, sampayuttadhamme ca passati tappaṭicchādakamohavidhamanavasena🔽asammohato. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi tatheva micchāsaṅkappādīni pajahanti, nirodhañca
analyzed: pajahati nirodham ārammaṇam karoti sampayutta dhamme ca passati tad paṭicchādaka moha vidhamana vasena  a sammohataḥ sammāsaṅkappa ādayaḥ pi tathā iva micchāsaṅkappa ādīni pajahanti nirodham ca
translated: He abandons wrong view, makes cessation its object, and sees the states associated with it.🔽And he does so by the act of sweeping away the delusion that conceals the noble truths.

original: ārammaṇaṃ karonti, visesato panettha sammāsaṅkappo sahajātadhamme abhiniropeti. Sammāvācā🔽sammā pariggaṇhati. Sammākammanto sammā samuṭṭhāpeti. Sammāājīvo sammā vodāpeti.
analyzed: ārammaṇam karonti visesataḥ pana ittha sammāsaṅkappo sahajāta dhamme abhiniropeti sammā vācā  sammā pariggaṇhati sammā kammanto sammā samuṭṭhāpeti sammā ājīvo sammā vodāpeti
translated: Right thought, etc., abandon wrong thought, etc., and make cessation their object in the same way. But in particular right thought impels the states associated with it towards cessation. Right speech🔽rightly defines them. Right action🔽rightly originates them. Right livelihood🔽rightly purifies them.

original: Sammāvāyāmo sammā paggaṇhati. Sammāsati sammā upaṭṭhāpeti. Sammāsamādhi sammā padahati.
analyzed: sammāvāyāmaḥ sammā paggaṇhati sammā sati sammā upaṭṭhāpeti sammā samādhi sammā padahati
translated: Right effort rightly exerts them. Right mindfulness rightly attends to them. Right concentration rightly concentrates them.

original: Api cesā sammādiṭṭhi nāma pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā hoti, maggakkhaṇe ekakkhaṇā
analyzed: api ca isā sammādiṭṭhi nāma pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā hoti magga kkhaṇe eka khaṇā
translated: And this right view, which is called “knowledge of the way things are,” is at first successive and has different objects. But at the moment of the path it is singlefold,

original: ekārammaṇā. Kiccato pana “dukkhe ñāṇa”ntiādīni cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsaṅkappādayopi
analyzed: eka ārammaṇā kiccataḥ pana dukkhe ñāṇa nti ādīni cattāri nāmāni labhati sammāsaṅkappa ādayaḥ pi
translated: having a single object. But as regards function, it gets the four names beginning with “knowledge of suffering.” And right thought, etc.,

original: pubbabhāge nānākkhaṇā nānārammaṇā honti. Maggakkhaṇe ekakkhaṇā ekārammaṇā. Tesu sammāsaṅkappo
analyzed: pubbabhāge nānā akkhaṇāḥ nānā ārammaṇāḥ honti magga kkhaṇe eka kkhaṇāḥ eka ārammaṇā tesu sammāsaṅkappaḥ
translated: At the earlier stage they are of different moments and different objects. At the moment of the path they are of the same moment and the same object.🔽Of these, right intention

original: kiccato “nekkhammasaṅkappo”tiādīni tīṇi nāmāni labhati. Sammā vācādayo tisso viratiyopi
analyzed: kiccataḥ nekkhamma saṅkappa uti ādīni tīṇi nāmāni labhati sammā vācā ādayaḥ tisso viratiyo pi
translated: gets the three names beginning with “intention of renunciation” according to function. Right speech, etc., are three kinds of abstinence,

original: honti, cetanādayopi honti, maggakkhaṇe pana viratiyeva. Sammāvāyāmo sammāsatīti idampi
analyzed: honti cetanā ādayaḥ pi honti magga kkhaṇe pana viratiyā iva sammāvāyāmo sammā satī iti idam pi
translated: and they are also kinds of volition, etc., but at the moment of the path they are abstinence only. Right effort and right mindfulness

original: dvayaṃ kiccato sammappadhānasatipaṭṭhānavasena cattāri nāmāni labhati. Sammāsamādhi
analyzed: dvayam kiccataḥ sammappadhāna sati paṭṭhāna vasena cattāri nāmāni labhati sammāsamādhi
translated: also get the four names beginning with “right endeavour” and “right mindfulness” according to function. Right concentration,

original: pana pubbabhāgepi maggakkhaṇepi sammāsamādhiyeva.
analyzed: pana pubba bhāge pi magga kkhaṇe pi sammāsamādhiyā eva
translated: however, is right concentration both at the earlier stage and at the moment of the path.

original: Iti imesu aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhagavatā nibbānādhigamāya paṭipannassa yogino bahukārattā
analyzed: iti imesu aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhagavatā nibbāna adhigamāya paṭipannassa yoginaḥ bahu kāra ttā
translated: So of these eight things, right view is taught first by the Blessed One for a man who is practising for the realization of Nibbāna because it is of great service.

original: paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā. Ayañhi “paññāpajjoto paññāsattha”nti ca vuttā. Tasmā
analyzed: paṭhamam sammādiṭṭhi desitā ayam hi paññāpajjotaḥ paññā satthanti ca vuttā tasmā
translated: For this is called “the light of understanding” and “the sword of understanding” . Therefore,

original: etāya pubbabhāge vipassanāñāṇasaṅkhātāya sammādiṭṭhiyā avijjandhakāraṃ vidhamitvā
analyzed: etāya pubba bhāge vipassanā ñāṇa saṅkhātāya sammādiṭṭhiyā avijja andhakāram vidhamitvā
translated: at the earlier stage, by means of this right view called “understanding of insight” he dispels the darkness of ignorance,

original: kilesacore ghātento khemena yogāvacaro nibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tena vuttaṃ – “nibbānādhigamāya
analyzed: kilesa core ghātentaḥ khemena yogāvacaraḥ nibbānam pāpuṇāti tena vuttam nibbāna adhigamāya
translated: The meditator who has killed the thieves of defilement reaches Nibbāna in safety. Hence it was said:

original: paṭipannassa yogino bahukārattā paṭhamaṃ sammādiṭṭhi desitā”ti.
analyzed: paṭipannassa yoginaḥ bahu kāra ttā paṭhamam sammādiṭṭhi desitā ati
translated: “Because it is of such great service to the meditator who is practising for the attainment of Nibbāna, right view is taught first.”

original: Sammāsaṅkappo pana tassā bahukāro, tasmā tadanantaraṃ vutto. Yathā hi heraññiko hatthena
analyzed: sammāsaṅkappaḥ pana tassāḥ bahu kāro tasmā tad anantaram vuttaḥ yathā hi heraññikaḥ hatthena
translated: But right thought is of such great service to that right view, and so it is taught next. For just as a gold-tester,

original: parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇaṃ olokento – “ayaṃ cheko, ayaṃ kūṭo”ti🔽jānāti. Evaṃ yogāvacaropi pubbabhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanāpaññāya olokayamāno
analyzed: parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā cakkhunā kahāpaṇam olokento ayam chekaḥ ayam kūṭaḥ ti  jānāti evam yogāvacaraḥ api pubba bhāge vitakkena vitakketvā vipassanā paññāya olokayamāno
translated: after taking a nugget of gold in his hand, tests it by burning, etc., in order to find out whether it is genuine or not,🔽so too the meditator, after apprehending a mental or physical state with right view in the way described, tests it by means of the remaining path factors in order to find out whether it is a mundane or a supramundane state.

original: – “ime dhammā kāmāvacarā, ime dhammā rūpāvacarādayo”ti pajānāti. Yathā vā pana purisena
analyzed: ime dhammā kāma avacarā ime dhammā rūpāvacara ādayo ti pajānāti yathā vā pana purisena
translated: Or just as a man needing heartwood,

original: koṭiyaṃ gahetvā parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā dinnaṃ mahārukkhaṃ tacchako vāsiyā tacchetvā
analyzed: koṭiyam gahetvā parivaṭṭetvā parivaṭṭetvā dinnam mahā rukkham tat śakaḥ vāsiyā tat śetvā
translated: if he cut down a great tree and stripped off its outer, inner and rotten heartwood, would finally reach the sound heartwood;

original: kamme upaneti, evaṃ vitakkena vitakketvā vitakketvā dinne dhamme yogāvacaro paññāya
analyzed: kamme upaneti evam vitakkena vitakketvā vitakketvā dinne dhamme yogāvacaro paññāya
translated: so too, when the meditator has stripped off the outer bark of wrong view, etc., with right view, and in the same way has stripped off the inner bark of wrong thought, the sapwood of wrong speech, etc., and the softwood of wrong effort, he finally reaches the sound heartwood of right concentration.

original: – “ime kāmāvacarā, ime rūpāvacarā”tiādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme upaneti. Tena
analyzed: ime kāmāvacarāḥ ime rūpāvacarā ati ādinā nayena paricchinditvā kamme upaneti tena

translated: He fulfills the three kinds of good conduct and is reborn in a heavenly world. The fourth method of conversion is stated with reference to these two. This is the method of conversion that comes from the outside. But there is also one that comes from within the Dispensation.🔽For one who has undertaken the ascetic practices lives in a way that is hard on himself. Or, because of his little merit, he may search the whole village and still not get enough to fill his belly. He thinks, “I will make provisions.”

original: vicaritvā udarapūraṃ na labhati. So – “paccaye uppādessāmī”ti vejjakammādivasena
analyzed: vicaritvā udara pūram na labhati saḥ paccaye uppādessāmi iti vejja kamma ādi vasena
translated: He then makes a living by practicing medicine, etc.,

original: vā anesanaṃ katvā, arahattaṃ vā paṭijānitvā, tīṇi vā kuhanavatthūni paṭisevitvā niraye nibbattati.
analyzed: vā anesanam katvā arahattam vā paṭijānitvā tīṇi vā kuhana vatthūni paṭisevitvā niraye nibbattati
translated: or he claims to be an Arahant, or he makes use of the three kinds of wrong means of livelihood. He is reborn in hell.

original: Aparo ca tādisova puññavā hoti. So tāya puññasampattiyā mānaṃ janayitvā uppannaṃ lābhaṃ thāvaraṃ kattukāmo anesanavasena tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā niraye uppajjati.
analyzed: aparo ca tādisaḥ iva puññavā hoti saḥ tāya puñña sampattiyā mānam janayitvā uppannam lābham thāvaram kattu kāmo an esana vasena tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā niraye uppajjati
translated: Another is of the same kind but is also virtuous. He generates pride through that excellence of his merit. Desiring to make his gain permanent, he fulfills the three kinds of misconduct through wrong livelihood and is reborn in hell.

original: Aparo samādinnadhutaṅgo appapuññova hoti, na labhati sukhena jīvitavuttiṃ. So – “pubbepāhaṃ🔽akatapuññatāya kiñci na labhāmi, sace idāni anesanaṃ karissaṃ, āyatimpi dullabhasukho
analyzed: aparaḥ samādinna dhutaṅgaḥ appa puññaḥ iva hoti na labhati sukhena jīvita vuttim so pubbepāham  a kata puñña tāya kiñci na labhāmi sace idāni an esanam karissam āyatim pi dullabha sukho
translated: Another undertakes the ascetic practices but is not virtuous. He does not get his living easily. He thinks: “Formerly,

original: bhavissāmī”ti tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā arahattaṃ pattuṃ asakkonto sagge nibbattati.
analyzed: bhavissāmi iti tīṇi su caritāni pūretvā arahattam pattum a sakkontaḥ sagge nibbattati
translated: because I did not make merit, I got nothing. If I now make merit through wrong livelihood, I shall be one to whom happiness is difficult in the future as well.” He fulfills the three kinds of good conduct, but being unable to reach Arahantship, he is reborn in a happy destiny.

original: Aparo puññavā hoti, so – “pubbepāhaṃ katapuññatāya etarahi sukhito, idānipi puññaṃ karissāmī”ti anesanaṃ pahāya tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā arahattaṃ pattuṃ asakkonto sagge nibbattati.
analyzed: aparaḥ puññavā hoti saḥ pubbepāham kata puñña tāya etarahi sukhitaḥ idāni api puññam karissāmi iti anesanam pahāya tīṇi su caritāni pūretvā arahattam pattum a sakkontaḥ sagge nibbattati
translated: Another is virtuous. He thinks: “Formerly, because I made merit, I am happy now. If I now make merit, I shall be one to whom happiness is easy in the future as well.” He abandons wrong livelihood and fulfills the three kinds of good conduct, but being unable to reach Arahantship, he is reborn in a happy destiny.

original: 383. Āgatiñcāti – “asukaṭṭhānato nāma ime āgatā”ti evaṃ āgatiñca. Gatiñcāti idāni
analyzed: āgatim ca ati asuka ṭṭhānataḥ nāma ime āgatā ati evam āgatim ca gatim ca ati idāni
translated: “Coming” : “They have come from such and such a place.” “Going” : “Now they are going to such and such a place.”

original: gantabbaṭṭhānañca. Cutiñcāti tato cavanañca. Upapattiñcāti tato cutānaṃ puna upapattiñca.
analyzed: gantabba ṭṭhānam ca cutim ca ati tatas cavanam ca upapattim ca ati tatas cutānam punar upapattim ca
translated: and the place to go to. Death means the dying there. Rebirth means the rebirth of those who have died there.

original: Kiṃ sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahissāmīti – “kena kāraṇena garahissāmi, garahitabbameva hi mayaṃ🔽garahāma, pasaṃsitabbaṃ pasaṃsāma, na bhaṇḍikaṃ karonto mahārajako viya dhotañca🔽adhotañca ekato karomā”ti dasseti. Idāni tamatthaṃ pakāsento – “santi kassapa eke
analyzed: kim sabbam tapam garahissāmi iti kena kāraṇena garahissāmi garahitabbam eva hi mayam  garahāma pasaṃsitabbam pasaṃsāma na bhaṇḍikam karontaḥ mahā rajakaḥ viya dhotam ca  ekatas karoma ati dasseti idāni tam attham pakāsento santi kassapa eke
translated: Why should I condemn all austerities? – “For what reason should I condemn them? For it is only what should be condemned that we condemn,

original: samaṇabrāhmaṇā”tiādimāha.🔽384. Yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcavidhaṃ sīlaṃ, tañhi loke na koci “na sādhū”ti vadati.🔽Puna yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcavidhaṃ veraṃ, taṃ na koci “sādhū”ti vadati. Puna yaṃ te
analyzed: samaṇa brāhmaṇa ati ādim āha  yam te pañcavidham sīlam tat hi loke na koci na sādhu iti vadati  puna yam te pañcavidham veram tam na sādhu iti vadati puna yam te
translated: and what should be praised that we praise. We do not make a hodge-podge of it like a certain great king’s chief cook, who, when he was making a curry, threw everything he had into it, saying, ‘If it is good for this curry, it will stand the test; if not, it will not’” . He shows that he does not do this. Now, in order to make that clear, he said: “Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins” .🔽What they have in common is the fivefold virtue, for no one in the world says that that is not good.

original: ekaccanti pañcadvāre asaṃvaraṃ, te kira – “cakkhu nāma na nirundhitabbaṃ, cakkhunā
analyzed: pañca dvāre asaṃvaram te kira cakkhu nāma na nirundhitabbam cakkhunā
translated: Again, what they have in common is the fivefold enmity, for no one says that that is good. Again, what they have in common is the five doors of non-restraint, for they say that the eye should not be restrained, that what is seen with the eye should not be restrained, that the eye-consciousness should not be restrained, that eye-contact should not be restrained, and that agreeable, disagreeable, or indifferent feeling that arises with eye-contact as condition should not be restrained. And so with the ear, nose, tongue, and body.

original: manāpaṃ rūpaṃ daṭṭhabba”nti vadanti, esa nayo sotādīsu. Puna yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcadvāre saṃvaraṃ.🔽Evaṃ paresaṃ vādena saha attano vādassa samānāsamānataṃ dassetvā idāni attano vādena
analyzed: manāpam rūpam daṭṭhabbanti vadanti esa nayo sota ādīsu puna yam te pañca dvāre saṃvaram  evam paresam vādena saha attanaḥ vādassa samāna asamāna tam dassetvā idāni attanaḥ vādena
translated: Again, “Some say” : they say that restraint is in the five doors.

original: saha paresaṃ vādassa samānāsamānataṃ dassento “yaṃ maya”ntiādimāha. Tatrāpi pañcasīlādivaseneva attho veditabbo.
analyzed: saha paresam vādassa samāna asamāna tam dassentaḥ yam mayanti ādim āha tatra api pañca sīla ādi vasena iva atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Having thus shown the similarity and dissimilarity of his own doctrine to that of others, he now says “What we” in order to show the similarity and dissimilarity of others’ doctrines to his own. Here too the meaning should be understood according to the five precepts, and so on.

original: Samanuyuñjāpanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: samanuyuñjāpana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion

original: 385. Samanuyuñjantanti samanuyuñjantu, ettha ca laddhiṃ pucchanto samanuyuñjati nāma,🔽kāraṇaṃ pucchanto samanugāhati nāma, ubhayaṃ pucchanto samanubhāsati nāma. Satthārā🔽vā satthāranti satthārā vā saddhiṃ satthāraṃ upasaṃharitvā – “kiṃ te satthā te dhamme
analyzed: samanuyuñjantanti samanuyuñjantu ettha ca laddhim pucchantaḥ samanuyuñjati nāma  kāraṇam pucchantaḥ samanugāhati nāma ubhayam pucchantaḥ samanubhāsati nāma satthārā  vā satthāranti satthārā vā saddhim satthāram upasaṃharitvā kim te satthā te dhamme
translated: “Let them discuss” : let them discuss. Here, one who asks about the opinion is discussing;

original: sabbaso pahāya vattati, udāhu samaṇo gotamo”ti. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sabbasas pahāya vattati udāhu samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ iti dutiya pade pi esā iva nayo
translated: one who asks about the reason is investigating; one who asks about both is cross-questioning. “With the Teacher” : with the Teacher, referring to the Teacher. “What does your Teacher say” : “Does your Teacher conduct himself having abandoned these things entirely, or does the ascetic Gotama?” The same method applies to the second question.

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ yojetvā dassento – “ye imesaṃ bhavata”ntiādimāha. Tattha akusalā
analyzed: idāni tam attham yojetvā dassentaḥ ye imesam bhavata nti ādim āha tattha akusalā
translated: Now, in order to show that meaning by combining it, he said “those that are of these” and so on. Herein, unwholesome

original: akusalasaṅkhātāti akusalā ceva “akusalā”ti ca saṅkhātā ñātā koṭṭhāsaṃ vā katvā ṭhapitāti
analyzed: akusala saṅkhātā ati akusalā ca iva akusalā ati ca saṅkhātā ñātā koṭṭhāsam vā katvā ṭhapitā ati
translated: and called unwholesome: unwholesome and called “unwholesome,” known, or placed in a category.

original: attho. Esa nayo sabbapadesu. Api cettha sāvajjāti sadosā. Na alamariyāti niddosaṭṭhena
analyzed: atthaḥ esa nayaḥ sabba padesu api ca ittha sā avajjāti sa dosā na alam ariyāti niddosaṭṭhena
translated: This is the meaning. The same method applies in all the passages. But here blameworthy means with hate. Not fit for noble ones means

original: ariyā bhavituṃ nālaṃ asamatthā.
analyzed: ariyāḥ bhavitum na alam a samatthā
translated: not fit to be noble ones in the sense of being without hate.

original: 386-392. Yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantāti yena viññū amhe ca aññe ca pucchantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ,
analyzed: yam viññū samanuyuñjanta ati yena viññū amhe ca aññe ca pucchantā evam vadeyyuṃ
translated: If the wise should question us: if the wise should question us and others thus,

original: taṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati, atthi taṃ kāraṇanti attho. Yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyāti
analyzed: tam ṭhānam vijjati atthi tam kāraṇanti attho yam vā pana bhonto pare gaṇa ācariyā ati
translated: it is possible that we would say this, that there is that reason. Or else, if the masters should say to others:

original: pare pana bhonto gaṇācariyā yaṃ vā taṃ vā appamattakaṃ pahāya vattantīti attho. Amheva
analyzed: pare pana bhontaḥ gaṇa ācariyāḥ yam vā tam vā appamattakam pahāya vattanti iti atthaḥ amhā iva
translated: but the masters, sirs, should say to others, “Give up that or that trifle,” and behave thus.

original: tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti idaṃ bhagavā satthārā satthāraṃ samanuyuñjanepi āha
analyzed: tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti idam bhagavā satthārā satthāram āha
translated: We would be mostly praised there: this the Exalted One said even when he was questioning the teachers about teachers.

original: – saṅghena saṃghaṃ samanuyuñjanepi. Kasmā? Saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito.
analyzed: saṅghena saṃgham samanuyuñjane pi kasmā
translated: And why? Because when the Community is being praised, the Master’s praise is established too.

original: Pasīdamānāpi hi buddhasampattiyā saṅghe, saṅghasampattiyā ca buddhe pasīdanti, tathā🔽hi bhagavato sarīrasampattiṃ disvā, dhammadesanaṃ vā sutvā bhavanti vattāro – “lābhā
analyzed: pasīdamānāḥ api hi buddha sampattiyā saṅghe saṅgha sampattiyā ca buddhe pasīdanti tathā  hi bhagavato sarīra sampattim disvā dhamma desanam vā sutvā bhavanti vattāraḥ lābhā
translated: For when they are being confirmed in faith, they are confirmed in faith in the Community through the Blessed One’s accomplishment and in the Blessed One through the Community’s accomplishment.

original: vata bho sāvakānaṃ ye evarūpassa satthu santikāvacarā”ti, evaṃ buddhasampattiyā saṅghe🔽pasīdanti. Bhikkhūnaṃ panācāragocaraṃ abhikkamapaṭikkamādīni ca disvā bhavanti vattāro🔽– “santikāvacarānaṃ vata bho sāvakānaṃ ayañca upasamaguṇo satthu kīva rūpo bhavissatī”ti,
analyzed: vata bho sāvakānam ye evarūpassa satthu santika avacarāti evam buddha sampattiyā saṅghe  pasīdanti bhikkhūnam pana ācāra gocaram abhikkama paṭikkama ādīni ca disvā bhavanti vattāraḥ  santika avacarānam vata bho sāvakānam ayam ca upasama guṇaḥ satthu kīva rūpaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: For when they see the Blessed One’s bodily appearance or hear his teaching of the Dhamma, they say: “How fortunate are those disciples of his who live with him and attend upon him!” In this way they are confirmed in faith in the Community through the Blessed One’s accomplishment.

original: evaṃ saṅghasampattiyā buddhe pasīdanti. Iti yā satthupasaṃsā, sā saṅghassa. Yā saṅghassa
analyzed: evam saṅgha sampattiyā buddhe pasīdanti iti yā satthu upasaṃsā sā saṅghassa yā saṅghassa
translated: But when they see the bhikkhus’ conduct, resort, and deportment in going forward and returning, looking ahead and looking aside, their flexion and extension, their gaze in looking straight on and looking away, and when they see their guarded conduct of body, speech, and mind in the six directions, they say: “How great must the Blessed One’s qualities be, since his disciples have such qualities!” In this way they are confirmed in faith in the Blessed One through the Community’s accomplishment. So the praise of the Community is the praise of the Blessed One, and the praise of the Blessed One is the praise of the Community. Thus when the Community is being praised, the Master’s praise is established too.

original: pasaṃsā, sā satthūti saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito bhagavā dvīsupi
analyzed: pasaṃsā sā satthu iti saṅgha pasaṃsā api satthuyā iva pasaṃsā siddhitaḥ bhagavā dvīsupi
translated: And why? Because when the Community is being praised, the Master’s praise is established too.

original: nayesu – “amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyu”nti āha. Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ
analyzed: nayesu amhā iva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti āha samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ime dhamme anavasesam
translated: “They will praise us there for the most part.”🔽The recluse Gotama lives having abandoned these things without remainder.

original: pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyātiādīsupi panettha ayamadhippāyo
analyzed: pahāya vattati yam vā pana bhonto pare gaṇa ācariyā ati ādīsu pi pana ittha ayam adhippāyaḥ
translated: Or else, in the passages beginning, “Or again, friends, the recluse Gotama speaks thus: ‘Only here is there a recluse, only here an ascetic, only here is there the highest purity, only here the highest life of holiness,’ ” the meaning is as follows:

original: – sampattasamādānasetughātavasena hi tisso viratiyo. Tāsu sampattasamādāna viratimattameva
analyzed: sampatta samādāna setu ghāta vasena hi tissaḥ viratiyaḥ tāsu
translated: For there are three kinds of abstention, namely, that consisting in the obtaining of virtue, that consisting in the restraint of sense faculties, and that consisting in the destruction of taints.🔽Of these, the others have only the abstention consisting in the obtaining of virtue,🔽but the destruction of taints abstention is completely absent in them.

original: aññesaṃ hoti, setughātavirati pana sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Pañcasu pana tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇappahānesu
analyzed: aññesam hoti setughāta virati pana sabbena sabbam natthi pañcasu pana tad aṅga vikkhambhana samuccheda paṭipassaddhi nissaraṇa ppahānesu
translated: And of the five kinds of abandoning, namely, abandoning by substitution of opposites, abandoning by suppression, abandoning by cutting off, abandoning by tranquillization, and abandoning by rooting out,🔽the others have only the abandoning by substitution of opposites and by rooting out,

original: aṭṭhasamāpattivasena ceva vipassanāmattavasena ca tadaṅgavikkhambhanappahānamattameva
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti vasena ca iva vipassanā matta vasena ca tat aṅga vikkhambhana ppahāna mattam eva
translated: which are respectively the eight attainments and insight.

original: aññesaṃ hoti. Itarāni tīṇi pahānāni sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Tathā sīlasaṃvaro, khantisaṃvaro,
analyzed: aññesam hoti itarāni tīṇi pahānāni sabbena sabbam na atthi tathā sīla saṃvaro khanti saṃvaro
translated: The other three kinds of abandoning are completely absent in them.🔽Similarly, there are five kinds of restraint, namely, restraint by virtue, restraint by heedfulness, restraint by knowledge, restraint by energy, and restraint by patience.

original: ñāṇasaṃvaro, satisaṃvaro, vīriyasaṃvaroti pañca saṃvarā, tesu pañcasīlamattameva
analyzed: ñāṇa saṃvaro sati saṃvaro vīriya saṃvaro ti pañca saṃvarā tesu pañca sīlam attam eva
translated: Of these, the others have only the five training precepts.

original: adhivāsanakhantimattameva ca aññesaṃ hoti, sesaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: adhivāsana khanti mattam eva ca aññesam hoti sesam sabbena sabbam natthi
translated: and only acquiescence in the acceptance of the Observance, and nothing else, is theirs.

original: Pañca kho panime uposathuddesā, tesu pañcasīlamattameva aññesaṃ hoti. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ
analyzed: pañca kho panime uposatha uddesā tesu pañca sīla mattam eva aññesam hoti pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam
translated: And there are five kinds of Observance-day reciters, of whom only the five training precepts are theirs,🔽and the virtue of restraint by the Pāṭimokkha is not theirs at all.

original: sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Iti akusalappahāne ca kusalasamādāne ca, tīsu viratīsu, pañcasu🔽pahānesu, pañcasu saṃvaresu, pañcasu uddesesu, – “ahameva ca mayhañca sāvakasaṅgho
analyzed: sabbena sabbam na atthi iti akusala ppahāne ca kusala samādāne ca tīsu viratīsu pañcasu  pahānesu pañcasu saṃvaresu pañcasu uddesesu aham eva ca mayham ca sāvaka saṅghaḥ
translated: So in the abandoning of the unprofitable and in the undertaking of the profitable, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonings,🔽in the five observances, and in the five reciters, it is only the Blessed One and his Community of monks that are recognized in the world,

original: loke paññāyati, mayā hi sadiso satthā nāma, mayhaṃ sāvakasaṅghena sadiso saṅgho nāma
analyzed: loke paññāyati mayā hi sadisaḥ satthā nāma mayham sāvaka saṅghena sadisaḥ saṅghaḥ nāma
translated: for there is no teacher equal to the Blessed One and no Community like the Community of monks.

original: natthī”ti bhagavā sīhanādaṃ nadati.
analyzed: natthi iti bhagavā sīha nādam nadati
translated: This is the Blessed One’s lion’s roar.

original: Ariyaaṭṭhaṅgikamaggavaṇṇanā🔽393. Evaṃ sīhanādaṃ naditvā tassa sīhanādassa aviparītabhāvāvabodhanatthaṃ – “atthi,
analyzed: ariya aṭṭhaṅgika magga vaṇṇanā  evam sīha nādam naditvā tassa sīha nādassa aviparīta bhāva avabodhana attham atthi
translated: The Noble Eightfold Path

original: kassapa, maggo”tiādimāha. Tattha maggoti lokuttaramaggo. Paṭipadāti pubbabhāgapaṭipadā.
analyzed: kassapa maggo ti ādim āha tattha maggo ti lokuttara maggo paṭipadā ti pubbabhāga paṭipadā
translated: Having thus roared his lion’s roar, he now said “There is a path, Kassapa” , etc., in order to make it known that that lion’s roar is not upside-down. Herein, the path is the supramundane path. The way is the way that is a prerequisite for that .

original: Kālavādītiādīni brahmajāle vaṇṇitāni. Idāni taṃ duvidhaṃ maggañca paṭipadañca ekato🔽katvā dassento – “ayameva ariyo”tiādimāha. Idaṃ pana sutvā acelo cintesi – “samaṇo🔽gotamo mayhaṃyeva maggo ca paṭipadā ca atthi, aññesaṃ natthīti maññati, handassāhaṃ🔽amhākampi maggaṃ kathemī”ti. Tato acelakapaṭipadaṃ kathesi. Tenāha – “evaṃ vutte
analyzed: kāla vādi iti ādīni brahmajāle vaṇṇitāni idāni tam duvidham maggam ca paṭipadam ca ekato  katvā dassentaḥ ayam eva ariyaḥ ti ādim āha idam pana sutvā acelaḥ cintesi samaṇo  gotamaḥ mayhaṃyeva maggo ca paṭipadā ca atthi aññesam natthi iti maññati handassa aham  amhākam pi maggam kathemi iti tatas acelaka paṭipadam kathesi tena āha evam vutte
translated: The words “timely speaker” and so on are praised in the Brahmajala Sutta. Now, combining that twofold path and practice together, he said, “This is the only noble path.” But after hearing this, the naked ascetic thought, “The ascetic Gotama thinks that only I have a path and practice, not others. Well then, I will also explain my path.” Then he explained the naked ascetic’s practice. Therefore it is said:

original: acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca…pe… udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharatī”ti.
analyzed: acelaḥ kassapaḥ bhagavantam etat avocape udakorohana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati iti
translated: The words “timely speaker” and so on are praised in the Brahmajala Sutta. Now, combining that twofold path and practice together, he said, “This is the noble path.” But having heard this, the naked ascetic thought, “The ascetic Gotama thinks that only I have the path and practice, not others. Well then, I will also explain the path to him.” Then he explained the naked ascetic’s practice. Therefore it is said: When this was said, the naked ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One… and lives engaged in the practice of plunging into water.

original: Tapopakkamakathāvaṇṇanā🔽394. Tattha tapopakkamāti tapārambhā, tapakammānīti attho. Sāmaññasaṅkhātāti samaṇakammasaṅkhātā.
analyzed: tapaḥ upakkama kathā vaṇṇanā  tattha tapa upakkamā ti tapa ārambhā tapa kammāni iti attho sāmañña saṅkhātā ati samaṇa kamma saṅkhātā
translated: Explanation of the Discourse on the Practice of Austerities.

original: Brahmaññasaṅkhātāti brāhmaṇakammasaṅkhātā. Acelakoti niccolo, naggoti attho. Muttācāroti
analyzed: brahmañña saṅkhātā ati brāhmaṇa kamma saṅkhātā acelako ti niccolaḥ naggo ti attho mutta ācāro ti
translated: Here, the practice of austerities means the undertaking of austerities, the performance of austerities is the meaning. Called the practice of ascetics means called the work of ascetics. Called the practice of brahmins means called the work of brahmins. Naked means always naked, the meaning is. Unrestricted in eating means

original: visaṭṭhācāro, uccārakammādīsu lokiyakulaputtācārena virahito ṭhitakova uccāraṃ karoti,🔽passāvaṃ karoti, khādati, bhuñjati ca. Hatthāpalekhanoti hatthe piṇḍamhi ṭhite jivhāya
analyzed: visaṭṭha ācāraḥ uccāra kamma ādīsu lokiya kula putta ācārena virahitaḥ uccāram karoti  passāvam karoti khādati bhuñjati ca hattha apalekhano ti hatthe piṇḍamhi ṭhite jivhāya
translated: He is one who does not avoid the open, who does not refrain from the behaviour of ordinary people in connection with defecation, etc., but who does it openly, standing.🔽He is one who licks his hands, who licks his hands with his tongue to get every bit of food off them.

original: hatthaṃ apalikhati, uccāraṃ vā katvā hatthasmiññeva daṇḍakasaññī hutvā hatthena apalikhati.
analyzed: hattham apalikhati uccāram vā katvā hatthasmin ñeva daṇḍaka saññī hutvā hatthena apalikhati
translated: He is one who licks his bowl, who licks his bowl with his tongue to get every bit of food off it.

original: “Bhikkhāgahaṇatthaṃ ehi, bhante”ti vutto na etīti na ehibhaddantiko. “Tena hi tiṭṭha,🔽bhante”ti vuttopi na tiṭṭhatīti natiṭṭhabhaddantiko. Tadubhayampi kira so – “etassa
analyzed: bhikkhā gahaṇa attham ehi bhante ti vuttaḥ na eti iti na ehi bhaddantiko tena hi tiṭṭha  bhante ti vuttaḥ api na tiṭṭhati iti tat ubhayam pi kira saḥ etassa
translated: He is one who goes without being invited, who does not go when invited with the words, “Come, venerable sir, for alms.”🔽He is one who does not wait for the invitation to be repeated, who does not wait for the invitation to be repeated with the words, “Venerable sir, stay for a while.”

original: vacanaṃ kataṃ bhavissatī”ti na karoti. Abhihaṭanti puretaraṃ gahetvā āhaṭaṃ bhikkhaṃ,
analyzed: vacanam katam bhavissati iti na karoti abhihaṭanti puretaram gahetvā āhaṭam bhikkham
translated: It seems that he does not do so because he thinks, “Let what he says be fulfilled.”🔽He is one who takes what is put in his bowl, who takes almsfood put into his bowl.

original: uddissakatanti “imaṃ tumhe uddissa kata”nti evaṃ ārocitaṃ bhikkhaṃ. Na nimantananti
analyzed: uddissa katanti imam tumhe uddissa katanti evam ārocitam bhikkham na nimantananti
translated: He is one who takes what is pointed out, who takes almsfood pointed out thus, “Give to the venerable one what is prepared here.”

original: “asukaṃ nāma kulaṃ vā vīthiṃ vā gāmaṃ vā paviseyyāthā”ti evaṃ nimantitabhikkhampi
analyzed: asukam nāma kulam vā vīthim vā gāmam vā paviseyyātha ati evam nimantita bhikkham pi
translated: He is one who does not consent to an invitation, who does not consent to an invitation thus, “Enter such and such a village or town, venerable sir, for alms.”

original: na sādiyati, na gaṇhati. Na kumbhimukhāti kumbhito uddharitvā diyyamānaṃ bhikkhaṃ🔽na gaṇhati. Na kaḷopimukhāti kaḷopīti ukkhali vā pacchi vā, tatopi na gaṇhati. Kasmā?🔽Kumbhikaḷopiyo maṃ nissāya kaṭacchunā pahāraṃ labhantīti. Na eḷakamantaranti ummāraṃ
analyzed: na sādiyati na gaṇhati na kumbhi mukhā ati kumbhitaḥ uddharitvā diyyamānam bhikkham  na gaṇhati na kaḷopi mukhā ati kaḷopī iti ukkhali vā pacchi vā tatas api na gaṇhati kasmā  kumbhika ḷopiyaḥ mam nissāya kaṭacchunā pahāram labhanti iti na eḷakam antaranti ummāram
translated: He does not accept almsfood that is passed from one bowl to another.🔽He does not accept almsfood that is passed from one vessel to another.🔽Why not? “The pot and the vessel will get a blow from my spoon.” He does not accept almsfood that is given after making a heap.

original: antaraṃ katvā diyyamānaṃ na gaṇhati. Kasmā? “Ayaṃ maṃ nissāya antarakaraṇaṃ labhatī”ti.
analyzed: antaram katvā diyyamānam na gaṇhati kasmai ayam mam nissāya antara karaṇam labhati iti
translated: Why not? “This person will get a blow from my spoon.”

original: Daṇḍamusalesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: daṇḍa musale supi esā iva nayo
translated: The same explanation applies to the case of a stick and a sword.🔽He does not accept almsfood from two people who are eating together, from one of them getting up to give it.

original: Dvinnanti dvīsu bhuñjamānesu ekasmiṃ uṭṭhāya dente na gaṇhati. Kasmā? “Ekassa kabaḷantarāyo🔽hotī”ti. Na gabbhiniyātiādīsu pana “gabbhiniyā kucchiyaṃ dārako kilamati. Pāyantiyā
analyzed: dvinnanti dvīsu bhuñjamānesu ekasmin uṭṭhāya dente na gaṇhati kasmai ekassa kabaḷantarāyo  hoti iti na gabbhiniyā ati ādīsu pana gabbhiniyā kucchiyam dārako kilamati pāyantiyā
translated: Why not? “One of them will be interrupted in his eating.”🔽He does not accept almsfood from a pregnant woman, thinking, “The child in the womb is cramped.”🔽He does not accept almsfood from a woman who is nursing, thinking, “The child’s supply of milk will be interrupted.”

original: dārakassa khīrantarāyo hoti, purisantaragatāya ratiantarāyo hotī”ti na gaṇhati. Saṃkittīsūti
analyzed: dārakassa khīra antarāyaḥ hoti purisa antara gatāya rati antarāyaḥ hoti iti na gaṇhati saṃkittīsu uti
translated: He does not accept almsfood from a woman with a man, thinking, “Their enjoyment will be interrupted.”

original: saṃkittetvā katabhattesu, dubbhikkhasamaye kira acelakasāvakā acelakānaṃ atthāya
analyzed: saṃkittetvā kata bhattesu dubbhikkha samaye kira acelaka sāvakāḥ acelakānam atthāya
translated: and after announcing it, they had the food prepared,🔽at a time of famine, it seems, for the sake of the naked ascetics.

original: tato tato taṇḍulādīni samādapetvā bhattaṃ pacanti. Ukkaṭṭho acelako tatopi na paṭiggaṇhati.🔽Na yattha sāti yattha sunakho – “piṇḍaṃ labhissāmī”ti upaṭṭhito hoti, tattha tassa
analyzed: tato tato taṇḍula ādīni samādapetvā bhattam pacanti ukkaṭṭhaḥ acelako tatas api na paṭiggaṇhati  na yattha sā ati yattha su nakhaḥ piṇḍam labhissāmi iti upaṭṭhitaḥ hoti tattha tassa
translated: When the alms food was announced, it seems, the lay disciples of the naked ascetics collected rice and so on from here and there and cooked it for the naked ascetics in a famine. The naked ascetic Ukkatthāyana did not accept even that.🔽He did not accept what was brought without being offered to him where he was standing, thinking, “I shall get alms.” Why not? Because it would be an obstacle to his alms.

original: adatvā āhaṭaṃ na gaṇhati. Kasmā? Etassa piṇḍantarāyo hotīti. Saṇḍasaṇḍacārinīti samūhasamūhacārinī,
analyzed: a datvā āhaṭam na gaṇhati kasmai etassa piṇḍa antarāyaḥ hoti iti saṇḍa saṇḍa cārinī iti samūha samūha cārinī
translated: He did not accept what was brought from a place where flies were swarming, thinking, “Flies will follow it and settle on my food.”

original: sace hi acelakaṃ disvā – “imassa bhikkhaṃ dassāmā”ti manussā bhattagehaṃ pavisanti,
analyzed: sace hi acelakam disvā imassa bhikkham dassāma ati manussāḥ bhatta geham pavisanti
translated: For if people saw a naked ascetic and thought, “We shall give alms to him,” they would enter the house to fetch the alms food,

original: tesu ca pavisantesu kaḷopimukhādīsu nilīnā makkhikā uppatitvā saṇḍasaṇḍā caranti,
analyzed: tesu ca pavisantesu kaḷopi mukha ādīsu nilīnāḥ makkhikāḥ uppatitvā saṇḍasaṇḍā caranti
translated: and while they were doing so, flies that had settled on the rice and curry would fly up and alight all over the place.

original: tato āhaṭaṃ bhikkhaṃ na gaṇhati. Kasmā? Maṃ nissāya makkhikānaṃ gocarantarāyo jātoti.🔽Thusodakanti sabbasassasambhārehi kataṃ sovīrakaṃ. Ettha ca surāpānameva sāvajjaṃ,
analyzed: tatas āhaṭam bhikkham na gaṇhati kasmā mam nissāya makkhikānam gocara antarāyaḥ jāto ti 🔽thusodakam ti sabba sassa sambhārehi katam sovīrakam ettha ca surā pānam eva sāvajjam
translated: He did not accept what was brought from there, thinking, “Because of me the flies have had an opportunity to contaminate the alms.”🔽He did not accept what was brought in a vessel in which liquor had been kept, thinking, “It has the smell of liquor.” Herein, only the liquor itself is blameworthy,

original: ayaṃ pana sabbesupi sāvajjasaññī. Ekāgārikoti yo ekasmiṃyeva gehe bhikkhaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: ayam pana sabbesu pi sāvajja saññī ekāgāriko ti yaḥ ekasmiṃ yeva gehe bhikkham labhitvā
translated: But this one is aware of danger in all.🔽One who goes for alms in one place only is one who, having got alms in one house, turns back.

original: nivattati. Ekālopikoti yo ekeneva ālopena yāpeti. Dvāgārikādīsupi eseva nayo. Ekissāpi
analyzed: nivattati ekālopikaḥ ti yaḥ ekena iva ālopena yāpeti dvāgārika ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ ekissa api
translated: One who goes for alms in two places: one who gets on with two places. The same method applies to one who goes for alms in three places, etc.🔽One who lives on alms got in one bowl: in one bowl called a “measure” , into which they put the first alms and set it aside.

original: dattiyāti ekāya dattiyā. Datti nāma ekā khuddakapāti hoti, yattha aggabhikkhaṃ pakkhipitvā
analyzed: dattiyā ati ekāya dattiyā datti nāma ekā khuddaka pāti hoti yattha agga bhikkham pakkhipitvā
translated: One who lives on what he gets by one going: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms once a day.🔽One who lives on what he gets by two goings: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms twice a day.🔽One who lives on what he gets by seven goings: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms seven times a day.🔽One who lives on what he gets by one round: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in one round.

original: ṭhapenti. Ekāhikanti ekadivasantarikaṃ. Addhamāsikanti addhamāsantarikaṃ. Pariyāyabhattabhojananti
analyzed: ṭhapenti ekāhikanti eka divasa antarikam addhamāsikanti addha māsa antarikam pariyāya bhatta bhojananti
translated: One who lives on what he gets by two rounds: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in two rounds.🔽One who lives on what he gets by seven rounds: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in seven rounds.🔽One who lives on what he gets by one wandering: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in one wandering.🔽One who lives on what he gets by two wanderings: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in two wanderings.

original: vārabhattabhojanaṃ, ekāhavārena dvīhavārena sattāhavārena aḍḍhamāsavārenāti evaṃ
analyzed: vāra bhatta bhojanam eka aha vārena dvīha vārena sattāha vārena aḍḍha māsa vārena ati evam
translated: One who lives on what he gets by seven wanderings: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in seven wanderings.🔽One who lives on what he gets by one search: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in one search.

original: divasavārena āgatabhattabhojanaṃ.
analyzed: divasa vārena āgata bhatta bhojanam
translated: One who lives on what he gets by two searches: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in two searches.🔽One who lives on what he gets by seven searches: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in seven searches.

original: 395. Sākabhakkhoti allasākabhakkho. Sāmākabhakkhoti sāmākataṇḍulabhakkho. Nīvārādīsu🔽nīvāro nāma araññe sayaṃjātā vīhijāti. Daddulanti cammakārehi cammaṃ likhitvā chaḍḍitakasaṭaṃ.
analyzed: sāka bhakkho ti alla sāka bhakkho sāmāka bhakkho ti sāmāka taṇḍula bhakkhaḥ nīvāra ādīsu 🔽nīvāraḥ nāma araññe sayaṃjātāḥ vīhi jāti daddulanti camma kārehi cammam likhitvā chaḍḍitaka saṭam
translated: One who lives on what he gets by one going: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in one place.🔽One who lives on what he gets by two goings: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in two places.🔽One who lives on what he gets by seven goings: one who lives on what he gets by going for alms in seven

original: Haṭaṃ vuccati silesopi sevālopi. Kaṇanti kuṇḍakaṃ. Ācāmoti bhattaukkhalikāya laggo
analyzed: haṭam vuccati silesopi sevālopi kaṇanti kuṇḍakam ācāmo ti bhatta okkhalikāya laggo
translated: “Refuse” is what is called “rubbish” and “refuse-rag.” “Filth” is a cripple. “Slop” is rice gruel left over from a meal.

original: jhāmakaodano, taṃ chaḍḍitaṭṭhānatova gahetvā khādati, “odanakañjiya”ntipi vadanti.
analyzed: tam chaḍḍita ṭṭhānataḥ uva gahetvā khādati vadanti
translated: He eats it after picking it up from where it is thrown away. They also call it “rice-gruel-refuse.”

original: Piññākādayo pākaṭā eva. Pavattaphalabhojīti patitaphalabhojī.🔽396. Sāṇānīti sāṇavākacoḷāni. Masāṇānīti missakacoḷāni. Chavadussānīti matasarīrato
analyzed: piññāka ādayaḥ pākaṭāḥ eva pavatta phala bhojī iti patita phala bhojī  sāṇāni iti sāṇavāka coḷāni masāṇāni iti missaka coḷāni chava dussāni iti mata sarīrataḥ
translated: “Forest roots and fruits” are obvious. “One who lives on what he gets fortuitously” is one who lives on whatever falls into the chance lap.

original: chaḍḍitavatthāni, erakatiṇādīni vā ganthetvā katanivāsanāni. Paṃsukūlānīti pathaviyaṃ🔽chaḍḍitanantakāni. Tirīṭānīti rukkhatacavatthāni. Ajinanti ajinamigacammaṃ. Ajinakkhipanti
analyzed: chaḍḍita vatthāni eraka tiṇa ādīni vā ganthetvā kata nivāsanāni paṃsukūlāni iti pathaviyam  chaḍḍita nantakāni tirīṭāni iti rukkha taca vatthāni ajinanti ajina miga cammam
translated: “Rag-robes” are robes made of strips of cloth from a rag-heap. “Mixed rags” are robes made of strips of cloth from a rag-heap mixed with other cloth. “Graveyard- refuse” is cloth discarded from a corpse or made of cloth got by collecting from a charnel ground, or made of eraka grass, etc.

original: tadeva majjhe phālitakaṃ. Kusacīranti kusatiṇāni ganthetvā katacīraṃ. Vākacīraphalakacīresupi
analyzed: tat eva majjhe phālitakam kusa cīranti kusa tiṇāni ganthetvā kata cīram
translated: “Refuse-rag” is cloth discarded on the ground. “Tree-cotton” is cloth made of tree cotton. “Deer-skin” is the hide of a deer. “Half- deer-skin” is the same, cut in half. “Grass-cloth” is cloth made of strips of eraka grass, etc. “Bark-cloth” and “leaf-cloth” are made in the same way.

original: eseva nayo. Kesakambalanti manussakesehi katakambalaṃ. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ kesa kambalanti manussa kesehi kata kambalam yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: “Hair-blanket” is a blanket made of human hair. It is said of this that:

original: “Seyyathāpi bhikkhave, yāni kānici tantāvutāni vatthāni, kesakambalo tesaṃ paṭikiṭṭho
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave yāni kānici tantāvutāni vatthāni kesa kambalaḥ tesam paṭikiṭṭhaḥ
translated: “Monks, just as a blanket made of horse-hair is rough to the touch,

original: akkhāyati. Kesakambalo, bhikkhave, sīte sīto, uṇhe uṇho appaggho ca dubbaṇṇo ca duggandho dukkhasamphasso”ti.🔽Vāḷakambalanti assavālehi katakambalaṃ. Ulūkapakkhikanti ulūkapakkhāni ganthetvā🔽katanivāsanaṃ. Ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyuttoti ukkuṭikavīriyaṃ anuyutto, gacchantopi
analyzed: akkhāyati kesa kambalaḥ bhikkhave sīte sītaḥ uṇhe uṇhaḥ appagghaḥ ca dubbaṇṇaḥ ca duggandhaḥ dukkha samphasso ti  vāḷa kambalanti assa vālehi kata kambalam ulūka pakkhikanti ulūka pakkhāni ganthetvā  kata nivāsanam ukkuṭika ppadhānam anuyuttaḥ ti ukkuṭika vīriyam anuyuttaḥ gacchantaḥ api
translated: so too is the blanket of hair. It is cold in cold weather, hot in hot weather, expensive, ugly, and unpleasant to the touch.”🔽A blanket of coarse animal hair: a blanket made of the hair of horses, etc. A blanket of owls’ wings: a blanket made of the wings of owls, etc.

original: ukkuṭikova hutvā uppatitvā uppatitvā gacchati. Kaṇṭakāpassayikoti ayakaṇṭake vā pakatikaṇṭake🔽vā bhūmiyaṃ koṭṭetvā tattha cammaṃ attharitvā ṭhānacaṅkamādīni karoti. Seyyanti sayantopi
analyzed: ukkuṭikaḥ iva hutvā uppatitvā uppatitvā gacchati kaṇṭakāpassayikaḥ ti aya kaṇṭake vā pakati kaṇṭake  vā bhūmiyam koṭṭetvā tattha cammaṃ attharitvā ṭhāna caṅkama ādīni karoti seyyanti sayantaḥ api
translated: Devoted to the practice of squatting: devoted to the practice of standing and walking on tiptoes.

original: tattheva seyyaṃ kappeti. Phalakaseyyanti rukkhaphalake seyyaṃ. Thaṇḍilaseyyanti thaṇḍile
analyzed: tattha iva seyyam kappeti phalaka seyyanti rukkha phalake seyyam thaṇḍila seyyanti thaṇḍile
translated: He sleeps wherever he happens to be: he sleeps wherever he happens to be.

original: ucce bhūmiṭhāne seyyaṃ. Ekapassayikoti ekapasseneva sayati. Rajojalladharoti sarīraṃ🔽telena makkhitvā rajuṭṭhānaṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati, athassa sarīre rajojallaṃ laggati, taṃ🔽dhāreti. Yathāsanthatikoti laddhaṃ āsanaṃ akopetvā yadeva labhati, tattheva nisīdanasīlo.🔽Vekaṭikoti vikaṭakhādanasīlo. Vikaṭanti gūthaṃ vuccati. Apānakoti paṭikkhittasītudakapāno.
analyzed: ucce bhūmi ṭhāne seyyam eka passayiko ti eka passena iva sayati rajaḥ jalladharo ti sarīram  telena makkhitvā raju ṭṭhāna ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati athassa sarīre rajaḥ jallam laggati tam  dhārā iti yathā santhatikā iti laddham āsanam a kopetvā yat eva labhati tattha iva nisīdana sīlo  vekaṭikaḥ ti vikaṭa khādana sīlaḥ vikaṭanti gūtham vuccati apānakaḥ ti paṭikkhitta sīta udaka pānaḥ
translated: He lies down on a high couch. He lies on one side only: he lies down on his right side. He wears dust and dirt: he smears his body with oil and stands in a dusty place, and the dust and dirt stick to his body and he wears that. He is a “as-he-finds-seater”: he is one who has the habit of sitting down on whatever seat he finds.🔽He is a “coarse-food-eater”: he is one who has the habit of eating coarse food. “Coarse food” is said for excrement. He drinks what is prohibited: he drinks cold water that is prohibited.

original: Sāyaṃ tatiyamassāti sāyatatiyakaṃ. Pāto, majjhanhike, sāyanti divasassa tikkhattuṃ🔽pāpaṃ pavāhessāmīti udakorohanānuyogaṃ anuyutto viharatīti.
analyzed: sāyam tatiyam assa ati sāya tatiyakam pāto majjhanhike sāyanti divasassa tikkhattum  pāpam pavāhessāmi iti udakorohana anuyogam anuyuttaḥ viharati iti
translated: He lies down on a high place. He sleeps on one side only. He wears dust and dirt. He smears his body with oil and stands in a dusty place. The dust and dirt stick to his body. He wears that. He uses what he gets. He does not complain about what he gets. He eats coarse food. Coarse means excrement. He drinks what is prohibited. He goes into the water three times a day. In the morning, at midday, and in the evening. He lives engaged in the practice of entering the water.

original: Tapopakkamaniratthakatāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: tapaḥ upakkama niratthaka tā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the uselessness of austerities.

original: 397. Atha bhagavā sīlasampadādīhi vinā tesaṃ tapopakkamānaṃ niratthakataṃ dassento
analyzed: atha bhagavā sīla sampad ādīhi vinā tesam tapaḥ upakkamānam niratthaka tam dassento
translated: Then the Blessed One, showing the uselessness of their austerities without the perfection of virtue, etc.,

original: – “acelako cepi kassapa hotī”tiādimāha. Tattha ārakā vāti dūreyeva. Averanti dosaveravirahitaṃ.
analyzed: acelakaḥ ce pi kassapa hoti itiādim āha tattha ārakā vāti dosa vera virahitam
translated: said, “Kassapa, even if one is a naked ascetic,” etc. Here, far away means far away. Without hatred means free from the hatred of ill will.

original: Abyāpajjanti domanassabyāpajjarahitaṃ.
analyzed: a byāpajjanti domanassa byāpajja rahitam
translated: They are not offensive, they are free from the offense of displeasure.

original: 398. Dukkaraṃ, bho gotamāti idaṃ kassapo “mayaṃ pubbe ettakamattaṃ sāmaññañca brahmaññañcāti

original: mama sīlasamena sīlena mayā samaṃ puggalaṃ na passāmīti attho. Ahameva tattha bhiyyoti🔽ahameva tasmiṃ sīle uttamo. Katamasmiṃ? Yadidaṃ adhisīlanti yaṃ etaṃ uttamaṃ sīlanti
analyzed: mama sīla samena sīlena mayā samam puggalam na passāmi iti atthaḥ aham eva tattha bhiyyaḥ ti  aham eva tasmin sīle katamasmin yat idam adhisīlanti yam etam uttamam sīlanti

original: attho. Iti imaṃ paṭhamaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati.🔽Tapojigucchavādāti ye tapojigucchaṃ vadanti. Tattha tapatīti tapo, kilesasantāpakavīriyassetaṃ
analyzed: iti imam paṭhamam sīha nādam nadati  tapojigucchavādāti ye tapojiguccham vadanti tattha tapati iti tapo kilesa santāpaka vīriyaḥ etam
translated: I am the best in that virtue. In what? In that which is called the highest virtue. The meaning is: in that which is called the supreme virtue. Thus he roars his first lion’s roar.

original: nāmaṃ, tadeva te kilese jigucchatīti jigucchā. Ariyā paramāti ettha niddosattā ariyā,
analyzed: nāmam tat eva te kilese jigucchati iti jigucchā ariyā paramā ati ettha niddosattā ariyā
translated: Ascetic and moral devotee: here ascetic is austerity, a name for the energy that burns up the defilements. That itself is the moral devotee, since it is disgusted with the defilements. The noble ones are supreme: here the noble ones are so called because they are free from hate.

original: aṭṭhaārambhavatthuvasenapi uppannā vipassanāvīriyasaṅkhātā tapojigucchā tapojigucchāva,🔽maggaphalasampayuttā paramā nāma. Adhijegucchanti idha jigucchabhāvo jegucchaṃ, uttamaṃ
analyzed: uppannā vipassanā vīriya saṅkhātā tapojigucchā tapojigucchā ava  magga phala sampayuttā paramā nāma adhijegucchanti idha jiguccha bhāvaḥ jeguccham uttamam
translated: The austerity and moral devotee that arises by way of the eight grounds for the exercise of energy is austerity and moral devotee.

original: jegucchaṃ adhijegucchaṃ, tasmā yadidaṃ adhijegucchaṃ, tattha ahameva bhiyyoti evamettha
analyzed: jeguccham adhijeguccham tasmai yat idam adhijeguccham tattha aham eva bhiyyaḥ iti evam ettha
translated: The austerity and moral devotee associated with the path and fruit is called supreme. Here the state of being disgusted is disgust. The highest disgust is supreme disgust. Therefore, I am the best there in that which is called supreme disgust. Thus he roars his first lion’s roar.

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Paññādhikārepi kammassakatāpaññā ca vipassanāpaññā ca paññā nāma,
analyzed: attho daṭṭhabbo paññā adhikāre pi kammassaka tā paññā ca vipassanā paññā ca paññā nāma
translated: In the case of understanding, too, the understanding of the state of being one’s own , and insight-understanding are called understanding.🔽The supreme understanding is that associated with the path and fruit.

original: maggaphalasampayuttā paramā paññā nāma. Adhipaññanti ettha liṅgavipallāso veditabbo,
analyzed: magga phala sampayuttā paramā paññā nāma adhipaññanti ettha liṅga vipallāsaḥ veditabbo

original: vimutti nāma, samucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇavimuttiyo pana paramā vimuttīti veditabbā.
analyzed: vimutti nāma samuccheda paṭipassaddhi nissaraṇa vimuttiyaḥ pana paramā vimuttī iti veditabbā
translated: But the kinds of freedom consisting in the severing of the fetters, in the calming of them, and in the escape from them should be understood as the supreme kinds of freedom.

translated: And here too the meaning is that “the freedom called ‘supreme freedom’ is just mine, not another’s.”🔽In an empty place: in an empty house. The intention is that he should sit alone.

translated: And in assemblies: in the eight assemblies . For this is said:

analyzed: byākaroti iti vissajjesi cittam ārādheti iti pañhā vissajjanena mahājanassa  cittam paritosetiyā iva no ca kho sotabbam maññanti iti cittam ārādhetvā kathentassa pissa

translated: “My Saṅgha of disciples is the best” is one. “My Saṅgha of disciples is the best in taking up wholesome qualities” is one.

analyzed: ekaḥ paññāyape vimuttiyāpe sīha nādam nadantaḥ parisamajjhe nisīditvā nadāmi iti
translated: “There is no one equal to me in virtue” is one. “There is no one equal to me in concentration” is one. “There is no one equal to me in wisdom” is one. “There is no one equal to me in freedom” is one. “I sit in the midst of the assembly and roar my lion’s roar” is one.

analyzed: ekaḥ visāradaḥ hutvā nadāmi iti ekaḥ pañham mama pucchanti iti ekaḥ pañham puṭṭhaḥ vissajjemi iti
translated: “I roar confidently” is one. “They ask me questions” is one. “When asked, I answer” is one.

original: eko. Vissajjanena parassa cittaṃ ārādhemīti eko. Sutvā sotabbaṃ maññantīti eko. Sutvā🔽me pasīdantīti eko. Pasannākāraṃ karontīti eko. Yaṃ paṭipattiṃ desemi, tathattāya
analyzed: ekaḥ vissajjanena parassa cittam ārādhemi iti ekaḥ sutvā sotabbam maññanti iti ekaḥ sutvā  me pasīdanti iti ekaḥ pasanna ākāram karonti iti ekaḥ yam paṭipattim desemi tathattāya
translated: “By my answers I satisfy the minds of others” is one. “They think what they hear is worth hearing” is one.🔽“They are confident in me” is one. “They show their confidence” is one. “They practice in accordance with the way I teach” is one.

original: paṭipajjantīti eko. Paṭipannā ca maṃ ārādhentīti eko. Iti purimānaṃ dasannaṃ ekekassa
analyzed: paṭipajjanti iti ekaḥ paṭipannā ca mama ārādhenti iti ekaḥ iti purimānam dasannam ekekassa
translated: “Those who practice satisfy me” is one. Thus, of the first ten, each one is one.

original: – “parisāsu ca nadatī”ti ādayo dasa dasa parivārā. Evaṃ te dasa purimānaṃ dasannaṃ🔽parivāravasena sataṃ purimā ca dasāti dasādhikaṃ sīhanādasataṃ hoti. Ito aññasmiṃ
analyzed: parisāsu ca nadati iti ādayaḥ dasa dasa parivārāḥ evam te dasa purimānam  parivāra vasena satam purimā ca dasa ati dasa adhikam sīha nāda satam hoti itas aññasmin
translated: are the retinues of the first ten.

original: pana sutte ettakā sīhanādā dullabhā, tenidaṃ suttaṃ mahāsīhanādanti vuccati. Iti🔽bhagavā “sīhanādaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo nadati, tañca kho suññāgāre nadatī”ti evaṃ vādānu
analyzed: pana sutte ettakā sīha nādā dullabhā tena idam suttam mahā sīha nādanti vuccati iti  bhagavā sīha nādam kho samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ nadati tat ca kho suññāgāre nadati iti evam vāda anu
translated: But in other suttas, there are not so many lion’s roars as in this sutta. Therefore this sutta is called the Great Lion’s Roar. Thus,

original: vādaṃ paṭisedhetvā idāni parisati naditapubbaṃ sīhanādaṃ dassento “ekamidāha”ntiādimāha.

original: Titthiyaparivāsakathāvaṇṇanā🔽404. Tattha tatra maṃ aññataro tapabrahmacārīti tatra rājagahe gijjhakūṭe pabbate🔽viharantaṃ maṃ aññataro tapabrahmacārī nigrodho nāma paribbājako. Adhijeguccheti
analyzed: titthiya parivāsa kathā vaṇṇanā  tattha tatra mama aññataraḥ tapa brahmacārī iti tatra rājagahe gijjhakūṭe pabbate  viharantam mama aññataraḥ tapa brahmacārī nigrodhaḥ nāma paribbājakaḥ adhijeguccha iti
translated: The explanation of the story of the wandering of the sectarians.

original: vīriyena pāpajigucchanādhikāre pañhaṃ pucchi. Idaṃ yaṃ taṃ bhagavā gijjhakūṭe mahāvihāre

analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tassa tibba chanda tam viditvā na kassapaḥ parivāsam arahati iti

analyzed: aññataram bhikkhum āmantesi gaccha bhikkhu kassapam nhāpetvā pabbājetvā ānehi iti

original: So tathā katvā taṃ pabbājetvā bhagavato santikaṃ āgamāsi. Bhagavā taṃ gaṇamajjhe🔽nisīdāpetvā upasampādesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “alattha kho acelo kassapo bhagavato santike
analyzed: saḥ tathā katvā tam pabbājetvā bhagavatoḥ santikam āgamāsi bhagavā tam gaṇa majjhe  nisīdāpetvā upasampādesi tena vuttam alattha kho acelaḥ kassapaḥ bhagavato santike

analyzed: pabbajjam alattha upasampadanti acirupasampannaḥ iti upasampannaḥ hutvā naciram eva  vūpakaṭṭho ti vatthu kāma kilesa kāmehi kāyena ca iva cittena ca vūpakaṭṭhaḥ appamatto ti  kammaṭṭhāne satim a vijahantaḥ ātāpī iti kāyika cetasika saṅkhātena vīriya ātāpena ātāpī

Not long after his Acceptance: having become a monk, not long after that.🔽Well-concentrated: well-concentrated in body and in mind by abandoning bodily and mental desires. He was heedful: he did not abandon mindfulness in the meditation subject.🔽He was ardent: he was ardent with the ardour of energy consisting in bodily and mental work.

original: Pahitattoti kāye ca jīvite ca anapekkhatāya pesitacitto vissaṭṭhaattabhāvo. Yassatthāyāti🔽yassa atthāya. Kulaputtāti ācārakulaputtā. Sammadevāti hetunāva kāraṇeneva. Tadanuttaranti
analyzed: pahita tto ti kāye ca jīvite ca anapekkha tāya pesita cittaḥ vissaṭṭha atta bhāvaḥ yassa atthāya ati  yassa atthāya kula puttā ati ācāra kula puttā sammat eva ati hetunā ava kāraṇena iva tat anuttaranti
translated: He was resolute: he was one who had resolved his mind, who had set his mind on the task, who was not concerned about his body or his life. For the sake of which: for the sake of which purpose.

original: taṃ anuttaraṃ. Brahmacariyapariyosānanti maggabrahmacariyassa pariyosānabhūtaṃ arahattaphalaṃ.
analyzed: tam anuttaram brahmacariya pariyosānanti magga brahmacariyassa pariyosāna bhūtam arahatta phalam
translated: Young men of good family: young men of good conduct. Rightly: by means of a cause, by means of a reason. That unsurpassed: that unsurpassed. The culmination of the spiritual life: the fruition of Arahantship, which is the culmination of the spiritual life of the path.

original: Tassa hi atthāya kulaputtā pabbajanti. Diṭṭheva dhammeti imasmiṃyeva attabhāve. Sayaṃ
analyzed: tassa hi atthāya kula puttā pabbajanti diṭṭhe iva dhamme iti imasmin yeva atta bhāve sayam

analyzed: jātipe abbhaññāsi iti  evam assa paccavekkhaṇa bhūmim dassetvā arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpetum aññataro

original: na desessāmā”ti evaṃ parivitakkapubbabhāgo panesa sabbabuddhānaṃ labbhati. Tenāha
analyzed: na desessāma iti evam parivitakka pubba bhāgaḥ pana isa sabba buddhānam labbhati tena āha
translated: as to what they should do or not do, or what Dhamma they should teach or not teach. However, this preliminary reflection is found in all Buddhas. Therefore it is said:

analyzed: yaṃnūna ahanti yadi pana ahanti attho

analyzed: unnādiniyā ati uccam nadamānāya evam nadamānāya ca ssā uddham gamana vasena uccaḥ

original: vuṭṭhāya kattabbaṃ nāma cetiyavattaṃ vā bodhivattaṃ vā ācariyupajjhāyavattaṃ vā yoniso🔽manasikāro vā natthi. analyzed: vuṭṭhāya kattabbam nāma cetiya vattam vā bodhi vattam vā ācariya upajjhāya vattam vā yoniso  manasikāraḥ vā na atthi tena te pātova vuṭṭhāya bāla ātape nisinnā imassa hatthaḥ sobhano  imassa pādaḥ ti evam añña maññassa hattha pāda ādīni vā ārabbha itthi purisa dāraka dārikā ādīnam  vaṇṇe vā aññam vā kāmassāda bhavassāda ādi vatthum ārabbha katham samuṭṭhāpetvā anupubbena  rāja kathā ādi anekavidham tiracchāna katham kathenti tena vuttam unnādiniyā uccāsadda mahāsaddāya
translated: saying, “His hands are beautiful,” “His feet are beautiful,” etc., or about the beauty of women, men, boys, and girls, etc.,🔽or about some other topic that leads to sensual pleasures and worldly success. original: anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentiyā”ti.
analyzed: aneka vihitam tiracchāna katham
translated: Therefore it is said, “in a noisy and loud voice, in a voice that is not calm, in a discussion that is not calm, in a discussion that is not conducive to opening up the heart, in a discussion that is not conducive to concentration of the mind, in a discussion that is not conducive to the destruction of the taints, in a discussion that is not conducive to the attainment of the unsurpassed security from bondage.”

original: Tato poṭṭhapādo paribbājako te paribbājake oloketvā – “ime paribbājakā ativiya aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: tato poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājako te paribbājake oloketvā ime paribbājakāḥ ativiya aññamaññam

original: agāravā, mayañca samaṇassa gotamassa pātubhāvato paṭṭhāya sūriyuggamane khajjopanakūpamā🔽jātā, lābhasakkāropi no parihīno. Sace panimaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇo gotamo vā gotamassa🔽sāvako vā gihī upaṭṭhāko vā tassa āgaccheyya, ativiya lajjanīyaṃ bhavissati, parisadoso
analyzed: agāravāḥ mayam ca samaṇassa gotamassa pātubhāvataḥ paṭṭhāya sūri yuggamane khajjopana kūpamā  jātā lābha sakkāro api no parihīno sace panimam ṭhānam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ vā gotamassa  sāvakaḥ vā gihī upaṭṭhāko vā tassa āgaccheyya lajjanīyam bhavissati parisa doso
translated: and since the appearance of the ascetic Gotama we have been like a piece of meat to a hawk,🔽and we have lost our gains and fame. But if the ascetic Gotama or one of his disciples or a lay follower of his were to come here, it would be a great embarrassment,🔽and we would be at fault.

original: kho pana parisajeṭṭhakasseva upari ārohatī”ti itocito ca vilokento bhagavantaṃ addasa.
analyzed: kho pana parisa jeṭṭhakassa iva upari ārohati iti itocitaḥ ca vilokentaḥ bhagavantam addasa
translated: and we have become like a dish of rice at sunrise since the time of the Blessed One’s appearance. And we have lost gain and fame. If the recluse Gotama or one of his disciples or a lay follower of his should come here, it would be a very great shame for us. For the fault of a gathering falls on the head of the chief of the gathering” . And as he looked here and there he saw the Blessed One.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “addasā kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako…pe… tuṇhī ahesu”nti.
analyzed: tena vuttam addasā kho poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājaka ope tuṇhī ahesun ti
translated: Hence it was said above: “The wanderer Poṭṭhapāda saw the Blessed One coming in the distance” .

original: 409. Tattha saṇṭhapesīti sikkhāpesi, vajjamassā paṭicchādesi. Yathā susaṇṭhitā hoti,
analyzed: tattha saṇṭhapesi iti sikkhāpesi vajjam assā paṭicchādesi yathā su saṇṭhitā hoti
translated: Herein, he arranged it is he trained it, he concealed its fault. He set it up so that it would be well arranged.

original: tathā naṃ ṭhapesi. Yathā nāma parisamajjhaṃ pavisanto puriso vajjapaṭicchādanatthaṃ🔽nivāsanaṃ saṇṭhapeti, pārupanaṃ saṇṭhapeti, rajokiṇṇaṭṭhānaṃ puñchati; evamassā vajjapaṭicchādanatthaṃ
analyzed: tathā nam ṭhapesi yathā nāma parisa majjham pavisantaḥ purisaḥ vajja paṭicchādana attham 🔽nivāsanam saṇṭhapeti pārupanam saṇṭhapeti rajaḥ kiṇṇa ṭṭhānam puñchati evam assāḥ vajja paṭicchādana attham
translated: Just as a man entering a gathering arranges his under and upper garments and brushes off his seat,🔽so he concealed its fault.

translated: “Quiet, good sirs,” he trains them, and he establishes them in that way so that they are well-ordered.

Paribbājakā kira buddhesu🔽vā buddhasāvakesu vā attano santikaṃ āgatesu – “ajja amhākaṃ santikaṃ samaṇo gotamo🔽āgato, sāriputto āgato, na kho pana te yassa vā tassa vā santikaṃ gacchanti, passatha
analyzed: appasadda kāmo ti appasaddam icchati ekaḥ nisīdati ekaḥ tiṭṭhati na gaṇa saṅgaṇikāya  yāpa iti upasaṅkamitabbam maññeyya ati idha āgantabbam maññeyya kasmā pana isa bhagavataḥ  upasaṅkamanam paccāsīsati iti attanaḥ vuddhim patthayamāno paribbājakāḥ kira buddhesu  vā buddha sāvakesu vā attanaḥ santikam āgatesu ajja amhākam santikam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ  āgataḥ sāriputtaḥ āgataḥ na kho pana te yassa vā tassa vā santikam gacchanti passatha
translated: Desiring quiet: he desires quiet. One sits down, one stands up, one does not live in a crowd.

original: amhākaṃ uttamabhāva”nti attano upaṭṭhākānaṃ santike attānaṃ ukkhipanti, ucce ṭhāne🔽ṭhapenti, bhagavatopi upaṭṭhāke gaṇhituṃ vāyamanti. Te kira bhagavato upaṭṭhāke disvā
analyzed: amhākam uttama bhāvanti attanaḥ upaṭṭhākānam santike attānam ukkhipanti ucce ṭhāne 🔽ṭhapenti bhagavataḥ api upaṭṭhāke gaṇhitum vā āyamanti te kira bhagavataḥ upaṭṭhāke disvā
translated: One should think of approaching: one should think of coming here. But why does he turn away from approaching the Blessed One? He is seeking his own welfare. Wanderers, it seems, when a Buddha or a disciple of the Buddha comes to them, think thus: “To-day the recluse Gotama has come to us, or Sāriputta has come, or so and so has come. But they do not go to us. See our pre-eminence.” They exalt themselves among their own pupils, they exalt themselves in the presence of their own pupils, they exalt themselves among their own pupils’ pupils, they exalt themselves in the presence of their own pupils’ pupils, they exalt themselves among their own pupils’ pupils’ pupils, they exalt themselves in the presence of their own pupils’ pupils’ pupils. They try to get the Blessed One’s pupils to go over to them, they try to get his own pupils’ pupils to go over to them, they try to get his own pupils’ pupils’ pupils to go over to them. When they see the Blessed One’s pupils,

original: evaṃ vadanti – “tumhākaṃ satthā bhavaṃ gotamopi gotamasāvakāpi amhākaṃ santikaṃ āgacchanti,🔽mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ samaggā. Tumhe pana amhe akkhīhipi passituṃ na icchatha, sāmīcikammaṃ🔽na karotha, kiṃ vo amhehi aparaddha”nti. Athekacce manussā – “buddhāpi etesaṃ santikaṃ
analyzed: evam vadanti tumhākam satthā bhavam gotamaḥ api gotama sāvakā api amhākam santikam āgacchanti  mayam aññamaññam samaggā tumhe pana amhe passitum na icchatha sāmīcikammaṃ  na karotha kim vaḥ amhehi aparaddhanti atha ekacce manussāḥ buddhāḥ api etesam santikam
translated: “Your teacher, Master Gotama, and your disciples come to us,🔽but we do not want to see you, Master Gotama, nor do we want to do you honour. What have we done to displease you?”

original: gacchanti kiṃ amhāka”nti tato paṭṭhāya te disvā nappamajjanti. Tuṇhī ahesunti poṭṭhapādaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti kim amhākan ti tatas paṭṭhāya te disvā na pamajjanti tuṇhī ahesunti poṭṭhapādam
translated: Some people thought: “If the Buddhas go to them, why shouldn’t we?” And from then on they did not neglect to visit them.

original: parivāretvā nissaddā nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: parivāretvā nissaddāḥ nisīdiṃsu
translated: They sat down in silence: they sat down in the place reserved for the Teacher, surrounding the Elder and remaining silent.

original: 410. Svāgataṃ, bhanteti suṭṭhu āgamanaṃ, bhante, bhagavato; bhagavati hi no āgate
analyzed: svāgatam bhanta iti suṭṭhu āgamanam bhante bhagavataḥ bhagavati hi naḥ āgate
translated: Welcome, Master Gotama: he says: “Welcome, Master Gotama,” meaning: “It is good that Master Gotama has come;🔽when Master Gotama comes, we are glad, but when he goes, we are sad.”

original: ānando hoti, gate sokoti dīpeti. Cirassaṃ kho, bhanteti kasmā āha? Kiṃ bhagavā pubbepi
analyzed: ānandaḥ hoti gate sokaḥ iti dīpeti cirassam kho bhante iti kasmai āha kim bhagavā pubbe pi
translated: Why does he say: “It is long since Master Gotama went to see the brahmin Pokkharasati”?

original: tattha gatapubboti, na gatapubbo. Manussānaṃ pana – “kuhiṃ gacchantā, kuto āgatattha,
analyzed: tattha gata pubbaḥ ti na gata pubbaḥ manussānam pana kuhim gacchantā kutas
translated: Did not Master Gotama go there before? He did not go before. But people said: “Where are you going? Where have you come from?

original: kiṃ maggamūḷhattha, cirassaṃ āgatatthā”ti evamādayo piyasamudācārā honti, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: kim cirassam āgata ttha ati evamādayaḥ piya samudācārāḥ honti tasmai evam āha
translated: “Are you lost on the path? Have you come after a long time?” and so on.

original: Evañca pana vatvā na mānathaddho hutvā nisīdi, uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavato paccuggamanamakāsi.
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā na mānathaddhaḥ hutvā nisīdi uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavato paccuggamanam akāsi
translated: Having spoken thus, he did not sit down with his head bent down with shame, but he rose from his seat and welcomed the Blessed One.

original: Bhagavantañhi upagataṃ disvā āsanena animantento vā apacitiṃ akaronto vā dullabho.
analyzed: bhagavantam hi upagatam disvā āsanena a nimantentaḥ vā apacitim a karontaḥ vā dullabhaḥ
translated: For, having seen the Blessed One come, it is difficult for one to be disrespectful or not to invite him to a seat.

original: Kasmā? Uccākulīnatāya. Ayampi paribbājako attano nisinnāsanaṃ papphoṭetvā bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: kasmai ucca akulīna tāya ayam pi paribbājakaḥ attanaḥ nisinnāsanam papphoṭetvā bhagavantam
translated: Why? Because of his high birth. This wanderer, too, having rubbed his own seat,🔽invited the Blessed One to a seat, saying: “Let the Blessed One sit down, venerable Sir, this seat is prepared.”

original: āsanena nimantento – “nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā idamāsanaṃ paññatta”nti āha. Antarākathā
