original: dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho poṭṭhapāda mayā ekaṃsiko dhammo desito”ti ettha
analyzed: dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati kho poṭṭhapāda mayā ekaṃsikaḥ dhammaḥ desito ti ettha
translated: in the way already stated in the passage ‘ “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering” is a single track, Potthapada, that I teach’ ,

original: sammādiṭṭhisammāsaṅkappavasena pariyāpannattā āgatāti veditabbā. Kāmasaññāti pañcakāmaguṇikarāgopi
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappa vasena pariyāpanna ttā āgatā iti veditabbā kāma saññā iti pañca kāma guṇika rāgaḥ api
translated: where it is included under right view and right thought . ‘ Sensual perceptions’ : sensual desire for the five strands of sensual desire is one kind of sensual perception,

original: asamuppannakāmacāropi. Tattha pañcakāmaguṇikarāgo anāgāmimaggena samugghātaṃ gacchati,
analyzed: asamuppanna kāmacāraḥ api tattha pañca kāmaguṇika rāgaḥ anāgāmi maggena samugghātam gacchati
translated: and non-arisen sensual lust is another kind. Herein, sensual desire for the five strands of sensual desire is what is abandoned by the path of non-return,

original: asamuppannakāmacāro pana imasmiṃ ṭhāne vaṭṭati. Tasmā tassa yā purimā kāmasaññāti
analyzed: a samuppanna kāmacāraḥ pana imasmim ṭhāne vaṭṭati tasmā tassa yā purimā kāma saññā ati
translated: but non-arisen sensual lust is what is intended here. Therefore ‘any previous sensual perception’

original: tassa paṭhamajjhānasamaṅgino yā pubbe uppannapubbāya kāmasaññāya sadisattā purimā
analyzed: tassa paṭhamajjhāna samaṅginaḥ yā pubbe uppanna pubbāya kāma saññāya sadisa ttā purimā
translated: is said of the kind that is similar to the sensual perception that arose previously in one who possesses the first jhana.

original: kāmasaññāti vucceyya, sā nirujjhati, anuppannāva nuppajjatīti attho.
analyzed: kāma saññā iti vucceyya sā nirujjhati anuppannā ava nuppajjati iti attho
translated: The meaning is that it ceases and does not arise again.

original: Vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hotīti tasmiṃ paṭhamajjhānasamaye
analyzed: tasmin samaye hoti iti tasmin paṭhamajjhāna samaye
translated: ‘He is one who feels only the pleasant and the neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant’ .

original: vivekajapītisukhasaṅkhātā sukhumasaññā saccā hoti, bhūtā hotīti attho. Atha vā kāmacchandādioḷārikaṅgappahānavasena🔽sukhumā ca sā bhūtatāya saccā ca saññāti sukhumasaccasaññā, vivekajehi pītisukhehi
analyzed: viveka ja pīti sukha saṅkhātā sukhuma saññā saccā hoti bhūtā hoti iti attho atha vā kāmacchanda ādi oḷārika aṅga ppahāna vasena  sukhumā ca sā bhūta tāya saccā ca saññā ati sukhuma sacca saññā viveka jehi pīti sukhehi
translated: The perception of the fine, which is called the happiness and bliss born of seclusion, is true, is fact, is what happens, is the case. Or alternatively, it is fine since it is the abandoning of the gross factors beginning with lust,🔽and it is true and a fact since it is a real thing, thus it is the fine-fact perception. Associated with the happiness and bliss born of seclusion,

original: sampayuttā sukhumasaccasaññāti vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā sā assa atthīti
analyzed: sampayuttā sukhuma sacca saññā ati viveka ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññā sā assa atthi iti
translated: it is the perception of the fine and the true, thus it is the perception of the fine and the true born of seclusion. He has that perception,

original: vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: viveka ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññī iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ esa nayaḥ sabbattha
translated: thus he is a “contemplator of the fine and the true born of seclusion.” This is how the meaning should be regarded here. So too with all the rest.

original: Evampi sikkhāti ettha yasmā paṭhamajjhānaṃ samāpajjanto adhiṭṭhahanto, vuṭṭhahanto
analyzed: evam pi sikkhāti ettha yasmai paṭhama jhānam samāpajjantaḥ adhiṭṭhahantaḥ vuṭṭhahantaḥ
translated: “He trains like this”: he trains thus because he trains in attaining, determining, and emerging from the first jhāna.🔽That is why it is said that the first jhāna is “training” in this sense.

original: ca sikkhati, tasmā taṃ evaṃ sikkhitabbato sikkhāti vuccati. Tenapi sikkhāsaṅkhātena
analyzed: ca sikkhati tasmā tam evam sikkhitabbataḥ sikkhā ati vuccati tena api sikkhā saṅkhātena
translated: And it is by means of that same first jhāna that has the name of “training”

original: paṭhamajjhānena evaṃ ekā vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā uppajjati. Evaṃ ekā kāmasaññā
analyzed: paṭhama jhānena evam ekā viveka ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññā uppajjati evam ekā kāma saññā
translated: that this one kind of perception arises in him, that is to say, the perception of the fine and the true born of seclusion.

original: nirujjhatīti attho. Ayaṃ sikkhāti bhagavā avocāti ayaṃ paṭhamajjhānasaṅkhātā ekā
analyzed: nirujjhati iti atthaḥ ayam sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca ati ayam paṭhama jhāna saṅkhātā ekā
translated: the meaning is, it ceases. This training, the Blessed One said: this one training, called the first jhāna, the Blessed One said. The meaning should be construed in each instance in this way.🔽But since the discerning of the jhāna factors belongs only to Buddhas and is not found in disciples even such as Sāriputta,🔽only the discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation is found in disciples. And this discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation has been brought in here by the words “perception and attention accompanied by sensuality” and so on.🔽But since the discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation belongs only to Buddhas and is not found in disciples even such as Sāriputta,🔽only the discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation is found in disciples. And this discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation has been brought in here by the words “perception and attention accompanied by sensuality” and so on.🔽But since the discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation belongs only to Buddhas and is not found in disciples even such as Sāriputta,🔽only the discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation is found in disciples. And this discerning of the jhāna factors by approximation has been brought in here by the words “perception and attention accompanied by sensuality” and so on.🔽 Translation: nirujjhatīti attho | ayaṃ sikkhāti bhagavā avocāti ayaṃ paṭhamajjhānasaṅkhātā ekā

original: sikkhāti, bhagavā āha. Etenupāyena sabbattha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: sikkhā iti bhagavā āha etena upāyena sabbattha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: sikkhāti bhagavā āha | etenupāyena sabbattha attho daṭṭhabbo |

original: Yasmā pana aṭṭhamasamāpattiyā aṅgato sammasanaṃ buddhānaṃyeva hoti, sāvakesu sāriputtasadisānampi
analyzed: yasmā pana aṭṭhama samāpattiyāḥ aṅgato sammasanam buddhānam yeva hoti sāvakesu sāriputta sadisānam pi
translated: yasmā pana aṭṭhamasamāpattiyā aṅgato sammasanaṃ buddhānaṃyeva hoti, sāvakesu sāriputtasadisānampi

original: natthi, kalāpato sammasanaṃyeva pana sāvakānaṃ hoti, idañca “saññā saññā”ti, evaṃ
analyzed: natthi kalāpato sammasanam yā iva pana sāvakānam hoti idam ca saññā saññā ti evam
translated: natthi, kalāpato sammasanaṃyeva pana sāvakānaṃ hoti, idañca “saññā saññā”ti, evaṃ

original: aṅgato sammasanaṃ uddhaṭaṃ. Tasmā ākiñcaññāyatanaparamaṃyeva saññaṃ dassetvā puna
analyzed: aṅgataḥ sammasanam uddhaṭam tasmai ākiñcaññāyatana paramaṃyā iva saññam dassetvā puna
translated: aṅgato sammasanaṃ uddhaṭaṃ | tasmā ākiñcaññāyatanaparamaṃyeva saññaṃ dassetvā puna

original: tadeva saññagganti dassetuṃ “yato kho poṭṭhapāda…pe… saññaggaṃ phusatī”ti āha.🔽414. Tattha yato kho poṭṭhapāda bhikkhūti yo nāma poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu. Idha sakasaññī🔽hotīti idha sāsane sakasaññī hoti, ayameva vā pāṭho, attano paṭhamajjhānasaññāya
analyzed: tat eva saññagganti dassetum yatas kho poṭṭhapādape saññaggam phusati iti āha 🔽tattha yatas kho poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu iti yaḥ nāma poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu idha saka saññī 🔽hoti iti idha sāsane saka saññī hoti ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ attanaḥ paṭhamajjhāna saññāya
translated: tadeva saññagganti dassetuṃ “yato kho poṭṭhapāda…pe… saññaggaṃ phusatī”ti āha |

original: saññavā hotīti attho. So tato amutra tato amutrāti so bhikkhu tato paṭhamajjhānato
analyzed: saññavā hoti iti attho so tatas amutra tatas amutra ati so bhikkhu tatas paṭhamajjhānato
translated: the meaning is, he is percipient.🔽From there he emerges and he arrives at the second jhāna …

original: amutra dutiyajjhāne, tatopi amutra tatiyajjhāneti evaṃ tāya tāya jhānasaññāya sakasaññī
analyzed: amutra dutiya jhāne tatas api amutra tatiya jhāne iti evam tāya tāya jhāna saññāya saka saññī
translated: the meaning is, he has perception. He has perception of that and that: that bhikkhu has perception of that first jhana and that second jhana, and so on. Thus with perception of this or that jhana he is himself the perceiver.

original: sakasaññī hutvā anupubbena saññaggaṃ phusati. Saññagganti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ vuccati.
analyzed: saka saññī hutvā anupubbena saññaggam phusati saññaggam ti ākiñcaññāyatanam vuccati
translated: Having become a perceiver, he eventually touches the peak of perception. The base consisting of nothingness is called the peak of perception.

original: Kasmā? Lokiyānaṃ kiccakārakasamāpattīnaṃ aggattā. Ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattiyañhi ṭhatvā🔽nevasaññānāsaññāyatanampi nirodhampi samāpajjanti. Iti sā lokiyānaṃ kiccakārakasamāpattīnaṃ
analyzed: kasmā lokiyānam kicca kāraka samāpattīnam agga ttā ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattiyam hi  nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam pi nirodham pi samāpajjanti iti sā lokiyānam kicca kāraka samāpattīnam
translated: Why? Because it is the highest of the mundane kinds of direct-knowledge attainment. For standing in the base consisting of nothingness,

original: aggattā saññagganti vuccati, taṃ phusati pāpuṇātīti attho.🔽Idāni abhisaññānirodhaṃ dassetuṃ “tassa saññagge ṭhitassā”tiādimāha. Tattha ceteyyaṃ,
analyzed: agga ttā saññagganti vuccati tam phusati pāpuṇāti iti attho  idāni abhisaññā nirodham dassetum tassa saññagge ṭhitassa ati ādim āha tattha ceteyyam
translated: he enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and the attainment of cessation. So it is called the peak of perception because it is the highest of the mundane kinds of direct-knowledge attainment. He touches it: he reaches it.

original: abhisaṅkhareyyanti padadvaye ca jhānaṃ samāpajjanto ceteti nāma, punappunaṃ kappetīti
analyzed: abhisaṅkhareyyanti pada dvaye ca jhānam samāpajjanto cetā iti nāma punappunam kappeti iti
translated: Now, in order to point out the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, he said, “When he is thus standing in the peak of perception” . Herein, he would form, he would contrive: when he enters upon jhana, he is said to form it and to contrive it, since he makes it again and again.

original: attho. Uparisamāpattiatthāya nikantiṃ kurumāno abhisaṅkharoti nāma. Imā ca me saññā
analyzed: atthaḥ upari samāpatti atthāya nikantim kurumānaḥ abhisaṅkharoti nāma imā ca me saññā
translated: He is called “one who does not intend and does not form” in the sense that he does not form the intention and the formation of resolve for the purpose of attaining the higher attainment.🔽May these perceptions of mine cease: may these perceptions of the base of nothingness cease.

original: nirujjheyyunti imā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā nirujjheyyuṃ. Aññā ca oḷārikāti aññā ca oḷārikā🔽bhavaṅgasaññā uppajjeyyuṃ. So na ceva ceteti na abhisaṅkharotīti ettha kāmaṃ cesa🔽cetentova na ceteti, abhisaṅkharontova nābhisaṅkharoti. Imassa bhikkhuno ākiñcaññāyatanato🔽vuṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā “ekaṃ dve cittavāre ṭhassāmī”ti ābhogasamannāhāro
analyzed: nirujjheyyunti imāḥ ākiñcaññāyatana saññāḥ nirujjheyyuṃ aññā ca oḷārikā ati aññā ca oḷārikā  bhavaṅga saññāḥ uppajjeyyum saḥ na ca iva ceteti na abhisaṅkharoti iti ettha kāmam ca isa  cetentaḥ iva na ceteti abhisaṅkharontaḥ iva na abhisaṅkharoti imassa bhikkhuno ākiñcaññāyatanato  vuṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samāpajjitvā ekam dve citta vāre ṭhassāmi iti ābhoga samannāhāro
translated: And other, grosser perceptions arise: other, grosser perceptions of the life-continuum arise.🔽Herein, although he does not intend and does not form, he does intend and form.

original: natthi. Uparinirodhasamāpattatthāya eva pana ābhogasamannāhāro atthi, svāyamattho🔽puttagharācikkhaṇena dīpetabbo.🔽Pitugharamajjhena kira gantvā pacchābhāge puttassa gharaṃ hoti, tato paṇītaṃ bhojanaṃ
analyzed: natthi uparinirodha samāpatta tthāya eva pana ābhoga samannāhāraḥ atthi svāyamattho 🔽putta ghara ācikkhaṇena dīpetabbaḥ 🔽pitu ghara majjhena kira gantvā pacchābhāge puttassa gharam hoti tatas paṇītam bhojanam
translated: For this bhikkhu, after emerging from the base of nothingness, enters upon the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and abides in it. He does not have the adverting, the act of will, the volition, the mental application, the mental survey, the mental holding, the mental stablising, the mental fixing, the mental control, the mental mastery, the mental non-remissness, the mental non-distraction, the mental non-perturbation, the mental non-agitation, the mental non-confusion, the mental non-bewilderment, the mental non-forgetting, the mental non-loss, the mental non-remissness, the mental non-distraction, the mental non-perturbation, the mental non-agitation, the mental non-confusion, the mental non-bewilderment, the mental non-forgetting, the mental non-loss, the mental non-remissness, the mental non-distraction, the mental non-perturbation, the mental non-agitation, the mental non-confusion, the mental non-bewilderment, the mental non-forgetting, the mental non-loss, the mental non-remissness, the mental non-distraction, the mental non-perturbation, the mental non-agitation, the mental non-confusion, the mental non-bewilderment, the mental non-forgetting, the mental non-loss, the mental non-remissness, the mental non-distraction, the mental non-perturbation, the mental non-agitation, the mental non-confusion, the mental non-bewilderment, the mental non-forgetting, the mental non-loss, the mental non-remissness, the mental non-distraction, the mental non-perturbation, the mental non-agitation, the mental non-confusion, the mental non-bewilderment, the mental non-forgetting, the

original: ādāya āsanasālaṃ āgataṃ daharaṃ thero – “manāpo piṇḍapāto kuto ābhato”ti pucchi.
analyzed: ādāya āsana sālam āgatam daharam theraḥ manāpaḥ piṇḍapāto kutas ābhato ti pucchi
translated: The elder asked the young man, who had come to the assembly hall bringing the alms food, “Where did you get such good alms food? ”

original: So “asukassa gharato”ti laddhagharameva ācikkhi. Yena panassa pitugharamajjhena gatopi
analyzed: saḥ asukassa gharato ti laddha gharam eva ācikkhi yena panassa pitu ghara majjhena gataḥ api
translated: He pointed out the house where he had got it, saying, “From such and such a house. ”

original: āgatopi tattha ābhogopi natthi. Tattha āsanasālā viya ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpatti daṭṭhabbā,
analyzed: āgataḥ api tattha ābhogaḥ api na atthi tattha āsana sālāḥ viya ākiñcaññāyatana samāpatti daṭṭhabbā
translated: But he had not gone there or come back by the way of his father’s house, nor had he made any effort to do so.🔽Herein, the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness should be regarded as the assembly hall,

original: pitugehaṃ viya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti, puttagehaṃ viya nirodhasamāpatti,
analyzed: pitu geham viya nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpatti putta geham viya nirodha samāpatti
translated: the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception as the father’s house, and the attainment of cessation as the son’s house.

original: āsanasālāya ṭhatvā pitugharaṃ amanasikaritvā puttagharācikkhaṇaṃ viya ākiñcaññāyatanato
analyzed: āsana sālāya ṭhatvā pitu gharam a manasikaritvā putta ghara ācikkhaṇam viya ākiñcañña āyatanataḥ
translated: Just as, when he was in the assembly hall, he took no cognizance of his father’s house, but pointed out his son’s house,

original: vuṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā “ekaṃ dve cittavāre ṭhassāmī”ti pitugharaṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samāpajjitvā ekam dve citta vāre pitu gharam
translated: so, when he has emerged from the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness, he enters upon the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, thinking, “I shall stand in one or two conscious moments” ,🔽and he takes no cognizance of his father’s house, but gives his attention to the attainment of cessation above.

original: amanasikaritvāva uparinirodhasamāpattatthāya manasikāro, evamesa cetentova na ceteti,
analyzed: a manasikaritvā āva uparinirodha samāpatti thāya manasikāraḥ evam esa cetentaḥ iva na ceteti
translated: As he does so, he does not advert to anything,

original: abhisaṅkharontova nābhisaṅkharoti. Tā ceva saññāti tā jhānasaññā nirujjhanti. Aññā
analyzed: abhisaṅkharontaḥ iva na abhisaṅkharoti tā ca iva saññā ati tā jhāna saññā nirujjhanti aññā
translated: and those perceptions cease in him.

original: cāti aññā ca oḷārikā bhavaṅgasaññā nuppajjanti. So nirodhaṃ phusatīti so evaṃ paṭipanno
analyzed: ca ati aññā ca oḷārikā bhavaṅga saññā nuppajjanti so nirodham phusati iti saḥ evam paṭipanno
translated: and no other gross perceptions of the life-continuum arise. He touches the cessation, he touches the attainment of cessation, he reaches, he arrives at, cessation, is the meaning.

original: bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ phusati vindati paṭilabhati.🔽Anupubbābhisaññānirodhasampajānasamāpattinti ettha abhīti upasaggamattaṃ, sampajānapadaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu saññā vedayita nirodham phusati vindati paṭilabhati  anupubba abhisaññā nirodha sampajāna samāpattim ti ettha abhi iti upasagga mattam sampajāna padam
translated: He touches cessation: he finds, obtains, cessation of perception and of consciousness.🔽With full awareness he enters upon and dwells in the attainment in which there is cessation of perception and consciousness: here the prefix abhi is merely a reiterative intensifier. The word with full awareness is placed

original: nirodhapadena antarikaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Anupaṭipāṭiyā sampajānasaññānirodhasamāpattīti
analyzed: nirodha padena antarikam katvā vuttam anupaṭipāṭiyā sampajāna saññā nirodha samāpatti iti
translated: between the words cessation and attainment. With full awareness he enters upon and dwells in the attainment in which there is cessation of perception and of consciousness, is the meaning.

original: ayaṃ panetthattho. Tatrāpi sampajānasaññānirodhasamāpattīti sampajānantassa ante
analyzed: ayam pana itthatthaḥ tatra api sampajāna saññā nirodha samāpatti iti sampajānantassa ante
translated: But the meaning here is this. Here too, with full awareness he enters upon and dwells in the attainment in which there is cessation of perception and consciousness: in one who is fully aware, at the end of his life,

original: saññā nirodhasamāpatti sampajānantassa vā paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno saññānirodhasamāpattīti ayaṃ visesattho.
analyzed: saññā nirodha samāpatti sampajānantassa vā paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno saññā nirodha samāpatti iti ayam visesa ttho
translated: there is the attainment of cessation of perception. Or the meaning is this: in the fully aware, wise bhikkhu there is the attainment of cessation of perception. This is the distinction in the meaning.

original: Idāni idha ṭhatvā nirodhasamāpattikathā kathetabbā. Sā panesā sabbākārena visuddhimagge paññābhāvanānisaṃsādhikāre kathitā, tasmā tattha kathitatova gahetabbā.
analyzed: idāni idha nirodha samāpatti kathā kathetabbā sā pana isā sabba ākārena visuddhi magge paññā bhāvanā nisaṃsa adhikāre kathitā tasmā tattha kathitataḥ va gahetabbā
translated: Now, the discussion of the attainment of cessation should be given here in the same way as it is given in the Path of Purification in the chapter dealing with the benefits of understanding . But since it is given there, it should be brought in here by means of the summary in the way already given.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā poṭṭhapādassa paribbājakassa nirodhakathaṃ kathetvā – atha naṃ tādisāya
analyzed: evam bhagavā poṭṭhapādassa paribbājakassa nirodha katham kathetvā atha nam tādisāya
translated: The Exalted One, having thus expounded the doctrine of cessation to the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda, then expounded the doctrine of the path to him, saying:

original: kathāya aññattha abhāvaṃ paṭijānāpetuṃ “taṃ kiṃ maññasī”tiādimāha. Paribbājakopi
analyzed: kathāya aññattha abhāvam tam kim maññasi iti ādim āha paribbājakaḥ api

analyzed: no hetam bhante iti vatvā puna sakkaccam bhagavato kathāya uggahita bhāvam dassento

analyzed: evam kho aham bhante ti ādim āha atha assa bhagavā su uggahitam tayā iti anujānantaḥ
translated: he said, “But, venerable sir, I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One thus.” The Blessed One assented,

analyzed: evam āha  atha paribbājakaḥ bhagavatā ākiñcaññāyatanam saññaggam ti vuttam etat eva nu

analyzed: yathā kho poṭṭhapāda nirodham phusati iti pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu yena yena kasiṇena paṭhamajjhāna ādīnam  vā yena yena jhānena idam vuttam hoti sace hi pathavī kasiṇena karaṇa bhūtena pathavī kasiṇa samāpattim
translated: “As one touches cessation”: by means of whichever kasiṇa, or

analyzed: eka vāram samāpajjanto purima saññā nirodham phusati ekam saññaggam atha dve vāre  tayo vāre vāra satam vāra sahassam vāra sata sahassam vā samāpajjanto purima saññā nirodham  phusati sata sahassam saññaggāni esa nayo sesa kasiṇesu jhānesu pi sace paṭhamajjhānena
translated: by means of whichever jhāna, beginning with the first jhāna. This is the meaning: if, by making the earth kasiṇa the means, he attains once the earth kasiṇa jhāna and touches the prior cessation of perception, that is one “foremost attainment of perception”; if he attains it twice,

original: karaṇabhūtena ekavāraṃ purimasaññānirodhaṃ phusati ekaṃ saññaggaṃ. Atha dve vāre,
analyzed: karaṇa bhūtena eka vāram purima saññā nirodham phusati ekam saññaggam atha dve vāre

original: tayo vāre, vārasataṃ, vārasahassaṃ, vārasatasahassaṃ vā purimasaññānirodhaṃ phusati,
analyzed: tayaḥ vāre vāra satam vāra sahassam vāra sata sahassam vā purima saññā nirodham phusati
translated: thrice, a hundred times, a thousand times, a hundred thousand times, and touches the prior cessation of perception,

original: satasahassaṃ saññaggāni. Esa nayo sesajjhānasamāpattīsupi. Iti ekavāraṃ samāpajjanavasena
analyzed: sata sahassam saññaggāni esa nayo sesa jhāna samāpattīsu pi iti eka vāram samāpajjana vasena

original: vā sabbampi sañjānanalakkhaṇena saṅgahetvā vā ekaṃ saññaggaṃ hoti, aparāparaṃ samāpajjanavasena bahūni.🔽416. Saññā nu kho, bhanteti bhante nirodhasamāpajjanakassa bhikkhuno “saññā nu kho
analyzed: vā sabbam pi sañjānana lakkhaṇena saṅgahetvā vā ekam saññaggam hoti apara aparam samāpajjana vasena bahūni  saññā nu kho bhante iti bhante nirodha samāpajjanakassa bhikkhuno saññā nu kho
translated: So it is either by way of attaining once only or by way of taking all as a single aggregate of perception that there is one aggregate of perception. But there are many by way of attaining again and again.

original: paṭhamaṃ uppajjatī”ti pucchati. Tassa bhagavā “saññā kho, poṭṭhapādā”ti byākāsi.🔽Tattha saññāti jhānasaññā. Ñāṇanti vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Aparo nayo, saññāti vipassanā
analyzed: paṭhamam uppajjati iti pucchati tassa bhagavā saññā kho poṭṭhapādā iti byākāsi  tattha saññā nāti jhāna saññā ñāṇanti vipassanā ñāṇam aparaḥ nayo saññā ati vipassanā
translated: “Perception, venerable sir?”: the bhikkhu who has attained the attainment of cessation asks thus, “Is perception the first to arise?” The Blessed One answered, “Perception, Poṭṭhapāda.”

original: saññā. Ñāṇanti maggañāṇaṃ. Aparo nayo, saññāti maggasaññā. Ñāṇanti phalañāṇaṃ. Tipiṭakamahāsivatthero panāha –
analyzed: saññā ñāṇanti magga ñāṇam aparaḥ nayo saññā iti magga saññā ñāṇanti phala ñāṇam tipiṭakamahāsiva thero pana āha
translated: Herein, “perception” is the perception of the jhāna. “Knowledge” is the knowledge of insight. Another method: “perception” is the perception of insight; “knowledge” is the path knowledge. Another method: “perception” is the perception of the path; “knowledge” is fruition knowledge. But the Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa-Abhaya said:

original: Kiṃ ime bhikkhū bhaṇanti, poṭṭhapādo heṭṭhā bhagavantaṃ nirodhaṃ pucchi. Idāni nirodhā
analyzed: kim ime bhikkhū bhaṇanti poṭṭhapādaḥ heṭṭhā bhagavantam nirodham pucchi idāni nirodhā
translated: “What are these bhikkhus talking about? Poṭṭhapāda asked the Blessed One about cessation below . Now he asks about the arising of perception and knowledge after the attainment of cessation.

original: vuṭṭhānaṃ pucchanto “bhagavā nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa kiṃ paṭhamaṃ arahattaphalasaññā
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam pucchantaḥ bhagavā nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa kim paṭhamam arahatta phala saññā
translated: He asks about emergence thus: “When the Blessed One emerges from cessation, does the perception of the fruition of Arahantship arise first,

analyzed: uppajjati pacchā paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam tasmā saññā kho poṭṭhapādā ti āha tattha  saññā uppādā ti arahatta phala saññāyaḥ uppādā pacchā idam arahatta phalan ti evam paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇa uppādo
translated: and reviewing knowledge arises afterwards. Herein,🔽arising of perception is the arising of the perception of the fruition of Arahantship. Afterwards, with the arising of reviewing knowledge, there is the reviewing thus, “This is the fruition of Arahantship.”

original: hoti. Idappaccayā kira meti phalasamādhisaññāpaccayā kira mayhaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ uppannanti.
analyzed: hoti idam paccayā kira mā iti phala samādhi saññā paccayā kira mayham paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam uppannanti
translated: “With that as condition” : with the perception of the fruition attainment as condition, reviewing knowledge arises in me, it seems.

original: Saññāattakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: saññā atta kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the discussion of perception

analyzed: idāni paribbājakaḥ yathā nāma gāma sūkaraḥ gandha udakena nhāpetvā gandhehi anulimpitvā
translated: Now, just as a village pig, after being bathed and anointed with perfume and

analyzed: mālā dāmam piḷandhitvā sirisayane āropitaḥ api sukham na vindati vegena gūtha ṭṭhānam eva
translated: draped with a garland of flowers, does not find happiness but quickly runs away to wallow in the mud,🔽so too, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda, after being bathed in the stream of the Dhamma with the water of the Master’s rational and logical explanations, and after being anointed with the perfume of the Dhamma, and draped with the garland of the Dhamma, did not find happiness in the Master’s presence, but quickly ran away to the Jains.

original: gantvā sukhaṃ vindati. Evameva bhagavatā saṇhasukhumatilakkhaṇabbhāhatāya desanāya
analyzed: gantvā sukham vindati evam eva bhagavatā saṇha sukhu mati lakkhaṇa bbha hatāya desanāya

analyzed: nhāpita vilitta maṇḍitaḥ api nirodha kathā siri sayanam āropitaḥ api tattha sukham na vindanto  gūtha ṭṭhāna sadisam attanaḥ laddhim gahetvā tam eva pucchanto saññā nu kho bhante
translated: though he has placed the head of the corpse of the brahmin’s view on the couch of the discourse on cessation, and though he has covered it with the sheet of the discourse on the aggregates, still he finds no happiness there.🔽Taking his own position to be like a cesspool, he asks the Exalted One: “Is perception a person’s self, venerable sir?”

original: purisassa attā”tiādimāha. Athassānumatiṃ gahetvā byākātukāmo bhagavā – “kaṃ pana
analyzed: purisassa attā iti ādim āha atha assa anumatim gahetvā byākātu kāmaḥ bhagavā kam pana
translated: Then, wishing to explain after getting his consent, the Exalted One says: “But what is your view about this, brahmin?”

analyzed: tvanti ādim āha tatas saḥ arūpī attā ati evam samānaḥ api bhagavā desanāya su kusalaḥ

analyzed: saḥ me āditas uva laddhim mā cintetvā laddhim pariharantaḥ oḷārikam

original: kho”tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā tattha dosaṃ dassento “oḷāriko ca hi te”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kho tiādim āha athassa bhagavā tattha dosam dassentaḥ oḷāriko ca hi te tiādim āha
translated: Then the Exalted One, showing the fault in that position, says: “Brahmin, I have told you that the self is both material and immaterial.”

analyzed: tattha evam evam santanti evam sante bhummatthe hi etam upayoga vacanam evam santam attānam

analyzed: paccāgacchataḥ tava ati ayam vai ettha attho catunnam khandhānam ekuppāda eka nirodha ttā  kiñca api yā saññā uppajjati sā ava nirujjhati apara aparam upādāya pana aññā ca saññā
translated: Because the four aggregates arise and cease together,🔽although the perception that arises ceases,

translated: it is said that “one perception arises and another ceases” in terms of one after another.

analyzed: idāni aññam laddhim dassento manaḥ mayam kho aham bhante tiādim vatvā  tatra api dose dinne yathā nāma ummattakaḥ yāva assa saññā na patiṭṭhāti tāva aññam gahetvā  aññam vissajjeti saññā patiṭṭhāna kāle pana vattabbam eva vadati evam eva aññam gahetvā
translated: Now, showing another opinion, he said, “Venerable sir, I am mind-made.”

analyzed: aññam vissajjetvā idāni attanaḥ laddhiṃya iva vadantaḥ arūpī kho ti ādim āha tatra api

analyzed: yasmā saḥ saññāya uppāda nirodham icchati attānam pana sassatam maññati tasmā tathā iva assa
translated: since he wishes for the arising and ceasing of perception but conceives himself to be eternal, therefore

analyzed: dosam dassentaḥ bhagavā evam santam pi itiādim āha tatas paribbājakaḥ micchā dassanena
translated: The Exalted One said, “Even though this is so,” etc., in order to show his anger. Then, because the wanderer was overcome by wrong views,

analyzed: abhibhūta ttā bhagavatā vuccamānam pi tam nānattam a jānantaḥ sakkā pana itam bhante  mayā iti ādim āha atha assa bhagavā yasmā so saññāyaḥ uppāda nirodham passantaḥ api saññā mayam
translated: he did not understand the difference between the Exalted One’s words. Therefore he said, “But, venerable sir, could I know🔽whether or not I am such a person?” The Exalted One said, “It is difficult for you to know,” etc.,

original: attānaṃ niccameva maññati. Tasmā “dujjānaṃ kho”tiādimāha.
analyzed: attānam niccam eva maññati tasmā dujjānam kho ti ādim āha
translated: because, although he saw the arising and cessation of perception, he still thought of himself as permanent.

original: Tatthāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – tava aññā diṭṭhi, aññā khanti, aññā ruci, aññathāyeva te🔽dassanaṃ pavattaṃ, aññadeva ca te khamati ceva ruccati ca, aññatra ca te āyogo, aññissāyeva
analyzed: tattha ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ tava aññā diṭṭhi aññā khanti aññā ruci aññathāya iva te  dassanam pavattam aññatra eva ca te khamati ca iva ruccati ca aññatra ca te āyogaḥ
translated: Here is the meaning in brief: Your view is one thing, your approval is another, your liking is another, your perception is another,

original: paṭipattiyā yuttapayuttatā, aññattha ca te ācariyakaṃ, aññasmiṃ titthāyatane ācariyabhāvo.
analyzed: paṭipattiyāḥ yutta payutta tā aññattha ca te ācariyakam aññasmin tittha āyatane ācariya bhāvaḥ
translated: your approval is one thing, your liking is another, your practice is another, your devotion is another, your teacher is another, your sect is another.

original: Tena tayā evaṃ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena
analyzed: tena tayā evam añña diṭṭhikena añña khantikena añña rucikena aññatra ayogena aññatra ācariyakena
translated: Therefore, since you have a different view, a different approval, a different liking, a different perception, a different practice, a different devotion, a different teacher, a different sect,

analyzed: dujjānam etat ti atha paribbājako saññā vā purisassa attā hotu aññā vā saññā
translated: “It is hard to know this.” Then the wanderer thought, “Whether perception is a person’s self or if perception is one thing and the self another,

original: taṃ sassatādi bhāvamassa pucchissa”nti puna “kiṃ pana bhante”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tam sassata ādi bhāvam assa pucchissanti puna kim pana bhante tiādim āha
translated: I will ask him whether the self is permanent or not.” So he asked again, “But, Master Gotama,

original: Tattha lokoti attānaṃ sandhāya vadati. Na hetaṃ poṭṭhapāda atthasañhitanti poṭṭhapāda
analyzed: tattha lokaḥ iti attānam sandhāya vadati na ha etam poṭṭhapāda attha sañhitanti poṭṭhapāda
translated: “World” here refers to the self. “This, Poṭṭhapāda, is not conducive to welfare,”

analyzed: etam diṭṭhigatam na idhaloka paraloka attha nissitam na atta ttha para ttha nissitam na  dhamma saṃhitanti na nava lokuttara dhamma nissitam na ādibrahmacariyakam ti sikkhattaya saṅkhātassa
translated: This view is not based on the welfare of this world or the next world, or on the welfare of oneself or others.🔽“It is not conducive to the Dhamma,” it is not based on the nine supramundane states.

original: sāsanabrahmacariyakassa na ādimattaṃ, adhisīlasikkhāmattampi na hoti. Na nibbidāyāti🔽saṃsāravaṭṭe nibbindanatthāya na saṃvattati. Na virāgāyāti vaṭṭavirāgatthāya na saṃvattati.
analyzed: sāsanabrahmacariyakassa na ādimattam adhi sīla sikkhāmattam pi na hoti na nibbidāya ati  saṃsāra vaṭṭe nibbindana tthāya na saṃvattati na virāgāya ati vaṭṭa virāga tthāya na saṃvattati
translated: “It is not conducive to the fundamentals of the holy life,” it is not even the beginning of the training in the higher virtue of the spiritual life of the dispensation.🔽“It does not lead to disenchantment,” it does not lead to disenchantment with the round of rebirths. “It does not lead to dispassion,” it does not lead to dispassion for the round.

original: Na nirodhāyāti vaṭṭassa nirodhakaraṇatthāya na saṃvattati. Na upasamāyāti vaṭṭassa
analyzed: na nirodhāya ati vaṭṭassa nirodha karaṇa tthāya na saṃvattati na upasamāyāti vaṭṭassa
translated: “It does not lead to cessation,” it does not lead to the cessation of the round. “It does not lead to peace,” it does not lead to the peace of the round.

original: vūpasamanatthāya na saṃvattati. Na abhiññāyāti vaṭṭābhijānanāya paccakkhakiriyāya
analyzed: vūpasamana atthāya na saṃvattati na abhiññāyāti vaṭṭa abhijānanāya paccakkha kiriyāya
translated: it does not lead to the stilling of the defilements. It does not lead to direct knowledge: it does not lead to the direct experience of the round of rebirths.

original: na saṃvattati. Na sambodhāyāti vaṭṭasambujjhanatthāya na saṃvattati. Na nibbānāyāti
analyzed: na saṃvattati na sambodhāya ati vaṭṭa sambujjhana tthāya na saṃvattati na nibbānāya ati
translated: It does not lead to full enlightenment: it does not lead to the full enlightenment of the round of rebirths. It does not lead to Nibbana:

original: amatamahānibbānassa paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati.
analyzed: amata mahānibbānassa paccakkha kiriyāya na saṃvattati
translated: it does not lead to the direct experience of the supreme peace of Nibbāna.

original: Idaṃ dukkhantiādīsu taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā tebhūmakā pañcakkhandhā dukkhanti, tasseva dukkhassa
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti ādīsu taṇham ṭhapetvā tebhūmakā pañca kkhandhā dukkhanti tassa iva dukkhassa
translated: As regards the passage beginning with “This is suffering” , the five aggregates of the three planes of existence are suffering, except for craving.

original: pabhāvanato sappaccayā taṇhā dukkhasamudayoti. Ubhinnaṃ appavatti dukkhanirodhoti,
analyzed: pabhāvanato sa paccayā taṇhā dukkha samudayo ti ubhinnam appavatti dukkha nirodho ti
translated: The manifestation of the cause of that suffering is the origin of suffering. The non-manifestation of both is the cessation of suffering.

original: ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti mayā byākatanti attho. Evañca🔽pana vatvā bhagavā “imassa paribbājakassa maggapātubhāvo vā phalasacchikiriyā vā
analyzed: ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggaḥ dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ti mayā byākatam ti attho evam ca  pana vatvā bhagavā imassa paribbājakassa magga pātubhāvaḥ vā phala sacchikiriyā vā
translated: The noble eightfold path is the way leading to the cessation of suffering. This is how I have proclaimed it.🔽Having said this, the Exalted One thought: “This wanderer has neither the manifestation of the path nor the realization of the fruit. And it is time for me to go for alms.”

original: natthi, mayhañca bhikkhācāravelā”ti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi. Paribbājakopi taṃ ākāraṃ
analyzed: natthi mayham ca bhikkhā ācāra velā ti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi paribbājakaḥ api tam ākāram
translated: And so he remained silent. The wanderer thought:

original: ñatvā bhagavato gamanakālaṃ ārocento viya “evameta”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: ñatvā bhagavataḥ gamana kālam ārocentaḥ evam etat ti ādim āha
translated: and he said “So it is” as if announcing the time of the Exalted One’s departure.

original: 421. Vācāsannitodakenāti vacanapatodena. Sañjhabbharimakaṃsūti sañjhabbharitaṃ nirantaraṃ
analyzed: vācā āsannita udakena ati vacana patodena sañjhap bharima kaṃsu iti sañjhap bharitam nirantaram
translated: With the water of speech-taunting: with the water of speech-taunting. They made it filled with a continuous

original: phuṭṭhaṃ akaṃsu, upari vijjhiṃsūti vuttaṃ hoti. Bhūtanti sabhāvato vijjamānaṃ. Tacchaṃ,
analyzed: phuṭṭham akaṃsu upari vijjhiṃsu iti vuttam hoti bhūtam ti sabhāvataḥ vijjamānam taccham
translated: pouring: they made it filled with a continuous pouring. They pierced it above, is what is meant. Existent: existing in actuality. True,

original: tathanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Dhammaṭṭhitatanti navalokuttaradhammesu ṭhitasabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: tathanti tassa iva vevacanam nava lokuttara dhammesu ṭhita sabhāvam
translated: real: these are synonyms for the same thing. The state of being established in the Dhamma: the state of being established in the nine supramundane dhammas.

original: Dhammaniyāmatanti lokuttaradhammaniyāmataṃ. Buddhānañhi catusaccavinimuttā kathā
analyzed: dhamma niyāmatam ti lokuttara dhamma niyāmatam buddhānam hi catu sacca vinimuttā kathā
translated: The regularity of the Dhamma: the regularity of the supramundane dhammas. For the Buddhas have no talk that is not free from the four flaws.

original: nāma natthi. Tasmā sā edisā hoti.
analyzed: nāma natthi tasmā sā edisā hoti
translated: Therefore, their talk is of this kind.

original: Cittahatthisāriputtapoṭṭhapādavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: cittahatthi sāriputta poṭṭhapāda vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Citta Hatthisariputta and Poṭṭhapāda

original: 422. Citto ca hatthisāriputtoti so kira sāvatthiyaṃ hatthiācariyassa putto bhagavato
analyzed: citto ca hatthi sāri putto ti so kira sāvatthiyam hatthi ācariyassa putto bhagavataḥ
translated: Citta Hatthisāriputta: it is said that he was the son of an elephant trainer in Sāvatthī. He went forth in the presence of the Exalted One,

original: santike pabbajitvā tīṇi piṭakāni uggahetvā sukhumesu atthantaresu kusalo ahosi, pubbe
analyzed: santike pabbajitvā tīṇi piṭakāni uggahetvā sukhumesu atthantaresu kusalaḥ ahosi pubbe
translated: mastered the three Piṭakas, and became skilled in the subtle and recondite .

original: katapāpakammavasena pana sattavāre vibbhamitvā gihi jāto. Kassapasammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: kata pāpa kamma vasena pana satta vāre vibbhamitvā gihi jātaḥ kassapa sammāsambuddhassa
translated: It seems that in the dispensation of the Perfectly Awakened Buddha Kassapa

original: kira sāsane dve sahāyakā ahesuṃ, aññamaññaṃ samaggā ekatova sajjhāyanti. Tesu eko
analyzed: kira sāsane dve sahāyakāḥ ahesum aññam aññam samaggāḥ ekatas va sajjhāyanti tesu ekaḥ
translated: there were two friends who recited the scriptures together in harmony. One of them

original: anabhirato gihibhāve cittaṃ uppādetvā itarassa ārocesi. So gihibhāve ādīnavaṃ pabbajjāya🔽ānisaṃsaṃ dassetvā taṃ ovadi. So taṃ sutvā abhiramitvā punekadivasaṃ tādise citte
analyzed: an abhirataḥ gihi bhāve cittam uppādetvā itarassa ārocesi saḥ gihi bhāve ādīnavam pabbajjāya  ānisaṃsam dassetvā tam ovadi saḥ tam sutvā abhiramitvā puna eka divasam tādise citte
translated: was dissatisfied with the life of a layman and aroused his mind to become a monk. He told the other,🔽who pointed out the dangers in the life of a layman and the benefits of the life of a monk.🔽When he heard this, the first friend became dissatisfied with the life of a layman and became eager to become a monk. But on another day, when he had aroused the same kind of mind,

original: uppanne taṃ etadavoca “mayhaṃ āvuso evarūpaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati – ‘imāhaṃ pattacīvaraṃ
analyzed: uppanne tam etat avoca mayham āvuso evarūpam cittam uppajjati imā aham patta cīvaram
translated: he said to his friend: “I have this kind of mind, friend: ‘I will give you my bowl and robes.’“

original: tuyhaṃ dassāmī’ti”. So pattacīvaralobhena tassa gihibhāve ānisaṃsaṃ dassetvā pabbajjāya
analyzed: tuyham dassāmi iti so patta cīvara lobhena tassa gihi bhāve ānisaṃsam dassetvā pabbajjāya
translated: Because of his greed for the bowl and robes, the other friend pointed out the benefits of the life of a layman to him and the dangers of the life of a monk.

original: ādīnavaṃ kathesi. Athassa taṃ sutvāva gihibhāvato cittaṃ virajjitvā pabbajjāyameva
analyzed: ādīnavam kathesi athassa tam sutvā ava gihi bhāvataḥ cittam virajjitvā
translated: When he heard this, his mind became detached from the life of a layman and became eager for the life of a monk.

original: abhirami. Evamesa tadā sīlavantassa bhikkhuno gihibhāve ānisaṃsakathāya kathitattā
analyzed: abhirami evam esa tadā sīlavantassa bhikkhuno gihi bhāve ānisaṃsa kathāya kathita ttā
translated: In this way, because the benefits of the life of a layman had been discussed with him by his virtuous friend,

original: idāni cha vāre vibbhamitvā sattame vāre pabbajito. Mahāmoggallānassa, mahākoṭṭhikattherassa
analyzed: idāni cha vāre vibbhamitvā sattame vāre pabbajitaḥ mahāmoggallānassa mahākoṭṭhika therassa
translated: and now, after six rebirths, he has gone forth in his seventh existence. Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākoṭṭhita,🔽

original: ca abhidhammakathaṃ kathentānaṃ antarantarā kathaṃ opāteti. Atha naṃ mahākoṭṭhikatthero
analyzed: ca abhidhamma katham kathentānam antar antarā katham atha nam mahākoṭṭhika thero
translated: Now, after having gone forth six times, he had gone forth for the seventh time. While the Elder Mahā Moggallāna and the Elder Mahā Koṭṭhita were expounding the Abhidhamma, he interrupted their talk. Then the Elder Mahā Koṭṭhita

original: apasādeti. So mahāsāvakassa kathite patiṭṭhātuṃ asakkonto vibbhamitvā gihi jāto.
analyzed: apasādeti saḥ mahāsāvakassa kathite patiṭṭhātum a sakkontaḥ vibbhamitvā gihi jātaḥ
translated: disapproved of him. Unable to endure the talk of the Great Disciple, he went forth and became a layman.

original: Poṭṭhapādassa panāyaṃ gihisahāyako hoti. Tasmā vibbhamitvā dvīhatīhaccayena poṭṭhapādassa
analyzed: poṭṭhapādassa pana ayam gihi sahāyakaḥ hoti tasmā vibbhamitvā poṭṭhapādassa
translated: But Poṭṭhapāda was his lay friend. Therefore, after having gone forth, after two or three days, he went to Poṭṭhapāda’s

original: santikaṃ gato. Atha naṃ so disvā “samma kiṃ tayā kataṃ, evarūpassa nāma satthu sāsanā
analyzed: santikam gataḥ atha nam saḥ disvā samma kim tayā katam evarūpassa nāma satthu sāsanā
translated: presence. Then, after having seen him, he said: “Dear friend, what have you done? After having gone forth in the Dispensation of such a Teacher as this,

original: apasakkantosi, ehi pabbajituṃ idāni te vaṭṭatī”ti taṃ gahetvā bhagavato santikaṃ
analyzed: apasakkantaḥ asi ehi pabbajitum idāni te vaṭṭati iti tam gahetvā bhagavato santikam
translated: you have come back. Come, now it is proper for you to go forth.” After having taken him, he went to the presence of the Blessed One.

original: agamāsi. Tena vuttaṃ “citto ca hatthisāriputto poṭṭhapādo ca paribbājako”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam citto ca hatthisāriputto poṭṭhapādaḥ ca paribbājako ti
translated: Therefore it was said: “Citta Hatthisāriputta and the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda.”

original: 423. Andhāti paññācakkhuno natthitāya andhā, tasseva abhāvena acakkhukā. Tvaṃyeva
analyzed: andhā ati paññā cakkhunaḥ na thitāya andhā tassa iva abhāvena acakkhukā
translated: Blind: because of the absence of the eye of wisdom, they are blind; because of the absence of that very eye, they are eyeless.

original: nesaṃ eko cakkhumāti subhāsitadubbhāsitajānanabhāvamattena paññācakkhunā cakkhumā.
analyzed: na isam ekaḥ cakkhumā ti su bhāsita dubbhāsita jānana bhāva mattena paññā cakkhunā cakkhumā
translated: He is “one with eyes” in the sense of having the eye of wisdom that knows what is well spoken and what is badly spoken.

original: Ekaṃsikāti ekakoṭṭhāsā. Paññattāti ṭhapitā. Anekaṃsikāti na ekakoṭṭhāsā ekeneva koṭṭhāsena
analyzed: ekaṃsikā ati eka koṭṭhāsā paññattā ati ṭhapitā anekaṃsikā ati na eka koṭṭhāsā ekena iva koṭṭhāsena
translated: “One-sided”: of one portion. “Ascertained”: established. “Not one-sided”: not of one portion, not of one kind.

original: sassatāti vā asassatāti vā na vuttāti attho.
analyzed: sassatā ati vā a sassatā ati vā na vuttā ati attho
translated: “Ascertained”: not stated as eternal or not eternal.

original: Ekaṃsikadhammavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekaṃsika dhamma vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the One-Sided Truths

original: 424-425. Santi poṭṭhapādāti idaṃ bhagavā kasmā ārabhi? Bāhirakehi paññāpitaniṭṭhāya🔽aniyyānikabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Sabbe hi titthiyā yathā bhagavā amataṃ nibbānaṃ, evaṃ
analyzed: santi poṭṭhapādā ti idam bhagavā kasmai ārabhi bāhirakehi paññāpita niṭṭhāya  aniyyānika bhāva dassana attham sabbe hi titthiyāḥ yathā bhagavā amatam nibbānam evam
translated: “There are, Poṭṭhapāda” : why did the Blessed One begin in this way?

original: attano attano samaye lokathupikādivasena niṭṭhaṃ paññapenti, sā ca na niyyānikā.
analyzed: attano attano samaye lokathupikā ādi vasena niṭṭham paññapenti sā ca na niyyānikā
translated: In order to show that the final goal proclaimed by the sectarians is not the final goal. For all the sectarians proclaim a final goal of their own, such as the doctrine of the world’s finitude, etc., as does the Blessed One with his doctrine of Nibbāna, the deathless element. But that is not the final goal.

original: Yathā paññattā hutvā na niyyāti na gacchati, aññadatthu paṇḍitehi paṭikkhittā nivattati,
analyzed: yathā paññattā hutvā na niyyāti na gacchati añña datthu paṇḍitehi paṭikkhittā nivattati
translated: For it is not the final goal as proclaimed; it does not lead to the final goal, but rather it is rejected by the wise as a dead end.

original: taṃ dassetuṃ bhagavā evamāha. Tattha ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passanti puratthimāya
analyzed: tam dassetum bhagavā evam āha tattha ekanta sukham lokam jānam passanti puratthimāya
translated: In order to show this, the Blessed One said, “There are, Poṭṭhapāda.” Therein, “knowing, seeing a world that is entirely blissful” :

original: disāya ekantasukho loko pacchimādīnaṃ vā aññatarāyāti evaṃ jānantā evaṃ passantā
analyzed: disāya ekanta sukhaḥ pacchima ādīnam vā aññatarāya ati evam jānantā evam passantā
translated: “The world is all-round pleasant” or “The world is pleasant in the west” or “The world is pleasant in the other directions” .🔽“You should live thus knowing and seeing thus.

original: viharatha. Diṭṭhapubbāni kho tasmiṃ loke manussānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānādīnīti. Appāṭihīrakatanti
analyzed: viharatha diṭṭha pubbāni kho tasmin loke manussānam sarīra saṇṭhāna ādīni iti appāṭihīraka tanti
translated: The bodily forms of human beings in that world have been seen by you before.”🔽“Not a wonder”:

original: appāṭihīrakataṃ paṭiharaṇavirahitaṃ, aniyyānikanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: appāṭihīrakatam paṭiharaṇa virahitam aniyyānikam ti vuttam hoti
translated: not a wonder, devoid of a wonder, not leading out, is what is meant.

original: 426-427. Janapadakalyāṇīti janapade aññāhi itthīhi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānavilāsākappādīhi asadisā.
analyzed: janapada kalyāṇī iti janapade aññāhi itthīhi vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna vilāsā kappa ādīhi asadisā
translated: “The most beautiful woman in the country”: unequalled in the country by other women in beauty, figure, grace, charm, and so on.

original: Tayoattapaṭilābhavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tayā uatta paṭilābha vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Attainment of the Three Kinds of Self

original: 428. Evaṃ bhagavā paresaṃ niṭṭhāya aniyyānikattaṃ dassetvā attano niṭṭhāya niyyānikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam bhagavā paresam niṭṭhāya aniyyānika ttam dassetvā attanaḥ niṭṭhāya niyyānika bhāvam
translated: Having thus shown the non-leading-out nature of others’ paths, the Blessed One now said, “Three kinds of self, Potthapada,” etc., in order to show the leading-out nature of his own path.

original: dassetuṃ “tayo kho me poṭṭhapādā”tiādimāha. Tattha attapaṭilābhoti attabhāvapaṭilābho,
analyzed: dassetum tayo kho me poṭṭhapādā ti ādim āha tattha atta paṭilābho ti atta bhāva paṭilābho
translated: Herein, the attainment of self is the acquisition of an individual existence.

original: ettha ca bhagavā tīhi attabhāvapaṭilābhehi tayo bhave dassesi. Oḷārikattabhāvapaṭilābhena
analyzed: ettha ca bhagavā tīhi atta bhāva paṭilābhehi tayaḥ bhave dassesi oḷārika tta bhāva paṭilābhena
translated: And here the Blessed One showed the three kinds of becoming by the three kinds of attainment of self. By the attainment of self as gross he showed sensual becoming, by the attainment of self as subtle he showed fine-material becoming, and by the attainment of self as neither-gross-nor-subtle he showed immaterial becoming.

original: avīcito paṭṭhāya paranimmitavasavattipariyosānaṃ kāmabhavaṃ dassesi. Manomayaattabhāvapaṭilābhena
analyzed: avīcitaḥ paṭṭhāya para nimmita vasavatti pariyosānam kāma bhavam dassesi manaḥ maya atta bhāva paṭilābhena
translated: He showed the sensual-desire becoming that starts with the Avīci Hell and ends with the gods who control others’ sensual desires.

original: paṭhamajjhānabhūmito paṭṭhāya akaniṭṭhabrahmalokapariyosānaṃ rūpabhavaṃ dassesi.
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna bhūmitaḥ paṭṭhāya akaniṭṭha brahmaloka pariyosānam rūpa bhavam dassesi
translated: He showed the fine-material becoming that starts with the plane of the first jhāna and ends with the highest pure state.

original: Arūpaattabhāvapaṭilābhena ākāsānañcāyatanabrahmalokato paṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanabrahmalokapariyosānaṃ
analyzed: arūpa atta bhāva paṭilābhena ākāsa anañcāyatana brahmalokato paṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatana brahmaloka pariyosānam
translated: He showed the immaterial becoming that starts with the Brahmā-world of the base of infinite space and ends with the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: arūpabhavaṃ dassesi. Saṃkilesikā dhammā nāma dvādasa akusalacittuppādā. Vodāniyā
analyzed: arūpa bhavam dassesi saṃkilesikāḥ dhammāḥ nāma dvādasa akusala cittuppādāḥ vodāniyāḥ
translated: The states that are defiling are the twelve classes of consciousness accompanied by defilements.

original: dhammā nāma samathavipassanā.
analyzed: dhammā nāma samatha vipassanā
translated: The states that are purifying are serenity and insight.

original: 429. Paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattanti maggapaññāphalapaññānaṃ pāripūriñceva vipulabhāvañca.
analyzed: paññā pāripūrim magga paññā phala paññānam pāripūriñca iva vipula bhāvañca
translated: The fulfilment and abundance of understanding: the fulfilment and abundance of the understanding that is the path and the understanding that is fruition.

original: Pāmujjanti taruṇapīti. Pītīti balavatuṭṭhi. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Yaṃ avocumha “sayaṃ
analyzed: taruṇa pīti pīti iti balava tuṭṭhi kim vuttam hoti yam avocumha sayam
translated: The gladness is tender joy. The rapture is strong satisfaction. What is meant? What we said above, namely, “he abides contemplating arising phenomena in the feelings … in the mind … in the mental phenomena” , is the fulfilment of understanding.

original: abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihiratī”ti, tattha tassa evaṃ viharato taṃ pāmojjañceva
analyzed: abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihirati iti tattha tassa evam viharato tam pāmojjam ca iva
translated: The gladness and rapture that arise in him as he abides thus contemplating the mental phenomena of the path in this way are the abundance of understanding.

original: bhavissati, pīti ca nāmakāyapassaddhi ca sati ca sūpaṭṭhitā uttamañāṇañca sukho ca
analyzed: bhavissati pīti ca nāma kāya passaddhi ca sati ca su upaṭṭhitā uttama ñāṇañca sukho ca
translated: and the happiness and the serenity of mind and the mindfulness and the well-placed attention and the knowledge and the bliss,

original: vihāro. Sabbavihāresu ca ayameva vihāro “sukho”ti vattuṃ yutto “upasanto paramamadhuro”ti.
analyzed: vihāro sabba vihāresu ca ayam eva vihāro sukho ti vattum yuttaḥ upasantaḥ parama madhuraḥ ti
translated: in all the kinds of abiding this is the only kind of abiding that is called “blissful” and “peaceful” and “supreme” and “sweet.”

original: Tattha paṭhamajjhāne pāmojjādayo chapi dhammā labbhanti, dutiyajjhāne dubbalapītisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: tattha paṭhama jhāne pāmojja ādayo cha pi dhammā labbhanti dutiya jhāne dubbala pīti saṅkhātam
translated: Herein, in the first jhāna there are six ideas, namely, rapture and the rest, that are mentioned in the way beginning, “Rapture and pleasure” . In the second jhāna the rapture, called “weak rapture” , is absent,

original: pāmojjaṃ nivattati, sesā pañca labbhanti. Tatiye pīti nivattati, sesā cattāro labbhanti.
analyzed: pāmojjam nivattati sesā pañca labbhanti tatiye pi iti nivattati sesā cattāraḥ labbhanti
translated: and the remaining five are present. In the third jhāna the rapture is absent and the remaining four are present.

original: Tathā catutthe. Imesu catūsu jhānesu sampasādanasutte suddhavipassanā pādakajjhānameva
analyzed: tathā catutthe imesu catūsu jhānesu sampasādana sutte suddha vipassanā pādakajjhānam eva
translated: And so in the fourth jhāna. In these four jhānas the “confidence” in the Confidence-inspiring Discourse is said to be the jhāna that has only pure insight as its support.

original: kathitaṃ. Pāsādikasutte catūhi maggehi saddhiṃ vipassanā kathitā. Dasuttarasutte🔽catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpatti kathitā. Imasmiṃ poṭṭhapādasutte pāmojjaṃ pītivevacanameva
analyzed: kathitam pāsādika sutte catūhi maggehi saddhim vipassanā kathitā dasuttara sutte  kathitā imasmin poṭṭhapāda sutte pāmojjam pīti vevacanam eva
translated: In the Discourse on the Inspiring of Confidence it is said to be insight together with the four paths.🔽In the Ten-Questions Discourse it is said to be the fruition attainment that has the fourth jhāna as its support.

original: katvā dutiyajjhānikaphalasamāpattināma kathitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: katvā dutiya jhānika phala samāpatti nāma kathitā iti veditabbā
translated: In this Poṭṭhapāda Discourse it should be understood that the “rapture” is called “weak rapture” and is said to be the fruition attainment that has the second jhāna as its support.

original: 432-437. Ayaṃ vā soti ettha vā saddo vibhāvanattho hoti. Ayaṃ soti evaṃ vibhāvetvā
analyzed: ayam vā saḥ iti ettha vā saddo vibhāvana atthaḥ hoti ayam saḥ iti evam vibhāvetvā
translated: “This is he” : here the word “or” has the meaning of “or else”. Having thus distinguished “this is he”,

original: pakāsetvā byākareyyāma. Yathāpare “ekantasukhaṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā”ti puṭṭhā “no”ti
analyzed: pakāsetvā byākareyyāma yathā apare ekanta sukham attānam sañjānātha iti puṭṭhāḥ na uti
translated: having shown, we would answer. As others, when asked “Do you perceive self as absolutely happy?” say “No”,

original: vadanti, na evaṃ vadāmāti attho. Sappāṭihīrakatanti sappāṭiharaṇaṃ, niyyānikanti
analyzed: vadanti na evam vadāma ati attho sappāṭihīrakatanti sappāṭiharaṇam niyyānikanti
translated: so we do not say. “With a sign” : with a sign of escape, that is, with a way out.

original: attho. Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti
analyzed: atthaḥ moghaḥ hoti iti tucchaḥ hoti natthi so tasmin samaye iti adhippāyaḥ saccaḥ hoti iti
translated: “It is vain” : it is empty, the meaning is, there is no such thing in it. “It is true” :

original: bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya
analyzed: bhūtaḥ hoti su eva tasmin samaye saccaḥ hoti iti atthaḥ ettha pana ayam cittaḥ attanaḥ a sabbaññutāya
translated: it is real, the meaning is, it is true in that moment. But here Citta, being not omniscient,

original: tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi,🔽attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti
analyzed: tayo atta paṭilābhe kathetvā atta paṭilābhaḥ nāma paññattimattam etat ti uddharitum na asakkhi  atta paṭilābho tu eva niyyātesi athassa bhagavā rūpa ādayaḥ ca ittha dhammā atta paṭilābho ti
translated: having spoken of the three kinds of self, was unable to extract the conclusion that self is a mere concept,🔽but he concluded that there is self. Then the Blessed One, wishing to show him that the things called form, etc., are mere concepts,

original: pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva
analyzed: pana nāma mattam etam tesu tesu rūpa ādīsu sati evarūpāḥ vohārāḥ honti iti dassetu kāmo tassa iva
translated: that the expression “self” is used in regard to them, said:

original: kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ “yasmiṃ citta samaye”tiādimāha.
analyzed: katham gahetvā nāma paññatti vasena niyyātana ttham yasmin citta samaya iti ādim āha
translated: He said “On whatever occasion, Cittā” in order to answer by way of the naming of the idea.

original: 438. Evañca pana vatvā paṭipucchitvā vinayanatthaṃ puna “sace taṃ, citta, evaṃ puccheyyu”ntiādimāha.🔽Tattha yo me ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho, sveva me attapaṭilābho, tasmiṃ samaye sacco
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā paṭipucchitvā vinayana attham puna sace tam citte evam puccheyyuḥ iti ādim āha  tattha yaḥ me ahosi atītaḥ atta paṭilābho su eva me atta paṭilābho tasmin samaye sacco
translated: And after saying this, he said “If, Cittā, they were to ask you thus” in order to answer by way of the question.🔽Herein, he shows the meaning in this way: “Whatever my past acquisition of self was, that was my acquisition of self on that occasion.

original: ahosi, mogho anāgato mogho paccuppannoti ettha tāva imamatthaṃ dasseti – yasmā ye
analyzed: ahosi moghaḥ anāgataḥ moghaḥ paccuppannaḥ ti ettha tāva imam attham dasseti yasmai ye
translated: It was true. The future was false. The present was false” .🔽Herein, since those past ideas are not now, and they are reckoned as “were”,

original: te atītā dhammā, te etarahi natthi, ahesunti pana saṅkhyaṃ gatā, tasmā sopi me attapaṭilābho
analyzed: te atītā dhammā te etarahi natthi ahesunti pana saṅkhyam gatā tasmā saḥ api me atta paṭilābho
translated: therefore that acquisition of self by me was true on that occasion.

original: tasmiṃyeva samaye sacco ahosi. Anāgatapaccuppannānaṃ pana dhammānaṃ tadā abhāvā tasmiṃ
analyzed: tasmiṃ yeva samaye saccaḥ ahosi anāgata paccuppannānam pana dhammānam tadā abhāvā tasmin
translated: But because of the non-existence of future and present ideas on that occasion,

original: samaye “mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno”ti, evaṃ atthato nāmamattameva attapaṭilābhaṃ
analyzed: samaye moghaḥ anāgataḥ moghaḥ paccuppannaḥ ti evam atthataḥ nāmam attam eva atta paṭilābham
translated: the future was false and the present was false. So he admits that the acquisition of self is in fact only a name.

original: paṭijānāti. Anāgatapaccuppannesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: paṭijānāti anāgata paccuppannesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: The same method applies to the future and the present.

original: 439-443. Atha bhagavā tassa byākaraṇena saddhiṃ attano byākaraṇaṃ saṃsandituṃ “evameva
analyzed: atha bhagavā tassa byākaraṇena saddhim attanaḥ byākaraṇam saṃsanditum evam eva
translated: Then the Blessed One said “So too, Cittā” in order to connect up his own declaration with the declaration of the Elder Anuruddha.

original: kho cittā”tiādīni vatvā puna opammato tamatthaṃ sādhento “seyyathāpi citta gavā khīra”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: kho citta atiādīni vatvā puna opammato tam attham sādhento seyyathā api citta gavā khīra nti ādim āha
translated: After that he said “Just as from milk comes curd” in order to establish the meaning by means of a simile.

original: Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho, yathā gavā khīraṃ, khīrādīhi ca dadhiādīni bhavanti, tattha🔽yasmiṃ samaye khīraṃ hoti, na tasmiṃ samaye dadhīti vā navanītādīsu vā aññataranti
analyzed: tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yathā gavā khīram khīra ādīhi ca dadhi ādīni bhavanti  yasmin samaye khīram hoti na tasmin samaye dadhi iti vā navanīta ādīsu vā aññataranti
translated: Here is the meaning in brief: just as from milk comes curd, and from curd comes butter, and so on,

original: saṅkhyaṃ niruttiṃ nāmaṃ vohāraṃ gacchati. Kasmā? Ye dhamme upādāya dadhītiādi vohārā
analyzed: saṅkhyam niruttim nāmam vohāram gacchati kasmai ye dhamme upādāya dadhi itiādi vohārā
translated: at the time when there is milk it does not get the designation, the description, the appellation, the name, the conventional expression, “curd” or “ghee” or “cream of curd” or “butter-milk” or “oil-cake flour” or “chocolate.” Why? Because of the absence of those states that are the reason for the conventional expressions “curd” and the rest.

original: honti, tesaṃ abhāvā. Atha kho khīraṃ tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhyaṃ gacchati. Kasmā?
analyzed: honti tesam abhāvāḥ atha kho khīram tu eva tasmin samaye saṅkhyam gacchati kasmai
translated: But at that time it gets the designation “milk.” Why?

original: Ye dhamme upādāya khīranti saṅkhyā nirutti nāmaṃ vohāro hoti, tesaṃ bhāvāti. Esa
analyzed: ye dhamme upādāya saṅkhyā nirutti nāmam vohāro hoti tesam esa
translated: Because of the presence of those states that are the reason for the conventional expressions “milk,” “description,” “appellation,” “name,” and “conventional expression.”🔽This is the method in all instances.

original: nayo sabbattha. Imā kho cittāti oḷāriko attapaṭilābho iti ca manomayo attapaṭilābho
analyzed: nayo sabbattha imā kho cittā ati oḷārikaḥ atta paṭilābho iti ca manaḥ mayaḥ atta paṭilābho
translated: “This, Cittā, is the gross appropriation of a self” is the appropriation of a mind-made self.

original: iti ca arūpo attapaṭilābho iti ca imā kho citta lokasamaññā loke samaññāmattakāni
analyzed: iti ca arūpaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ iti ca imā kho citta loka samaññāḥ loke samaññāmattakāni
translated: and the formless self-theory, these are the world’s designations for the three kinds of self-theory. They are mere designations in the world,

original: samanujānanamattakāni etāni. Tathā lokaniruttimattakāni vacanapathamattakāni vohāramattakāni
analyzed: samanujānana mattakāni etāni tathā loka nirutti mattakāni vacana patha mattakāni vohāra mattakāni
translated: mere acknowledgments, mere worldly conventions, mere terms, mere usages, mere descriptions.

original: nāmapaṇṇattimattakāni etānīti. Evaṃ bhagavā heṭṭhā tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā idāni
analyzed: nāma paṇṇatti mattakāni etāni iti evam bhagavā heṭṭhā tayaḥ atta paṭilābhe kathetvā idāni
translated: Thus the Blessed One, having explained the three kinds of self-theory below, now says:

original: sabbametaṃ vohāramattakanti vadati. Kasmā? Yasmā paramatthato satto nāma natthi,
analyzed: sabbam etam vohāra mattakam ti vadati kasmai yasmai paramatthato satto nāma natthi
translated: “All this is mere usage.” Why? Because in the ultimate sense there is no being,

original: suñño tuccho esa loko.
analyzed: suññaḥ tucchaḥ esa lokaḥ
translated: this world is void and hollow.

original: Buddhānaṃ pana dve kathā sammutikathā ca paramatthakathā ca. Tattha “satto poso devo
analyzed: buddhānam pana dve kathā sammuti kathā ca paramattha kathā ca tattha sattaḥ posaḥ devo
translated: But the Buddhas have two kinds of talk: conventional talk and talk on the ultimate sense. Herein, talk such as “being,” “man,” “god,”

original: brahmā”tiādikā “sammutikathā” nāma. “Aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā khandhā dhātuyo āyatanāni
analyzed: brahma ati ādikā sammuti kathā nāma aniccam dukkham anattā khandhāḥ dhātuyaḥ āyatanāni
translated: “Brahma,” etc., is called “conventional talk.” Talk such as “impermanent, painful, not-self, aggregates, elements, sense bases,

original: satipaṭṭhānā sammappadhānā”tiādikā paramatthakathā nāma. Tattha yo sammutidesanāya
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā sammappadhānā ati ādikā paramatthakathā nāma tattha yaḥ sammuti desanāya
translated: foundations of mindfulness, right endeavours,” etc., is called “talk on the ultimate sense.” Herein, he who understands, penetrates,

original: “satto”ti vā “poso”ti vā “devo”ti vā “brahmā”ti vā vutte vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ
analyzed: sattaḥ iti vā posaḥ iti vā devaḥ iti vā brahmā ati vā vutte vijānitum paṭivijjhitum
translated: when “being,” “man,” “god,” “Brahma,” etc., are taught conventionally,

original: niyyātuṃ arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa bhagavā āditova “satto”ti vā “poso”ti🔽vā “devo”ti vā “brahmā”ti vā katheti, yo paramatthadesanāya “anicca”nti vā “dukkha”nti
analyzed: niyyātum arahatta jaya ggāham gahetum sakkoti tassa bhagavā āditas vā sattoti vā posoti  vā devaḥ iti vā brahmā ati vā kathā iti yaḥ paramattha desanāya aniccanti vā dukkhanti
translated: If he can grasp the victory of the Arahant path, then the Blessed One speaks to him at the very beginning about “a being,” “a person,” “a god,”

original: vātiādīsu aññataraṃ sutvā vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ
analyzed: vāti ādīsu aññataram sutvā vijānitum paṭivijjhitum niyyātum arahatta jaya ggāham gahetum
translated: or “a Brahmā.” If he can understand, penetrate, and grasp the victory of the Arahant path after hearing any one of the statements beginning with “impermanent,” “suffering,”

original: sakkoti, tassa “anicca”nti vā “dukkha”nti vātiādīsu aññatarameva katheti. Tathā sammutikathāya
analyzed: sakkoti tassa aniccanti vā dukkhanti vā ati ādīsu aññataram eva kathā iti tathā sammuti kathāya
translated: or “not self,” then the Blessed One speaks to him about “impermanent,” “suffering,” or any one of the other statements. In the same way,

original: bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Sammutikathāya pana bodhetvā🔽pacchā paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: bujjhanaka sattassa api na paṭhamam paramattha katham kathā iti sammuti kathāya pana bodhetvā  pacchā paramattha katham kathā iti paramattha kathāya bujjhanaka sattassa api na paṭhamam
translated: he does not speak the truth of the ultimate meaning to a being who is to be awakened by a conventional statement. But after awakening him🔽with a conventional statement, he speaks the truth of the ultimate meaning. He does not speak a conventional statement to a being who is to be awakened by the truth of the ultimate meaning. But after awakening him

original: sammutikathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā sammutikathaṃ katheti.
analyzed: sammuti katham kathā iti paramattha kathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā sammuti katham kathā iti
translated: with the truth of the ultimate meaning, he speaks a conventional statement.

original: Pakatiyā pana paṭhamameva paramatthakathaṃ kathentassa desanā lūkhākārā hoti, tasmā
analyzed: pakatiyā pana paṭhamam eva paramattha katham kathentassa desanā lūkhākārā hoti tasmā
translated: But if he speaks the truth of the ultimate meaning at the very beginning, his teaching has a harsh aspect, and therefore

original: buddhā paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ kathetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ kathenti. Sammutikathaṃ
analyzed: buddhā paṭhamam sammuti katham kathetvā pacchā paramattha katham kathenti sammuti katham
translated: The Buddhas first speak a talk of the world’s habit, and afterwards a talk of the ultimate meaning.🔽When they speak a talk of the world’s habit they speak only truth, only what is factual, not what is false.

original: kathentāpi saccameva sabhāvameva amusāva kathenti. Paramatthakathaṃ kathentāpi saccameva🔽sabhāvameva amusāva kathenti.
analyzed: kathentā api saccam eva sabhāvam eva kathenti paramattha katham kathentā api saccam eva  sabhāvam eva kathenti
translated: When they speak a talk of the ultimate meaning they speak only truth, only what is factual, not what is false.🔽The Enlightened One, the best of speakers,

original: Duve saccāni akkhāsi, sambuddho vadataṃ varo;
analyzed: duve saccāni akkhāsi sambuddhaḥ vadatam varaḥ
translated: Has told of two Truths: the world’s habit and the ultimate meaning.

original: Sammutiṃ paramatthañca, tatiyaṃ nūpalabbhati.
analyzed: sammutim paramattham ca tatiyam nūpalabbhati
translated: A third is not to be found.

original: Saṅketavacanaṃ saccaṃ, lokasammutikāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: saṅketa vacanam saccam loka sammuti kāraṇam
translated: The world’s habit is a truth of what is agreed by the world,

original: Paramatthavacanaṃ saccaṃ, dhammānaṃ bhūtalakkhaṇanti.🔽Yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasanti yāhi lokasamaññāhi lokaniruttīhi tathāgato taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparāmāsānaṃ
analyzed: paramattha vacanam saccam dhammānam bhūtalakkhaṇan ti  yāhi tathāgataḥ voharati a parāmasanti yāhi loka samaññāhi loka niruttīhi tathāgato taṇhā māna diṭṭhi parāmāsānam
translated: The ultimate meaning is a truth of the specific characteristics of dhammas.🔽The Tathāgata speaks without misapprehending what the world misapprehends, and he speaks without misapprehending what the world misapprehends.🔽The Tathāgata speaks without misapprehending what the world misapprehends because of the absence in him of misapprehension due to craving, conceit, and views.

original: abhāvā aparāmasanto voharatīti desanaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā arahattanikūṭena niṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: abhāvāḥ aparāmasantaḥ voharati iti desanam vinivaṭṭetvā arahatta nikūṭena niṭṭhāpesi
translated: He concludes with the peak of the arahant path, having turned aside from teaching.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: The rest is all plain in meaning.

original: Iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: So in the Sumangalavilāsini, the commentary on the Long Division,

original: Poṭṭhapādasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: poṭṭhapāda sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Poṭṭhapāda Sutta is finished.

original: 10. Subhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: subha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 10. Description of the Subha Sutta

original: Subhamāṇavakavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽444. Evaṃ me sutaṃ…pe… sāvatthiyanti subhasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ anuttānapadavaṇṇanā. Aciraparinibbute
analyzed: subha māṇavaka vatthu vaṇṇanā  evam me sutaṃpe sāvatthiyanti subha suttam tatra ayam anuttāna pada vaṇṇanā acira parinibbute
translated: The story of the youth Subha

original: bhagavatīti aciraṃ parinibbute bhagavati, parinibbānato uddhaṃ māsamatte kāle. Nidānavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: bhagavati iti aciram parinibbute bhagavati parinibbānataḥ uddham māsa matte kāle nidāna vaṇṇanāyam
translated: Thus have I heard. … At Savatthi … . This is the Subha Sutta . Herein, not long after the Blessed One attained nibbana means not long after the Blessed One had attained nibbana, in the course of a month after his final nibbana.

original: vuttanayeneva bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ ādāya āgantvā khīravirecanaṃ pivitvā vihāre🔽nisinnadivasaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Todeyyaputtoti todeyyabrāhmaṇassa putto, so kira
analyzed: vutta nayena iva bhagavataḥ patta cīvaram ādāya āgantvā khīra virecanam pivitvā vihāre  nisinna divasam sandhāya itam vuttam todeyya putto ti todeyya brāhmaṇassa putto so kira
translated: As stated in the Introduction, taking the Blessed One’s bowl and robe, he came to Savatthi, drank milk-cure, and sat down in the rest-house.

original: sāvatthiyā avidūre tudigāmo nāma atthi, tassa adhipatittā todeyyoti saṅkhyaṃ gato.🔽Mahaddhano pana hoti pañcacattālīsakoṭivibhavo, paramamaccharī – “dadato bhogānaṃ
analyzed: sāvatthiyāḥ avidūre tudigāmaḥ nāma atthi tassa adhipatittā todeyyaḥ iti saṅkhyam gataḥ  mahat dhanaḥ pana hoti dadataḥ
translated: The day on which this was said is referred to here. The son of Todeyya means the son of the brahmin Todeyya. It seems that not far from Savatthi there was a village called Tudigara. He was called Todeyya because he was the lord of that village.

original: aparikkhayo nāma natthī”ti cintetvā kassaci kiñci na deti, puttampi āha –
analyzed: aparikkhayaḥ nāma natthi iti cintetvā kassaci kiñci na deti puttam pi āha
translated: He was very rich, having a fortune of four and a half hundred millions. He was extremely avaricious. Thinking “There is no end to the use of wealth,” he gave nothing to anyone. He even said to his son:🔽“Having seen the exhaustion of ointments

original: “Añjanānaṃ khayaṃ disvā, vammikānañca sañcayaṃ;
analyzed: añjanānam khayam disvā sañcayam
translated: And the accumulation of ant-hills,

original: Madhūnañca samāhāraṃ, paṇḍito gharamāvase”ti.
analyzed: samāhāram paṇḍitaḥ gharam āvasa iti
translated: and a store of honey, the wise man will live in the house.”

original: Evaṃ adānameva sikkhāpetvā kāyassa bhedā tasmiṃyeva ghare sunakho hutvā nibbatto.
analyzed: evam adānam eva sikkhāpetvā kāyassa bhedā tasmin yeva ghare su nakhaḥ hutvā nibbattaḥ
translated: Having thus instructed him in the practice of charity, he was reborn in that very house as a dog after the dissolution of his body.

original: Subho taṃ sunakhaṃ ativiya piyāyati. Attano bhuñjanakabhattaṃyeva bhojeti, ukkhipitvā🔽varasayane sayāpeti. Atha bhagavā ekadivasaṃ nikkhante māṇave taṃ gharaṃ piṇḍāya
analyzed: subhaḥ tam su nakham ativiya piyāyati attanaḥ bhuñjanaka bhattaṃya iva bhojeti ukkhipitvā  vara sayane atha bhagavā eka divasam nikkhante māṇave tam gharam piṇḍāya
translated: Subha loved that dog exceedingly, and gave him his own food to eat, and after lifting him up🔽he let him lie down on his own bed. Then one day, after the young man had gone out, the Blessed One entered that house for alms.

original: pāvisi. Sunakho bhagavantaṃ disvā bhukkāraṃ karonto bhagavato samīpaṃ gato. Tato
analyzed: pāvisi sunakhaḥ bhagavantam disvā bhukkāram karontaḥ bhagavato samīpam gataḥ tatas

analyzed: nam bhagavā avoca todeyya tvam pubbe pi mam bho bhoti paribhavitvā su nakhaḥ jātaḥ

analyzed: bhukkāram katvā avīcim gamissasi iti sunakhaḥ tam katham sutvā vippaṭisārī

analyzed: subhaḥ āgantvā kena ayam su nakhaḥ sayanā oropitaḥ iti āha manussāḥ na kenaci iti vatvā
translated: Subha came and asked, “Who has taken my dog away from its bed?” People said, “No one has taken it away.”

analyzed: tam pavattim ārocesuṃ māṇavaḥ sutvā mama pitā brahma loke nibbattaḥ samaṇaḥ pana gotamaḥ

analyzed: musāvādena ca udetu kāmaḥ vihāram gantvā tam pavattim pucchi bhagavā tassa tathā iva vatvā

analyzed: a visaṃvādana attham āha atthi pana te māṇava pitarā na akkhātam dhananti atthi

original: suvaṇṇapāti, satasahassañca kahāpaṇanti. Gaccha taṃ sunakhaṃ appodakaṃ madhupāyāsaṃ

translated: If you should recognize him as your father.” He did so. Sunakkha told him all.

original: naṃ – “pitā me”ti ñatvā bhagavati pasannacitto gantvā bhagavantaṃcuddasa pañhe pucchitvā
analyzed: nam pitā mā iti ñatvā bhagavati pasanna cittaḥ gantvā pañhe pucchitvā
translated: Then, knowing him to be his father, he went with a mind full of confidence in the Blessed One, asked the Blessed One fourteen questions,🔽and at the end of the answers

analyzed: vissajjana pariyosāne bhagavantam saraṇam gataḥ tam sandhāya vuttam subhaḥ māṇavaḥ
translated: he went for refuge. The verse refers to him as “the student Subha,

translated: He addressed a certain student: after the Teacher had attained final Nibbana, it was reported that the Elder Ananda

analyzed: kho pana gantvā mahā jana majjhe na sakkā sukhena paṭisanthāram vā kātum dhamma katham
translated: had come with the Teacher’s bowl and robe. A great crowd of people went to see him. “But it is not possible to receive visitors or to listen to a Dhamma talk comfortably when one is in a monastery

analyzed: atthi tam pi nam pucchissāmi iti cintetvā aññataram māṇavakam āmantesi appābādhanti ādīsu  ābādhaḥ ti visabhāga vedanā vuccati yā eka dese uppajjitvā cattāro iriyāpathe  ābandhitvā viya gaṇhati tassāḥ abhāvam pucchāti vadati appa ātaṅko ti kiccha jīvita karo
translated: I will ask him about it.” He addressed a certain student:🔽In the passage beginning “Are you free from sickness?”🔽sickness is said to be an unpleasant feeling that arises in a certain part of the body and seizes the four postures as if binding them with a rope. He asks whether he is free from that.

original: rogo vuccati, tassāpi abhāvaṃ pucchāti vadati. Gilānasseva ca uṭṭhānaṃ nāma garukaṃ
analyzed: rogaḥ vuccati tassa api abhāvam pucchāti vadati gilānassa iva ca uṭṭhānam nāma garukam

analyzed: hoti kāye balam na hoti tasmai niggelañña bhāvañca balañca vadati
translated: And it is difficult for a sick person to get up. He has no strength in his body. Therefore he asks whether he is free from pain and has strength.

analyzed: gamana ṭhāna nisajja sayanesu catūsu iriyāpathesu sukha vihāram pucchāti vadati
translated: Pleasant abiding is said to be a pleasant abiding in the four postures—going, standing, sitting, and lying down. He asks whether he has that.

original: pucchitabbākāraṃ dassento “subho”tiādimāha.
analyzed: pucchitabba ākāram dassentaḥ subha iti ādim āha
translated: Then, showing the way he should be asked, he said “Are you well?”

original: 447. Kālañca samayañca upādāyāti kālañca samayañca paññāya gahetvā upadhāretvāti
analyzed: kālañca samayañca upādāya ati kālañca samayañca paññāya gahetvā upadhāretvā ati
translated: “Taking into account the time and the occasion”: having taken the time and the occasion with wisdom, having considered them.

original: attho. Sace amhākaṃ sve gamanakālo bhavissati, kāye balamattā ceva pharissati, gamanapaccayā
analyzed: attho sace amhākam sve gamana kālaḥ bhavissati kāye bala mattā ca iva pharissati gamana paccayā

analyzed: ca aññaḥ aphāsu vihāro na bhavissati atha itam kālam ca gamana kāraṇa samavāya saṅkhātam
translated: The meaning is: If the time for our going tomorrow will be, then strength will be distributed in the body, and there will be no other discomfort due to going.

original: samayañca upadhāretvā – “api eva nāma sve āgaccheyyāmā”ti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: samayañca upadhāretvā api eva nāma sve āgaccheyyāma iti vuttam hoti
translated: Having considered that time and the occasion called the concurrence of the conditions for going, it is said: “Perhaps I might come tomorrow.”

original: 448. Cetakena bhikkhunāti cetiraṭṭhe jātattā cetakoti evaṃ laddhanāmena. Sammodanīyaṃ
analyzed: cetakena bhikkhunā ati ceti raṭṭhe jāta ttā cetakā iti evam laddha nāmena sammodanīyam
translated: The monk Cetika: because he was born in the country of Ceti, he was called Cetika.

analyzed: api ca satthu parinibbānena tumhākam sokaḥ udapādi satthā nāma na kevalam tumhākam yeva  parinibbutaḥ sa devakassa lokassa kaḥ dāni aññaḥ maraṇā muccissati yatra
translated: Moreover, with the passing away of the Teacher, grief arose for you. The Teacher, indeed, did not pass away only for you,🔽but for the great loss of the world with its gods. Who else, after him, will be free from death?

analyzed: so sa devakassa lokassa agga puggalaḥ parinibbutaḥ idāni kam aññam disvā maccu rājā lajjissati iti

original: Upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaroti upaṭṭhāko hutvā santikāvacaro, na randhagavesī. Na vīmaṃsanādhippāyo.
